Definitely worth it if you hate flossing but realize you should probably floss. It comes with a small sample bottle of mouthwash but you can use whatever you like for refills (I use Listerine. Manual says you can use any mouthwash or water.)

I did a fair amount of research trying to find an accordion I could buy and learn accordion with as an absolute beginner. I settled on this one partially because it fit my criteria and partially because it was on sale (you win again this time, Amazon).I was too chicken to try ebay because as a non-accordion player who doesn't know any accordion players, I was worried that something could be wrong and I wouldn't even know. And I'm a little dubious about the ability of local music shops to have anyone on staff who knows anything about them. So I wanted to buy new and hopefully limit those risks.I wanted something I could grow into, so more than the 12 bass button starter model, but not something that was going to be as heavy or intimidating to learn on as a full 120 bass button model. (I would have settled for 30-60, so this 48-button one being on sale settled that part of the debate.)I wanted a good brand. I was concerned when I read that a lot of Hohner models, including this one, are made in China (the really expensive ones are made in Germany). Further looking eased my worries though. As I read it, Hohner shipped an entire factory to China, so you are getting a product built with German engineering and German specifications, overseen by Germans, but cheaper cost of production and cheaper superficial materials -- the keys of this model are made from plastic whereas some of the German models are made with wooden keys. Since this doesn't impact the sound at all, it's purely aesthetics (and cost). The actual mechanisms for generating sound are, as I understand it, the same quality and materials in both the Chinese made ones and the German made ones. I would be a little more dubious of the even cheaper models that don't quite say "Hohner" on them ("Hohnica"?) or have a model number printed on them but I think you're pretty safe with the ones that actually have the Hohner name and model printed on the accordion.So my internet research suggests, anyway.Note that this model is still limited. You can't change the (what's the word?) octave of the keyboard. Some more expensive models have buttons for that. This one has 2 buttons for 2 voices (violin and clarinet) and that is the end of the fancy features. Still, I felt it was a good starting point to see if I could learn to play and if I'd enjoy it and having started with practice I can say I think I'm happy I didn't try to learn on a full one. Intimidation factor aside, accordions are fairly heavy so you might appreciate not trying to learn while also having a 22 pound bellows strapped to your chest.As the other review suggests, compare your prices. The price I paid was way less than other retailers were offering, but immediately after I bought, the price went up. It's still slightly less than I saw other retailers offering but Amazon changes prices regularly so make sure you do some comparison shopping.I would also be dubious of 3rd party sellers. If it says "Ships from and sold by Amazon.com" then you're in good shape. If there's a problem, the usual Amazon return policy should be in effect -- just save your box and materials and it should be super easy to send back if you need to. If it's sold by a 3rd party, you will be subject to their rules, which are usually not as generous.That said, mine arrived in perfect condition and so far so good on trying to learn to play the accordion!

Old Spice's rebranding campaign has totally worked on me. When I saw they were making shampoo now, I jumped on it. I used to just grab the most bland, least scented thing I could find on the shelf but I have to admit, Old Spice shampoo has a nice scent to it. I had been using "Bulk Up" but now I'm trying the "Swagger". Swagger is a little lighter on the scent but both are excellent. In a world of scented mango rosebud shampoos, it can be hard for a guy to find something his style, but Old Spice has you covered.

This isn't the best phone ever -- compare the specs with the Galaxy S4, for example. This processor isn't as fast, the screen quality is clearly not as good, but functionally, I have no complaints. For the price, it's nice to have a large screen. I used it to read Kindle books and while I had to bump up the text size a little bit to get it looking good, it was nice. Note that it doesn't do LTE (Verizon) but rather, a form of advanced WCDMA -- ask your carrier if you're not sure if this phone will work for you.You WILL look silly holding this phone up to your face but it does support bluetooth so you could just do that. It has GPS and works fine with Google Navigator and so forth. I'm not sure what the lesser processor will mean long term (maybe it can't handle games as well? I dunno, I don't play smartphone games) but so far so good.

I live in a townhome and while they don't technically disallow car washing in the parking lot, I can't reach my car with a hose from my house so I usually just resort to those insert-quarter-do-it-yourself washes. I decided to bring this along as a finisher. The quarter operated washes are okay for removing the major dirt but it doesn't do a very good job, either. This, I find, fills the gap. After washing the major dirt off with the power wash, I went back home and used this stuff to go over the car again. This took it from the usual "meh" level of clean I get from the powerwash to a real shine.I can't imagine using it to wash my car from a dirty state -- if nothing else you'd need a lot of microfiber towels -- but as a finisher or a touch-up, it's great.

I never would have thought that putting a grilling element in a microwave was a thing that makes sense, but it actually does work and lets you cook some things you would have otherwise never tried in a microwave. I followed the directions for frozen hamburger patties and was surprised it actually turned out well. I did frozen hot dogs the same way. And tater tots. And a steak (I'm not saying this is the greatest way to cook a steak but I had to try it. Not bad, actually. You're basically broiling it.) I dunno what the actual cost savings is here but previously if I wanted to make tater tots I had to heat the oven, which I always thought seemed rather inefficient. I had thought about one of those countertop toaster ovens but I think this covers most of what I would have used that for. The directions suggest you grill most things in "combo" mode, which uses 30% microwave power in addition to the grill, so the burger went from frozen solid to a nice medium-well (with grilled browning) in like 5 minutes.I will say it's a bit more dangerous, if you're using the grill. Better teach the kids to treat it more like a regular oven. Don't touch the hot plate without oven mitts and since the hot plate is set close to the top of the microwave, you need to take it out to flip things over and then put it back in. The hot plate is not dishwasher safe but it's easy to clean.Otherwise it's just a normal microwave with all the usual features. Nice modern look to it.

The biggest advantage to this stuff is just that you can use it while still in the shower. The disadvantage is I feel like it's harder to get right...you apply it, then you rinse, then you dry off.... but how much should you rinse and how much are you taking off with the towel? It doesn't work as well as I had hoped but it may just be that I'm not using it entirely right.Still, I do like the convenience. If you're searching for a dry skin lotion, it's worth a go to see how it works for you. I also personally like the scent -- it's basically like using a body spray -- but be aware that it is a pretty noticeable scent. Usually I buy unscented lotions.

So I think the bluetooth part is gimmicky, but you can also just totally ignore that feature if you want. You don't have to connect to your toothbrush to use it. That said, if you've shopped other electric brushes, you've probably seen some that come with a small, separate display that you can stick on your bathroom wall, which shows you brush times and so forth. The bluetooth feature on this brush just turns your phone into that display. Which is nice. If you want a display.I used the display for a while but then just stopped. The toothbrush itself gives you all the feedback you need -- you're meant to brush your teeth in quarters (top left, top right, bottom right, bottom left), 30 seconds each, and it will buzz and flash green every 30 seconds to let you know you can switch areas, then buzzes twice after 2 minutes to let you know you've hit the suggested 2 minute mark for brushing your teeth. It also flashes red if you're pressing too hard. The bluetooth app will tell you this stuff too and may be useful to people who are new to the electric toothbrush concept.All that out of the way, the brush itself is great. This is a top tier electric brush. If you've never used one before, it can take some getting used to but it's a vast improvement over traditional brushing. Electric brushes work the gums and crevices much better than regular brushing. If you're familiar with brushes and are just shopping for a new one, I think this will be a good one. My previous brush was an Oral-B as well, purchased about 3 years ago and was still going strong. After years of use it didn't look quite as pretty or hold a charge quite as long but it was durable. Despite being dropped multiple times, it never gave me any problems at all. I'm hoping this model will prove to be as good.

It would be nice if the bandoliers could be tightened up more or were made from a softer material. I find they hang a lot looser than I would like, with the rather stiff material preventing it from hanging naturally. Still, it looks good from the front and the quality seems good for a costume piece. It also perfectly fits nerf darts.Of course, you could buy a regular REAL bandolier, usually made from a cloth-type material, that would fit and work better but if you want the "old west" leather look for a costume, I dunno if you can beat this for the price.

This is a tasty, basic snack bar. No HFCS ("dried cane syrup" seems to be just another way to say "regular old sugar"), no terribly suspicious ingredients and it's like a nice, chewy nut bar with just enough caramel to hold it together and give it a little sweetness. At only 6g of sugar (compared with 21g for a Payday candy bar), it's easy on the waistline while being filling enough to quell your hunger.I like it because the caramel taste is very light. It's more like a nutty snack and not a candy bar.

Here's what I consider the holy grail of gaming headsets:* Surround sound* Cloth headrest and earmuffs (not that thin weird material some companies like that looks great and shreds after 2 months)* Solid construction* Volume control as part of the headset* Good sound quality* Good mic quality* DOES NOT REST ON MY EARS. Maybe I have big ears but a lot of headsets rest directly on my ears and it's uncomfortable after a while.This is apparently impossible to find. If you know of any, let me know (but then, you probably wouldn't be shopping for these). I've tried a number of gaming headsets and they all fail pretty much 2 or more of the above. This headset only fails the top one: it's straight stereo. Granted things like the Logitech G35 aren't true surround sound in that they use software to simulate it (it's technical) but I think it's a good improvement over stereo. But all of the surround sound headphones I've tried, including the G35, were of inexcusably bad build quality and just fall apart in one way or another all too soon. I don't know why companies spend so much making a great sounding and feeling headset and then screw it up with thin parts that easily break/disintegrate.So, so far I'm happy with this purchase. The cloth liner should last longer than that Logitech G35 junk. The build is a mix of plastic and metal but the stress points seem solid. Mic quality is good and the mic pickup is very good -- had to turn it down whereas most headsets make me maximize the mic volume. The ear piece is large, encompasses my ears and doesn't press on them -- no discomfort after a couple hours having them on nonstop. Sound quality is perfect to my ear.Just note that it's not surround sound and you need functioning mic/audio jacks on your computer (as this is not a USB headset).I'll update this review if I have any build quality issues but it LOOKS solid enough, in a "but don't sit on them" sort of way.

I bought this because I've had so much success with one of the bigger CyberPower towers, which I use for my gaming rig. But what good is maintaining power to my gaming rig when my cable modem and router go out? So I got this smaller one to handle those items after a different brand of UPS gave up the ghost. With this thing working downstairs and the tower working upstairs, my power went out for about 5 seconds the other day and everything worked great. No loss of internet, no loss of power to the PC.I've gone through a number of battery backup systems over the years and while I understand rechargable batteries wear out over time and must be replaced, my experience with other systems has been that they wear out quicker and sometimes the electronics go, too, rendering the whole thing into junk. CyberPower is the first brand I've tried that I've actually been happy with long term. I've had the tower (CP1500) for just over 5 years and it's still going strong with no battery replacements and still has a good charge. Hopefully this smaller one will last just as long for my cable modem and router.

So, just up front, these things say you can use them with or without the handles (sold separately). Get the handles. They sell them separately because you may want multiple bands (for more resistance or to hook to their other options, like a door frame hook) but you really need the handles to get started on the basic stuff. The handles add a lot of length, so you can actually do the exercises listed on the package, and the straps are pretty uncomfortable to use alone. You only need 1 set of handles for multiple bands.All that said, this is a good basic workout option if you want something simple for home/travel that's inexpensive and doesn't take up much space. It's no home gym but it's more interesting than a bunch of pushups and situps and gives you more ways to work out, using something that can easily fit in a drawer or luggage (try doing THAT with a home gym).

For veteran Lego builders, I think you'll find the main thing wrong here is that while Lego kits are all about the build, this kit is almost like a puzzle -- you have to find the right pieces! We timed one search and it took us 7 minutes to find the right piece. This happens many times so it adds up. We sped it up a bit by having one of us search while the other builds. Basically it's just not well organized and it's frequently hard to tell the difference between the dark green and the grey blocks that the instructions call for. Reading the line marks between blocks with dark colors is difficult too.That said, once you've completed it it's pretty amazing. It's big, it's fun and it has lots of clever moving parts. There's nice details like the seats, the computer screen and other pipe and tank details. Plus you get lots of cool characters with backpacks and weapons, all interchangeable. It really came together nice in the end.My suggestion is that if you're experienced with Lego kits, you'll find this Mega Bloks kit a lot more time consuming to get through but the end product is pretty fantastic. It's still good for kids, so long as they don't run out of patience with the block search.I hesitate to rate it 5 stars because the build process was so much more tedious than Lego kits but we thought the quality was good and the end product was great. Maybe you LIKE searching for parts? It is a bit like a 1300 piece guided puzzle, I guess! And in the end you've got a great toy.

Imagine a chocolate Oreo cookie dipped in thick, quality milk chocolate. Bam. Here you go. They are as delicious as you might hope.I'll leave the price concerns up to your decision. The cookies are pretty hefty, though. 140 calories each, 2 per package. The chocolate is probably the best milk chocolate I've had. Very thick, creamy and melty.The real question is how shipping these things is going to work. Either they're going to start using refrigerated trucks or it better be cold out. These things have a low melting point and will easily melt in your hand (AND in your mouth...AND probably in the UPS truck). I didn't have any problem but it was in the 60s when they delivered. Anyway, packaging and pricing aside, they are fantastic.

I mostly compared this to the X-mini KAI2 Bluetooth Portable Capsule Speaker XAM18-GM, Gun Metal.* Both are small enough to fit into your pocket (this one -- the iSound -- fits easier, though, since it's flatter).* The iSound is a good bit cheaper* The iSound is noticeably louder* The KAI2 sounds a little 'clearer' to my ear. Less of what I would generally call "small speaker distortion". I think all small, portable speakers like this have a bit of distortion to their sound and while the iSound and KAI2 are really close, the KAI2 does sound a little better.* The KAI2 has an audio-out function that lets you hook it up to other speakers* The KAI2 has a microphone so you can use it as a speakerphone* Both feature device controls for pause/play and next/previous functions.So, as I see it, the KAI2 is generally better and more feature rich but the iSound has more volume and is cheaper and less conspicuous in your pocket (the KAI2 is like having a golf ball in your pocket).I'll leave it up to you to prioritize those items and decide which speaker is right for you. Both are pretty impressive sounding speakers for their size (that you can put in a jeans pocket) and it's mainly a question of price and which features you care about the most.

In theory I like smoothies but in practice I don't like cleaning my blender. This system replaces your blender and your food processor and makes the concept of smoothies way easier.The big thing is that you are blending it right in your drinking container. This comes with 3 of these cups (with travel lids) and here's how it goes:Put the ingredients in your cupScrew the blending lid onto the cup (this lid is water tight and has the blades on it)Put the cup upside down on the blenderPush down to blendUnscrew the blending lid and replace it with a travel lid if you want and away you go!Put the cup and lid in the dishwasher when you're done.Way easier than washing the blender, not to mention guessing how much to stuff to put in there. Saves you a little countertop space too.And of course the "2-in-1" portion is that you also get a food processor sized container to bend things in. It uses the same motor to drive it.If you're looking for a blender to make some morning smoothies for the road, this is ideal. Or if you're just lazy like me and hate washing more than is absolutely necessary and generally dealing with your big stupid blender, this is ideal.

You'd think "a speaker is a speaker" (well, I'd think that) but I guess there's a lot to be said for the acoustics of the speaker body. Or something. Actually I have no explanation for why this sounds as good as it does. It might be witchcraft. I've tried other small speakers and been pretty happy but this one is a couple steps above the rest. Let me count the ways:* Great sound. As is typical for small speakers don't expect a lot of bass but the mids and highs are astounding. The bass is good compared to similar size devices but if you want booms you're just going to have to go big.* Super clever design:** It compresses to fit into your pocket. It's like an accordion.** There's a stereo jack wound into the bottom of the speaker.** There's a rubber lid that protects the top of the device that turns into a rubber base when you're using it.** There are media controls (previous, pause/play, next) on the device for use through bluetooth.I honestly wonder if the people rating it poorly realized you need to take the rubber top off. I mean the instructions show this but maybe they didn't read the instructions? I'm just guessing.The "buddy speaker" concept is worth a mention too. Basically this thing has an audio OUT jack, which is an unusual feature. It lets you hook this up to another speaker -- any speaker. I hooked it up to my larger bluetooth speaker and basically had a tweeter and a woofer combo. If I had two of these KAI2 speakers I could hook them together to get double the sound but, again, it's standard audio-out so it will go to any device. (One obvious use might be that you have a really nice non-bluetooth home stereo system. Welp, connect to your Kai2 with bluetooth then use this "buddy speaker" to connect the Kai2 to your real speaker system and off you go. Wander around your house using your home stereo as if it was bluetooth via this Kai2 device.)All in all, I'm thoroughly impressed.

These are nice gaming stereo headphones that really boost the booms and explosions. They sound great when playing the usual FPS/RTS games I play. The built-in equalizer is subtle but the on-ear volume control is nice. The mic is sensitive and works better than my previous gaming headset for consistent voice comms.My one real complaint is that the equalizer doesn't have a good "music" setting. The highs and mids, even on the setting that's meant to emphasize them more, are dull and muted. It sounds "okay". I can still watch Netflix shows with them, but it's clearly not as good at full range audio as my previous headsets have been.Still, for gaming they're great and the construction is nice too. I like the cloth lining to the earmuffs and that the earstrap has metal running through it, so hopefully it will prove to be sturdy. If you JUST want a headset for gaming, this will do it for you. If you want something more full range for a variety of uses (movies and music), you might keep looking.

I just wanted to chime in and say "This series starts slow". But man. The last few of season 1 and what I've seen so far of season 2 make it so worthwhile. I really toughed it out in the first episodes because I like the main character, I like the actors and I love the concept but it felt like the show lacked direction. But the events of Captain America: Winter Soldier shook things up and shook them up very much for the better. It focused the whole show.So don't get discouraged early on if it seems slow. Season 2 is awe-some.

I've been using Carhartt long sleeve shirts for years. They always fit me well, with a little bunchiness in the sleeves, which I like, and the stitching and colorfastness has always been rock solid.No exception on this hoodie. Same good quality, thick material, solid stitching and no-nonsense washing instructions (cold/low).The one thing I will warn you about is that the front pocket has a smaller inside pocket that seems perfect for a smartphone. I advise against this. There's no zipper, it's at an angle and there's no tension so you're liable to have your phone slip right out (I heard a clunk taking a corner in the car....yep, my phone slipped out). Still, it would work as a change pocket or to store earbuds or something a bit less slippery than a phone.Anyway, solid product. If you're familiar with Carhartt stuff, this is their norm.

This is basically a polycom for your laptop. While we frequently conference with GoToMeeting at the office, the laptop's built in speakers and mic leave a lot to be desired. There are plenty of options out there but what you'd really like is something compact that sits on your desk and has everything in one device....like a polycom.Well, here you go.The ability to switch from "all mics" to a single directional mic is nice too. It really does cut down on noise from other directions if you just pick a single mic and face it towards the speakers. In a quiet room though, you can leave it set to omnidirectional. The mics are sensitive and the speaker is surprisingly good.There's nothing you need to control from your computer (other than telling the computer which mic and speaker to use). On Windows it shows right up in your playback/recording device list and the controls you need are on the unit itself. No need for a power plug -- the USB is all it requires.Note that this is NOT a bluetooth device. It operates through USB or an optional audio jack.

Just so we're clear, this smells like original Juicy Fruit gum. I am not claiming that this is a good or a bad thing. I'm just saying that if you know what Juicy Fruit gum smells like, then you know what this smells like and you can base your decision on this. Does your ladyfriend think you should smell "delicious"? Maybe she does. Maybe you should find out.

This is not an easy glue to use. Be sure to read the directions, especially the part about needing moisture to get it rolling. If some other type of glue can do the job, you might want to try that first. It's also best if you have a way to clamp the pieces together for a couple of hours.That said, when nothing else works, this probably will. I use it for minor household repairs where other efforts have failed.

See what I did there? A good twist?! Cause it's got.... you know... it twists....nevermind.So yes, these are twist-top ziploc containers. The lids go on like a mason jar. The only thing to really be aware of here is that they are still thin plastic so you can still easily crush them (and squeeze out your contents in the process) but they're a step above the usual "burp" lids. They aren't going to pop off or have the old "I thought the lid was on tight but it wasn't" problem.One of those ideas that seems so obvious, you're not sure why they weren't doing it all along.

I will start off with the one possible use case, which is why I didn't give this thing 1 star:* You want minimalist design. No bulky case, just a monitor that has everything in it.* You don't mind that it has to always be plugged in (this is a desktop, not a laptop or tablet).* You want Dell warranty and Dell support.* You want something very, very basic for like Facebook, maybe Facebook games, simple web pages -- news, weather -- maybe an MP3 player and that's it.If that's you then okay, maybe this IS what you're looking for. Simple, basic, compact, not too fast and not too expensive.But this product makes me grumpy. Read on and I'll tell you why.It's compact, and has a lot of the problems that compact machines come with, namely lack of power. But usually compact machines lack power because they are meant to be portable and run off of a battery -- power is your tradeoff. This machine, however, is a desktop. It needs to be plugged in, which limits its portability anyway, which would be fine IF IT HAD POWER, but it doesn't. It's neither portable nor powerful!The Celeron processor is meant for notebooks. The 2.16 Ghz clock speed with 2 cores and 2 threads is anemic even by laptop standards. The 5400 RPM drive is painfully slow and is a real bottleneck (it particularly dragged out the update process, which took ages).What really grinds my gears, though, is that the machine is barely powerful enough to handle Netflix. Running it on Chrome causes the video to desync after a while and the audio will start to turn to static. I've updated the drivers from the Dell site (except for the BIOS, whose update consistently fails -- haven't figured out that one yet) and Netflix won't work under Chrome. It's like it can't keep up. It does work under Internet Explorer -- presumably IE is doing something just efficiently enough to get it over the hump -- but the bottom line is that I should at least be able to open up my favorite web browser and use all aspects of the web -- including compressed, streaming HD video -- straight out of the box on a machine that has no batteries and must be plugged into the wall to operate for this kind of price tag.I feel like this machine is a bad idea coming out of marketing, or people who didn't understand that these days, even the web needs a fair amount of processing power to handle compressed video streams. The overall sluggishness when doing literally anything in Windows just adds to the pain. Frankly, if you're looking for a desktop machine which must be plugged in, like this one, you could spend $500 on NewEgg, build your own machine using one of their "Super Combos" and end up with something that will blow this thing out of the water.I really liked what I assumed was the concept -- the minimalist desktop computer with everything built into a touchscreen monitor -- but they should have put in a better processor (if there's enough wiggle room in that price tag to add in a small SSD for the operating system, that would go a long way to alleviating the pain too).Oh, also, it does not have any USB 3.0 ports and there is no video out (possibly owing to the overall lack of power in this machine) or built in DVD drive. Not problems in themselves (though the lack of any video out was disappointing) but it makes me grumpy on top of the other issues.There's just not enough power in this box to make this machine feel painless.

These are great except for the care needed to wash them. After reading the other reviews here, I made sure to follow the directions, namely laying them flat to dry rather than tumble drying. This still causes some wrinkling and they have to be ironed out (particularly the edges). I didn't notice any shrinking or fading but still, this is a hassle.The ribbing design looks and feels great but I think that's the main culprit behind why they're so hard to wash -- that and they're 100% cotton. Which normally I am in favor of but while thin cotton (such as a t-shirt) tumbles well and hangs well without needing an iron, my experience has been that thick cotton will need an iron and this is no exception.So I do like these better than the usual vinyl or bamboo placemats, be prepared to put time into keeping them maintained.

This is a very nice coffee press. There's another 34oz Fancois et Mimi stainless steel press and the only real difference is that this one is shiny while the other one is "brushed", giving it more of a flat metal look. Both are quite attractive and do the job well.The parts are basically the standard french press gear: inside is a metal mesh on a rod that you press down after the brewing process. The mesh can be unscrewed and thrown into the dishwasher. The only really tricky thing is that the knob on top also unscrews, so you need to unscrew the mesh by twisting the rod, not the knob.The double wall is nice for keeping your coffee hotter while it brews (versus the standard single-wall glass presses) and it's nice to have a metal press so I don't worry about breaking it.These french presses are perfect for the office where you want your own custom coffee brew without having to use the community coffee maker.(I also use mine to brew loose leaf tea. Same principle as brewing coffee and I think it's a little less hassle than the "tea balls" other people use.)

I have this and the Clarisonic Aria. Which is better? Kind of a tossup.The Clarisonic does a very quick back-and-forth vibration (like your electric toothbruth probably is). It feels more vigorous and is easier to control but I find it hard to use on my nose because the vibration is pretty intense. The brush head is larger so it's a bit easier to make sure you're getting your whole face.The Phillips does a far gentler vibration. Most of the motion is a straight circular motion of the brush head. Is this better? Couldn't tell you at this point. It certainly feels nicer (especially on the nose!) but the question is whether it's doing the job. I believe it is but it's going to be hard to measure.My feeling is that you should try the Clarisonic first and if you just find it's too intense for you, try this Phillips, which has a much easier, gentler feel....but maybe vigor is what you prefer!

So far so good on this thing. After reading other reviews I'm a little worried about rust... I have a porcelain fire pit that's been outside in all weather for years and still looks great so this one being cast iron makes me nervous. You CAN get high temperature protective coatings for cast iron but so far mine has not shown a spec of rust, so we'll see if that's something I need to try later or not. [update: after being in the rain under the provided cover for many days, there's still no rust. I'm pretty sure it's already got a protective paint on it.]Calling this portable is a bit of a marketing gimmick in my opinion... it's still nearly 40 pounds and has no handles so the fact that you aren't prevented from moving it counts as "portable", I guess. It IS more portable than my porcelain firepit so I guess you win THIS time, CobraCo, but yeah, it's not exactly something you'd take camping unless you intend to camp within short distance of your truck.Anyway, assembly was easy, the thing looks and feels sturdy and so far its been a success. I'll update this review if rust becomes a problem.

This is a great bathroom rug. I was mainly worried that being such a thick pile, it would dry slow and either give me wet feet later or worse, mold up. No such problems, though. It dries really fast despite stepping straight onto it out of the shower and leaving it fairly wet. I guess that's modern fiber technology for you. It's machine washable which is nice too. And the rubber backing is nice, to keep it from sliding.Looks nice, feels great, dries quick. Can't go wrong here.

I'm a big fan of the Vicks UV 99.999% Germ Free Humidifier but it has one problem: it's a real pain to clean. Boiling water for steam leaves mineral deposits behind (unless you use distilled water, which will cost you) and getting the deposits out of the Vicks is no small task.This boiler seeks to fix that problem by making the whole boiling chamber -- the lower part of the unit -- *dishwasher safe*. You can detach it and throw it right into your dishwasher and the biggest problem is solved.I hesitate to give this humidifier 5 stars (as I gave for the Vicks) mainly for 2 reasons:* No germ-killing UV light. So you'd better take your cleaning more seriously. (I mean, it does boil the water though...)* The humidistat is not very useful.I'll explain that last point more. A humidistat is just like a thermostat but for humidity instead of temperature. Set it to 40% humidity and the unit should run until that level is reached. On the Vicks, you can tell where your current humidify level is (and therefore judge where to set the dial) because it goes "click" when you pass the current humidity level. The humidistat on this unit makes no noise so you have no idea how to set it.That said, the steam output on this unit is higher than the Vicks. It's a bit noisier -- mainly, I think, because it's boiling more vigorously. You can set it to "low" which will cut the boiling a little and make it a little quieter but then you're getting less steam, too.All in all I think I might go with this unit over the Vicks if only for the fact that it's easier to clean. I wish it had a UV light, I wish the water chamber was not so tinted (hard to see the water level), I wish the humidistat provided some feedback.....but man....so much easier to clean.It's a tossup, really. This one or the Vicks!I personally do not advocate the cold ("spritz") humidifiers. They are quieter but I think they are not as good for you. Look at what's left in the boiling chamber of a hot humidifier and realize that a cold humidifier is spraying that stuff all through the air.

This is a nice, simple caddy that should fit most showers. The picture shows it going to a wall to the right of the spigot but it will work to the right or left (mine is left).The shelves can be arranged any way you like. If you just want one shelf, you can leave off the other two as well as space them how you like.The suction cups at the bottom are probably unnecessary but they do keep the caddy stable.The whole thing is very easy to clean. The shelves can be lifted out and the bottom of each shelf can also come out by itself to be cleaned. Note that the top of the shelf aligns with the top of the shower spigot so if that's too tall for you to reach, the upper shelves probably will be too. I'm seeing a lot of mixed reviews but I didn't seem to have any of those problems. For me it hangs level, took like 30 seconds to install and sits solidly against the wall. No problems at all after using it for about 3 weeks.

I'm really digging this stainless steel french press over the glass ones I've been using. I don't fear breaking it, plus it just looks nicer. The double wall sides will help keep your coffee from losing as much heat during the brewing, too.The design is pretty standard. The "press" part comes apart if you unscrew the rod from it, just like other presses, for easy cleaning. The only thing I don't like, really, is that the knob on the top also unscrews, which makes it a bit tricky to unscrew the rod from the press for cleaning. Not a big deal, just be aware that the press DOES disassemble for cleaning, but you may have to grip the rod to twist it apart without the top knob coming off.There's another 34 oz Francois et Mimi coffee press and the main difference between them is if you want brushed (this) or polished (the other one). I think I prefer the brushed look -- it doesn't show water spots so I feel it's easier (lazier) to keep looking clean.

I was surprised to see all 5-star ratings. Did I get a bad one? The big problem I ran into was that the screw-hole that's going to let the ball mount screw onto the tripod was not big enough -- the screw doesn't fit!I also felt that this is what you get when you can't use someone else's patented solutions but still want to sell a similar product. I thought the legs of his tripod were a bit too stiff and hard to manipulate versus those of the very similar Joby GorillaPod (although that should allow this one to hold a heavier camera). The Joby GorillaPod also has a simple switch to lock and unlock the tripod's screw mount while this mount uses a big plastic screw that takes a few twists to lock and unlock the mount point.The phone holder itself seems fine and is similar to the "Joby GripTight Smartphone Mount" and there's no question that this is cheaper and works well enough but it's not as nice or easy to use as the Joby stuff.I probably would rate it as 3 or 4 stars except for that problem with the screw hole. Judging from other reviews it sounds like I'm the only one who encountered that issue so maybe it was just bad luck. Even ignoring that, though, I'd say pay a little extra and stick with Joby.

I really wasn't expecting anything from an electric brush this cheap, but other than being noisy and using regular batteries, it seems just as good as my Braun rechargeable that cost literally 10x more.The battery life is good too. I thought that would be an easy win for the rechargeables -- that this one made me go through batteries a lot -- but I've used it for 2-3 minutes 2-3 times a day for 3 weeks and I'm still on the battery that it came with.Mechanically it seems about the same as the Braun. Replaceable head, back-and-forth rotation. My Braun has a couple of nice touches (like a battery power display and an indication of how long you've been brushing and if you're pressing too hard) but for the basic act of brushing your teeth, it's hard to say which is better.I still think if you're looking for a main toothbrush you might come out better in the long run with a rechargeable but if you just want something effective to throw in your suitcase, this is definitely a good choice.

The one big downside to these headphones: they are stereo only. A lot of gaming speakers offer "software simulated surround sound" -- basically they register as 5.1 or 7.1 speakers and sounds meant to come "from behind" get tweaked a little bit to sound like they should if they were coming through your ear instead of beside your ear. While not as good as real 7.1, I do think it's a good addition for gaming headsets to have......and this doesn't have that.So it's just stereo.Still, it's hard to find fault with that when it does everything else so well. The stereo sound is flawless, the mic works great and best of all, the construction is solid.And that is a big plus.I've gone through a number of "gaming headsets" including high end Logitech and Creative Labs headsets that cost more than this and I dunno why they all do this but for whatever reason they love to use really awful quality materials. My last Creative headsets had the thin plastic break one day just putting them on my head. The Logitech earpads easily shred and they also use very flimsy plastic at important connection points. I guess they want them to break so that you will buy new ones occasionally? I dunno, but I'm tired of it and THESE headphones don't have that problem. They are solidly built with metal components that seem like they will last and have been durable so far. They're also just as comfortable as my Logitechs and the padding goes over my ears for a bit of sound isolation from the room.Note that these headsets are not USB so you'll need an actual sound source to plug them into -- I just use my motherboard's built in connections and it works fine there.

This is one of the bigger entries in the Ion line. I have 3 different ones (from the pocket sized to this) and they're all fantastic bluetooth speakers. The sound on this is great with great bass and a good battery life. You can also just leave it plugged in to play if you want.The light on the top is SUPER BRIGHT. You can turn it off if you like. Frankly I prefer to put the thing above eye level because it really is too bright to want to look into it but the good news is you don't need a dark room to get the full effect of the light show -- it really is that bright. The one thing that makes me frown, in fact, is that it doesn't come with a mounting bracket, like for a standard 1 3/8th inch speaker stand. I think it's big enough to warrant it. I bought a bracket separately and hope it will screw into the case okay (Magic 8-Ball says "ask again later").The handle (luggage-style that lets you wheel it around) feels flimsy but hasn't caused me any problems so far. It has two good grip points on the side but it IS pretty heavy so the handle and wheels get some use.If you want a good, portable bluetooth speaker with the ability to play away from a power source, this is a good way to go. Pairing is simple and the range seems standard for bluetooth.

I love this thing! It's just like Ion's other speakers only small enough that you could put it in your pocket (in a very "oh you ARE happy to see me" sort of way).The sound is not bad. I mean it's a tiny speaker so don't expect it to knock your socks off but the bass and range is surprisingly good and will be a huge improvement over any phone or tablet speaker you may have. The light show is a bit silly but it's bright and does actually pulse to the beat if you turn it up enough that it can catch on (at low volumes it can't seem to find the beat and just sort of does random switches). You can turn the light off if you prefer.It recharges via USB and connects to your device via bluetooth. No problem with pairing and the bluetooth range is about "the usual" -- like 50 feet or so and it works fine.Personally I think this sounds better than a lot of slightly larger bluetooth speakers I've heard. It's great for a purse or luggage. It'll fit in your jeans pocket but you will look terribly silly.

If you want to try gaming on a Fire, you might as well pick up one of these. And so far I'm kinda surprised -- I wasn't expecting much from Fire TV games since they are, as far as I can tell, Android games, but with the controller they're not much different than X-Box games, at least in terms of how you play. The controller itself is basically identical to an X-Box controller. Not sure how they get away with that, really, but it's what you'd expect -- the two sticks let you do things like first person shooters where one stick aims/turns and the other moves you. Two triggers, two above-trigger buttons, 4 buttons (even labeled the same as the X-Box controller), etc.You can also use it to navigate the regular Fire TV menus and it is a little less clumsy than the default remote. It didn't indicate this anywhere but "A" selects and "B" goes back on the Fire TV menu, just like in every game (there are also 4 buttons for menu navigation in the middle of the controller but for the most part you can just use the stick and A+B).Pairing was no problem. Follow the directions on the little sheet it comes with (Fire TV instructions were on the back, Fire tablet on the front).Don't get me wrong -- this is no X-Box One. It's not even an X-Box 360. The Fire TV and and Fire Tablet is not, that I can see, much more powerful than your typical phone, but still, it's HD graphics, albeit with lower resolution textures and the gameplay is pretty good considering the games are like $5. I would think this would be an easy choice for people with young kids who would enjoy a little cheap gameplay and probably wouldn't get their money's worth out of $60 full console games anyway.

I have a hard time imagining why you would want this when there are so many rechargeable packs out there. I guess the points that could be in favor of this device are:* It uses a fairly standard CR123A battery. You can buy replacement batteries for about $2 each (in packs of 10).* These batteries are used in a lot of cameras so maybe if you're already using them, this device makes sense.* These types of batteries hold their charge for a long time so you can put them on a shelf and forget about them for years.* It's cheap.* You could have a pack of batteries in your trunk for a lot of "2 hour power" charges.But just so we're clear, this is NOT a rechargeable device. It just lets you use a particular type of external battery to charge your phone. And they call it "2 hour power" (based on a Samsung Galaxy S2) because one of these batteries is not enough to fully charge a smartphone.I would suggest searching for "external battery" in the Cell Phones & Accessories category though, and look at some of these 5000+ mAh / 2.5+ Amp type chargers that will refill your whole phone, are strong enough to charge tablets and are reusable while still being pretty small and lightweight.

Corel VideoStudio Ultimate X7 vs Pinnacle Studio 17 Plus vs Adobe Premier Elements: tough call.Well. Out of the three, I would put Adobe Premier Elements as the hands down loser, being the least easy to use, the most clunky and the hardest to find help for online. I think Adobe is more focused on their Pro version, which is to say, the really expensive one you probably don't need.Corel vs Pinnacle is harder to call. I might put Pinnacle on top personally because I find the more advanced features are quicker to get to and the built-in audio editing function of Pinnacle is beast but if you're a beginner looking for something better than the free tools out there while still wanting something that's easy to understand and get started with, Corel might be a better choice.For example, when you want to adjust the brightness and contrast in Corel, you CAN bring up a nice advanced window that lets you tweak the numbers and see a side-by-side preview (which is a nice touch) but there's also a kind of "easy mode" that presents you with 8 images of varying brightness/contrast -- presets, basically. Pick the image you like and presto, your video is updated. It does make for very quick, simple to understand editing.All the features you'd expect are there: splitting and merging clips is easy. There are plenty of transitions, text/graphics options and so forth to choose from. Exporting your final project to the format of your choosing is dead simple. The tools are pretty standard and won't take you too long to find and get the hang of.I think if I dock Corel for anything versus Pinnacle, it's that their effort to make things simple can get in the way of some of the more advanced features. Odds are pretty good that this doesn't matter to you and indeed, you may prefer the straightforward simplicity of how Corel presents things. I think personally I'm going back to Pinnacle because I'm a stickler for details and Pinnacle does a good job of serving up details without getting TOO bogged down in complication.Mostly I think it's a flavor choice. In the end, Corel and Pinnacle do pretty much all of the same things. I think Corel aims more for the casual user, someone who wants a simple and easy edit while Pinnacle aims more for the stickler who wants to spend time fidgeting with more details. I find both products to be pretty good and should handle any basic video editing project. Basically if there's something you want to do that Corel VideoStudio can't handle, I doubt you'll find anything under $100 that will.

As others have noted, this is not really "Generation Anything" night vision, but then, it's also not $3000.It's a pretty sensitive digital camera with a wide aperture, a built-in monitor and a high powered infrared light. If your goal is to see in the dark on the cheap, this is the level of technology you're probably looking for. The infrared beam is invisible to the human eye (though you can see the lens glow red if you look right at it) but the camera can pick it up as a grey scale image. The power of the infrared light is pretty impressive plus the camera itself does a good job of picking up some details in very dim lighting so between the camera and the IR light, you can see perfectly well into underbrush that's pitch black to the naked eye and 50+ meters away.You can also record video and take snapshots if you insert an SD card (not included).Note that it has a mounting rail too, so you can fit something like a rail mounted laser on there if you wanted, which would make it a bit easier to quickly zero in on what you wanted to look at (as the field of view of the device itself it very narrow).It's rubberized to be weather resistant and is a cinch to use once you learn the buttons! It also has a standard tripod mounting bracket so you can get a stable image from zoom.The infrared light can operate in high, low and off and the light sensitivity of the camera itself can be adjusted for a wide range of lighting conditions. Overall I think you'll be impressed with the features and ease of use at this price point.

So it sounds like there's a new version of the hardware out there that maybe works better, but all I can say is that the one I have does not work all that well.Namely:* It seems to get stuck on "Connecting" a lot, even for a device it was connected with just a moment prior. The fix seems to be to pick up the device and hold down the button to get it to reconnect but that rather defeats the purpose.* "Locate device" doesn't presently seem to do anything except show me where my phone is. As in the phone that I am looking at in my hand, even though I intentionally left the device at home.The basic functionality is there -- I can pair the TrackR to my phone and use my phone to sound an alarm on the device from at least 50 feet away. It can also be set to ping me if I get too far away (which I suspect is "whatever range causes Bluetooth to disconnect"), which is cool -- if you walk off without your wallet or something, it will remind you -- so I see the use case for the device but the bugs and reliability need fixing.

Edit: Warning! The top of the case is pretty thick and the hole for connecting to the audio jack is too small to accommodate most cables. The headphones that came with my Samsung fit but the generic male-to-male cable I bought for connecting to my car does not fit with this case on. You'll need cables with slender connections (meaning the plastic/rubber around the connector) to fit this case.This is a pretty straightforward case. The main thing I like about it is how thin it is while still feeling like it gives the phone some protection, especially from corner drops. The box claims to protect it from 2m corner drops. I'll hopefully just be able to take their word for it. I like my Otterbox case but it adds so much thickness all around the case that I felt I was giving up too much to gain the drop protection.I also like the sleek black/white look of the design. Gives the phone a little flavor.No trouble with the fit. Goes perfectly over the S4 and gives you access to all of the phone's functions.

This is a perfect office desk lamp. I frown on it as a bedside lamp because the power button is always lit up and I think it's too bright for the bedside, but in any other room it's perfect: you can always find your light switch! The controls are simple touch-sensitive pads.The different light levels are the nice touch and the LEDs give off a pure white light. The lamp doesn't rotate away from the base but you can angle the vertical bar and the horizontal lamp portion.

...or a new error, if you're a grag.I agree with other reviewers that this feels a bit like a farewell tour. Technically it's a Moist von Lipwig book ("Going Postal", "Making Money") but it has plenty of familiar faces and feels like more of a playful romp than a lot of Pratchett's older material. That is, the villains are a bit less fleshed out than usual, they are a bit more easily defeated than usual and I felt the book lacked the same grip of Pratchett's older works. It's like an easy ride with old friends.And there's a lot of classic Pratchett to love in this novel. The wit and humor is all there and Moist von Lipwig continues to develop as a character. Without delivering a lot of spoilers, I'll at least say it's been my favorite of the most recent Pratchett books. You should definitely pick it up if you're a Discworld fan.The eternal question for all Discworld books: can you read this without being a Discworld fan. Maybe? I would advise at least reading the other Moist von Lipwig books I listed above although you'd still be missing some relevant backstory (e.g., the Battle of Koom Valley). For non-Discworld fans I typically suggest starting with "Guards! Guards!" or "Equal Rites" and then look online for the "Discworld Reading Order Guide" and go from there. Moist is a fairly close spinoff of the Guard series, I'd say, since it's more centered around Ankh-Morpork.

I love this technology! I have a phone holder that works like this too:So basically it sticks to things with some sort of suction technology but it's not a suction cup. It just looks like a flat surface that feels a bit tacky but put it on a flat surface (I'm using it on bathroom tile) and it easily clings to it.There is no adhesive so they are completely reusable and they leave no residue behind. Just give them a wash and they're ready to be used again. I'm using it as a shower hook for washcloths (because hanging them on the curtain rod is much less suave) and it works great for that.Note that these things work best on a completely flat surface like glass or tile. If your surface is textured at all, they may stick less or not at all.

I am tempted to deduct a star because I feel like their clamp could have been designed better to fit more things...as it is, it's a "V" shaped clamp that will only open up an inch and a half, but that should be enough to clamp to most things, especially typical lawn chairs made out of 1" metal tubes.What I really like about it, though, is how adjustable it is. It shouldn't matter what direction you clamp it to something -- horizontal bar, vertical bar or anything in between -- or where the sun is -- because the umbrella can be tilted and twisted any-which-way. It seems sturdy enough and works just fine on the back of my collapsible lawn chair.Just make sure that the thing you want to clamp to is less than 1.5" wide and it'll probably work for you too.

Here it is, the next big entry in the MMORPG genre -- also the next big Elder Scrolls game.This almost needs 2 reviews. One for Elder Scrolls and one for an MMORPG...As an Elder Scrolls game, you have to ask yourself one thing: "Do I want to play an Elder Scrolls game with a bunch of other people?" If the answer is "yes, at all costs!", skip the rest of this review and click "buy". If the answer is "Yes!....wait, what costs?", then read on.The first cost, of course, is the actual monthly subscription fee. What this gets you is a multiplayer world and (we all hope) regular content updates included as part of the subscription. The other cost is a bit more subtle...how do you have an Elder Scrolls style world where everyone can go everywhere while still customizing all content to YOU? The answer is "you can't", or at any rate, they didn't make any new big innovations here. ESO is more linear than other Elder Scroll games, far more like other MMORPGs. When you are level 15 you need to be in an area that's appropriate for level 15. The game isn't totally linear -- it's not Half-Life 2, for example -- but it's no Daggerfall or Skyrim either. You need to move through the world as is appropriate for your level. Consequently this has the same problem as all PvE MMORPGs, which is that if you want to play with your friends, you need to work to stay in synch. If someone runs ahead and plays 8 hours of quests without you, you can't just log in the next day and join them where they are (not unless you want to die a lot because you're in an area too high level for you).So that's what being multiplayer does to Elder Scrolls. If that's acceptable to you, buy away. If you were looking for a single player experience, though, you may be disappointed.For people already familiar with MMORPGs (and may not be familiar with Elder Scrolls) probably the biggest surprise is going to be the combat system, which is, in my opinion, far more immersive and engaging than a lot of games. You are expected to actively swing your sword and actively block and actively dodge. This isn't WOW where you target something and eat nachos while mashing "Shadowbolt" over and over. You need to get involved. And it works surprisingly well. The lag seems to be invisible and the game's performance is actually amazing.I really mean that. I dunno who they hired to do their network code and graphics engine but they're not paying them enough. The game handles hundreds of players on screen in crisp, high resolution graphics and it is frankly better and more amazing than any other MMORPG I have ever played, and I've played most of them. From high end machines to low end, all of my friends and guildmates are amazed at how well this game runs and how good it looks.Character design is more akin to Elder Scrolls than regular MMORPG tropes too. Don't look for a "tank" or a "healer". Decide what role you want to play, decide which class looks like the most fun and then figure out how to build that class into that role. All classes can be any role, in their own way. I'm playing a Nightblade, which on the surface looks like a rogue, but I'm playing him as a tank. One of my friends is playing a Nightblade healer. It basically means we both have some decent abilities for burst damage and escape but I am very tanky and he is very healy and our character builds don't look much alike, despite being the same class. You could be a sorcerer tank or a dragonknight archer, etc. The class/role system is pretty wide open.PvP? Elder Scrolls offers probably the best PvP we've seen since DAOC. It follows the DAOC model, which is somewhat like the GW2 model but with some important differences:Most of the world is PvE but the 3 teams come together in the middle of the map. The middle zone is, we estimate, on the order of 15 times larger than GW2's "Eternal Battleground" (search YouTube for the travel time comparison video someone made), and that's the 3-team PvP area. There are keeps to fight over, PvE quest hubs (where enemies can and will gank you, but the XP is great if you can avoid getting murdered), "Elder Scrolls" to steal from enemy keeps, small public dungeons (where enemies can and will gank you), LOTS of open space to hunt in and, "coming soon", the Imperial City, which is a huge PvEvP area in the middle of the PvP map (not yet implemented, though you can SEE it...)Will this game have legs to go long term? I dunno. At worst, I think it'll be the next Rift -- alive and kicking for a year or two before the new wears off for everyone. I don't think it'll be another SWTOR -- which was closing servers due to lack of players less than a year after launch. Whether it's the new WOW, exploding onto the MMORPG scene and there to stay, remains to be seen. It may depend on how popular the PvP is (which sustained DAOC for years) and how well they can deliver new content.All things said, I'd vote "go ahead and get it". The only people I think will be unhappy are those who expected another Skyrim with an open world meant for soloing. This is not that.For me, it's fun. I dunno if it's long term ("Magic 8-ball says: "Ask Again Later") but it really has its moments and is not a flash in the pan.

So I have this thing and a Chromecast. I gotta say, I'm not sure why Google went the direction they did because this thing seems easier to setup and use and it effectively does more.The Chromecast requires apps support it. You have to, for example, launch the Netflix app and then hit the "Chromecast" button to hook it up to your TV. And initial setup requires getting the Chromecast connected to your wifi, which can be a hassle.I guess the Chromecast advantage is that probably all phones can support it. Not so with this Miracast -- it worked just awesome with my Galaxy S4 but I could not get it connected to my work phone, which is an HTC One. It SHOULD work and connect but I couldn't get it to see the device.Anyway, I'm still rating it 5 stars because with my Galaxy S4 it was very simple to use -- it's just the "screen mirroring" function built into the phone. No connecting to wifi or anything else was needed. I just went to Screen Mirroring (Settings -> Connections tab -> "Screen Mirroring" at the bottom), the device came right up and I selected it and that was that.Unlike the Chromecast this requires no app support. It just mirrors whatever is on your screen. Netflix, gallery photos, YouTube, your home screen, the browser, Angry Birds, whatever. The only real catch is "does your phone support it". If you have a Galaxy S4, at least, you're good to go. Anything else, I guess ask around or take your chances!

I do like this concept and it works okay for what it is -- a cup that sticks magnetically to your fridge and can hold pens -- but the magnet isn't very strong so it doesn't take much to knock it off. I think it would be about ideal if they could just double the sticking power of the magnet.Still, ya know, for the price, it gets the basic job done.

Quartet! What are you doing. Stop making these whiteboards with magnets too weak to actually hold the whiteboard to a surface. This is the second small Quartet board I tried and they both came with these really thin, flimsy magnets that barely stick to the 'fridge and are so weak they can't really even hold the product up. I had to reinforce it with other magnets I had laying around. You might as well just use the double-sided tape to stick it directly to your fridge, though I feel that somewhat defeats the purpose.The cork board is a nice touch and I like that the whiteboard itself is magnetic and it works fine as a whiteboard but the included mounting magnets don't work well enough.

This is a small no-frills whiteboard that I thought would be handy for the fridge (what with the magnets and all) but I found the included magnets were very weak -- not strong enough to even hold the product to my fridge! I had to shore it up with a couple of my own extra magnets.I like that the whiteboard itself is magnetic so you can stick magnets to it (and it comes with 2 magnets that are fine for that purpose) and it's fine if you mount it some other way but really, who decided to ship it with such weak mounting magnets?

Yes, it works going from bigger hard drive to smaller msata! I cloned my 500gb Samsung evo SSD to a 250gb MX200 Crucial. As long as your bigger hard drive has less data than than the destination can hold. My samsung ssd only had 75gb of data on it. And obviously, if you're cloning a smaller hard drive to a larger msata, then that would work without any issues.This is usb 3.0 and it's blazing fast! As mentioned, I had about 75gb and it took about 5 minutes, but in that 5 minutes the case got extremely hot. I would never use this to house a msata for external hard drive storage purpose. I think this should solely be used for upgrading purposes and put away. It comes with a CD for the EZ GIG IV software, but this is always free on their website. If you don't have a rom, just go to their site to download the software. I always use their software even before purchasing this msata. If you are the go-to tech guy in the family, or if this is your business, this is an invaluable tool to have. Aesthetically, it looks much nicer than any other adapter on the market, and you can depend on the Apricorn brand versus the plethora of unknown names out there. Go for it!

This is not a verified review, but we've recently purchased 3 from Amazon for our clients using our business account. These Edsal racks are common at your local Lowes and Home Depot, they may just be branded differently. The $75 to $90 price range is usually more common for the 48x24x72 models with the particle board. Not only are these bigger but they come with the wire racks which are much sturdier than the particle board version and less prone to bowing. When big retailers drop the price to $89, Amazon price matches and it's a super bargain to have it at this price and delivered to your door. Are you kidding me? This thing is huge and heavy, it would cost more than $89 to ship it. I don't understand how Amazon does it. Really, how can small businesses compete? But I digress.. don't even hesitate, buy this, you won't regret it. BTW, it's powdered coated and will come to you with scratches and paint imperfections. No biggie.Okay, HERE ARE SOME TIPS:---------------------------------------------1. TOOLS REQUIRED - A MALLET: You absolutely need this so you don't do this incorrectly, and then come here and write a bad review about how they don't stay connected. You need it to whack the beams so they will interlock tight. You don't want to use a hammer because it will damage or dent the beams. Once you have the whole rack done, you should do a walk around and whack it some more. Because I realize that as I was connecting the beams, the force of the mallet was actually disengaging other beams. So do one last walk around and make sure everything is tight.2. EDSAL VS HUSKY INSTRUCTIONS: For some reason, Amazon's inventory see these brands as interchangeable. They shouldn't because there are differences and the Edsal units are better. If you receive a set with Husky instructions, then you might want to consider returning it. As mentioned above, these things can be found at your local hardware store under different brand-names, so I wasn't surprised when I received one with Husky instructions. Husky is also a Home Depot brand. But because we had ordered 3 sets. I was able to compare and contrast and I found out the subtle differences, and the Edsal units are superior. Maybe I just so happen to receive a bad husky set, but of the 3 sets, 2 were edsal and 1 was husky, and only the husky set had bent poles. The couplings/braces that connect the two pole halves were also different, and the Edsal couplings were far superior. I will discuss the coupling issues below. Also, the Husky poles are slightly shorter than the Edsal poles, so you cannot mix them up because the holes won't line up properly to connect the beams. BTW, this is how the packaging arrived for our 3 units from Amazon. We received two Edsal units with Edsal instructions, but they came in Husky boxes flipped inside out to hide the Husky brand. And we received one Husky unit with Husky instructions that came in a completely unbranded brown box. Are you confused yet? LOL!3. COUPLINGS: The most time you'll spend on assembling this rack is while connecting the upper and lower post with the couplings. The posts are metal thin L shape bars and they have to slide into a coupling whose opening is equally thin. I have attached an image below to show you the difference between a husky coupling and an edsal coupling. The husky coupling maybe looks nicer because it'll cover the seems from the outside, whereas the edsal is built inside/out, so it'll cover the inner seams, but the outer seams will be exposed. But the edsal couplings are superior!A.) EDSAL COUPLING: The edsal coupling is harder to connect, but it's superior because of that, and you will have no issues connecting the top and bottom poles EQUALLY. I'll get back to what I mean by "equally" when I discuss the husky coupling below. If you find that you cannot connect the edsal posts no matter how hard you whack with the mallet. You'll need to get a small flat head screw-driver and pry open the coupling end that you're having issues with. I simply use the same mallet to wedge the flat head into the coupling. You don't want to use a big screw driver, the idea is to open it just a little, and not compromise its purpose. If you pry it too big, you will compromise it's ability to hold the top and bottom post together. Because ultimately, you do want it to be a tight fit. Reading this may not make any sense now, but you'll understand when you have it in your hands.B.) HUSKY COUPLING: The husky coupling openings were sightly bigger than the edsal couplings, so it's looser. Just like the edsal assembly, you start by whacking in a coupling onto a pole (bottom), then when it's half way in, you stop. Actually with the edsal, there is some sort of built in road-block right in the middle of the coupling, so no matter how hard you whack, the coupling cannot slide past the half-way point, so when you whack in the top pole, even with all the force, the coupling stays put and does not slide further down the bottom pole, as you keep whacking, the top pole will eventually touch the bottom pole, and you have a perfect assembly. But the issue with the husky coupling is that it does not have the built in road-block that the edsal has. So when you whack the coupling into the bottom pole, you'll need to eyeball the half-way point and stop yourself. The problem begins when you try connecting the top pole. When you start whacking in the top pole down, because of all the force, the coupling will slide further down the bottom pole, it doesn't stay put due to the lack of road-block. And because it doesn't stay put to give you leverage, the top pole isn't even going in. You think you're whacking in the top pole into the coupling, but all you end up doing is hammering in the coupling further down the bottom pole. Once this happens, you will have an absolutely swell time trying to remove the coupling from the bottom pole. Absolutely swell! The time of your life. So if you get a set with the husky instructions and couplings, RETURN IT IMMEDIATELY. DON'T EVEN TRY. Be sure to look at my pictures below to see the pictures of the couplings.4. YOU ACTUALLY DON'T NEED TO USE THE COUPLINGS (BUT YOU MAY NEED A HELPING HAND): This will work for either brand. That's right, they are not necessary and I'll tell you why. Did you now the older models never came with couplings? I own both old and new models, so I know. The reason is you can simply connect the upper and lower post by installing a shelf right in the middle. The beams will connect the upper and lower posts together. Installing a center shelf was a requirement in the older model. The couplings now simply give you an option so you don't have to put a shelf in the middle, so you can divide the sections any way you want. So if you're planning to put a shelf in the middle anyway, then you can avoid the coupling hassle. But you may need a helping hand to hold the two posts while you connect the beams. But they don't mention this in the instructions, and if you look at the Amazon product picture, you can see they use couplings to connect the halves, and the middle shelf is slightly above the coupling. Did they find some security issues in their old models? So now they decided to add couplings? Or, is it simply to allow this to truly be a one person job? I don't know. But all the older models in my home without the couplings are doing just fine.But I love the couplings! I should say I love the "edsal" couplings! Because I store bulkier things, boxes, bins, etc. So with the old models where I'm forced to put a shelf in the middle, once I install the other shelves above and below, my clearance became too small. With this new model, I do not use all 5 sets of shelves and beams. I only use 4 sets to create a three section rack divided equally with no center shelf. The thickness of the beams are approx 2.5 inches. So for my three section rack, which means using 4 sets of beams. 4x2.5 = 10 inches of clearance that you'll lose. Subtract that from the total height, which is 78, and you get 68. Divide that by 3 and spaced evenly, I get 22.6 clearance. If you use all 5 sets of beams to create a 4 section rack just like the product picture, and you space it evenly, your clearance is only 16.375. That was not good for me. So it all depends on the type of items you'll be storing.5. The holes in the posts are very useful if you think creatively. I have two bins hooked up to it. I have included a picture so you can have an idea.Bottom line, at $89 for a 60x24x78 rack that comes with the galvanized wire shelves that do not bow easily, it's a great deal. The smaller version 48x24x78 is currently $99. Some complain the beams are flimsy. Well think about it, they are 60 inches long. I can't believe this is even a complaint by some people. It's physics, individually, yes they can bend, but once assembled and connected properly, it is absolutely ridged. Try bending the the finished product!! If you want heavy rigid metal beams, how much do you think you'll need to pay? So If you have reasonable expectations, this is a lot of bang for your buck. I also did the math on material cost to make these racks out of 2x4s and the savings wasn't worth the hassle. Get it! But remember, if you are shipped a husky brand with husky couplings, you might want to return it.

Wow, this is hit or miss for many. But the listing says that it WILL NOT work on factory installed ipod adapters. I suspect many are not reading the listing carefully. I installed an ipod adapter in 2007, since then, I don't even use an ipod anymore. This thing worked flawlessly for my Android phone. Love it.

I started using a trackball in 2011, the Logitech M570, so that is the only experience I have. I just got through mentioning in my LG tv review that I don't believe large companies are dumb enough to have shills writing bad or good reviews, but some of the bad reviews for this mouse has me thinking.. hmm. If you click on my reviews and rummage through it, you'll find me raving about the Logitech M570, so I'm definitely not a Kensington employee or anything. Trackballs will be prone to bad reviews if the reviewer has only used it for one day and decide to piss and moan. You need to understand this word when it comes to trackballs.. KNACK. It takes getting used to, and after awhile you'll develop a knack for it. There is so much false information floating around in the bad reviews. For example, someone says the scrolling pad touches the ball, so when you scroll, you'll be chasing your page all over the place. Wow! For the first time, I'm thinking maybe shill reviewers do exist in these corporate battles. There is a small gap between the ball and the scrolling pad, so no, it does not touch the ball and you won't be chasing your pages. This person is probably just touching the ball with her other fingers.Anyway, here are my pros and cons when examining it from the M570 point of view.PROS:--------1. The ability to move the ball with a combination of your index, middle and ring finger gives this mouse potential for optimal precision. I think you can use all three middle fingers if you want, I personally think the most comfortable and natural is just to use the index and middle finger. The index does the main steering, while the middle can provide further support for more precision. The middle finger or the ring finger can be used for scrolling, you'll have to find your own knack. The pinky is used for right clicking. At first I found this uncomfortable, but I realize it's because I was trying to click with the tip of my pinky. If I relax, and just use the whole length of my pinky to press, it feels much better. I love my M570, but the thumb is not going to give you the type of precision that you can achieve with your fingers. I'm not quite there yet, but I already feel the comfort and I see the potential when I finally develop the "knack."Honestly, that's it. That's the main advantage it has over the M570, but it's a big one. Because if you master it, and I plan to, the other short comings will be worth it for me to put up with.CONS:---------1. No back and forward buttons. And it would seem so easy for them to give it to us. The right and left clicks are on the sides of the mouse and they are big. They could make the left click smaller and squeeze in a back and forward button right under it. For now, if you need to go back or forward, you'll need to right click (with your ringfinger or pinky) to bring up the menu. Or, scroll to your browser's buttons. But here is some good news... You can program the back and forward if you want. The left button that serves as the click/selection button can never be re-programmed for obvious reasons. But you can program the right button. Since most of us do copying and pasting, reprogramming this button is not an option. So one last recourse is the double press! You can program it so that when you press both left and right buttons, your browser will go back. So you can't have both back and forward, it's either/or. You need to download their software and play around with it. It's self explanatory.2. Another complaint I see is regarding the touch scrolling wheel. Many say it's hit or miss, or that it requires a few swipes for it to react. It's not as smooth as the M570, but certainly not as bad as some are saying. I would set the scrolling to a tick above the slowest speed. I find that to be the sweet spot where it's not too slow, and I don't get lost. If you set the speed to medium or higher, you will get lost cause the scrolling will jump or skip lines. Here's my theory why so many think it's faulty when in actuality it isn't. You see some web pages will not allow wheel scrolling until the browser has finished loading a certain percentage of the page. I think psychologically, you're less annoyed when a physical wheel isn't responding because it's tactical. When you hear and feel the wheel scrolling, your brain says it's functioning even though the page is not scrolling until the browser is good and ready. Since it doesn't bother you, these instances are not remembered. But when it comes to something that is based on touch, psychologically you get annoyed easily.
