When something that's based on touch doesn't respond, you think it's not reliable or finicky, when the truth of the matter is that both the physical and touch scrolling wheels has its fair share of unresponsive moments. But if you insist that the scrolling is horrible, then you can program the double press so that it functions as a middle click. So when you press both left and right buttons at the same time, a scrolling cursor will appear and you can use the ball to scroll. I believe some call this "chording?" The DOUBLE PRESS is a good way to get another function, but you just have to choose what is most important to you. Since scrolling is fine as is for me, I program the double press to be my BACK button.And honestly, that's it for the cons. You see, most bad reviews have one subject in common, ergonomics. But like I said, these things require developing a knack.  If you wanted something easy to use, then buy a conventional mouse. That's why the majority of the population DO NOT use trackballs. They are by nature, NOT EASY TO USE. If you purchase one, then understand you'll need time to master it. If I can master this mouse, it will replace my M570 because I like the control potential. When I develop the knack, I'll comeback and change the rating to 5 stars.

Pleasantly surprised by the size of this train. We imagined it would be a smaller, but it's about the size of a football. There are only 3  controls: 1. Forward 2. Reverse 3. Auto. The auto is the center button, push it and it will do a little song and dance on it's own. There isn't any steering left or right, so in order to change direction, you'll have to reverse and figure things out, but that's only an issue when the adults are playing. LOL! When your 2 yr old is playing, he'll just go and move the train physically when it's stuck or hit a wall. I'm imagining the only way to have a left and right, is to have a directional stick and two buttons for forward & backwards. But then as you can imagine, you're entering a different age group. These basic buttons are fine for a toddler's first RC.Now keep this in mind. If the train has been inactive for a while, I think it goes into some sort of sleep mode. You may need to get real close to it, or turn off the controller, and turn it back on again. I think some may be complaining and describing this quirk as "not working anymore" or unreliable. But that's all it is, a quirk. We have never failed to get it out of its inactivity state by getting real close to the train, or by turning the controller or/and train off & on again. If you can teach your child to turn off the train and the controller every time he/she is done playing then you will not have this issue. But good luck with that! LOL!

Terrific value! Got mine from another source on Black Friday, so this is not a verified purchase review. There are people claiming many reviews are fake, so you just have to use your head and analyze the reviews yourself. There are a fair share of 5-star reviews from "verified purchases," and a fair share of accusatory reviewers who are not verified purchasers. If LG has shills, then Sony, Samsung, they all have shills and it's a stupid silly game. Personally, I don't think a corporation this big would risk writing fake reviews and damage their rep. I think people who are unhappy with their TV are just paranoid.Anyway, back to the TV. First off, this is a basic TV, and you're paying accordingly. So I understood I had to tempter my expectations. It's not for my main living room, it's for my bedroom and it's more than adequate. It's a beauty too! Less bezel is always better. The bezel is so thin, it's out of sight, out of mind. Out of the box, I did not like the picture quality. You need to calibrate it. I find that the Wizard program built in the TV produced great results. The model I owned previously was a budget Sony Bravia from 2009, it had ghost spots from the beginning. This LG model has none, so that's an improvement already.There was one quirk I didn't quite understand. Every time I changed the channel, the tv would dim for a split second, then brighten up again when the channel gets settled in. You don't need to even be changing channels. If a program is changing segments or going to a commercial, it will normally transition with a black screen. Well this black screen will also cause the TV to dim then brighten back. So I dug through the reviews and I even posed a question asking if this was normal. Turns out this an automatic dimming feature on purpose by LG for reasons I'm too lazy to get into, but to get rid of it, all you need to do is turn off "dynamic contrast." It's found in your settings..PICTURE, then scroll down to EXPERT CONTROL.Once I ran it through the wizard for calibration and my xbox one for further calibration recommendations, and turned off dynamic contrast.. everything was dandy! For $500, the picture quality is awesome! My go to movie scene to make sure I like the black levels is Back to the Future, the parking lot scene where Marty meets Doc at Twin Pines Mall in the middle of the night. The night sky is nice and black, the subjects are bright and crisp. Maybe I got a good panel, but for my experience, I believe all the great reviews on Amazon. Those who are accusing LG of fake reviews probably got bad ones, don't know how to calibrate, or are expecting a $3k tv for $500.

Tremendous! I got mine during black friday from Sony. So this is not an Amazon verified purchase. Anyway, I'm coming from the Canon 70D, before that, the 60D and lugging a full size dslr around started to feel cumbersome. So I decided to jump into the mirrorless world, and I'm not sure if I will ever turn back. Look I'm not a professional, I think I'll be "entry level" my whole life. I don't have a keen eye for picture differences, nor am I that picky. I cannot tell the difference in quality between my 70d shots and my Sony shots, so if you're like me, and you can't tell the difference... then why lug around the bigger camera? Simple logic.I'm either going to sell the 70D, or keep it as a dedicated product photography camera, while the Sony will be my take out camera. One feature I really like is how you don't have to choose between the viewfinder or the screen. As your eye approaches the viewfinder, it automatically senses and switches accordingly. I do wish the Sony had touch screen like the 70D, but I'm sure that's down the line. That's how they milk ya!In terms of aesthetics, after years and years of all black Canon cameras, I wanted a change! So I went with the silver body with the black grip and I think the black and silver contrast looks awesome. I wanted a black lens, but Sony didn't allow to mix and match, but I realize it looks fine since there is a touch of black because the face of the lens is black. I also purchased and highly recommend the Sony lower body case model# LCSEBC/B. It fits nicely.Highly recommend the A6000! Go for it!

Terrible instructions... I've installed countless screen protectors, so this is not mindless user error. There are always two layers that you need to peel.. lets say SIDE A for the sticky side that will stick to your screen. Then there is SIDE B, this is the front side with no adhesive. This product's SIDE A has two layers unknowingly to me. Instructions does not warn you of this! As you all know, it is extremely difficult to prep your glass and get it just right with no dust. Every little spec of dust, you find yourself wiping, wiping, wiping to no end. Finally, when the screen is ready, this is the moment you have to GO!! Hurry before another spec of dust arrives. Well, when I removed the SIDE A, I hurried up to apply it, but it won't stick. I'm scratching my head! I realized there is another outer edge layer that I need to peel. How stupid is that?????????? When I removed the first layer, it had already exposed the middle of the glass. So now I have to fiddle with it to remove the outer edge. Well when you have to fiddle with it, dust particles land on the protector since the middle has already been exposed. I can keep an eye on my Sony screen and still keep it clean, but there is no way you can tell whether or not particles have landed on the protector while you're fiddling with removing the second layer. I knew it was going to be bad, but I installed it anyway, and sure enough... dust specs galore! To make matters worse, it was difficult to remove and it leaves a sticky residue. I haven't been able to wipe my glass clean for fear that if I scrub any harder, I may actually scratch the screen. The corners of the protector are not rounded, and does not cover the screen as neatly as the Larmor version. The Larmor version is also nicely rounded on the corners, but you'll pay twice as much. But as the saying goes, you get what you pay for.

Unless you got this at the giveaway price of $19, I would stick with the Amazon Fire tv box. I guess I'm a techie, and we tend to be frivolous with gadgets and buy redundant technology just to check them out. So I either own or have tried them all. I am biased against the stick because it performs poorly with PLEX. Even its competition, the supposed weaker Chromecast, streams flawlessly with Plex. Xbox One, Roku, and the Amazon Fire TV box all perform PLEX perfectly.If you don't know or don't use Plex, then you'll be happy with the Stick. It does everything else well. If you bought this for Plex, you might want to just buy the Fire TV. If you think about it, the stick isn't a bargain compared to the Fire TV. From $99 to $39 retail, at first glance, you may think it's a bargain, but it isn't. You don't get the Voice remote like you do with the Fire TV, that's $30 sold separately. So when there's no black Friday, no cyber Monday, and we're back to retail as usual, that's $70 total for the stick and the voice remote. Might as well pay an extra $30 to get the box where you get double the power, USB port for accessories like a keyboard. If you know what SIDE-LOADING is, you're going to want to use a keyboard when using Android apps that are not made for the Amazon interface. There is also an Ethernet port on the box.If the lesser Chromecast can do Plex nicely, then I'm thinking this isn't a hardware issue, and hopefully a software update can solve the problem. Others who are using it for Plex and are happy are making me per-PLEX-ed. LOL! I wonder if they had experience with any other gadgets to compare the quality to. But there are plenty of reviews similar to mine, with the conclusion that this is bad for Plex.BTW, if these box makers would just give us a HDMI input, they can completely wipe out the Smart TV business. Seem so easy, but only the high end Xbox One has this feature.-----------------------------------------------------Dec 4th, 2014 REVIEW UPDATE-----------------------------------------------------I have now revised my review for this product. Initially I was biased against it because I thought it performed horribly with Plex. I thought I couldn't use 1080p, so I had to set the quality to 720p which gave me so much blocky artifacts. As it turns out, I made a simple rookie mistake in 1080p mode. In my plex setting, when I would set the quality to above 8 mbps for 1080p, but to test out my movie, I would go into the RECENTLY VIEWED section and I would RESUME a movie. Well, the terrible quality and stuttering comes from the fact that I'm starting mid-stream cold, no buffering. I played around with it again today, this time I started all the movies from the beginning and it streamed perfectly and quality is outstanding!I initially rated the stick 2 stars. I still will not give it 5 stars because the value to me is deceptive. The voice remote is sold separately for $30 which brings the grand total to $70. At that point, you might as well get the Box version for $99 for all the reasons I mentioned above. If you got this for the pre-order price of $19, then it is a 5 star all the way!

We have a $20 babys r us type umbrella stroller that needs upgrading, so we opted for this! After setting it up and testing it out, it works and functions great. This is the same stroller, made by the same company as the Jeep Cherokee Sport Stroller, Cobalt. So be sure to read reviews there too since the bulk of the sales is coming from that listing, but I chose this Kolcraft branded one for the black/red color combo. The main issue I read is that there are no back support. It is padded and there is a piece of cardboard inside, but no cross bars or anything. But if you're like us, upgrading from those $20/$30 babys r us umbrella strollers, then this shouldn't be an issue. If during the ownership of those $20 strollers, you felt you needed back support, then this model is NOT for you, but if back support was never an issue, then you'll be happy with this stroller. Besides, it is still an upgrade after all. There is more padding than those $20 strollers, which actually had zero padding. You also have to have some perspective, this is a $60 stroller so you can't expect the world. We also own the Britax B-Ready which is a $300/$400 system, and so we understand what not to expect from $60 strollers. These strollers are for quick errands, and for my wife when I'm not around since the Britax is too heavy for her.It came down to this model and The First Years Ignite Stroller, Naturalization, which had back support. But once again, back support was never an issue with us. We only started thinking about it due to the reviews. We ultimately decided on the Kolcraft because it just beats out the Ignite and all other similar price range strollers in so many ways. Here is the breakdown of why we chose Kolcraft over the First Years Ignite.BACK SUPPORT: Ignite Wins!--------------------------It has some sort of metal cross-bar for the back, so for those who think their child needs it, probably the heavier ones, they should buy the Ignite model. If you are new to umbrella strollers, you need to know that these strollers have very little to zero back support. it's like a shock to some people and so they leave bad reviews. Some babies are fine, like ours. But some may look uncomfortable, so you need to observe your child.WHEELS: Ignite Wins!--------------------The Ignite back wheels are also double wheels, so you have 8 total wheels versus the Kolcraft which has 6 total wheels. Not sure if the child can feel the difference, so not a big deal to us.BASKET: Kolcraft Wins!----------------------Kolcraft has a bigger basket, not to mention accessible. The Ignite has a basket too, but it's smaller on top of not being accessible. The problem is there is a crossbar in the way. I'm not talking about the back support cross-bar, there is another cross-bar that is part of the overall frame. Now, with your child sitting down, all the reviews say there is no way you can reach this basket. You can poke your hand in and out from the side, but there is no way to comfortably grab a bag, a blanket, etc. with your child already in the seat. You'll need to remove the child first. This is not an issue with the Kolcraft.CANOPY: Kolcraft Wins!----------------------The Ignite Canopy is fixed in one location, and it's not that big. You'll need to buy a shade accessory. The Kolcraft's canopy is quite generous and there is even a second layer that extends. The child will be fully covered even from the side angles.ACCESSORY HOLDERS: Kolcraft Wins!---------------------------------The ignite has a accessory bag at the handle bar for the parent, the Kolcraft has a double cup holder and tray. It's a wash, depending on which you prefer. But the Kolcraft still wins in this department because the child has a snack tray! This tray will also serve as a horizontal bar like you see in higher end models. For children who likes to hold on to something, this is great.RECLINE: BOTH RECLINE---------------------Both will recline, but if this is "VERY" important to you, then don't buy either of this model, check out Summer Infant 3D lite Convenience Stroller, BlackSECURITY: BOTH ARE FIVE POINT HARNESS-------------------------------------WEIGHT: Kolcraft Wins!----------------------Kolcraft is approx 12 lbs, the ignite is approx 14 lbs.FOLDING: DEPENDS ON PREFERENCE!-------------------------------This is also a wash depending on your preference. The Ignite folds like a traditional umbrella stroller, it folds exactly the same way as those cheap $20 strollers. But these are more heavier than those $20 strollers, so you'll need to get on the ground. But it'll take up less space in terms of girth, but more in terms of length. Some reviews say it was too long to fit in their trunk/back.The Kolcraft will fold up while you're standing, and it will fold up standing on its own as well. You won't need to ever go to the ground. Watch the video clip of this either here or on youtube. It's great, we love this feature. So it will not fold like an umbrella. It'll take up more space in terms of girth/width, but it'll be shorter than the ignite, which means it should fit in any trunk.At the end of the day, these are all cheap strollers. People will swear by you the quality of one cheap stroller over they other. But at this price range, you're getting a cheap stroller no matter what you choose. So I would focus more on function. I also wanted to get away from models that fold up like an umbrella because I could never use my feet to lift up the bracket or mechanism that controls the folding. I would always have to bend down and pull with my hands and was always conscious whether my fingers would get caught. The Kolcraft one-handed or two-handed fold while you stand sealed the deal.Highly recommended!

I bought the 67mm for my Canon 18-135 and the 52mm for my 40m pancake. I've used the sticker versions before, but it would lose it's adhesiveness. So I thought of drilling a hole in my canon caps, but then decided to drill generic versions and save my Canon caps for resale value. So i started looking for generic caps and what do you know, I found these already pre-drilled. Any idea you can think of, others have already thought of it. That's a guarantee in life. :) This product is 5 stars and self explanatory.

$15 at my local Home Depot. I used this for my wall mount vacmaster. I have to use an adapter coupling to change the 1-1/4 to 1-7/8. I wanted more floor coverage when vacuuming saw dust. Sucks them up effortlessly. When it comes to nozzle reviews, I see so many people blaming the nozzle, when maybe they just don't have a good shop vac. So disregard reviews, you need to trial and error yourself. This one works perfectly for my vacmaster. I love the smooth gliding wheels. You can step on the tab located on top of the left side and release the brushes. Left the tab to retract the brushes. Comes with an adapter for 2-1/2, but I had to use my own 1-7/8 adapter.

If you lay it... they will come!I think I saw Shoeless Ant Jackson playing baseball on my kitchen counter top! This product simply works. At first, you will get goosebumps when you see them come out by the masses. But don't touch them, don't kill them, resist the temptation. You need to let them enjoy the juice and give them time to bring it back to their colony. After several days, we got rid of our ant problem in the kitchen. Ours love the kitchen counter top, so we just decided to not doing anything on the counter top for several days. We let them takeover for several days, and now they're gone. 5 star product!8/27/2014 UPDATE----------------They came back. After several days of being gone. They came back, same location. So we have to put these out again. But what does this mean? Different colony, or same colony just never finished?

We're knocking out two star for the rounds of replacements we have to go through. Otherwise, this could be a five star product. If I get a perfect replacement, I'll add back a star to make this 4-stars. For all the QC issues, it cannot be 5-stars.FIRST KNIFE:The first knife we got, the blade was a little wobbly. Something that we would have accepted since others have mentioned it too. Not so loose that it would fall out, it would cut perfectly fine. But what we couldn't accept was the fact that the blade compartment could not be closed flush. It will come to you from the factory flush. Obviously even though we do not need to exchange blades on a brand new knife, we like to to test out everything, and that means opening up the blade compartment and looking around. Well, we couldn't close it back flush. We had the exact problem that reviewer FS2 mentioned. That review is currently the "most helpful critical" review. And he is correct, no matter how strong you are, you will not be able to close it flush. There is one way to fix this, and that is if you have a vise. We put the knife through our vise, and was able to close everything up flush. After applying pressure with the vise, the compartment had more give. Future closing was possible with hand force. But the fact that the blade remain a little loose, we decided to ask for an exchange.SECOND KNIFE:The replacement was "almost" perfect. The blade was nice and tight, no wobbling. The blade guard compartment could be opened and closed flush, but you'll still need some hand muscle, which is good because you want the compartment nice and tight. If you use all your might and you can't close it flush, then it's defective, like the first one we got. But if you use reasonable force and it closes flush, then you got a good one!  Now, why did I say "almost?" Because I noticed the big round hinge bolt is not installed evenly. Everything is working fine, but we're just concerned whether or not this will have an effect later in time.So we've asked for a THIRD knife. If the hing bolt is fine, but then we have some other issues like the first knife, then we'll just keep the second knife. But we're hoping 3rd time's a charm. Lastly, I want to mention that this EXACT knife has been branded by Sheffield and Craftsman, so don't buy all the Bessey fluff about quality control. These companies are getting these knifes at the same Chinese factories and slapping their brand on it, or packaging it with other accessories. I mean examine these knives carefully, THEY ARE THE SAME KNIVES.1.Craftsman Folding Utility Knife with Holster2.Sheffield Premium Lockback Utility KnifeBTW, if someone knows what tool can unscrew the hinge bolt, can you please comment below?8/27/14 UPDATE--------------Was hoping to get a perfect one and I would bump this review up one star, but unfortunately, I'm going to knock off another star instead. The third knife I got was once again, ALMOST perfect. The blade guard can close flush, the blade sits nice and tight, the hing bolt is installed evenly. Unfortunately, this one did not close when you press the hinge release mechanism. It will, but you need to give a hard shake with your hand. I thought it was something good old WD-40 would fix, but it didn't. Upon closer examination, the lower and the upper body are not aligned, that is the reason why it won't fold easily.So we're just going to keep the 2nd knife with the hinge bolt imperfection... for now. We may just decide to return it too. Good knife with too much QC issues.

This is not a verified purchase. Got mine from BuyDig, but returned it.THREE MAIN THINGS YOU NEED TO KNOW!1. FOCUS BREATHINGThis is new to me. I didn't even know such a phenomenon existed, therefore I didn't even know the term. Search "Breathing" in the reviews and you'll see that there is probably one other person who has mentioned this. So as a consumer, there is no way you can be warned by reading reviews, most people who own this lens probably aren't the wiser because they don't have another 250mm to compare too. I still don't really understand all the technical explanation of this phenomenon, so I'm not going to pretend. You should search the internet for info. Basically, when you zoom all the way to 250mm on the Sigma, your magnification will be much less than if you were to zoom in at 250mm on the Canon. So if you've never had any lens that was capable of 250mm, then you're not missing out on anything. Like I said, you simply wouldn't be the wiser. But if you do have a lens that can do 250mm, like I did, YOU WILL FEEL CHEATED. And the difference is a lot. The other reviewer who said the Sigma zoom at 250mm is like 40% less than the Canon's is NOT exaggerating.2. VIDEO RECORDING IS LOUD!The motor on this Sigma is loud when focusing and if you shoot video, you'll record all of the sound.3. FOCUSING RING IS SUPER TIGHT!I once dropped a Canon lens, and the result was a tighter focusing ring. So it did not give me a good feeling when the Sigma was so tight. However, unlike in my case, this isn't a defect or damage. Many other reviewers have mentioned the focusing ring being tight. So it's just the way it's built.This lens is good only for pictures and only for people who've never owned a Canon 55-250mm. Like the saying in the Matix movie, "Ignorance is bliss."  I think I would have been happy with this lens if I didn't own a 55-250mm and never found out about the focus breathing. For the best walk-around including shooting video, I think nothing beats the Canon 18-135mm with STM.Lastly, never-mind the THUMBS DOWN to my review. That is to be expected by people who own it and don't want to hear anything bad about it. Otherwise, if you don't own it yet, why would you give thumbs down to this information? I'm just informing the public of things that are not obvious in the product advertisement. Search online, or DPREVIEW, search focus breathing and you'll see people posting images of the zoom difference at 250mm between this Sigma and the Canon 55-250mm. http://www.dpreview.com/forums/post/54091986

The top cover was a pain to remove!  Why do I say guitar people will have no issues? It's because they have developed callous in their fingers. That's what you'll need to pry this off  pain-free. If you don't have callous, prepare for a little torture. You have three issues going through your mind while trying to remove the top: 1. It's so tight, you're worried about scratching your mac. 2. It's so tight, you're worried about snapping and breaking the product. 3. Lastly, the pain.I finally got it off and I have returned it. I would recommend the IPEARL versions. They snap tight too, but they have more give. You can easily snap one end free, and then slide it out. With the Topcase, you cannot free any end easily, it's a kung-fu grip!

For the Canon 70D, this is it!!I tried the Larmor brand and wrote a review on it here: LARMOR 0.5mm Self-Adhesive Optical Glass LCD Screen Protector for CANON 70D That one did not work for me, it was frustrating, the bubble would not clear no matter what I did. This Afunta version just took one try. I simply laid it on the glass, and you can see the bubble underneath slowly moved like a wave and eventually vanished. Now, I will say I did something this time that I did not do with the Larmor version, and I'm not sure if that was the difference. This Afunta version came with a little isopropyl alcohol pad, so I wiped the screen with it, then cleared out any dust with the microfiber cloth, also included. I don't know if the isopropyl alcohol was the difference, or if this Afunta version is simply superior. If I had moisten my glass a bit when trying the Larmor version, maybe that would have done the trick? I don't know. I'm thinking this is simply the superior product, because after all, you have to dry the glass, so moisture probably has nothing to do with it. Lastly, the touch screen still works perfectly with this glass on top! It is .3mm thick whereas many on the market, including the Larmor version, is .5mm thick. Logic dictates the thicker, the less touch sensitive, right? This one is just perfect, and .3mm is plenty thick, it feels nice and solid.What you get:1 .3mm thick glass1 microfiber cloth1 dust extraction sticker (if you take your time and make sure there are no dust, then you don't need this)1 isopropyl alcohol padWhat you DON'T get:You do not get the smaller glass to protect the top lcd screen. FWIW, the Larmor version included this. So something to think about.

Not what I expected, but it simply works. It has nothing to do with clamps, tension, or even adhesives as you might imagine. I'm not sure if gravity is the right word to describe how this works, but that's what I thought of. It hooks onto your front bezel and that's it! Like a rock climbing hook. The back part is a frame that's held in place by a hinge. You open this hinge as wide as you need to depending on how thick your flat screen is. The kinect will clip onto the seat/plate securely. The seat/plate has buttons on each side that you need to press in order to slide the Kinect in. Likewise, you need to press the side buttons if you want to release the kinect.The whole thing can be easily lifted off your LCD if you lift it straight up, you can even slide it along the TV bezel. There is virtually no tension. Yet it sits nicely and securely due to gravity because it's hooking on your front bezel. Very nice!

After reading the poor reviews for the silver version Generic Protective Vinyl Skin Decals Cover for Microsoft Xbox one Console and 2 Xbox one Controller Sticker Skins-Carbon Firber Silver by the same "GENERIC" brand and seller, I was hesitant. But I figure, this is fulfilled by Amazon, so there is nothing to worry about. If it does indeed suck, I would have no problem unpeeling everything and sending it back. However, I was pleasantly surprised. These are not cheap paper stickers, they seem to be some sort of vinyl material. The cut-outs are very accurate, and it's very forgiving. What I mean is if you need to unpeel or push out an air bubble, it's easy to do. Just have a credit card with you while you're doing this to help squeegee out things. I didn't have to unplug anything either because there are no skins for the back connections. But I guess you can unplug everything and sit down at a table if you want to be very careful.My simple tip is to line up the logo cut-outs. The parts with no logo cut-out, you should line up from the edge. The parts with logo cut-outs, you should line up from the logo, then everything will fall into place. I'm very perplexed by the bad reviews the silver carbon version got. I would advise you to be suspicious at those reviews, it could be from competing sellers. Or, it could just be from people who are clumsy and simply messed up so badly, that they feel the need to trash the product because they can't accept that it was user installation error.This product is fine, and if you apply it correctly, you'll like it a lot.8/7/2014 UPDATE:---------------Since some complain that the skin will peel off. A reviewer mentioned 30 minutes after. I've waited close to a month to give an update. Nothing has come undone. Superb product!! I've uploaded some pictures to the product gallery.

NOT AN AMAZON VERIFIED PURCHASE. I BOUGHT MINE ON EBAY.I know the debate between Xbox One and PS4 is a heated one, but those are usually from the gamers. I have spent and will spend ZERO minutes on games, and I love my Xbox One!!! In terms of converting your TV into an entertainment center/smart hub, there is nothing on the market like the Xbox One.You name it, I've tinkered with them because I'm a videophile. Roku 3, Fire TV, Apple TV, PS3, Chomecast.. I've played with them all. But the simple fact is, none of them can mimic a smart tv because none of them have a HDMI pass-through for my tivo. If you've seen those Samsung Smart TVs or those LG TVs with WebOS, then you know what I'm talking about. You move in and out of your video sources just like an app, without the need to change your TV's inputs or power up separate boxes. So in a way, this is a cheap way to upgrade your TV if you're not ready to spend over $2k. If you don't care about integrating your tivo or cable boxes, or having a blu-ray player all integrated, then yeah, getting a roku or fire tv would be more economical and they are also way ahead of the game in number of apps. Xbox One has very limited apps right now, but I'm willing to wait because I'm really waiting for nothing. Amazon Prime and Youtube are there and that's all I need. They are working on a Plex app, but until then, all you have to do is download the Xbox Video app and you've got yourself DLNA. I'm a bit confused by some of the reviews complaining about lack of DLNA, maybe those were early adopters and the Xbox video app wasn't available yet? Anyway, with this app installed on your Xbox One, your smartphone will be able to see your Xbox one with video apps like AVIA, BubbleUPNP, Twonky Beam, etc. All these apps can push your video/photos to the Xbox One. My collection of movies is served by Plex in my computer in the garage, I use BubbleUPNP to access my movies and then push it to the Xbox One... everything plays smoothly.Lastly, the one advantage that the Xbox One has over even smart tvs is the integrated Blu-Ray player. So this is truly THE ONE, all your video sources in just one HDMI connection. Once again, If you don't care about having all your sources in one input, then buying a Roku, Apple TV or Fire TV will make more sense. They also have way more apps right now. But for me, paying a premium for having all my entertainment in one input is worth it. For example, I can start an Amazon Prime movie, and all of a sudden, I realize Sportscenter is on, I click on my TV app, and boom there is my TV immediately. Once I'm done with sportscenter or live tv, I click on Amazon Prime and boom my movie resumes instantly. If you have a blu-ray in the player, it works the same way. If you have a movie being pushed via DLNA, it works the same way. When resuming a movie via DLNA, it may buffer a little first. You can jump in and out of apps, and almost everything resumes instantly, just like changing channels. It will never be as fast as changing "real" channels, but this is the closest thing ever. Going from a show on live TV to a movie on Netflix or Amazon Prime is almost as snappy as changing channels. And that is the whole point in having everything integrated in one HDMI connection, managed by a "smart" operating system. This is only going to get better once they get us more apps such as a dedicated Plex App. BTW, voice commands and the "Minority Report" type hand gestures work well too, but I don't really care about those things. All I care about is the console serving as my central media hub. But FYI, the hand gesturing thing is a gimmick. It's something you'll show off to your friends and family, but will not use when you're alone. The voice command is actually more practical, but your remote will still be king. It takes too damn long and too much concentration to make a selection with your hand, and the cursor is very sensitive. It works, it's cool! But what takes you 10 seconds to do with gesturing, takes a split second with a remote. The voice command is very cool and accurate, but you need to be loud and clear. On several occasions I have found it useful when I couldn't find the remote.One last thing, I was on the fence for the longest time because Xbox required their Live subscription to access all the entertainment apps, which was absolutely ridiculous. When they finally dropped that requirement, that's when I jumped in. You'll need it if you want to play games online.Advice to HARMONY USERS: (If you don't own a Harmony remote, don't read this, it'll only confuse you.)------------------------I have the Harmony 900. When you set your activity to WATCH TV, make sure to add both Xbox One and Tivo or whatever cable box you use, and of course your tv. When you have both Xbox and Tivo as part of your devices in your activity, you can then delegate your buttons to each box. Half of my buttons are dedicated to the Tivo, and half is dedicated to the Xbox one. This way, you don't have to change activities to control xbox and tivo, one activity will control both boxes. You'll need to get creative. I have the normal buttons dedicated to tivo, and I program the number buttons dedicated as my Xbox directional buttons, select button, back button, menu, etc. For example, if you take a look at your number buttons, 5 is in the middle so that's the SELECT button, 2 is above 5, so that's the DIRECTIONAL UP, 8 is below 5, so that's the DIRECTIONAL DOWN. 4 is to the left of 5, so that's the DIRECTIONAL LEFT, and etc. You get the picture. :)

Could it be that easy? I was skeptical, and to my surprise, it is that simple! I'm somewhat of a newbie to the DIY world, and I never thought creating threads to accept machine screws could be done at home. I always thought those threads in furniture and objects are manufactured at the factory. Several reviews say this is a must if you do a lot of drilling and tapping. I say even if you don't, this should be in your toolbox for those inspirational moments. In the past year I had some ideas, but like I said, I'm a newbie and I didn't think it was possible to do this at home. I didn't even know the lingo, such as tapping, deburring countersinking, etc. Now I know. :) I don't have a current project, but I was anxious to try this, so I used a large PVC coupling, nice and thick. Clamped it down properly and did my drilling with the 1/4 bit. The hole came out perfect with all the threads. I had some sort of camera adapter plate lying around, it has a 1/4 machine screw. It screwed on the PVC perfectly. I kept unscrewing and screwing just out of sheer amazement. LOL! I'll be ready next time I'm in my garage and I have one of those moments where I'm thinking.. if only I can connect this here or there, or create a thread here, etc. I'll be ready. This will open up a whole new world of possibilities for you. It's a must have in your toolbox!

First of all, it should be noted that I'm a wannabe DIY'er, not a working professional. I think I've noticed most of the complaints are from professionals who know what they want. I won't be dragging this thing around, it's going to be stationary. I just needed a drawer system to have quick access. I was tired of stacking and unstacking my bosch L-boxxes, and their drawer system is way overpriced.So for a weekend warrior, I have no complaints. But here are three minor issues I want to discuss:1. For the upper drawer, they gave us a bunch of containers with lids that fill up the whole drawer. To me, this defeats the purpose of having a "quick access" drawer. I don't want to open the drawer, then open a lid to a container. I would rather they gave me trays. Then I had an epiphany.. Just remove the lids!! LOL! The lids can be completely separated, and was actually useful in solving my 2nd issue.2. Build quality is questionable. There is a gap between the bottom drawer and frame. It's as if the unit is missing a middle support leg, so the center bottom frame sags. You can solve this easily with those round felt pads that are used under chair legs to balance a wobbling chair. You can think of a million things to solve this, that's why I say it's a minor issue. But what I actually did was take one of the lids from the containers and wedged it. The shorter end of the lid has these spikes/feet that makes it equal height to the actual corner feet of the unit. So if you wedge this lid in, you will eliminate the gap. It's a nice tight fit, the lid won't budge and it does not affect the sliding motion of the bottom drawer. I included pictures to show you what I mean.3. Not a big deal, but it is more comfortable sliding the drawer of the Tstak unit than the Tough unit. With the Tstak, a good portion of your fingers can go under the handle, your fingers then press a latch underneath to slide. With the Tough unit, only the tips of fingers can get underneath the handle, so it's not a good grip. You then press with your thumb to slide. This is a non issue, just an observation because I own both. It should not deter you from buying the Tough system if you need more space. The Tstaks are smaller, hence, the price difference.Here is a link to pictures of all the things I've talked about:http://s100.photobucket.com/user/thisthatandtheotherthing/library/Dewalt%20Tough%20Drawer

BTW, I just love prime shipping on a Sunday. :)Well, these boxes function fine, and they look nice. The drawers will never slide out accidentally because you need to press some sort of latch while simultaneously sliding it out. I have a bunch of L Boxes that came with Bosch tools, but needed some drawer units for quick access to things, but it costs an arm and a leg to put together a L-Boxx drawer unit. They are way over priced. So the heck with color coding in my garage, I decided to buy these Dewalt boxes.I'm knocking out a star for quality. I don't want to knock 2 stars because I do like these boxes, and I can live with the imperfections. These tstak boxes, are warped on the bottom front corners. These warped corners do not affect the functioning of the box. I ordered two of these 2-drawer units and they both came warped at the bottom corners. I know that asking for a replacement would just be a waste of time. This is how I know.. First of all, both of my boxes are warped. Secondly, just click on the 2-drawer stock photo on Amazon's listing, you can see the warp their too. Prior to purchasing, you wouldn't know it, but now that I have these in hand, and I re-exam the Amazon stock photo, I can see the warp now. So I'm sure this is just their standard quality. But like I said, it functions properly. The bottom drawers will slide without issue, and the units will stack and latch on without issues. How it will function over time? Will the warp get worse and prevent the bottom drawer from sliding out? I don't know. I'll have to monitor this closely within my return window.I made a photobucket album to show you close up pictures of what I'm talking about, here is the link: [...]------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------MAY 15, 2015 UPDATEClose to a year already, wow! I have one advice. If your bottom drawer can't close due to the weight of stacking, what you need to do is lift the handle as you close. By lifting the front handle, the back is lowered and then will be able to clear. How hard you have to lift depends on what kind of stuff you have in it. Not so bad really. I still like these a lot.

This review is geared towards those thinking about purchasing this for their Amazon Fire TVs. Yes, it works! Just plug in the unifying receiver into your Fire TV and you're off running, no need to do any set-up. This won't be a replacement for your Fire TV remote, it should only be a supplement for when you're using or configuring side-loaded apps. The main interface of the Fire TV was programmed for their remote, so the mouse cursor won't just click on anything just because you hover above it. You'll need to follow the rules of the Fire remote, so going anywhere on the main interface requires using the arrow keys on the keyboard, then hitting ENTER on the keyboard. That would be equivalent to using the directional pad and select button on the Fire remote. And of course there are no speakers or mic on the keyboard, so there is no way to make voice search work. So I don't even bother using this keyboard unless I'm using my side-loaded apps. Play Store apps are designed for smartphones so you can touch, swipe, etc. So they don't work properly on the Fire TV. This keyboard is your answer!One concern I had before buying was how fast or how much ground does the cursor cover with a swipe of the touch pad? Sometimes the cursors are slow, and you can adjust the speed in your PC. But when using it with the Fire TV, you won't have any access to any keyboard settings. But as it turns out, the cursor moves very well and covers a lot of ground. It is effortless to use on my 52 inch tv. The touchpad has both left and right clickers, but I've never been comfortable using the left click on touchpads, and I guess Logitech knows there are people like me, so they added a left click button all the way on the upper left end of the keyboard. This allows you to hold the keyboard with both hands like a gamepad. Your right thumb moves the cursor around, and your left thumb can push the left click button. Brilliant!! Another thing I like about the keyboard is that there is a SLEEP button design to put your PC to sleep. Well, it works for the Fire TV too. Push it and the lights on your Fire TV goes off instantly. For those who own the Fire TV, you know it takes a while for it to go to sleep. This button puts it to sleep immediately.This keyboard serves my purpose. 5 stars!!

1.) PRICE: First of all, get it at walmart online, it's $40. At that price, I was willing to accept the colors. I prefer the more neutral colors with the white boards so that I can slap on my favorite NBA team logo. But anything equivalent to this quality/thickness/model where  the hoop can grow with your child will cost over $70 bucks. So at $40, it's a deal even if the colors are not ideal.2.) DIFFICULTY: Read the reviews, people are not kidding. YOU WILL have a hard time putting this together. You don't have to be Einstein. It's pretty easy, but the parts just don't connect easily, you'll need to use a lot of force. The manufacture knows this, that's why the instructions even advise rubbing the parts with soap and water.3.) BONUS BALL RETURN ACCESSORY: I didn't realize it because it wasn't obvious in the product pictures, but there is a ball return accessory that you attach to the rim. When the ball goes through the hoop, it will return to you. But because of this accessory, they had to design the hoop in a way that I've never seen before. The rim is actually made of 2 rims. A basketball net is looped inside the smaller rim. This smaller rim is then placed inside the bigger main rim, and the two parts are screwed together. 4 screws are provided. Sounds strange, but you'll understand why when you see it. The outer rim is used to attach the ball return accessory.4.) You will also have to weight it down, if you don't, your kids will pull down the system if they grab on the rim.  The base is a container with a cap. You can put sand, rice, etc. My son is 19 months and I fear he will pull it down. It is not stable without weight.5.) Lastly, you may think from the pictures that you can adjust from 3 to 6 ft by sliding the pole up or down. That's only true for 4 to 6 feet. My son is 19 months and currently is on the lowest level, which is 3 ft. The pole comes in 2 pieces. The base has 2 slots. The first slot is for the smaller pole which serves as the 3 ft height. The second slot behind it, allows you to store the bigger pole until you need it. When your child is ready for 4 ft and greater, you then slide the smaller pole inside the bigger pole. Take a closer look at the product pictures, at the lowest level, you'll see another pole behind the hoop. I never noticed this.In terms of price and quality, this is a 5 star.

This product is self explanatory, so no need for an extensive review. So I'll just mention a few things that I was pondering about prior to buying.1.) Does the tray swing with a hinge?No, you have to remove it completely, or use it. It basically clips in.2.) Can you adjust the height of the seat while your child is sitting on it?No, the adjustment is made on the underside. You'll have to flip the booster over to play with some latches. Very easy though.3.) Can you remove the back support?Yes.For $25, everything is acceptable. And we should have bought this sooner. We use our highchair in two different rooms in the house, one of which is the dining room. No need to lug the high chair around anymore.

First of all, I got this at Lowes for less than $14. So get off your butt sometimes, Amazon's not always the lowest price. :) I was about to come here and write a scathing 2-star review. Then I had an idea, and thought I'd share it.I cannot use this cord reel the way I imagined it because the power source plug (male) is hidden inside the core of the wheel. To give it power and to take advantage of the outlets, you need to get to the middle. And in order to get to the middle, you would have to always unreel COMPLETELY. I don't always need to reel out my extension cord completely. When I stood there looking at it at Lowes, I didn't think much about it. I thought surely, they've designed this thing around me because the world revolves around me. LOL! I thought this wheel can stay stationary with a power source always plugged in. And when you need to use your main extension cord, you just reel out the amount of cord you need. It doesn't work that way. You can't be spinning the reel, with the power source cord connected. So it has to be disconnected. You can leave it connected to the core, you just have to disconnect the other end from your wall outlet or whatever you're using. You can then reel both the main extension and power source cord up, but as others have noted, you'll have lots of tangle fun. The best way to use this, as it is currently designed, is to disconnect the power source cord completely when not in use. When you need to use your extension cord, unreel it completely, then you can plug in your power source cord.They should redesign this so that the power source plug is on the outside like one of the 4 outlets. They could make 3 of them outlets, and one of them the male power plug. So with that in mind, and a 1 ft cord laying around, a light bulb went off. Pretty simple idea and I've uploaded images, numbered 1 to 5, to the product page. If you can't see it, just click on my user-name, or this link: http://www.amazon.com/gp/customer-media/customer-gallery/A1R3A8F7OSP3ZL?ref=pdp_new_c_img_link All we're doing is using the 1 ft cord as the de facto power plug. Plug in the 1 ft cord, and feed the other end out of one of the pre-designed holes. You should loop back in and come out again a second time so it's nice and tight. This cord has to be as short as possible and I think 1 ft cords are the shortest available. The reason is so it does not tangle when you're reeling and unreeling your main extension cord. Your main extension cord will reel on top of this 1 ft cord without any issues. With this set-up, you no longer have to unreel completely. Just unreel the amount of cord you need, then plug in your power source and go to work. When finish, unplug power source and reel your cord back up.Your needs may be different and you may be completely fine with how it works as is because you will always unreel 100% of your cord. But this idea is for those who do not always need to unreel their entire extension cord. Not only that, this set-up allows you to use those outlets without needing to unreel your main extension cord at all. If they had designed this with the power source plug on the outside, then this would be a 5 star product. Because I had to work at it, I'll give it 4 stars. Hope this helps out some of you.

This thing is impressive. Load capacity says 1.1 lbs. My softbox was close to 5 lbs and it held it with no issues. Going to get more of these. I take product photos and started to hate all the light stands taking up space. Super clamps and these HD flex arms allow me to put the lights anywhere. Manufactures are very conservative with load capacity for lawsuit reasons. This thing can do much more than 1.1 lbs.

I purchased the Vacmaster VWM510 on Amazon, and Amazon recommended the detail cleaning accessory kit, Vacmaster V1MK. The only issue is that the accessory kit is based on 1-1/4", while the Vacmaster is 1-7/8". This set will allow you to use the V1MK kit, as well as accessories based on 2-1/2. BTW, this adapter kit is the exact one offered by Home Depot under the Ridgid branding, Model# VT1755. While the Vacmaster V1MK is also offered under the WORKSHOP brand, Model# VT1215. http://www.amazon.com/WORKSHOP-Wet-Dry-Vacs-VT1215/dp/B0026T1FB6/ref=sr_1_20?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1397812404&sr=1-20

My first shop-vac, so I don't have anything to compare it to. It cleans up my working area, so I'm happy. I drill a lot, so I mainly clean around my drill press. There are some very technical and critical reviews about suction power, but if you're not a professional contractor or something, or who does heavy duty work in the garage, then I wouldn't pay too much attention to those reviews. This vacuum should be more than enough. If this is your first, go for it, you'll like it, especially the remote control feature. Some of the reviews says the remote doesn't work properly. You have to return it if that's the case, I don't think there is any gray area. It should work! Not 10% of the time, not 50% of time, but all the time.. 100%. Mine has never failed. On the main unit, you have OFF, ON, and REMOTE. If you switch it to "Remote," then the only way to trigger the vacuum is from the remote. Fairly basic stuff, and I'm happy mine works perfectly. It's just strange to me some are saying it works "some" of the time, but they're okay with it. I wouldn't be okay with it. The remote was the main feature why I bought this. I don't want to be going back and forth to the main unit, or dragging it around as I detail my car. Speaking of which, the detail cleaning accessory kit that Amazon recommends is not compatible. This vacuum is based on 1-7/8" when most shop vacs are based on 2-1/2" and detail accessories, like the one they recommend, are based on 1-1/4". Home Depot sells a Ridgid 3 piece adapter kit for less than $10 bucks, Model # VT1755. With this kit, you can virtually use any hose accessory in the market. If you want to do all your shopping in one place, Amazon sells the same Ridgid adapter kit under the WORKSHOP brand, Model # WS25055A. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00FX2R2LK/ref=oh_details_o02_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1.As a mater of fact, the same detail accessory kit can also be found under the WORKSHOP brand, Model# VT1215. http://www.amazon.com/WORKSHOP-Wet-Dry-Vacs-VT1215/dp/B0026T1FB6/ref=sr_1_20?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1397812404&sr=1-20I would browse the WORKSHOP offerings on Amazon, they have other 1-7/8" accessories. That's because they sell a similar wall mount shop vac based on 1-7/8", except it doesn't have a remote. Enjoy!

I had used an optical glass protector for my 60D and loved it because it allowed me to not worry about leaving the LCD screen face up all the time. But when the 70D first came out, there weren't any optical glass screens yet. So I installed a regular screen protector. It was a good screen protector, not glass, but not thin film either. This is why I'm so upset. I removed a perfectly good working screen protector to install this!! My glass was super clean since it's been protected since day one. Not a single speck of dust, but this Larmor screen just wouldn't lay properly. There were sections of air bubbles that just wouldn't seal properly. I've installed many screen protectors in my life and I know when it's user fault. When you can see dust particles in the bubbles, that's user fault, and you can usually remedy that by using some sort of sticker to pull out the dust. But in this case, there was absolutely no dirt, not a single dust particle. It is so clean that i was able to toy with this thing for close to half an hour. I kept re-positioning it, but no matter what I do the giant air pockets just wouldn't go away. Squeegee, rubbing thumbs, you name it.. nothing worked. Finally, near the end of the half hour, I see real dust that crept in. When you are re-positioning for nearly half an hour, I knew that was bound to happen.I really wanted to like this protect. The packaging was very impressive and that's why I'm giving it two stars. It came with a plastic case that houses the screen protector, and it even came with a smaller protector for the top LCD screen. If this was truly made for the 70D, then the only thing I can think of why it did not work for me was because i had previously installed a screen protector? Maybe that somehow altered the properties of the surface of my screen, but I've never heard of such thing. I've replaced worn out screen protectors on electronics before and the new ones would apply properly.

I like it, but I'll tell you why my wife hates it.You cannot simply open and fold like a laptop. It is some sort of transformer contraption that you will either love or hate. She hates it! But the thing that she hates the most is the opening aspect. When it's folded, it is actually clipped into place. This is very hard to articulate, but here goes.. there is a notch cut out on the keyboard, so when you fold it up, the clip fits nicely into this notch and is completely recessed. There was no design into how to easily open it. What do you do when things are shut tight with no designed mechanism to free it? The answer is you pry it open! This wasn't a big deal to me, you just pry one of the corners. Or, you can dig your fingers in the seam to pry it open. Going from the smart cover, my wife really hates this prying thing. She feels like here finger nails will scratch her Ipad inside. So the best way to open it is to use two hands and target one corner to pry it open. But watching my wife open this thing, I can see why people with small hands may hate it. She has to brace the whole thing against her tummy, or her elbows are tucked in with her arms supporting it while her fingers are prying. It's not a pretty site. But I see it as a non issue because most of the time, you'll be opening in bed, or while you're sitting at a desk in which case you can use the desk or bed for support.Now once it's open, you're presented with a contraption that will feel awkward at first, but once you get used to it, you'll think it's cool. At least, I think the guys will think it's cool. Once again, my wife is like what the heck is this ugly thing? Your Ipad is not immediately supported once open. It is protected in the case, it just can't stand on it's own yet. You'll need to slide out a hidden rail. The Ipad can rotate and stand vertically or horizontally. If you look at the product pictures, you'll see the silver circle on the case. That circle is where all the actions at, it allows you to pivot/rotate, and honestly by the looks of it, it will probably break during your ownership.Some people are saying the Bluetooth disconnects when you close it, and it's true. Once the Ipad goes to sleep, it disconnects. But it's not a hassle as some of them make it out to be. You DO NOT need to go back into your settings and pair it again. The keyboard has an on/off switch. So all you need to do is turn it off, then turn it on again and your Ipad will connect automatically. Anyway, you should turn off the keyboard when you close it. I mean you want to conserve its battery after all, right? Why are people closing this thing and not turning off their keyboard?I like it, my wife hates it. That's why I came to the conclusion that you will either love it or hate it. LOL!

I had purchased the 32gb Sony Microvault with duo heads, usb on one end and micro usb on the other end. But the drive had issues clearing my phone's case. So I got this PNY 128gb drive and an OTG cable. Accomplishing the same thing and getting more bang for my buck. I'm a not nut with regards to speed, so I don't go through all the speed tests. This thing just works and that's good enough for me. I remember 14 years ago, in the year 2000, when I configured a computer at circuit city, the highest capacity hard drive I could configure was 40 GB, and you had to pay an arm and a leg for it. The sales rep thought I was crazy for wanting 40 GB and said, "Why do you need that much? You're set for the next 50 years." LOL! 14 years later, pcs are now equipped with Terabytes and a little flash drive like this can be crammed with 128 GB. I don't nitpick about speed because this is amazing enough.

First thing you need to consider is the thickness of your smartphone's case and whether or not the cut-out for the micro usb port is wide enough to allow the sony drive to clear. My Armor Gear case is very thick, and the opening for the micro usb port was not wide enough. Take a look at the flash drive picture, the base where the Sony logo appears is wider than the cut-out for my port, so it does not fully insert. It makes a connection, but it's dangerous because it's not fully inserted. A little movement and the drive will be unmounted improperly and you could lose data. So in my situation, whenever I need to plug in this drive, I would have to remove the smartphone case. Not so convenient for me. I ended up using it with an OTG cable, which kind of defeats the purpose of buying a flash drive with duo heads. Because the OTG cable serves the same purpose. So I decided to go a different route, and I ended up getting more bang for my buck. You can get a PNY Turbo 128GB flash drive for $48 right now on Amazon. Connect that to an OTG cable and you can accomplish the same task. It won't look as elegant as the Sony Microvault, but you get 4 times the capacity for just $20 more.I still give it 4 stars because it's nice. Not everyone use thick cases. You're paying a premium for the small size.

Got mine at Rockler's, so this is not an Amazon verified purchase. Those Macbook screws are tiny, so I didn't think even the smallest extractor was small enough. But to my surprise, it worked! These bits are two sided. One side is to burnish/drill the screw, and the other side is to extract. The smallest extractor was slightly bigger than the Macbook Air screw, but the tip is pointy and small enough to dig in and drill. Once I extracted the defective screw, I was able to finally reach the trackpad and fix it. Not sure if this needs to be mentioned, or if there are even old power drills that can't go in reverse, but your drill must be capable of going reverse to extract. For over 6 months, the trackpad was not clicking, but I couldn't get to it because a stripped screw was in the way. Apple will charge $200 to $300 hundred to fix your trackpad. To add insult to injury, the stripped screw in my Macbook came directly from them.If you're curious whether or not this will work with Macbook Air screws.. IT DOES!

Perfecto!!!I got the 5-Port Metal version. I'm using this with the Actiontec Moca Adapter. Coaxial goes into the moca adapter, then you connect an ethernet cable from the adapter to one of the ports on the switch, and voila!! You now have 4 ethernet ports to play with.I love the solid build. But this is one of those products where Amazon makes money off of your habit of shopping with them. They make shopping so easy, you forget to compare prices. This metal version is actually $20.99 at Staples right now. Oh well, no big deal.

Even though this is highly rated on Amazon, there is still 25 thus far who have given it 1 star, and I truly feel sorry for them. This thing is changing my life! Your home is going to be much more organized, and that aspect alone, is worth the price of this machine. Speaking of price, I had $90 in staples rewards, so I had them match Amazon's $409 price, then applied my rewards. So my cost came out to about $345 tax included. I also sold the acroboat XI for $150 on the popular auction site. So this scanner was not expensive at all, it just takes a little leg work. Do you guys realize that the Adobe Acrobat XI bundled with this machine retails for $299? I didn't! That's probably why the machine is so expensive. Many are flipping the acrobat dvd for about $150. You don't need the acrobat xi to use this, unless you're a big fan of it, or need to have a bigger control of your PDF files, then I would sell it. For most people, home users, all you need is the organizer software that it came with and just downloand the free version of adobe reader, which 99% of you already have. Even without the various ways to reduce the cost of this scanner, would I pay over $400? Heck yeah!If you have a notebook without a DVD drive, then your set-up could take over an hour. You will need to download everything from their site. Initially, I was disappointed because I thought you could only wirelessly scan to your mobile and not your pc. But after a few updates, you'll be able to scan wirelessly to your pc as well. In terms of operation, it is so easy and so smooth. I had crinkled papers and it would never jam. Even thin receipts from years ago would be detected and never jammed. There is a learning curve for all the various ways you can scan. When you throw a batch of paper for it to scan, you can scan to 1 large multipage PDF, or tell it to generate separate pdf pages. You can also tell it to scan single or double sided. Unlike your all in one printers, the paper just goes through once and both sides have already been scanned, it's amazing! It is amazingly fast too! If you set it to the highest quality, it will be slow but still much faster than your all in one printers. But you really don't need the highest quality, you can set it to the second highest quality and it'll be super fast. When you're finish, you just close the lid, it'll automatically shut down. When you want to scan, open the lid, your pc will wireless detect it. Mobile scanning is a breeze too with their provided app which you can download at the play store. I've tried it and it's great, but I like the control of my pc, so I'm very happy that you can wireless scan to pc.You'll need to suck it up and just start organizing all that paper. The initial work will take a lot of effort because I'm sure you have years, if not decades worth of paper in boxes. But once you're caught up, then all future incoming papers can go straight to scanner and shredder. Just do them as they come, don't ever let them pile up again. And with the simplicity, convenience and speed of this scanner, I don't think papers piling up will ever be an issue again. Nobody enjoys using those all in one printers to scan. Mine is in the garage, so there was never any motivation and to think about how slow it would have taken, and the difficulties of duplex scanning.. forget about it!Lastly, a suggestion on how to go about scanning.... The wireless feature, whether to mobile or pc is not practical when you begin. It is only practical when you're all caught up. For example, lets say you're caught up, and you now only have to worry about incoming mail. You get your new auto insurance policy, and your scanner is in the kitchen, but your notebook is upstairs. It's okay, you just scan it and go shred the policy. When you have time, and you're next to your notebook, you can then rename it and put it in the proper folder. When you begin, you can't be running back and forth, your notebook should be right next to the scanner connected via usb for the fastest speed. You can then rename your files as you scan. I do not advise scanning everything to one folder, then going back to rename and organize later because you'll have to click on each pdf file to remind you what it was. That's not good strategy. Rename them as you scan them. I had my notebook connected via usb to the scanner in the middle of my bedroom floor. Files and boxes all around me, hefty trash bags for papers that can be tossed without shredding, and a pile for papers that will need to be shredded. But all the work has paid off, I'm caught up and now and my scanner can be placed anywhere. New papers coming in will be scanned wirelessly and tossed immediately. You will appreciate the extra space in your house, and how awesome it feels to locate a file in your notebook, instead of rummaging through your folders and boxes. This game changer now sits on my nightstand next to my bed. I'm also planning to archive our old photos, and will update this review on how scanning photos worked out (if I have time).Oh yeah, when you go paperless.. BACK UP YOUR HARD DRIVE!

Don't mess around with this if you know that there is a slight chance of hurting your back. Otherwise, it works very well. We broke our first one from a few years ago. We liked it so much we ordered another one. Very accurate. For those with strong arms, it'll be a cinch. For those not so strong, like me, if you don't mind looking like an idiot for a few seconds, then you'll be okay too. Because the faster you can hold the luggage steady (off the ground), the faster it will register. So as you can imagine, strong people will have no issues. There will be a little wobbling and shaking for the rest of us. LOL!

I was using a PVC trash frame variation, but it didn't hang on the edge of the table. So I was curious of this product. Nice! Glad i bought one. Not much to review, the pictures speak for themselves. Your trash bag will hang against the edge and you just slide you trash into it. We have outdoor parties from time to time using those long folding tables. These were perfect. I got mine at Lowes for less than $10. So look at your local hardware store before paying $19.45 + $9 shipping, that's highway robbery.10/27/2014 UPDATE:------------------I now own THREE of these! Love them. The first one I got was for less than $10 bucks at my Lowes, but I never had any luck finding it again. Whenever they drop on Amazon to about $15 with prime shipping, I would grab one. Highly recommended!

Our Sony Bravia actually has enough inputs, but they are on the side of the TV, so it looks ugly. Not only that, the HDMI input didn't play nicely with our new Tivo Roamio. You know when you select an input source, the screen would flicker and the HDMI input info would display. Well, it kept doing this recently even when we're not changing input. We thought it may have been faulty HDMI ports or cables. This switch box solved the problem! We thought we had to manage an extra remote now, not a big deal, but it turns out that the Kinivo brand is in the Harmony list of supported devices. When you go to add a device in your Harmony software, it is under AMPLIFIER - AUDIO/VIDEO SWITCH - KINIVO, then type in your model, 501BN.We also have a Chromecast connected to this. Our Tivo and Chromecast are never off and this box works fine. Not sure why some are reporting this doesn't work for Chromecast.

Terrific! Looks very neat. Fiberglass is thin, but what do you expect at this price. The decision to include a real rubber basketball is interesting. Because it's heavy and your rim and board will bang and clang. I think a soft nerf ball is more appropriate. Still 5 stars! I'll just go and buy a nerf ball at the equivalent size.

The 3.6v ZipSnip's main competitor is the Skil 2352-01 (3.6 volt) cutter, however, Skil has a newer version out! As of October 19, Lowes is the only place that carries the newer Skil 2352-02 (4.0 volt) version. Since the Rockwell Zipsnip has dropped down to $20, I picked up both for testing. $40 for the newer Skil Cutter and $20 for the Zipsnip. Here are the results...The Skil 4.0 has a no load rotational speed of 240 RPM, If someone can confirm via comments below what the 3.6 version is, that would be great. But I'm sure it will be 240 rpm also. The ZipSnip has a no load rotational speed of 260 RPM. You guys can find this info on the underside of the tool.ADVANTAGE ZIPSNIP (normal thickness): I tested the cutters with normal cardboard boxes that I get from shopping too much online from places like Amazon. Due to the larger rotational speed, the ZipSnip wins when you're cutting normal boxes with the usual thickness. The Skil cuts fine, but the ZipSnip was slightly zippier. I felt this way prior to knowing about the RPM speeds. I started looking for an explanation, so I looked for info on the underside of the tools, and it confirmed my feelings.ADVANTAGE SKIL 4.0 (unusually thick card-boards): So where would you feel the advantage of the extra voltage from Skil? The answer is when you're cutting thicker material. I folded a regular amazon shipping box to 3 layers. The ZipSnip would snag, and I would need to keep re-hitting the trigger to get it going again. With the Skil, it was also a strain, but the blades never ever snag, they keep spinning, and you just have to use your strength to cut through. Get the Skil if you work with thicker materials often.ADVANTAGE ZIPSNIP (GRIP): The grip on the Rockwell ZipSnip feels much better. Because the safety button is at the top where your thumb will naturally press it. Your other 4 fingers then presses the base trigger. You don't need to keep your thumb on the safety once you've pressed it, but like I said, the design is so logical, there is no where else for your thumb to go, so you'll end up not letting go of the safety button, which is okay. Or, your thumb will just slide to the side. The SKIL's layout is a bit strange. The safety switch is available on each side. I think it's design for both left and right handers and the intent is for you to use your index finger to press the button on the outer side, but you'll see, your finger length and the button placement will not be a perfect match, thus, sometimes I had to re-grip after pressing it.ADVANTAGE ZIPSNIP (PRICE): Right now the ZipSnip is only $20 and will stay there for a long time since Lowes shows that it will stay at that price for the rest of the year, so I'm certain Amazon will keep the price at $20 too. The only reason I could think of choosing Skil over Rockwell is because Skil is a Bosch company. Maybe their tools have better longevity? But at $20, you can buy a few ZipSnips and take care of that issue. You can also get replacement blades for the ZipSnip at $10 for 2, but once again at $20, why not just buy a few units. LOL!Lastly, people who give bad reviews for either one are simply expecting TOO MUCH. If you need to cut up cardboard boxes like the shipping boxes you get from shopping online like Amazon, then either cutters are sweet! I make and resize boxes and have been cutting with shears by Fiskars made specifically for cardboard. Those shears were great, but when you do as many as I do, your hands will start to feel it because you still need to add pressure. With these cutters, they go through like butter. People who want to zip through the thickest materials are expecting way too much. If you want that ability, then spend the money and buy the BOSCH PROFESSIONAL GUS 10.8V. You can find that cutter on Amazon United Kingdom. Using 10.8V batteries, that thing has a no load RPM of up to 700.

As of October 19, Lowes is the only place that carries the newer 2352-02 (4.0 volt) version. Since the Rockwell 3.6v Zipsnip has dropped down to $20, I picked that up as well. $40 for newer Skil Cutter and $20 for the Zipsnip. Here are the results...The Skil 4.0 has a no load rotational speed of 240 RPM, If someone can confirm via comments below what the 3.6 version is, that would be great. But I'm sure it will be 240 rpm also. The ZipSnip has a no load rotational speed of 260 RPM. You guys can find this info on the underside of the tool.ADVANTAGE ZIPSNIP (normal thickness): I tested the cutters with normal cardboard boxes that I get from shopping too much online from places like Amazon. Due to the larger rotational speed, the ZipSnip wins when you're cutting normal boxes with the usual thickness. The Skil cuts fine, but the ZipSnip was slightly zippier. I felt this way prior to knowing about the RPM speeds. I started looking for an explanation, so I looked for info on the underside of the tools, and it confirmed my feelings.ADVANTAGE SKIL 4.0 (unusually thick card-boards): So where would you feel the advantage of the extra voltage from Skil? The answer is when you're cutting thicker material. I folded a regular amazon shipping box to 3 layers. The ZipSnip would snag, and I would need to keep re-hitting the trigger to get it going again. With the Skil, it was also a strain, but the blades never ever snag, they keep spinning, and you just have to use your strength to cut through. Get the Skil if you work with thicker materials more often.ADVANTAGE ZIPSNIP (GRIP): The grip on the Rockwell ZipSnip feels much better. Because the safety button is at the top where your thumb will naturally press it. Your other 4 fingers then presses the base trigger. You don't need to keep your thumb on the safety once you've pressed it, but like I said, the design is so logical, there is no where else for your thumb to go, so you'll end up not letting go of the safety button, which is okay. Or, your thumb will just slide to the side. The SKIL's layout is a bit strange. The safety switch is available on each side. I think it's design for both left and right handers and the intent is for you to use your index finger to press the button on the outer side, but you'll see, your finger length and the button placement will not be a perfect match, thus, sometimes I had to re-grip after pressing it.ADVANTAGE ZIPSNIP (PRICE): Right now the ZipSnip is only $20 and will stay there for a long time since Lowes shows that it will stay at that price for the rest of the year, so I'm certain Amazon will keep the price at $20 too. The only reason I could think of choosing Skil over Rockwell is because Skil is a Bosch company. Maybe their tools have better longevity? But at $20, you can buy a few ZipSnips and take care of that issue. You can also get replacement blades for the ZipSnip at $10 for 2, but once again at $20, why not just buy a few units. LOL!Lastly, people who give bad reviews for either one are simply expecting TOO MUCH. If you need to cut up cardboard boxes like the shipping boxes you get from shopping online like Amazon, then either cutters are sweet! I make and resize boxes and have been cutting with shears by Fiskars made specifically for cardboard. Those shears were great, but when you do as many as I do, your hands will start to feel it because you still need to add pressure. With these cutters, they go through like butter. People who want to zip through the thickest materials are expecting way too much. If you want that ability, then spend the money and buy the BOSCH PROFESSIONAL GUS 10.8V. You can find that cutter on Amazon United Kingdom. Using 10.8V batteries, that thing has a no load RPM of up to 700.

Works, but you know the instructions actually recommend you use a power drill and a 1/8 bit if you have one, so I didn't even touch the hole puncher. My wife is too busy, so I don't have a set of helping hands, and believe me you'll need them. So I busted out my collection of clamps. I measured and cut the pieces I needed on my workbench holding down the plastic with clamps cause it will want to coil up. I also clamp them into place in the railings. When you have clamps holding down the plastic nice and securely, drilling holes will be much easier. Using the hole punch relegates you to punching holes near the edges, but using a power drill, you can make holes in the middle and add more zip ties for additional security.My most important advice would be to try and cover as much area as you can with one piece. Don't cut up sections just for the sake of cutting up sections. Cut only when you're forced to. The reason is because your baby will be very exploratory and when they can no longer grip the rails, they will soon bang on the plastic and their hands will ultimately find the seams or edge of the sections. These edges can be rough depending on how smooth your cutting skills are. If you have seams, I would tape it down with clear tape, making an ugly thing even more uglier. LOL! But safety of our babies come first! Actually, there is a way to hide the seams of two sections coming together, and that is to let them coil into the rails. The right side coils over, and the left section coils under just like locking your fingers together over and under.
