Writing mechanics were good in these stories, but I didn't enjoy the content. I grew up on a farm in a small rural community, so I was familiar with the settings and could relate on that level. Some of the family dynamics were similar to mine, so again, I could relate. However, I found the stories to be extremely slow, boring and flat. None of the characters really came to life for me and the stories did not hold my interest. I can't quite put my finger on it, but there was something lacking in the execution. For example, to paraphrase one author, she says that they had to walk through an area covered in cow patties to get to and from the watermelon patch. She goes on to tell the reader what her grandfather called the cow patties and how they had to spend a lot of time cleaning their shoes if they stepped in the manure. I know this book is a memoir/anecdotal style work, but the "I did this and I did that, and this person said this or that person said that, or they did this or they did that, and that is what happened next" method of writing the stories did not work for me. The authors told us what they saw or did, but they put nothing of themselves in the stories.Others will quite likely disagree with my assessment, and I am not trying to be mean-spirited with my review; believe it or not, I am trying to be constructive. Bottom line is that I really did not like this book and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

This is a well written romantic suspense book that was fairly entertaining. I had no trouble putting it down to do something else, but I did enjoy it.The hero, Michael, has been hired to find the heroine, Elisabeth/Lily, by her psychopath husband. This is a romance book, so of course Michael and Lily fall in love with each other and get their HEA. Both were likeable characters, but as they were written, Michael carrried the angst to extremes and both Lily and Michael has moments of less than stellar intelligence. For example, they know the husband and his goons are looking for them, but do they hunker down and use room service until it is time to escape? You guessed it! No, they opted for wandering around out in the open and going to restaurants. Hello, has anyone heard of pizza delivery? There were other instances like this, where the reader had those "you must be kidding me" moments. Despite this, their characterization was executed well enough that they remained appealing characters. It was just that with a bit of tweaking, they could have been so much more than they were.The husband was a well written, slightly over-the-top villain, who almost stole the show. Definitely evil personified. The young son was a cute, appealing character, and other secondary characters were brought to life by the author's descriptive writing.  Although the restaurant employees, the costumer, Lily's grandmother's friend and one of the minions were minor characters, they were fleshed out with enough detail and personality, that they were not cardboard or one-dimensional characters.The plot about Lily trying to save her son and to escape from the psychotic husband was a good one, and it held my interest. The author presented multiple points of view, which was an effective technique. The reader could share the thoughts of the heroine, hero, and villain, as well as those of one of the minions. In addition, the author alternated scenes between the central characters, so the reader had a sense of the events happening in conjunction with each other and this made it feel more realistic. The plot could have used a little tweaking also, but overall, it held together and engaged me.This was a very good book for curling up with to pass the time, and it was enjoyable. The author writes well, but this book was a little disappointing. Although it was a good book, it wouldn't have taken much to be even better. The framework was there, and most of it was filled in, but there were a few skimpily covered areas that made it feel patchy.Despite some flaws, I do recommend this book to anyone who wants a light, entertaining read. The Mira imprint's romantic suspense books are usually not as heavy and dark as mainstream suspense or thriller books, and this book follows that pattern; it entertains without a lot of highly graphic violence. There are some mildly graphic sex scenes, a couple accompanied with some violence by the husband, but these didn't go into much detail. It was more of a PG rated read than an R rated one.There was one annoying formatting problem. When the story moved between scenes, there was no marking of the division. For example, the reader would be in a scene with the hero and heroine, then the husband would be talking to his minions and the reader would have a few seconds of disconnect until the transition was made. Once the pattern was understood, it wasn't really a problem, but it still should be corrected.Recommend.

I loved some of the author's other work, but I didn't really care for this book. It was well written with no problems in editing. The plot had an interesting premise but the execution didn't hold my interest. Overall, I liked the characters, some more than others. There were a few times when the heroine was more disagreeable and whiney than I like my heroines to be; I understood that the author was writing the character that way, in order to convey how much the heroine was devestated by all of the events and revelations she experienced. It was a contrast with the heroine's normally caring personality and the heroine was usually a presented in a positive light. I couldn't seem to warm up to her, though.I had trouble sticking with this book. I finished the book, but it was easy to put down and reading it felt like a chore. There really wasn't anything overtly bad about the book. It felt a bit slow and flat to me, because the execution was uneven. There were periods of sparkling dialogue, followed by, what were to me, dry boring conversations and internal thoughts.I admit that straightforward contemporary romance is not my favourite genre and I am very picky about it. There are a number of very popular, famous award-winning authors with large followings, whose contemporary romances I dislike. So my review should be viewed in that light, and anyone who is uncertain, can check some of my other reviews to see if our tastes are alike or not. Readers who love contemporary romances may really like this book. On a personal level, I would rate this book one or two stars, but I realize that would be unfair to the author, so I compromised with three stars.For those who care, the book has some mild sex scenes. It is definitely not erotica, but the porn patrol might want to give it a miss.I recommend this book with reservations. It is one of those books that will definitely have an appreciative audience, but it will also have readers who would be bored to tears with it.

Normally, I am not fond of straightforward contemporary romances, but there are a few authors on my 'automatic buy' list. Sharon Sala is on that short list and she always delivers. This book is no exception to her high quality work; it is well written, entertaining, kept me engaged and left me with a 'feel good' reaction at its conclusion.I'm not repeating the synopsis, as others have covered that in their reviews. This is a stand alone book in a series centred around the small town of Blessings, Georgia and Ruby's 'Curl Up and Dye hair salon, where all the gossip eventually finds its way. Some characters have recurring roles but the plots focus on new characters who are introduced in each volume. Since I started this series at the beginning, I can't say if subsequent volumes leave new readers confused by the number of characters. Obviously some reviewers thought this was a problem, but I tried to view this book objectively, and I honestly don't think I would have been lost if I started with it. This is an element that may or may not be an issue for some readers, then. I felt the number of characters was necessary in order to create the setting and character of the town. We see the pharmacist, doctor, police officers, bartenders waitresses, cooks, day care operator, teachers, lawyers, minister, neighbours, friends, local characters, good ole boys, and of course, the women working in or patronizing beauty salon. Sala paints the town so vividly, that one can visualize the main street and its shops, the townspeople, various neighbourhoods and the rural areas surrounding the town.  To me, Sala brought the town to life and made it pivotal to the series, as much a lead character as any human character. I loved it and found myself wishing I could visit it.Some reviewers felt that the book did seem like a stand alone book to them. One reason was that characters and events that were in previous books were referred to, which left them a bit lost. The other was the teaser chapter at the end. In any series, there are going to be allusions to previous characters and events. That is the nature of a series and why most readers like well done ones, and think this is a well done series. Sala gives enough information to give backstory without boring readers who follow the series. Other writers, such as J.D. Robb/Nora Roberts employ this same technique. If readers picks up a book in the middle of a series, they are not going to get every nuance of the backstory, but should have enough information to follow the particular volume they are reading. I think Sala accomplishes that.As for the teaser chapter, that is also common practice and is not cheating by the author. I loathe cliffhangers, but a teaser chapter is not at all the same. This story line ended and the book was completed with no loose threads. I actually enjoy teaser chapters because they give me a hint about where the author plans to take the next book. However, those who hate books with a teaser chapter will be unhappy that this book has one.There is profanity in this book and readers who don't read books with profanity should avoid it. They will be missing out on a great book, but that is their choice. To me, a woman in her mid-sixties, it wasn't anything I haven't been hearing or reading for years. I don't agree with those who think it means the writer is lazy for not finding other ways to convey the emotions or habits of characters. The language was not gratuitous, but was suitable to the characters and their situations. I regularly see elementary kids using the "f" bomb. It has lost any shock value it ever had, and it would be ludicrous to not expect characters in contemporary non-Christian fiction to use it.There is one fairly innocuous graphic sex scene on the hero's and heroine's wedding night. It won't make either the 'no sex' or the 'hot sex' camp happy. The rest of us will likely enjoy it.This was a 'feel good' book that focuses on the underdogs and their trials before the happily ever after. Sala doesn't write Christian fiction, but there are often references to God, church attendance, prayers, belief and faith, but she is never 'preachy'. This book contains those references, but she points out that church attendance does not make one a Christian or a good person. Some characters who attend regularly are hypocrites who don't act out their purported beliefs, and do harm to others by their inaction and their overt actions of hurtful gossiping, snide comments, and 'holier than thou' attitudes. She balances this with characters who do act out their faith and give help and encouragement.Sala also addresses the subject of bullying and how some schools turn a blind eye to it. As well she points out that the class divisions between the haves and have nots, often influence how authority figures treat people. As with religion, Sala balances criticism with examples of authority figures who are not influenced by anything except a person's character and actions. Sala often make a point to show examples of injustice, but she is never heavy handed. With Sala's books, I always feel entertained by a good story but am also left with food for thought.Was the plot totally realistic? Not really, but there is realism in it. This book reads and ends the way readers of romance books want in their books. We want the underdog to succeed, we want the villains punished and we want a happily ever after. Many readers don't experience that in real life, but they want the hope and the fantasy when they pick up a romance book. Sala delivers that in this book. It is an easy, light read that is still compelling; it pulls the reader in and keeps the pages turning, long after the lights should have been turned off. I highly recommend it.

I have this book in paperback and liked it a lot. I was glad to see that it was available on Kindle and happily replaced my paperback. This is a well written rainy day or beach type of read. It wouldn't go in my desert island pile, but it is a solid, enjoyable book.As the synopsis says, the heroine is a psychic and the hero is a homicide detective. They are likeable characters, but as another reviewer said, the book was light on the romance. There was no real passion, and by that, I don't mean sex. I felt as if the love was a bit lukewarm. The author actually voiced the problem. In one scene, the hero's mother is contemplating his relationship with the heroine, and she was concerned that the heroine was so self-contained that the passion needed for a relationship was missing. Then she saw the passion in the heroine's photography, and was relieved. The problem for the reader is that we need to see it expressed between the hero and the heroine, and not in the heroine's work. So the romance was a bit flat, but it was pleasant.The writer almost seemed to be setting the scene for sequels. Instead of putting more focus on the romance between the heroine and hero, she hinted at the possibility of a romance between the hero's brother and a family friend. She actually did include a side romance between the hero's sister and a family friend. They were all nice characters and their inclusion added to the reader's understanding of the hero and heroine. I liked having them present, but they diluted the central romance.The mystery/suspense part of the book was stronger than the romance. As one reviewer said, this was not a thrilling story, but it was still entertaining and it engaged me. I easily guessed who the villainess was, but that didn't matter. The entire journey from start to finish was what was important. I reread books I have enjoyed, because it doesn't matter if I know the ending, as long as the writer offers a worthwhile story that takes me on a journey to another place. I never understand readers who feel a book is spoiled if they know who the villain is or know the ending. Descriptive prose, well written characterizations, dialogue, setting and plot are what attracts me to a book. This book was well written and held my interest, even beyond my first reading of it.I recommend this book to anyone wanting a pleasant, simple, entertaining story with a bit of romance and a bit of suspense. It has some mild sex scenes, but they are a minor part of the book. Anyone wanting a one hundred percent clean read will want to avoid it. Anyone wanting a lot of hot sex and a fast paced, breathtaking thriller would probably be disappointed in this book.  It is simply an undemanding book that is perfect for when ones to relax and curl up with a good book. I definitely recommend it.

My old copy of this book came up missing years ago, so I was happy to see it available as a Kindle book. I wondered how it would have aged, but I thoroughly enjoyed rereading it, after almost fifty years.This book was written in a simpler time, when books in this genre were not so graphic when it came to sex and violence. Consequently, this book might seem "tame" to anyone expecting a modern thriller. This is a fairly slow paced book that has a lot of philosophizing about the political situation of the immediate pre-WWII era, mixed in with a light spy story. This book was written not long after WWII ended, when events were fresh in everyone's mind. As a result, it gives a sense of how some, British, Germans and Americans viewed this era, which is as interesting as the story itself.MacInnes hits upon some key features. She depicts the previously close relationship between some German and British intellectuals, as a result of intermingling at universities. She shows how hard line political stances undermine this previous camaraderie and makes enemies of former friends. As well, she illustrates popular attitudes about Appeasement and the consequences of it, and attitudes about the influence of capitalists on this political policy. We see the general air of fear and uncertainty about the possibility of war, in both Britain and Europe; we see the British contempt for all aspects of Nazism and for those who blindly succumb to its lure; we see British frustration that the American public doesn't understand what is actually happening in Europe; we see German and other Europeans who hate what is happening and are fearful; we see allusions to how Jews, Slavs, trade unionists, communists and critics of the Third Reich are being rounded up. All of these are incorporated into the setting and plot, in a superficial but still enlightening way.This book isn't "War and Peace" but it is a nice little spy story that is reflective of an era with different gender roles, slow communications, totalitarian politics, and people raised in a world vastly different from that of today. If a reader expects a pulse-pounding thriller with non-stop action, sex and graphic violence, this is not the book to choose. For those willing to accept a slower pace in order to get a feel for the times, while receiving a nice yarn, this would be a good choice.  Recommended.

This book is an excellent addition to the "In Death" series. Several books back, I was beginning to get bored with the repetitious backstory, and then Roberts started making the backstory much briefer. This book continues that trend, with a succinct backstory that informs newbie readers without boring the rest of us. That was definitely a plus for me.As the cast of characters grew, Roberts initially tried to include everyone in each story. It became unwieldy after a while and interfered with the flow of the plots. Eventually, the inclusion of supporting characters sometimes seemed added just for the sake of adding them, rather than because they were essential to the story. It was wonderful seeing Roberts create a circle of friends and family for Eve and Roarke and I love these supporting characters; however, it is counterproductive to have all of them included in every book. Roberts began to focus more on the core law enforcement group, as she did in this book. There were allusions to the missing characters and Roberts was skillful at catching us up with them without having them stop the momentum of the story. This was another plus for me.The relationship between Eve and Roarke continues to evolve in this book. Roberts maintains Eve's "kick ass" attitude, sarcasm, bewilderment with idioms, and aversion to all things rural and cute. She is still very much the Eve we love, but she has become softer and more confident in her relationship with Roarke. In this book, the balance is just right; Eve still has her hard edge when it comes to law enforcement, but the interaction with Roarke has more give and take as she learns to be part of a couple. As well, the sex scenes seem more like lovemaking than the aggressive battle they often were in previous books. I used to skip the sex scenes because I wasn't fond of Roberts' approach, but in this book and in the last few, I actually read and enjoyed those bits.The supporting characters were very well written, and it was a pleasure to see Eve's law enforcement colleagues in action. Roberts continues to develop these characters and to bring them to life. Peabody is more self-confident in her job and relationship with Eve, although she still has the occasional lapse into self-doubt. Trueheart is coming along nicely and is ready to become a detective. He is still a bit nave but very competent. We see more of Baxter and learn more about his personality. He has been mentoring Trueheart and is more anxious about Trueheart taking the detectives' exam than Trueheart is. We knew Baxter was cocky and brash, but now we see another side of him. The rest of the gang were treated similarly, and we see them in more depth. I like that Roberts included fewer characters in this book but developed them more than she could if she were throwing in every single friend and colleague of Eve's and Roarke's.The plot of this book was superb. Roberts did something a bit different in this book and borrowed from authors like R. Austin Freeman and from shows like Columbo. We know who committed the murders and we are given full access to the murderers. We know their background, what they look like, their motivation, their modus operandi, their thoughts, and we see them committing some of their crimes. It is up to Eve, Roarke and the team to figure out "who dunnit", "how they dunnit", and where they are. Some reviewers disliked this pattern, but it made for a refreshing change. Like a lot of readers, I want a certain predictability from my favourite authors, but not so much that the writing becomes stale. Roberts hit it just right with this one.One reviewer said this book was too much like a police procedural, as if that is a new and bad thing, and further said that the character development and familiar characters were missing. I've already commented on the character development and inclusion of characters, so I will address the reviewer's comment about the police procedural. I think these books have always been police procedurals, accompanied by strong characterizations. The previous books took us from a murder to the hunt for the killer, to the capture of the killer. This book had a different starting point, but it still involved the search for a killer. The uniformed officers on the ground, the detectives, the medical and forensics people, the electronics division, the psychological profiling, the police hierarchy and the d.a. all played a role in this book, as they have in the others. The presence or absence of Mavis and Bella do not determine whether or not these books are police procedurals. It was refreshing to have a greater focus on fewer characters, which strengthened the plot of this particular addition to the series.A few reviewers thought this book was especially violent. I didn't think it was any more violent than some of the other "In Death" books. Roberts was very effective in creating great sympathy for the victims and their families in this book. It was masterful writing in the sense that she made these people real and made the reader connect with them. When I finished the book, the victims continued to resonate with me and I still felt for them. Similarly, Roberts created truly despicable villains and brought the reader face to face with pure evil. This book was very affecting and suspenseful, but it didn't give me nightmares. People react differently to situations, though, and this book might be too violent for some readers. I found it made me think about crime, criminals and the victims of crime. As well, it made me think about the police officers who deal with the worst situations imaginable. The book was funny, suspenseful, violent, tender and thought-provoking, all at once.My husband and I both read this book from the library, in one sitting and couldn't put it down until we finished it. We have all of the other J.D. Robb books and have reread them more than once. We both loved this one and think it is easily among her best. As soon as the Kindle price reaches paperback price, we will be buying it. Highly recommended.

This book is a bit of a departure from the author's other work. She usually has few to no sex scenes in her books, although some have strong sexual tension. This book had a lot of sexual tension and a lot of sexual content. I almost gave the book four stars because it had more sexual content than I like, but the book was so good that I had to give it five stars. The opening battle scene grabbed my attention and I couldn't stop reading the book; I was hooked. The world building on both the research station and the rebels' planet was well done, so graphically depicted that it was easy to visualize the setting and to feel drawn into the action taking place. The writing is deceptive; it looks like a simple straightforward narrative, and then you realize how carefully the words are usually chosen and placed, so as to have the most impact. The reader sees, hears, smells and feels everything taking place, which is not an easy thing to create. As well, the book was very fast paced but didn't feel rushed.Tamryn is a strong heroine and Makk is an adorable alpha hero. One reviewer commented that it was difficult to see Makk as a hero because of what he did in battle. I think part of the problem is the author's choice in calling the attackers "terrorists". That word has negative connotations, and as another reviewer pointed out, Makk's crew could be considered rebels. Using the word "rebels" puts the attack in a different light and gives their cause legitimacy. Regardless, Makk has morals and acts with honour, especially considering that he is fighting for the lives of his people, people who have been all but annihilated by the ancestors of those they are attacking. There is a lot of sexual tension between Tamryn and Makk, as they fight each other and the attraction they feel, since they are enemies.What makes Makk endearing is his humility and his inner dialogue. He is instantly smitten by Tamryn, as in figuratively pole axed and swept off his feet. He doesn't know what hit him. His amusing inner thoughts about his reactions to both Tamryn and his unruly, uncooperative penis, as well as his goofy smiles whenever she tries to best him or kill him, and his little-boy-look hurt feelings, all combine to make him an engaging hero. Tamryn is his worthy match as a heroine. She is not his equal physically, but she holds her own against him, sometimes bests him, and never stops trying to outwit him, even as she falls in love with him.I loved the way the sex scenes were written, erotic but not erotica. However, I felt there was too much space devoted to them. A little bit less would have been perfect.I loved this book and couldn't put it down. It held my interest from beginning to end. The author has tackled a variety of genres, from clean reads to sensuous ones, fantasy, science fiction, steampunk, futuristic romance and contemporary fiction. She hasn't let me down, and continues to put out first-rate work. Highly recommend this book.

I had a paper copy of this book, purchased elsewhere. If this book were in another category, I would say it was well written, but too depressing to read, and I love depressing 19th century Russian literature. Frankly, this book made me sick, stomach-churning sick.***********************************SPOILERS****************************Early in the book, we have the graphic gang rape of the hero. The heroine rescues him afterwards, and we learn about his bleeding rectal area, with semen dripping down, and about his weeks of anal pain as the heroine tends to him. The heroine has been raped by the same people and there are descriptions of her continuing angst about it. The hero is suicidal and ashamed, the heroine is also suffering emotionally, and this is still very early in the book. It doesn't get any better.This was the bleakest, darkest book I have ever read; I can't believe it won romance awards. There are arguments that the author depicted the era realistically and that it is wonderful that she broke out of the box to do so. Excuse me! Wonderful in an historical romance is not having anachronisms; it is trying to give the flavour of the times while creating a feel-good romance. ROMANCE. Not all of the horrible, realism of the times. If I want realism, I wouldn't be choosing a romance book.I don't care how many experts and literary critics call this book a romance; just because everyone admires the emperor's new clothes does not mean he is actually wearing anything. This is not a romance book and any unsuspecting readers who pick it up expecting a traditional romance will be sorely disappointed.If readers want graphic realism, complete with gang rapes and unimaginable suffering, then they might like this book. For anyone else who just wants a well written, pleasant romance book, prepare to be shocked if you pick this book up.Not recommended.

This wasn't one of the better books by Ms. Thompson. I picked it up and put it down several times, read something else in-between, and finally forced myself to finish it. Writing mechanics were good, but I did notice the same formatting that others described, where there were no spaces between shifts. It didn't bother me once I got used to it.I found the book to be flat, dull and slow. There was a lot of action, as other reviewers stated, so the book should have been fast paced and exciting, except it wasn't. Even the dialogue felt dull, forced and stiff. Ruby and Sam were nice, but flatly drawn and not memorable. Ruby's sister, Misty, was portrayed as so smart and level headed, but in the book, she did some truly brainless things. The author intends the town and some characters to be part of a series; to provide the groundwork, she devotes a lot of time to Justine, the sheriff, and her autistic son. I felt these really dragged the central action to a slow crawl. The story never engaged me and held my interest, and I didn't warm to any of the characters, except for Sam. Even the children did not endear themselves to me.I didn't hate the book, and I can see why others loved it. I am in the minority, but I didn't like this book.  I wouldn't recommend it, so I suggest readers try a sample or get it from the library first. You may disagree with me and love it.

This is an exceptionally good, outstanding compilation. I was only familiar with a few of the authors, but this was a good introduction to the others; I will definitely be checking out more works by them.As it says in the description, this compilation has of a variety of romance sub genres. Some of these are contemporary, historical, futuristic, fantasy, and paranormal with ghosts. I like all of these sub genres, so I was happy to have a bit of each. Surprisingly, given the diversity of sub genres, they all fit well together and I never had the sense of being jarred when moving from one to the next.Each author had a very strong entry. Plots, setting, characterization, and dialogue were very well done. In very little space, the authors created worlds and well developed characters that were easy to visualize. The heroes and heroines were very likeable, with strong heroes who are physically or emotionally wounded. Some heroines have also experienced trauma, but each couple finds strength and healing through the love and support of their partner.A couple of the stories ended a bit abruptly, but with conclusions that suggested there was a happily ever after. I would have liked a little epilogue for these stories, but it wasn't really necessary. None of the stories had cliffhangers and any that were part of a series were easy to follow and never made me feel lost or as if I was missing something from the story.  ******SPOILER ALERT / CONTENT WARNING ******I normally like Rebecca York's books but I didn't enjoy her story as much as the others. I had reservations about it because of the heroine's rape by four soldiers. It was done 'off screen', but the hero was moved to tears when she told him about all they had done to her. It wasn't graphic and the reader isn't given any of the details, but it was still darker than I like for a romance book.The sex scenes ranged from none to infrequent mild encounters. When there was a sex scene, it fit into the flow of the story and didn't seem intrusive or too long. There was also some mild cussing. To me, the stories were almost clean, even with the sex and swearing. These stories were character driven and not simply vehicles for hot sex scenes.I highly recommend this book to anyone who likes these sub genres or who wants to try out stories by some unfamiliar authors. With some compilations, the reader is lucky to have a few good stories, but these are all first rate.

I'm in the minority right now, but I hated this book. I have almost all of Alexandra Ivy's and Rebecca Zanetti's books, so I expected to love their stories. I wasn't familiar with Duvall's or Jayne's work, but I thought that since the book had two familiar authors' stories, it was worth trying. Unfortunately, it was not a happy purchase.  ********POSSIBLE SPOILERS********Ivy's story involved a Sentinal, Mika, and a healer, Bailey. They had been engaged, but Bailey got cold feet and bailed out. (I know, that was a cheap shot.) To continue, though, it is several years after the separation and they reconnect when Mika is on a case, tracking someone down. I hated Bailey. She walked out on Mika without a word, just packed up and moved home, because she wanted to see if he loved her enough to come after her. Talk about cruel and immature. Her excuses and apology were too little, too late in my opinion. However, this is a romance book, so Mika forgives her.Bailey's immaturity continued to grate throughout the story. She hated routine and authority to the point where stubbornness overrode common sense. She reminded me of a small child sticking her tongue out at the adults frantically yelling at her to come away from the road as she continues to blithely back into traffic. Mentally, I had her saying things like "I don't have to, you can't make me, I'm not going to so there, I can do it myself", as she thrashes around on the floor having a temper tantrum. Did I mention that I hated her? Why do authors create heroines who are not only self-centred, but too stupid live? Anyway, the story line itself and the rest of the characterization were excellent. I would read more from this series, as long as it doesn't contain more Baileyesque heroines.Zanetti's story had immediate closure, but an overarching story line that continues the series; at least I think it continues. The ending reminded me a bit of a Twilight Zone episode, where it is implied that more continues off-screen; it didn't feel complete, but it was an acceptable ending. The problem I had with this story was the huge amount of sex scenes---too long and too many.  I found myself skimming through a lot of pages in order to return to the story. The story suffered for this, because there wasn't enough room left in the novella length to develop the story and characterization. What there was of the plot and characterization was great and I would have liked more details. I might try more books in this series, but I wouldn't purchase any more until I had a chance to read one for free to see if I liked it. (As an aside, I read Zanetti's other series free from Kindle Unlimited and loved the books. I bought all of them so I could have them to reread. They had borderline too much sex, but the stories were so well written that I decided that I could live with having to skip those scenes.)Duvall's story also devoted too much space to sex and not enough to plot and characterization. Like Zanetti's story, it had a great concept but the balance between sex and story was uneven. The hero and heroine were very likeable and the concept was great. I liked what I saw of the Immortals and would like to see more of them. This story had immediate closure with an overarching story line, that engaged me and left me wanting more. I just wish there had been more story and less sex. In a longer work, the author can get away with a bit too much sex, but in a novella, there isn't room to have a lot of sex and still develop the story as well as it could be.Jayne's story didn't seem to fit into the anthology. It was more lighthearted and was a clean read. If it were a mystery, I think it would be in the sub genre of cosy. I didn't mind that it wasn't a perfect fit, but I did mind that the romance was almost nonexistent. Nina, the vampire heroine, and Pike, the bird shapeshifter hero, were likeable but there was very little chemistry and no declaration of love until near the conclusion. As well, I wasn't entirely happy with the world building. Maybe this was because the novella length made it difficult for the author to depict her world, but for whatever reason, I couldn't see enough of it to form an opinion. Everything skimmed along the surface and didn't go deeply enough to let the reader in. I wouldn't go out of my way to read more of this series because it didn't engage me and I was a bit bored with it. The author writes well, and for those who like this style, it might be worth trying.Conclusion: One story had an acceptable amount of sex, two had too much sex, and one was clean. One had an obnoxious heroine, three had likeable heroines and all four had likeable heros. None of the stories was as well developed as I would have liked, but none of them had cliffhangers. The stories had good writing mechanics, and other than my complaints above, were very well written.I'm giving the book three stars, although it was a one star book for me. I just didn't enjoy it, but I can see its positive points. I wouldn't recommend this book to anyone who has reading tastes very similar to mine. Readers who are more into paranormal romances with a lot of sensuous sex scenes might like the first three stories. It's not erotica although it is explicit, which I like, but in smaller quantities. Anyone  who only likes clean books will hate it, even though one story is clean.

I first read this book in the late 1960s, and I thought it was hilarious. The movie reinforced my view of this book as a humorous work. Upon rereading it today, I found that it was satirical, had a few chuckles, but was not what I would consider to be humorous.Others have given the synopsis, so I see no need to rehash it. The premise of a small country declaring war on the US in order to receive rehabilitation, as in post-war Germany, was amusing. Ultimately, though, the bits of humour were wrapped around the serious subject of the superpowers, nuclear capabilities, weapons of mass destruction and disarmament. Sure, there were smiles, but the author was trying to make a point about his views on the Cold War and the 1950s diplomatic, political and military establishments, on both the left and right political spectrum. He uses the satire in the story to make the point that ordinary people are forgotten by both political sides of the Cold War, and indeed, in any situation where the elites and power brokers are determining policies.There were a couple of places where the book seemed dated, but overall, it still seemed relevant and timely. However, it also evoked feelings of sadness. We are presented with Mr. Wibberley's wishful vision of how to ensure that there is a balance of power that gets rid of weapons of mass destruction and ensures peace. He wants, and presents to the reader, a world where ordinary citizens can live their lives without the fear of destruction being unleashed by politicians who have lost their moral compass and common sense. One of the drawbacks of aging, though, is that one has "been there, done that ". Since reading this book the first time, I have seen wars in the near, far, and Middle East, as well as other places, too numerous to mention. There have been countless terrorist attacks. There is nuclear proliferation with nuclear weapons in both democratic and totalitarian regimes, and enough unbalanced rulers who aren't afraid to use them if or when they feel it is warranted. Germ and chemical warfare are still in use in some places. The Cold War is supposed to be over, but Russia is edging into former Soviet satellite countries. The old "duck and cover" is a quaint concept of the past, because we know how useless it is. Polarization is replacing co-operation, and there are those who would tear down a society, regardless of the consequences, rather than reach a win-win compromise. We are inured to most of what's going on and don't even get anxious about most of the issues anymore. In some ways, then, this book was a depressing reminder of how little politics and diplomacy have changed for the better, and of how precarious are the lives of ordinary citizens, as political parties and countries vie for one-upmanship and ordinary people are their pawns.This was a very well written book and the satire was brilliantly done. It captures a moment in time, in the 1950s, giving a glimpse of the post-WWII/Cold War era. A number of reviewers found this book to be hilarious, so maybe it can be read as a humorous book; I couldn't read it that way. Once I adjusted my expectations, I saw humorous elements, but I read it as a political and social satire.I highly recommend this book, with the caveat that some people will not find it all that funny. Accept it for what it is, with no preconceptions about its humour, and it should be a very satisfying read, that gives some laughs, but also forces one to think. The humour is used to make the author's message palatable, but he demands that the reader dig beneath the surface to discover and reflect upon his underlying message.

This book had a number of positives, but ultimately, it was an unsatisfying read. I liked the plot, but the pacing was too slow. The story bogged down in places and there was a lot of repetition that didn't further the plot. For example, the heroine, Lily, had slow scenes where she vacillated about whether or not the hero, Tierney, was the killer. These scenes should have built tension and quickened the pace, but instead, they seemed oddly slow and flat. Scenes with Lily and Tierney, that took place at the cabin, were also slow and dull. Too often the narrative concentrated on how cold it was, what Lily and Tierney needed to do to keep warm and hydrated, the frequent forays necessary to get wood and medication, and Lily's asthma symptoms. It focused on the mundane rather than building on characterization. Yes, Lily talked about her daughter and her marriage to Dutch, but she felt remote when talking about it and Tierney never did communicate in the cabin scenes. Consequently, it was difficult to establish any rapport with the hero and heroine, until the end. As well, Dutch's and Wes' scenes, where they expressed anxiousness to get up the mountain and those scenes of their efforts to do so, were repetitious and ineffective at creating urgency and tension.I don't like too much sex in my romance books, so I was surprised when other reviewers felt the book had an excessive amount of sex, because I didn't think it did. Because this was a romantic suspense book, I found the supporting characters' sex scenes between teachers and students over eighteen to be acceptable for that genre. In a straightforward romance, it wouldn't fit, but this genre is usually a bit grittier. I found the depiction of the student/teacher sex scenes to be well written. The author managed to convey that it does harm, even though it is technically legal, and she was able to portray the ambivalence that a lot of people have about it. In addition, I don't like 'forced seduction' scenarios in romance books, and there weren't any; the rape fantasy is apparently popular, though, so I was not bothered by its inclusion. The book was certainly not pornograhic, in my opinion. I don't think the sex scenes were hot enough for readers who want erotica, but they will probably offend those who want a clean read.I was ambivalent about this book. I liked it enough to replace my paperback with a Kindle edition when it was on sale. I liked how the author brought the supporting characters to life; they were well written and I actually felt more of a connection with these secondary characters. I liked some aspects of the hero and heroine, but disliked others, and ultimately could not really connect with them. I liked the idea of the plot a lot but wasn't entirely happy with the execution. I was disappointed with this book, but Sandra Brown writes very well, so even though it was disappointing, I still enjoyed it.I would not recommend this book as the place to start for readers who aren't familiar with Sandra Brown's writing. I would recommend it to her fans, especially for those times when a reader is looking for an easy read and understands that it isn't her best work but is still a good way to pass the time. I would have given this book two and a half stars, but rounded it up to three.

I admit that this book has major plot holes, but I loved it anyway. It is a book where the reader definitely has to suspend disbelief, but for readers who can do that, it was a great read.As is usual in a book by Sandra Brown, the quality of the writing was excellent. In addition to good writing mechanics, she brings her settings and characters vividly to life. I noticed that some reviewers complained that she used words that were 'too big'. Ms. Brown's writing is definitely not 'high-brow' or academic, but neither does it contribute to the dumbing down of the English language. Ms. Brown is writing popular fiction for adults and she uses words that are in common usage among average, ordinary adults. If any writer uses an unfamiliar word, one can easily find the meaning in a dictionary, thereby improving one's own command of the English language. Kindle books even have a built-in dictionary that is simple to use. My own mother and father were functionally illiterate and my brother has dyslexia, so I know some people genuinely struggle to read anything. For those of us who have no learning disability, laziness is the only reason Ms. Brown's writing might seem too pretentious and difficult to understand.**********Possible Spoilers**********Other reviewers have mentioned some of the holes in the plot, and they are glaring. Gillian goes home after her date with Chief, her sister is sleeping in her bed, so she drives to her sister's house to sleep. Gillian has a guest room with a made-up bed, so why is her sister sleeping in her bed? Why does Gillian drive to her sister's house to sleep, when her own house has a perfectly good guest bed and a sofa to sleep on?  As well, the original deception about identity makes sense; someone killed 'Gillian', so why admit to being 'Gillian'? However, there was no good reason to continue deceiving Chief because she knew he was not the killer and he was helping her to find the killer. These two scenarios were central to the main plot, but they didn't make sense. I rolled my eyes, but I suspended disbelief and continued reading, because I was hooked from the beginning. I simply ignored those plot holes and loved the rest of the story.This book has an 'instant attraction and love' romance, which I liked very much. The hero and heroine were so attracted to each other that they even made love on their first date. Readers who dislike that scenario will likely find it objectionable, but I found it to be very romantic.This is a romantic suspense book, so I don't expect it to be a thriller, like a straightforward mystery or suspense book. Still, the murder plot and conspiracy were suspenseful enough for the genre and held my interest.All of the principal characters were well drawn. The hero and heroine were shown to be flawed, but still very likeable. The central villains were fleshed out and easy to visualize; the main antagonist was depicted as someone truly amoral, villainous and easy to hate. The central police officers were also fleshed out enough to be interesting and more than one-dimensional characters.I enjoyed this book, warts and all. It was an easy, engaging read, that held my interest. I liked it enough that I have read it more than once, and I replaced my paperback with the Kindle version. I highly recommend this book to anyone who wants a pleasurable read and isn't bothered by plot holes, so long as the rest of the book is entertaining. Not everyone will like it; it wasn't Sandra Brown's best book, but it still kept me entertained.

(Review by Ann's husband, Dirk; Canadian Forces vet, '69-77)  The author's writing is detailed, interesting and so readable I could not wait for a chance to get back into the book.  The author puts you right there: in meetings of opposing factions, behind the scenes, and in the dust and chaos of thee house to house fights with the individuals in the fight for Fallujah.  The author describes the personalities and motivations of the key participants, and makes the religious and cultural issues clear and interesting.  This is the book to which all others about the Iraqi war will be compared.  In my opinion, this will be the seminal work about the battle and background to the events in Iraq concerning Fallugjah.

I am replacing my paperback Agatha Christie books with Kindle versions, so when I see that one is on sale, I snag it. When I saw this one, my finger was all set to hit the one-click button, when I noticed the name 'Sophie Hannah' in very small print at the bottom of the cover. The name 'Agatha Christie' was prominently displayed at the top of the cover, in extremely large letters that mimicked the font and style of actual Christie book covers, so it is no wonder I was misled. Was this a deliberate marketing ploy? Mais, oui. Yes, methinks it was VERY deliberate.Regardless of what I think about second rate hacks exploiting dead good writers like Agatha Christie and Rex Stout, I can live and let live. I may think it is an abomination, but hey, I don't have to read them. When the cover and advertising blurb are deliberately designed to present the deceased author as the author of the volume, however, then the gloves are off. That goes beyond stealing someone else's intellectual property and becomes an attempt to defraud the reader.I will undoubtably be criticized for rating a book I haven't read, but frankly, I don't view that as any worse than putting someone else's name prominently displayed as the author of a work they didn't write or authorize themselves. The cover of a book is a significant part of the book. In some cases, it can have a huge impact on sales of the book, so if information on it is misleading, then it is fair to review the cover as part of the contents. The publishers definitely share most of the blame on this issue but regardless of who authorized this cover, it is still cheating and a cheap ploy to sell a book.

This was an entertaining read. The small town, one major employer setting was described well; there's the one powerful family that almost everyone is afraid to cross, there's the right side of the tracks residents and the white-trash wrong side of the tracks residents, there's the established southern Texan residents who know each other's entire family histories and the northern Yankee interloper who is treated with suspicion and shunned, and there's a charismatic good ol' boy hero and the appealing  Yankee heroine. The author fleshes all of that out and brings the town and its residents to life.Some of the characters were mean and nasty, some were slutty and some were average people just getting on with their lives. Their interactions with each other and with the heroine were what drove the plot and created the conflicts. I didn't feel that anything was overdone or over the top. Everything played out naturally and at a good, even pace.The reason I am giving this book four stars instead of five was because I didn't enjoy the plot line where the heroine and hero go out of the country to find her daughter's body. It didn't spoil the story and most people probably think it was a crucial element in the story. To me, it felt a bit awkward and briefly slowed the Texas part of the story; I thought the author could have found a different  way to introduce another central character.There was language and graphic sex scenes in the book, as well as teenage heavy petting. It was all pretty mild, but those who don't like those elements should avoid this book.This was a nice story to relax with and pass the time. It engaged me and I liked several of the characters. Those I disliked were necessary to the plot and made enjoyable protagonists who livened up the story. The author's descriptions and dialogue brought the characters to life, making for a very entertaining read. I recommend this book to those who like romantic suspense books, with the emphasis on the romance. This wasn't Sandra Brown's best book, but it ranked up there as a very good one. I liked it enough that I bought the Kindle version to replace my paperback.

I read this book as an eBook from my local library, and as soon as the price goes down to paperback price, I intend to buy it. It was an excellent, well written romantic suspense book.Characterization was extremely well done. Holly and Crawford were a wonderful hero and heroine. Both were well developed characters, likeable and easy to visualize. Crawford came across as very human, flawed but with his character strengths outweighing any minor flaws. Holly initially seemed very rigid but gradually became more understanding and flexible as the story progressed.The major antagonists were also well developed characters. Crawford's father-in-law, his fellow police officer nemesis, his snitch, and the central villain were easy to visualize. The villain was suitably evil, for a villain in a romantic suspense book. There was some violence, but nothing too graphic.I loved the story; I'm not sure how true-to-life some of the judicial and police actions were, but I had no problems suspending disbelief. A purist might find errors, but the story kept me engaged and turning virtual pages well into the night. The plot may have had minor holes, but if so, they weren't egregious and I didn't notice them. There was some suspense and tension, some warm and tender moments, and a heartwarming romance. These elements combined to create an appealing and entertaining read.There were a few short sex scenes that were not overly graphic and did not interrupt the flow of the story. This book had a situation where the hero and heroine initially disliked each other, but became attracted to each other rather quickly, and acted upon it early in the story. It didn't seem like "instant love" with no basis. The rapid attraction and falling in love took place during an unusual period of intense emotions in life-and- death situations. The hero and heroine were operating in an intense situation where each quickly learned the other's character, personality, flaws and strengths. In this instance, the early romance was integral to the plot and helped to further it.I highly recommend this book. Ms. Brown's fans are sure enjoy this, her most recent offering. Those unfamiliar with her writing shouldn't be afraid to start with this book; it is a good example of the high quality of her work and well worth reading.

I got this book through Kindle Unlimited. This book had a great premise, I enjoyed the final twist and the writing mechanics were fairly good. Those were the positives. Unfortunately, they were outweighed by the negatives.The writing and dialogue felt stilted and awkward, in both the author's narrative and the characters' voices. Sentences weren't smooth, didn't flow, and felt short and choppy. It almost read like a book aimed at younger readers, except for the subject matter. As well, the actions, dialogue and inner thoughts of characters came across as odd. For example, the two female protagonists met in a parking lot when the lawyer initiates a bizarre conversation about her future client's watch. The future client's response is equally strange. If a stranger approached me in a parking lot when I was putting groceries in my car, commented on my watch, asked me where I got it, said her mother was buried with one just like it, that she didn't want her mother buried with it but her brother insisted because he bought it, I wouldn't be answering her questions, exchanging names and acting like best buds. Then the same day, the potential client shows up at the lawyer's home uninvited, says she looked up the address, and instead of being wary and wondering if this was a potential stalker, the lawyer invites her in for dinner. This all took place early in the book and it went downhill from there. It was impossible to suspend disbelief when characters thought and acted outside the bounds of normal fictional behaviour. I don't expect realism in fiction, but I expect something to make sense within the context of the story and characters.This book received a number of positive reviews, so I am in the minority, but I didn't enjoy this book. It was an acceptable first draft, but it needed further work to make it read like something aimed at an adult audience. The potential was there, and I admit that I couldn't write a book half as well as this author, but this book wasn't what it could have been.

This was a thoroughly enjoyable romantic suspense book. It was weighted more towards the suspense, but the romance was a strong component. The hero and heroine were very sympathetic and likeable, as were the supporting characters. The villains were easy to hate. One was overtly evil and made no pretence of being anything but evil. The other was more despicable because he contributed to great suffering through both his actions and inaction, while still believing he was a good person.The plot held together well and the story was generally fast paced. As the synopsis indicates, the plot deals with what happened years earlier to three teenage foster children and one infant and the effects that resulted from it. In addition to dealing with the personal toll that experience had on their lives, the protagonists are faced with current threats from enemies from the past. One protagonist remains a mystery, but the author contrasts the effects the abuse had on the heroine with that of her foster sister. While no rapes are depicted, there are discussions about rapes that happened to characters and there are threats of rape.Despite the dark subject matter, the overall tone is hopeful and optimistic. This is a romance, so we know there will be a happily ever after for the hero and heroine. Beyond the happy conclusion to the romance, however, there is a sense of redemption and of second chances. There is the sense that while life is not always perfect and we don't always have a happy outcome in every aspect of our lives, there is still love and happiness to be found.There were a couple of brief, mild sex scenes, so those who want hot and those who want clean are warned.I highly recommend this book to anyone who likes well written romantic suspense books. This one was highly entertaining and kept me engaged and turning virtual pages, well into the wee hours of the night.
Not by Amanda Quick! It's a trick.

I've found Nora Roberts to be a reliable writer, with most of her books earning four or five stars from me. Sometimes she writes a book that I absolutely hate, 'Black Hills' and 'The Search' being amongst that small number. Consequently, when I read some negative reviews of this series, I was wary, and almost didn't buy it. However, I am glad that I decided to try it, because I enjoyed it greatly.Each book in the series is a standalone, but they are closely linked with one another. The three heroines are best friends and the three heroes are brothers. There is a ghost that is a central character, but this didn't feel like a true paranormal series to me. That may not make sense, but to me, the series felt more like straightforward contemporary romances that just happened to include a ghost.Straightforward contemporary romances are not my favourite romance sub-genre, so I tend to be a demanding reader. This series engaged me and held my interest; I preferred the first book in the series, but I liked the other two. There was a great deal of tension and conflict in the first book, which made it more interesting. The second and third books concentrated on the unfolding romances and the investigation of the ghost's history, which made for pleasant reading, but did not have the same level of excitement as the first book.Prior to beginning this series, I read how Ms. Roberts based the setting's businesses on her real-life properties, and how she referenced her other books in the stories. Some reviewers were critical of this, while others thought it was cool. I subscribe to the cool factor camp and thought it added a personal touch. The use of real businesses and the references to Eve and Roarke were the sort of in-jokes that add a touch of humour.The pace was leisurely, with the descriptions of the characters' everyday activities slowly unfolding and painting a picture of the lives of the central characters. A few times, the pace slowed a bit too much in the last two books, but each time, it quickly picked up again. Although the books were not fast paced, neither were they too slow or boring. These books are not romantic suspense books, where one expects a fast pace, so readers expecting fast paced excitement will be disappointed. The stories focus on the characters; who are they, what are they like, what is their background, how did they become the people they are, what do they think and feel about things, what are their hopes and dreams, what are their daily lives like, how do they interact with each other and do their jobs, how are their romances progressing, and will everyone get their happily ever after? These books read more like Roberts' well-crafted vintage Silhouette series romances than her later paranormal or suspense books, or her edgier J.D. Robb works.There are a few mild sex scenes in each book, as well as profanity. The books are not clean reads, but neither are they erotica. Readers who are easily offended, however, will probably do well to skip these books.I highly recommend these books to readers who like a traditional, leisurely paced, contemporary romance. They are in the Silhouette style, but with more depth and characterization than usually found in those books.

We bought this Miele Microset when we bought our Miele vacuum cleaner at an appliance store. My husband love gadgets and wanted this kit, which I didn't think was necessary. I suppose it isn't strictly necessary, but it has proven its worth, several times over.We have several oil paintings, most with intricately decorated frames. As well, we have tapestries, various types of framed and hanging textile art decorations, and the usual electronic devices found in a home.  We use this kit to lightly and safely vacuum the oil paintings and textile art. It also cleans tiny, intricate items and delicate, hard to reach places. It has been a very worth well accessory.I highly recommend this kit. I admit that it can be seen as a luxury item, but it is extremely useful and functional.

We bought this Miele vacuum cleaner at an appliance store after doing a lot of online research. My husband and I have physical limitations and my husband has asthma and copd; we wanted a vacuum that would be very lightweight, powerful and allergy-friendly. As well, we planned on staying in our apartment that had all tile and flat, low level carpeting, and we had no pets, so we did not need the electronic beater bar.This was the best vacuum we ever had in over forty years, even better than our electroluxes. The suction is beyond powerful, it was easy to manoeuvre in small, tight spaces, it was so lightweight that it didn't affect bad backs, knees or shoulders, it didn't kick up dust that would aggravate allergies and it was so quiet that we barely noticed it was running. We bought the more expensive hepa filters, although the ones included with the machine worked extremely well. We were concerned about having to replace vacuum bags frequently, but surprisingly, they last far longer than any larger bags we used on other machines. The machine's performance exceeded our expectations and we loved it. Then we moved to a house with hard floors, but bought a couple of high pile area rugs, and got two cats. Disaster? Absolutely not.This vacuum still performed as advertised and continued to exceed expectations. It easily handled soil and grass carried in from outdoors, small amounts of sawdust, messes left from sanding drywall, cat hair, and it did an admirable job on the area rugs, so we didn't feel we needed a different vacuum cleaner. Then we inherited a new canister vacuum cleaner with an electronic beater bar. It was much larger than the Miele, was very heavy and didn't manoeuvre as well as the Miele, the suction didn't seem as powerful when cleaning bare floors, but it did clean the rugs better, although it created a bit of airborne dust. Our rugs looked clean when we used the Miele, and it certainly removed superficial debris; however, we could actually notice a difference in the cleanliness when we used a beater bar. Now we use the Miele for regular cleaning and haul out the other vacuum when we want to give the rugs a deeper cleaning.This Miele still rates five stars because it performed exactly as advertised. We saw the Miele model with the electronic beater bar in use, and it cleaned high pile carpets amazingly well. We were idiots, however, and went with the cheaper model since we didn't need the beater bar at that time. My advice is, if buying a Miele, buy the model with the beater bar.The Miele came with accessories for regular cleaning, but we purchased an extra kit that was for the fine cleaning of items like keyboards, electronics, and intricate or delicate items. It wasn't necessary but it satisfied my husband's need for gadgets and it is actually useful.I highly recommend a Miele. Considering its size, it outperforms larger vacuums and is a blessing to anyone who has physical limitations, lives in a small home or in one crowded with furniture. It handles a larger house as easily as it does a small apartment, and deals with pet hair, routine and extraordinary clean ups with efficiency and ease. As another reviewer said, the Miele really sucks, which is fantastic in a vacuum cleaner.

I had mixed feelings about this book. Sandra Brown's writing mechanics were excellent and deserved five stars. Her descriptive prose was masterful, and brought scenes and characters to life.Some reviewers criticized some aspects of the plot, the amnesia device in particular, as being a clich. If authors only used new and unique storylines, no new books would have been written since ancient times. It is the way in which an author personalizes a story that brings freshness to a familiar story or plot device. Ms. Brown created an engaging story using the amnesia device and I found it to be thoroughly enjoyable.The romance had less prominence than the suspense, but there was enough romance to lighten the darker suspense portion. The suspense was well done, with a gradual buildup towards the revelation that opened the heroine's eyes. The author took time to let the reader become familiar with the story's setting and characters, and gradually peeled back layers, so the reader could see beneath the surface. Overall, the story had a leisurely pace, but did not drag.There were some well done, graphic sex scenes, but they were fairly mild and there wasn't too much space devoted to them. They were a minor part of the book and were by no means erotica. There was also some profanity, so those who dislike sex and profanity might want to skip this book.There were a few violent scenes, but about what one would expect for the genre. It wasn't a 'gore fest' book by any means.**********************SPOILERS*********************I definitely enjoyed this book but one plot point lowered my rating from outstanding to acceptable. The false identity seemed totally unnecessary to me and stopped me from suspending disbelief. The author tried to explain it, but it didn't work. There was no plausible motivation for the heroine using a false identity. The heroine was a lawyer and she would eventually have got a job she wanted. All she had to do was keep sending out rsums and wait, like any normal person would. It was illogical and stupid to assume someone else's identity. She risked all kinds of legal penalties fo no good reason.As well, there is no way the heroine could have hoped to sustain a false identity when her grandmother and best friend were known to residents in her new town. Besides, she would have had to have all false documents, such as driver's license and social security. She couldn't just waltz in with a rsum and no supporting identification. How did she get licensed to practice law in a new state? She also got married using a false identity, but how did she get a marriage license with no birth certificate or other identification? If her marriage had lasted and she remained in that town, was she going to live her whole life with a false identity? She was committing major felonies on a whim, simply because she wanted to be a public defender and didn't feel like waiting for her own job offer? Even when dealing with the federal authorities over her testimony on a serious matter, she kept the false identity to the bitter end. I really hated that plot device.*********End of Spoilers *********I liked this book and I recommend it, despite what I whined about in the spoiler. The prose, the story, the characterization and the pacing made for a satisfying read. My three star rating may seem harsh, given that everything else merited five stars. However, the flaw was too egregious to ignore.

The first time I read this book, I loved the first part but had mixed feelings about the second part. The first part was riveting. I think it gave me expectations of an action-oriented/thriller plot, and that wasn't what the story ultimately was like. I decided to reread the book, this time more carefully and without pre-conceived ideas. This second reading gave me an entirely new perspective on the second part.Some reviewers likened Elizabeth/Abigail to a robotic Data. I found her to be very human and more like the character Bones, rather than an unfeeling robot. She was socially inept, took things literally, and tried to remain logical and detached. Underneath, she wanted to connect, to form relationships, to love and be loved, and to be 'normal'. She was an extremely likeable character, as was the hero, Brooks.The 'love at first sight' scenario also generated criticism by some reviewers. Nora Roberts' books are not contemporary novels or non-fiction; Nora Roberts writes romance and romantic suspense books. By their nature, they are fictional works, fantasies, fairy tales, idealized depictions of love, romance and 'happily ever after'; most readers read these types of books for that very reason. It seems ingenious to read a type of book one dislikes and then to give one star and to criticize the book for being what it was intended to be.This was a book where the journey in the second part focused on personal growth, relationships, and personalities. Elizabeth/Abigail chose to live in this town and hoped to be able to settle permanently in it. Therefore, the personality of the town and some of its inhabitants were important to the story. Readers got to see the town and some of its characters through various eyes and perspectives, including those of Abigail, Brooks and the secondary characters. Part of this included some of the day-to-day interactions of Brooks as a police chief, colleague, friend, son and sibling, as well as Abigail's lover. Readers saw Abigail progress from an aloof person who had no interactions with the town, other than brief shopping forays, to someone who learned about her neighbours and formed connections through Brooks. The wife-beating drunk and the young punk with his wealthy, bullying father, are not superfluous to the story. The relationships between them, other residents of the town and Brooks, provide depth and richness to the story. As well, these connections were what helped strengthen Abigail's resolve to face her past and to stop running. Once the reader understands that these relationships and Abigail's character development are the story, it all falls into place.Abigail's character development began with her relationship with John and Terry, where she had her first exposure to normality. It stopped with their deaths; she knew she was stunted, but didn't know how to achieve more than a lonely survival mode. She was an outsider, looking in, wanting to fit in, not knowing how to, being afraid to try, thinking she was doomed to always being alone and apart. Therefore, the connections she forged in this town, through Brooks, and her increasing involvement with the people and happenings of the community, as well as the loving relationship between her and Brooks, are actually more significant than the trial that eventually wrapped up the book's first part.I liked this book, with reservations, when I first read it. Upon reading it again, I enjoyed it even more and really loved the pacing, characterizations and plot. I highly recommend this book to anyone who loves romances and romantic suspense books. It is superb.A warning to those unfamiliar with Nora Roberts' writing, this book has explicit sex scenes and swearing. They don't comprise a large percentage of the book, but they are there.

When I read a book, I read it for what it is, and adjust my expectations accordingly. It was fairly obvious that this was a Silhouette reprint. Even if that detail had been absent, it is easy to find out whether or not a book is a reprint. In addition, the clearly stated size of two hundred and twenty pages indicates that this is not one of Nora Roberts' longer, well developed works. It seems a bit harsh for people to give the book low ratings because they didn't pay attention. More and more authors are having their blacklists digitized because readers have indicated that they want them, so neither the author nor the publisher is trying to cheat potential readers.This is one of Roberts' older series romances and it is an excellent one that has aged very well. The technology is old because of when the book was written, <eye rolling>, so I don't see why some reviewers criticized the book because of it. I don't expect cell phones in a work by Dickens or in any book written prior to their widespread use. The hero, Cliff, is not perfect but he is still a well written hero. He was written as a bit of a jerk in the very beginning because he stereotyped the heroine, Maggie. As part of the journey from their initial meeting to Cliff's proposal, Maggie's actions and personality changed Cliff's mind about her. He admitted he was wrong and his behaviour changed. I felt this was an important element in the story, as it showed the hero's growth as a person.Maggie has a lot of backbone. She was quietly assertive and stood up for herself. She was very clear about not owing others explanations about her life and her decisions, if it was none of their business. Cliff did pressure her for sex but he wasn't abusive about it and Maggie was assertive enough to refuse until she was ready.I don't expect the same type of mystery in a series romance as I do in a much longer book. There simply isn't room to develop it properly. The mystery component of this book was light and I easily guessed who committed the murder, but I still enjoyed it immensely. I don't think the murder was significant as a major element of suspense; it worked more as a vehicle to reflect the qualities of the hero and heroine, to let them learn more about each other and to further the romance.This was an extremely good series romance that contained elements of a mystery, some conflict, and good characterization. It is the kind of book one picks up for a quick read and to escape into a fantasy life for a few hours. I highly recommend it to readers who like series romances and good writing skills.It puzzles me as to why anyone would buy a series romance and then complain because it is a series romance. So for those who dislike "cheesy romances", old technology and reprints of a good book, stay away from this one. Leave it for those of us who appreciate the genre.

I just replaced my paper copy of this book with the Kindle version and reread it. It had been quite a while since I originally read it, so I wasn't sure if I would still like it. I'm happy to say that it was a thoroughly enjoyable book. I read some of the negative reviews, and while some criticisms may be valid, I didn't find anything in the book that detracted from my enjoyment.I've visited Savannah several times, but am not very familiar with its geography and police department. I suppose mistakes made in the book would irritate someone who is familiar with those areas, but they didn't bother me. I have been irritated by authors who place ports in landlocked cities and commit other major faux-pas, but I can live with minor glitches. As for Savannah not having full time hostage negotiators, I allow literary license in fiction, as long as it isn't too egregious. In this case, it added to the story and I could easily suspend disbelief.I liked Phoebe, Duncan and their friends and family. Sometimes when reading fiction, I just want to relax and escape from real life. Maybe the characters were not realistic, but it was nice to imagine that such loveable characters exist. Who wouldn't want to meet a man like Duncan, or have such loving and supportive family and friends? Romance readers love heroes who are vampires, shape shifters, demons, ghosts, time-travellers, super heroes, royalty, and a myriad of other types of heroes, so why not a multi-millionaire with a heart of gold? Also most people who read romances expect a bit of fantasy like love at first sight and I love that particular scenario. I know it isn't realistic, but I don't read romances for realism. Since this book is romantic suspense and not a straightforward romance, I expect some violence and language. I didn't feel either was over done and I enjoyed the element of suspense. There was a good amount of tension but not so much as in a thriller. I enjoyed the chapters that presented the villain's point of view and motivation, which added depth to the story. Those chapters managed to reval a lot about the villain without revealing his or her identity.There were flaws that I considered to be minor and which did not detract from the story. I absolutely hated 'Black Hills', so I am not a non-judgmental reader of Nora Roberts' books. Was this book a classic literary masterpiece? No, and it didn't pretend to be. It was a nice romantic suspense book that allowed the reader to escape for a few hours and to immerse himself or herself in a world where there is love at first sight, multi-millionaires with a heart of gold who are perfect heroes, close-knit loving family and friends, a place where good triumphs and where there is a happily ever after. I read books by authors like Tolstoy and Dostoyevsky when I want realism and expect a tragedy, or I read the news. This book was excellent for its purpose of entertaining a reader and allowing the reader to escape from reality for a few hours.I recommend this book for readers who like romantic suspense and Nora Roberts. It may not be her very best book, but it is definitely one of her better ones.

I had these books in paperback and replaced them with Kindle books before the boxed set was available. These are short, very well written traditional regencies and I enjoyed them immensely.
