They were originally written under the name 'Claudette Williams', so some readers may remember having read them when the author used that name.These were clean, sweet romances and while longer than novella length, were fast reads. They are perfect for when the reader simply wants to be entertained for a few hours. I don't think any reader who appreciates this genre will be disappointed. However, readers who want their regencies to be thinly disguised contemporary romances, with anachronisms and lots of hot sex, will be very disappointed.

I was very disappointed in 'The Hunt" by Hannah Howell. I normally love her books and have replaced almost every one of my paper editions with Kindle. I like the McNachton storyline, but this particular story felt like all sex loosely held together by a bit of story. I don't mind explicit sex in stories, but I want a good story. I became angry at the number of story-interruptuses there were and felt like screaming at the characters to get over it, already. The characters were good, the hero and heroine were likeable and the plot was great. Unfortunately, especially given the novella length, the characterizations and plot suffered because of all the sex. There was a lot of unfulfilled potential in this story. I don't know if the author chose to focus on the sex or if it was done at the urging of the publisher, but I hated it. I would rate this story one star and only recommend it to readers who want to complete the McNaughton storyline.'The Rescue', by Lynsay Sands, was very well written. The characters were wonderful, the plot was engaging, the dialogue both sparkled with humour and tugged at the heart strings, not an easy feat. The opening scene alone, with the hero's reaction to the heroine's singing, had me laughing out loud. As someone who cannot sing a note, I had no trouble visualizing the action. As well, the heroine's efforts to help the hero usually ended up in pure farce, further reducing me to tears of laughter.The hero was a sweetheart. He was honourable, brave and noble, and he showed great tenderness, sensitivity and compassion when interacting with the heroine's dying father. For such a strong alpha hero, he was like putty in the heroine's hands; he definitely didn't know what hit him when he met her.There was sex in this story, but it was a minor part of it. The story was the focus in this novella and it was Ms. Sands at her finest. I would rate it five stars, ten if I could, and I highly recommend it.As a compromise, given the uneven quality of the stories, I am rating this book three stars and recommend it for the story by Lynsay Sands.

The Rainshadow series is fantastic and this book is a very strong entry. Each Rainshadow book is a stand alone work, so no fear of cliffhangers or needing to have read previous books in order to understand what's going on.I loved everything about this book and think it was perfect. The opening scene was brilliant and a memorable way to introduce the heroine. The hero and heroine, Rafe and Ella, were very likeable and strong characters. The romance and suspense components of this book were well balanced, and Rafe's and Ella's characterizations worked perfectly in both aspects.The dialogue was wonderful, with amusing banter, mild sarcasm, and pithy comments. The story was fast paced and flowed very well. It was extremely engaging and I couldn't put it down until I finished it. It just pulled me along and I couldn't turn the pages, well, the electronic ones, fast enough; I was very eager to see how the romance and the mystery unfolded. I know, I know; readers know there will be a happily ever after and that the bad guys will lose, but the journey to that conclusion was enthralling.Each book in the series has a dust bunny companion, and this one had a lot of personality. Lorelei almost stole the show. Her love for her bridal veil and powdered doughnuts were sweet, and her initial meeting with Rafe was a very funny scene. It was obvious that she was checking him out as a potential mate for Ella.There were a few well written sex scenes that weren't overly graphic but were sensual and romantic. I liked that the book focused on the story and not the sex, although the sex scenes were crucial in advancing the romance and paranormal connection between the hero and heroine.One scene was poignant, when a predator died. The heroine's reflections on its death were thoughtful, acknowledging the necessity but at the same time seeing the tragedy. This scene added some depth and weight to an otherwise light romance, without dragging the story down and slowing the momentum; it was very skillfully written.Any fans of Jayne Ann Krentz's books will likely fall in love with this one. She truly outdid herself. For anyone approaching her work for the first time, don't hesitate to try this book. It is usually always better to read a series in order, but someone who wants to start with this book shouldn't feel lost.I highly recommend this book to anyone who likes Ms. Krentz's writing, as well as to anyone who likes or wants to try futuristic paranormal romances.

This brand is extremely comfortable because of the wide straps. The bra has an excellent fit and gives good support, plus it stands up to repeated washings. Excellent quality and value for the price. It's my favourite brand.

I saw the trailer for this movie as a child at a Saturday matinee. I was dying to see it but it was rated for a higher age group. I was ecstatic when I saw it was available on DVD and immediately ordered it. Unfortunately, times have changed and the movie probably doesn't have the same impact it did when it was released for the box office.I love many 'B' British movies, so that was not the problem. The main problem is that the movie wasn't scary. It would have terrified me years ago, but it was extremely tame by today's standards.Other factors were also related to the era when it was produced. The music was cheesy and annoying; it definitely had that late 1959s/early 1960s 'B' movie music flavour. As well, scenes that were meant to titilate were very tame by today's standards. For example, a woman dressed in what was a provocative dress at the time and did a shimmy-like solo dance for a group of men in a pub. Then she went home, undressed to her corset, went out of sight, and came back wearing a nighty that was probably considered to be sexy. The dance was painfully embarrassing and there was nothing that sexy or risqu by today's standards. I'm sure that the young men watching it in theatres were salivating back then, but today's youth would likely find those scenes to be boring.The main character has a distractingly bad hair piece. I don't know if it was real hair or a wig, but it looked ridiculous. Looked almost as bad as Donald Trump's toupee. Instead of being a scary character, the actor's scenes were stolen by his hair, and it undermined his credibility as a villain.The acting itself was good 'B' movie acting. The henchman was very stiff and the tart over-emoted, but everyone else definitely gave decent portrayals of their characters. Some of the dialogue was stiff and cheesy, which detracted from performances, but the actors did well with what they had to work with.Unless you are like I was, and simply HAVE to see this movie, I wouldn't recommend it. It was boring and not up to the standards of the great British 'B' movies.The quality of the DVD was excellent, with crisp and clear picture and sound. The pressing seemed good, with no imperfections. There were no liner inserts but the dust jacket on the case was very informative and included photos and artwork. There are a number of sellers for this DVD, so there may be some differences depending upon the seller, but mine provided a first-class product.

This product was as described. I don't like the fact that the user can't manually control the off button; it shuts off automatically after five minutes. I don't know if I missed that in the description or if it wasn't mentioned, but I prefer to shut it off as soon as I'm done using it.I edited this review and lowered my rating, because after using the thermometer a few times, I became very disappointed in it. I already had a digital thermometer but it didn't say it was an instant one. When I use it, I have to wait several seconds as it climbs up to the temperature of the food. I kept hearing about instant thermometers and bought this one because it was described as instant. The first time I used it, it gave a reading fairly quickly. However, on subsequent uses, it took several seconds to climb, just like my older thermometer. I experimented by using both thermometers at the same time. To my chagrin, my older thermometer reached the temperature reading faster than this one.The digital screen on my older thermometer is larger and much easier to read. If this thermometer was faster than my older one, I could live with it; but it isn't faster, so this is just one more area in which it fails.Other reviewers have praised this thermometer, so it obviously works for them. I am disappointed with it, though, and do not recommend it. I do recommend the seller and this is not a criticism of the retailer.

I have several of this author's books in paper, bought years ago. This book is a well written traditional regency romance, with a hint of mystery. I loved some aspects of the story and it came so close to being a five-star book, but the heroine spoiled it.The heroine was incredibly annoying and 'too stupid to live'. As part of her characterization, she is written as a stubborn person, well known for doing the opposite of what someone tells her. As a result, she puts herself in danger, even when she knows someone is trying to kill her. The hero tries to protect her and to make her aware of precautions she needs to take, but she either reacts out of anger or brattiness, and thwarts his efforts. She simply refuses to believe that certain characters could be involved in a plot against her, no matter how the hero tries to warn her.Every time I would get lost in my enjoyment of the story, the heroine would say or do something stupid and contrary, pulling me out of the moment. I would get back into the story, and then it would happen again. It was very frustrating.This was a great traditional regency, apart from the heroine's moments of stupidity. The author stayed fairly close to the social norms, there were no glaring anachronisms, no bad language and no sex scenes. This was a very clean read. I recommend this book to anyone who likes this genre and can get past the heroine's characterization. I like it well enough that I have kept it, despite my criticisms of the heroine.

Like some of the other reviewers, I was familiar with a few of the authors, but most were new to me. I'm glad I took a chance on the set because it was of very high quality with excellent writing.I confess that I did not read the story by Felicity Heaton. I scanned a few pages to determine if the writing was of similar quality to the other stories, and it was. I'm usually very open-minded; I will read erotica, romances with explicit sex, gay couples, heroes or heroines who are demons, shape-shifters, vampires, witches, former bad guys or bad girls, and so on. My Baptist upbringing came into play on this one though and I was unable to read a story with Satan as the hero. This is a personal quirk and no reflection upon the author, but it stopped me cold. It may be unfair or hypocritical, but there you have it, I'm a satan bigot. I will try other works by this author and I did not deduct points for what is my phobia, and not the author's fault.The other stories were all good reads in their own way. The stories by Caris and London had darker settings, with future earth worlds that were semi-apocalyptic, with disorder, crime and corruption. The protagonists were likeable and the plots were entertaining. These seemed to be stand alone works that were part of series. I liked the world building and characterization enough that I will try other books by these authors.The other stories had contemporary settings. The story by Vanak was good, but a bit weaker than the others. There was a bit too much repetition and the hero drove me crazy because he gave orders with no explanations and he didn't give the heroine basic information about his werewolf community. For example, the heroine encouraged a werewolf to drink something that almost killed him, because no one told her it was deadly to betas. However, the hero definitely redeemed himself in a very unselfish and heroic manner. Maybe the author had the correct idea in writing him as she did, because the reader could see how he was transformed by falling in love with the heroine, and this strengthened the plot.Ashley, Kellison and Gleason had strong entries with likeable protagonists, entertaining plots and even pacing. I'm not familiar with Kellison's work so I don't know if her story is part of a series. I hope so, because the characterization and world building were very good. Ashley's and Gleason's books were part of their series, and I especially love Ashley's shifter community. Their books were stand alone works with the support of regular characters, and both were excellent additions to their respective series.I saved Quinn's book for last. This story was outstanding and I fell in love with it. The Reaper was a swoon-worthy, to-die-for hero. (Sorry, I couldn't resist the pun. My bad.) He was protective, sweet, loveable and totally adorable. The heroine was a perfect match for him, a loving, compassionate woman with a good heart. The unfolding of their romance and the way they communicated with each other was heart-warming. The children were very well written and significant to the plot; they were not simply one-dimensional props. The plot was suspenseful, with just the right amount of 'scary' for a romance book. I will definitely be looking for more books from this author.All of these books have well written, explicit sex scenes, some longer and more explicit than others. None of these books could be considered erotica, but they are not clean reads.I often buy these inexpensive boxed sets; some have been duds while others have been very good buys. This set is outstanding and I don't think anyone who likes paranormal romances would be disappointed with it. Individual tastes differ, so some readers might not like all of the stories, but they all (except for Satan), appealed to me and held my interest. Sometimes, in these boxed sets, there may be one or two strong works anchoring the set, but these books are evenly matched and all are strong entries. I highly recommend it, and recommend buying it while it is still an incredible bargain at $0.99

I've had my paperback copy of this book for years and often reread it. In many ways it is a typical Harlequin Romance of the time of its publication; you know fairly well what to expect when you pick one up. I mean that as a compliment, because Harlequin had some very good writers and published some exceptionally good series romance books.This book is very well written, with likeable protagonists and a very good plot, which definitely kept me engaged. Readers know a romance book will have a happily ever after, but even knowing that, Cresswell created enough suspense about the impersonation and tension from the growing attraction between the hero and heroine, that that I couldn't put this book down. Once I had read it the first time, the quality of the writing and the characterization kept me returning to it whenever I wanted a 'feel good' book.I highly recommend this book to anyone who likes this genre. I think Cresswell has been underated as an author; although she branched out into mainstream romantic suspense books and historical romance books, this book is a good representation of the quality writing she did for Harlequin.

I bought this book in paperback years ago and it has remained a 'keeper'. I'm surprised it hasn't been offered in Kindle yet. It was a very well written paranormal, historical romance, with very engaging protagonists and a storyline that held my interest.The main story revolves around the nave, unprepared heroine who inherits a brothel in the American west, complete with the ghost of the hero, and their romance. However, the author does an excellent job with the characterization of the prostitutes, depicting them as individuals with histories, strengths, weaknesses, talents, hopes and dreams. They are supporting characters but are more than just stock, cardboard tropes.There was mild sex and sexual innuendo in the book, but it played a small part in the story. Those who want a perfectly clean romance will probably want to avoid this book, which is a shame. This is such a nice, traditional historical romance, albeit with a ghost for a hero.I highly recommend this book and hope it eventually makes it to Kindle.

I bought the Kindle version of this book to replace my old paperback edition. I loved this book and the other time-travel romances the author wrote, back when I was first introduced to the genre. Having reread them, I feel they stood the test of time.This book was well written and entertaining, with a likeable hero and heroine. It was an interesting concept to include Louis Riel and the Mtis Rebellion in the story, as it seems more common to include Native Americans from the American west. The author illustrated the adjustments the heroine had to make to living in the past and the various prejudices she encountered, as well as the plight of the Indigenous peoples, Mtis, soldiers and settlers that made up the society in which she found herself.The romance evolved slowly and realistically. The overall pace of the book was even, both the highs and lows of life in that time were depicted, and the balance between the romance and the plot was fairly even. There was explicit sex in the book, but it was quite mild and not a large component of the book. This was by no means a hot erotic work. Anyone expecting either a very clean or a very erotic work will likely be hugely disappointed. This book has stood the test of time but it has a traditional feel to it.I recommend this book to anyone who likes traditional time-travel romances that are well written, with attention to characterization and setting.

I got a few of this author's books when they were free and discovered they weren't really to my taste. Having said that, they were very well written and should appeal to those who like this genre.This was a sweet romance with a likeable hero and heroine. There was explicit vanilla-style sex with a fairly even balance between sex scenes and the rest of the story, and there definitely was a story; this book wasn't all sex and no story. Given the short length of the book, the story was suitably developed, but not as well as in a larger work, which is understandable.This is a good book for when a reader wants something quick, sweetly romantic and slightly erotic. It would have worked well as a longer piece, where the author could have developed it better, but it was still an enjoyable, well written short story. Although it was not my type of story, I can appreciate it for what it is. I recommend it to readers who like this genre, and the quality should please those for whom writing mechanics are important. The author has done a good job.

This author was new to me but the book was free, so I decided to try it. It turned out that it was not to my taste, but it was a good book for its genre.The hero was sweet and both he and the heroine were likeable. The erotic sex scenes were a significant portion of the book, but there was a nice, simple story framing the sex. The sex scenes were explicit, well written, mainly of the vanilla variety, and love was the impetus-----yes, there was lust, but it was based on falling in love. The falling in love was fast, but having a shifter's mate involved accounts for that. As well, this was a short story, so the reader should expect a fast pace for both the love and the sex.The author did a good job combining a sweet love story with an erotic one. This was a short read, perfect for when one wants a quick, sensuous read. As I said, it was not my style, but I could appreciate it for what it was. I recommend it to readers who like this genre.

I have this short story in the paperback anthology in which it was first published, as well as the stand alone paperback. Contrary to some reviews, it is not an abridged book and it has a conclusion. There was nothing deceptive about its republication as a short stand alone book or as an eBook, because this is a common practice and because the blurb made it clear that this was an older work.Like some other reviewers, I wish this were a novel instead of a short story, simply because I enjoyed it so much and wanted more. I loved this little story and it is perfect for when you want a Jayne Ann Krentz fix but don't have much time. It is a typical Krentz/Castle work, which means wonderful protagonists, dialogue, world building and plot. For a short work, it delivers a high quality story.Currently the Kindle price is $2.99, which is more than I am willing to pay for a short story. The publishers set prices, and while the quality of this story is excellent, I have my paper copies to enjoy, so I will wait in hopes of a price drop. Otherwise, I would probably cave in and buy it, because it is a nice addition to the Harmony series.

Enjoyed the good balance of high level strategy, unit combat, and a leavening of individual experiences.  Until reading this book I had no concept of how poorly trained and sadly equipped the troops defending Singapore were, or how commanders influenced the campaign through incompetence or by heroism.  The poor showing of some of the Indian & Australian forces vis-a-vis the heroism of most is dealt with in a fair and balanced way.  Finally,  the history of the colony and the complicated relations between the various cultures is examined.  The book is very readable; flows well, and appears well researched.  I wish the editors had provided a few basic maps through the book to give a broad view of the peninsula and the island, to show just how near & surrounded the island is to the mainland.  I recommend this book highly as the comprehensive history of the development of, & the fall of, Malaysia & Singapore.

I read this book through the Kindle Unlimited programme, so I won't show as a verified purchaser.I have almost all of this author's books and both my husband and I love them. This book was very different from her other work, but every bit as good in its own way. As I started reading it, I was taken aback at first. I was expecting a book in the style of EE or her Ruby Lionsdrake space series, but once I saw where it was going, I relaxed and went along for the adventure.The world building, characterization, and dialogue were excellent, as per the author's usual standards. The plot was very entertaining and the time travel, facilitated by a time machine, was a nice nod to H.G. Wells and early science fiction. The hero and heroine were very likeable and made a great team, while supporting characters were also well fleshed out.This story was definitely grittier than Buroker's/Lionsdrake's other works and the sex was more explicit. I'm quite catholic in my reading tastes. I like books with no sex, profanity or violence and I like them with a moderate amount of explicit sex, situationally appropriate profanity and moderate violence. With this book, Buroker told an engaging story with the right amount of sex and violence appropriate to the plot.I enjoyed this book as much as Buroker's/Lionsdrake's other books. It was very well written, held my interest and left me wanting more. While the quality of the writing and storytelling was of the same caliber as Buroker's other works, this book was very different. Readers who want another EE will be disappointed. Those who like to explore other genres and sub-genres, and can adjust to an author writing in more than one style, might really enjoy this departure from Buroker's norm.I highly recommend this book. Fans, read it for what it is, on its own merits, and not for what you expect or want it to be, and you will discover how versatile a writer Buroker is. Those new to Buroker/Lionsdrake, this is a departure from her normal style, but it is also an excellent read.

Contemporary romance is my least favourite in romance sub-genres, although I do like to read it for a change from the other sub-genres. Since it is not my favourite one, however, I tend to be more critical when reading it. I had reservations when getting this set because most of the authors were unfamiliar to me, but there were two whose works I like, so I decided to try the set. I thought that if the rest were duds, for the low price I would at least have two books that I liked. To my surprise, I liked all of the novels and novellas. Since this is a set, I am reviewing it as a set, rather than as individual books.I know for certain that at least some of these authors write or wrote for Harlequin Romance and these works reflect that series style. I like the Harlequin/Silhouette style because the books are usually well written and perfect for light reading, which these works are. The works in this set are entertaining and engaging, just right for relaxing and unwinding.I looked at some of the one star reviews and was puzzled at seeing some books in the set characterized as porn, with all sex and no story. If anyone has read some of my other reviews, it is clear that I am fine with some amount of explicit, fairly vanilla sex scenes, but that I hate books that have too much sex, more sex than story, and the darker type of sex scenes. So I guess it depends upon one's definition of porn and what one considers to be more sex than story, but I found that there were not long, frequent sex scenes. While there were some explicit as well as non-explicit sex scenes, even the explicit ones were rather mild. I didn't view them as super hot and frankly, I think any readers who want a lot of very hot sex scenes would be bored with this set. I found them to be just right, a good balance of both slightly explicit and clean romances, perfect for this grandmother who finds that long, frequent sex scenes interrupt the storyline and get to be very boring.There were also complaints about profanity. There was profanity in some of the stories, and yes, the 'F' bomb was used. I don't understand why some people consider one bit of profanity to be worse than others, but obviously, some people do. So if profanity in general and the 'F' bomb in particular, bothers potential readers, they would be advised to avoid this set. Considering how ubiquitous profanity is on even the schoolyards today, however, I think it has lost its shock value. Nevertheless, none of these books was particularly profanity-riddled. It was used judiciously in some of the books and was not used gratuitously.Others have given a synopsis of each book so I am not going to repeat their work. I do think the works in this set were fairly even in terms of quality. A few had minor editing errors, some were clean reads and some were not, some used literary license in their depictions, some required more suspension of disbelief than others, all had good characterization, some protagonists were more likeable than others but none were unlikeable, all books were evenly paced, none dragged and all were enjoyable. One's reaction to books is very subjective. This set worked for me. I really didn't expect to enjoy any of it, other than the two books by authors whose work I like. Considering my negative feelings when starting to read these books, I think it speaks well for the set that I ended up enjoying it. Judging the individual books for exactly what they are, light series-style contemporary romances, they more than fulfill their purpose to entertain and to leave readers with the warm feeling given by a 'happily ever after '. Collectively, the set is even better than the sum of its parts. I certainly plan to check out other works by these authors.I definitely recommend this set to others. Those familiar with the authors will probably like it very much. For those unfamiliar with the authors, take a chance, especially if you like this genre. I am giving it five stars, not because every individual book met my definition of a five star book, but because as a set, it did measure up to five stars.

Overall, I mostly enjoyed the series, so I had mixed feelings about my review of this final book. If I were reviewing the series in its entirety, I would probably average it out to a three star rating, but this conclusion to the series had some issues, as well as a fatal flaw.The virus plot point got strung out too long and it dragged down the pace, seemed to go nowhere fast, and became boring. I think that having it drawn out the way it was, with the males deteriorating to the point of death, was supposed to quicken the pace and add tension as the clock was ticking down. It didn't do that for me, and as I said, it actually created the opposite effect.In the beginning of the series, as the world and plot were being set up, there were a lot of battle and fight scenes. That was alright for the first book, but it continued through every book. By the time I read this volume, I was sick of all the space devoted to battles and fights. They became very boring and I wanted more substance, character development, and plot expansion.That leads me to my next issue. If these people weren't fighting or dealing with a virus, they were having sex. Frequent sex. Pages of sex. It seemed like every other chapter sex. Prepare for a mission, have sex, leave for mission, fight, return from mission, have sex, get bad news, have sex, plot out strategy, have sex, prepare for mission, have sex, rinse and repeat. Every bloody book. By the time I read this one, I had had it with all of the sex. I have no problem with sex scenes, but for heaven's sake, how about more plot and character development.The real deal breaker, though, was the abusiveness of the hero. This hero was wonderful throughout the series. Yes, he was alpha and a hardened warrior, but he was sweet, honourable, protective and loving towards the heroine. Then in this book, the author wrote him as way too Neanderthal and abusive. He was angry with the heroine for not obeying, spanked her hard as punishment for not obeying, made her sob for a long time while he held her and told her it was for her own good and that she needed a good cry to help with her emotions, and the idiot heroine agreed with him and thought he was wonderful. That did it. A great hero was turned into a macho, abusive jerk. In all of the books, the heroes were very alpha, sometimes almost stepping over a line. The heroines usually asserted themselves and the males were loving , but ultimately the males were too aggressive. This book just showed the aggressiveness carried to the extreme.The author can write well and this series had a lot of potential. I think that most readers liked it, and that I am in the minority. However, I thought books two and three improved upon book one, but each of the others became too repetitive.This series is good for readers who like a lot of sex scenes in their romances and who like ber alpha males. If a reader swoons when a hero goes all caveman, threatens to spank a heroine, does spank a heroine, and uses sex to show his power over the heroine, then this book is perfect. I'm not trying to be snarky, and I know that a lot of readers do like this book.  We all have different tastes and this book just hit the wrong spot for me.

I read this book immediately after I read the first two. The second book was better than the first, and this one is slightly better than the second. So far I am really enjoying the series. Others have given a detailed synopsis of this book, so I am just going to give my opinion of it.For starters, it is well written. Writing mechanics are good and the world building and story line remain consistent with the earlier books. There are some typos, not enough to affect the reader's enjoyment, but I expected better from a traditionally published book.Characterization for both the protagonists and the antagonists is good. They are fleshed out, with enough back story, inner dialogue and dialogue to get a sense of who they are and what their motivations are. Because of the overarching storyline, the central and some supporting characters appear in every book. Each book has the emphasis on a different hero and heroine, however, and ones in this book are very likeable. Con, the hero, is alpha but less domineering with his mate than his brothers are with theirs. He was depicted as a man who loved his mate enough to sacrifice his own desires by releasing her to fulfill her potential and destiny. As well, he was depicted as a man who studied her craft, not only for his own political agenda, but to become an understanding and supportive part of her life. He was confident enough in himself that he took pride in his mates' abilities, even when she bested him. Moira, the heroine, was very young and inexperienced when mated and is conflicted as a result. She is very strong, confident and decisive when it comes to her craft and her duties as a witch. However, when it comes to personal relationships, especially with her mate, she is extremely insecure, indecisive and she constantly second-guesses herself. The author portrayed them perfectly for the situation in which she placed them, and it made for a strong and satisfying romantic component of the the book.The pace was fairly brisk and even. The author created enough suspense and tension, that the suspense component balanced the romance. The story line was strong and very engaging. I couldn't put the book down and stayed up until the wee hours to finish it.My only complaint is the amount of sex. I think this book had less of a ratio of sex to story than the others, but it was still too much for my tastes. The book was definitely not erotica and the sex scenes were well done. Most readers of paranormal romances would likely be very happy with this aspect of the book. My personal preference is for less sex and more story in my romance books. No matter how well written sex scenes are, I find that if there are too many or they are too long, they slow down the story and, frankly, they get boring fast.I recommend this book and the series. I've read the next two books since I finished this one, and the quality remains consistent and good. I've read several paranormal romance series, and well there are some I liked more than this one, it ranks highly on my scale.

This author was new to me and I just read the first book in this series yesterday. I enjoyed it, so I read this one today. Both books had good writing mechanics with only a few typos that did not detract from the stories. This book continued seamlessly from the first and was a bit better because the hero and heroine were more likeable than those in the first book.The world building was excellent and I can seem a pattern emerging in how the males in this world interact with their mates. Readers will probably either love it or hate it. Mates are part of a fated couple and both the heroes and heroines are unable to resist the sexual attraction and mating urge for any length of time. Even when the human heroines initially resist, the heroes refuse to let their mates walk away. I've noticed that some reviewers view the males negatively because of this, but I don't see them as macho jerks who won't take no for an answer. Neither part of a couple has a choice when they are a fated mate, and the males grow up knowing that, while the human females have no idea what is happening and they think they have a choice. Given the danger the fated females face from the evil villains, the heroes have no choice but to forego a lengthy courtship in order to protect the heroines. Since this conflict is an integral part of the author's world building, how readers respond to it will be a factor in whether or not they like the books.Some reviewers hated the way the heroes in both books used sex to manipulate or control their mates. Again, the strong sexual attraction between mates is a main component in the author's world. I did feel that the hero in the first book bordered on using emotional abuse, but he didn't actually cross my personal line. The hero in this book tried to give his mate more space and control, so I found him to be more likeable. A reader's personal response to this type of hero and plot device will likely influence whether or not he or she likes the book. I REALLY don't like my heroes to abuse and rape women in my romance books, and I did not feel these heroes crossed that line. At least one reviewer felt that the hero raped the heroine, so obviously this is an area that is very subjective. I felt that the heroine was always willing but didn't always want to feel such a strong sexual attraction that she couldn't resist.The only thing that I disliked about this book was that there was too much space devoted to sex for my tastes. The sex scenes were well written and they didn't overshadow the story. This was definitely not a thinly veiled erotica book pretending to be a paranormal romance. The amount of hot sex is probably about what most readers of paranormal romances want, so that is definitely a plus for those readers. I just skimmed over them and enjoyed the rest of the story.The story was very well written and engaging. The pace was fairly even and neither too slow nor too fast. Supporting characters were well fleshed out and likeable. The villains were suitably evil and cunning, but the mood was definitely not dark and gritty, like urban paranormal romances. These were simply very nice paranormal romantic suspense books that should have broad appeal.There is an overarching storyline to the series but the books are standalone with a firm conclusion; No cliffhangers here.So if you like your paranormal romances to have highly alpha males and a fair bit of hot sex, I recommend this book, and if the series continues like the first two books, I recommend the series. I'm looking forward to the next volume.

I wasn't familiar with this author but the synopsis of this book sounded good, so I decided to try it. I bought the entire series on faith since the books were on sale at a good price, but this is the only one I've read thus far. I have mixed feelings about it and am rounding my three and a half rating up to a four.I loved the world building and it was easy to get totally immersed in it. The author did a fantastic job with the types of characters, their abilities, their limitations and the conflict between them. I was definitely engaged.Characterization was also a strong feature of the book. For the most part, the protagonists were very likeable, especially the little girl, Janie. However, there were some weaknesses that lowered my rating. I didn't have a problem with the instant overwhelming sexual attraction between the hero, Talen, and the heroine, Cara. It is common in paranormal romances and the author gave a good explanation for it, as part of the world building. Therefore, there was an acceptable reason why the heroine couldn't resist the hero. What did bother me was that the hero was borderline abusive. He was portrayed as a wonderful, loving, gentle male who had diplomatic skills as well as his abilities as a warrior. On some occasions, he didn't explain things to the heroine until after the fact. He ordered her about, but didn't sit down and discuss issues. Not very diplomatic.As well, Talen threatened Cara  with punishment a few times and I was afraid there was going to be a spanking scene. Spanking doesn't do it for me as part of a sex scene, but to each his or her own. However, used as punishment is a real deal breaker for me. The books would have been returned immediately. Talen's good characteristics balanced what I considered to be the bad, though, so I still liked the book.Cara annoyed me at times. Most of the time she was likeable, but in some circumstances she came across as a stubborn brat. Again, this wasn't enough to spoil the story, which was enjoyable, despite her less than perfect characterization.The author created good, believable villains. They were suitably evil and contributed to an exciting storyline.The storyline itself was great. The good versus evil conflict, the 'fated mates' romance, and the concept of children who were psychics and destined to save the world, made for a very enjoyable read.  It definitely engaged me and I read the book in one sitting.What I really hated about the book, besides the hero's emotional abusiveness, was the interminable sex scenes. This is very subjective and I know a lot of readers view numerous sex scenes as a plus; I don't. These sex scenes were well written but there were too many and they were too long. The book was definitely not a sex book with a thin plot, but I prefer a higher ratio of plot to sex scenes, than what the author wrote. In all honesty, I think the balance the author provided would be just right for a lot of paranormal romance readers, just not for me. I ended up skimming over those pages.In the final analysis, I did like the book very much. If I hadn't already purchased the rest, I would have done so after reading this one. The author wrote well and there were just a few typos, but the writing mechanics were good. One reviewer commented that some of the wording sounded like English used by a non-native speaker, but I didn't see that. However, I'm Canadian lol, and my speech patterns don't always match American ones.I recommend this book. The hero wasn't the most well written one I've seen, but he was acceptable and the story was strong enough to outweigh his flaws. Those who prefer less sex in their romances shouldn't have a problem skimming over the sex scenes, and again, the story mitigated any annoyance resulting from it. I think it is a fact of life that paranormal romances will be a bit heavy on the sex now, so as long as the reader has made peace with that, it is possible to still enjoy a well written one like this one.

The book is highly detailed in many of the individual dogfights, tactics, during this roughly 24 hour period.  The events occurring to individual civilians on the ground as a result of falling bombs, pieces of aircraft, & airmen parachuting out of aircraft flesh out the overall strategies perfectly.  The prose is at a level that would be suitable from adolescents to the retired.  The book never falters nor bogs down due to too much detail or too much strategic discussion.  It is a great balance that kept me spellbound and entertained.

******SPOILER ALERT ******'A Distant Echo' is another one of Ms. Hutchinson's enjoyable backlist books that is being released on Kindle. I have been waiting to replace my old paperback with the Kindle version, so I was happy to see it available.This is a well written time travel romance that has two romantic couples, although one couple features more prominently. I really liked this book, but in all honesty, it did have some flaws, which I will address first.One of the heroines, Zelda, was likeable but she verged on being a disagreeable character. The author wanted to show how she was ahead of her time regarding the rights of women, so she was written as a strong character. This translated into a person who was at times excessively stubborn. Her father worked ten hour shifts in a coal mine, but he had to take his turn with cooking and dishwashing. She refused to listen to what her brother wanted, and tried to force him into a career path that he didn't want. She had good intentions, but almost alienated him. In addition, she knew that her lover, Tom, wanted to return to the future, where he was wealthy. Living in the past, he was penniless and would have to labour at difficult jobs in order to make a living. Since her brother wanted to go to the future also, it would have been ideal. However, when her dying father refused to go, she refused to go and got angry when Tom said he was going, even without her, because he only had one chance to leave. She refused to see his point of view and wanted him to make all of the sacrifices. This part of the plot was a bit weak. Throughout the book, Zelda was shown to be able to manage her father and he listened to her. It was apparent that he only had weeks to live and given Zelda's forceful personality, she could easily have pressured her father into going, but she didn't even try. It was as if she was using her father's refusal as an excuse to stay in the past. These were the issues that made the book less than perfect.Now for the positives. Almost every character was likeable, even Zelda, despite her flaws. The supporting characters were fleshed out and memorable. There were some poignant scenes, one in particular that touched on the terrible price coal miners pay in both health and safety. Despite this, the story was not depressing; it just made one pause and think for a moment.The plot with two friends, Tom and Jackson, traveling back in time together and having to adapt, held my interest. The story was evenly paced and engaging. It was nice to see Canada used as a setting, and our Royal Canadian Mounted Police being featured, even if they were portrayed as doofuses.There were some fairly mild sex scenes and a small amount of profanity that fit with the circumstances in which it was used. However, the 'F' bomb, which seems to freak out some people, was used once. Considering that that word is as ubiquitous today as McDonalds, I would think it had lost its shock value, but apparently not. In all other respects, this was a very traditional romance book, not hot, not fast paced and not full of graphic violence, just a nice, pleasant story. This is one I wouldn't hesitate to let my granddaughter read.I do recommend it to readers who like this genre. It is an enjoyable read and perfect for curling up on the sofa to relax.

I was glad to see this book released on Kindle because I loved the story and wanted to replace my paperback. This edition had some minor changes, such as updating the year the story began, but it is basically the same as the original.This was a well written time travel romance, with likeable protagonists. The author described the 1865 setting very well, with some realism regarding outhouses, wood stoves, the dust, dirt, lack of air conditioning, law and order, medical care, mortality rates and women's rights.The author took time to show how the heroine, her mother and her mother's friend adjusted to going back in time. This was unusual as most time travel romances I've read focused on one character doing the time travel. It was interesting to see how this closely connected trio integrated into their new society. As well, it was nice to see how the women grew and how their attitudes changed. Daisy gained self-confidence, began to take an interest in life, and blossomed. Elvira realized she did love her husband, that she hadn't shown him love, that she had been too critical of him, and she missed him. In addition, Hannah came to know her mother better and to realize that love was based on more than economic security. As well, Hannah herself had an impact on the hero, Logan, and he came to realize love was more important than revenge.This book was evenly paced, taking a leisurely path to the conclusion. The author took the time to let the women adjust and to let the hero and heroine court and fall in love, but the pace was not too slow. The romance itself and the sex scenes were low key and not explicit. I view this as a romance in the traditional mode. This was not a hot, fast paced romance, but it was a very good read for anyone wanting a more traditional romance book. ****** POSSIBLE SPOILERS ******I think some reviewers misunderstood the ending of the story. Readers were not left hanging. The hero found his way to the future and to the heroine. She offered to go back to the past with him but he chose to stay in the future with her. This was a very brief scene and it did seem abrupt. An epilogue would have been perfect, but even without one, the story did conclude with a clear 'happily ever after'.I definitely recommend this book to readers who like time travel romances and traditional romances. This was a very nice story, and I would have no hesitation in letting my teenaged granddaughter read it.

This is a brilliantly written story describing the day by day actions of the American's drive to move through the almost impenetrable  Huertgen forest in the drive to the Rohr.  I enjoyed the author's style, his "just right" amount of detail, and the flow of the narrative.  The tragic events caused at times by over optimism, or excess caution, or unwillingness send higher authorities the grim truth of casualties, and the piecemeal replacement of one division after another into the forest against a well entrenched German force led to a war of attrition causing tens of thousands of needless casualties.  This long battle has been mentioned - but in a passing way, in many books I have read about the Battle of the Bulge, war in Europe et al, but this book puts this drawn out fight on center stage where it belongs!  I recommend it highly to anyone interested in the WW II battles as the American Armies were crossing the border into Germany at Aachen and southwards.  It is a military history more at the unit & higher levels, describing the decisions made, and also contains enough of the infantryman's feelings to make it a living book.  If you put it down - good luck, for it is a book that takes you into the action played out in a dark, cold & rainy hell that never seemed to end for those who were there.

I did not enjoy this book. I could not connect with the characters and I did not find them to be likeable. Between the characters and the odd plot, it almost felt as if the author had channeled Kafka into a suspense book. The sex scenes felt cold and clinical, not at all sensuous. There were a number of typos, but not enough to be distracting. Overall, the writing mechanics were good. Although I finished the book, it did not engage me.I think the author's intent was to have unsympathetic protagonists and the plot reflected that. It was almost like a black comedy. In that sense, the author did succeed, it is just that I don't like that genre. Readers who like this type of book will likely find it to be well written. I may be in the minority, but I really disliked it, well written or not.

'Butterfly' is another of Sala's well written romantic suspense books. It is a light, entertaining book, perfect as a rainy day read. I thoroughly enjoyed it but I can understand why some readers did not.The hero and heroine, Ben and China, are very likeable characters, and I was easily able to suspend disbelief for Ben's ' love at first sight' reaction to China. This is a plot device that readers either like or hate; while I do like it, I know that many readers are put off by it. So one's reaction to this book will depend very much upon whether or not one can accept a 'love at first sight' plot.Sala's casting of the villain was well done and kept me guessing. There was suspense, but not a lot of tension or graphic violence, which is why I view the book as a light, pleasant read. Some reviewers felt the book leaned more toward romance than suspense, and I agree. This was not a negative for me, however, and I liked the emphasis on the character development of China, as she transformed from an insecure victim to a woman secure in the love of Ben. This was not a fast paced book but neither was it slow and boring. Anyone happy with a leisurely paced book should enjoy how the story unfolds.There were a few mild, non-graphic sex scenes and I view this book as a clean read, although purists will probably disagree.I recommend this book to anyone looking for a fairly clean romance that has some suspense, but is focused more on the romance and character development.

This book didn't have quite the same depth as some of Ms. Sala's books, but it was still an excellent read. It was very well written, which is pretty much a given with any of her books. It engaged me and kept me figuratively turning pages on my Kindle app. I've read this book at least twice in paperback, so the story definitely held its appeal.The heroine and hero are very likeable, as is the hero's brother. The kindness and loving relationships shown by them gave the story a feeling of warmth. Characterization for the secondary characters was well done and brought them to life. The villain's characterization was very good, as he was shown slowly descending into madness. It was easy to visualize his struggle to function and to hold on to his sanity well enough to hide his condition from others.The book was suspenseful and the mystery about the stalker's identity kept the reader guessing. The plot moved along at an even pace and never dragged. The scenes often alternated between the protagonists and the villain, which worked to increase tension.The romance was the area that I felt did not have enough depth. The hero and heroine were great characters and there were emotional moments and lots of warmth in the story, but for some reason I didn't feel the same emotional response or sense of connection that I get with most of Ms. Sala's characters. I felt that perhaps more attention was given to the angst of the hero and heroine and not enough to the actual romance. Don't get me wrong, it was still a nice romance, but not the best Ms. Sala has written.There were some very mild sex scenes, enough to upset readers who want a perfectly clean romance and not enough to please those who want a really hot romance. I feel sorry for the poor authors who have to navigate those waters.I recommend this book to anyone looking for a pleasant, well written romantic suspense story, with likeable characters, mild violence and mild sex scenes. It is a good beach read and a good book with which to pass the time on a lazy, rainy day.

I have almost every paperback book by Sala/McCall and I have replaced almost fifty in Kindle, thus far, so I am obviously a fan of her writing. Being a fan does not mean I can't be objective, however; I have no hesitation in giving a favourite writer a bad review if I hate one of his or her books. I read 'Legend' when it first came out and loved it, so I wondered if it would stand the test of time. To me, it does.The hero and heroine are extremely likeable. Joseph is pretty much a perfect human being. He made mistakes when he was younger but has matured into a sensitive, selfless, loving person. Raine seems a bit more flawed because she isn't entirely honest with Joseph, at first, but she has had a difficult life and is coping the best way that she can. Raine's depiction is realistic because she has the same immediate reactions to her situation as most of Sala's readers would. She is angry, at times bitter, she rails against the burdens God has given her, she feels abandoned and unloved, and she has lost hope. Then she rises above those feelings and determines to live the rest of her life with acceptance, love, peace and joy.  Sala has written her hero and heroine as ordinary people who face the problems they have been given and become better people for it. Although there is a supernatural element that is part of Joseph's heritage, it is just another facet of his humanity and decency; he is a good, grounded person, with or without that element in the story.Sala's depiction of Joseph's brother, Benny, is another one of her superb characterizations. Just as the reader starts to hate Benny, he shows a decent streak. This happens more than once, and the reader sees the struggle Benny has in trying to overcome his weaknesses, and they are weaknesses. Benny isn't evil, he knows when he is wrong, he vacillates between doing the right thing and becoming the person he wants to be, or taking the easy way out for material gain. He wants respect but is still learning that it has nothing to do with how much he has, but how he acts and lives his life. Sala does a brilliant job of garnering sympathy for Benny, while still revealing his many character flaws.On the other hand, Sala's characterization of the villain demonstrates the evil inherent in those whom wealth and power have corrupted. We can't pity this villain because he has no morals, has no boundaries, thinks he is entitled to whatever he wants and is so selfish, that nothing and no one matters except his own desires. It isn't that he is evil because he has wealth and power, but that they have corrupted him.Some of Sala's books are pure escapist romantic suspense, while others, like this one, have a deeper message. There are moments when this book has tearjerker scenes, such as the burial of Raine's and Joseph's baby, but the overall theme is one of hope, love and redemption. Sala manages to depict the reality of life, such as death, grief and loneliness, but she offers hope and optimism at the same time; her characters always have their 'happily ever after', despite what they may have gone through.This is not a clean read. I wouldn't hesitate to let my granddaughter read it, but those offended by language and sex scenes won't be happy with it. It isn't a particularly hot read, either, so those readers who only want a lot of very hot sex scenes would be disappointed. I think the story has universal appeal but it isn't for everyone. I definitely recommended it, though.

The premise sounded great, but the story did not engage me. The protagonists were likeable enough, but they seemed very immature for their ages. I found it difficult to believe that these were young adults on the verge of starting their own families; they seemed more like high school teenagers. For example, early in the book, four of the protagonists went to the pickup for beers and to drive around, which seemed irresponsible. As well, the giggling and over-the-top dialogue seemed more suitable to teenagers, and I could not relate to the characters. That surprised me because I do read young adult fantasy and science fiction with young protagonists, and have no problems relating to the characters.Another serious problem for me was the lack of resolution. The story concluded with two heros and two heroines entertaining into relationships but with no idea where they would go from there. They just hooked up but they live in different states, so what happens? We aren't given any insight into the resolution. I hate cliffhangers, and calling a book part one of a series does not mean the author gets a free pass on providing an ending.I found the different points of view and flashbacks distracting. Some readers like them, but I didn't like the switching back and forth.On the plus side, the writing mechanics were good with only a few minor typos.This book might appeal to a younger audience, but I don't believe it is one with universal appeal. It is not one I would recommend, but I can see that others would like it. Thus far, mine is the only negative review, so I am obviously in the minority on this one. My opinion is just that, my personal opinion about the book. I deleted it, which normally would be a one star book, but I raised it to a two because of the writing mechanics.

I used to love books by Heather Graham, but the last several Krewe books felt as if they were the same boring book with some new characters added. For example, this book had way, way, way, way too much repetition and it acted as just so much filler. The filler-like repetition seems to have become the norm in Ms. Graham's more recent offerings. It slows the action down to a moribund level and kills the storyline.Part of the repetition is simply repeating the same information about characters and plot points several times. I guess it could be called standard repetition. Then there is the dreaded LECTURE repetition, which is even worse. Good authors can incorporate factual information without seeming to digress into lecture mode; unfortunately, in her last several books, including this one, the author seems to be quoting from the most deadly dull tourist brochure imaginable. This hectoring, lecturing digression gets repeated in various ways. If it didn't put you to sleep the first time, keep trying until it works!The LECTURE repetition has a variation called the DEFENSIVE LECTURE. Let's see how many ways we can defend Wicca, how many ways we can say we are all-inclusive when it comes to religion, why our friends could not be the murderer, and so on, which brings up the next point.  ******SPOILER ALERT******Could we please, for once, have the murderer be a stranger? What's wrong with a plain old garden variety serial killer? Why must it always be part of the heroine's and hero's clique? What are the odds of that happening? The first few times it might be fresh, but it gets old, fast.Ms. Graham can and has written excellent five star books. The Krewe series presents a rich field for new and exciting books. Unfortunately, it seems as if the author has developed a template, to which she adheres religiously. This book was slow, slower, slowest, monotonous and boring. Likeable characters alone will not save a book like this one.If I am overly harsh, it is because Ms. Graham is an experienced author with a traditional publishing house supporting her. There is no excuse for this kind of laziness or sloppiness. Where were the editors? This book was an insult to loyal readers.

I read some of the reviews that stated this was not a set and that one part ended on a cliffhanger with no continuation. My set was an actual set and the cliffhanger was immediately followed by the next volume. If there had been a problem, it seems to have been resolved. I wanted to try a new author and the synopsis of this set attracted me. I read all eight books and they were not at all to my taste. They were well written with a few typos but the writing mechanics were good. They were written in the first person with the main protagonist narrating his story. The tone was conversational and the narrator came across as a very likeable young man. The overarching plot was a classic good versus evil scenario and most of the protagonists were likeable.The reason I didn't care for the books is because the books were all wrong for me. I am a mid-sixties female and most of the protagonists were early twenty-somethings, or else older vampires who had been turned at young ages. Add in the mixed martial arts and the young male perspective, and it's a recipe for a disastrous matching of demographics and genres.The books were good for the right audience. I think they would appeal to both genders, from early teens and up to thirty-somethings, although I think they would appeal more to males than females. I could be wrong, but that is what I thought as I was reading them. The books are light reading and there is very little graphic gore. These are not dark, heavy vampire and werewolf stories. There is some romance, some young adult soul-searching and angst, and some young male coming of age, bonding, teasing and trash-talking. I think they would definitely appeal to my teenaged and twenty-something grandsons. If I were a lot younger, I would have liked the books.I do recommend these books to the right audience. I tried to judge them for what they were and did not measure them against what genres interest me. It would be unfair to the author to penalize him because I was hoping for hot paranormal romances. ;)

******SPOILER ALERT******I love some of Stephanie Bond's books, but this is not one of them. I almost gave this book two stars because the writing mechanics were excellent. However, I really did hate this book, which is why I gave it one star.This book is labelled as a humorous romantic mystery book, but I found nothing humorous in it. I know that many other reviewers found it to be very humorous, but I didn't. I think the nasty arguing and fist fighting the sisters engaged in were supposed to be funny, but I thought it was appalling. Grown women fighting and rolling around in their driveway did not amuse me. As for the bedroom fight scene with two of the sisters and the boyfriend/fianc, it was simply sad that women would demean themselves like they did, and I did not see any humour in it.I disliked the boyfriend/fianc, because he was a sleaze. That was good, because readers were supposed to dislike him. He was one of the villains, after all. The problem was that I detested two of the sisters and disliked the third, but I was supposed to like them; they were the heroines. Unfortunately, they did not act like heroines. Two of them were selfish, self-centred, bitter, vindictive, amoral and thoroughly unlikeable. Sleeping with one's sister's fianc for over three years and then running off with him the morning of the wedding does not endear a character to me. Nor does having revenge sex with various married men over a twelve year period. Yes, they made up at the end and reformed, but by then it didn't matter to me. Admittedly, the third sister seemed angelic in comparison with the other two, but she came across as weak. She was the one with the conscience, but she gave in to her selfish sisters' arguments and withheld information about a murder all three witnessed. It could be argued that she was only fourteen at the time, but as she grew older, she was supposedly bothered about not coming forward, but she had 'promised' her sisters that she wouldn't tell. A man was sentenced to prison for life, twenty years later he was still proclaiming his innocence, but hey, a promise is a promise. So what if a potentially innocent man stays in prison when your evidence might help him. I felt like slapping some sense into her.There were three very likeable, possible heroes/new love interests for the sisters, but two of them got almost no page time and the third got very little. It seemed as if the narration/inner musings by the sisters, just droned on and on about themselves, the fianc issue, the vengeful wife issue, the parent's marital and financial issues and the missing father issue. A lot of the action was the interaction between the sisters as they argued, fought, pouted, had temper tantrums and proved just how dysfunctional they were. The romances were hinted at but were never really developed.I forced myself to finish this book, but neither the characters nor the story engaged me. I don't recommend this book to anyone who expects a humorous romance. If readers are interested in a chick-lit style novel about a dysfunctional family, they might like it.

As other reviewers have noted, this book consists of four short story/novella length reissues from older anthologies. I am a bit puzzled about the complaints regarding that, because I am pleased to see older works available for Kindle. I am also happy to have the stories available in one place, rather than having to buy four separate anthologies with works of uneven quality, simply to get the stories by Hannah Howell. The original anthologies may have had themes, but I find that these stories stand alone and work very well in a dedicated Hannah Howell edition. It is a matter of personal taste, and critics are entitled to their opinions, but I am very happy that these stories have been reprinted in a single volume.As for the stories themselves, they are very well written vintage Hannah Howell works. Given the constraints of the short format, the author has written engaging stories with likeable protagonists and believable antagonists.Are these stories as well developed as the author's longer works? No, but I have found that shorter stories never are. I usually prefer novel length works for the added depth, but there are times when I just want a short read. However, I still want my shorter reads to be well written and engaging, with good characterization and entertaining dialogue and plots. These stories meet those expectations and are perfect for those times when one wants something short to read.The stories have mild but graphic sex scenes, so they won't appeal to those who want a perfectly clean read. For everyone else, the stories have broad appeal and are suitable for late teens up to seniors. I recommend this book to those who like short stories and who want to acquire Ms. Howell's older works.

I have almost every one of Hannah Howell's books in paper and in Kindle, so I obviously love her writing. However, this book was not one of her better ones.As usual, in Ms. Howell's books, the writing mechanics in this one were very good. The beginning of this book was extremely well written and engaging, with very likeable characters. I was certain that I would love the rest of the book and was eager to delve into it. Unfortunately, it was downhill from there.As others have noted, the hero was an ass. The book was written quite a while ago and some of his behaviours were popular with readers, so I don't fault him for some of his actions, such as the 'forced seduction'. I remember that I used to find it romantic, so he doesn't lose points for that. His overall treatment of the heroine is deplorable, however, especially regarding his former mistress.Some of the scenes, such as the hero's brother trying to seduce the heroine, were a little too graphic for comfort. I'm fine with graphic sex scenes and I'm fine with a nasty villain attempting to ravish a heroine; I'm not fine with a heroine getting turned on when a man other than the hero is fondling her and she admits he could make her enjoy it. Ugh! That is not why I read romance books.This book had so much potential and I could easily have loved it. Some of the characters were incredibly well written and engaging. Some of the dialogue was outstanding and the witty repartee was very amusing. Unfortunately, some of the dialogue was simply embarrassing. I really wish the author would do a rewrite on this book, as some romance authors have done with their books that didn't withstand the test of time. It certainly wouldn't take much to turn it into a five star book, and this is a book that is begging for a chance to shine.

I freely admit to being a philistine; this journal would appeal to my fine arts friends but I pretty much hated it. I loved the stories by Vincent Zandri and Robert Mayette, but nothing else appealed to me. I prefer prose to poetry, but love the maligned WWI poetry, so needless to say, the poetry included here did nothing for me. The illustrations are well done, but too avante-gard for my tastes.Although the journal is well written and illustrated, I think it will only appeal to a specialized audience. I'm giving it 4 stars, even though I hated most of it, because it is not the authors' and artists' fault that I have plebeian tastes. Readers who like this genre will likely love it.

This is a very professional magazine, with well written and edited stories and articles. Although the stories proved to be outside my area of interest, I did enjoy the earlier stories and they held my interest. Given the limitations of the short format, the authors were still able to imbue their works with elements that brought the characters, settings, dialogue and narration to life. These stories would be excellent for when one wants a quick but professionally written read.The last few stories were as well written as the earlier ones, but the content was not my cup of tea. There was nothing objectionable about them; they just didn't hold my interest.I got this magazine when it was free and the only reason I would not pay for it is because the stories were not in my areas of interest, even though they were good. For anyone who likes this genre, it is probably worth the $0.99 price. I do highly recommend giving this magazine a chance. Check out the sample first, and if you like it, the rest of the work is of the same quality.

The quality was consistent in each of the stories in this anthology and the stories were well matched. Writing mechanics were very good and the stories were well written. I enjoyed the Australian idioms and the flavour they gave to some of the stories. However, the book did not appeal to me or capture my interest.I'm not sure why the stories did not work for me. I think it was partly because they were technically excellent, but did not have enough soul for my reading tastes. The stories were certainly well developed, given the restrictions of the short story format. Various emotions were conveyed well, and the reader could easily see what the characters were feeling. Descriptions brought the settings, characters and actions to life. Still, the stories failed to grab me.Although this book did not work for me, I gave it a higher rating based on the technical quality of the work. These stories could definitely work for the right audience. There was some very mild sex in a couple of the stories, but I would still rate the book as suitable for young adults and older. The book is currently free, so it is well worth trying. Not everyone has the same tastes, so there are readers out there who will probably love it.

The story is as well written as the first two books.  The likeable characters and the interactions & dialog are further developed, and have realistic spontaneity.  There is a perfect balance of action, dialog, introspection & humor and the plot continues without a hitch. The author's style is very engaging, free of over wrought prose, and will keep a reader spell bound to the conclusion. A joy for fantasy readers from 14 to 65.

I had mixed feelings about this book. I wanted to like it, but there were problems that prevented that.Several people mentioned the editing problems, and there were a lot of them. Spell Check might have been the problem for the frequent use of wrong words. When I see feint instead of faint, heel for heal, and starred for stared, as well as many other examples, my first thought is Spell Check.  There were other editorial issues such as the mix up with the type of cars and clothes, which made the book feel like a first draft. This was not a major issue for me, but it does indicate that the author needs some good beta readers, because the editorial problems will be a killer for many readers.My main problem with the book was that it seemed flat. It was a good story and it almost succeeded in being a great story, but it missed the mark. Part of the problem was the characters.The heroine had potential, as she was fairly likeable, but she veered close to being 'too stupid to live' a couple of times. To the author's credit, she avoided this pitfall, but it was too close and made the character seem weak, rather than noble and vulnerable, which I think was the objective. As well, the heroine's character seemed slightly subdued or flat, even when expressing emotion. For example, she accepted werewolves and her own change too easily and she seemed blas about many things that happened. It felt as if she was on Valium sometimes.The characterization for the hero and his brothers, the villain Enrique, and the minor supporting characters was well done and they were fleshed out and consistent. However, the villain Luc, was problematic. The author tried to show that he had redeeming qualities, but the way in which he lost his temper and tried to exercise total control over the heroine demonstrated his vicious qualities. I could see what the author was aiming for, but it didn't quite work as written.The narrative was another area that bothered me. It also felt a bit dull in places and slowed down the story. For example, I really liked the links to the park sites, but I thought there was too much information about the parks in the narrative, which slowed the main story. I believe that the author did not plagiarize this information, but it was unnecessary in furthering the plot. As well, I didn't enjoy all of the details about the coyotes and the plight of those crossing the border with their 'help'. I'm all in favour of authors incorporating educational information into a book, but in this case, there was too much space given to it and it slowed the story and was depressing, which is not the best emotion to evoke in a romance.Overall, the book was well written and the author has good writing mechanics, despite the Spell Check fiasco. As the book is written, I think many readers would like it and would view it as worth four or five stars. I hate to be harsh, but I think it would benefit by a rewrite with better editing and some minor tweaks to bring some vibrancy to the story. I realize the author is an established writer and I am not, but I am a voracious reader. This book is close to what I look for in a paranormal romance, but it doesn't quite make it.For those who care, there are a couple of mild sex scenes, so those who want a perfectly clean romance or a super hot one would likely be unhappy with this book.Despite my criticisms, I recommend this book to those who enjoy a traditional style series-type paranormal romance book. It reminded me of some of my 'Silhouette' or 'Harlequin' paranormal or suspense romances., which I quite enjoy when I am in the mood for a light, entertaining read.

Liked the flow of the writing, the smooth development of characters, the well balanced plot, and the very skilful writing.  The first few chapters mostly featuring the heroine were a bit of a stumble out of the chocks, with me thinking "she's too dumb to live," at times, but her character develops into a more well rounded person after that.  I honestly believe the author is a writer who will hold you enthralled, with just the right amount of humor fitting in seamlessly. Any reader from teen to retired (me) should find this book very entertaining.  The end is well done, hinting at the next books in the series, but can stand alone. i.e. - no cliff hanger.
Really like the reload feature - the automated system really makes it easier to keep a gift card balance active.
Deleted app after a few days - a few bugs.
A fun way to pass the time.
Okay but not great.  Ended up deleting from my fire.
A fun game to pass the time.

The players:Quinlin Westin. Coltons sister.  College student and girl who is tired of falling for the bad boy and having her heart broken.Hawkin Play. Lead singer of Bent. Bad boy rock star and a guy with a heart that survived all the damage.A choice made based on a promise, land Hawkin on a college campus playing rock star turned professor when the TA with a back bone catches his eye.  Quinlin might get a little weak in the knees when she stands too close, but she sure isnt going to let him know just how much hes getting to her.  Ready to keep her distance, Hawkins plays on her attraction and wears her down.  Wanting one thing from her but getting so much more than he bargained for.  After all, a man like Hawkin does not do love, he cant.  But damn if this little spitfire isnt making him chase when he normally would be running. Kristy is back with the sixth book in the Driven series, and yes ladies  Colton does make an appearance  all alpha, overbearing brother  and all.  So let me just say what I loved about this book.  The feels.  The way some just snuck up on you.  Sure there are so many parts of this story were emotions were high and the story really had the ability to crack your resolve, but then there were these little sneaky moments.  The ones I love the most, because they come out of nowhere and they hit you head on.  There is no preparing for them, you just have to let them happen.  Oh, and boy did they happen.  Hawkin won my heart and it broke for him.  Over and over again.  He was this perfect mix of bad boy and broken.  The real tragic kind.
