The kind that make you want to buy all the glue in the world so you can put them back together again.But lets not forget our Quinlin.  She might end up being the strongest heroine that Kristy has written to date (although Rylee grew some strength as the Driven trilogy progressed, she was not this sturdy at the start).  I loved that although she was sure that giving into Hawkin had nothing but bad idea written all over it, she still wasnt ready to live with the regrets of saying no.Much like the books prior in this series, the twists took me by surprise.  This could have been just simple romance, it was all there  but nope.  Kristy turned it up a notch and delivered so much more with her story than just two people falling in love.  The characters and their backgrounds offered enough for this to be a solid story on its own  but the story that Kristy gave us took this to the next level.I was a little worried after reading Hads book if Im being honest.  I was worried that the voice of this author would always be shadowed by Coltons story.  That worry is gone.  I think with Sweet Ache, she really came into her own and although this is still part of the Driven Series, it really stands on its own and in a way was able to combine all of the feels that she delivered with the three books for Colton and Rylee into one story for these two, and without making it seemed rushed.  I cant wait for the next release!

Elizabeth didnt always want to be a trophy wife, but a hard lesson was learned as a child and finding a man that could provide her with money became far more important than finding one that could provide her with love.Married to Senator Cal Fitzgerald, rising Presidential hopeful should sound like a dream, but it quickly becomes a living nightmare.  Enter Alex Matthews.  Ex-Military. Sex on Legs. Hired Security. And her live in babysitter.Sparks fly as the stranger gets through her walls and sees the woman living behind the shell of the woman she shows the world.  But leaving her husband is not an option, not when he holds all the cards.This was a suspenseful romantic read that was okay  not great  but not bad either.  The one thing that really bothered me the most was the mix up of the use of the term Congressman while dealing with a Senator.  An easy slip, but something that definitely should have been caught along the writing/editing/early reading process.  I am not a stickler for grammar s***, but slips like this typically catch my attention and is a bit of pet peeve... so I sucked it up and pushed forward, wanting to know just how this twisted tangle was going to end.I was a bit surprised by the ending and the plot twist, so very well done on that front.  I had some thoughts as to where this was going and although I was close, I was far enough off that it still gave me a bit of a jolt of surprise when I hit the ending.This was my first read by this author and I can say the ending sure left me wanting to know exactly what was going to happen next.  And although I did not love this story, I did enjoy it.  Mixing in politics into romance is a hard sale for most.  It is something that evokes such polar reactions that I usually try to avoid this at all costs.

I feel like Ive been waiting forever for a Blake story and although this was a short look into the younger life of Blake, rather than his full novel, Unsaid... I was so freaking happy to finally get this boy in my hands!Avery delivers another fantastically funny read that still manages to be hot as F!  I loved the dynamic between Diego, but so fell in love with the idea of him and Miguel.  You cannot go into a story from Avery Aster without being prepared to laugh your tail off. There is just no way to avoid it.  Sexual antics are pushed to the extreme and this group of friends just cant help but land themselves into trouble at every turn!I adore getting a chance to see the start to these characters, their bonds, their adventures... all of it.  I cant wait to read Unsaid and get my hands a little dirty with Blake!

Im going to go in to detail with this, since I DNFd at 26% but I do want to explain what it was that held me back. The story itself felt a tad choppy and although I was still getting through it, what did it in was word choice.UmbilicusWe have Lake Freeman, ex-military, now private security who doesnt necessarily act on the right side of the law, especially since he is the kidnapper/hero of this story. So when he sees her and reflects on her body... I need his words. I need the characters voice to match the character. Now, I am guessing even if you havent heard the word used, you can figure it out. It is a bellybutton or navel... That is what caused me to stop. I really could have chugged along even if the story hadnt kept me glued to the pages, I really liked the theme of this and this particular genre is a favorite; but I was not able to gain any connection to who the characters were because although they behaved one way and were described another... they didnt stay constant.It might be overly picky  and maybe I should have pressed forward, but this was the second time when Lake used a term that just did not fit who he had been built as.

In Silent Whisper (book one of the Limbo Series) we learn of Parrishs gift, now with one stalled soul rescue under her belt, she gets a request from her Ma for round two. As Parrish begins to journey back to the seventies, via Ceces memories, a love story that ends in tragedy is retold, leaving Parrish to aid FBI agent Marco Trevani Jr. in bringing her murder to justice and bringing peace to two souls, one here on earth and the other thats been stuck in the in between.Clouds in my Coffee was so freaking good. I found myself forgetting that we were in the midst of revealing a murder mystery as I started to fall in love with Cece & Erik. But although we get a tragic ending to one love story, we get to see the glimmer of hope of a new love story develop with the introduction of Marco.Andrea has been able to pull of two books so far in this series that allows the reader to experience love stories that although they dont end with a typical happily ever after, they still leave you with peace in the end and closure. I found myself wishing that shed continue this series but with the use of other fictional characters that weve had to suffer the loss of. Imagine if your favorite book boyfriend that was offed by that author (who shall not be named) could come back to give us closure! I would die. Happy.I look forward to the additional books in this series, to find the closure of the tragic side of love and watch a new love bloom between Parrish and Marco.

In the emotional conclusion of the His Series, Finding Me brings this story full circle. Weve watched Ace and Max fall in love and fall apart. We saw the events as they played out through both sets of eyes and as the reader, we were absolutely gutted right alongside these two.Ace ran. Escaped. Her whole world was destroyed with one phone call. Now on the East Coast, Ace is finally trying to get a grip a girl named Harper. But returning home for her sisters wedding is going to place her right back in the middle of all her fears.When I picked up Becoming His in February of this year, I had no idea that I was about to discover a gripping romance that was going to take such a hold on my heart. I fell in love with all of the characters, but my heart was stolen by Max. A slightly damaged man who had found the love that he had been searching for in the arms of Ace. Their relationship was a joy to watch unfold and was heartbreaking to watch fall apart.I went into Finding Me with hope. I knew that Ace had to find some way of reconciling her past and that Max had to find some way to forgive her for running. But I had not expected the level of angst that had me in knots throughout this entire read.There was not a single moment where I could predict where this story was going. I loved it (although I may have screamed out some choice words at certain times). This story held my attention, it filled in all the pieces I needed to accept Max and Aces actions and it ultimately made me love the series so much more than I thought possible.Mariah Dietz is a superb writer  she gave her characters depth, she created an entire fictional world where they existed. This wasnt a story or series of two main characters, this was a story that every character had a major part. You got to know them, they aided in driving the story forward and although the first book was a little overwhelming with getting to know all the Bosse girls, I walk away feeling like I have a handful of new friends. This series was her debut, but there was nothing green about the way she molded her words or told her story.This book was a fantastic conclusion to this series and will go down as one of my favorite romance series of the year. If you have not yet read this series, you need to do that (right now!)  it will not disappoint. Bravo Mariah on another successful release and I cant wait to see what you have in store for us next.

In Black Balled we see two industry adversaries face off: the author and the critic.L. Blackburn is trying to make a name for himself and an indie author when he finds his latest review slammed by review Babu.  And as much as he knows he should not engage, he just cant help himself.  With one quick hit of the post button, the drama ensues as these two face off in a battle of wills that ends up in the most unlikely of places... the bedroom.What I enjoyed about BB was the humor and bits of sarcasm that we were treated two as these two battled it out, but coupled with an actual story line that gave both characters some emotional depth as the story progressed.  I had read books from Andrea before, but this was my first initiation into Evas writing.... I have to say that it wont be my last.Tossed in with the humor and intriguing coupling of the writer/reviewer was the sexy times these two shared.  I am still fairly new to the M/M genre of romance although I have a few titles under my belt, it is a genre that I do find myself overly picky when it comes to one-clicking a book.  But these two deliver the heat perfectly!  I loved seeing two very alpha men struggle to stay on top but be oh-so-willing to bottom when it came time.Now, I know this story has more than its share of publicity and quite a few readers that were content with blacklisting Black Balled without further thought.  And yeah I can see that there can be some lines of comparison drawn, but in reality even if the suspicions had any truth behind them... I say put on your big girl undies and suck it up.I feel my own little rant going on...I read a lot.  I read books I love and I read books that I dont love.  That is just how it shakes out.  A great book loved by most can easily be a book disliked by some.  I dont expect my reaction to any book to be the same as anyone elses.  However, I do try to take some care in my reactions to a book that I dont enjoy.  That is my personal choice.  I may not succeed in lessening a blow with a low rating when it comes to an author reading said review  but the intent is always to explain why I did not like something  not to drag the author through the mud.  Now, imagine you are dating a comedian and you screw with them, guess what is going to happen.  Youre going to become the punchline of their joke on stage, your actions are going to give them material... I see reviewers who behave badly in the same light.  Does this make a writer a bully?  No, as much as the comedian is not a bully by using their own personal experiences to draw from.  So heres the deal.  You want to write your honest reactions to a book  go for it. But heck, expect some blow back and when it happens take it like a champ.As a reader who stumbles upon nasty reviews from time to time I can tell you that for the most part they prompt me to do one thing.  Typically that is to buy the book.  Honestly sometimes that purchase is just because the reviewer was just so mean that I felt like I needed to lend silent support for an author who may not be great at what they love  but did in fact have the balls to hit publish.  So that in itself deserves some praise.  So Ill sum this up by just saying  dislike a book all you want.  Dislike it for your own reasons, not for the reasons of someone else.  But also recognize the difference between someone reviewing a book and giving feedback as to what worked and what didnt work vs someone trashing another person.  I get that authors need to stew silently when it comes to seeing bad reviews, thick skin is a must but there is also a time and place when it is perfectly okay for someone to stand up for themselves.  As a reader, Ive gotten messages on both five star and single star reviews and I have to say that no matter the rating, the approaching author did so with class and ultimately making me want to continue to consider their books.  Its a hard fact to admit, but the customer is not always right, sometimes the customer is just a jackhole.  And although policy may dictate that the customer should never be told they are a jackhole, but sometimes it just feels darn good to say it out loud.

Random & Rare is the second book in the Lock & Key series that focuses not only on the love story of Grace and Dig but then splits into a part two that draws her new love story with Miller into the picture.Who wants to read a story about a dead guy?  Well this reader certainly did.  There was no doubt that the story of Grace & Dig caught my attention in Lock & Key.  Although Dig was gone, I felt so drawn to their love story that I wanted to know more of how it all started and sadly, how it ended.But this wasnt just a story about Graces first love.  Cat Porter ties in Graces past with her present all while delivering a chance a future.  I loved this about this story.  My only fault that I really found was that the first part of this story where we are given Dig and Graces story felt a bit choppy.  We jumped quite a bit scene from scene and I completely understand that this was needed  there was still a story that had to be told so the pages could not be filled with a fluid love story, but I just wanted more of them together and sort of expected the story to begin with the little girl that asks a biker to help her sister and end with a broken woman who lost everything in one moment.But getting a chance to get back to Miller and Grace filled that gap for me.  I had an idea that somehow things would play out exactly as they had, although I wasnt sure how wed get there  I just knew that it would happen.  I have to say, that was one of the most touching moments for me.  It was giving me a taste of Digs love for her long after their story ended.I am looking forward to this authors future releases tremendously.  Lock and Key is easily one of my favorite MC reads and one that stands out completely from just a general biker story.  If you love a good MC read that is filled to the brim with emotion and where the drama is not the star of the show, but rather the characters  this is one series you need to pick up.

100% Spoiler Free Review. First I owe Reanell T. a huge thank you for not only recommending this author but for sending me a copy of Beloved; which ultimately hooked me.Part two of the Consolation Duet is tricky, its all about the resolution that comes from the first part and the shocking ending of Consolation and so it would be a huge disservice to the readers out there to go into that resolution. If you have not read Consolation yet, fix that. Be wary of spoilers in reviews to Conviction  avoid them at all costs!I was dying for this book seconds after hitting the end in book one. After that ending, I knew I wouldnt survive the long (which ultimately wasnt long  a few months, but in book world that is like a lifetime!) wait. I was dying. I needed book two. This reader had questions and needed answers, but most of all I was scared to know. I was equal parts fearful and excited to start this read. I knew it was going to consume me and I also knew that I was going to be an utter mess while reading it.I was gutted within the first 10% of this book. My heart broke and then it broke again. The dual POV allowed me to get attacked by the feels at all sides  I was in tears and I didnt even make a dent in the story. At 15% I got the piece of book one that I wanted so badly and it confirmed everything I thought it would, but even that moment made everything more intense, more emotional. From this point to the halfway mark I was an utter mess. I was waiting for a huge moment that would twist my insides. The angst was delivered perfectly. I had to stay guarded, I had a heart I needed to protect but I couldnt help myself from having hope. This battle between my head and heart was all consuming and at this point, I was way past midnight and knew I hit the point of no return. There was no way I was going to be sleeping.Corinne Michaels wrote an incredibly gripping love story that was not an easy read, nor was it a simple story of two people falling in love. We grieved alongside these characters, we were standing beside them with our fist held high in anger, and we wept with them.One thing I love about this series (and the prior) is that although we are getting military heroes; we are getting a look inside the lives of the women who love them. We are shown the strength they have while they hold their lives together at home while their hearts are halfway around the world. Often times we get the romances with the soldier who has returned home, we rarely see the side of the story for those who are still active duty. I love that this author is paying homage to the wives of those serving.Jackson might have made me weak in the knees, but Liam stole the breath from my lungs. I am excited for Marks story in Defenseless and although Liam is going to be hard to top, there was something about the Mark we saw in this book that makes me think we are in for one helluva story. Now although this duet can be read as a standalone, I highly recommend that if you are going to read it  that you also read the Beloved Duet.

**Refresher: Lourdes is the photographer friend of Dair that we meet in Wild Side. We got a little taste of this story at the very end of the 3rd in that series, introducing us to the start of Heath & Lourdes twisted tale.**Lourdes is an early forties, recently divorced, mother of two who stumbles upon our brooding, twenty-five year old Heath. Everything about him screams danger but everything about him also screams sex. Hard. Punishing. Sex. Lourdes is left reeling as one encounter after the next leaves her needy in all the right places as Heath sneaks his way into her life and under her skin. But nothing is as it appears. For those that read The Wild Side, you know the backstory  or at least part of it  for new readers, hold on tight, because youre in for one helluva ride!I love R.K. Lilleys writing. Whether it is in the form of erotic romance (as we got with the Up in the Air Series, an emotional gripping romance (as we saw with Danika & Tristan) or this. A rhythmic, erotic romance that is filled the brim with suspense and teetering on the edge of darkness. The style was so different from the prior trilogies that put her on the map, yet the talent and the flawlessness was so evident from the very start.What I truly loved about his series was Lourdes. She had this confidence that we rarely see in our heroines. Sure there were slight moments of weakness, but she was not this pieced together girl verging on adulthood. She had lived a life. She had seen what the love she once held had lacked and seen the possibilities of so much more when she looked up on her friends (and yes, by friends I mean Frankie, Bianca and Danika).I think what I enjoyed most about this novel was not knowing what the heck was going on or what was going to happen. I loved that none of the pieces fit until it was time for them to fall into place. There was a constant hint of what was to come in the method that Lourdes narrated her story, but yet, even with that constant foreshadowing we were left in the dark until it was time for the lights to come on.Heath was this brutally damaged hero, which is one of my favorites. I loved that although it was so clear he craved more, his character stayed true. His growth was organic and not forced nor faked. It felt so natural as he shifted just slightly into what we saw towards the end of this novel. Nothing was rushed, it was paced perfectly.RKL produced another off the charts hot read with story. There is no doubt that every reader is going to need a little quiet time to themselves after a few encounters with Heath. Punishing doesnt even to begin to describe the way this man took what he wanted. It was unstoppable.All I can say after finishing this one is bravo~ oh, and bring us Tanner. I really want Tanner. He needs a woman to tame his wild ways!

Coops book. Okay so I do admit that Mr. Ryan had to win me over a bit, I was not a fan of his from his Sugartown days #TeamJackson all the way, but I can say without a doubt that I was easily won over. Cooper Ryan was downright delicious!Cooper Ryans life was in a downward spiral. After Holly left him (with his child) for another man, he was slowly drowning in the booze and the fame. But all that was about to change when one daring outburst tosses another red head into his path. Ali.Ali was on the brink of being swallowed alive by life. Alone, living in her car and having her dream job threatened if she refuses to become the personal assistant for one Mr. Cooper Ryan. Saying no to going on tour isnt an option, at least not when Cooper Ryan is insisting you go.Off the charts chemistry, sexual tension and a little bit of hate fuels this relationship into something explosive and utterly unexpected.So, Ms. Jenner.... where do I even begin. What the heck did I just read? Ill tell you  one hot as f#&% read, that is what I read.I never in a million years would have guessed this story was heading in THAT direction. But holy-h*** did it veer off into a fantastical fantasy world where, this girl was wishing on every star to live the life of this destitute girl for just ten minutes.Ali. B*@$#, Im jealous. And I mean that for both the real and the fictional Ali-cat ;)Again, we get a solid read that is filled with some of the hottest sex scenes that Ive read in a while and such humor that I could not keep the laughs to a reasonable level. If you have not read this author, you are missing out. Her humor is quirky and witty, a complete stand out from others in this genre. Where so many attempt, Ms. Jenner succeeds. Able to make her books not only humorous and sexy, but intense and oh-so-emotional when needed. She pulls you through the low times and catapults you during the high times. There is no room for just okay in these stories, it is just brilliant.Another stunningly sexy, hysterical, witty and emotional read from Carmen Jenner. I cant not wait for Levis book. Like, I might die if she does not hit publish like right now.

Okay, so I am a fan of the Evan Arden Series and I admit that after reading Isolated I was scared to jump into Irrevocable.  For those that have not yet read single book in this series, stop reading reviews of the final books!  Youre ruining all the fun and suspense.So Evan is back in Chicago, his stint as a law abiding citizen didnt last very long, if at all.  He lost the one woman that gave him a bit of peace because he had ties too strong to a man that he saw as a father to ever truly sever.  So he returns.  Back to Rinaldo Moretti and the mob.  Back to sleepless nights.He was only away for a few months, but things have changed.  Faces that Evan doesnt recognize and a feeling in his gut that something just isnt right.  But as Evans mind spirals he finds comfort in arms of a new woman.  A hooker, one that seems smart enough not to make the mistakes of the ones that came before.  Suddenly Evan is finding more than just slumber in her arms.  But for a man like Evan, normal just isnt going to be possible.  Normal doesnt play into his future.So I am slightly torn on this.  The writing and the story was done so exceptionally well.  No doubt there. And yeah, I got over my Lia issues near the end of this story but still feel a little on the fence over the whole thing.  And although this had strong elements of a romance story, it really lacked the romance side for me.  The action, suspense and drama were utterly nailed.  But the love just sort of felt like a very secondary part of the story.  By the time I started to have real feelings for Alina, I was looking for a grand gesture of sorts.  And I know that Evan is very limited in his abilities to be normal and I didnt need him to suddenly become this white knight... but I felt like the mob side of the story overpowered the other aspect.So here I am, a few days after finishing it.  Debating on my rating.  The writing and story  six stars all the way.  The small glitch I had with the romantic changes and romance playing a smaller role  four stars.  So the middle ground is still a five star read.  But I am still so flipping torn over the genre shift that I felt this book had.  Alina and Evan shared some hot moments but I didnt get the butterflies at their interactions like I did when Evan first met Lia in the first book. I think we had so much more time to watch that love story develop and Irrevocable just didnt lend itself enough pages to get it all down on paper for Alina and Evan.Overall as a series, this was an amazing series.  The story line was exciting and suspenseful and Evan shined as one crazy dark hero. There was a cast of characters that although you never got a chance to get too close to, you still enjoyed.  I will never hear someone say custom without thinking about Jonathan.  If you like fast paced action-romance, this is a series you should pick up.  Shay has a talent with taking on the male POV and creating a wonderful fantasy world to fall into.  Not many authors can deliver so often with the males POV  but Shay does. Each and every time.

The final installment of The Excess Series took me by complete surprise.  I will not go into details of what happens.  That is something that truly has to be experienced firsthand. What I can tell you, is that you did not see that coming!  There is absolutely no way.  Like at all.What I loved about this series, much like with the Awakening Series is the maturity of the story and the characters.  It is become more and more rare to read about women in their mid-thirties, instead we get nineteen year old girls that we are expected are mature enough and ready enough to meet the man of their dreams.  Not with this series or this author.  You get a heroine that has lived a life already.  A non-perfect life and you get to watch her discover a new opportunity and a chance at love.  Feelings and situations are dealt with in an adult manner so the angst is low but the drama is high  if that makes sense.Aiden or Devin? Devin or Aiden? By this part in the series we have all made our choice. I know I made mine.I cant recommend this authors books enough.  If you need a great read then look no further.  So far her two series have been absolutely fantastic.  The writing is solid, the plot is a bit unpredictable and the sex is off the charts hot.

Media brings you the final three installments of the Social Media Series (Status, Profile and Home).  As we have all come to expect from Julie's writing, we kick off part two of the bundle with what almost feels like a whole new set of books. We are getting a glimpse at the real Grace and Vaughn.  We are getting pieces to the puzzle that we need in order to solve it.  But again, this is a JA book - so we won't be solving anything until she is ready for us to see it.This series was nothing like I expected.  We start off with this sweet(ish) romance between a fan girl that is finding herself in the arms of the movie star she's fantasied about for years.  A fantasy that wanted and proving to be a bit too much for our Grace to take.  But what we get in part two is so much more.  More than I could have seen coming; a twisty plot line and characters that leaped off the pages as they took shape.Julie delivered yet another hit with this sexy, twisty romance series!

Social is the first three installments of the Social Media series that were released late 2014; this bundle consists of Follow, Like and Block.  So I won't go into the individual books, you can read those reviews if you wish.  From where we start with book one (Follow) and where we end up in Block - it would give far too much away.So I'll just say this...Don't let the start of this series fool you.  Sure, some may give up and miss out on one heck of an experience.  For those that are #fans of Julie's work, you know that nothing is ever as it seems and that she'll reveal all that to you in her own time, her own pace.  The story of Grace and Vaughn is no different.In the start of this series we get to know the characters.  We see who they are on their own and we start to get the real set up for who they can be together.  Oh, and yeah we get this hint of a secret.  Someone is hiding something.  Or maybe it's both of them that are hiding something?The first three books of this serial novella had my attention.  I was dying to know what was going to happen, how Julie was going to lay it all out for us as readers and ultimately I just waited to experience it all play out.  With total faith in this author's ability to get me there, when she was ready for me to arrive.  And once I got there, yeah.  She nailed it.

This NAS is an excellent intermediate unit between the basic models from companies like WD and Seagate, and cheaper than larger more epensive units from QNAP and Synology. Setup is simple, and the unit was up and running in under 10 minutes. Apps are plentiful and the UI is pleasing. Because this is a lower power unit, I'm not seeing the same transfer speeds as on my DS214play from Synology, but it is still fast enough for day to day use with backups and remote storage. The unit has been stable with no crashes or disconnects during my large file transfers.All in all, you get yourself a really flexible NAS with a fantastic UI, without the price of a big name.

(Written with my 9 year old daughter):The game started off well, then it started getting a little weirder, like when you have to punch back some hits from enemies, but the game wouldn't let you - this may be a glitch, or poor gameplay.Thew game is about two twins dipper and Mable and they go to find mystery junk for their Gruncle Stan and with the game, the mystery junk is hard to get to, and you can't proceed till you gather all the junk.I kind of got bored with it pretty quickly, and as said, it started great, then just got annoying when things didn't work right.

The new Q-See QCN8029Z is an excellent HD PTZ camera with shoddy software. The camera itself is excellent - and produces incredible picture quality and rock solid streaming.Installation is simple - you use the included template to find your location, unscrew three hex screws, then remove the top off the camera. Sadly, there is no separate mounting plate, so when you open the top, the entire inside of the camera is exposed. It would have been better to have designed a mounting plate so you don't come face to face with the inside. This also means you need to be very careful to install in dry weather, and to screw it shut correctly when done to prevent moisture getting inside the camera.Connections come from a power plug and Ethernet jack, though it does support PoE, which sadly means the power plug is then left unused (and dangling) with no included hardware to close it off. Again, in a perfect world, PoE support would mean you could remove or hide the power cable.This brings us to the software - which is a complete trainwreck of poorly translated stuff with badly documented features. I could easily detect the camera using the config software, but the NVR app (SmartPSS) is horrible.Thankfully, I was able to add it to BlueIris and use it there, though in BlueIris, I can't get the PTZ to work as it appears to be a newer generation Dahua PTZ protocol (yes, Q-See is owned by Dahua/Hikvision).Once in BlueIris, the camera is amazing. I get a rock solid 1080p stream with 30fps. At night, the camera is incredible sensitive.PTZ is speedy and the zoom lens is excellent going from very wide to really close.All in all, a great camera, at a pretty decent price for 1080p PTZ, but one you'll most likely need to invest more in to replace the software.

Short version of the review: The product works, the instructions are quite extensive, and it takes around 30 minutes to make a small batch of cookies.Long version: The oven looks cute, doesn't weigh much, and comes with everything you need to make a single batch of Thinmints.Setup isn't too hard, plug in, turn on and start work on the batter. The Thinmint instructions take around 30 minutes including a variety of steps, including cooling, washing and decorating. The small tray needs to be lubed up a little.In our case, the water mentioned in the directions was too little - we needed to add almost twice as much to get a decent consistency. Scooping is a challenge because the batter is extremely sticky.The simple list of steps:Wash and dry all the parts.Mix the cookie batterScoop into the traySlide the tray into the ovenCook for 7-9 minutes (needed 10 in our case)Let cool for 10 minutesSlide the tray outRemove the cookies, and place on wax/parchment paperMelt the icing/chocolate coverDecorate the cookiesLet cool, eatIngredient packs are around $5, but are currently in high demand on Amazon, so prices are being pushed up by hoarders. If you can't find a mix here for the right price, just try your local Target.All in all, this is a fun product, and my 9 year old was able to follow all the steps on her own.

This 21.16 ounce jar contains around 120 small 5 gram squares of chocolate. My initial annoyance is that the weight of the product is in ounces, and the weight of the chocolate is in grams. This way, they make it harder to find out you are essentially paying $60 for 120 tiny squares of chocolate, or 50 cents each when you ignore the price of the pretty poor quality glass jar. Unlike a good quality jar, this one lacks a rubber seal, it does come with a plastic shrink-wrap.The chocolate itself is just ok - keep in mind that this is essentially just the premium brand from the Hershey company, despite the cool German sounding name. The taste is pretty boring. The darks are pretty intense, going up to an 82%, which is a bit too high for a delicate piece of chocolate and an an average taste. The milk on the other hand is also too dark at 41%, it lacks the sweetness you'd expect from a good piece of milk chocolate. For a starter in chocolate (and someone who gets Scharffen Berger really will be), I'd recommend staying no higher than 70% on the dark as it is less intense.There are many other (better) brands of Chocolate on Amazon where you get better value for money, a better chocolate, and perhaps a slightly less attractive packaging, but quite frankly, I'd rather get more chocolate and less packaging. For lower budget shoppers looking for good quality, consider some of the bars from Leonidas or other Belgian brands, or Dutch brands like Droste found here on Amazon. You'll get a much better product at a better price. The Droste Pastilles ship in a 12 pack for $30, which will get you 42 ounces, or twice as much good chocolate for half the price. Again, they won't come in a cheap glass jar, but for most people, the jar will just end up in the trash anyway. Most premium brands also have gift boxes here on Amazon, where you'll get a little less chocolate, but still save up to 50% on the price of this assortment.

Where to begin with this pen... I've been a Livescribe user since the very first pen, and I've gone through all of their models in recent years. I currently use a Sky WiFi, along with many of their accessories.My first frustration with Livescribe 3 was its Android support - customers were made to wait well over a year for Android support. Sadly, that is also one of the major frustrations with Livescribe in general - their software products are a mess. Livescribe desktop and the various SmartApps are all gone (along with my investment), and the current newest pen is essentially phone only, taking advantage of the cloud.This Moleskine version is a great looking product (initially). It includes the pen, Stylus tip, MicroUSB cable, Molesine book, fabric pouch for the book and replacement ink.The pen is massive - really massive. It isn't too uncomfortable to use, and I do appreciate the rotating ink retractor, as it means you don't need to use the silly covers as on the previous pens. The pen clip is too rigid, making it almost impossible to wear on a shirt.As for the software, it usually works. The phone needs two apps for some reason - Livescribe Link and Livescribe+. Why they couldn't just put both features in a single app is beyond me.Transfers are fast - 10 pages were in my phone in seconds. Character recognition is weak - and despite a relatively clean handwriting, I'd say it only gets around 20% right. I also own the Neo N2 Smartpen, and find it much easier to use. It is also smaller, but lacks the pen retraction.Other downsides include the silly fabric cover that makes it impossible to use the left pages of the book as the fabric only covers a portion of the front - which means you are writing on a non-flat surface.All in all, the pen isn't all that bad, and I'm still a huge Livescribe fan, but this pen has too many shortcomings to be worth $225. Livescribe has a decade of experience to perfect their pen, and this is sadly just not something I consider perfect.

Unless you are trained to look at a watch and determine its value, this Lucien Piccard watch will definitley fool you into thinking the lucky owner has a very expensive timepiece. The watch comes in a well made box, but shipping has made a few dents in it. The watch itself is wrapped around its holder, in a plastic protection sleeve, with a tag (no price). The build qualuty is excellent, and accuracy has not been a problem. Of course, this is not a handmade Swiss chronometer, it is in fact made in China. Many Chinese vendors sell these watches under a variety of names, but they rarely come in a such a nice box with good packaging, plus it usually take 3-4 weeks to get one, whereas this one can be shipped on Prime.Definitely something that most people should own, as there are too many peiple who dress up nice, then put on their lousy plastic watch. If you own a good suit, you need to own at least one good watch, and this is a great place to start.

This kit comes with the microphone, decent quality cable, a carrrying case, mic stand adapter and a small manual. What it lacks, is any kind of software, a table stand and headphones. The microphone isn't bad, but it isn't great either. You can not replace the mic with a better XLR version as the rig lacks phantom power, so you are essentially stuck with it.Still, it is much, much better than using the mic built into your phone, and the whole setup is great for on-site interviews or other recordings. There is plenty of software out there that'll help record and check the levels.My main issue with this is price - at $100 it is priced far higher than most other products in this category. The microphone is apparently the star here, and while it does perform admirably, it doesn't perform at a $100 level.

In my review, I'm going to compare this new Epson PictureMate C11CE84201 photo printer to the most popular competitor on the market - the Canon Selphy CP910. Why? Read in and see the biggest difference between these and decide for yourself which printer is best.The basics are present in both printers:Wi-FiDisplayCard readerExcellent print qualityCamera supportGoogle Cloud Print supportThat is pretty much where the comparison ends as the Canon uses Dye-Sub technology whereas the new Epson uses their excellent inkjet tech. Included with the Epson is a starter cartridge, and like most Epsons, it wants to go through a lengthy (4 minute) initialization before you can use it.Based off current print supply prices on Amazon, the Epson is more expensive to operate. The Canon print pack (ribbons and paper) is $28, and the similar Epson pack is currently $48. That said, the MSRP for the Epson T320 print pack is $41. This put prints at the following prices:Canon 28 centsEpson 41 centsThis is a pretty significant difference. Print quality on the Epson is a lot brighter and more vivid, and prints come out much faster. I tested 1:39 seconds on the Epson, and 2:12 on my Canon. The Canon is much smaller, but it needs a lot of room on the front and rear to pass the paper through. Because the Canon uses Dye-sublimation, the prints appear to be less sharp, but in a side by side, most people won't see the difference. If you are a pro photographer, you'll most likely disagree with me here, but your average point and shoot photos looks perfectly fine on both printers.Pricing is also way different - a Canon Selphy CP910 is $80, and this new Epson is a whopping $249.Both models support Google Cloud Printing and the Epson adds support for their own Epson Connect Services, Both models claim support for many years of archival quality prints, but without waiting 100 years, I have no way to confirm this. The Epson claims a 200 year use when stored in an album.The major difference between the two is that the Canon prints have a small fold-off perforated tab on the edges, and it can only do 4x6, whereas the Epson is true edge-to-edge with support up to 5x7.Epson prints are  5760 x 1440 dpi, the Canon (since it uses Dye-Sub is only 300x300).Both printers continue the dismal history of not including a USB cable. For the Canon, you need MiniUSB, the Epson uses MicroUSB. And finally, both have a built in card reader and USB host option for connecting to a camera.Portability is also a big issue - the Epson is just too large to be portable, especially since it uses liquid inks. In the Canon, there is no liquid ink, and it has support for a battery pack (an additional $50-$75). If you want to print photos off-site, then the Canon is the best option.In the end, it is hard to justify this printer over the much, much cheaper Canon. Prints for consumers look the same to me, and with the $170 price difference, the average consumer really doesn't need the Epson. Don't get me wrong, it is a damn fine printer, but you can buy several years worth of ink and paper with the savings on the Canon.And finally, something I REALLY hate about the Epson is that it wants to print setup instructions for the cloud services on a piece of photo paper instead of just displaying it. This means you've gone through 2 pieces of the included paper sheets and some ink just to get the printer online.Reasons to pick the Epson over the Canon? Speed is one of them.

What you get in the latest version of this mount is not what I'm used to from Cheetah. As soon as the box arrives, you'll notice something - it is much shorter than the mount should be. This is because you need to assemble 50% of this thing yourself. In the box is a half assembled unit, and a variety of bagged metal parts.The entire left side comes in pieces, and you'll need a variety of tools (not included) and around 60 minutes to put this together the way it should be.Sadly, the final assembly is not as good as Cheetah mounts used to be, and even with careful work, the end result is kind of shoddy - the whole unit curves a little and the back is not straight. That said, it did straighten itself out once I mounted it thanks to the screws going into my wall studs, but it is still bad to see something go on the wall that is crooked.Additionally, I quite badly injured myself unscrewing one of the screws in a rail as I failed to secure the piece to a work bench when I tried to loosen one of the screws to prepare the TV mounting portion. While I do take some responsibility for this, putting a TV mount together should not require safety gear unless you are drilling into a concrete wall. I have a one inch deep gash right under my eye. Half an inch higher and I would have damaged my eye. Some of the screws are pre-installed in their factory, and need to loosened and removed before use, but they over-tightened many of them.The price is definitely fine, and the final unit isn't bad at all, but I'd recommend spending a bit more on a unit that comes fully assembled. Additionally, I think it is pretty disingenuous of Cheetah mounts to not mention the amount of work required to assemble the mount.

In every possible way (other than price), I find this better and easier to use than Photoshop Elements. When compared to the full Adobe CS or Adobe Photography package, this one is also much cheaper, but compared to Photoshop CS, it costs a little more.Installation was a breeze. The include bonus content is quite extensive too, and with this ultimate edition, you also receive ON1 Picture Effects, AfterShot 2 (Which is great for managing RAW content), Perfectly Clear 2 SE, perfect for those (like me) who don't have a lot of editing skills, as it automatically does your post processing, in a much better quality than say Picasa "I'm feeling lucky" mode. And finally, the DVD also includes around 100 free backgrounds, which are not all that valuable or impressive.These tools alone are fantastic value, and that is even before you've immersed yourself in PaintShop Pro Ultimate. Inside the package are all the features you'd expect in a top of the line editing suite - features like auto text wrapping, Geolocation support for data extraction from your files, 4K monitor support (which works very nicely to scale the interface correctly.Additionally, the package has some great batch editing options, for adding watermarks or removing metadata.All in all. this is a real worthy upgrade, and at just under $100, you get a LOT for your money.

This keyboard is an excellent edition for many media players or TV's with USB support. In my test, I have it on an X810 Sony 4K Android  TV, and in most apps it works perfectly. The trackpad is responsive, range is great and the illuminated keys are perfect at night. In some apps (like Amazon Prime Video), the keyboard does not work, but this is an issue on their side, and not Logitech as the on-screen keyboards is made to work with the arrow keys on a remote, and not with a USB keyboard. The keyboard charges off MicroUSB, which is good and bad - it lasts long, but when it is dead, you need to charge before you can use it, instead of just swapping out some batteriesAll in all, if you do a lot of typing, you'll definitely get a lot of use out of this. That said, it is pretty expensive for what it does, and you can get the same (without the backlighting) out of a $25 Logitech keyboard/trackpad. You need to be the judge of whether backlighting and recharging are worth $100.

I feel horrible doing this, but there is no other rating I can give to these other than a single star. The company (from its videos) appears to be pretty smart, and dedicated to their product, but what they released is quite simply not ready for prime time. In the cheap copies piece of manual included, they make it quite clear that these are not for consumers, and only for developers, but that should not permit the manufacturer to release something of really questionable quality.Let's walk through some of the issues:ComfortPut simply, these things are unwearable. They are so extremely uncomfortable that after about 4 minutes I couldn't bear wearing them any longer. They are extremely tight and quite heavy, so the combination makes them downright useless. They are also massive.The nose bridge is very uncomfortable, and there is a weird piece of plastic above it which is held on by 2 weak magnets, and appears that it will be lost int he first week.ControlsAgain, poorly designed here. The buttons are integrated into the slightly sticky black rubber housing, and there is zero tactile feedback, so you don't know when you actually power them on. You also need to press really hard on volume and the trackpad button on the bottom.The trackpad is no better, and controlling the cursor is really tough. I also couldn't get two-finger scrolling to work, which means it is virtually impossible to scroll though Android lists of options.OSThe unit comes with Android 4.4 KitKat - and that too is unacceptable in this day and age. Almost 30% of all Android devices have been upgraded to Android 5 Lollipop, so releasing 4.4 in 2015 just won't cut it.AppsThis may be sold as a developer edition, but there are no sample apps anywhere to be found. The company also makes regular mention of augmented reality, but they clearly didn't bother creating any demo apps to show off these capabilities. The only non-stock app installed is a sensor readout interface.To get the most out of the unit, you need to push Teamviewer to it using ADB, which will then allow you to open a remote desktop connection to it. This also makes it pretty clear that doing any real work on the unit is too painful to complete.DisplayThe company makes a lot of claims about their "Flip-Vu" folding display, but in reality all it does is move up and down - you can set it for see-through (like in the Epson Moverio or glance (like in Google Glass). They claim the display offers 33 pixels per degree of vision, on a 640x480  display. Sadly, even with this, getting the unit aligned for a good image requires a lot of fiddling. The standard angles of the flip-vu are not sufficient for a good picture, and you end up having to move the whole thing higher or lower on your nose. When you wear them, you also see too much of the frame surrounding the display unit projected on the optics.Value for moneyThe number one way to know that this product is doomed is that the manufacturer didn't even bother including a MicroUSB cable. These usually retail for $3, so not including one with a $1000 pair of augmented reality glasses is pretty weak. They also feel pretty crappy - definitely not $1000 specs. There is no case, no replacement frames, no headphones and no AC adapter. Most AR / HMD products I've tested come with a variety of accessories. Again, I'm fully aware that this is a developer unit, but other similar products are also sold strictly as development platforms, but do come with a good variety of accessories.There are several decent competitors out there, including Google Glass, which of course relies on your phone connection to use. The Epson Moverio BT-200 is another excellent option - which is half the price of the ORA-1, and offers DUAL displays. They are a bit heavier, but the display quality is much better, and it has a small external Android controller with integrated trackpad (and support for 2-finger scrolling). The Moverio also offers a built in custom app store and several pre-installed demo apps.All in all, this is a beta version of something that may become something good at some point, but is nowhere near close enough for retail sales, or even for developers. The SDK from Optinvent is impossible to find. On the Optinvent site, there are two videos showcasing the product - one shows a non-existent version of the ORA-1 with a much smaller frame, the other is a bit more realistic, showing the Android app drawer and a basic compass. There are no videos showing the ORA-1 with a truly well built augmented reality app, and the only options out there appear to be the same ones anyone can download from the app store (like Google Sky Map).Again, I apologize to the Optinvent team for such a brutal review, but charging $1000 for something this weak is only something Google can get away with, and their beta product was far more polished than the ORA-1.

Many of the features on this mid $30 stylish dual USB dock are nothing special - USB 3.0 support, dual bays for 2.5" and 3.5" drives, support for additional SATA drive protocols (UASP) and a decent package which includes a good quality USB 3.0 cable.What sets this specific product apart is that it has built in clone capabilities. With two drives, you can create instant clones of the source, especially handy for in an IT department where you are doing a lot of deployments. On the front of the unit is a clone button, and it has several LED lights that show activity, power and clone status.I tried several clones - first with a smaller drive (a WD 250GB), and copied to an identical drive. This is paramount to getting a successful clone - the target drive needs to be the same size or larger. Keep in mind that actual formatted size varies from vendor to vendor, so be sure to check the sticker on the drive for the exact formatted capacity.A second clone between 2 Samsung 120GB SSD drives worked fine too, but my third test using 1TB drives (Seagate) didn't work right. The unit started (or what appeared to be started), but progress never went up, even though I could hear the heads moving. Since this is such a cheap dock, it lacks an LCD display with error messages or status.All in all, your experience is hit and miss, but at this price point, you may end up finding it lacking as a clone dock, leaving you with a perfectly usable dual bay USB 3.0 dock.

The parent who has their kid(s) come home to this will be the best parents in the world. To start off, it arrives in the largest box I've ever seen from Amazon - the poor FedEx driver had to drag it up our driveway as it was too large to lift.The Unicorn itself is quite well made - parts are very soft and squishy, and others are rigid. It is sturdy enough to sit on for a bit, but not to replace a rocking horse.The size in the picture represents the height with a child around 3-4. My 9 year old comes quite a bit above it.The mane, tale and face are all very cuddly, and it has been a huge hit. At just under $100, it is definitely not a cheap toy, but most certainly one that will be very well received.

This Linksys router appears to be running DD-WRT on a heavily skinned Linksys interface. The unit has three LAN ports, a WAN port and a DMZ port. Setup took me around 20 minutes, and I used my Moto X Pure to connect using OpenVPN. Throughput on a 120mbit/s connection was around 36mbit/s. which is more than enough for anything I'd want to do (which is mostly connecting to my security cameras).The unit appears to be well made, and does't get too hot (as it lacks wireless radios to heat it up).It'll stay installed, as it provides a better and more reliable VPN endpoint than the VPN options in other products (including routers with basic VPN support built in). It is also (in the long run) cheaper than paying for a VPN service, unless you use that service to get endpoints in other countries of course...

I'll refrain from touting any credentials that make me a "professional IT person" - Here are the steps I took to get this router up and running:I used Wi-Fi scanner on my Android phone to determine the best channels - and set the range extender up to use channels as far away as possible from my main router. Once placed, I set the channel to rebroadcast setup security to my main router had the link up right away. Going from the router to extender to Ethernet to my laptop, I measured 89mbit/s, when directly on the main router Wi-Fi, I measure 104mbit/s, which means the speed loss is quite limited, and the connection is definitely faster than when on Powerline which was my previous setup.The interface is rather messy, and documentation is quite limited - but there wasn't much I couldn't find when I needed it. I have not experienced any signal drops yet, which is most likely due to ensuring I was not overlapping on any of my other channels.

Things you need to know about this projector:VERY bright - even in a partially lit meeting room, the projector handles itself very wellResolution is 720p - which means 1280x768, which is sufficient to read any text in a presentation, but may be too low for a small font Excel sheetLCD - which means no color banding as you see on a DLPUnder $650 - which is incredible for a projector with these featuresWiFi enabled - which means you can join the WiFi network created by the projector to send content from your phoneMHL and HDMI - which means you can connect any HD source, or use a dedicated MHL cable to connect a phone or Roku stick. With the Roku stick installed, you can actually control some of the features using the Roku remote.As a meeting/business projector, this thing ROCKS, and if you take it home on the weekend for entertainment, you won't be let down - other than the relatively weak speaker. There is also no Audio output on the projector, so you'll need to use an HDMI audio extractor like this one:http://www.amazon.com/J-Tech-Digital-Premium-Extractor-Converter/dp/B00G9FDJNA/ref=sr_1_3?s=audio-video-accessories&ie=UTF8&qid=1444443457&sr=1-3&keywords=hdmi+audio+extractorWith that, you can hook up the projector for video, and route the audio to different source. Alternatively, you may be able to route it through a speaker bar if it supports HDMI Audio pass-through.All in all, a good investment for both entertainment and business, but its strongest features are definitely for the meeting room.

This is a decent entry level knife set, sadly, the quality is not in line with other products from this brand. At first use, you'll notice that they are definitely not as sharp as they should be, but a few minutes with a whetstone or other knife sharpening product can take care of that.In the kit, besides the sturdy block, you get all the knives a decent kitchen needs (with the possible exception of a large cleaver). After 7 days use, and several times handwashed and in the dishwasher (which they advise against), I have yet to see any rusting or staining, and I'd be very disappointed if I did as stainless steel shouldn't rust to the point others mentioned.The set is made in China, and you can tell some shortcuts were taken - the block is acacia, but when you inspect it, it appears to be acacia on the outside only, and given its weight, I suspect it is not solid acacia. The rivets are not 100% flush on each knife either. At its usual price point here on Amazon, it is only moderately well priced, there are better deals to be found, especially when brands like Henckels and Zyliss sell similar sets for less.

At first glance, this new Epson VS240 appears to be an incredible value for money - you get the incredible Epson 3LCD projection technology (which means not having to deal with the drawbacks of DLP), a great compact form factor, HDMI and a hole host of other features. What you also get is SVGA - which means 800x640 resolution, and in this day and age that just isn't acceptable. Unless you are 100% sure you can get away with this low resolution, spend a little bit more and get one with higher resolution.At SVGA, the resolution is just enough for some very basic computer connectivity or TV/video content that you can deal with in a resolution below HD. If all you ever do is some presenting in PowerPoint, make sure your text is larger than usual, so you'll prevent seeing jagged edges, or make the text entirely unreadable. On a screen around 110 inches, Excel sheets are barely readable without making the text much larger.Aroubd $100-$150 more gets you a 720p projector, where the resolution is high enough for actual business work, or even for some entertainment, but keep in mind that none of the projectors in this series are really well suited for movies.In operation, the projector is a real dream - relatively quiet, really bright, easy to setup and very quick warmup.

These are NOT the Eagle Creek packing cubes you are probably used to - instead of thicker Nylon, these are made of parachute style fabric. Make no mistake though, that isn't really a bad thing as it allows these cubes to be packed down to next to nothing. They weigh nothing, are incredibly thin, and hold just as much as the original thicker ones.That said, despite all the good, I've had to remove one star for the price. You are essentially paying $10-$15 more for this thinner and lighter material, and that just doesn't seem fair. Still - these are the best packing cubes on the market, and the quality is hard to beat.

The new ATHENA (BTW, poor name as it shares its branding with a Yoga store) router is the newest from Amped Wireless. Amped Wireless routers are essentially good quality routers with their transmission levels bumped up to the maximum allowed by the FCC. What you end up with, is a router that can get your devices signal where many others can't go.This new 802.11AC router is relatively no-frills - it features all the tools you expect, but doesn't add things like media servers, VPN server or built in apps. This (to me) is a good thing, as it just opens a router up to potential issues.The results in my home are based off switching off an Asus and reception has increased by at least 30%.

Appears well made, non replaceable battery, but time will tell whether the unit works.This new Tria Age-Defying laser uses light pulses to reduce the effects of aging - the technology has been "FDA cleared", which doesn't really mean much, but Tria has along history of making good quality laser products. Given the requirement for at least 2 weeks of use, I'm going to regularly update this review with the results.Downsides to the unit are a slightly over-simplified operation - you turn it on, and it senses when it is on your skin, and uses vibrations to let you know when the laser is "firing". There is no pain or other sensation you get with hair removal lasers, so the whole process is rather pleasant.The internal rechargeable battery is not replaceable, and most likely won't last beyond 2-3 years.

Because this product page includes options for multiple products, let me clarify that my reviews is for the Belkin 3-port headset switch.The Belkin 3-port headset switch is a bit of an oddball - it is really designed for a pretty rare setup where you require three different headset sources; mobile, desktop computer and desktop phone. Sadly, the device doesn't really include many of the cables required to make the setup actually work. For most phones, you need audio (3.5mm) to rj11, and for your PC and phone, you'll possibly need other cables. What you essentially have here is the beginning of a setup - Belkin includes a sheet with parts numbers for the various other cables, but at the time of this review, none of those cables are available on Amazon. Without the desktop phone cable (for my Polycom phone), i could only test this on my smartphone and desktop. When you finally have all the cables plugged in, the setup does work, but it isn't sexy by any means. Most people are going to want to connect to their smartphone using Bluetooth, which can't be done using this switch.All in all, it works, but only for very specific setups, with very specific cables (which you can't yet get). Not impressed.

This really is the best iOS mobile controller I've ever tested. I own controllers from Mogo and Logitech, but those always felt like "mobile first, gaming second), whereas this SteelSeries controller is definitely designed around gaming first. Unlike others, there is no way to mount your phone or tablet onto the controller, but you can easily get around that with a decent standing case.The controls are excellent, and despite being paired over Bluetooth, there is not too much lag. At $40, it isn't even priced too high, and is in the same price range as similar controllers for consoles. Support is in place for iOS7 and higher, as well as OS X.Additional features include a multiplayer LED indicator (which requires app support) and a MicroUSB port (which I assume is for updating its firmware).

Let me open right away with the elephant in the room - the price of this charger is quite insane - at least 5x more than (what appears to be) comparable chargers. But this Belkin 10 port charger is in fact extremely well made, and has some features not found on other chargers.For starters, there is the immense power brick - putting out 6.6A at 24V (or 31.6A at 5V), which means it can truly deliver over 3A per port.Building the main power source in an external brick helps dissipate heat. Additionally, it features a built in fan to keep the main unit cool. The unit itself is extremely well made, with solid USB ports. And finally, this power brick is actually designed for the Belkin tablet/iPad stands and secure enclosures, and these need to operate at things like schools, tradeshows and labs - where the devices may be plugged in and charging all day long.I own several much cheaper 10 port chargers, and none feel as well made as this one.I hesitate to remove any stars for the price, quite simply because this unit is extremely well made, and is for a much more demanding audience than most cheaper chargers.

The AeroFryer is essentially a hot air convection oven. It features a blower fan, Quartz lamp heater and a mechanical timer. The whole setup feels rather cheap, with a thin aluminum cooking tray, an assortment of accessories and the top heater unit. To use it, you place a very small amount of food in the cooking tray, then place the top on it. The whole setup feels a bit cheap, and the mechanical controls don't help that much either.The cooked products are pretty decent, and the hot air convection really can crisp them up. I tried oven fries and mozerella sticks, and in each batch I got a good crisp from the fryer.That said, I don't care for the design of the unit, especially when compared to products like the T-Fal Acti-Fryer or the Philips AirFryer - in those, you don't need to disassemble the whole setup to cook something, plus they are priced around the same as the AeroFryer.

If you are looking for a well performing home theater projector, this is not it - its resolution isn't really suitable for home theater use. That said, as an office projector, this thing is incredible. It features an incredibly bright 3200 Lumen lamp, networking, MHL support, and a neat cubby to store your MHL compliant device.Some of the basics; it is your everyday run of the mill DLP projector, but it features something that makes the colors appear a bit brighter and more vivid. Startup time is short, but it lacks a good short throw setting, so you'll need plenty of space to hook it up. Even though it is an office projector, it lacks a carrying case, so expect to spend an additional $50 - $75 on a case.Audio is excellent, and it supports audio over HDMI. Inputs include dual VGA, HDMI, Composite, USB and network. The network feature is pretty slick, and once installed, you can send content to it, and mirror your own screen. This worked much better than most laptop mirroring solutions, and saved having to mess around with video cables. If you hook this up to your office network, all you need is power and LAN, and you'll be able to send content to it off any other network port. Of course, this does require you to install the software.All in all, you get a rock solid projector, 1 year warranty on the lamp, 3 years on the projector and if you happen to bring it home for the weekend, it won't let you down - it may not be designed for home entertainment, but it'll serve you well on the occasional home movie. The projector even supports active LED 3D glasses.

As a left handed mouse user, I actually appreciate the ergonomics of this mouse - and it also scores high marks from me on all other fronts. The grip is just right - it has a slightly rubberized portion, a good amount of easy to reach buttons and a good sensor that really does work on glass. Now, not many people work on a glass surface, so it also works well on other shiny surfaces.The receiver is small, and stores right inside the mouse, but the battery compartment is quite hard to open, and a real nail buster.Batteries are included in the packaging, and need to be installed (unlike most others where you need to pull a tab).The mouse has a physical on/off switch, but I prefer the system found on Microsoft mice where the mouse turns off when you put the receiver back.All in all, this mouse is a good $20 cheaper than similar pro-grade products from Logitech and Microsoft, and along with its good ergonomics, good sensor and good buttons, I give it five stars.

So little to say about an energy meter - these things either work, or they don't. What sets the Belkin apart from most others is its ability to show your carbon footprint - though it is entirely up to you whether this is a relevant metric or not.The unit comes in one of the new Amazon frustration free packages, so you'll have it up and running in no time. "Installation" is simple, and only requires you to plug the unit in, then plug your appliances or other devices into the front outlet. The gauge itself is on a nice long and thin cable, and can be placed in view.The unit appears to be quite accurate (when compared using a Fluke Clamp Meter and line splitter. My only concern is the price - the Kill-A-Watt line of meters is available for 1/5th the price, and does the same, so you are paying here for the brand, reliability and looks. As an owner of a Kill-A-Watt, I actually prefer the looks of this Belkin.

This is a pretty smart device - unlike most other activity trackers, this one adds something that is truly important to those that sit at a desk - posture alerts. Through the Lumo Lift, I've learned that there are times I slouch too much, in addition to the usual distance/step counter. The unit itself is well designed, and can be attached using magnets, or worn.Software was easy to install from the Android Play store, and paring was effortless. I own multiple other wearables, but this one impressed me the most thanks to the additional information provided that actually makes a difference at the end of the day. Steps, while important are really only an indication of what you did (or didn't), but posture and sitting down too much can make a real impact on your health. Thanks to Lumolift, I'm learning to sit up better, and start walking around once an hour

These Linksys High-Gain antennas provide 4-7dBi improvement on your router. Based off my tests on an Asus AC68U router, the results are definitely good. The antennas are extremely well made, with heavy SMA connectors (which are actually a bit too stiff and heavy if you ask me). The antenna itself is thick plastic, with a larger portion at the bottom. You definitely feel like you got something good. Given their weight and the stiffness of the SMA screw, I'd advise that you are careful not to damage your router antenna connectors screwing them on.That said, the performance increase was identical to a $20 set of 9dBi antennas I got here on Amazon. Using WiFi scanner at the farthest range I can get a reliable signal, I did not see any increase in performance.Asus sells a 9dBi antenna on a sturdy base with SMA and extension cable for $27 - which means three (for my router) are almost $50 cheaper than this kit.In fact - these antennas are so pricey that you could actually buy TWO new WiFi access points (like the Ubiquiti UniFI AP) and get better range for LESS money than an antenna set.While I'm all for better antennas, inside these things is little more than some copper and wires - nothing inside these 7dBi antennas makes them worth $130. Better range comes from good router placement, checking that you are on the right wireless channel (and not on overlapping channels), and possibly upgrading to better antennas - but you don't need to spend more than $30 on an antenna kit. If you use an Android device, I highly recommend WiFi Scanner software from inSSIDer - it'll show you your signal strength, overlapping channels and more. In most cases, 10 minutes with this will get you more ways to fix your WiFi than spending money on antenna kits.

The Recon Jet eyewear has been one of the most anticipated wearable products since it was announced almost 2 years ago. Sadly, a lot has changed in the wearables world, and the Jet has been left behind.The specs are impressive;CameraGPSBluetooth and ANT radiosRemovable battery packRecon styled sunglassesOptical trackpadRecon proprietary Android OSSetup is not as complex as others made it seem - you do need to start the install on a computer, which is a bit odd, especially for a wearable that will "live" connected to your smartphone.In the box is a small and pretty useless fioldout manual, a Micro USB cable, carrying case and the Jet glasses. The lack of an AC charger is a disappointment as it would have been cheap to include and would have made the product a bit more complete. In the case are some open spaces for what I can only assume is for spare batteries, but when you open the case for the first time, you can't help feel underwhelmed and wondering if something is missing.Operation is ok, but not great. You lose a lot of field of vision in your right eye where the ocular display sits. There is a small joystick style adjustment knob to move the display around, and you'll use that along with the adjustable nose bridge to get the perfect fit. In my case, I got a relatively good fit, but it never seemed to be perfect.Compared to my Google Glass, having the display at the bottom of your vision takes some getting used to, and the display unit is much larger for the same resolution. Also, the display on the Jet is not see-through like on the Glass.Controls are good - using a small optical trackpad and a small rocker button.Using the Jet in the real world is tricky to explain - if you found people wearing Glass to be weird, you'll get a real laugh out of people wearing these. You essentially turn into a mix of Robocop and Georgi Laforge from Star Trek.Once setup on your phone, Jet shows a great amount of information on its display which of course syncs to your mobile device and online site.This brings me to the biggest problem - since this product was announced, better wearables have hit the market. Android wear devices like the Sony Smartwatch 2 feature GPS, the Microsoft band does the same, and of course, the newest FitBit also offers GPS. One thing these devices don't offer is ANT connectivity. The new Garmin Vivoactive does offer GPS and ANT+ support, which means you can get something that is almost 1/3 the price, with the same sensors, without looking like a dork.Don't get me wrong - there are definitely situations where having an HUD is convenient, and biking with the Jet is a real treat, but it feels incomplete. App support is coming soon, and Recon actually managed to get LESS battery life out of the Jet than with Google Glass, which is quite an achievement. 4 hours is all you'll get, which means the product becomes useless halfway through a long bike ride.All in all, the product just isn't as impressive as the hype would have made us believe. It came out. The product was announced in January 2013, and if it came out in springtime of 2013, it would have been amazing. Sadly, coming out in the summer of 2015 just makes it too little, too late. There are not enough sensors, not enough great apps at launch, and limited battery life. All in all, a real shame because I really wanted to love these.

The GOAL ZERO Venture 30 power pack is a battery pack in a very crowded field of other chargers. Inside the pack are Li-NMC cells with a total capacity of 7800mAh, and with the usual losses, this means you'll get around 2 full charges of a standard smartphone when you start charging around 20%. The pack also features a built in MicroUSB cable (sorry Apple users).The pack has dual 2,1A outputs, which means it can charge an iPad or other high power USB device. Per its specifications, the ports are "smart", and it even includes a shipping mode, a built in multi-mode flashlight and a very good waterproof rating. Despite its high waterproof rating, the top USB port is unprotected, so you may need to blow water or dust/sand out of it.Sadly, despite all of these features, some of the basics are lacking; its input charging capacity never got above 0.5A - which means an entirely full charge took 19 hours - totally unacceptable. I've tried multiple chargers and USB cables, but it never gets about half an amp. Much cheaper packs from brands like Anker can charge up to 2A - which makes its charging speed almost four times faster, but of course those lack the ruggedness of this pack.The waterproof Unifun pack (Amazon ID B00MG9VVW4) is just $20, and has higher capacity, can charge at 2A, has a brighter flashlight and even has a built in carrying clip. It does lack the built in cable of the Venture 30, and doesn't specifically support solar charging from other Goal Zero products.Of course, GOAL ZERO is a top quality brand, but there is a limit as to what an a-name brand can charge for something this simple.

As a case, this Case Logic case isn't too bad - it fits my Rebel T5i very snugly, but my A6000 with 18-105 lens fits with some space. What does this case in though is the price. $60 is essentially three times more expensive than similar cases, including the one from the Amazon Basics line. Case Loigic isn't the kind of brand that deserves a really high price tag. Quality is good, but since I also own the Amazon Basics case, I can compare the quality to a cheaper bag, and it is basically the same. As much as I like the KDH-101, I really can't recommend it due to its price tag.

A one of the most expensive stylus products for the iPad, I had high hopes for this newest Jot Script pen. Sadly, some of the most essential features are basically the same as I get off one of those $2 discount store pens. The tip has too little friction, so it feels like writing on a piece of ice. The slickness is so smooth that really accurate writing is not possible.The magnetic USB charger is a nice touch, and the pen does charge fast, but this new feature is outranked by horribly laggy Bluetooth to apps. Some of this can probably be fixed in software, but the pen tip can't be fixed, and that is its biggest flaw.

I use these mounts for my home automation tablets,  and they are a much better solution than the older self adhesive Brackets I used to use.  Installation takes a bit more work,  but the final installation is much neater.  The mount supports a variety of different sizes.

This is a quality dispenser - it comes complete with anchors, screws, silicone, adhesive pads, a wall template and the required attachment plate. Both dispensers can be removed from the plate for easy refilling or cleaning. Unlike most of the crappy plastic dispensers, this unit has a nice brushed nickel bottom, and nickel on the front of the dispenser plungers. Installation was easy, but required a tile drill (which is not included). The unit even includes a small nickel hanger for sponges, and other items. The tops of the dispensers can be removed, and they lock in place quite nicely.While I would normally remove one star for the excessive price of this produce, I feel the build quality and included accessories make it worth a five star rating. In my shower, I filled it with shampoo and conditioner, and used the included stickers to indicate which products are in the dispensers. Dispensing is nice and fluid, and you get a decent amount of product on each push. Additionally, the top opening is large enough to leave a bottle overnight to empty all its contents.
