From the start of my college course, I was spending an immense amount of time studying German each day on my own, usually an hour a day or more. I could read basic text in German fairly well, pass the vocabulary tests with flying colors, and understood my professor's German speaking on the whole. But passing a collegiate-level foreign language course requires more and different abilities than just learning conversational German, demanding an intimate and extensive knowledge of grammatical rules. If one doesn't know all of the grammatical rules within your native language, then of course you can't even begin to apply that knowledge to another language. While memorizing the vocabulary words in German was certainly doable, especially due to it's common origins with English, the grammatical ignorance on my part was really making me struggle. I found myself turning to Google Translate or some similar program constantly in order to quickly write or phrase complete sentences and questions properly, even when I knew all of the basic vocabulary to put together what I wanted to express. That is so frustrating and demotivating. No one in my personal life outside of class spoke German at all, and as I'm primarily an auditory learner, I was at a real disadvantage in that regard. Forming questions, as opposed to making statements, are even more difficult in German. Asking questions in German is frequently done with reversed word order, compared to how we'd ask the same thing in English, and word order is also altered depending upon whether it's open-ended or a yes/no question. If you're struggling with similar issues, please read on to see if this book is for you.I wish I'd had a good grammar book (or knew about the great websites for learning German which I now utilize regularly for help) from the very beginning of my studies. That would've eliminated some of my frustration, probably would have improved my grades a tad, and it would have left me feeling less clueless in class when the grammatical topics came up. My excellent professor recommended this particular book as an add-on to our mandatory Kontakte textbook, which even she acknowledges is a horrid textbook for learning German. (She had no choice but to teach from it though, for the time being). Me being me, I didn't buy the book until about the end of the semester, and that was really moronic on my part. Will you need this particular book on your very first day of learning German? With the Internet to utilize as a vast reference library today...probably not. If your grammar skills are super-strong to begin with, you may not even need a brush-up on the topics within it. But it still wouldn't hurt to have this on hand as an add-on to your textbook, especially for use during class time (as long as your instructor will allow this). If you don't have Internet access and/or have no firm foundation in grammar, a book of this nature will be essential to your studies, in my humble opinion.The Pros Of This Book- It uses very basic, beginner-friendly German vocabulary to demonstrate it's points, and the English translations are right there with the German for easy deciphering (something for which Kontakte gets a giant FAIL!) This book excels at clarifying the English language's grammatical rules vs. those of German. If you ignored all that grammatical teaching in English class like I did as a kid, you will probably need this book to maximize your German study time and master the new language more quickly. It's a great introductory reference book which shouldn't overwhelm the new-to-German student too much. While it requires consistent and repeated effort to understand and memorize the concepts, I DO feel more confident now in speaking or writing German sentences and questions. I owe that in part to this reference guide.The Cons Of This Book- It has a few limitations you should be aware of. Many times this book says, "Refer to your textbook for further information/elaboration". (I'm paraphrasing, but that's the gist of it). My Kontakte textbook has confusing, occasionally incorrect, and illogically-laid-out grammatical help. So with that being said, I still must turn to the Internet for further elaboration on the topics first presented in this book. Thankfully, there are MANY free and very detailed websites on various topics like dative clauses. Also, this book doesn't bring up more intermediate-to-advanced grammatical learning, like using the comparative and superlative forms of German adjectives. I highly doubt that this would be the only grammar guide that you'll ever need as a student of German, especially if you'll be going beyond taking just one semester of it.Some Additional Resources To Consider- I mostly utilize the Web and a variety of Smartphone apps for additional resources in learning German. I can say that about.com has superb grammatical advice for English speakers who are learning German. My professor loves this online resource, and the site is pretty thorough when it comes to teaching grammar with LOTS of good examples to pore over.

Finally I  can have great tasting bread again!I just received my book this afternoon and made the Basic sandwich bread .When done it looked like wheat bread all high and with a perfect crust.When I cut off a slice while it was still hot  and tasted it I couldn't believe how delicious it was.The texture was just like  fresh home made white (wheat)  bread that I use to make all the time.My husband who looks pityingly at me when ever I have to eat gluten free bread, thought I made him a loaf of wheat bread and grabbed a slice and said it was as good as usual and that says a lot.Yes the book does give instructions how to use the recipes on the  Zojirushi BBCC-X20 Home Bakery Supreme bread machine but for me that was a bonus because that is the bread machine I own.The instructions are clear and simple. I have done most of the FirstPlace Bible Studies and would say, Renewing Hope is one of my favorites.Others that rate at the top of my list are, Choosing Thankfulness and Healthy Boundaries.

The artistic aspect of this movie is off the charts. It is a visual feast.It also give incredible insight into the vast and subtle cultural differences within Eastern and Western minds.I have heard that Asian children adopted as infants into Western families tend to have deep issues with self-worth and connections if they grow up in an area where they are the only Asian or one of few; especially if the family is unable to connect the child with their heritage due to lack of resources or understanding.After watching this movie I started to wonder how much harder it might be for an older child who is adopted. Their brain is already being wired for language, behavioral, and thought patterns that are so different from a Western approach.I understand that love can bridge many gaps, but parents and children in the adoptive process have so many expectations. Adults, especially first time parents, may not be prepared. Parenthood like marriage takes work. Marriage and parenthood are wonderful, but are definitely not lived out in fairy tale conditions.Even parents of biological children get a bit of a wake-up call as their child traverses the road to adulthood and often stands in opposition to them. I can only imagine how confusing it must be for adoptive parents when they are blessed by a child with a well-formed sense of self from a culture they do not understand.So it becomes not just parent-child misunderstandings and tension but a deep cultural aspect adds a very confusing layer of mystery.I know that some people are up to the task, but I hope that adoption agencies are really and truly preparing parents because the children have so little choice in the matter. We owe it to the children we so desperately want to love.These are all the thoughts that have been brewing in my mind after watching this movie and none of these topics were blatantly addressed. It is a movie that causes you to question and think without telling you what to think or what conclusions to draw.Please note, you never see Jinhee with her adoptive family. "A Brand New Life" leaves the viewer with many thoughts of what her "brand new life" will be. Instead of thinking about the happy family you think about what the child will be facing in a place where her struggles may be incomprehensible to those who want to love her.
This can get a little bit messy, but it is fun for the little ones. If you don't mind picking up after play, or have an outdoor area where the kids can use this you will like it better.

We did not use this for deodorant as I wanted to try it out on zits, since some of the reviewers said it was supposed to work on bad eruptions. We saw no real difference in comparison with using other products. I would not purchase this again. It may work for you, it did not work for us.

This was highly recommended to me by a friend and I was so happy to see that I could try it out for free through Amazon Vine. My friend has very curly hair and uses the "curly girl" method for her hair in that she rarely washes it with soap. This is her go to co-wash conditioner. Since her hair always smells great and looks amazing, we decided to give it a try and have been very happy with it. I've never found a Pantene product that I didn't like.If you are going 100% natural in your products, then this won't be a product you'll want to use: Water, Sodium Lauryl Sulfate, Sodium Laureth Sulfate, Cocamidopropyl Betaine, Glycol Distearate, Sodium Citrate, Cocamide Mea, Sodium Xylenesulfonate, Dimethicone, Fragrance, Citric Acid, Sodium Benzoate, Polyquaternium-76, Sodium Chloride, Tetrasodium Edta, Trisodium Ethylenediamine Disuccinate, Panthenol, Panthenyl Ethyl Ether, Methylchloroisothiazolinone, Methylisothiazolinone.

This is probably the most pratical "sippy" cup innovation since the "Tommee Tippee" version.Basic Information:-Munchkin has two versions, this one is the slower flow version for the little ones who are handling a cup for the first time.-It is made for the Canadian company in China.-As stated in the informational section, it is BPA free; but the packaging and informational slip inside the cup gives no further information regarding the manufacturing materials.-You can wash this in the dishwasher on the top shelf, but from personal experience with other such products, I recommend alternating machine washing with hand washing, just to preserve the life of the softer materials, especially if you don't have a closed basket to keep the soft pieces secure-Other cautions given by Munchkin: don't use this cup with carbonated or pulpy juices and don't allow your little one to play with or chew on the "valve" (the entire insertable piece).Overall review:These cups are rather expensive but they are quite practical for teaching children to use a regular cup. There still will be an adjustment period, because when you tip a regular cup beyond a certain angle, you get a face full of water. No sippy cup is going to be perfect.I can see there being a problem when the little ones reach teething age, because they just naturally bite down on everything and teething often coincides with the age at which the little ones start drinking from a regular cup (3-12 months is the teething range and most babies start drinking from a cup around 6 months). So if your little one is really biting down on everything, this cup might not be the best option if they are not closely observed while using the cup. The upside is this: most mom's do not leave an infant unsupervised while eating or drinking.

My son has been using this product for about two weeks now and we have not seen a significant change in his skin condition (mild acne). In the chin area, we are actually seeing new breakouts.I am giving the product a 4 instead of a 3 star rating because it has been our experience that different products work for different people and sometimes the produce starts being more effective after a longer time frame. If we see any difference by the end of four weeks I will adjust the review.The product is very good quality. I love the foam wash because it encourages my son to use it. Still, we've not seen an improvement.

I use a lot of pocket folders on a regular basis for various needs. I have loved receiving the Avery pocket folders in every variation because they truly have 5 distinct colors and have so many large tab options. The minute I get them, I start putting them to use.They are also very sturdy and as a consequence reusable.I love this specific iteration because of the fun designs. These would be better suited for students and casual use as opposed to typical business presentations. They fit my needs perfectly and will get many years of use.

I really like the concept of the expandable pocket folder dividers and I will use these. I'm just not so sure about how durable they will be over time. The weak link is the top of the pocket. In order to allow for the expandability, the material of the top of the pocket seems a little flimsy. If they last and endure the beating I give them, I will come back and correct this review.I do love the fact that I can just write on the tabs, and if I want to change the wording on the tab, I'll remove the ink with nail polish remover.

I haven't had a blender in years, but I have been looking for one. Even the top and most expensive blenders seemed to have issues that made me question if I should purchase one.When I had the opportunity to give this model a test run without paying for it, I decided to give it a try.I tried it this morning with a yogurt smoothie. I followed the instructions regarding what order to add the ingredients (liquids first then frozen solids and ice). The blades did stick a bit but I did not follow the instructions to let the frozen items sit out for about 15 minutes. Next time I'll try that and see if there is any difference. It wasn't a huge problem: I just took a spoon and separated joined chunks of fruit and then mixed things up a bit before restarting.I don't know what the life of the item will be as two important parts are made of a plastic type material. I'm including pictures below. The plastic on the bottom of the pitcher is a little softer and has a slight "give" and the plastic slot on the base is a hard material.The blades worked very well. I used a frozen berry mixture of cranberries, cherries, strawberries, blueberries, and raspberries. All were blended to a pulp...of course the seed of the raspberries and cranberries were detectable, although definitely broken down.The soft plastic in the cover had a very strong smell even after washing in cold water. I'm pretty certain it will dissipate over time.The cap can be a little hard to align at first and does need to be pushed down firmly to get a good deal once it is in its proper position.All in all this is a solid little blender and from what I can tell in this short period of time, priced fairly. If I have any troubles within two years, I will report them. After that the warranty is up, so I figure that is the expected lifetime of the motor and parts with regular use.
I love being organized and these tabbed three-pocket folders are an organizer's dream.Pros:SturdyMulticoloredLarge tabsCons: Non that I have encountered so far.

Scharffen Berger says this is because of the coffee, but I also think there are some turbinado style sugar crystals to balance out the bitterness of the coffee. I love New Chapter vitamins. Their use of high quality ingredients is what made me purchase their daily multivitamins for the kids and adults in our family.The turmeric is also the same high quality as their multivitamins and I am very pleased with this product.

I found this stapler to be very awkward to work with. The mechanism for loading the staples does not tend to remain latched when stapling. The loading mechanism does not seem very sturdy.It also took a while to get used stapling because of the place where you place the paper for stapling and the fact that you have to hold onto the stapler with both hands to keep it sturdy.I will use this, and it will come in handy from time to time, but it is definitely for home use. If you used this at work the frustration wouldn't be worth it.I stapled 43 pages of Xerox 24 pound Premium all purpose paper and that seems about the max it can reach for a secure hold.So the process is awkward, but end result is as it should be.Also, the stapler does not hold a lot of staples.

I am glad that the author found a way to beat the chains of her addiction. It was interesting to see how all those years around people living on alcohol lodged itself in a part of her mind that made her want it in spite of seeing the sad lives of the drinkers staying in her home.I expected the story to have more of a hold on me, but it did not. The writing is not poor, but did not pull me in. I can't put my finger on the reason why.If you are interested in someone's journey into and then out of addiction, you will find the story sad, but encouraging.

The idea behind this small case is that it will help make switching lenses a little safer. If you're doing a wedding you're typically carrying two cameras so it is better suited for when you are doing outdoor landscape type shots (not animals, they'd hear the Velcro sounds and be gone). For this type of situation, the case is quite practical.The "pop up" temporary case for the lens you've just removed is quite ingenious. Place the removed lens there, take out your replacement lens, twist it on to the camera, and the take the other lens out of the pop-up case and place it in the more secure spot.The only problem I see behind this concept is that once you take the new lens out the case becomes a little unstable. So, this is a nice protective lens case but you still need to be a little careful if you're setting it down as opposed to hooking it on your belt (probably the best option) or using the included shoulder strap.I've included a picture of how the case sits with a lens in the temporary pop up.

One of my kids recommended this movie to me. I was hesitant because, even as a teen, I never really cared for the "teen" movie genre. This is not an exciting movie. It is an incredibly thoughtful one. It keeps you thinking long after you watched it and you'll find that you have little to complain about if you enjoy this type of movie. Even though quite thoughtful, this movie deftly incorporates humor. You will laugh a lot, you will cry, and in some instances you will be laughing and crying. Keep the kleenex's handy.I found the movie to be well-written and the acting superb. It reflects a confusing stage of growth with such sensitive intelligence and yet without being morose. Yes, there are some flat characters that are a bit cliche, but they are used appropriately in moving the story line along and they are not portrayed in a completely vacuous or a completely reprehensible light. Even the flat characters get an intelligent and gentle touch and some are given the chance to grow. I love the way the writers developed the characters without imposing too much of an adult sensibility. Somehow they captured that hard to define space between childhood and adulthood.We enjoyed the mother's character. She is not too intense, allows her daughter some space, tries to provide a different perspective when necessary (without being pushy), and has a sense of humor. I guess I can relate to her because my parents approached parenting the same way. They didn't live my life for me, but there was no doubt they were there for me.Vanessa's (main character) father is never seen in the movie, but his mother keeps an open line of communication through letters. Though she is never seen, the grandmother actually plays a pivotal role in Vanessa's growth process.I love magical realism in literature and movies. "Dear Lemon Lima" has just the right amount. I feel like every person's life has a little bit of magical realism in it if they are willing to see it. I feel like these are the events in our lives when we realize that there is an entire world beyond just the physical and that our value is somehow more tied up in the intangible that we normally don't acknowlege. In this way the movie makes a nod to the rich spiritual searching in the lives of teens, even those who've been overtaken by the commercialism of our current society.I want to watch this movie again. But I will wait a while, because right now I want to savor the beauty of my surprising first encounter.SPOILERS FOLLOW:~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~There is very little foul language in this movie. What a relief for my ears. In the winter games, one team calls themselves "fubar", but as far as I can remember the "f" word is never spoken, although it is blurred out in one scene.One of the characters commits suicide. This is a very delicate issue and if you have a teen struggling with depression and suicide this might not be the movie for them. The script handles this in a very delicate way. I found it to be incredibly beautiful even though the Inuit beliefs of the after life differ from mine. There is no discussion of the value of human life and the need to try and draw on the strength of your community when suffering from depression or feeling like your life is of no value. I am fine with this but other parents may not be. You can always have a discussion with your child after the movie.Note: I read a review that said it was not believable that the particular character who committed suicide would have done so. Sad to say at this age, it is hard to say who is a candidate for suicide. We never know what can push a kid into thinking their life isn't worth living. They of all people have fewer skills to deal with the blows that life sends, and they have a much harder time understanding and articulating how they feel. They also have a time being heard, because adults don't always take their struggles seriously. This is not a knock on adults, it is hard being a parent. We made it through, so we figure they will have the wherewithal to do the same thing. We need to take a step back and listen. (Talking to the choir).

Ingredients: water, decyl glucoside, sodium myreth sulfate, PEG-200 hydrogenated glyceryl palmate, cocamidopropyl betaine, sodium chloride, panthenol, sodium benzoate, citric acid, sea salt, bisabolol, polyquarternium-10.Notes on ingredients:*Decyl glucoside and cocamidopropyl betaine are both derived from coconut. The "glucoside" aspect of the decyl glucoside is derived from corn starch.***sodium myreth sulfate - similar to sodium laureth/lauryl sulfate, so if you or baby has allergies to either of the later, do a test run****PEG-200 hydrogenated glycerly palmate is derivative of hydrogenated palm glyceride*sodium chloride: table salt...helps make the gel "viscous"*panthenol: vitamin B5...basically there to moisturize the skin*sodium benzoate: preservative (often used in food)*citric acid: exfoliant, astringent and preservative*sea salt: can contain a variety of minerals that are good for the skin*bisabolol: water soluble oil oil derived from German chamomile, has anti-inflammatory properties*polyquarternium-10: derivative of hydroxyethyl cellulose used as a thickenerScent: other than the ingredients, none. It smells "chemically" for lack of a better term, but the scent is not offensive and doesn't linger.Texture: This is very thick, so start with a little because it will go a long way.

This apron came exactly as advertised. It will fit little ones between the ages of 4-10 depending on their size. It is a very fun pattern and cute color combination and seems to be well constructed. If we have any problems after washing, I'll come back to make a note.

Compared to the Assassin's Creed and Call of Duty Mega Bloks sets that I've received to review lately, this set has considerably fewer pieces, but then it is targeting a younger age group (4-10). The 10 year olds may find it a bit too simple if they're into the building aspect, but they won't be disappointed with the versatility of the Barbie Mansion. It will be fun for them to switch room locations around and the fact that it comes with 2 figurines makes it more "shareable".Even though this is targeting a younger age group, I do wish that the figurines were articulated like the figures in the sets for older kids. I think that would have made the set infinitely more fun. This is why only 4 stars. It would have been possible to make them articulated in a way where they don't come apart and become a safety hazard.Other than this, the girls like the set and all in all I like the quality of the Mega Bloks sets.

One of my kids recommended this movie to me. I was hesitant because, even as a teen, I never really cared for the "teen" movie genre. This is not an exciting movie. It is an incredibly thoughtful one. It keeps you thinking long after you watched it and you'll find that you have little to complain about if you enjoy this type of movie. Even though quite thoughtful, this movie deftly incorporates humor. You will laugh a lot, you will cry, and in some instances you will be laughing and crying. Keep the kleenex's handy.I found the movie to be well-written and the acting superb. It reflects a confusing stage of growth with such sensitive intelligence and yet without being morose. Yes, there are some flat characters that are a bit cliche, but they are used appropriately in moving the story line along and they are not portrayed in a completely vacuous or a completely reprehensible light. Even the flat characters get an intelligent and gentle touch and some are given the chance to grow. I love the way the writers developed the characters without imposing too much of an adult sensibility. Somehow they captured that hard to define space between childhood and adulthood.We enjoyed the mother's character. She is not too intense, allows her daughter some space, tries to provide a different perspective when necessary (without being pushy), and has a sense of humor. I guess I can relate to her because my parents approached parenting the same way. They didn't live my life for me, but there was no doubt they were there for me.Vanessa's (main character) father is never seen in the movie, but his mother keeps an open line of communication through letters. Though she is never seen, the grandmother actually plays a pivotal role in Vanessa's growth process.I love magical realism in literature and movies. "Dear Lemon Lima" has just the right amount. I feel like every person's life has a little bit of magical realism in it if they are willing to see it. I feel like these are the events in our lives when we realize that there is an entire world beyond just the physical and that our value is somehow more tied up in the intangible that we normally don't acknowlege. In this way the movie makes a nod to the rich spiritual searching in the lives of teens, even those who've been overtaken by the commercialism of our current society.I want to watch this movie again. But I will wait a while, because right now I want to savor the beauty of my surprising first encounter.SPOILERS FOLLOW:~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~There is very little foul language in this movie. What a relief for my ears. In the winter games, one team calls themselves "fubar", but as far as I can remember the "f" word is never spoken, although it is blurred out in one scene.One of the characters commits suicide. This is a very delicate issue and if you have a teen struggling with depression and suicide this might not be the movie for them. The script handles this in a very delicate way. I found it to be incredibly beautiful even though the Inuit beliefs of the after life differ from mine. There is no discussion of the value of human life and the need to try and draw on the strength of your community when suffering from depression or feeling like your life is of no value. I am fine with this but other parents may not be. You can always have a discussion with your child after the movie.Note: I read a review that said it was not believable that the particular character who committed suicide would have done so. Sad to say at this age, it is hard to say who is a candidate for suicide. We never know what can push a kid into thinking their life isn't worth living. They of all people have fewer skills to deal with the blows that life sends, and they have a much harder time understanding and articulating how they feel. They also have a time being heard, because adults don't always take their struggles seriously. This is not a knock on adults, it is hard being a parent. We made it through, so we figure they will have the wherewithal to do the same thing. We need to take a step back and listen. (Talking to the choir).

A friend of mine is a doctor and he told me that our calcium to magnesium intake should be in a ratio of 2 parts calcium to 1 part magnesium. While this Schiff supplement doesn't follow the exact formula is is a great option to take every few days if you are not getting enough calcium, magnesium, and vitamin D.The vitamin D comes as 800 IU of cholecalciferol.The calcium (as noted in the description) comes as 1.2g of *calcium carbonate.The magnesium comes as 400mg of magnesium oxide.*This is important for those with shellfish allergies because it is billed as not containing shellfish according to "LiveStrong".

Building Process/Tips:As with the Assassin's Creed Gunboat, you might want to plan to do this build over the course of a few days as your fingers will start to get sore after a while with the many small pieces you will be snapping together. Parents, if your kids are younger you may want to be there to sort out the pieces in a way that makes sense for your child and put them in ziplock bags so nothing gets lost in the building process.End Product:The end product is incredible. I love the nearly invisible stands for the mini-figures. It really does look like they are in outer space. You can manipulate the figures to be in any position on the stand (upside-down, sideways...).It doesn't matter if your kid never plays the game and never will because of your own personal standards. The Space Station doesn't need the game reference to be fun.Fun Mechanisms/Features:This piece has some fun featured like the hingeing mechanisms that allow you to open and close the all the outer panels and the rotational feature on the top attachment.Another important feature is the stand that elevates the structure. It gives a better "feel" of being in outer space.Action Figures & Accessories:The action figures are almost fully articulated (like the figures in Assassins Creed) and much of the clothing can be removed and switched up. The main difference here is that you will not see faces as the helmet is not removable. The coolest accessories are the guns because each one has a unique look.None of the clothing has the flexible feel that some of the Assassins Creed cloths do, but this is outer space and this makes it more realistic for this particular setting. Much of the clothing/packs are removable and interchangeable which makes this much more fun for the kids, but also requires the extra care in not losing the pieces.General Details: The metallic gold and silver pieces at just enough realism that help the kids as they imagine they are in outer space. With all the detail comes lots of smaller pieces, but it is worth it the sore fingers!

I was taking care of a family member in another state and stumbled upon a wonderful natural food store with a deli. It their deli they sold a Lemon Kale salad that included Soofoo. I became addicted to that salad and now that I'm back home I've been CRAVING the salad. I called the store and they said that I could find the recipe on Soofoo's website as well as purchase the product there.For the moment, Amazon's price is cheaper by over a dollar so in the future I will buy from Amazon.The recipe was on Soofoo's website. I am not a vegetarian, but I love good vegetarian foods that is also filling. This salad fits that requirement for me. If you are trying to eat healthy and want to enjoy the process, you need to include Soofoo in your menu schedule. The Soofoo website has a lot of recipes, but for now I'm stuck on the Lemon Kale salad.

Our Lego fan has not been totally won over by the Mega Bloks, but he is still pretty impressed by the look of this gunboat.Action Figures: The figures are highly articulated, look very realistic, and have removable and interchangeable head gear (hair, hats) and of clothing. I think this allows the kids to be creative and imaginative on so many more levels. These details make make the transition from the present day to the pirate past more seamless than "cartoony" looking figurines.Game Compatibility: If you are an Assassin's Creed Black Flag purist, this boat is not one of the pirate's warships you'd see in the game, it is a smaller ship (sloop). That said, this is a pretty big boat.Detailing: The gunboat has a lot of really nice smaller details: lamps, barrels, two toned pieces, gold toned pieces, etc.Rigging: The rigging that goes through the "sheets" (sailing speak for sails) is very strong, but I'm not so sure how well the sails and the shrouds (the rigging that has a woven triangular look) will hold up in play. I'd advise the kids not to try to have the figures hang on to the shrouds.Packaging: The packaging is fairly well thought out. I especially like special "encapsulated" type packages that the small clothing pieces come in (such as the sashes). I've included a shot of that packing from a sash that we haven't used yet.Notes:-Our builder completed the complete hull of the ship first and then took several days to complete the detailing. He said his fingers really hurt from all the pressing in of the little pieces. So if your kids are younger you may want to do the build over several days as opposed to doing it all in one session.-In between the hull build and the detailing I went to look at the remaining pieces and saw them all dumped into the box. Most of the pieces were small so I separated them by color (gold, silver, red, light and dark brown). You may want to do the same after the hull is complete. It will help you find those small pieces much easier.-I also put the rigging and sails in a separate bag because the delicate shrouds were tangled up in the mess and I could foresee them getting damaged before actually being put on the ship.

Great for my 2 grandsons. While I would never leave them unattended in our pool, these make it possible for me to stay dry while I watch them from the decking! But mostly of the time I'm right in there with them. As a former competitive swimmer, I never believed in these, but if the kids have never had lessons, then one is forced to hold them for hours or take the risk of "sink or swim". Not on my watch! So "swimmies" it is. And their arms are free to help them stroke a bit so they hold them up & serve a bit for that.
Didn't stay on, didn't fit. Tossed in garbage.

Used it a couple of times for hotdogs & a grilled cheese & love it! Never owned one of these before, but can understand why these are so popular in restaurants. It's a bit small if you are cooking a large amount of whatever, so check into their larger sizes too. I'm very happy with this purchase & the quality. My hubby did have to get his tools out as you need a special tool that I've forgotten the name of, to put it together securely; you can't do it with just pliers and a screwdriver..

Just got this to replace the same one that got abused by metal utensils in my absence! Be forewarned that while the package label says "commercial", the company told me that it's commercial-grade made for the home kitchen. Not sure why on earth they are talking out of both sides of their mouth, but don't buy this if you have a restaurant! Mine is for my home. It's a great skillet for smaller cooking. (3-egg omelette, 2 grilled cheese etc)

I've been feeding this to my 2 cats for a couple of months. They likes it the first day and are so-so about it since then. I'm just at odds about feeding it as there are no good kibble options out there. The GOOD is that this contains 40% protein which is very important for felines (carnivores). Cats should NOT eat fruits, herbs & veggies which most brands are now adding for ridiculous reasons... The BAD is that ROSEMARY is the preservative. Rosemary is toxic to cat digestion, so there will be long-term issues unless you know how to counter this problem (I do) by dosing cats with supplements.The company simply needs to replace the Rosemary with VIT E. I'm unsure if the company is kitty-nutrition incompetent (excusable & fixable) OR is deliberately cutting costs by using (cheap!!) rosemary (inexcusable).I hope they read these reviews & make a very necessary correction. In the meantime, I'm also offering other kibble that doesn't have rosemary, along with this & have my fingers crossed that this formula will soon be made healthier!

Got this for visiting grandkids & it sure makes my life easier to have so many viewing choices right at my fingertips! I'm technically challenged, so my adult son hooked it up, therefore, I cannot say anything else other than it works just fine!

Bought this to replace the 40 yr-old one that disappeared from my kitchen during remodelingIt was fun to see it again as brand new and shining! It's just so cute. My only issue now is that my new range has such huge burners that it's not as easy to use this tiny saucepan. Not the fault of the pot, but me for not realizing that large burners mean no small pots, or careful use if I do.

I found these at a Lowe's that is 2 hrs away from me, so I was happy to see them here on Amazon. I bought 2 more sets and my new kitchen now has great organization in ALL the drawers! These allow you to really customize the interior for those drawers that just need a center divider or 2. I'm thrilled with them!!

Finally, a dry dishwasher!!! We just re-did our kitchen & have 2 Monogram dishwashers that were not drying the dishes. My plumber (son) told me about this product & said to try it. I did, and it solved the problem. WHile I don't like adding any chemicals to a final rinse, I do this as I can't stand the dripping of dishes onto the hardwood floor after a cycle is complete. I also learned that new dishwashers require one to run the hot water in the sink before beginning a cycle. Apparently they use very little water, so it needs to start out hot. Not sure why this helps the drying process, but a company rep told me this is the solution (he didn't know about this product, so I have to assume a combo of both is the best method, and is what I'm doing..)

There are already many great reviews on this product so I'll just say that it's a hit with my very bright, 6 yr-old master builder grandson, but will include a couple of negatives:CONS: Buyer beware: the instruction booklet includes instructions for ALL of the sets which only upsets children who don't have THOSE sets, so right from the beginning, one feels like a crumb when the child wants to build something that is impossible due to lack of needed shapes; Very cleverly, the company made sure that each set doesn't include ALL the shapes, so showing those cool models that one cannot make with this set is a bit mean in my opinion. Isn't it enough that I just spent $130+ on this set, without causing me to have guilt that we don't have the other shapes???  Everyone was shocked at the high cost, BUT the kid loves itAnother issue for me is that I save boxes for storage so this is put away after a day of continual play. The problem is that there is no way to know how to place the pieces back the way they came. And there was a particular order/manner in which to do this. I've emailed the company & asked for a photo of how the box was packed upon opening it up. There are wells for the pieces but several don't fit no matter how we try. It's minor to most people, but for those wishing to keep the pieces in the box between visits to grandma's, it's impossible without a diagram.

I bought this to replace Diamond Naturals Active Cat chicken & rice because Diamond has changed the ingredients & now includes fruits, vegetables & some very feline-toxic herbs. WIthout going into the science as to why those items will harm a cat, I will just say that cats don't have the apparatus to process them. Felines are obligate carnivores & need just meat.So, because of the change in what was an almost ideal cat kibble (Diamond Naturals Active Cat),  I seek a good substitute. Unfortunately most all cat kibbles contain harmful ingredients.Enter Sportmix Wholesomes chicken & rice...Each kibble is extra tiny & I have to wonder if this is the reason my 2 cats are not eating it after initially giving it a paws-up for a day. They seemed frustrated trying to pick the tiny kibbles up with their teeth and then barely chewed them. (actually, cats don't "chew", but pierce food with pointed teeth; they have no flat molars. That said, I still don't think cats should swallow kibble whole & but more than a few people who've fed his say their cats seem to be swallowing whole too) This bothers me.The ingredients are ok BUT the protein is too low so one must supplement with meat. (ideal protein for kibble is 40% or higher & must be meat-based protein). So that's another bother but can be easily resolved by offering some roast chicken etc.My biggest concern is the addition of EXTRA L-Lysine! I learned a lot about Lysine after my immuno-compromised cat died from daily Lysine supplements that I misunderstood as being good for him, when in fact, the opposite was true. L-Lysine is meant only for short-term use, not daily ingestion. I don't have all details, but someone I know consulted the Sportmix  "expert" who is the one who suggested Sportmix add extra Lysine to this formula & his initial reasoning made no sense. We await further clarification from that expert but he has not replied to a follow-up call, as he said he would.With the loss of the original Diamond Active Cat kibble (40% animal protein), there are just 2 other kibbles that don't contain harmful ingredients, but they are also very low protein (30-32%), so a private feline nutrition expert is researching what one can give (anti-oxident etc) to counteract the effect of the additional Lysine that mayl cause an imbalance that could lead to harm down the road...It's sad that vets only get a few hours in pet nutrition & then are used as "expert" consultants for pet food formulas. The people who talked the pet food industry into adding fruits & veggies or herbs (rosemary & yucca are the most toxic) to cat kibble will be responsible for many cat deaths down the road. IF you are feeding cat food (wet or dry) that contains fruits & vegetables (with the exception of pumpkin) please take note that your cat may eventually experience urinary issues (crystals, stones etc) that can & do lead eventually to chronic renal failure (CRF) due to the change in the urine from acidic to alkaline. Alkaline urine is caused by plant & vegetable matter = kidney damage. Acidic urine is produced by meats. For optimal feline health, cat urine should be acidic at all times, so DO NOT FEED a cat fruits & vegetable-based food.I assure you that my info is correct. I challenge any vet or pet food company to disprove me. My info is based on fact & research; their info is based on marketing/advertising/sales gimmicks, and only that, and at the cost of feline health! Just sayin'..So, will I continue to try to feed this? Maybe, but not until I find out what I need to give to my cats to counter the unnecessary addition of extra Lysine that will throw off the nutrients that must be properly balanced...

Joan Rivers was a genius. Gone way too soon as she had so much more to give us. I'll miss her very much. This book is very funny . She has something to say for each day of the year & won't disappoint.
Bought for dear friend & she's very happy with it so far! Sounds clear when we speak.
Great shampoo. Really cleans. A bit hard to spread it around the scalp but worth the effort. Clean scent.
These bio's are always good reading. This one didn't disappoint.
Great information. Highly recommend for those with the brainpower to understand science.
Good product if you have the patience. I started it, but haven't stuck with it. But all is here if you need help. Very clear & good instructor.
This is a replacement for one I bought last year but never used. When I went to use it, it didn't work. Hopefully this one will work. My son has it for his kids. I got for our catsGo figure! lol
Super idea. Now if only I could remember to take it with me on my photo-shoots! ;)
Great product. Does what it's supposed to.
Finally, color choices & so affordable!!!  If you are looking for uber-thick matting, then these are not for you. But they are well-cut and look great! 100% happy camper here!

After reading the many reviews, I ordered my usual size but also chose the "C/D" wide width and glad I did as they wouldn't work if any narrower - I had to keep tucking the tongue in before closing them. Really frustrating. And I don't measure as a wide foot so I think the company needs to rethink the width of this line. People shouldn't have to buy Wide when they don't normally wear Wide. I bet the regular width fits narrow feet perfectly, and the reviews seem to agree.What I don't like:1. Velcro closures. Due to zip closure being unavailable in my size in Wide, I had to get the velcro. The straps overhang the attachment strip so I have "wings" sticking out the side of each foot. Not a great look but not extreme do will do as I needed comfortable sneakers, and these are very comfy.2. Removable sole. I can't imagine taking it out as there would be no support at all. With the sole in the shoe,  my heel doesn't feel like it's sitting down as low as it should due to the thickness of the sole.  I'll have to get used to this new feeling.3. The color: the photos must be black and white because the true color is not white on white; the faux leather areas are  off -white & makes the sneaker look like a child's "t-strap" shoe because it stands out. Result: looks juvenile imo. But comfy, so keeping.I wish more wide widths were available both in retail and online stores; some don't carry wide sizes at all, and the others are all out of 9 and 9.5 wide in the zip style, which is the one I wanted.Today is only day one of wearing this shoe, but I was in them for 4 hours and they were comfy the entire time.

It's difficult to find this set in the USA, so this was a nice find on Amazon! My 5 yr old grandson was over the moon about this set of books! He'd never seen them before until I brought a couple over from the days I taught nursery school. He has a wicked sense of humor so when I saw his utter delight over them (and his perusal of each book's tiny icon on the back cover), I decided to order this set for his birthday. TIP: if the book get dumped out, make it a game of putting them back in order.a pattern develops on the spines that stick up in the box. Can't recall what it was exactly, but helps you know where to put each book...
My friend's cats love these. I was surprised at how large they were, but he said the larger size went over well with his cats. I assumed incorrectly that they were small springs. But all worked out.

Just too thick and unyielding to use. I saw the ones the dentist made for my daughter and these are rather like the football mouth guards we used for our son many many years ago. I can't imagine how one would keep the gel from going all over the gums. Not using/tossing out.

We did 2 home offices in Sauder Classic Cherry & when we needed an additional bookcase/storage unit, it was nice to find that it's still being manufactured, so all is good! The final product fit and finish looks very nice & has held up well over the years!

The cat "daddy" I gave this to said his cats love this! He's loaning it to me and if mine like it too, I'll buy one for them. They have the Cat Sitter DVD so I didn't think we needed another one, but he said this one is really really good...

Really like the polished chrome look of this in my small, elegant guest bathroom that has a pedestal sink, therefore no storage. The only caveat is that the larger (jumbo) type rolls are a bit too small. Because we have other bathrooms in the house, I wait until a new roll is used enough to fit and then swap it out into this. Looks much better on the toilet tank than a bare roll.

Love these cards! I'm a repeat customer, having first bought the card for a Nikon D80. There are just so many features on the high end digital cameras, it's difficult to remember each one when you aren't a daily shooter. These help reboot my brain's memory!

Hard to review something bought in error but here goes. When this arrived I noted there was nothing on the box or instructions about setting up a fax. I always assumed "multi-function" meant a fax was included. Amazon took it back & I ordered the MFC7360N monochrome as that has a fax. If you only want monochrome & no fax, this would be great I'm sure!
Ate my first one today while on the golf course. Tasty enough, but disappeared in about 4 bites. Not a very large bar.

Very nice mix of flavors though I can't say I could detect pumpkin. Maybe they meant it had cinnamon and nutmeg in it. Anyway, to me it seemed to taste like an oatmeal cookie, but one that had been greatly overcooked. You have to sort of gnaw on these since they are quite hard.I did like them and found the crunch and the flavor satisfied my craving. Good for times you are on-the-go, like on the golf course.

My mother loved the Flint Hills so this was a perfect gift for her. I very much enjoyed reading about the various artist whose paintings and some photos are featured in this book. One per page with the facing page in text.Here's what you can expect. Cally Krallman, Topeka - "It gives me a feeling of oneness with the earth when I am in the open plains and feel the wind rush through my hair and all the sounds and smells that are found on the prairies." The scene on the facing page shows a sunset, the hills and in the foreground lovely grasses bending in the breeze.You could even take out a few pages to frame and create a gallery wall in your home.
Just the right amount in the bag to satisfy my chocolate craving. The small pretzel gives it some crunch but most of the flavor is chocolate.

My sister got one of these and she highly recommends it. Eco-friendly and energy efficient, it really is helpful if you have hemorrhoids or the related surgery. This is made with anti-bacterial material, uses aerated bubble infusion technology, and is really helpful for feminine cleansing.She was quite lyrical about it.

I did wish for a happy-ever-after ending but even without that, I thoroughly enjoyed the two characters and their encounters. She leaves California to sort herself out in an Irish cottage. He's the landlord and local laird. She's recovering from a traumatic loss of an elderly aunt who raised her. He's elusive, but hooked on her.Spoiler, it seems the next book takes her to London and she meets someone new. Not sure I want to read that. The characters and situations are quite enjoyable, but I don't want her to meet someone else.

Starts off with plenty of action involving the heroine and hero in a rescue. They both have special abilities, she has visions and he's a slayer. There are vampires, including one who has it in for the heroine, so the hero is on the hunt for the vampire to protect her.As one reviewer noted, the characters weren't consistent through the book. The heroine's visions only come into play in the first part, not later. There are a few slow parts where they approach and back off a few times. Guess that's to build sexual tension, but I found the story and characters compelling enough to keep coming back for the finish.Enjoyable enough, but not going to win any awards.

I just got this set at Sam's Club and love the smooth feel of the fabric. It has good deep pockets for the mattress. I also liked that it didn't shrink when I washed it in hot water and came out of the dryer without wrinkles.

What a special story. Cassandra pours out her feelings in a notebook that delights the reader with the sweetness, the quirkiness, the apt descriptions... It's so hard to tell how it makes you feel.You are transported back to 1940s England which is when this book was written. Cassandra's family, fallen on hard times, rent a dilapidated castle. They barely have enough to eat and live in hopes that their father will resume his writing which brought him fame and for awhile, a good income. The characters include the dysfunctional father, an artistic and rather impractical step-mother, Cassandra's older sister who longs for a swain, a younger brother and a young man who has lived with them ever since his mother died.They live quite isolated in the castle, with little hope in sight that their situation will improve. Overnight, it all changes as an American family moves into the local manor house. The older sister sees the opportunity for an advantageous marriage that could save the whole family. Cassandra records the whole scenario in her journals.Life isn't simple any longer and Cassandra finds new feelings that stir her up and complicates the situation. A wonderful coming-of-age story told beautifully.

I love reading the childhood stories told by 80 and 90 year olds. This book pieces together the stories of 95-year-old Dorothy Carney Chase who lovingly narrates her memories of Sheepscot, Maine. The collector of the stories is Bird Stasz who intersperses some background information on the people and places that Dorothy describes. Vintage photos show scenes to accompany the memories.A delightful reading experience.

Got this for my spouse and he likes the plush, cushy feel of it. I wish I'd known that there was a contoured one with these same features. That would have been his preference for his back and neck problems.Anyway, he doesn't seem to feel it is any cooler than other pillows we've had but likes it for the memory foam.

I have 26 mini-blinds that get super-dusty and then when it is humid, the dust gets moldy. I got this gadget to clean the thin slats in the mini-blinds. It is still quite a tedious job and the microfiber covers on this cleaning device got clogged with dust half-way through the first blind.The cover is washable and I admit that I had months of dust accumulated. If you are starting with clean blinds and then using this every week, it would probably be OK. Still, it is a finicky job to line the fingers up between the slats and run it across.You can wet the cloth covers too and I'll try that next.

Poems to delight a child or to take an adult back to a 1950s or 1960s childhood. Cynthia Ross writes short poems like "Ride a Stick Horse" or other topics from her childhood. The poems reflect her Kansas roots and country upbringing.Charming.

Sturdy, water-resistant picnic blanket. Sort of a vinyl on the exterior. Comes with a strap that can be adjusted for carrying over the shoulder or change to tote on your back with both arms through the straps.Great for taking to an outdoor concert where you can stretch out on the grass, have a picnic, listen to the music. Easy to refold into compact carrying form.Also while folded makes a cushion for sitting on hard bleachers at a sporting event.

If you loved Seabiscuit, then you'll love this horse story too. Snowman is a horse rescued from the truck that was heading for the glue-factory. Harry de Leyer, newly immigrated to America from Holland after WWII, buys the horse for $80 to rehabilitate for giving riding lessons. The story evolves with Harry and Snowman developing a lifelong bond and making history in show jumping. They compete against the elite stables with their pampered thoroughbreds and win in venues like Madison Square Gardens.The story of the family, of a special horseman/trainer and a very special horse makes engrossing reading.

The package calls it a cereal but I wanted it for snacking. The crunchy granola of slightly sweet browned oats and dried banana chips is yummy straight from the box. I think I'll mix it with some raisins and dried cranberries and toss in some almonds for even more variety. It's fine just the way it is, but I like to experiment.

Beautiful card selection with  with all sorts of embellishments (3-D, foil, great designs). You get 25 cards for the price you would pay for 3 fancy cards like this in a card shop. In addition the box is decorative and quite sturdy, so after the cards are gone, you can store all manner of things in it.I'm thrilled with the selection. Sure there are 1 or 2 that may not exactly fit my taste but I definitely got my money's worth without those.

This one is lightweight, so better than one I had by another manufacturer. The old one was so heavy that it made my portable clothes rack lean to one side.This new one doesn't go all the way to the floor, so that leaves room for shoes or a box underneath. I like the mesh pockets on the side and will stash scarves in those.

If you don't want to run out to the store every few days for milk, keep some of this on hand. It's easy to mix up and chill, then drink or use in coffee or recipes. You can even put it in powdered form in recipes to get more calcium.Ingredients are nonfat dry milk, vitamin A Palmitrate, Vitamin D3.The first time I made it, I followed the directions and put water in the container then dumped in the powder and shook it up. Turned out a sludge settled in the bottom and didn't get dissolved. The second time, I put the water in a bowl, added the powder and stirred it with a whisk. Then I poured it into my milk jug. No problems with undissolved powder this time.Tastes like milk, convenient to keep on the shelf, great product to have on hand. The only problem for me, given the amount of milk I use, is this runs out way too soon. I'll be stocking in a larger quantity for future.

Lucille Ledoux narrates her parent's story and then her own first 30 years to her son, Denis. He wrote these down and I'm so glad he did.This memoir gave me insight into the life of my own Franco-American mother-in-law as there were many parallels to her life. Lucille's parents left Thetford Mines, Quebec to make a life in Lewiston in southern Maine. So many immigrated from Canada in that early part of the century, that French-speaking communities sprang up around the mills where many of them worked.Lucille tells stories of her school years and of growing up in a large family. The eldest of 12 children, she had to assume some of the care of the younger ones while she was still a child. It was a hard life, but families helped each other out and times gradually got better.The story continues into Lucille's adulthood and her marriage. The time includes the Great Depression and World War II where her husband was away in the war. I found it a most enjoyable read since I love these homespun memories. I wish more people would take the time to collect their parents' stories and commit them to paper.

This cover is just what we wanted to keep our patio coffee table sheltered from the sun or from rain. We already had the chair and loveseat covers that we bought locally but couldn't find the coffee table cover anywhere.It looks just like pictured here.

An extremely useful handbook to have in your RV. My copy was damaged, so I'm shopping for a newer edition. The older edition like this is still useful if you have an older RV. Look at the publication dates when you order a used copy.

This is loaded with diagrams showing the internal workings of RVs so you can understand how the basic systems work. It has troubleshooting advice for when the furnace won't work, the refrigerator quits functioning and other necessities of life. Refer to it for fixing your exterior issues too from awning problems to skylights.Lots of how-to info (using sway bars for a trailer for example). Just an all-around useful manual for repairing and maintaining your recreational vehicle. You hope it never has anything go wrong with it, but you know it will.

They need to break this into 2 books by region. It's just too awkward to handle while on the road. I'm the navigator and it's a struggle to find campgrounds in this while you are bouncing down the road.Lots of campgrounds are not in the book, as we see the signs along the way.

Fits like a glove! I bought the ladies large (L) and it fits snugly like a golf glove should.There are a number of flex point across the knuckles of the fingers (shown in pink on the glove) . Those are lycra. The glove is holding up well and I would buy it again.

Vintage romance that satisfies readers who liked Mary Stewart's early books. The descriptions of the characters and the highland scenes delighted me. Seeing the character regain her joy of life after a bad marriage made a sweet story.I enjoyed it so much, I read the author's other 2 books right after finishing this one.

This isn't the witty, steamy Janet Evanovich I look for. I considered it a run-of-the-mill mystery with some romance thrown in. The heroine, divorced and about to lose her house, takes a job at a restaurant with a hunky owner.He challenges her to find out who is sabotaging his home-brew business. The pacing and suspense and romance just seemed pretty sluggish. I finally skimmed the final third of the book just to get it finished.

You'll find 3 different stories criss-crossing in this book. First you meet Thomas Meeker, a young boy living on the St Louis streets, stealing to survive. Rescued by a stablemaster who let him sleep in the stable and taught him to work with horses.Next is Frederick Wagner, born into poverty in the Chicago slums. He left his overcrowded, abusive home to live on the streets. Bullied and extorted by street kids, newspaper boys, he gets taken under the wing of a bigger bully and learns to kill and steal.Third is Seamus McGregor, born in Scotland who took over his father's blacksmith work on his death. Raised in a supportive and moral home, he left for Canada and then the U.S. to earn money to send his family.Time progresses and in the 1890s gold is discovered in the Yukon. I found this part of the story more interesting. Each of the characters wend their way to the gold fields. There's lots of great history and colorful characters to keep you reading.The style of writing is grandiose, matching the popular writing of that era. To some modern readers, that may seem wordy and overblown, but I adjusted to the style and got caught up in the narrative.

Excellent golf glove. It has felx points across the fingers and the back of the glove to allow easy movement. The palm is reinforced with an extra layer. It's a little hard to determine what size you need when ordering online like this.I took a chance on the medium/large and just got one. Now that I see it is a bit snug, I'm ordering a good batch in large.

I loved the book. It's an intense reading experience, trying to absorb all the historical and genealogy information provided in the side notes. Later I may go back and just read the main text of the autobiography alone so I can enjoy the flow of Wilder's writing.This book is a treasure and fans of the Little House books or even the television series seem to have an insatiable curiosity about the real story behind the classic children's books. This satisfies with so much detail and great photos and maps.

I brought a number of these back from Australia when we moved back to the states. Now they've all been used up. Sigh...I'm not a fancy cook, but these always worked for me and really impressed my neighbors when I served them for dessert.

This is a memoir telling the story of growing up as one of 7 children in the 1950s. The setting is Australia both rural and small town. The author creates vivid scenes of a sometimes idyllic childhood, yet hints at the secrets her mother kept from them. There was an earlier husband and children that were taken from her.The last part of the book is the author's attempt to learn more about the experience of her half-siblings who grew up separated in orphanages. Although that part lacks the flow and the warmth of her childhood memories, it's an important contribution to the history of Australia's institutionalized children of that era.I see now that there was an earlier book that she wrote about her mother's life explaining what happened to her and her children in that first marriage.

I picked this up to see what secrets of the rich and famous might be within. It was more the story of neglected, yet overindulged children. The author is a twig off a branch of the Astor/Burden family tree. A great money-making family, but with the generations spiraling downward with drink, drugs and mental illness.Wendy grows up in the 60s and 70s. Her father committed suicide and her mother is mostly absent and self-involved. That leaves Wendy seeking attention from her ultra-rich grandparents, feeling an outsider with too-frequent relocations, feuding with her brothers.You get behind-the-scenes peeks into the wealthy homes, meet the servants and all through it, Wendy snipes and complains about them all. Quite the dysfunctional childhood and coming of age.She makes it all pretty interesting and makes me glad to have had a boring childhood in a middle-class home.

Callie and Luke both have some raw feeling from bad relationships in the past. In this short romance, the pair seem to have moved past those to find a solid relationship together. They even share a house and Callie hopes they have a long future together.Too easy, eh? Well, the fly in the ointment soon appears. It's Luke's former lover, Victoria, who he thought was well out of the picture. Their meeting is accidental but Victoria never misses a chance to bring a man to heel. He warns her off, but the thought of taking Luke away from his new love is irresistible to selfish Victoria.The suspense begins as the reader wonders how far will Victoria go to spoil Luke and Callie's relationship. The characters develop over the short span of the story with Callie feeling vulnerable and insecure in Luke's feelings and Luke struggling with a reluctance to bring up past issues and his difficulty in articulating his true feelings.There are some tense scenes and some pretty sexy ones too that keep the story moving. There are 2 more stories in this series but this one easily stands alone. You aren't left hanging.Apparently the next book features Callie's best friend who is a real estate agent.

I'm delighted to discover this early novel by Elsie Lee, writing under the pseudonym of Ian Gordon. Hard to believe it came out 50 years ago, but Elsie Lee has some devoted fans who will want to check it out.The publisher didn't know quite what to do with a sexy, smart, liberated career girl novel, so they marketed this with a slutty cover and lurid blurb. Here's the inside description: "Michel, Art, Rafe, Alex and too many others to remember had shared her bed before Robin. Too many male bodies had possessed her, the girl with the soul of a courtesan combined with the morals of a geisha. Until Robin came...You're frightened to death of this man -- and you want him again, as quickly as he'll take you, she thought."In today's writing market, it might be called erotica, but most likely it would just be listed under romance.

Despite the purple prose on the cover and the trampy cover art, this is an Elsie Lee romance. It was later issued under her name with the title, The Apartment.Essentially it is the story of young career women sharing an apartment and on the hunt for a husband. Fifty years ago, the sex scenes in this book were considered erotica, but by now such graphic descriptions are pretty much expected in romance novels.

A Baltimore friend brought these as a hostess gift. I know good manners dictate that I share them with everyone present, but I just wanted to hoard them for myself. They are really special.The cookie is merely the base for the heavy fudge icing. Each vanilla cookie has the hand-dipped icing covering the top and spread out around the sides. You can break off a chunk of chocolate to eat by itself or eat the base and icing combined.Don't eat a whole cookie at one time without a glass of milk handy. Don't eat 2 cookies in a row or you will seriously overdose on goodness.

I'm in love! A visitor brought these as a hostess gift and let me tell you, this hostess was thrilled. I'm trying to pace myself and not eat them up all at once.Each square is individually wrapped and is 50 to 70 calories depending on the flavor. The dark chocolate is divine at just 50 calories. The caramel and other flavors have a center filled with yumminess that just melts in your mouth.

This book made me glad that no children came along as baggage in my second marriage. The syndrome described by the author is all too common from stories I hear from my twice-married friends. It's the dad trying to make up for the divorce by giving his kids more than he should, teaching them to be dependent and always asking for more.It's no fun being trapped as a stepmom with grown stepchildren plaguing their re-married dad and making life miserable. Kerry Kendall found a way to cope with counseling, girlfriends and a glass of wine. She turned the horrifying downward spiral of her stepkids into a fun read.Each chapter is another part of the saga, the train wreck that is her life. I couldn't stop reading as I couldn't wait to find out what the next disaster was and how she applied her wicked sense of humor to it.I've heard the author read from this book and it's even funnier in person, probably due to her experience as a television reporter. If you get a chance to hear her, don't miss it.

I love memoirs like this one. She writes about her parents' courtship, her own early childhood and time in a TB sanitorium, then growing up in the 1920s and 30s in Bristol, England. The family struggled against poverty and Joyce starts work at 14 as a servant, then later works in a corset factory.Her descriptions of the family, the life of that time and her own feelings kept me engrossed. As she enters young adulthood, she enjoys more freedom from the disharmony in the household, but feels pressured to marry before she is ready.

Not the sturdiest tablecloths but much cheaper than the ones with the backing. I got 3 for a party and they really livened up the room with their bold, big shamrock design. They are easily scruffed and torn, but I'll get a 2nd year of use from them.They are really long, so had to fold them under for the 6 foot tables I have. Ended up cutting off the excess on 2 of them and using it to cover the bar for the party.

Slim slightly-contoured liner for protecting your underwear. They adhere to the fabric but are easily removed. The length is longer than standard pantiliners.I bought them at Walgreens, but if you don't have one of those near you, here they are.

These sturdy crackers are large enough for a half slice of cheese. Love them with Swiss cheese or with a spread of humus. They are chock full of odd grains like amaranth and teff. They taste great.Keep in mind that these are not wheat-free, so not for gluten intolerant folks.

Spiral-bound, this handy directory is just what any RVer with a big rig needs. The binding allows it to be opened and lay flat as you search for a campground. It's arranged by states and then by city.Helpful info includes detailed listing of sites within an RV park that are suitable for a big rig. For example, "for a 70 footer, try #133 thru 148." You'll know ahead of time if there's wi-fi, if the sites are pull through, and which exact site in an RV park will hold a long RV.

Growing up in a remote coal mining village in England, Winifred Foley tells the little stories of family hardships and the love that kept them going. Her memoir is of the 1920s but the village in the Forest of Dean could have been in the 1800s. No running water, meat only for Sunday and bread spread with lard for the rest of the week.It was a hard childhood but she captures the reader with her descriptions of playing in the forest, her memories of her grandparents and aunties, and her childish tribulations (no doll, no pretty dress to wear to the school performance).  At 14, she must go into service to lessen the burden on the family. The second half of the book recounts the difficulties of adjusting to different households often with stingy mistresses who overworked her.I stayed up late reading this one and didn't want to stop. A masterful, very personal glimpse into the past.The last 10 pages might better have been left off. She skimpily mentions her interest in Socialism and then her first sexual experience. It seems abrupt and lacks the eloquence of the rest of her memories.

Short, but then that's what most Kindle readers want, something to give them some info but not blather on too long.It tells you how to prep during the week to be ready to write on the weekend. There are tips for exercise breaks, proper eating and other necessities to keep the writer in optimum mode.It seemed useful while I was reading it, but a lot of it didn't stick in my mind. Here it is a week later and I can't remember much of it.

The author explains his method for turning out 2 books a week including how to choose the topics. These are short ebooks that you self-publish. There was no explanation of how he markets these other than getting the SEO right starting out.Can someone else read this and do the same? I'm doubtful that many of us can research topics and write as quickly as he says he does. Is it worth trying? I'm thinking the main purpose of the book is to inspire wanna-be-writers to jump into the ebook market with both feet.Is the book worth $2.99? I'm glad I got my copy while it was free. I'm wondering how many of the readers of his 100 books feel they got their money's worth from his short "books." Actually in today's age of short attention spans, that's exactly what many readers want.

I usually load up my Kindle with free books, but this one looked so good, I paid for it. I'm glad I did.It reminds me of Half-Broke Horses by Jeannette Walls. The writer retells the stories she heard from her grandmother and does it in such a way, that you feel you are hearing them first-hand from Maude herself.She didn't have an easy life and her problems parallel the early times around the turn-of-the-century in Missouri, on into the hard life of the Great Depression, the migration to find work in the north, struggle to adjust to big-city life, sending sons off to WWII, etc.It's not a dry history book, it's the life of one woman struggling to care for her family. Her account of the Depression era adds to what I learned from my mother's memoir, My Flint Hills Childhood: Growing up in 1930s Kansas.

This is quite entertaining reading, beyond being an account of the regiment's movements during the Civil War. I discovered it while working on genealogy and finding I have an ancestor who served in Company A of this regiment.It includes first-hand accounts from recruitment to mustering in, and training. As the chapters progress, you learn about incidents, often humorously told, of long days marching, nights huddling in a tent with rain running through it and of foraging for food to supplement the rations.There is great detail on the Siege of Vicksburg, descriptions of scenery and people... Really a great book for learning about the life of a Civil War infantryman.The copy I read was available online and was searchable.

I bought a bracelet that had this kind of clasp and it was so easy to put on and take off, that I wanted this for other pieces I wear. The clasp converter can be used with any of my necklaces or bracelets. Then I can easily put them on without fiddling with tiny clasps behind me or putting on a bracelet one handed.The two powerful but small magnets are easy to guide together. Just get them in the vicinity of each other and boink, they grip. It's strong enough that I don't have to worry about them letting loose. I love it.

We bought a string of these to hang in our gazebo which we use for outdoor dining. We attached them to the crossbeams using those plastic ties that you can use for wires.The globes look fabulously festive. I'm just ordering a 2nd string now for even more light in that area.

I'm perfectly satisfied with this spray bottle (but got mine for $2 at Walmart).It's pretty much your basic sprayer like those that Windex comes in. I wanted this to use with my moss gardens which need frequent misting to stay happy. Works fine for that.

Handy little fan for desktop use. Only 4 inches high, it puts out a good breeze and sits firmly in place.You can tilt the round part to aim the breeze up or down. There's only 1 speed, so essentially it is either on or off. Suits me fine.I wanted mine to supplement the chill pad for my laptop. It still was overheating and shutting down, so I got this fan and aimed it for the hot spot under my laptop computer. So far, it is keeping my laptop cool enough that there have been no more crashes.PS - I found a great deal on this at Walmart.

Fairly easy to install and it lays flat against the tailgate when not in use. We have a covered bed, so didn't worry about the rust possibility that some reviewers found a problem. Seems quite sturdy and you can put a hand on the end of the truck to help balance as you climb up.Most of the others we considered were considerably more expensive than this one.
Very convenient to order these online and I'm particular about getting the pure d-alpha. Saves us a long drive to the store.

I enjoy reading childhood memoirs from this era, but this one had the novelty of being an Australian childhood and teen years rather than the more common American ones.Fun to read, and you'll learn a lot about the typical activities of kids in that era. Some of the family scenes were funny. The author's father was British and her mother was a New Zealander. Their adjustment to living in Australia adds further dimension to the memoir.Towards the end of the book, the author does some backpacking and you get thumbnail sketches of traveling in Turkey, around Asia, and Europe. I kept wanting her to go into more detail there about her feelings on the experience as it read like postcard briefs.

I'm a fairly new tea drinker as I had to get away totally from sodas. This sampler gave me a chance to try out some flavors to see what I liked. The tea is in small bags with no string (better for the environment, I guess) and then sealed in 5 packets to protect the flavor.My favorite one was the honey vanilla chamomile, so I'll be ordering some of that to have for drinking in the evening when I don't want caffeine.My least favorite was the peppermint one which reminded me of toothpaste. You might react differently, as flavor preferences are very personal.
