This is the third in this series of little garden statues that I've purchased. I add one each year to my garden. They look delightful placed among the ferns or in my moss gardens.This one arrives in 2 pieces but it is simple to place the wings on the back of the fairy using the small bracket there. Just insert the flange on the wings into the bracket on the fairy's back.These hold up well though the patina changes slightly as they weather. I take mine inside over the winter and just place them in the garden in the summer.They look like stone or metal but are a hard vinyl. This keeps the price down but gives the look of a more expensive figure.

Lady Julia's wedding falls on Midsummer Night. She describes the event in letters to a relative, but it reads like it's happening right now. It's the 1890s and she's madly in love with her part-gypsy commoner. The wedding day could have been a disaster with a notorious jewel thief lurking around, a house fire, a kidnapping and a rift between the groom and his people.A number of the plot lines link back to earlier Lady Julia mysteries, but I'd not read those and it did not detract from the story. Enjoyable read and I'll look for more by Deanna Raybourn.

Hubby wanted something compact (this folds down fairly flat) to keep the sun off the steering wheel (yes, it does that).I wanted something besides a silver reflective panel in the window. This has a nice scene.Fits our Ram truck just fine.

In this series, a zombie epidemic breaks out and it's up to Cass and her crew to fight them, and find out why there is the epidemic. Along the way, she soon learns that zombies aren't the only ones to fear.The story goes along at a good pace and has a lot of action. The characters are good, and they're likable enough.  There is also enough plot twists to keep the reader hooked.For me, this is a tale of two books. Books 1-3 were outstanding! I loved them, and couldn't read them fast enough. Books 4-5 were really bad. They took a religious turn and the ending left a lot to be desired.Just know going into it, first three books are fantastic, and the last two there was a major drop in quality

I have mixed feeling about this book. Don't get me wrong, there's a lot of good lessons when you want to focus on multiple intelligences. That being said, there are some very poor project lessons that are highly inappropriate. One of them is to reenact the Kennedy assassination. What?? Reenact that?? That's a great way to get in trouble with the administration.

This is a very good book for teachers to read if they want good classroom management, and classroom management  is very important on the classroom. It talks on how to properly react to kids who act out.  This shows how you can have discipline, but still give the child dignity.

This is an excellent resource for any teacher that's in the primary grades. The book goes into many ways on how to help a child read, and it will play to the child's strengths. I highly recommend this book, and should be in every teacher's classroom.

Words can't express how amazing Taylor is.  I came across her by accident on youtube, I heard her, and I honestly moved to tears. That's something that never happens to me. I then went out and picked up all 7 of her CD's, this is truly a magical CD.  My favs are Pirates of the Caribbean, James Bond, Harry Potter, Indiana Jones, and Mission Impossible.  I can't say enough good things about the gift Taylor has.  I'd love to see her in concert. Get this now, and I ***promise*** you won't be sorry.  Taylor is beyond talented.
I'm just going to cut to the chase, this is a fantastic read. The stories are very scary, perfect for this time of hear. If you get it, I can promise you won't be sorry.

It seems this is a real story that happened to Keene. The problem is that it's so mind numbingly slow.  Honestly, it's Keene just rambling on with no clear direction. It seem that this was written for cathartic reasons, and Keene has to work out personal demons. If that's the case, that's fine, but it should never have been published.  The only things that happens are a glider moves and toys turn on and off.  He even said how he went and looked up the accident  that killed the girl and then he *knew* it was her because he saw a picture of her in the paper.  The problem is that he never saw the girl on the glider to identify her.This is a boring read, skip it.

This is set in the 17th Century. It seem that Christopher is good at mixing potions and serves his Master well. It seems that there's a secret society out there, and they're killing people, and through a series of events, the society is targeting Christopher. With the help of his Master, and friend, Christopher uses his skills at potions and mixing to bring the secret society to justice. The problem is that this secret society has set their sights on Christopher and the people he cares about. That's all I want to say about the plot, if I say anything more, it would be spoilers.This is a very good read that will hold the attention of YA readers.  I couldn't help that when I was reading about Christopher mixing elements to beat the bad guys, that he's a young MacGyver.

In this go around, Reacher gets off a train, and a woman comes to him, thinking that Reacher is someone else.  The woman is Michelle Chan, ex FBI and now a PI, and she's looking for her missing partner. Soon Reacher joins the search, and uncovers something much, much, bigger. That's all I want to say about the plot.Wow, this is a clunker. The downward spiral continues. There are so many problems with it. 1) It's far too long.  This book was easily 100-150 pages too long.  If you cut that you, then you'd have a nice tight story.  2) We get page after page of useless description on non essential things and places. We get an endless inner monologue by Reacher, and it just drags the plot down.  Honestly, at one point, I wasn't sure if Reacher was fighting, or planning his moves. 3) It seems that plot gets dragged out for no reason, it just adds to the tedious mind numbingly plot, it's fluff, and nothing more.  4) There's a repetitiveness of terms and sayings, it grew old, really fast. Okay, we get it, do we have to hear the same phrase over and, and over, and over, and over?  5) The female character was flat and boring. 6) Reacher obsessed on finding out what the town is called "Mother's Rest". To be honest, it was a distraction. 7) Either one of two things have happened, 1-Lee Child just doesn't care anymore, or 2- He's having the book ghost written. Ever since The Affair, and when the Reacher movie came out, the books have changed. Either way, I'm kind of let down by Child.Now, that all being said, there was one good part of the book that I really liked...at the end, there was a plot twist. It was one I didn't see coming.There have been rumors that Child is planning on killing off Reacher pretty soon. If this is the case, then he better give Reacher an honorable death. Personally, I'd love if Child just ended the series, and keep Reacher alive, it'd be nice to know that Reacher is still out there.  I just want Child to get back to the basics.If Make Me was tightened up, this could have been really good, but it wasn't, and it's not.

This is the first time I read this author, and I was impressed, and that's not easy to do. Pizza Delivery is a short story of a pizza delivery boy who delivers pizzas, then he goes to the wrong house.  He witnesses a mass murder, then he killer sets his sights on the delivery boy. I know it sounds like a simple plot, and it is, but it's a heck of a ride.  I plan to read more by this author.

McCoy is called to a town that seems to have problems with paranormal creatures, and pretty much he's the only one that can deal with them. When he gets there, he begins to see that there's more than meets the eye. There's a special reason why this town is under attack, and it's up to McCoy to get to the bottom of it.This really is a nice start to a series.  If you like Things that go Bump in the Night.....and someone who bumps back, then this is must read. I'm looking forward to getting the next book in the series.

This is such a good season. I'll skip over what the show is about. If you've seen any of the seasons, then you know what this is about.  It had a lot of interesting  couples and nice challenges.I really disliked Jonathan. He was abusive- emotional, verbally, and physical against Victoria. He's the only low point in the season.If you have someone in your life that loved The Amazing Race, then this is a must have for them.

Fantastic! If you have a teacher in your life, then this is a must have for them.  The quality of the sweatshirt is very high. Much better than I expiated. Not only is it good quality, but it's nice and warm.

This is fantastic!  The colors are bright and vivid. I love how the characters look, this is such a cool shirt. If you have a Big Bang Theory fan in your life, then this is a must product for them. I can promise you, you won't be sorry.

This is a very solid follow up to the first  book.  This time Flea is "fitting in" to the life at the North Pole.  Soon he find outs that Jack Frost is planning an attack, Frost can't be found. Flea soon finds out that the danger is much, much closer than he thinks and soon finds that he's been betrayed by someone. With all of this going on, he learns some new things about his family.  Honestly, that's all I can say about the plot, anything more would be spoilers.I really liked how Flea was fitting in. He took part in some snow games and against many different people that's at the North Pole. Think of it as the Triwizard Torment from the Potter books. After this is done, Flea learns of an attack at from Jack Frost, but soon Flea learns that everything isn't as it seems. I really like that the character of Flea is growing and developing.I can't enough good things about this book series. If you have a child that doesn't like to read, then I highly suggest you introduce them to this series they'll be hooked.

In this go around, Kari's brother has been kidnapped and it's up to Kari and her friends to get her brother back. The thing is that Kari has to go up against an unseen force, and when all the puzzles pieces are in place, Kari isn't ready for what she has to face, who she has to face, and the sacrifices that it brings. She also has to get help form a total stranger.Overall, it was an okay read at best. The reason I gave it four stars was because I really liked the "End Game" that Sealed with a Lie has. I can't really say too much because it would involve a lot of spoilers and I want the reader to discover them on their own.That being said, this wasn't a perfect read. I grew tired of Kari's worrying about her brother. She's worried, I get it. But do we have to heard about it every other page? It was just so over the top for me. Say it one or twice, but that's it. We know she's worried about her brother, that's why she wants to rescue him, we get it. Also I could have done with out all the times that Kari is checking someone one out, I can't say who, but then says, "I don't like him". It was done over and over, and was annoying. Then this author did one that's a major pet peeve of mine, and that's using parentheses when she writes. I loathe that, it just grates on my nerves. Anything an author puts in a parentheses is nothing more than meaningless jibber-jabber. It adds nothing to the story.Overall, this was an okay read, not as good as the first, but I liked it enough. I really liked the End Game. If it didn't have that, I'd give it 2 or 3 stars.

I picked this up for my friend's daughter for Christmas. She loves Dorothy, she was Dorothy for Halloween, and she's going to love this.  This is so cute, and plays Somewhere over the Rainbow.  Great gift, I can't wait to see her expression when she opens it.
I bought this for my son's friend who is Autistic and he loves elephant.  I know this will be a perfect gift for him.This is so cute, and perfect for Christmas.

I bought this for my friend's son who is Autistic, and he loves elephants, and I know this will be a major hit with him. This will be warmed up before bed or nap time, and it will help keep him warm.  I know he's going to love this.

I bought this for my friend's daughter who's four, and I know she will one this. This can be heated up in the microwave before her nap or bedtime, and it will keep her warm and something to snuggle up to. This is a fantastic gift.
These are so good. It has a nice Strawberry flavor and a nice crunch. If you're into healthier eating, then you must get these. You won't be sorry, I know I wasn't.

Anne is back at school, and she wants to uncover a mystery at the Wheatley School. It seems that one of her favorite teacher has vanished off the face of the Earth, and Anne wants to know why.  What Anne doesn't know is that some secrets should stay buried. That's all I really want to say about the plot. Anything more would be spoilers.This was an okay read, not great, but okay. I have to tread lightly here because of spoilers. I consider there are two endings to the book. The first ending to me was a let down. Something happened to Anne, and the consequences of her actions didn't make sense. For me, it felt rushed, and not a lot of thought was put into it. The first ending was thrown together. The "second" ending was interesting. It leaves room for Taylor to visit Anne once again, if she decides to. The door is open, and the plot lines are there.This was just an okay conclusion to the series. Not bad, but not great. Consider this a "middle of the road" ending.

I saw this had it's fair share of poor review, so I took a gamble on it, not sure what to expect. I'm glad I picked it up, because it was such a good read. Suzanne's boyfriend, Joe, is shot in the line of duty, and has to spend time with her so he can recuperate. As the story develops, someone is after Joe, and knows exactly where Joe is, and goes after him. With this going on, someone from Suzanne's past is also after her, and this person knows where Suzanne is. That's all I really want to say about the plot, anything more would be spoilers. Some things happen with secondary characters that just add a nice touch to the book/series.One part I really liked was the we, as the reader, get the point of view from the person that's after Joe. It was a nice touch. For me, the series is still fresh and new and keeps me glued to the page, and that's all I can ask. I'm entertained, and that's what counts.As usual, this has recipes that sound really good. Not fat free, but good. :O)Get this book, you won't be sorry, I know I wasn't.

I had such high hopes for this book. For me, this series is a hit and miss, with most of them being good. This isn't one of them.To make a long story short, Tricia's sister has a secretary, nobody liked her, and she was found dead. It's up to Tricia and her sister to solve the murder.This had such a shot at being a good book As Tricia digs into the victim's murder, and finds some pretty shocking things her. To me, that was really good and interesting. I actually wanted to find out more about it. The problem is that there was so much fluff to it. There was one plot line about Tricia's ex and a love triangle. For me, that didn't work, and it had a very creepy element to it. It was just uncomfortable to read. Also to add to the fluff, Tricia learns something about her past, a deep dark family secret. Just more fluff.I so wanted to like it, but it was a major letdown. To be honest,  may not read any more books in the series.

First off, I really wanted to like this. I really liked the first one in the series, and I was really wanted to like this one. This was a major let down.First off, there's far too much fluff.  The first 20 pages are a complete waste. She talks with her friends about solving a "Locked Room Mystery". It has nothing to do with the plot (and I use that term loosely) and just drags us down with useless information. Then we get to what I thought was the "plot" about a guy who hung himself, but it was actually murder and Mack solves it. The problem is that she solves it quickly, and that lead to another case for her to solve. In other words, it was a total waste of time.  Secondly, the writing style is pretty bad. Some characters talk, just to talk, and it was tedious to read and grew steadily on my nerves.Normally, I'd say get this book at the library, but don't even waste your time. Life is far too short to waste time on reading books like this. I don't plan on reading any more books in this series.This is a clunker, skip it.
These are fantastic! These have a nice smokey flavor to it. If you're into almonds, you have to get these. I bought these, and I'm glad I did. This is a great healthy snack.

I'm starting to eat almonds due to the good health benefits they provide. I bought these on a whim, and I love them.  They're crunchy and fantastic! The thing is that I'm really not a fan of dark chocolate, but these are so good. If you get these, you won't be sorry, I know I wasn't. I'll be getting more of these.

First off, I want to say that I'm a big fan of the show The Pretender.  When I found out that the series was going to be continued in books, I was excited, I couldn't get this fast enough, boy was I let down.There are so many things wrong with this. 1-This is just a retelling of the plot, but with a few things added. 2- The start was confusing and hard to follow. From what I able to get from it, it was terrorists mad at each other, and some shooting.  3- The writing style is horrible. It was as if an elementary school child wrote it.  It was complete with BAM! WHAM! BANG! SMASH! For a second or two, I thought I was watching the old Batman (The one with Adam West) TV series. 4-The language. What was the purpose with all the swearing. It's not necessary. 4-The sex in the book was over the top. Come on, The Pretender has nothing to do with sex. It was a joke.Over all, skip it. There are good stories among us.....this isn't one of them.

This is a fantastic poster, and it's going to be a fantastic movie. When you look at the poster you can really see the sadness in Chloe's eyes, and the hard choices she'll have to make in the movie.  If you put this in a nice frame, as I did, and put it on a wall, it will become the center piece of the room.  Get it now, you won't be sorry. I know I wasn't.

Jessica is a high school student by day and a paranormal investigator by night. She comes across a graveyard that has rumors of paranormal activity. Jessica will soon find out just how haunted this graveyard really is. She soon learn of something that Jessica just can't let go of, and soon the spirit of the graveyard sets it's sights on her. That's all I want to say about the plot, anything more would be spoilers.This really is a good read that will keep you hooked to the very last page. There are some funny and spooky elements to it. I too am a paranormal investigator, and Shea really hits the nail on the head with this story. There are small nuggets that he puts in his story that makes it feel like an investigation.If you pick this up you won't be sorry. Hey it's free, or it was when I picked it up, and you can't go wrong with free. I plan to get the next book in the series.

This Pet Magasin product is a really fantastic one for car cleanliness. It's made of a heavy, quilted Cordura-like synthetic fabric with a semi-waterproof backing (which does have an unpleasant vinyl smell for a few hours after unpacking; I'd plan on airing it out before the first use). It slings like a hammock across a car's backseat from headrest to headrest. Mounting and dismounting is easy, and it appears very washable (though I haven't yet tried). It ought to contain all but the biggest messes easily for almost any length of drive I guess if a large pet has a large accident, you might still want to pull over to mop up some of the liquid, but even that should be a quick and easy process, and anything short of a Niagara Falls-like flood should allow you to drive on. It's also very useful for non-pet messy cargoes I'll be leaving it in the trunk and using it for large plants and soils, and building materials, for instance. A great car accessory at a reasonable price.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

This kids' scarf and hat set from Chinese direct-seller Simplicity is a shockingly high-quality and attractive ensemble considering its low price. I ordered the red color, which is fun and festive without being too gender-coded girls and boys might both enjoy the slightly Christmasy red-and-green look. The acrylic material is soft and pleasant next to the skin but also seems like it'll wash and clean up easily, and the knitting is excellent, regular and smooth. All in all, apart from the cheap cellophane packaging (which will be forgotten instantly after unwrapping), this is a first-rate set for any kid between about 6 and 10 or so, maybe even a little older depending on their size.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

This Viva Labs product is a solid source for Vitamin C supplementation in a large bulk quality (it's sold as 200 capsules but I received a "bonus" 250-capsule package). It's vegetarian-friendly, and the capsules are a standard size which, if not the easiest to swallow in the world, is certainly the best packaging for this bulk of vitamin that you're going to find. There's no unpleasant flavor or backwash later on, and while I can't directly evaluate the manufacturer's somewhat dubious claims of better bioavailability than other forms of Vitamin C, it's certainly no worse than others. A good bulk C capsule for megadosing if that's something you're into.

This silk scarf from the Chinese direct-sales brand Simplicity is a really impressive one in appearance, that could easily pass for a much more expensive gift if it's repackaged before giving. Despite the page title, the variety I received (B10634), like one of the other three choices, is a design apparently derived not from Van Gogh but from Klimt's Tree of Life, covered in curlicues in a gorgeous color gradient from deep earthy orange at one end to deep ocean blue at the other. This, combined with the scarf's length, allows for lots of variety in how you wear it. The material feels good it's not going to pass for Herms, but it's smooth and attractively lustrous, with a nice hand and rolled edges and the printing is high-quality.Really, the only sign of the budget price is the packaging, a simple cellophane wrapper within a protective ziploc bag. If you're buying for yourself, that shouldn't be a problem at all and if you're giving it as a gift, I'd recommend simply repackaging it before giving. The scarf's folded size as shipped is 9.5" x 11", so a flat presentation box such as this or this should do nicely; and after re-wrapping it, you could tell someone you got it for them at a high-end museum shop (or just let them guess) and they'll be none the wiser. It's a first-rate, attractive product.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

For the price, this Nivea multi-pack is a great deal on men's grooming products, though not all the components are first-rate or even really worth buying individually. It's a nice cheap gift option, but gift buyers should be wary of the packaging: mine came with a big, prominent sticker reading "Special value! $9.99!" That's not exactly something to make any recipient feel appreciated.The individual components, all in fairly full-sized containers, are body wash, face wash, aftershave balm, and a lip-balm stick. None is luxurious, but all are usable enough, with pleasant mild drugstore-manly Axe-like or medicinal scents. The body wash is a nice basic product, nothing special but functional. The face wash has a somewhat unpleasantly slimy consistency, and contains polluting non-biodegradable plastic microbeads; altogether it's the least pleasant product in the bundle. The aftershave balm is also a fine, basic product, with a mildly spicy aquatic scent. The lip balm is waxy and nice, with only a mild Chapstik-like scent. I'm not sure I'd buy any of these products in preference to my usual ones, but they're all perfectly fine, and together at this price it's hard to argue with the assortment.

This scale from Accuweight is excellent for kitchen use and will also be very functional for mailing and packaging (provided the packages are fairly small). It's compact, arrives well and durably packaged (I appreciated the recyclability of the cardboard packing materials), and setup is as easy as removing the insulating strip from the battery compartment. Use is similarly foolproof, with a simple tare function and one-button metric/imperial unit conversion. After unpacking, I tested it a few times against a more expensive, German Soehnle kitchen scale, and found the Accuweight exactly as fast and accurate. It's a great scale that will see a lot of use in my house, for mailing as well as cooking.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

This YOPO product is a solid basic Apple Watch charging stand, much like many others. It's a solid metal material with a shiny silver finish, backed by silicone rubber on both the weighted foot and the display stand arm. Some assembly is required the arm mounts to the base with a couple of very small screws, and an allen wrench is included, but it's a slightly fiddly process to get them in. Once done, the flexible rubber backing accepts the Apple Watch magnetic charger with only a little bit of shoving, and holds it firmly. The stand looks nice enough, and works well. It's nothing special, but it's a nice basic stand.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

This Eightwins nailclipper is an excellent one, with a somewhat unusual design in heavy steel. The large pivoting handles so big that they may be a little too big for small or weak hands to operate provide a lot of leverage, useful for tough toenails. The blade is reasonably sharp and precise, unlike some budget drugstore models, and the look is attractive in an industrial way. All in all, it's a nice product, nicer than many of the cheaper ones, and I'll be using it frequently.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

Considering the low price, this Freeker is a really good two-pronged "rabbit"-style vibrator (provided you like the smooth texture and look). It's made of a surprisingly high-quality, warm fuchsia silicone that feels pleasant and cleans easily, and the smooth sides make for easy maintenance. The look is basic in size (not excessive) and abstract shape, with a little bit of flex (it's not rigid on either end of the two-pronged head). The motor is surprisingly strong, smooth, and quiet for a budget-oriented vibe, with multi-speed and pulse operation available with repeated button presses (a long press turns it off again). It's a nice, very fun and functional choice for a basic rabbit-style vibe without the odd look of the actual animal-shaped ones, just a tasteful abstract shape that won't weird anyone out.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

This Cupider vibrator has some nice points the shape, the waterproof use but is a little weaker than some of the manufacturer's other products. It's essentially two pieces, a slightly soft silicone toy with an insertable bullet vibe. The toy is nicely shaped, smooth and usable in different ways, but the vibe is a bit on the weak side and uses a hard-to-find "AAAA" battery, which limits its practicality and strength. It does have pulsed as well as steady operation, which is a nice feature, available with repeated button presses (a long press turns it off). But the vibration transmitted to the tip of either prong of the toy is a little weak. The manufacturer's other toy in this shape is stronger and more rigid, and so provides a little more fun.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

Considering the low price, this Freeker is a really nice basic vibrator (provided you like the "realistic" veiny look). It's made of a surprisingly high-quality, warm purple silicone that feels pleasant and cleans easily (which is good, because the textured "veins" do collect grime a little bit, compared to smoother vibes). The look is basically realistic in size (not excessive) and shape, with a nicely flared base. The motor is strong, smooth, and surprisingly quiet for a budget vibe, with multi-speed and pulse operation available with repeated button presses (a long press turns it off again). It's a nice, very fun and functional choice for a basic vibe that won't break the budget you could give 'em out as party favors at this price!The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

First and most importantly, the Remington Beardsman Beard Boss (cram the word "beard" into the branding a few more times, won't you?) MB4045A is essentially identical, apart from cosmetic details, to the MB4040, which is sold at a lower price. Buy whichever one is cheaper; there is no reason to pay substantially more for this kit's few extra nice, but cheap, accessories, much less its "copper" (brown) color or its ridiculously twee beardo branding.That said, this is a nice trimmer for beards, sideburns, body hair, and so on. It's way too narrow and jams too easily to use for a full haircut; you'll want a full-size trimmer such as Wahl's for that. But the narrow width, along with the nice adjustable guides, allows precise grooming and easy handling. It's a convenient size, the battery lasts for a long time, and the lower cutting power that's sometimes annoying in a cordless hair trimmer doesn't seem to be a problem for the Remington at all. It's a nice, tidy little package for personal grooming.

(Note: Several different products are gathered under the same Amazon listing. This is a review of the 70% dark chocolate.)Once you get inside its many layers of overpackaging a massive, protective, but ugly outer cardboard box opens to reveal three bars that are individually boxed and double-wrapped  it takes a little inspection of the label to discover that these "Cailler L'Ecorce" chocolate bars are a new product line from megacorporation Nestle, rather than some new artisanal or newly imported-from-Europe chocolate maker.Unfortunately, the flavor of the product inside all the luxury packaging and French-heavy branding is not really up to this high-end chocolaterie appearance; in taste it is a pleasant and smooth dark chocolate, but nothing remotely special or worth the very high price. The bar is attractively formed enough, molded with little wave shapes, but seems like it's trying to simulate an artisanal product when it's really a purely industrial one. I'd recommend buyers looking for a serious and flavorful chocolate go to Lindt's 70% dark chocolate for somewhat better, richer flavor at a more reasonable price, or move up to a genuine artisanal product.

(Note: Several different products are gathered under the same Amazon listing. This is a review of the Milk Chocolate with whole Almonds, Hazelnuts & Raisins variety.)Once you get inside the many layers of insane overpackaging a massive protective outer box, around two bars that are boxed and double-wrapped individually  it takes a little inspection of the label to discover that these "Cailler L'Art du Brut" chocolate bars are a new product line from megacorporation Nestle, rather than some new actually-artisanal or newly imported-from-Europe chocolate maker.Unfortunately, the flavor of the product inside all the luxury packaging and French-heavy branding is not up to this high-end chocolaterie appearance; in taste it resembles a Cadbury fruit-and-nut bar more than anything else. It presents a more attractive-looking package  the half-submerged raisins and nuts sticking up at the top of each segment are a nice touch but the flavor is tooth-hurtingly oversweetened, not very chocolatey, and just plain boring. I'd recommend against this if you're looking for a serious and flavorful chocolate.

This iPhone case from Willnorn (Norn One? Silk? the product name is almost impossible to figure out) is a nice choice for ultra-thin decorative scratch protection, but don't expect major drop or bump protection. It is made from a single thin layer of plastic, well-manufactured with precise cutouts; insertion and removal are easy. The plastic appears to coated with an iridescent paint that looks really cool shiny and glisteny, with a pearlescent look that appears different colors from different angles but is also quite dusty when first unwrapped, leaving behind a lot of grime and small particles. I'd recommend wiping it down carefully before first use. Apart from that, it's a nice thin case for basic, slim scratch protection, nothing more.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

This LED candelabra bulb from TGM is a nice one. Be aware that "daylight white" 6000K is a very blue color temparature in a candelabra and a candle-style bulb, especially, it can look a little weird, and if you're used to incandescent you might want to go with a warmer white. But presuming you're looking for a bright blue-white bulb that gives true color indoors, this is a wonderful choice. I like the way the "filaments" look inside the clear glass bulb; it's a look more like a traditional Edison bulb than you might expect.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

The Ulak Clear Slim case is a very nice combination of protection and attractive slenderness. It's one of the best iPhone 6/6s cases I've seen, especially considering the price, and well worth considering for clear-case fans. The case resembles those ultra-thin soft and flexible TPU cases you can buy for a dollar in transparency, allowing you to show off the phone, but provides a much sturdier-seeming thick rim and more rigid back plate for protection, with air pockets at the corners that appear as if they'd help with impact from a short drop. It's still not an ultra-protective case, but considering the slenderness and clearness it's a good tradeoff; for a step up in protection I'd go to the Silk Pureview, but that's also noticeably thicker and has a less clear rim. If you want complete transparency, this is a great choice.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

This Hoover Commercial upright vacuum is light enough to be easy to move around, but still boasts very good suction power. On my first quick living-room pass with it, it pulled a significant amount of junk out of my carpet.Unboxing is easy but not instant. The vacuum comes mostly assembled, but needs to be lifted vertically out of the box, a bit of a challenge, and a Philips-head screwdriver is required for the one screw attaching the handle -- but after that, it's plug and play. The instructions aren't great, and the illustrations do not clearly show how to insert the one (and only one!) provided bag: the secret is that the bag's rigid cardboard hole-guard inserts into a guide in the front, and the rest of the bag fits behind the guide.In use, the vacuum is light and easy enough to maneuver, comparing well to other full-sized uprights. The handle tilts easily when unlocked using the foot pedal, which is easy to operate like all of its controls and attachments. It's not quiet at all in fact it's pretty loud, as a "commercial" model, compared with most home vacuums but considering the combination of power and lightweight plastic that's not a huge surprise. And the noise level is not intolerable.The dust bag detaches and empties easily, and the "one-touch" drop system is really nice, requiring little to no contact with the dirty full bag. The Y-type bags the machine takes are enormous and should last for a very long time between changes.All in all, I think this Hoover vacuum is a pretty good value. It's lightweight, usable, powerful, clean, and seems well-made.

NOTE: THIS IS A UV, ULTRAVIOLET, LIGHT. Don't buy it if you're looking for a regular flashlight; it's a "black light" for revealing stains, lighting parties/raves, etc.Having said that, this is a nice, sturdy UV LED flashlight from Zookki. Build quality is solid and compact but sturdy; the LED bulb assembly seems well built. The UV light is fairly bright, very useful in a semi-dark or darkened room. Kids (or adults!) who like to play CSI-style science and investigation games will have a lot of fun with it; so will ravers or astronomy fun-house types.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

I've only used the camera for a moment, so I'll try to update this review once I have some more experience with the DBPOWER dashcam, but on first impressions it is a solid and useful product. Dashboard cameras are useful for insurance and legal purposes but also for fun, allowing you to document your travel easily. This one, while it requires a memory card, has a nice lens, is compact and attractive, and works well, with easy looping video recording that doesn't require much intervention (fortunately) while driving. It can record a time stamp that's legible at all times, useful for legal or insurance purposes, and all the functions I've tested so far are straightforward enough for easy operation.It appears to be a very high-quality product at a reasonable price.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

There's not much to say about these Reynolds muffin cups besides that they work great, look nice, and are a terrific value for the money. They have an attractive blue design that presents well, and the free-standing bake capability (while probably best not tested with super-heavy and wet liquid batters) works nicely and is a useful feature for cramming an oven as full as possible. This is a nice product at an attractive price, and I'd recommend it for general use.

This Avantek antenna works well, is well made, and seems like a good deal all around. It arrives packed well, requiring only minimal connection and assembly the parts are the flat sheet antenna, with molded-in cable, a separate small stand, and the AC power adapter (which, instructions indicate, is optional: you can use it in powered or unpowered configurations). It all pops together instantly and plugs into a TV or receiver with a fairly well-made coaxial connector. And, as advertised, it really helps! Even unpowered, I found my set able to pick up many more FM radio stations, and digital TV channels, than it can with the cheapo wire antenna that's the only thing included in the box these days. A useful and well-made device!The manufacturer provided a sample for review.

These LED light bulbs from Lohas are excellent, a true warm white that resembles incandescent bulbs. They run cool, have a small and durable-seeming form factor (also much like incandescent), and are instantly nice and bright. To me, the brightness seems greater than claimed more like a 60W incandescent than a 40W, or at least somewhere in between but in any case, it's a useful mid-level brightness that will work in bedrooms, reading lamps, or multi-bulb fixtures without overpowering you. Recommended.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

Not much you could say about this Colgate mouthwash, which is entirely typical of its category. It's strongly artificial-mint-flavored, like a wintergreen candy. The one real feature setting it apart is just that it's fluoridated, which helps keep teeth intact, a good thing. It seems fairly expensive compared to drugstore brands, and is indistinguishable from them in flavor and function, but if you like the brand for some reason it's a fine choice, as it also is given that fluoridated mouthwashes can be slightly harder to find.

This SoTru protein shake mix is a nice concept a soy-free, protein-heavy, low-carb mix of vegetable and mushroom derivatives with lots and lots of apparent nutritional value, much more than the average protein shake. I was expecting to enjoy using it to supplement my diet while exercising. But it tastes so disgusting, so completely unpalatable, that I couldn't even manage to choke it down after a few tries, either mixed with yogurt or plain water. The strong cocoa flavor and excessive stevia sweetening can't mask the underlying bitter, nasty mix of fermented flavors, and combine with them to make them even worse. There's a strong stevia/metallic aftertaste, and all in all the experience is more or less like intensely artificially sweetened, hot-cocoa-flavored vomit. (Not exaggerating, it made me gag.) I'd recommend shopping elsewhere for a more palatable, less horrible-flavored shake.

Wrath of the Righteous is another in a series of fun customizable card games in the Pathfinder series, but there's not a lot new here for players of previous versions it's more of the same, but still fun. In brief, I'd still recommend it strongly as an entry point for people looking for a collaborative light-RPG-like adventure experience, but there's nothing to prevent you from picking up previous sets instead (perhaps used) if you haven't already played them.The rulebook is still one of the worst in gaming, with terribly opaque explanations, distracting color text and layout that doesn't make the basic rules' structure clear, and all kinds of annoying ambiguity. Short of a total rewrite by a better writer, a quick reference card would be really welcome here. As with previous versions, new players will probably spend a lot of time searching rules questions on Web forums while you get up to speed.The game, though, is still a lot of fun, capturing the spirit of dungeon-delving power gaming in a quick, playable form and needing no Game Master or competitor to give collaborating players a feeling of a fun but eminently winnable challenge. This version gives a nice sense of "higher-level" play, with powered-up characters. These include some fun variations, and some returning old favorites from previous versions, and feel somewhat better balanced than previous sets, especially the terribly unbalanced Rise of the Runelords, where some were borderline unplayable. It's genuinely fun to replay and experiment with different party combinations.As with the previous sets, though, there is a lot of reliance on adventure-deck expansions to provide more hours of play. You can, theoretically, design your own adventures, but in practice the variety and leveled-up progression of the expansion decks make play a lot smoother though more expensive. It'd be nice to see this already fairly expensive box provide more variety before players are asked to spend another chunk of dollars. Still, it's enjoyable enough that I'm probably on the hook for the whole "adventure path" set!

The Soundpeats M20 are a great set of cheap in-ear buds, with soundquality far exceeding their price. TheThe M20s are packaged in a clear plastic box, reasonable but not great in appearance or quality -- mine arrived somewhat banged-up and dented. Inside, you'll find the earphones along with a baggie of extra tips in various sizes. I found the initial fit good enough that I didn't need to experiment too much with the others, though they're nice to have. The earphones themselves are well-made, light enough to stay in the ear without much fuss. The cable is flat and soft-feeling; the one major problem with it -- and the set as a whole -- is the amount of noise it transmits. Handling the cable or brushing against it at all results in quite a bit of in-ear noise.The sound, though, is impressive for earphones this inexpensive, rivalling sets that cost two or three times as much. I found it satisfyingly bassy and also sharp at the top end, with perhaps a bit of a hole in the lower midrange, though not too bothersome or steep. Everything from vocal and guitar-heavy music to jazz ensembles to hip-hop sounds well defined and surprisingly clear, considering the price.The M20s' sound is really impressive for earphones this inexpensive, and I'd recommend them for any use except exercise, given the slight problem of cord-handling noise.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

Though it works as a Bluetooth scale, the iHealth HS4 is a deceptive privacy nightmare, sharing your health data in ways that the manufacturer doesn't disclose until after you've already purchased and set it up. It requires not just the use of an app on your phone reasonable enough, by itself, for local app data viewing and storage but also that you set up an account on iHealth's servers. After which setup, it silently and without your consent sends all the data it collects to iHealth's servers! Let me repeat for emphasis: this scale has no apparent option allowing only local data display and collection. There is no opt-out allowing you to store your data only in iOS's secure and local-only HealthKit, and no clear disclosure that you are consenting by using the app to uploading all your data to iHealth's corporate servers forever. There is also no apparent way at all to delete your iHealth account once created your data is theirs forever once uploaded!In a huge and unethical grab, using iHealth's app at all means being coerced into sharing your private health data with iHealth and storing it on their servers. Since this is a totally unacceptably invasive practice, I strongly urge buyers to stay away from this and all their products.

This repair kit from DBPower is a convenient one-stop solution to replacing the iPhone 6's screen. As far as the quality of the replacement components, only time will tell, of course; I can say, they look fine on first use.But the real selling point here is the complete kit, which is an impressive deal. It includes a wide and useful variety of the necessary little electronic-repair tools -- plastic wedges and spudgers, micro screwdrivers, suction cup, cleaning cloth, etc. -- along with the screen/digitizer front panel assembly, packed cleanly and carefully in foam inside a rigid plastic shell. None of the tools are ultra-high-quality, of course, but they're all functional and they're all right there. This is really great and worth considering over just buying the part alone if, like me, you always end up losing a crucial one of these tools just before a project like this. It could save you days of annoyance.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

The DBPOWER BX-100 is a surprisingly okay-sounding little speaker for such a small package, though its volume is limited. It's a substantial rectangle the size of pair of bars of soap end-to-end, with only a USB charging cable (annoyingly, a wall-plug AC adapter is omitted -- this limits its usefulness as a bedside or in-room clock radio) and a headphone connector. Switched on, it's easy to pair (giving its name as "BX-100") and works straightforwardly. You'll want to turn the volume up to maximum immediately, as that's the only way to get it to a listenable volume level (even then it's not very loud), and use your source device's volume adjustment from there. It provides sound of something like the quality of a tabletop FM radio -- not room-filling dance beats by any means, but perfectly pleasant as background listening even for most kinds of music, as well as podcasts and other talk content.This won't really replace anyone's main stereo, or even their computer speakers or good headphones, but it's still a nice backup speaker for travel use, for hotel-room listening, or a small office desk or kitchen, that kind of thing. For that use, it's a nice pickup -- you'll just have to remember to keep it charged. For bedside use as a clock radio, I'd look for a different device.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

The Klymit Inertia O-Zone (what a silly name!) is a pretty nice ultralight inflatable sleeping pad for backpacking, with an impressive combination of comfort, light weight, and small packed size. It's a strong competitor to products like the old standby for ultralight hikers, the Therm-a-Rest ProLite, in comfort and weight, but the Klymit is significantly less convenient to pack and unpack, so you might want to try it out in person before buying.The design is interesting -- like a traditional inflatable sleeping pad (note that there's no foam core inside the fabric facing), but riddled with big circular Swiss-cheese holes. This saves weight, obviously. There are a ton of bonded seams, both around these holes and elsewhere in the pad to create air chambers that give the pad a surprisingly rigid structure when inflated, even without any internal foam. (All those bonded seams also make me pretty worried about the prospects for the pad's long-term durability, even compared to a Thermarest.) It isn't "self-inflating" like a Thermarest (which mostly aren't, either, in my experience), and needs to be blown up by mouth, which only takes a moment or two.The O-Zone is quite surprisingly comfortable when inflated, both for back and side sleeping, and the built-in pillow with separate air chamber and valve is an excellent touch, far better than you'd expect for an ultralight backpacking pad -- it might even let you dump a few extra ounces if you've been reliant on a hiking pillow for head support.But packing it is a bit laborious. Compared to a rectangular Thermarest, the Klymit is very finicky to deflate and roll; even on a flat indoor floor, I found it needed several steps. Only after first rolling it up repeatedly to remove the air was I able to re-fold and roll it tightly enough to be packed in the teensy included stuff sack. And without any straight lines or right angles in the pad's design I had a lot of trouble rolling it evenly after folding it over in fourths, as the stuff sack demands. It's not a big hassle, but it is one more little one, and added to every morning's routine that might be enough to make me prefer a solid-foam pad or an easier-to-roll Thermarest.Apart from packing and possibly seam durability, though, this is a nicely designed product and a great addition to the sleeping-pad choices for backpackers. Worth checking out.

The "Summer Palette" version of these cloth napkins is far nicer in person than it appears in the photos. The colors are much warmer, richer, more saturated; with the purple, green, and yellow, it seems sort of like a 1980s Benetton color scheme, not the weak, washed-out cool yellow represented in the photos here.The fabric is soft, thick, coarse and heavy, though not at all wrinkle-resistant; the napkins are very large, more like dishrags than anything dainty, and will do a great job for casual dining. Recommended, and don't be put off by the appearance of the color palette in the photos.

The Kelty TN2 is a really, really nice tent for moderate 2-person backpacking use, with a ton of nice little touches.In weight, it's a moderate backpacking tent. It's not for ultralight packers, but it still checks in at a fairly reasonable figure, with a claimed minimum packed weight of 4 lbs and a packed weight of 4 lbs 9 oz (though those are optimistic figures; on my scale the complete packed tent, in its packing cube with its stakes, checks in at a fairly portly 4 lbs 12 oz). For light or ultralight use, something like the significantly smaller, non-freestanding classic Sierra Designs Flashlight 2 saves more than a pound in packed weight; the TN2 is a direct competitor not for that but for their Flash 2, a taller freestanding 2-person tent with a more reasonable, non-squashed footprint, and it's a good competitor.The design is a traditional, two-pole freestanding tent (with a small extra spreader pole), with a big side-zip door, a mesh canopy and a fly with a small extended vestibule. It's a fairly easy pitch, with some helpful color-coding, well-designed grommets and clips, a pole "hub" up top, and good quality aluminum poles. A matching footprint is available, but a basic tarp trimmed to size should really serve just as well, since it's a rectangular design.But really, it isn't the basic design of the tent, but all the little nice, thoughtful touches that make it an attractive package. The fly has a roll-up "stargazing" feature -- I wasn't able to test this much, but it seems nice in concept. The included stakes are relatively high-quality, durable and rigid flat stakes, not the kind you have to throw out and replace immediately. The color choices are excellent, subdued greens and grays that won't be jarring and ugly in a wooded setting. The tent comes packed in a mesh-backed packing cube that, while it adds a bit of weight, makes a great stuff sack even if it gets wet in use. The fly and floor seams are taped from the factory, so it works well enough to get started without seam-sealing (the manufacturer still recommends urethane-based sealer for stronger waterproofing, but it's not as mandatory before the first use as it is for most cheaper tents).

The Soltech TubeMat is a nice, attractive rubber matting system that is adaptable to many different situations and locations. It can be a bath mat (at least if you don't need a water-absorbent cloth mat because your floor drains), a kitchen mat, an outdoor mat, or many other things; as the product page describes, it seems easy to cut to fit whatever size/shape you need and there are connectors provided that allow two or more mats to be fairly securely yoked to each other.The only problem is that you probably shouldn't rely on it for slip protection, even though it's designed for wet situations; the bottom tubes, and hence the mat itself, can slide around on many surfaces (especially sloped or curved ones like the inside of a shower). To use it for slip protection you'd have to bond it tightly to the surface it's covering, not just hope it won't slide around. Apart from that, it's very much as described, attractive, heavy, durable, and useful, and comfortable (if not quite flat) beneath bare feet.

This DeChunXian tea is a hard packed cake of "raw" pu-erh tea."Raw" of course means that it hasn't been aged and fermented for very long and shouldn't be expected to have the intense fermented flavor of an older tea. I found the taste consistent with that -- it's very pleasant tea, but quite light in flavor, with the dominant notes being basic, tannic bitterness and metallic/mineral aftertaste, rather than any noticeable tastes of fermentation. I suppose it can be aged further after purchase, but I haven't tried and I will probably use it all before any significant change in flavor occurs; if you're looking for a real heavily aged pu-erh, there are many other well-reviewed options on Amazon, like Longrun.The tea is high-quality, and seems to me basically worth the price, with nice long leaves and very little of the junk or twigs you sometimes see in a cheap pressed tea brick. It holds up to multiple steepings, too (the comically badly translated directions suggest 1-2 minutes steeping time, with longer times for later pots, but I found waiting a bit longer produced a richer tea, perhaps because I couldn't really understand the suggested portions either).The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

This mild insecticidal soap from Miracle-Gro seems to work well against aphids and other common garden bugs. Like all the similar potassium-fatty-acid soaps you have to spray heavily enough to cover the whole plant, or all the bug-affected surfaces, so you'll want to give it a little time. Competitors' products (e.g. Safer) are quite similar, and if you're willing to dilute and use your own sprayer, buying concentrate may be a cheaper way to go; myself, I like the pre-mixed form for convenience.Unlike some sprays it ships nicely packaged, with the spray head packed separately so the product remains securely capped and sealed in transit. A nice touch, and a nice product all around.

This product seems worryingly short on information about what it contains. Allergy sufferers might want to beware: it can cause pretty severe respiratory symptoms for a long while (days) after spraying. But it's impossible to determine what the offending ingredient is or how to address it: the bottle literally says nothing about what is in the product you've bought -- no allergy statement, no list of ingredients or potential problems. I'll be running fans all day to air out my house, disposing of the rest of this unused, and buying a more responsible brand's flea spray next time.

This battery-powered wireless mouse by Tonor is a perfectly fine, basic mouse with good feel on top but some poor design decisions on the bottom side. The battery compartment is hard to open, hard to insert the non-included AAA batteries in (the top one keeps popping out and has to be wedged at just the right angle), and hard to store the USB dongle in (there's a provided spot, but it sticks in very tightly and is hard to remove). Apart from that it's a nice mouse. The button feel is clicky and positive, the scroll wheel is excellent, the shape is comfy, and the finish is grippy. If you are looking for a wireless mouse with a USB dongle instead of a Bluetooth one, which I have no idea why you would be in 2015 (but who am I to tell you how to live), then this one is a fine and cheap choice.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

This AAA-powered Bluetooth mouse by Tonor is a perfectly fine, basic mouse once you figure out how to pair it. The one sheet of instructions, written in fractured machine-translated English, doesn't use the word "pairing" -- it says "matching" is what the tiny unlabeled second button on the bottom of the mouse does (that's how you put it into pairing mode). Once you slot in a pair of your own AAA batteries and discover that button, it pairs easily with Windows and Mac computers and works well. The button feel is nice, positive and clicky; the finish is a nice gloss black. It's a perfectly pleasant mouse to use, nothing special but good for the price.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

This bag from Avber is a very nice PU "leather" school-bag style tote in a size between purse and briefcase. It's small enough to work as a fashionable handbag but big enough for a guy to get away with, too.The bag is packed nicely, with paper stuffing to retain its shape and a two-layer overwrap to keep it from harm in shipping. Unpacking is easy and there's not much of the unpleasant vinyl offgassing smell that I encountered with another Avber bag. A thin, low-quality strap is included within the bag.The material is fairly heavy, soft and supple fake leather in two colors, an orange-brown stippled print for most of the bag and a burgundy accent color. It won't fool anyone into thinking it's leather up close, but it is soft and pleasant to touch. (I was reminded of '70s car seat vinyl, but in a good way, if that makes sense.) The top flap is two full layers of material, so quite heavy. Edge trim is nice if not totally neat, and the fasteners and fittings are a really nice slightly dull/antiqued brass, better than the ones on another Avber bag I tested. Magnetic closure on the two straps makes it easy to open and shut. There's a thin fabric lining with a few convenient pockets as well.All in all, this is a really nice bag and I'm looking forward to using it a lot. Recommended.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

The Tendak SuperSpeed is a nice, basic, fast and functional USB 3.0 Gigabit Ethernet network adapter.Though a mini-CD of drivers (shudder) is included in the basic plastic-bag packaging, it doesn't actually need them. It works seamlessly with Mac OS X, showing up immediately as an interface named "USB 10/100/1000 LAN" in the network settings. Speed is just as good as expected (though I didn't test it rigorously, I transferred a few files and found perceived speeds as fast as built-in Ethernet or high-speed wireless-N). The adapter is not ultra-compact, and it does run slightly warm in use, which worries me a bit about longevity, but at this price it's hard to complain. This is a nice, basic USB Ethernet adapter, and given how many smaller notebooks (like recent MacBook Pros) are dropping Ethernet, it's a good thing to have around in case of need.The manufacturer provided a free sample for this review.

Tauri's clear case for the Apple Watch is okay for basic scratch protection, but not really an impressive product.It's made of that thin, clear, rubbery polyurethane plastic that you see on ultra-cheap iPhone cases, and if it sold for their prices (say, at most a buck) it might be worth considering. But even so, it's neither attractive nor easy to use -- inserting the watch is very difficult, involving an awful lot of stretching and fiddling along with removing the band (which is hard to re-remove once the case is on). And once on, it cheapens the look of the watch considerably in exchange for not that much protection. I guess if you are planning to wear the Apple Watch while doing action sports or construction work the tradeoff might be worth it (though you might really want to consider a more armored outer-shell case instead), but for most wearers this is probably not going to be a very useful product.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

This Impressions sheet set is made from relatively nice-looking, soft-feeling microfiber, but it's still a 100% synthetic (polyester) fabric. The set (2 smallish standard pillowcases, fitted and flat sheets) is delivered in a basic zipped vinyl package. Construction and stitching are basically fine but wouldn't win any awards for neatness. The fitted sheet has good elastic running all the way around the perimeter, a good touch for a cheap sheet set, since sometimes only the corners are elasticized.The fabric is lustrous, almost to the point of being shiny, with attractive subtle gray stripes that run vertically on the bed. The feel of the fabric is very soft and smooth, but also a bit plasticky; it retains a lot of static electricity (feeling a bit strange and charged against body hair) and doesn't breathe well -- I felt very clammy sleeping under these sheets compared to cotton, which breathes better. Between these problems and the way microfiber retains smells so much more quickly than cotton, I didn't really enjoy my trial run with these sheets much, and I'll be switching back to cotton sheets immediately. Even similarly low-priced cotton sheets, to me, seem to breathe and feel much better. Buyers should be sure they're looking for microfiber before making the purchase, but if the material is okay with you, this set should be a fine choice.

This Geoffrey Beene silk robe is made from a very nice-feeling silk fabric and is attractive and pleasant to wear, but the rest of its presentation isn't quite commensurate with the luxury price tag. If you're giving it as a gift, you'll want to order in time to repackage it: the robe comes packaged in nothing more than a plain, clear plastic bag (the one mine came in was pretty dirty, even) with a white cardboard folder, more like a shirt from a cheap department store than a luxury product (you'd really expect at least a nicely designed cardboard box or something from most clothing at this price). And you'll want to use scissors to remove the hang tag boasting about Beene's charitable giving, since the silk fabric seems too fragile to pull.So the whole unpacking experience is kind of poorly thought out and un-luxurious, but once the robe is unpacked, it's pretty nice. The silk material is lustrous without seeming too glitzy, soft and thin, and yet pleasantly warm and breathable as only silk is -- its feel and look are simply wonderful. The white piping is more prominent than the photos here show, and quite attractive. There are two small hand pockets. The stitching is generally okay but not especially high-quality given the price -- mine had several loose threads and poorly-sewn overlocking at the seams, but nothing too bad. There's a sewn-in size tag in the neck that is quite itchy and annoying, a bit of an oversight in comfort and possibly something you'll want to remove.Here are some measurements from my Medium (taken lying flat, quite approximate):Length collar-hem: 49"Chest armpit-armpit: 26"Waist seam-seam: 23"The robe fits fairly well and forgivingly, but note that it's pretty long, perhaps longer than depicted in the photos -- it hits midway down the calf for me, not too high above the ankle. The sleeves, chest, and waist are all pretty much true to size, generous without being ridiculous. If you overlap the lapels enough and cinch the belt tightly, it can be worn in a not-too-baggy way (given that it's still a robe, of course), but it's cut in a way that will forgive wearers of most weights and sizes.If you're looking for a luxurious silk robe for yourself, this Beene will be a pleasure as soon as you throw out the packaging; if you're giving it as a gift, it will be a welcome one provided you re-wrap it. It's a fairly high-quality product, though perhaps not quite up to its price tag in construction or packaging.

This Avery 95930 is a really nice product, seemingly tuned for Internet sellers. With two big labels to a page, it's useful especially for those printable half-sheet USPS labels (though you'll want to remember not to print the receipt side!). The labels are shipped flat, in a 250-sheet package so heavy that it's easily damaged in shipping -- mine arrived with torn corners and the labels themselves slightly dinged/crumpled at the corners, though it doesn't affect their function. They look bright and adhere well. Basically, this is a great product for frequent online shippers, if not a cheap one. Recommended.

The Shark steam mop was a surprise and a revelation to me, never having used a device of this kind before -- and I found it works well enough to at least justify considering the purchase, despite the high price.Assembly and unpacking are a little annoying (it's packed in a pretty excessive quantity of boxes and bags within boxes and bags) but basically straightforward. The illustrated instructions are a bit inadequate -- they don't show that the nozzle connector is directional, and will only click into place properly in one way, and not if you're holding it upside down without knowing it. But that's easily enough resolved, and once unpacked it's a quick job to fill it (using a provided strange little water cup that, annoyingly, still spills lots of water easily, since it doesn't include a funnel or spout). Then you just plug it in, turn it on, and a minute later it begins to steam audibly and visibly.And it cleans pretty wonderfully. I found that a bunch of scum came up from my vinyl kitchen flooring that a soapy regular mop hadn't been able to remove -- and it lifted up without the effort or elbow grease of regular mopping. That's the most important test, and the Shark is a winner on that score. It really does clean well with little effort!

While it's a bit of a stretch to call it "pour-over," the KCM0802 delivers on its basic promise, providing better-tasting coffee than a standard drip machine at the cost of a slightly longer wait.Unboxing and setup are simple, and the machine is more attractive than most despite being almost entirely plastic, with a prominent stainless-steel outer casing on the drip basket displayed prominently. It has a smallish capacity compared to other machines its size, a nominal "8 cups" (denominated in those strange tiny coffee-maker-capacity cups) that equates to about three real 12-oz mugfuls of coffee when all brewed up. The machine is fairly big, but still just short enough to slot under a cabinet on a countertop. (Note that it fills from the top, though, so you'll need to pull it out a lot.) It has a number of nice convenience features, like an easy-to-see water level indicator and an attractive display with a programmable timer. The only down side to all the electronics is that it beeps -- quite annoyingly and loudly -- at the beginning and end of each brew cycle.The machine's concept is that it works like a pour-over brew at a high-end coffee shop, allowing the ground coffee to "bloom" in hot water before it completes brewing it with the remaining water. This means that the brew cycle takes a bit longer than a conventional drip machine (I clocked a 4-cup brew at 5:45), but in exchange should provide much more depth and richness of flavor.It doesn't quite live up to the "pour-over" promise -- I compared it directly, using the same fresh-roasted beans from my local high-end shop, to a real pour-over (as well as a French press), and the machine's brew was far weaker and much less complex in flavor (perhaps because of its lower brewing temperature; it doesn't seem to consistently get hot enough). But it's still a huge upgrade from drip coffee! If you like the taste of drip (better than the oily, chewy brew of a French press, still my favorite), this is a great way to upgrade to a richer brew that will get more out of good fresh-roasted beans. That's a quite specific niche, but for that use I'm happy to recommend it.

This Seville Classics storage cube/footstool is a nice little item for the price, resembling Ikea's BOSNS but with a nice light-gray finish and padded top. It's made of very thin-walled MDF all around the sides, encapsulated in a one-piece sewn fabric housing that becomes surprisingly rigid when you pop the bottom plate into place (this is the only assembly required, which is a nice surprise). The removable top is heavily padded and feels more rigid than the other parts. The fabric covering, in a variegated medium-light gray, is attractive and seems at least lightly stain-resistant.When the unit is put together it's remarkably sturdy to pressure and weight from the top (though not to flexing from the sides). I could sit and stand briefly on it without fear of collapse, which I wasn't expecting. All told, for the low price it's being sold at, this is a nice little piece of storage furniture or a pleasant footrest. Recommended.

Unless you have access to a Costco to buy Kirkland Signature's more premium-grade paper towels at a lower price, these Bounty Basics are about the greatest deal you'll find. 24 arrive at your house in a huge Bounty box inside an even huger Amazon shipping box, packed in separate plastic 12-packs, in what's... if not the best for the environment, at least a very protective arrangement. The paper towels inside are, as the name implies, basic, and fairly lightweight, but with a quite rigid imprinted or debossed pattern that greatly increases their air-holding and rigidity. They work better as napkins because of the debossing and should pick up much more dirt in the little pockets than bargain brands, despite being price-competitive. Of course, they're still fairly thin and light, so mopping up liquids sometimes takes one more of these than it would of a heavier, thicker towel. All in all, seemingly a great paper towel at a reasonable price, and easy to recommend.

This product from iGearPro is a very nice basic digital voice recorder with an 8GB capacity. It is quite small, with a postage-stamp-size screen that provides a barely legible UI, but fortunately once it's configured and you've set the time you won't need to look at it often.The device is packed with a passel of accessories -- everything you'd ever need and more, in the cheapest possible quality, from terrible earbuds to a terrible clip-on lavalier mic to a telephone adapter (with RJ45 cable, even!) -- which is actually kind of handy, despite the low quality of everything included, because it really expands the range of uses out of the box.Sound quality is pretty decent in use, provided you can position it somewhere out of range of knocks and vibration. The device is crazily hypersensitive to handling noise of any kind, including the button-presses necessary to turn recording on and off, so be sure to allow some time at the beginning and end of your recordings for editing, and don't talk while clicking buttons or placing it on the table. It records in some kind of slightly obsolete WAV format: I wasn't able to get a current version of QuickTime Player or preview on my Mac to open its files, but the old QT7 Player opens and exports/converts them just fine, so it's not a very big deal.This won't replace a high-quality recorder with good mics and better handling-noise muting, like those from Olympus, so spending a bit more might be worth it for the upgrade -- but at a low enough price the iGearPro might be worth it just as a disposable recorder.The manufacturer provided a free sample for this review.

The TP-Link Archer D2 is a nice package, delivering quite a lot of bang for the hardware buck -- complete with gigabit wired networking, AC750 dual-band wireless, and a functional DSL modem.It's a sleek-looking and attractive enough unit, though it's also a pretty large device, and it will be hard to conceal or position in a compact space, given the large external antennas and lack of a vertical stand or foot.  The D2 asks for a lot of desk space.Initial configuration is quick and painless, and even unconfigured, the Archer D2 provides basic security out of the box as it should, with the guest-network feature turned off by default and a default password printed on the bottom of the unit (in annoyingly tiny type on a tiny label!). The device's web user interface is bare-bones but functional, delivering quick and easy enough setup. Some of the instructions and online documentation are occasionally poorly translated and written in garbled English, but apart from the most advanced settings everything users need is basically straightforward enough for a mid-level or experienced user to set up without too much trouble.Note that to use the unit as a wireless router only, without DSL, requires taking up one of its four Ethernet ports, leaving you with only three to use networking your other Ethernet devices. It also requires you to log into the router and change "modes," requiring a reboot of the device.The D2's user interface is not remotely as nice as the simple, attractive user-facing web interfaces you see on routers from companies like Belkin or WD, but it's good enough to get the job done, and you don't really spend much time looking at these things once they're set up and working.The router's software provides all the basic functions users will want, though some of the advanced functions are a bit opaque and user-unfriendly compared to other manufacturers' offerings -- the QoS and similar advanced features, especially, could use better provided defaults rather than just blank fields to fill in. So far, the factory firmware appears stable and snappy enough based on my initial use, though TP-Link has seen its share of security problems in the past; I notice there hasn't been a single firmware update for this device, over more than six months of life, which isn't an auspicious sign about their level of support. The device appears not to be supported by open-source DD-WRT firmware for advanced users, limiting flexibility.Wireless-AC can be a pretty substantial improvement over Wireless-N in range and speed, but of course your computer or other devices need to support it before you'll see that improvement in practice. The D2's "AC750" designation makes it a middle-of-the-pack, basic AC device, without the eye-popping increases in claimed speed that some high-end AC routers promise, but in practice those higher designations are probably more useful to multi-user installations in busy areas than to your typical home user (since relatively smaller speed increases are delivered to single devices and the largest upgrades are in multi-device simultaneous uses). The D2's bandwidth should be perfectly sufficient for any typical home user for, at least, the next several years.While it's not perfect, the D2 is pretty clearly a good deal based on function, features, speed, and apparent stability -- better than anything else I've seen at this price point, as long as you're comfortable with its bare-bones interface. Compared to other DSL-router combos this seems like an excellent deal. I've been a fan of TP-Link's affordable and speedy, stable hardware for a while, especially their last generation of cheap, well-made Wireless-N routers, the WDR4300 and WDR3600, and this looks like another successful product (though I wish it had DD-WRT support).UPDATE: I'm dropping my rating on the Archer D2 after living with it for a while more, because of recurrent stability and speed issues. It has dropped and hung way, way more of its wireless connections than other routers I've tested in the same location and with the same clients.

The Turtle Beach Impact 100 is a pretty unexceptional product, a basic keyboard with not much to recommend it over any other one. It feels basically like the keyboard you'd get in the box with a new PC, neither a special beefy "gaming" keyboard nor one with especially pleasant key feel for writing.  The layout is a standard extended keyboard, with some slightly strange touches like modifier keys labeled with a weird triangular hieroglyph rather than a standard label.  The keyboard body is sturdily built, but not excessively heavy like some older metal-framed models. Keyboard and keys are finished in an attractive low-luster black with a red accent ring, and a basic non-detachable USB cable (despite the box's false claims it has a braided cable) with Velcro wrap is provided. (The font used on the keycaps is kind of silly and a bit hard to read, with little vampire fangs on the T and H like something you'd see on a schlocky heavy metal album cover; it's consonant with the "gamer" branding, I guess.) There's no backlighting, except, pointlessly, for the "Impact" logo on the space bar.Basically everything about the hardware and key feel is just okay -- not bad, but nothing special. In typing, it's soft and a bit mushy in feel, without a positive click or a clear way to feel when a keystroke is completed. The "guided sleeve design" seems like marketing without substance; the keys feel soft and wobbly in use. There's just no reason why anyone, gamer or typist, should choose this keyboard over other, much cheaper competitors from no-brands or makers like Logitech. The key feel, quality, and lack of features aren't good enough to differentiate this from a basic, cheapie replacement keyboard.Mac support is also nonexistent. As with the Impact 500, despite advertising Mac compatibility right in the product's title, the attitude with which that support is provided seems to be "hey, it's a USB keyboard, what do you want?" There are no included keycaps or labels for Mac modifier keys, for starters; users will have to label their Command and Option keys themselves somehow, or live with Weird Triangle Glyph and Alt keys, a very cheap-feeling omission for such a premium product. Furthermore, the keyboard doesn't report its layout correctly to Mac OS X: when it's connected for the first time, a Keyboard Setup Assistant pops up, requiring you to pick the keyboard layout, and even after choosing "ANSI" the modifier keys don't map correctly to the Mac standard layout (the one closest to the space bar should be Command, but instead it's Option). This can be fixed to some extent in OS X's Keyboard Settings -- I was able to remap most of the modifier keys to behave as I expected, though some others like the Windows Menu key, annoyingly, can't even be remapped there and don't seem to do anything when pressed.Essentially, this is the kind of Mac experience you'd expect if you were using a totally unsupported, Windows-only product. Turtle Beach's claims of Mac support are questionable at best -- I notice that the product's in-box manual doesn't even claim Mac compatibility for this keyboard. Competitor gaming keyboards like CM Storm also don't support Mac users very well, but at least they don't make false claims about it.
