For a high-end keyboard with genuine Mac support, the best option still appears to be the Das Keyboard, though models from Razer and Matias may also be worth considering if available.

This new "Enamel Strength" version is part of a somewhat baffling proliferation of toothpastes from Tom's of Maine, all of which are wonderful in subtly different ways. Apparently (if I've understood the packaging correctly, which I'm not sure of even after spending some time on it) the difference here is the inclusion of mineral fluorspar as a source of fluoride, which is claimed to help strengthen tooth enamel more than the regular Tom's peppermint toothpaste. (I obviously can't evaluate that claim scientifically, but I do note that the FDA endorsement only covers the claims about this being fluoridated, same as the regular one. Skepticism is probably warranted.)Anyhow, like all Tom's this peppermint-flavored gel is strongly and refreshingly flavored (peppermint), while being nowhere as sweet as the big traditional brands. (The lower level of sweetening can take some getting used to, but once you're used to it the other stuff tastes unpleasant and candy-like.) In texture this is a very soft, smooth, almost gooey paste, more like Tom's gel than the other products. My favorite, the baking soda Tom's, has a much more dry, scrubby feel, by comparison; this one is very wet and foamy. I still enjoyed the experience of brushing with it, and it left my mouth feeling ultra-clean. It tasted even more strongly and freshly minty than I'm used to with the baking-soda paste.Note that the tube is significantly smaller for this product than for other Tom's: this is 4 oz., not their regular 4.7 or 5.5 ounces (it's sold by weight, and not labeled with its volume, as I keep trying and failing to explain to the TSA).

Though it's very similar to the cheaper CM Storm, the Turtle Beach Impact 500 is a wonderful piece of hardware, pretty close to my dream keyboard for writing purposes, not just "gaming" uses as advertised. It's a compact "ten-key-less" keyboard layout (that is, it has arrow keys and Page Up/Down, but no numeric keypad), which fits even a very small lap or desk ideally for writing-centric users. The keyboard body is sturdily built but not excessively heavy like some older metal-framed models. Keyboard and keys are finished in an attractive low-luster black, and a nice braided-nylon-jacketed micro-USB cable is provided. (The only aesthetic flaw is a tiny one, easy to forgive: the font used on the keycaps is kind of silly and a bit hard to read, with little vampire fangs on the T and H like something you'd see on a schlocky heavy metal album cover; it's consonant with the "gamer" branding, I guess. I also noticed that Turtle Beach's marketing photos didn't exactly match the appearance and positioning of the printing on the key caps on the unit I received.)Basically everything about the hardware and key feel is great, thanks to the glorious Cherry MX Blue keyswitches, which have a light click reminiscent of the old ADB Apple Extended Keyboard, with cushy deep travel, and very positive action (that is, it's very easy to tell when you've completed a keystroke). After spending a few years on short-travel laptop keyboards, typing on the Impact 500 feels to the fingers something like flopping onto the world's most luxurious hotel mattress would to the whole body. It's simply great. And for Windows or Linux users, that's probably review enough.The only (and sadly somewhat major) fly in the ointment here is that despite advertising, and technically, I guess, providing Mac compatibility, the attitude with which that support is provided seems to be "hey, it's a USB keyboard, what do you want?" There are no included keycaps or labels for Mac modifier keys, for starters; users will have to label their Command and Option keys themselves somehow, or live with Windows and Alt keys, a very cheap-feeling omission for such a premium product. Furthermore, the keyboard doesn't report its layout correctly to Mac OS X: when it's connected for the first time, a Keyboard Setup Assistant pops up, requiring you to pick the keyboard layout, and even after choosing "ANSI" the modifier keys don't map correctly to the Mac standard layout (the one closest to the space bar should be Command, but instead it's Option). This can be fixed to some extent in OS X's Keyboard Settings -- I was able to remap most of the modifier keys to behave as I expected, though the Windows Menu key, annoyingly, can't even be remapped there.Essentially, this is the kind of Mac experience you'd expect if you were using a totally unsupported, Windows-only product. Turtle Beach's claims of Mac support are questionable at best. Competitors like CM Storm also don't support Mac users very well, but at least they don't make false claims about it. For a Cherry MX Blue keyboard with genuine Mac support, the best option still appears to be the Das Keyboard, though models from Razer and Matias may also be worth considering if available. And if you order a WASD Keyboard direct from the manufacturer they'll give you Mac keycaps or any other custom look you like for a price not that far off this one's.

The NYNE Cruiser is a surprisingly loud and acceptable-sounding little speaker for such a portable package, marred only by a very buzzy midrange. It's a substantial ovoid cylinder the size of a mini-football or a can of soda. Included in the package are a neoprene carrying case, audio and USB charging cable (no AC adapter is included, annoyingly) and a set of handlebar mounts (which are kind of a silly gimmick if you ask me, considering how quickly it'll be stolen if you ever leave it on the bike). Switched on, it's easy to pair and works straightforwardly. You'll want to turn the volume up immediately, as that's the only way to get it to a listenable volume level, and use your source device's volume adjustment from there. It provides sound of something like the quality of an old tabletop FM radio -- with impressive loudness good enough to fill a small room, and perfectly pleasant for background listening even for most kinds of music, as well as podcasts and other talk content. The only problem is a very buzzy, imprecise midrange; it sounds to me like the speakers are mounted too loosely in the housing and tend to buzz and get very muddy around sung vocals and guitars. Still, for undemanding music listening it sounds basically okay, I guess. The bass and loudness are downright impressive for such a small device.This won't really replace anyone's main stereo, or even their home computer speakers or a good set of heapdhones, but it's still a nice backup speaker for travel use, for hotel-room listening, or a small office desk or kitchen, that kind of thing. For travel, it also has the nice extra feature of providing USB charging capacity to other devices, which could come in very handy if a phone battery unexpectedly runs down. All in all, if you need a portable Bluetooth speaker and don't mind a buzzy midrange, it's a decent choice.

This LAX case is a pleasant, low-cost and fairly slim protective option for the iPhone 6 if you're looking for a shiny and sparkly look. It's fairly similar in form to the Silk PureView, my current favorite slim case, though with a more flexible back panel and, obviously, a very different look. Installation is easy, as the LAX is fairly flexible all around, and the rim feels protective while preserving button feel and function. It is a fairly substantial rim all around, though -- I found the cutout for the silent-mode switch slightly on the deep side, requiring a bit of a fingernail reach, and the lip on the front face of the phone is also deep enough (much deeper than Silk's) that it can get in the way slightly during use. Still, the LAX is a nice option and I would recommend it to anyone looking for some cheap and sparkly iPhone protection.

I ordered Head & Shoulders' new "Instant Relief" on account of the mentions of peppermint/tea tree in the description, hoping it would be a more pleasant-smelling form of the shampoo than the goopy medicinal scents usually offered by the brand. Unfortunately, I found it undifferentiable functionally -- despite the "instant relief" marketing, it behaves just like ordinary Head & Shoulders, with mild flake relief but not much difference, in practice, in how my scalp feels afterwards, from any other shampoo. And it seems pretty horrible in scent to me -- the large bottle I received, branded Instant Relief, contained a bright green shampoo smelling strongly of synthetic green apple, like nothing so much as coating my scalp in Jolly Rancher candies.Perhaps it's some kind of packaging mistake, but the shampoo I received appears very similar to Head & Shoulders Green Apple, not a mint/tea tree product. I don't think I'll be using it again; if you're looking for a true tea tree shampoo I'd really recommend Nature's Gate's superior natural product instead.

Repel Sportsmen Dry (don't think too hard about the name, they certainly didn't) is a very nice bug-repellent product in a slim and portable aerosol spray can. It seems like a direct competitor to [[ASIN: Off Deep Woods Dry]] and works just as well. It feels dry almost instantly after application, has no strong smell at all, and is easy to apply.Because of its relatively high concentration of DEET I preferred applying it mostly to clothing, not skin -- though the directions for the Repel don't have any strong cautions, so other users may not worry as much as I did. Repel also has non-aerosol products in a variety of forms -- from stick to pump -- if you prefer those.As a primary repellent for hardcore outdoorsmanship I've become a big believer in permethrin leave-in clothing repellent, but you always need a spray to supplement that and to touch up exposed skin. This Repel dry spray seems like a great portable choice for that.

(Be aware: several different Inateck products are grouped under this Amazon listing, and the unwieldy product names may make the reviews hard to distinguish.)This Inateck sleeve is a handsome, minimalist gray felt fabric case for the Kindle Voyage. It's made of a soft, thick felt fabric which is cushy enough to provide some bump protection, though I wouldn't want to test it on any severe drop. The quality of construction is very good, with handsome stitching around three edges and a nice-feeling faux-leather tab, attaching via Velcro, at the top; the top of the case also has a separate small Velcro closure. The top tab, rather ingeniously, connects to a small strap that runs beneath the Kindle when inserted within the case, making for very easy removal -- you just tug on the tab and the Kindle slides right out. I found the case fit my Kindle Voyage, as well as naked (fitting slightly loosely), even with a typical "Fintie" Chinese-made slim shell cover still on (fitting quite tightly, making the removal strap useful), which was an unexpected bonus.This is a really pleasant, useful case executed nicely in gray felt fabric, and I'm sure I'll be using it whenever I travel.The manufacturer provided a sample for this review.

This Dr. Scholl's product is a bit of a strange-seeming invention -- basically a battery-powered drum sander for callus removal -- but it works just as advertised and is quite pleasant. Living with it for a while, I've found it surprisingly useful; I'm updating this review after a few months because it's actually grown on me.It's packaged in a terrible hard plastic clamshell designed for drugstore shelves; you'll want to have a heavy set of shears ready, and even so it's not that easy to remove from the packaging. But once set up with the included two AA batteries, the sander (sorry, "electronic file") works just as expected, spinning its emery drum pleasantly against the skin and gently removing calluses or dead skin without pain or damage. Despite the dire warnings on the package against using it on any non-foot body parts, I found it worked fine on hand calluses, too; of course, a gentle touch is obviously best when power-sanding one's own body.It's hard at first to see what it offers that a much cheaper foot file doesn't, but in fact it actually makes it possible to achieve a smoother result, and to work on callused fingers and chipped nails as well. After living with the gadget for a while, I'm surprised how often I find myself reaching for it, despite my initial skepticism. It may seem silly, but it works really well.

I love the design on this shop vacuum.  The wall mount is a great feature, especially in the garage when coupled with the 21' hose length. A thick plastic mounting plate is easy to attach to the wall and from there, it's simple to hang the vacuum. There are two hoses than combine to get the 21' length. You can reach a good distance with the 20' cord length as well, so between the length of the hose and the power cord, you can cover a lot of area. The hose is 2" in diameter and can suck up good size debris. RIGID makes a few different filter types for different uses. Mine is just for standard vacuuming, so I don't have need for the fine particle filters, etc. Still, it's nice to have that option.It comes with the Utility Nozzle, Dusting Brush, 2 Extension Wands, Car Nozzle (with LED light), Crevice Tool, Diffuser, One Qwik Lock Filter, a 14 Foot Hose and a 7 Foot Hose - and again - both hoses can be hooked together. One hose is a 14' Tug-a-Long and the other is a 7' expanding hose. It's not too loud, it sounds as loud as our air conditioning unit, so not quiet, but not too bad. The suction power is very strong, even with both hoses in use.It's a reasonably priced shop vacuum that has a lot of great features, plus is has a lifetime warranty against material defects and workmanship.

Every week I am on the road for work and the SOLO Executive Backpack is a perfect addition.  I don't have to carry that much, but I have a laptop, an iPad, my phone, paperwork and a kindle for down time moments. I have some work documents and I even have room for my smaller Bento box for lunch and a bottle of water.The first thing that I like is that it looks professional. I'm not going to carry a briefcase and I did carry a shoulder bag, but this is much better for utility. The brown color and the design make this something I can carry into my work and off site meetingsThe backpack is well made, sturdy and nicely designed.  Side pockets are great for quick access to keys, phone, etc. and the interior fits my laptop nicely and safely. There are 3 compartments, the laptop is in the first one and the second and third are successively smaller. There are "D" rings that I sometimes use to attach my keys or ID card on a lanyard.There's plenty of room and pockets for pens, cards, mints, gum and the like. It seems sturdy, certainly for my use and I'm not about to use it to hike the Appalachian Trail.  For me, I load everything I'll need for my day in it. Then then I just grab and go.

We love to entertain and while for my part, while I like to cook, I'm learning presentation.  These 4 plates are 6" around, small but good for serving small bites. While they might not go with your formal dining room on Thanksgiving, these are fun informal plates. These are great for canapes and other small bites. They can go in the dishwasher or microwave, they are sturdy and the contemporary style is fun.One note, as of this writing, these are $36 from Amazon under 'other sellers' and $70 otherwise. I'd pay $36 for this set, $70? No.

I love to cook and I already have 2 GreenPan Ceramic pans that I love. Mostly I use cast iron, however there are some jobs better suited to ceramic pans.  We have eggs often and this is a perfect egg pan.  The size is just right to make a scrambled eggs, fried eggs and clean up is very fast. The handle doesn't get hot and the heat gets distributed nicely on my gas stove. I make 1 fried egg at at time and I've make a 4 egg scramble in this small pan. I've made omelettes too. The eggs come out great every time. If you want to impress someone with eggs for breakfast and you can't cook to save your life, beat some eggs, season lightly with salt/pepper, heat the pan to medium, add a little butter and add your eggs to the pan. Add some goat cheese at the end so it melts a bit. (Goat cheese is the duct tape of cooking.)Even though it's dishwasher safe, I can't see this getting to the point where you'd need a dishwasher. I have had cooking discoloration on my other GreenPans that came right out with a quick rub with baking soda. That hasn't happened with this pan, but if it does, I know I can do that as well to keep it looking like the day it arrived.Ceramic is better than any of the non-stick options out there, both in safety (No off gassing like with Teflon) and in use. I highly recommend ceramic. That said, you need to know that you cannot use metal utensils in the pan, you will likely scratch the ceramic coating. My recommendation is to use silicone utensils. This is a great value at $10 for an egg pan. If you make eggs a lot, this is a must own.

The ZAGG Folio Case Hinged Keyboard is not your best option from ZAGG.The keyboard case fits the iPad and it's easy enough to get it in and out of the case. Bluetooth pairing work as expected, I had no problems. The hinge is quite stiff and I hope it gets better with time. The exterior of the case has faux leather type surface, which grips nicely.The case should provide some good protection, however it's thinner than other ZAGG and other brands I use. They keyboard is comfortable and functional, but the keys aren't backlit. The battery life gave me all day use.There are some minor issue I've noted so why only 3 stars? The issue for me is that there are better value cases for the money from ZAGG, if you spend $10 more or even $25 less. There are a better values from ZAGG themselves. If the price were significantly lower, this case would be worth it.

I have many La Roche-Posay products that I am very happy with, they work well and are worth the cost. If you don't know about Vitamin C for skincare, in short, it's excellent and produces results over time.This is part of my AM and PM regimen. It feel great going on, a little goes a long way. Twice daily use get me several weeks from a tube. The feeling is not greasy, but smooth and absorbs well.Even if you don't use La Roche-Posay products, Vitamin C is an important part of skin care. You will not see results in days or week in most cases, but you will see them.

In short, I like this diffuser. It works well, does a good job, has a few nice features, however it's price is high as compared to units with the same features. I have a diffuser that is $28 that is essentially the same as this unit.The unit is simple. There are only 4 parts, the cord, a measuring cup for filling, the top and the body of the unit. You don't really need the measuring cup, but its nice to have. There is a single button on the front that is not just on/off, but rather cycles through the options of on with no light, on with blue light, off. Pay attention to the fill line, as if you go much beyond that it won't make mist. It runs until you turn it off or it runs out of water. The mist stream goes straight up, there is no directional option. There is a slow moving ceiling fan, so the scent is well spread.It performs well and the mist is generated fairly quickly and covers a large room, ~400 square feet. I have several oils and with some, the recommended 3-4 drops are plenty, however other oils need twice that to be effective, such as peppermint and orange. I tried different brands, same results.I get about 4 hours on a fill and during the day, I turn it off, refill and keep going. I don't use it in my bedroom, so running time is sufficient for me.I like all the features, the design but I can't figure out why it's $20 more than my other one that does the same thing,

Viva Labs is a brand often found in my home. While I am reviewing this for Vine, I already use this Vitamin D3 and other vitamins they produce. My feeling is if I am going to take a supplement for the betterment of my health, it's best to know the source and better still to trust it. I've come to trust Viva from use and happy that they are made in the USA. I use Labdoor, which has given them high marks on independent testing for label accuracy, product purity, nutritional value, ingredient safety and projected efficacy on other Viva Labs supplements. I expect when they test this D3 it will be no different.It seems we're alway hearing about the most important supplements. Vitamin D has always been known to be important and it seems we've recently been learning that it's even more important than we thought. Studies state that 70% of people are deficient in Vitamin D and the "15 minutes of sunlight" to get your RDA isn't that simple, there are many factors that go into that being sufficient or not. Sunscreen, skin pigmentation, body fat, age and living in a northern latitude all affect the Vitamin D bioavailability and production.Supplementation of 4,000IU daily is sufficient for most people and should you desire to test your level, people with 40-60ng/ml have the lowest all cause mortality.If you're inclined, search for the latest published studies to see just how much we've learned in the last few years to how Vitamin D works and how important a role it plays in our health.TL;DR: Vitamin D is important, supplementation can be good for you, great if you're deficient. Viva Labs makes quality supplements that I trust.

The Wolverine WS58V2 Portable Wireless Speakers are made for indoor / outdoor use and appear to be a second generation of this product. They aren't meant for being out in the rain, they can probably easily handle a splash by the pool, as the design is made to be water resistant. The speakers are light and have a carrying handle. They appear well made. The first thing I realized is that I liked having stereo speakers outside.  I often use the BRAVEN 805 Wireless Bluetooth Speaker [18 Hour Playtime] - Black/Black and while it sounds good, it's just one speaker. For a larger area, having two speakers gives a nicer effect.The speakers can be powered by batteries or an AC adapter and you can buy additional speakers to add to the network, which is a nice touch. I didn't use batteries, but I'll suggest AmazonBasics AA Rechargeable Batteries (16-Pack) if you decide on using batteries. The range from the base and speakers allows for plenty of distance. In my case, 50 feet, and Wolverine Data claims up to 262 feet. There are plenty of ways to input your music. I use Bluetooth, the base unit is Bluetooth 4.0. They include RCA plugs and line in 3.5mm jack as well for devices that don't have Bluetooth, so pretty much any output made in the last 30 years should be able to be connected. You can even connect this to older TV's and audio receivers via RCA or 3.5mm jack from any computer. That's one big plus over Bluetooth only speakers.With the 262 foot range, you can place the base near the source if need be, as in the case of using wires. I connected using Bluetooth and tested it outside listening to radio with coffee in the morning, background music while doing work and during a dinner party. Overall, high marks are justified for the easy of setup, use and sound.  The convenience is excellent as well, as you can place these where you want, more so if you use the batteries. (NOTE: I did not)The only reason for 4 stars is the sound. It was good, not great, but left a little something to be desired. The aforementioned Braven has very good sound and bass especially. Spoken audio, such as news and audio books were good, perfect even. It was only while listening to a playlist on louder volumes, when *some* songs sounded "muddy" and only occasionally.Overall, I'm quite happy with the Wolverine WS58V2 Portable Wireless Speakers. The are easy to setup, use and as long as you aren't expecting the same audio as a Vegas pool party, I think most people will be happy with the sound overall.

It's become so much more important to guard one's personal information and with documents containing your personal information, shredding them is a very secure option. I've had my identity stolen, no idea how, but between online precautions and shredding, I feel safer.The Sentinel FX124BC is a highly capable shredder for the home or small office. Beyond the high capacity, which can take the advertised amount, or heavy paper stock and go right through staples, it also crosscuts. That makes confetti basically and good luck trying to piece even a little of that together. It's quite secure.The shredder is similar to many others, the top has the shredder motor and it sits atop the collection bucket with a window to see how full it is.  This unit has a few nice additions. The top fastens to the bucket and can be carried by the handle. The shredded paper can be compacted, so you won't need to empty the bucket as often. It's fairly quiet for a shredder, compared to my much smaller and less powerful Office Depot one.I love Amazon Basics and have their 12 sheet shredder.  This is $10 less and has more features. While both are very good and are excellent for the home or small office, the Sentinel is my current pick.If you aren't shredding your personal documents, take a few minutes to see what highly personal information you might tear up and throw out. Then ask yourself how you would feel if someone were able to access those documents. Take it from someone who had their identity stolen, do what you can to protect yourself, with printed documents and of course, online.

There's too many headphone choices to count and I think the Apple headphones aren't very good, especially for use in sports.The Panasonic RP-HSC200 are reasonably comfortable, they do stay in place when I use them at the gym, biking, etc. I am not a fan of the ear clips, but you don't notice them after wearing them for a while. The sound is passable, but nothing great and I am not an audiophile. If you have more stringent standards than I do, you might not like the sound quality. There's only so much you can expect from a ~$20 pair of headphones, but they are on the tinny side, not too bad and bass is lacking. To be completely fair, good bass is hard to come by in a cheap, small pair. The cord is decently long, something you'll want when running or on a treadmill or bike, plus the controls are good as well.  It's a 3 button control, I prefer the single button with a volume control, but that's just me.My current favorite for sports headphones are the MEE audio M7P Secure-Fit Sports In-Ear Headphones with Mic, Remote, and Universal Volume Control(Black).For me, these are a very good cheap option for a sports use headphone. I tend to be frugal and shop for value, so while these are cheaper, I don't see them as a good value as there are better options for a few dollars more.

I tested the Instanatural Essential Oil Aromatherapy Diffuser for 2 weeks before reviewing and it's an excellent unit for me.It is used in the bedroom exclusively and it easily covers the ~300 square feet with whatever essential oil I use. It's also small enough that I take it when I travel, which I do 3 out of 4 weeks. I just bring some essential oils and plug it in at the hotel room and it's a nice touch while I'm away. It diffuses very well and I like the blue LED. I also like that I can turn the LED off as well when I'm not in the mood for the blue light. It is very quiet, I can't hear it running when I'm near it, let alone when it's ~10 feet away from me.Overall, this is a simple unit, uncomplicated and easy to travel with.  My only wish is that it would last longer than the 4 hours I'm getting, but I understand you can't have it both ways.  It would have to be bigger to hold more water to last longer.  As I use it at night, I'm often asleep when it automatically turns off, so that's not much of an issue.The design is nice and it looks and feels well made.  Lavender is my favorite for bedtime and after 10 minutes or so, the entire room smells softly of lavender.  This small unit does a very good job at diffusing the essential oils. I'm very happy with it and how it performs.**I received this product free or at a discount for my honest, unbiased review. Even so, I highly recommend this diffuser!**

I've been tempted to buy some inexpensive phone cases and while some are good, I end up buying a case from Speck or OtterBox. Why? I need my phone and while it's rare that I drop it, it's happened. The last time was a fluke and had a $5 case with a design I loved. My screen was shattered and the repair for my iPhone 6 was $140 for a new screen.I have 3 cases, I use one for the gym, one for going out and night and most often, the OtterBox Defender for all other times. I'll be straightforward, changing cases can be a pain to do or to remember to do.  When I am traveling in state or internationally, I love the no worry that I have with the case.The case fits my iPhone 6 very well. It's a snug fit and it protects very well. This is my 3rd Defender and while using them, none of my phones have been damaged.So if it protects so well, why do I change cases?  I have a case for going out, also an OtterBox, the OtterBox STRADA iPhone 6/6s Case - Retail Packaging - NEW MINIMALISM (BLACK/BLACK LEATHER). It holds a few cards and looks sharp, no need to take my wallet. I also swap out for my gym case to fit on my arm.I think that it's entirely reasonable to spend $30-40 on a case for your $600-700 phone. If you need good protection, you won't do much better than OtterBox.

I take supplements everyday and fish oil has been a part of my regimen for years. The benefits are well know and documented in these review and many places online, so chances are if you're reading this, your just looking for a good brand.One of the first things *I* look for in a fish oil is a 1:1 ratio (or close) of EPA and DHA. An equal ratio is associated with healthier blood vessels,  lower lipid counts, plus a reduced risk for plaque buildup. Fish oil has shown a decreased risk of diabetes and a number of forms of cancer, including breast cancer. At 880mg and 660mg per serving, the Zenwise is within range, in my opinion. It's well priced, especially for the amount of Omega-3's you get per serving.The benefits of fish oil take days and weeks to see. Don't expect an overnight miracle. The addition of lemon flavor helps with a common side effect of fish burps. Some people are put off by that, which is understandable. The lemon flavor helps, but taking them with food does as well.If you are serious about your supplements, I'll share that I often read laboor and examine dot com for in depth information on supplements. Highly recommended.Store these in a cool, dry place, as fish oil can oxidize if left out in the sun or in heat. I refrigerate mine.NOTE TO THOSE ON MEDICATION:Fish oil can reduce blood clotting and should be supplemented with caution if you are taking blood-thinning medications talk to your doctor!Such as:asprinwarfarin clopidogrel

To me, there's nothing better than a good cookbook. To learn about a cuisine and how to prepare it is exciting, especially when it's one you already enjoy. I love watching Sushi chefs work; they make everything look easy, but they have a lot of skills that belie the simplicity in preparing sushi and sashimi.The Complete Guide to Sushi and Sashimi is a great book on the subject and I'll recommend that you buy it if you're interested in making sushi or sashimi. It's spiral bound and made to be used, not sit on a coffee table! This is also a great gift for someone that cooks and like sushi too.After reading the initial chapters on what equipment and food items you need, I made a trip to the local Japanese grocery store. I bought all necessary ingredients and equipment to make sushi and sashimi. I bought my first Japanese steel knife recently as well. It wasn't 100% necessary to make have, but it sure helps. It's crazy sharp and is a pleasure to use. It's the Tojiro DP Gyutou - 8.2" (21cm) and I love it.The book is laden with great photos, something I appreciate when learning a new cuisine. The step by step instructions make it simple to understand. We made rolls and sashimi in not time. I have to work on my roll skills, and the first ones didn't look the greatest, but after a few, they looked great!I'm just starting out, but feel confident enough that I have some basic skills I can improve upon.Bottom line: This book is well written, with lots of great photos. It'll be a great source to teach or to just inform, making it a great gift or a gift to yourself.

For me, jerky is a great snack and it's satisfying, easy to store and not high in calories.  The Old Wisconsin jerky are gluten free, have zero trans fat and contain no MSG, BHT, BHA or fillers. That's the plus.However, in the beef sticks, the salt kills these for me. I don't eat a lot of sugar or salt in my diet. The results is that when there is sugar or salt, I can really taste it. These are really salty and have twice the salt of the brand I usually buy. The texture is fine and the flavor is ok, but honestly it's hard to judge the flavor when the salt is masking themI'd try these again if they could reduce the salt, but as of now, I'd only  buy or consume these if there weren't other jerky available.The turkey sticks have a better flavor and are sweetened from fructose. I limit my sugar intake, so the turkey sticks are not for me. They are the better tasking of the two, but it's the sweetener that makes it better.The company describes the sticks like this : " Fast fuel sticks and bites are a high-protein, low-calorie meat snack and a healthy alternative to sweet and salty snack options. " The beef has 580mg of sodium and the turkey has 600mg. An alternative to salty snack options? More like an alternative to a salt lick. But seriously, the US RDA is 2400mg of sodium. One of these snacks is 25% of that.If Old Wisconsin were ever to reduce the sodium in the beef sticks, I'd be open to trying them again. They have a lot of good qualities in making a fine product, but for now, these just aren't for me.

These are a welcome convenience. Like many conveniences theres a trade off. Sure, you can buy a plastic jug of bleach and use it as you need to. But if you want to have individual bleach pods that you can use around the house or in your laundry (they go in with the wash -*not*- the bleach tray), these are just fantastic. I know, we have pods for laundry detergent, dishwashing detergent, so why not bleach?These perform just like liquid bleach. I was unable to see any difference in laundry or cleaning. Only the form seems different.Pros:These are individual pods of bleach that you can toss in the washing machine. No spilling bleach or splashing where you *dont* want to get bleach.Drop one in the toilet to clean it clean and fresh.Easy to store, carry and use. They only turn into a bleach solution when added to water.Drop one in a bucket with a gallon of water to make a bleach cleaning solution.ConsThe only con I can offer (and its a bit weak) is that you pay for the convenience. With the current pricing, these come out to .23 each and you can buy a gallon of bleach for $5.These are versatile and easy to use. The minor cost differential is overshadowed by the may pros these bleach pods offer. If these pods prevent bleach from staining just one thing, youd be happy you spend a few dollars more for the bleach packs.

This is just a photo printer that prints 4" x 6" and 5" x 7" photos. It's not a multi purpose unit.The footprint is small, but as it only prints photos, that makes sense. This could be easily transported due to size and weight. I don't print a lot of photos, but enough that I'll get a lot of use from the PictureMate. It was really easy to set up and since it's wireless and small, finding a place for it was simple. You can print from your wireless device as well as your computer.You do need to buy Epson ink for this, as of this writing, there are no other options for ink. I'm ok with that as this is for photos and the Epson PictureMate produces very nice quality photos. I find myself finding more opportunities to send photos and updating the family albums.  I've had photo printers before and multi-use printers, but they don't come close to this quality.Epson states a 200 year lifespan of the photos, which I don't think we can prove or disprove at this time. What I can say is the clarity of the photos is stunning, the speed is pretty good but it doesn't come at a low cost. At $249.99, it's pricey, so you'd have to see if the exceptionally quality is worth it to you. There are more popular printers that are much less expensive, but at the expense of the photo quality. Also,the ink isn't as costly as I thought, as it's $35.83 for 1 ink cartridge or $38.99 for ink *and* and 100 sheets of 4" x 6" direct from Epson, who gives free shipping. After the initial cost of the printer, the printing cost per print, including paper is .39. Here's the link to the ink cartridge only: Epson T320 PictureMate Color Cartridge InkIf you want to print photos that are very high quality, that you intend to keep and store, this might just be the photo printer for you.

The bottom line comes first:For $10, every wine drinker should own this wine vacuum stopper.We don't always finish a bottle of wine and I'm sure we all know what happens if you try to put a cork back in or screw the top back on.  Vacuum pumps for wine bottles have been around and used to be much more costly. For $10, the Kollea wine preserver will pay for itself quickly in the wine is saves.We've used it several times recently and not only is it dead simple to use, it works very well.  A bottle of red we opened for dinner had had half left and using the Kollea wine preserver, it was perfect when we drank it 4 days later. We've used this for red, white and champagne.  The champagne worked but it had lost some carbonation. The reds and whites all were preserved nicely until we opened them again, never more than a week, as wine doesn't last that long around here.This is a nice gift to yourself or anyone that drinks wine. What's really nice is I can open a bottle and preserve it, whereas before, I might not open something if there weren't enough people to drink it.**This item was provided free of charge for an honest and fair review.**

Living in a sunny state, I wear sunscreen daily.  As the manufacturer advises this isn't for your face, I only use this elsewhere. Because I wear it daily,  I prefer sunscreens like this that don't smell like coconut or other beach scents. This sunscreen goes on smooth and absorbs quickly. I expect this tube will last a while, as a little goes a long way.It doesn't leave me oily and is a great daily wear and great for the beach as well.  It's higher priced, but for a 60spf and the many nice features make it worth it.

Astronomy is an interest of mine and I had purchased the original Super Moon In My Room 5 years ago and put it in my office. This one is much improved and is going in the kids bedroom. They love mine in the office, so this one is for them.It's just really cool. It looks great, with a textured surface that curves, it makes a nice effect on the wall. Kids and adults love it equally.The new model is larger, has some cool noises (cricket and moon landing) but the one we love the most is that it syncs to the moon phase once you set the date.You'll need batteries for the moon and the remote control, sizes C and AAA. I've been recommending AmazonBasics AAA Rechargeable Batteries (8-Pack) Pre-charged for the AAA and you can use the Panasonic BQ-BS2E4SA Eneloop C Size Spacers for Use with Eneloop Ni-MH Rechargeable AA Battery Cells, 4 Pack for the C cells.It's a great addition to a room. It's interesting, fun and the visual effect is just great. This would be a great gift idea for a birthday or Christmas, etc.

I use a lot of Viva Labs supplements and I've never been disappointed. Personally, I strongly prefer brands that I trust so I know I'm getting what the label says I am.CoQ10 is a popular supplement and there is a great deal of research on the various effects that supplementing with CoQ10 provides. My go to source is examine{dot}com, which concisely lists the different effects provides, how strong the effect and links to the studies. There's plenty of anecdotal reasons for taking CoQ10 that don't have research behind them, such as migraine relief. I take it for cardiovascular health and improved cholesterol levels, which are both backed by science.Lastly, Viva has paired CoQ10 with Bioprene which helps increase the absorption of the CoQ10.

XEN-TAN makes some excellent self tanners. I've just used the XEN-TAN Transformation Ultra Weekly Tan, 8 fl. oz. with great results. I should have left that one on longer, but it was my first time using it. Live and learn.It turned out to be a good thing as I was able to use the XEN-TAN Mousse Intense Weekly Tan. The texture of the mousse is great and allows for an even distribution of the product. I would do a few pumps and sections by section.  I also used the XEN-TAN Deluxe Tanning Mitt as well, making applying this even faster, easier and evenly. I'll suggest the mitt to you as it is washable and reusable, in addition to how it improves the application of the product.Take your time when you apply and be sure to not to let it accumulate unevenly and rub it in well. Also, you need time to let it set, so no shower, swimming, etc. for a few hours for best results. The color looks great and though I'm usually pasty white, the XEN-TAN gave be a great, natural looking tan.  It also smells good, which is a plus.While I did get great results, I'll share that I do exfoliate and moisturize regularly. I also use the Salux Nylon Japanese Beauty Skin Bath Wash Cloth/towel (3) Blue Yellow and Pink for exfoliation of my skin. They work well for me.

I play guitar and record my own tracks and I'd like to think I have a good ear. I'm far better at making the music than recording it. The M-Audio Micro DAC is amazing at improving the sound quality far beyond what you'd think is possible in a tough aluminum form factor that is barely bigger than a lighter.The Micro DAC is really very simple. It works for Mac/PC and plugs into the USB port. From there, you have two options for output, optical co-axial (digital) or  1/8" headphone jack (analog). I use the headphone to listen to the music and the co-axial to connect to the audio system. There is an impedance switch, so this will work will all headphone types.This is a great way to get a optical/digital out from a USB port that you can connect to recording equipment or sound systems. If you want to get professional sound quality from your Mac/PC, the M-Audio Micro DAC delivers.

I have two modes of skin color: sickly pale, my typical daily or burnt to a crisp, reserved for when I go on vacation. I'd like to look nicely tanned and I've used a number of self tanners to either tan for looks or before I go on vacation, as a 'pre-tan'. I've had mixed results in the past, once resembling a carrot-like skin color.  The XEN-TAN was much different and was a complete resounding success for me.I could have done it mostly all by myself but I had help and a XEN-TAN Deluxe Tanning Mitt. The cream applied easily and covered well. The scent wasn't bad at all. No chemical smell, more a sweet scent. Anyway, it's good.The biggest difference with this self tanner is that it intensifies with time, so you need to leave it on at least 45 minutes, then after you've waited the amount of time you like, you shower off.  The color will still intensify, so I had to guess and I went for two hours and then showered.  It came out great when woke up the next morning.The color looked natural, the best I've had a self tanner look.  I wish it didn't take hours, but to get these results, it's worth it to me.

This is a small speaker, the size of a typical yo-yo. Solid black, integrated rubberized buttons on the tops below the strap that you can use to hang the speaker. The strap can be unfastened/refastened so it can be hung in a variety of places.It powers on by holding the power button (the circular icon between the - and +) playing a 'power on' tone. If you press and hold the power button again for a few seconds, you put the speaker into Bluetooth discoverable mode and it plays a tone to let you know that. It connected quickly and easily to my iPhone. There is a small blue LED light that signals the speaker is on. The LED is red when charging.  A 6" USB cord plugs in under a rubber cover on the speaker. It arrived with a 50% charge and I was able to play music for an hour. It charged up fully in < 2 hours.The sound comes from one side, it seems to me, or the treble anyway.  It's a nice balance of portability and sound. Do not expect to have a home theater experience. It's a very small speaker that plays sound well for it's size. At the highest levels of both my phone and speaker, the sound degraded, as I expected. I just wanted to test.This is perfect for traveling as it is light and takes up no space. (I stuff it in a shoe in my suitcase). This is another well done Amazon Basics product.

We use a lot of baby wipes and have them everywhere and not just for the baby.These are sturdy, textured, actually have a very light scent and come in a 72 pack tub, with a resealable plastic lid. You can open, grab a wipe or two and close the lid with one hand, a skill anyone who's changed enough diapers is familiar with. The wipes are also for sensitive skin. You might want to note that wipes for sensitive skin tend to be more costly(.04 to .05) than ones that aren't(.02). If you don't need wipes for sensitive skin, you can buy Cuties Premium Baby Wipes, Lavender Scented, 864 ct (12 Soft Packs of 72) for $19.95 or .02 per wipe.The 72 wipe packs are convenient and we have them in the nursery, stroller, cars and baby bag.

I have been using AmazonBasics AA High-Capacity Rechargeable Batteries (8-Pack) Pre-charged and the Amazon Basics battery chargers for years now.The  Ni-MH batteries are excellent.  They hold a long charge, even when stored, and have completely replaced all AA and AAA batteries for me.  No more buying batteries, no more throwing away batteries.  The long term cost and convenience are a no brainer.  I always have extras on hand and cycle through the batteries as I use them. They included a USB port, a great touch as well. For me, I can never get enough USB charging ports.I use these in flashlights, remote controls, wireless devices - everything that I can. My only wish? If they made 9 volt batteries.The Amazon Basics has performed on par with Panasonic BK-3MCCA8BA Eneloop AA New 2100 Cycle Ni-MH Pre-Charged Rechargeable Batteries, 8 Pack, yet cost a lot less.Here's the short list about Amazon Basics batteries:- hold a good charge a long time, in use or in storage.- charge quickly (1 hour or so?)- cheap over the long run- nice to not run out of batteries- no more buying and throwing batteries in landfills when they die- can charge about 1,000 cycles- PLUS, there's a USB port as well

I was very happy to try the Ubervita Curcimim with Bioperine.  I already take Curcimim and Bioperine separately, so to reduce two pills to one, is preferable. Curcumin is poorly absorbed inherently, so the addition of Bioperine is one way to greatly increase the Curcimim absorption. If you are taking Curcimim and you're not also taking Bioprene, it's kind of a waste of time and even mega doses won't be absorbed enough to provide any value.Ok, so now that you know that Bioperine is a must and that it's in there, let's move on to what we know about Curcimim. As an avid reader of examine(.)com, I know the most notable effects are reduction of pain, inflammation and it's one of the better anti-oxidants available. I don't suffer from pain that Curcumin could help with, but I do read up on inflammation and right or wrong, I think that reducing it in our bodies is a good thing.  Finally, a good anti-oxidant? Who doesn't want that?

First, I'm a fan of the Jarrow brand as I like their quality.Additionally, I have a 'stack' of supplements that I take, something I have done since college. Reading up on phosphatidic acid & phosphatidylserine on Examine dot com, I was able to quickly see the research, the effects and the scientific consensus. Plus links to all the studies. It helps be decide to try a supplement or not. There's quite a lot of study around phosphatidic acid and phosphatidylserine, most notably as lowering LDL-C and total cholesterol. Additionally, studies show a minor, but measurable effect on both cortisol and lower stress in stressful situations. I do not take these with food and it's no problem for me.My personal observations are currently limited to the calming effect I have noticed. It's there, but it's not like I've been shot with a tranquilizer. My daily diet is consistent, so at the next checkup, I'll see it there's a change in my cholesterol. There's a lot of promising information from studies and there are ongoing studies as well, so I'm going to keep this up and use at least one more bottle before I make a complete decision. For now, this is in my daily stack.

This is a modest laptop from Toshiba at a modest price. For typical office usage, this performs well. I use it as a dedicated office solution, for email, browsing, Microsoft Excel spreadsheets, Quickbooks and similar programs, this is a fine option. The Celeron line of processors are slower, use less power and cost less. We have much more costly and powerful computers but for these tasks, the Toshiba Satellite appears no different. The 15.6 screen display looks sharp and bright. It comes with Windows 10, a DVD drive and 90 days of free support.It also comes with 4GB of RAM, which is pretty decent, the 500GB hard drive is also good for this size and price point. With cloud storage virtually everywhere, disk size isnt as important to some as it used to be. Connectivity options include the 802.11b/g/n wireless, 10/100Mbps Ethernet, Bluetooth 4.0, 1 x USB 3.0 port, 2 x USB 2.0 ports, DVD-SuperMulti Optical Drive, an HDMI / VGA output, Media Card Reader, Microphone input / Headphone output, so you can connect to a variety of peripherals including printers, speakers and mouse(mice?) easily.If you need speed and power for video editing or gaming, this is not for you. The keyboard is really good, its comfortable to type on, The laptop itself is quite light, weighing only 4.85 pounds.  The battery life is good, it went a full day on a single charge with moderate use and I was watching training videos over wi-fi, so the battery life was a little better than I expected. Wi-fi just worked fine, connecting as needed, but seemed to be a little weak and didnt get as strong of a signal in some places.The build is a little plasticly but at this price point, thats the trade off. Part of the build is to keep cost low and part to keep the weight down, so keep that in mind if you are rough on your laptops. We have this on a desk in the office or in a well padded laptop bag when were on the go, so it doesnt see a lot of wear and tear. I strongly suspect that it wouldnt hold up well under rough handling. If you are considering buying this for your child for school, this is a good machine for that, IF they take care of it.The primary feature of this laptop is price. Secondary features are its lightweight portability and decent battery life.  Personally, I see this as a laptop for school, office and traveling.My bottom line is that for $278, this is a very good value in a laptop earning 5 stars for what it gives your for the money.

The BLU Studio 7.0 II is an updated version of the BLU Studio 7.,  launched late in 2014.  This updated model is running Android 5.0, Lollypop.  It works on T-Mobile. Overall, its a few generations behind current Android options with regard to hardware, such as the display and camera, plus no NFC or flash for the camera. However, if you dont need those things, youre paying many hundreds less than a current Android with all up to date hardware.While this is a lot of phone for not a lot of money, it comes at a price.  Heres the good and the bad:Pros: Bright, great looking big screen Expandable to 64GB with a cheap flash card Very good battery life (so far) Looks like a nice phone Runs Lollipop 5.0 Plenty of apps from Google and Amazon FM RadioCons GSM only - NO LTE- NO CDMA (Sprint & build quality isnt as good as Samsung, Apple Low resolution camera No flash Audio is mediocre No covers available yet or other accessories Screen resolution is lower than typical smartphones Overall smoothness is lacking, pauses oftenIm rating this phone on what it is designed to be, not compared to phones at 3 and 4 times the price.  Im still unsure of what market this is looking to serve, but I do know I am not the target demographic.They obviously aren't competing with the flagship Android devices, but for capturing the lower end and offering a mix of features, I think theyve done ok.  Its very usable and the size is great.  They have left out the bells and whistles and used lower end hardware in a few places, but this remains a good solid phablet at a very low price point.When I could write about what it doesnt do that I wish it did, I recall this is $130 for this unit. Come to think of it, Im a bit amazed at what they can offer at this price.Im giving this 4 stars for value for your money.

With pets in the house a good vacuum is a necessity. The Panasonic Jetforce is as capable as it is compact. While I used to love my Dyson, the Panasonic has the same (and better) features, plus it edges it out in several ways.Its short and small, it rolls easily and for a vacuum, its on the quieter side. Its really easy to maneuver around the house, up and down 3 floors. Its lightweight and has a handle that makes it easy to carry. The power cord is retractable! So much nicer than the wrapping around posts.The HEPA filtered bagless system is easy to empty, but one trade off is that it doesnt hold a lot, so you might find yourself emptying this a few times in the course of a full day of cleaning. Also, the dust cup is fully washable as well. This is a feature I like as vacuums can accumulate a musty odor from the collected dirt and dust.  Washing the dust cup out goes a long way in preventing that.The Jetforce has a crevice tool and a dusting brush that snap on to the telescoping wand and are stored on the wand just below the handle. You can switch from carpet to hard wood with the push of a button on the wand. The Gliding Pet Brush works very well in picking up pet fur from the carpet and the sofa. It has two rollers and they do a noticeably better job at collecting pet hair than I am used to.Overall, this is a compact vacuum that has a lot of features and is well designed. The compact design is great not only for when youre using it, but it takes up little storage space as well. Its a pleasure to use, it does a great job with carpets, tile, hardwood and furniture. Its a lot less than what I paid for my Dyson and Id say this is easily my favorite vacuum.

Im a long time Roomba user and I like it. I was excited to try the Samsung VR9000 Powerbot.First, its more costly than a Roomba, so I certainly expected more from it. Its very different from a Roomba, with a blue LED screen and a ceiling facing camera that helps it navigate. Its 5 tall and cleans a path just over 12 wide.In the box you get: a docking station, a remote control, a cleaning brush and the VR9000. There are 4 cleaning modes to choose from, I use the max clean option, clean until theres no battery life left. Others are spot clean, auto (which cleans to the VR9000s satisfaction that the area has been covered) and manual clean.  The remote control allows you to fully control the VR9000 for scheduling cleaning times, direct it on manual mode, set the max cleaning with the dust sensor.The remote allows you to set the cleaning mode and drive the VR9000 to where it you want to vacuum. It will then set a pattern and clean that area.  As I have pets, I have this scheduled daily on max clean. I have yet to use the remote to drive it, other than testing it out.What really impressed me was the essence of the product: a vacuum. It vacuums very well.  It cleans a 4 room area with tile and carpet in under an hour (I didnt time it) and it gets up everything. While some of the features are more advanced than a Roomba, this is where it separated itself and made me prefer the VR9000 over my Roomba. The Roomba does a nice job, but the VR9000 just did better.There are 6 wheels that give high maneuverability to the VR9000. It moves around differently and doesnt go bouncing off obstacles, instead it senses them and slows down to very gently bump them or work around them. Its supposed to sense and remember the rooms, I cant tell if it has, but it has vacuumed all areas in the rooms.While I like the Samsung VR9000, its not without the some of the issues that the Roomba has.  Depending upon how we leave our chairs at our dining table, we can trap either robot, unintentionally of course. This happens when the chair is angled and allows a robot vacuum to get it, but hard to get out. Its hardly anything to be concerned about and the worst that happens is it doesnt clean when you expect it to. This never concerned me with the Roomba, it still doesnt with the VR9000, but it just goes to show that any robot vacuum has limitations.  Also, they can miss some debris, though the VR9000 was noticeably better at picking up, it had an occasional miss. There are areas that robot vacuums will not reach, thats just going to be a fact of life.While this is about ~$200 more than what my Roomba cost, to me, its worth it.  Its very good at what its designed to do and I really enjoy coming home to a freshly vacuumed room. With pet hair, its a must for me. Samsung has made an excellent robot vacuum and if youre looking for one in this price range, this is a very good option to strongly consider.

We make guacamole at least once a week.  This mortar and pestle is great not only to make it in, but to serve as well.I seasoned it with rice and salt, just to be on the safe side. Even when cooking items say they are pre-seasoned, I do it anyway so I know it's done. The mortar is a stout piece, heavy, but not overly so. The pestle has the natural rock finish and it's easily gripped, even with hands wet from lime juice, etc.Maybe it really is dishwasher safe, but I don't put it in there. It cleans up easily with hot water and a good scrub with my nylon bristled brush. We leave it on the counter and when we're not using it, it has something in it, like tomatoes, avocados, garlic cloves etc.

The first thing you should know is these are a very different type of headphone. They use bone conduction, they do not go in your ears. It's quite a different way of using headphones, but the concept is decades old. As these don't transmit audible sound like typical earbuds, no one can hear them but you. No sound leakage at all.They are very light and comfortably fit, since they don't cover my ears, these are great when riding my bike, something I do often.  I can't explain it better than to say you can hear your music/podcast/etc but you can also hear everything else around you.  So for a safety factor, these are excellent, however, if you want to tune out the world and listen to something, this is not for you. Additionally, the fidelity of the sound is not as good as in ear headphones. It's good for me, but I can tell the sound isn't what I get in my Shure noise canceling earbuds. That's not a fair comparison, but the underlying point stands.Once you get used to the proper placement, it'll be easy to do. If you don't place them properly, you won't hear anything. The cord is 47" long, plenty for me and the headphones are water resistant.Where I really loved these, was on a 12 hour flight and coupled with Etymotic Research ER20 ETY-Plugs Hearing Protection Earplugs, Standard Fit, Clear Stem with Blue Tip (Light Blue) it was perfect for me. I could hear my audio book perfectly, the ETY plugs dimmed the drone of the airplane and I could still hear the flight attendant when they came by.The function is good for my needs and I have use for these certainly, however, they will not replace my earbuds completely.

We've owned many Epson products over the years, some were good and others left something to be desired.  The Epson Expression is one of the good.It's smaller than expected, but that's a good thing. A small footprint is preferable to me. It fits nicely on a recessed bookshelf near my desk, something that the wireless connectivity makes easy to do. One big difference with the Expression line is the ink tanks. Part of the reason I placed the printed in a recessed bookshelf  is that it won't be moved, bumped, tilted, etc, which could cause the ink to spill. For most people that's not an issue, but it's good to know before you decide where to place the unit. That's also the reason they include a plastic bag to cover the printer, should you need to move it.The setup was quick and easy, the most notable feature is the ink tanks. I'm sure many people know the ink refills are a sore point for consumers, the high cost and the lengths some companies will go to ensure you are buying more ink all the time. With the Epson Expression, it's different. The printer is a higher cost, but the per page cost for printing and copying is about 1/4 of the current average with conventional ink cartridges. If you don't print and copy much, this is something to consider. If you do, you'll appreciate that you can print 20 times that of a typical cartridge!So far, everyone has been able to print from desktops and laptops, iPhone/iPads and a Samsung Note too. The Epson iPrint app is really good. Often printing software can be horrible, this one isn't. The speed is reasonable for a home office inkjet, the standard quality is very good. I'll print some photos next once I get some photo paper, plus I'll try printing from the flash card from my GoPro, as the printer has a slot for it.There are several Expression models, this is good for our home use. If you are needing features that are common in office printing, like high paper capacity, auto 2-sided printing/copying/scanning and faxing and 35-page auto document feeding, you might look at the other models.  For the home and home office, we find this to be more than sufficient for our printing needs.We are very happy with the printer.PROS:Wireless works with every device used so farYEARS worth of inkLow cost printingSmall footprintGreat printing appGood quality printingDon't have to buy cartridges!CONSDon't spill the inkBest for those that print often/ a lot

We spent a lot of time in the kitchen, either in front of the stove or the sink.  That means one of us in standing in the same area a few times a day for a good period of time. The Imprint Cumulus floor mat is really nice to have in the kitchen, as it is *very* comfortable to stand on. When you step on it, it's a great feeling. We use these in bare or stocking feet only.The 20" x 36" mat stays in place and doesn't slide around. It grips well to our tile floor and doesn't move or slide one bit. Of course being in the kitchen, it gets stuff dropped on it, but it cleans up easily. If you spill liquids, you need to take the mat up and dry the bottom. Because it grips the floor so well, any liquid caught between the floor and the mat won't dry out. We wash the mat and let it dry every time we mop our floors.When there's a lot of dishes, we move it to the sink area. I know it's just a squishy mat on the floor, but if you spend time in the kitchen like we do, you'll quickly appreciate the Imprint Cumulus floor mat. It's very nice on your feet and on your back.  This is one of the little things that you'll come to really love in the kitchen.

This review is for the seafood savories pack.Most everyone knows that cats are not all the same; what one cat loves another will turn their nose up at.  With two cats at home, that's what happened with the Wellness Divine Duos.The come in plastic cups with a plastic/foil top that you peel back to open. I peel back just a bit, serve a little and put the balance in the refrigerator for the second feeding. If you just peel enough to get a spoon in, you can almost reseal it.The favorite was the tuna ones, the least favorite was the salmon. Still one cat ate all without reservation. The other would eat a little of the tuna ones, but wouldn't touch the salmon. For what it's worth, they refused leftover sashimi from Nobu. Cats are weird. Moving on, the top layer is a pate, the lower layer is chunks in sauce.I am very familiar with the Wellness brand and they do make a very good product.  It's a little more costly than average wet food, but right in the middle of the pack for the upscale foods.

This is a brand I hadnt heard of before. The Florida based company states they have been making watches for over 25 years. This model, the Highlander chronograph, is their 2015 model and comes in 6 colors. This is the black on black model.The case is is a 316L stainless steel in a brushed finish with a synthetic sapphire crystal face and a wide stitch white on black real leather band with a tan opposite side. The movement is Swiss design, ISA 8171, a 3 jewel quartz electronic movement.  I expect this watch to keep very good time. The hands and markers are luminous and are very easy to see in the dark once exposed to sufficient light. The contrast between the white numbers and markers against the black face are sharp and make for easy reading.Swiss Legend rates the watch as water resistant down to 10ATM/100Meters, typically meaning that this watch can be worn in the shower or in the pool. No scuba diving with this one, besides the band is leather, so getting this watch wet repeatedly in the shower or pool wouldnt be a good idea.This watch is 52mm, on the large side and has some heft to it. Just on feel alone, the watch exudes a quality that belies the cost. If youve held a very cheap watch, you might know what I mean. My daily watch is 44mm, so this is noticeably larger.I do love watches and I have a small collection. These is very good looking watch. The design is quite nice and independent, meaning they arent trying to copy popular or expensive brands. These are priced well, have Swiss movement and a 5 year warranty. Overall, this is a very good looking watch that isnt cheesy looking for a very reasonable cost.4 stars

When I am sitting at my desk, I tend to have bad posture. I catch myself often and adjust my posture. For a while I took to sitting on an exercise ball, just like the one in this chair, just bigger. For me, its a great way to always keep a good posture while sitting.It is a comfortable way to sit as well. If youre not used to sitting with good posture, this might take getting used to. You will be forced into centering yourself using your abdominal muscles. This is good for your back and helps you learn good posture.  You can adjust the firmness and add more air if youre like me and prefer it more firm. I have used a ball as a chair before and Im used to it. However, I shared my desk with someone and they experienced some discomfort for almost a week.  It did go away and she prefers this to a chair now.This was easy to assemble taking just a few minutes. I used the included hand pump to inflate the ball. Im well below the maximum weight and at the top for height. This fits me ok at the desk, but I do wish it were a touch higher. The chair can roll on the casters, but I use the lock and keep them immobile. Also, make sure that you inflate the ball as per instructions. If this is completely new to you, expect that you will have an adjustment period. Id suggest that you give it a week at least before you decide if you like it or not.

In our house, we cook almost every meal. That means one of us in standing in the same area a few times a day for a good period of time. The GelPro floor mat is really nice to have in the kitchen, as it is *very* comfortable to stand on. When you step on it, it's a great feeling.It stays in place and doesn't slide around.  Of course being in the kitchen, it gets stuff dropped on it, but it cleans up easily. When there's a lot of dishes, we move it to the sink area. I know it's just a squishy mat on the floor, but if you spend time in the kitchen like we do, you'll quickly appreciate the GelPro Plush floor mat. It's very nice on your feet and on your back.  This is one of the little things that you'll come to really love in the kitchen.

I've used a lot of teeth whitening products and so far, this is above average. I drink coffee daily and wine here and there, so my teeth need some help staying white.The two part system is simple, brush with one for 1 minute, then the other for a minute.  After almost two weeks in, I have some progress which I can tell from taking photos from the start until now.  I have had no sensitivity to my teeth or gums, something common in whitening.Everyone is going to be different, but for me, I do a lot better using a whitening gel and then a whitening product like the Crest 3D.  It is working for me, slowly, but working.  Personally, I recommend 5 XL 38% Dentist Recommended High Intensity Teeth Whitening Gel Pro Dental Lab Direct! Highest Quality Carbamide Peroxide, Sensitivity Free. Sold by Dentists! Whiter Smile Labs FASTEST WHITENING RESULTS, 2-3 Full, 7 Day Treatment Cycles. FRESHLY MADE IN A USA, FDA Compliant, Dental Lab. NOT Cheap Imitation, Overseas Bleaching Gel. 100% Full Satisfaction Guarantee. With NEW Style Precision Gel Applicator Tip! Takes The Guesswork Out Of How Much Gel To Apply! Pharmaceutical Grade Syringes. FAST FREE SHIPPING to get your teeth white fast and THEN using the Crest 3D. That's just my opinion.Overall, this works slowly and gently, which is not a bad thing.

First, I have always been satisfied with Viva Labs products having used many of them. I find them to be above average in value, though they tend to be a little on the upper end, which is fine with me.In our house we use protein powder daily, or I do at least.  With a vegetarian in the house, there can be challenges to what we eat but the Viva Labs organic hemp protein is not one of them.  I was unfamiliar with hemp as a food, so I didn't know what to expect.The 15g of protein per serving is great, better is the 1g of NET carbs (overall carbs minus fiber=NET carbs). It tastes good, kind of a earthy nutty flavor. We've used this in smoothies, shaked it up with just water and even made protein bars with it. The bag is resealable.There is plenty of fiber as well and the sugar content is very low. For me, I'll keep using my whey powder, but I have to say this organic hemp is quite good, perfect for vegan or vegetarian needs.

The SanDisk Ultra was immediately recognized in my Galaxy Note.  A popup message let me know that in single shoot mode, photos would be stored on the San Disk card, but not in burst mode. Bursts are saved to device memory. It was nice that it worked right out of the box - no need to format it.For $13, the storage of my phone is doubled!  The price of these keep falling and next I'll get the 128GB and have room for everything.

This was far better than I expected!  It arrived in a large flat box and inside there were styrofoam protectors at each corner.It is really well made overall; the giclee is printed very well and the canvas is attached well to the wood frame. Open the box and it's ready to hang. The design is well done and the wood effect looks great. This would be very cool for anyone that liked the Avengers and wants a nice art piece that reflects that.If you've ever had something framed, you know how expensive it can be. At this price, I guess I didn't expect a lot and I was pleasantly surprised.

My water bottle is with me at work, gym and in the car.  I have several and after using the Contigo Autospout, its now one of my favorites. I do love my Kor One at my desk, but for me the Contigo is great on the go.  If you're reading this, I don't have to tell you how we should all keep well hydrated. That's why you're looking at water bottles!Its a BPA free plastic, standard these days, but always welcome. The body has measurements in metric and imperial on it.  The interior top has a rubber gasket to prevent leaking and a rubber ring on the exterior for a good grip.  The loop has a spring latch, like a carabiner. I like this a lot. The body is sturdy and already survived a flight of concrete stairs.  (I tend to drop things as I lock my door of my home). There is a button, that when depressed, opens up the top and presents a spout to drink from.  You can hold the Contigo, open the spout, take a drink and close it - all using only one hand. The spout attaches to a removable internal straw inside, which also has a rubber gasket. Everything can go in the dishwasher as well. There is also a lock to keep the spout from opening unintentionally, a great feature if you are packing it in bag.For such a simple product, the design is refreshing, feature packed and well executed. For $12 this is a great bottle.  Contigo states that it is not for hot or carbonated drinks, so know that.  I love that I can clip this onto my belt for a second. (No, I dont go walking about with it clipped to me). I do clip it to my backpack while biking, though. Its quite convenient.I havent found anything about the Contigo that I dont like.  In the car, I like it the best, as it fits the cupholder well and I can use it with one hand. I dont have to look at it and it closes up to prevent any spilling. 5 stars!

I camp several times a year in a variety of climates.  I tend to buy decent gear, but I wont be out for weeks or on long treks. To anyone that has shopped REI, you know that there is a wide range of costs on outdoor equipment. The Slumberjack boundary is in line with the gear I buy. Its not the most high tech, doesnt have all the bells and whistles but it does the job well at a good price.The Slumberjack is 4.5 pounds (2.04 kilos), so not the lightest or the most compact available in a 0 degrees sleeping bag. The build is good as well, but the fill is polyester, which has proven in my experience to not be the most effective at keeping you warm. It offers more room than my other mummy style, but just a bit more for me. The foot box is generous. The zipper has material running its length to seal it from drafts. The velcro sealed padded collar is comfy and keeps the draft out. The hood can double as a small pillow, but also works with my camping pillow nicely.For the money, this is a good sleeping bag, but you have to know what you are getting.  If you need a true 0 degree sleeping bag, this probably isnt for you. Or if you need a lightweight and compact bag, also, this isnt for you.  If those previous points dont concern you, then youll almost certainly like this sleeping bag. Its true in most products that you can choose a from a ratio of cost to features, this is no exception.  Its well designed, well made and is selling at a reasonable cost. If you compare this to Kelty or the ultra high end Vilandre, then it's not a fair or reasonable comparison.My feeling is that this is for the weekend adventurer, not a professional.

With everything being wireless, why would you want this? That is what I thought to myself. I have a good router and my ISP just increased my speeds for free (a little fear of Google fiber??) So with a 50Mbps line everything should be great, but I get far less speed (70% less) on the most distant computer and smart tv. As it turns out, the security settings plus the distance slow down the connection. I turned off the security and it was a big improvement. As I live in a densely populated area, I cant leave the wifi open.The TP Link Powerline solved the issue easily. It was very easy to setup and use, plus I get no slowdown. Yes, its hardwired, but it is a desktop and my smart tv, neither of which move. So wired or wireless for those doesnt matter. Now on those devices I get the full 50Mbps that I pay for and its crazy fast. Plus I still have my wireless too. Its the best of both worlds. Streaming HD? Not a problem, before it was unwatchable. Now, its perfect.Its as simple as plugging in the Powerline adapters, pugging in your ethernet cable and clicking pair. Its like magic.  If you have a situation that makes getting internet where you need it difficult, this will probably do the trick for you.

Im not a hunter, but I have a house in the foothills in Arizona.  We get a fair share of wildlife roaming, but they do a good job of keeping out of sight.The camera is really rugged and I expect that it will hold up well outdoors. The unit takes 8 AA batteries that fit in *very snugly*. It can take up to 32GB SD/SDHC cards and since memory is cheap, buy the 32GB and call it a day. At this writing, a Sandisk 32GB SDHC is $12. Maybe get a few.The mode options are photo and video with time lapse options for both. If you want to extend your battery life, photo is the obvious choice, as the more the camera is on, the faster the battery will run out.Our intended plan is to use this when we go camping, but it occurred to us that it would help solve a question for us: what is on our roof, making a racket at in the middle of the night? The roof is flat and I attached it on a corner with a complete view of the roof. We set it for photos. It took a couple of days, but finally we had some pictures.  What we initially (a few seconds)  thought was a neighbors cat, was in fact a bobcat. It climbed a tree to get on the roof, which I didnt think was possible, but now we have proof!The camera is really quite simple, yet its made rugged.  We will take it camping next to the high desert, though Im not sure its such a good idea. We could hear *something* outside rooting around. Do we want to know what is outside our tent? I do and Ill use the Primos trail camera to find out.
I thought it was free?? - I had to pay for it! - lol.Free-Floating...oh..okay...got it!Standard strainer for standard snare.Good price and arrived fast.
Bought this for my girlfriend as a fun gift for xmas.She is silly and loves me for it.Can't really go wrong with Elmo, eh? lol.

My kid delivered the daily newspapers in sub-zero temperatures.I remember when I was growing up working outside and had bought myself a ski suit.He should love me forever for this! - hahaha...right!The fit was good, the style wasn't too flashy and most of all he said it kept him warm and toasty.
Ruby Tubes Day - Who could hang a name on you?Typical tubes comparable to the standard brands in this price range.The price was right and the tone was acceptable.
