Even though this is for large breed, I have been giving small amounts to my small dogs as a treat. They absolutely love it. The food actually looks and smells delicious, even to me. I haven't tasted it, obviously, but I assume it is as good as it looks, based on the dogs reactions. Best of all, it seems to be made from quality ingredients using high standards.

This is a really cool concept. You stuff it with old clothes, and that adds the weight. It's a great way to use those clothes that don't fit you anymore to motivate yourself. Once you lose weight, you can stuff it with your fat clothes to keep yourself motivated. It's pretty cool. I've only had it about a month, so it seems sturdy so far.

This is a great quality food. Both of my dogs like this and eat it readily. I have not always had luck with the "healthy" dog foods, but they seem like this just fine. I'm impressed with the quality of the ingredients, as well. It's a bit pricey, so I don't know if I will continue feeding it to them. There are some good quality foods that are cheaper (Nutro, for example) and I might stick with one of those.

I have been using Nutiva Organic Hemp Protein Hi Fiber, which has about the same amount of protein but a little more fiber. I may end up switching to the Viva Labs. The Viva Labs blends a lot easier into my drinks and doesn't have as much grit. Hemp protein in general is great, because it has a lot of fiber and is free from allergens that can irritate the stomach. The sift on this is great. Even though it doesn't have quite as much fiber as the hi fiber hemp protein, it is still packed with fiber and the lack of gritty hulls is probably why it blends better. Overall, very impressed.

The curtain has a fabric-like feel to it. The color is kind of a dark khaki and the print is really subtle but very pretty. I like that this feels softer and more like fabric than a piece of plastic. To me it feels durable. I think the color and pattern are fairly neutral and would fit into any decor. The one thing that had me scratching my head was the packaging. It comes in a plastic pouch with the zipper. The pouch is too flimsy to be reusable, so the extra packaging just seems wasteful. Other than that, It's a nice shower curtain.

The book is great, but it isn't what I expected at all. Realistically, most of us can't just leave a job without a backup plan. If you are hoping to find a way to do that, this isn't the place to find it. This is more the memoir of Tess Vigeland, who left a high profile career as a radio personality to find herself. The description says this is "part memoir, part field guide," but really it is mostly memoir and other stories. It is an interesting, entertaining, and inspiring read, but not much of a guide at all.

I don't mind the color, but the formula is terrible It goes on really thin and uneven. Even with two coats it looks bad.ETA. After reading some of the other reviews praising the coverage, I thought maybe I was doing something wrong. I tried it again. I made sure it was shaken well and I did three coats. It still looked terrible. Usually nail polish kind of levels out on its own as it dries, but this didn't. It went on streaky and stayed that way. Maybe you have to have the under coat and top coat for it to look good.

You get a whole lot of batteries for a decent price, though they don't last very long. The package comes with a code to use to get free recycling, which is why they claim to be "green," but this claim is a bit dubious, as you have to buy multiple packs to actually qualify for the recycling. One thing that annoys me is that it has an American flag in the corner, which makes it seem like a US made product, but it's made in China like everything else.

I have a picky cat and he wasn't really impressed with this good. He ate the pate part of the tuna with salmon, but he didn't eat any of the soupy bits. He also completely rejected the other two flavors. That said, the ingredients are really great. I would love it if he would eat it. I might look into other Wellness foods. Right now, he's pretty much a Fancy Feast Ocean Whitefish and Tuna loyalist, but maybe I can find something by Wellness to satisfy him.

This book is very informative and well-researched. It's not the best writing in the world, but the information is solid and definitely worth reading. I've never been particularly fascinated with dolphins, but I did enjoy reading more about the way they live.l The ocean is a big mysterious place and I'm glad to know a little more about it.

I enjoyed this collection of short stories. I didn't think any were particularly groundbreaking, but they were all fun, quick reads. Sometimes that is all I want. If you are looking to have your mind blown, this isn't the right collection of stories. If you are looking for something to read on a leisurely afternoon with a glass of tea, then this is a fine collection.

If you are new to Word this book is a great place to start.  With it you get good advice on the most basic features of word processing (e.g., use tabs instead of many spaces) out through fancy/complex useful skills (e.g., doing mail merges).  While this book is clearly geared to people who are brand new to Word, if you are an old-time user you will find new tricks.  I have been using Word since the days of WinWord 3.0 and picked this up to see what was new or what I missed as Word evolved.  Happily, I found useful stuff in this book that I have never noticed (e.g., how to recover files that I forgot to save) as well as features that I had forgotten or thought lost as Word evolved.The writing is clear, the layout of each topic is consistent and very nicely done.  As you will see, if you preview the book, you get text instruction on the left side of each page and pictures to the right.  Each section has tips.  The tips are excellent.My only complaint is that some of the images are too small.  The author consistently shows large chunks of the display, which is nice because it keeps you oriented.  However, when the author is focused on what is happening on the ribbon (i.e., the top of the page) it can be hard to see exactly what is going on.  It is not too bad when you have word open in front of you but it does detract from the book.So, if you are new to Word and if you want to become a power user pick this up.

This is a very good keypad for when your mobile phone or tablet is on your desk.The setup is simple with Mac products.  All you do is turn on the keyboard, push a button to sync device 1, 2 or 3 on they keypad then enable they keypad in the blue tooth settings on your Mac device. That gives you a basic keyboard.  If you push function i you can enable Mac specific functionality (like search, home screen or the double tap on the physical button on an iPhone).For better or worse, the unit is not super lightweight.  Rather, it feels solid. The keys do not feel cheep but they are not as crisp as an expensive keyboard (like a real external Mac keyboard or a high end Logitech).They keyboard has a rechargeable battery built-in and the box includes the micro USB cable to charge.There is a handy slot to hold your tablet or phone if it is not in a heavy case.  My phone is in a Mophie recharging case so the keyboard can not be used as a stand.If you want to have a keyboard on your desk for your phone or tablet pick this up.

This tiny USB drive is wicked fast.  I move about 50 megs of photos on this to test it and it happened so fast I didn't think it worked!  If you want to transfer lots of stuff between a Mac, a PC and a smart phone this is the perfect buy.  The fact that it is warranted for years and is advertised as being hardened against the elements makes this the flash drive to buy even if it is not inexpensive.

I just used this bag for a 5 day business trip to Bogota Colombia, from the USA, and it was perfect.  It easily fit a man's business clothing (complete with a sport coat, dress shoes and medium weight jacket) and casual clothing for such a temperate destination.  The design, with two independent sides, one with integrated hanger holders, is excellent for holding dress shirts and sport coats.  There is a solid central flap with a mesh pocket that closes off one side and keeps dress clothing neat. The other side uses two triangular flaps with a plastic clip where they join to hold them together.  This is a brilliant design which also holds things in place well while allowing you to quickly get at things on that side of the bag. The inside pockets are nicely designed and out of the way but there is not a dedicated "waterproof" pocket.The zippers are solid and the pulls work perfectly.  The bag has a zipper to access the main part of the bag and one outside pocket.  The pulls are designed to be locked and the bag comes with one lock which is easy to set.  It would be better if the bag came with two locks instead of one.  I was able to use a standard travel lock on the second pocket.The bag rolls perfectly over nearly every surface.  The handle and general shape of the bag make it perfect for perching a computer bag on top.  Even with a fully loaded messenger bag threaded on the handle I was able to move it effortlessly even on cobbled/brick sidewalks.  I only tipped it once on a steep outside ramp with very large razed bumps.While this bag is not inexpensive, you get what you pay for here.  This is an absolutely excellent, perfectly functional, bag.

My two German Shepards absolutely love this chew.  The two of them have been working on it nearly constantly for almost a week and it is still in great shape.  The package says that this is for dogs up to 50 lbs but my dogs are 65 and 100 lbs and this is a good size for them.  I can't imagine a small dog being able to chew on this.  So, this is a great buy for big to huge dogs.

This travel sized headphone amplifier is great for getting some extra bass out of your headphones as the cost of some clarity on highs of songs. I tested this using iTunes on my iMac as well as with an iPhone 5S with the integrated music application with these high fidelity headphones: Grado Prestige Series SR325e Headphones . The unit itself is very, very small, perfect for your pocket next to your phone or on your desk. On it is a volume control as well as a switch that acts as a "bass boost" with three modes of operation, as well as two ports for standard headphone jacks. The amp charges with a generic micro usb port and battery life is decent at about 8-10 hours.This little unit adds a lot to the bass's presence. It is most noticeable in EDM and hip hop, where the bass is borderline overpowering on the middle switch, and ridiculous on the bass setting. In rock, loud alternative, and punk music, the amp feels almost balanced with a healthy amount of bass and decent acoustics on the middle range. I also noticed a very feint amount of static with the volume up very high in the form of a static in the background, which didn't bother me much but might be an issue for some. In more tame songs and jazz, the amplifier doesn't sound quite right; piano keys feel darker and heavier than they should, and string instruments don't sing quite like you'd expect. This is decent at best and grainy at worst.Depending on your music taste and how much treble clarity you're willing to trade for bass, this portable amplifier may or may not be right for you.

Everyone will think you are growing pot (by that I actually mean everyone) but this grows some nice little herbs (dill, basal and parley).  I have been growing these for about a week and as the package predicted they just started to sprout.  The setup is easy, basically you plug the thing in, fill it with water, add fertilizer, stick in the provided seed pods and press on...  It bubbles quietly like a fishtank but the LED lights can be rather obnoxious (but they turn off with the flick of a switch).  Overall, if you are looking to grow some herbs and you don't have the outdoor space or a windowsill this is a great buy.

These are small thin polyester cloths that are useful for polishing and drying glasses that you do not want spotted.  They are fine for that but they are too small for drying large jobs.  The big weakness is that they are white polyester so anything that could stain them will show and they can not be bleached.

This is exactly what I wanted in a chair mat.  It arrived flat.  It does not smell of plastic/chemicals.  It does not slide on my hardwood floor and the surface that I walk on is not slippery.  Basically this is perfect.

If you want to develop a new instrument/scale to assess health behavior get this book.  I have been doing biostatistics for a living for more than a dozen years and this book in its various forms has remained one of my favorites because of it's clear writing and spot on advice.  Over the years countless doctors have proposed using an instrument they have created to assess response to a new treatment.  This book covers exactly why that is two projects not one.  Development/validation of the instrument is its own project.  This book covers the statistics and methods used to properly assess the reliability and validity of new (or existing) instrument/test/scale with fantastically clear writing.  There are many examples taken from medicine and a fair number coming from education and psychology.  All are clearly explained.There are no proofs or derivations in this book.  Instead you will find basic algebra and worked examples for most of the statistics.  All the coverage is good but one of the truly excellent features of this book is the coverage of intra-class correlation.  Nobody has done a better job explaining ICCs.Some of my students find Norman and Streiner's Biostatistics the Bare essentials hilarious others find it too wordy.  While there are rare funny comments this book has been edited to be much more concise and not silly.  So, while it is not mathematically rigorous, it is a serious book.  While this is a statistics and methods book at it's core, the writing is accessible for anyone with a background in medicine, education or psychology, as well as people coming from mathematics who like clean prose.While this book could be better (if it had a web supplement with detailed coverage of SAS and/or R) it is otherwise fantastic.

This book is exactly what the title suggests: it contains eight full length practice SAT tests modeled after the newly redesigned SAT this spring. It also contains a breakdown of the new SAT and how it varies from the older variant of the test (for example, there is now no guessing penalty on the new test). Also included is the rubric for how the essay portion of the test is scored as well as the scale for how the rest of the test is scored. Otherwise, the book is just a set of questions with detailed answers to each question as well as how it is ranked in terms of difficulty to other questions in the section. I would recommend this to anyone looking to gain more experience with the SAT before actually taking it to familiarize themselves with the process of testing.

These are a great buy, especially for the price.  They work exactly as you expect.  I didn't try them without a pan but in a cupcake pan they make treats that are good looking with patterns that work well for kids of all ages....Ray

This is a simple, good looking, light weight watch with a comfortable wrist band.  The watch ships in a good looking box suitable for gifting. Along with the watch you will find a cleaning cloth and the simple easy to read manual.  Setting the date and time is trivially easy.  You pull out the crown and twist to set the date and then pull out again to set the time and push it back in when it is ready.  The crown mechanism feels solid.  The face is a bit large for a skinny wrist.  For scale I shot a picture next to a coke can.Overall, this looks nice and feels very solid.

I teach university level statistics and I find this book to be lacking because it covers no modern statistical methods and it has no coverage of analysis software.  If you are taking a high school level statistics class where you are not allowed to use a computer and if your teacher is still using methods from the 1960s this is not bad at all.  In general the writing and the graphics are nice and clear if you want to do things like calculate a median (or draw a box plot) by hand.  Nobody in their right mind works like this any more.  Perhaps worse is the fact that fundamental statistical topics are missing.  Bayesian statistics, which are the backbone for a huge number of modern methods are not even mentioned in the index.If you need something to supplement your work in high school class that stresses hand calculations consider this.  If you are not stuck working like the early 1960s consider OpenIntro Statistics: Third Edition instead.  It is clear and has great coverage of both SAS and R on the books website.
This is the best action movie of 2015. The plot is simple but it works just fine.  The HD stream from Amazon works great.  So, make yourself some popcorn and enjoy the ride.

If you need to split a wall plug six ways this is a nice basic unit.  We have not had any storms yet so I can't comment on the quality of protection.  My only gripe is that this only plugs into a single outlet.  There is a single peg that fits into the bottom socket to help hold the unit in place.  It would be much better if it plugged into both sockets to help keep this attached to the wall.  It has not fallen out but it feels like any bump will pull it from the wall.  Other than that it seems to be a fine buy.

The Turtle Beach X50s are a solid entry level headset at a reasonable price. They are mainly designed for Xbox One users with the newer Xbox controllers with headphone ports, and are to be just plugged into the controller. The chord is short, but this shouldnt be a problem if youre playing with a controller in your hands or if you sit next to your computer. The headset is comfortable to wear for many hours for gaming or music usage. The cups are made of a faux-leather material and slip right over your ears, and the headband has adjustable length to compensate for very small to medium-large heads. The microphone is easily detachable for storage and flexes well, and the headset itself feels generally sturdy. Attached to the chord is a volume control as well as a switch to turn your microphone on and off when it is attached.While they sound somewhat tinny compared to higher end gaming headsets/headphones, the soundstaging is solid for shooters at this price range. Basses are satisfying, but treble is lacking (this is somewhat expected for a gaming headset). I tested the headset by playing Counter Strike: Global Offensive, League of Legends, and Team Fortress 2 and I was able to hear around my surroundings well in Counter Strike, and spells and attacks sound clear in League. In Team Fortress 2, sound staging is more difficult to detect as the sounds start to wash together in the chaos, but I was still able to hear enemies creep up behind me and explosions go off in the distance.These do not do active noise canceling but they are substantial enough that they do block background noise.  If you are not mindful of your surroundings you will end up yelling while wearing these.However, to say this headset is for PC/Mac gamers is slightly misleading. In order to utilize the detachable microphone, you will need an adapter that accepts a headphone jack on one end and the red/green audio in and out ports. These are cheap and easy to find (I found one on amazon for eight dollars), (http://amzn.to/1LfmqI3) but it would have been nice of Turtle Beach to include this if they are going to advertise it as a PC headset.This headset is a solid buy for Xbox One users who want a microphone to talk to friends and teammates. PC gamers will be less satisfied due to the cost of an additional splitter, but this is an otherwise excellent product from Turtle Beach.

I teach programming at the university level and I think this is a thoughtful, well written book on computer algorithms ... in other words it does a good job explaining how software works.  I picked this up thinking that it could be useful to supplement my (not for majors) introduction to programming.  I will recommend it to people who are thinking about becoming a computer science major.  It is surprisingly deep while avoiding the mathematical notation (and rigor) that typically gets in the way when people who don't love math try to get beyond a cursory understanding of computer science.  Given the depth of the technical details, the authors clear style is to be envied.  However, the presentation is probably a bit dry and too deep for the masses.  Basically, the author strips out the math and the programming and explains, in fairly intuitive terms, how different programming methods work.  If you think that you want to get fairly deep under the hood of the machines that drive modern software this is an interesting place to start.

If you enjoy books which mix the supernatural into the modern world, especially if you are a fan of Simon Green's Nightside books or Jim Butcher's Dresden books you want to pick this up.  Kadrey's writing stands on its own but you will feel hints Green's zany humor and Butcher's snarkiness.  This book has real violence and heavy plot elements and some not so subtle religious themes which make it more than just brain candy.  The pace is excellent and the plot twists work well to make this an excellent book

The Magician's apprentice is one of the very best episodes of the Dr Who reboot.  It is great that Amazon includes the prequel episode with the season but they are currently missing The Doctor's Meditation which is the first scene of The Magician's Apprentice.  Be sure to hunt around for it because it is very funny and also adds some subtle points to the main episode.

Open the box. Unpack the scale (which takes 5 seconds).  Pull the plastic out to enable the batteries which ship inside the scale. Then step on it and it displays your weight in really big bright numbers.  If you want to track your weight changes the app seems to work nicely  and syncing with an iPhone is trivially easy.  The scale uses 4 AA batteries.  So you don't have to track down weird ones.The people who designed this did everything right.  It could not be any simpler.

These are the bags you want to have on hand for cleaning out the garage or for dealing with the aftermath of a major storm.  The plastic is heavy weight, and exceptionally hard to puncture.  They expand out to hold a LOT of stuff and they are easy to move around with the drawstrings.  While not inexpensive, with these bags, you get what you pay for.

If you need a lot of toilet paper, whether you or stocking your bunker for a zombie apocalypse or getting ready for a hurricane, this giant box of TP is for you.  This is Charmins Basic product, as compared to their Extra Soft and Extra Strong lines. Basic is pretty nice stuff, at a much nicer price. It is soft and not at all flimsy. The paper has a quilted appearance and is much softer and more substantial than most store brands. The double rolls last a pretty long time. Charmin Basic is a good quality product and if you have a lot of storage space this is a great value for the price.

This is a nicely constructed surge bar.  It feels solid and has turning covers that keep dust out of the unused plugs.I installed this last Friday and on Saturday one of the arms on the power pole behind our house was hit by lightening, caught fire and the transformer on one arm blew out.  No really! Thunderstorms in Miami are rough in the fall....  We had a brownout for about four hours before the power company turned off the power completely to replace the damaged parts.  All that time my APC and CyperPower uninterrupted power supplies (protecting my computers) were squawking about the low voltage and "noise" in the power line.  The circuit breaker on this little surge bar never tripped.  So, I can categorically say that it takes a lot to trip it.  Happily we had no problems from the outage including the TV, router and cable box that were protected by this bar.I have two gripes.  The biggest is with the insurance policy.  If this bar fails and you make a claim you need to have the original receipt for both this and the damaged device.  A minor complaint is the spacing on the plugs. They are the typical width apart.  It would be nice if there was more space to afford enough room for the bigger plugs on electronics.Overall, this things seems to work like a trooper and is a good buy for the price.

There is a reason why this is a classic... it is a great story.  The imagery is exceptionally vivid which helps offset for the slow pace in the first third of the story.  It is a very short book so the slowness is not a major drag.  The beginning is slow, the middle third builds tension exceptionally well and the end of the book is incredible.  So, don't be put off if the beginning seems to be going nowhere interesting.  It is worth sticking around to see how it ends.

We got a half-dozen of these cans to deal with hurricane season and they are all free of defects. The construction is solid and they do not have the nasty chemical smell that comes with cheep plastic.  My only gripe is that the sides are not perfectly flat. So you can't stack them easily.

Leo came to help with a couple old ceiling fans with lighting problems in our new house.  We thought from our attempts to open the casing that the coverings over the old bulbs were hopelessly stuck.  Rather than just replacing the units Leo studied them and then tried many tricks to get the covering off.  Unfortunately he could not open them. So, he quickly installed the replacements.  The service was on time, courteous and he did a perfect job cleaning, including offering to take away the broken equipment and the boxes.  We have a couple outdoor electrical plugs that need to be replaced.  We are hiring him back without hesitation.

I got this box to use the water as the carbonated base for mixed drinks and it did not disappoint.  This is a great buy if you are working on cocktail recipes because a can contains enough Perrier for a single drink with nothing wasted.  The cans are also perfect for people who enjoy a little glass of mineral water over ice but they are probably too small to use for serving with a full meal.

If you want a cup to hold water or black coffee and you don't mind washing the cup by hand this is a good buy because it does keep the temperature.  If you want a cup that can be used to hold coffee with cream or anything else that could breed bacteria keep looking.  I guess it is good that this comes with a booklet to explain how to disassemble and clean the lid but I would rather have a cup that does not require such special care.

This book is wildly creative and the premiss of exploring human life in the FAR distant future should have made this book legendary, but the writing which is a mixture of hard science fiction and action adventure does not work well.  The story gets bogged down in hard science (relativity theory and anthropology) and nearly grinds to a halt a couple of times.  The action adventure just instantly switches off an conflicts are not resolved because the next bit of hard science shows up.  I have never read a book where a hero looses depth and becomes less believable as the story unfolds. Unfortunately that happens here. Fans of hard science fiction may want to pick this up but it is not great for the masses.

I teach statistics and statistical programming for a living and while this is not a bad book, it is so far from optimal I would not recommend it for my students.  Typically people approach R because they have a dataset (in Excel or coming from REDCap) and they want to do basic summaries, graphics or make inferences.  In everyday use that data gets imported into an R object called a data frame and then people play with the columns inside of the data frame.  Rather than starting with real data imported into data frames, this book begins with manually typing data and doing basic operations on vectors.  The authors do not get to data frames until page 132.  Excel is not covered until page 229.Instead of first covering the basic tasks, like importing and describing data the authors cover key programming ideas, which are critical for a deeper understanding of R.  That coverage is not bad at all but it could be better.  All the material is hampered by the authors not sweating the details on their code.  R is a case sensitive language and the authors are not consistent in how they name objects.  For example in chapter 3, where they cover R naming, they include objects called Intro, Total.baskets, baskets.of.Granny.  Because R pays attention to what is capitalized, readers of the book who are trying to follow along will have to waste time fixing the authors inconsistent capitalization.In general the writing is good to very good but it could be better.  For example the coverage of methods vs functions is not crystal clear and it needs to be.If you are coming to R with a programming background there is some very nice stuff here.  The authors do regularly point out things that are different about R (for example its coverage of vectorized functions and recycling) and they have useful technical points throughout the book.  If you are coming to R from a database background you will find the lack of coverage on R and SQL integration disappointing.While each has its own flaws, readers are better off getting Data Manipulation with R (Use R!) to learn to slice and dice data and perhaps OpenIntro Statistics: Third Edition to learn statistics with R (or SAS) and/or The Art of R Programming: A Tour of Statistical Software Design to learn how R actually works.

These speakers are simple to use and they sound good.  Unpacking and setting them up with a MacPro took about 2 minutes total.  The construction feels solid. The sound is just right if you want to listen to TV shows or movies on you computer but you don't need audiophile quality sound.  I have been using them at work for listening to teleconferences and for when my computer proofreads writing and they are more than adequate.I normally use Grado headphones and Yamaha speakers (which are at a totally different price point).  So I can't say anything too good about the sound quality but these do not sound bad at all.  The big problem I have with them is that they shut off fairly quickly to save battery.  So, if you pause and come back you need to turn them on again and that takes a couple seconds (which feels like a long time after you push the play button for the 4th or 5th time in a day).  If you want good basic speakers to listen to your TV or computer they are a great buy.
These are comparable in every way to the filter that came with my air purifier.They fit correctly and work as expected.

This is a great cup for drinking beer by the pool.  It has a built in bottle opener and is insulated to help keep your brew cold.  I did notice that after the 5th beer there was some spillage.  I blame the cup.It is well made and feels very solid.  This would be a five star product if it was dishwasher safe but it is not.

This is a solid all purpose machine with a roomy 1 TB hard-drive.  The setup could not be easier.  The packaging is easy to open and the boxes are well laid out. The tower itself is pleasantly small.  The mouse and keyboard are both surprisingly comfortable with buttons that are easy to press/click and are not at all mushy.  The video card works with multiple cables (DVI, VGA and HDMI but not DisplayPort).  Because the OS is Windows 8.1 the configuration is easy.  If you don't have an outlook account it walks you through the steps.  Of course you then need to deal with idiosyncratic "features" of Windows 8.1 but the system does prompt you to allow the free upgrade to Windows 10 (for the next year).Once setup the boot time is quick and the machine is nearly silent.  For every day use the USB ports are plentiful with a good mix of USB 2 and 3 across the front, top and back.  For watching old movies or listening to your old discs there is a DVD drive.I stress tested the machine with modern AAA video games and was satisfied.  Alien Isolation runs on ultra settings with a good frame rate. Wolfenstein: the New Order runs cleanly with medium to high settings.  The only game that gave it trouble were the Metro Redux games.  Which ran on low setting perfectly but lagged with higher quality renderings.  Source games such as Left 4 Dead, Team Fortress 2 and Portal run perfectly over the built in WiFi.If you are looking for an all purpose machine for casual gaming, browsing the web, multi-media entertainment and/or photo editing this is a great buy for the price.

These cups are perfect for serving drinks to kids or for holding snacks.  The construction is not as solid as real Solo cups but it is very close.  If you want smaller plastic cups these are a great buy.

If you are re-watching the series (as you wait for January 24th 2016) this is a great buy.  This is a solid excellent two hour episode of the X-files which fits between season five ("The End") and season six ("The Beginning").  The HD streamed version looks and sounds great.

These are exactly what you expect and they work perfectly.  The only gripe could be the packaging. The packaging that contains the batteries can't be opened without seriously sharp scissors and for whatever reason, this tiny item ships in a box big enough to hold a large clock radio...

Alien 3 is nowhere as good as the first two movies in the franchise but if it was not held to such a high standard most people would say this is a very good sci-fi action flick.  The HD version looks and sounds great streamed.
The HD streamed version looks and sounds excellent.  If you are thinking about watching this classic, it is every bit as good as you remember and you can't beat the convenience of the Amazon stream.

This book is split between two timelines. One plot arc takes place on a frozen world with suspense and action, the other a soggy backwater world of bureaucracy.  I read about 20% of the book before I gave up because the bureaucratic timeline is just horribly dull.  I don't care to read about how the officers of an occupied planet are dealing with fish rationing.  Given the popularity of the book I am sure that it picks up but wow is the beginning deadly boring.

If you have read his Armageddon books, you know that Bourne can write action sequences with the best.  This book  also delivers brilliant page turning violence and big screen action.  In his other books you need a healthy dose of suspending reality because of the implausibility of zombies.  Here the scenario leading to the end of society is a stretch but not a wild leap and the post apocalypse is horridly realistic.  So. if you want a very intense, suspenseful, fairly depressing story with great action look no farther.

This is the brutally violent, sexually twisted, and wickedly creative Clive Barker that I was hoping to find after far too long of a lag.  If you liked his early work you will be pleasantly impressed.  He has not lost his touch.  There are a few places toward the end where there are some gaps in the narrative but overall this is utterly brilliant NC-17 horror.

This book tries to paint a picture of romance and survival in an America destroyed by drought.  I made it through the first 80 pages before I gave up.  The are big problems in this book.  Specifically the plot is uninspired, the imagery reveals nothing new, the characters are flat and the pace is extremely slow.  There is some suspense but that did not offset the dull cliche images that felt like a rip off of the mad max universe.  I think the biggest problem is that I recently read The Water Knife.  Because that world is so much more intense and oddly believable it makes this book seem like at best an afterthought or at worst a waste of time.
Silence is the strongest song on A Sign of Life.  The remixes here are all solid but none of them are better than the original.  If you, like me, love the original you will find lots to like here.

This is a brilliant collection of odd short stories.  The plot elements are exceptionally cool.  The only work I can compare this to is PK Dick when he is at his strangest.  He had a similar gift for creating totally bizarre scenes.  If you are looking for complete stories this is not for you.  Rather, this book will appeal to people who enjoy the feeling of wonder as you read something that takes the mundane and twists it into something unconventional and unfamiliar.

My son runs in these and reports that they are very comfortable for cross country.  His first pair held up well for many months of regular running.  So, they are comfortable and a good value for the price.
This works perfectly.  The only thing noteworthy about this cable is how it is a bit thicker and stiffer than others I use.  The clips feel solid. There is nothing to complain about here.

Amazon makes good cables and this is no exception.  The construction feels solid and the cable works perfectly.  The clip and its cover do not feel cheap and they are easy to pinch to connect and disconnect.  This is a great buy for the price.
This cable works perfectly, looks good and feels like solid construction.  The cable and plugs have a good weight to them and feel like they will last.

This is $62.70 including 2-5 day shipping to the USA on the authors website.  This is a great condensed collection of useful facts.  Risk factors for conditions, stage/grade and treatment guidelines are all clearly presented.

My family uses Vysk and Mophie charging cases for our iPhones.  Compared to those cases this OtterBox is our least favorite.  I let my daughter, who normally uses an OtterBox, try this and she disliked it.  These things in particular bothered her: it does not feel as rugged as the normal OtterBox, the install instructions are mostly useless, it is heavy, it makes the phone to big to fit into her "girly jean pockets" (her words not mine), it requires a headphone adaptor, it is slippery, it gets very hot as it charges and it changes the dimensions of the phone so much it is hard to hold.  The last point is noteworthy when compared to our other charging cases.  The outline of this case is nice and slim on the top and sides but that is at the expense of making a very large footprint at the bottom of the phone. There is so much material there, it makes it hard for her to reach across the entire phone display.  If you are looking for a charging case your best bet is probably the Vysk EP1 Privacy Charging Case for iPhone5/5s - Retail Packaging - Blue.  It has the good qualities of the Mophie cases but is less slippery (and it has a nice shutter to protect your phone's camera lens.

In some, but not all respects, this camera beats the GoPro at its own game.  The first advantage for this is the adapters.  The ones included in this set are incredibly versatile.  It is easy to use them as designed and with a bit of creativity we were able to attach them to all kinds of things including our dogs collar and a paddle-board. We spend a lot of time at the ocean and the camera itself has held up nicely after three weeks of playing including time in the surf.  The wrist mount display is extremely nice and far better than the display you can add to the back of a GoPro but it is not waterproof.  So, unlike the GoPro you can't see what you are shooting when you are snorkeling/paddelboarding/surfing.  However, the iPhone app that goes with the camera is excellent.  So, if you have a waterproof case for your phone you can check your shots while in the surf (or on a board).  That setup is a huge advantage over the GoPro because the back mounted display for a GoPro burns battery like mad.I have used a GoPro Hero 3 Black Edition since they came out.  I think it takes very good video but this beats it hands down.  The stabilization on this is at least as good and the resolution and frame rate are superb.  If you are going to share videos on the web you will not notice the difference but if you are going to capture stills off the video or stream to your TV the difference is big.Sadly the case on this camera, unlike the GoPro, can not be used for SCUBA.  The Sony MPKAS3 Underwater Housing (Clear) will work with this camera but it will set you back $40 and it does not come with extra o-rings or grease.  Again unlike the GoPro there are no Backscatter (or other brand) lenses for shooting underwater yet.So, if you are a diver get a GoPro. Otherwise give this camera serious consideration.

This is a good looking, well constructed, washable pot holder.  It is designed to fit on the handle of a pot and keep you from getting burned on the handle.  You can also use it to grip or hold a pan if you fold it over.  It holds very well when you fold it over but when it is on the pot handle it can slip around.  The ribbing which makes this not slippery is excellent but the coating is not on the inside of the sleeve that fits around the handle.  Because the handle can slip in the sleeve you need to have strong hands or lots of experience as a chef.  If that is you, pick this up.  If you are a novice or if you have small hands you are probably better off getting a hot mitt.

The second season is better than I remembered.  They conspiracy mythos gets deeper and the monster of the week episodes get downright frightening.  The entire season still works well.  In addition to the conspiracy episodes both Calusari and Our Town are still really excellent stories.

This is a nice necklace but it has its down sides.  Its biggest weakness is its really awkward length. It comes in a standard 18 inch length and has a two inch extender which helps but it is still awkward.  The necklace has two separate chains which are connected at the clasp so you can not adjust their lengths individually.  The main problem is that they do not lay together well.  The distance between the two pendants just doesn't work.  It seems that the smaller one should lay inside of the larger or they should be much farther apart.  The pendents are small but in a tasteful way.  See the picture for scale.  The stone is a nice rich purple and the chain and silver heart are nice and shiny.  The presentation is excellent. The pendent comes in a black velvet lined clam shell box with blue accents and that comes in its own black box.  You could easily slap a bow on this box and present it to someone.  However, the necklace came as a tangled mess.  So be sure to untangle it first. The proportions on the chains are really unfortunate because if you could adjust them individually or if the ratio was different this would be a five star buy.

This book is like Romeo and Juliet, without Capulets and Montagues but with demons, vampires and witches, without great writing and with an interesting, mysterious book which does something important but you never really know what.  This book, like that sentence, just will not end.... The book begins great with a modern day witch, who is hiding from her magic ability, stumbling across a strange book.  She is soon stalked by a pile of potentially interesting characters.  From there the book flames out and crashes  into a fabulously annoying romance.  I know the book was in trouble when it got to yoga with vampires.  I did make it through the entire thing in the hope it would resolve the story of the mysterious book but the ending is entirely unsatisfying.If you are looking for PG rated romance masquerading as an urban fantasy belly up to the bar.  Otherwise forget about this one.

If you have a small breed these are a fine buy.  The fact that the instructions on the back of the bag max out at 23 treats for a 75 pound dog leads me to think that my 105 pound German Shepherd could demolish the 4 oz bag in a sitting.  Given how popular these are I think she would agree with that assessment.  While they are a bit expensive for the amount you receive, they are made from natural ingredients and they are very popular. So, if you are looking for a training treat, you get what you pay for in this case.

If you have not seen The Cabinet before and if you have Amazon Prime watch either of the two unlimited streaming versions first because you will want to watch them both (to really understand the plot).  The Kino version is easier on the eyes and there is no hiss compared to the CreateSpace release but "modern" music on the Kino release is a bit distracting.Setting aside the restoration you choose, the movie itself is marvelous.  So much of modern horror is a retelling of what was done right the first time...

If you are trying to decide between this and a Mophie case, get this one.  I have been using a Mophie on my 5S for a year and I love the battery but that case is just too slippery.  I have dropped the case hard twice because it slipped out of my hands in the cold.  This case has similar battery performance and it is about the same size but it has a striated grip on the back which is not slippery.The phone comes with an app to handle security if you are worried about the security of the iOS.  I was not so I didn't add the clutter.  The battery is driven by a manual switch on the back so you don't need to mess with the app.  There is a manual slider to cover the camera (if you are paranoid).  EvenIf you are not, it does cover and protect the lenses.  Unfortunately it covers that flashlight.The speakers built into the case are small but surprisingly good.  If they are not better than the Morphie case they are at least as good.  The case requires a dongle to plug in your headphones.  Those are notorious for breaking but out of the box it works nicely and feels solid.The only gripe I have is with the instructions which do not mention that you need to pull the bottom off the case before attempting to slide the phone in.  I knew how to do it because of my other case but my son didn't realize that it slides apart so he was scratching his head trying to figure out how to get the phone into the case.So, while the case is not inexpensive, it seems to be well made and slightly better designed than the competition.

If you have not watched the X-files in a decade or more it is worth reliving the old shows.  The fashions and the phones look wacky, the cutting edge science is now really dated and the quality of the video is showing its age but the greatness of the dynamics between the stars still works perfectly.  I had totally forgotten how creepy some of the monster of the week episodes were.  The mythos is still great to rediscover and some of the random one-off episodes are better than I remember (Roland and Beyond the Sea are both fantastic).  These old gems are worth the money as we wait for the reboot.

This is a fairly high level introduction to data science which should be perfect for someone who is just starting out and wants to know the "what is what" in data science but not the gory details on "how do I accomplish ... whatever".  I do biostatistics and informatics for a living and nearly all my favorite tools are here (sadly SAS is mostly missing)  and the tools are all nicely explained.  Over and over you will see very simple code or screenshots that give a flavor for the tasks that the language/tools are used for.  The only real risk here is the reader may be left thinking that data science is easy, when in fact the devil is in the details.  If you want to get started with data science this is a great resource.  From here head to Coursera and look at the Johns Hopkins Data Science series.  It unpacks the tidy presentation that you will find in this book.

If you are not a mathematician but you are comfortable with basic algebra and you want to learn biostatistics, this is the book you want to get.  The writing is consistently very good and there are plenty of worked examples mixed into the body of the text.  This book does go deeper than the average non-math major biostat text but it does not get lost in proofs and derivations. Rather, it provides a decent in-depth explanation of how things work.  What sets this book apart from others is its solid (pleasantly balanced) introduction to Bayesian thinking.  While most of the book is about traditional frequentest hypothesis testing, the authors do bring Bayesian approaches into play in several chapters.The book is showing its age.  It is missing discussions on how to deal with the huge data problems associated with modern medical records.  It is also missing a web supplement showing how to do the statistics with programming languages like SAS/R/STATA or general purpose tools like Python.  Happily, it is easy to take the worked examples in the book and feed the data into analysis software to see which of the algorithms a package is using.Overall, this is my favorite biostat book for non-math-majors who want to go deeper into how statistics work.

Fans of the Baldur's Gate franchise rejoice because the folks at Obsidian have come through with the best isometric Role Playing Game  in a decade.  PoE plays essentially the same as Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale or Torment.  That is, you play it in real time by moving characters around the screen, which show outdoor worlds, buildings, caves, etc (rendered in an isometric view like Diablo 1, 2, 3).  Movement choices and conversations are controlled with clicks. You can use AI during easy combat or you can pause to micromanage your characters during difficult fights.  The big difference betwen PoE and the classic iRPGs is that PoE has been rendered for modern hardware so the backgrounds and animation are absolutely gorgeous.The game grows slowly so even if you have not played BG or its children it will be easy to pick this up.Combat is smooth an easy to figure out.  There are some places where it could be improved.  In particular if you are not moving your characters one at a time the AI can leave one of your characters blocking a doorway in a fight (basically wiping the party).Like the classic iRPGs there is some voice acting mixed into the game but you will spend a lot of time reading.The plot supporting PoE is competent but not impressive.  However, the writing which supports the story line is absolutely brilliant.  I have been playing games for decades and I can't remember ever thinking "that was a masterful choice of words" when reading dialog.  The prose and occasional poem in PoE are consistently great.  Clearly many extraordinarily talented writers devoted huge hours to this game because even the side stories are impressive.The replay on this game is staggering.  The game world is huge, and the set of choices for how you interact with the world's NPCs is strikingly diverse (going way beyond basic good and evil).  You are given many classes of characters to choose from and specialization choices are vast (and useful).If you have a a couple weeks to lose yourself in a beautiful, well thought through world pick this up.

If you want a LOT of chocolate this bag is a beautiful sight.  The 4+ pound bag is inflated like a pillow to keep the chocolates from being crushed and they arrived perfect and fresh.The only thing to complain about is the price.  It is easy to find 120 oz for the current $30 price tag.  However, the big box retailer which listed the cheaper price had complaints about the chocolate being melted.So, if you need a 4 pounds of chocolate and you want the quality of Amazon's distribution system this is your best bet.

This is a beautiful, easy to set up TV which  has a very limited set of apps.  Going from opening the box, through setup, to working perfectly took less than 5 minutes.  The assembly involves sliding on the base, screwing in 4 screws (no screwdriver included) and plugging in the power cable.  The TV automatically picked up the HDMI line in from my cable box and the automatic onscreen setup instructions were a breeze.  I have an ancient DVD/Video player which works nicely with the RCA plugs on the back of the unit (but that did take a minute or so to find which jacks to use).  Right out of the box, with no tweaking, the picture and sound are excellent.The remote has just the right amount of complexity.  You can easily jump to the apps that ship with the TV and quickly jump to the menu to set the TV in movie mode (or several other color configurations).  The simplicity of this remote is superior to those that shipped with my Samsung TVs (which have way too many buttons).  The stuff which I want is here and the display is not significantly cluttered by buttons that I don't need.There is only one noteworthy downside to the TV and that is the limited set of apps.  While there are plenty of jacks to set up streaming/casting to the TV, the TV itself does not have a library of apps to choose from.  So, unlike Samsung Smart TVs which have many, here you are basically stuck with what the box ships with.  For example if you want to watch the mlb.tv app you can't.  Instead you need to stream from another device or mess with the built in web browser (which is actually surprisingly responsive).Overall this is a great, well priced TV which is ideal for someone who craves simplicity.

Season 2 of Alphas expands and improves on the first.  New interesting heroes and villains are introduced and the existing characters grow.  The writing is consistent with the first season but the acting is frequently better.  The only real problem here is that there should have been a third season...

Alphas is a fun twist on the superhero motif.  The heros here have super human powers but no silly outfits and less over the top action than the typical comic book hero.  As expected for the genre, the heros fight against bad-guys who also have super human skills.  The characters have prominent flaws which are at times annoying but the flaws do  allow the cast to show off some very good acting skills.  Alphas is good, not campy, fun.

This is a good, no nonsense, supplement for people who are learning human anatomy and physiology.  Because I am a biostatistician, who does predictive modeling in medicine, I am forever needing to learn physiology to understand the projects I work on.  I picked this up to help.  The material on the area I know particularly well (neuroscience) is reasonably complete, accurate and useful.  The chapter covering the material I am currently learning, kidney function, is very good but not ideal.This book is written to supplement a textbook.  So, it is not as complete as I would have liked.  Specifically, there are excellent text descriptions of all kinds of things but the labeled diagrams that go with them are no always in the book.  Frequently the labeling of key pictures are left for exercises (with solutions).  That means that most everything is here but  you can't read this like a textbook and learn the material.  The reader without a solid textbook will have to scrounge on the web for diagrams (or look at the answer key).If your goal is to supplement your human anatomy/physiology textbook and/or to get additional test questions, this is an excellent buy.

If you are just starting out with SAS or if you are a guru, there is so much that you will like in this book.  I have been using ODS since SAS 7.  So, I know my way around but I often mind myself thinking there has to be an easier way (especially when dealing with Excel).  Everything here is practical.  The book begins with very basic things like controlling multiple output destinations and then it moves into tricks everybody needs to know (like how to temporarily stop writing to an output destination) and then into fancier voodoo to help make good looking output in any format.  Every chapter has stuff that I remember looking up and tricks that I have been meaning to lookup forever (like how to color code and italicize single key words in SAS output titles).  The chapter on Excel, which led me to get the book does not disappoint.  It has great coverage of the different ways of writing to Excel (with advice on the strengths of each) and it covers tricks that I needed (like how to keep zero padded values for medical record numbers).  If you want to impress people with beautiful reports this book is a must.

Where I live in Southern Utah, we are blessed with hiking trails literally everywhere. More than any place I've ever lived or even visited for that matter. Not that you need hiking trails to use a good water bottle, but I'm just illustrating why I chose to order this one. I've been using a plastic, insulated bottle which also has a built-in mister--which on these hot Southern Utah summers comes in quite handy. Unfortunately, even though "insulated" the water tends to warm up much faster than I would like. As in MUCH faster. My hope with the Contigo was to find something that would--if nothing else--provide a cooler environment for my water even on hot days.I was NOT disappointed. First off, its a nice size and the promise of a non-leaking lid is 100% Right On. Nice change of pace from the plastic bottle I mentioned before which, as it would get warmer, tend to leak, almost too much, regardless of how tight the lid was. I wish the bottle could hold a few more ounces of water, but I'm not going to complain too badly. I'll just need to buy another one if my hike's go farther I guess.Does the water stay chilled? YES--for the most part. On extremely hot days, you'll notice that the water will warm up, but nowhere as fast as in a plastic bottle or something entirely non-insulated. Let's face it: aluminum helps keep things cold better than plastic. It just does. I like how it is manufactured so that regardless of how cold the water is, the surface temp on the outside won't freeze your hand, which was a problem with another bottle I used recently. I left my bottle in my car overnight and when I got to it in the morning, even with the sun directly on it and quite warm to the touch, the water inside remained fairly chilled, which is just how I want it. I imagine it would work nearly as well keeping warm liquid warm, but I don't use my water bottles for that so I cannot offer an opinion regarding that, sorry.I DO have one small--but potentially very annoying issue--that I think is quite important to note before using your bottle. It was quite by accident that I looked INSIDE the bottle before using it. I'm rather glad I did. There was an additional information pamphlet regarding the bottle stuffed inside in such a way that it did NOT want to come out, even with needle nose pliers. I ended up getting it out in pieces, which made reading the material afterwards a bit challenging I must say. I just wish the pamphlet was placed almost anywhere BUT inside it. Bad form, Contigo. STOP doing that. Like NOW. I still like the bottle enough to give it 5 stars though, which should give you an idea of how much I like it. I think anyone would find this to be a wonderful water bottle--especially if they can deal with getting that paper out of the bottle before using...

Okay, yes the case looks great. It fits my S6 Edge+ wonderfully. My basic issue with phones today is that they manufacture many that are way too slick on the surfaces and/or the bezels are so slippery that holding the actual phone can be an exercise in holding tight otherwise the device will definitely reaching the floor soon. The Edge+ is without a doubt, THE coolest, well-made phone on the market as I write this (IMO). It is absolutely, positively well-manufactured and a world of difference from what we've seen Samsung make in the past, especially comparing it to the S5. With that new design comes what some would consider a deal breaker, the device is shockingly slippery in the hand. Much more so than the regular S6 due to the super slim bezels. For me, owning a case is a no-brainer, and this phone needs one more than most simply just to hold on to without fear of it falling from your grip.With that said, this case is AS slippery or more so than the actual phone by itself without a case. Again, it fit well and snapped on quickly and surely. However, the surface is SO slick itself, that I almost immediately dropped my phone after placing it in the case due to slippage. In MY personal opinion. that is a key design flaw which dropped it to 3 stars. Had it been easier and no nearly as slick and slippery, I would gladly have given it the full 5 stars. I don't want to increase my odd's of dropping my phone because OF the case I have it in...but unfortunately, that is exactly what happened. I kept it on for the better part of a day on the off chance that after getting a bit more used to it I'd figure out some trick to holding it differently, or better in order to not worry as much about dropping, but after the 9th time nearly hitting the concrete I just pulled it off altogether.If you have a grip which allows you to hold this better, kudos and maybe you'll love this case...but unless my hands were very sweaty, I found that holding my phone was more of an adventure in juggling than anything else.

All I can say is, WOW. Not only does the UAG case stand out with fairly unique looking design, but it just FEELS solid, too--all without adding major bulk to a very trim phone. The back is genuinely cool looking in my opinion and the clear color shows off the gold tint of my phone rather nicely.Button placement is spot-on. The phone by itself is slippery in a way that is almost ridiculous. The trade off for the new design for Samsung is a device that is as easily dropped as you are likely to find anywhere. I've always believed that a case is pretty much a required purchase for your smart phone no matter HOW careful you think you are. Sooner or later its gonna drop. Whether by you or someone else mishandling it. I guarantee it WILL happen eventually. Protecting your investment is not only wise, its downright critical. Why take the chance?The UAG Case is just about the best case for a phone I believe I have ever tried. Great protection for not a lot of money and best of all, it does all of that without adding unnecessary bulk to your phone. This Case is definitely a win-win investment if you ask me. I couldn't be happier with mine.

The honest truth is these are great...however, the included chalk tended to literally scratch the heck out of the actual planner. Like ridiculously so, which I found to be not only frustrating, but a little upsetting, too. I mean these were sold as writable wall planners (which they are) but the chalk provided actually tended to scratch and nearly ruin the actual vinyl.With that said, I gave them to a teacher I know who managed to use them for a myriad of other creative uses, mostly for decorations. But please keep in mind the scratching tendency before making your purchase. If they make chalk that is less likely to mess up the surface of the vinyl, you would be wise to invest in purchasing a lot of--but the chalk that it came with? Umm, no. I'd avoid using it for that particular purpose I'm afraid.Sorry. I really wanted to like it, too.

I was absolutely convinced that this would be compatible with using my bluetooth mp3 player when I selected it. As it turns out, it wasn't. However, does it work as advertised? Absolutely. I know better than to order without reading very carefully what the product can and cannot do, so that was MY bad clearly.My problem stems from the fact that I do not use my phone to listen to music. Period. I have mp3 players for that. However, I know a lot of folks DO use it for exactly that, and for this reason (and one other) I think it is actually quite convenient. It also qualifies as a very nifty tool for speaking to those who call you while on the road. If this is something you deal with regularly and if you find it difficult or maybe even nearly impossible to make out a conversation while driving, this device can literally be a life saver. Pump it through your speakers and never have difficulty again (provided your signal is good, of course).If you are searching for just such a device, I highly recommend this.

Let's be honest, complaining about how long it takes to fumble and attach a cord to charge your smartphone these days qualifies as a weak reason to moan when taking the world into perspective these days, am I right? Talk about first world problems. Plus having to worry about getting that darned Micro USB turned the right direction in the dark...? That's just shy of impossible as I think we all know. However, with that said, just sitting your phone down at night regardless of how dark it is, man is it hard to beat that for sheer convenience.Sure, its lazy to complain otherwise, I recognize that. I really do. Even so, I am over the moon happy to not have to worry about that plugging in thing so much. Plus, they have definitely come a long way in making it a lot faster to charge than those first generation wireless charging ports used to be. Do they equal plugging directly into the wall yet? No...especially when you have a device like I do that supports fast charging (Galaxy S6 Edge+). But for those times when you just place your phone down, man is it EVER a sweet convenience.The charger itself is pretty compact. It measures about 4" in diameter and another great plus is that when you set your phone down, a tiny, soft light encircling the charger lights up to tell you that its charging. Its a small--but VERY welcome convenience I must say. Setting it up was genuinely as simple as you can get. Take the included Micro USB charger, plug it into your computer (or wall charger) and then set your phone down. The should have an entire ad campaign surrounding me, "So easy even JEFF can do it!". Trust me, that ought to carry more weight than you realize. All in all, its small, ridiculously simple and works like a charm. I couldn't be happier with it.

My granddaughter loves Sponge Bob. Just loves him. This gift was a no-brainer for those little toddlers who enjoy and love Mr Square Pants as my little princess does. Playing was second nature for her when she saw what it was, she didn't even want help setting it up. We opened up the packaging and kind of left her to do what she wanted and within hardly any time at all she had it all set up as though she had read instructions. I must say she's a bright little girl, but it helps that its all pretty self explanatory.The toy is really simple and that is also part of its appeal. No need to complicate a child's imagination by forcing them to follow a specific plan of this or that, just set up the stuff and let the child's imagination go wild--which is exactly what happened here. I couldn't have been more pleased at her reaction and her pure thrills at seeing the box as she pulled off the wrapping was priceless in ways I can hardly express.GREAT present for a young toddler. Couldn't be more happy with it.

Got this for my Grandson who just turned 3. Not entirely sure exactly all that it can do but the look on that little guy's face when he opened up the box was over the moon excitement. For the typical little tyke, one of the biggest things they look for is, well, for a large gift. They associate all too often that large box equals better present, and we all know that isn't necessarily the case...but it certainly was with the Spinnyos.It wasn't too difficult to piece together and the assembly took hardly no time at all. Before long my little buddy was absolutely alive with excitement and thrills. It didn't take him long to master it and was even better than us old farts in short order.When it comes to stuff like this, all I have to say is this: the toy did its job, the child was beyond excited and loved every second he played with it. What more can you say?

I must admit, I do not own a GoPro, so I was reluctant to order this, but I was wrong--you don't need a GoPro in order to fully appreciate this incredibly diverse backpack, TRUST me.First off, the product is manufactured really well. In fact, impressively so. You could tell right away this was made to last. The additional smaller package was a nice touch, too and I must admit I wasn't expecting it. If you are one to bring gadgets of virtually ANY kind along with you places, you need to seriously consider the Lowepro backpack. It offers more nooks & crannies and small and large places to store almost anything you can possibly think of. Now I feel compelled to point out that there are scores of small to medium-sized places to store your gear, but no really large space as you might find in a typical backpack. This is specifically designed for smaller items to store, not bigger ones. I wouldn't buy this for your kid for school, but if they enjoy using a GoPro or maybe photography in general, you will be utterly amazed at how convenient this particular case will be.I use mine for hiking minor trips that don't require much gear, but what I DO pack, it handles quite well. The partitioned off area's are basically up to your imagination what you'll be able to use it for. Its really quite remarkably versatile.

More like 3 1/2 stars...truth is, there is a lot to like with these bluetooth earbuds. Seriously. Their range exceeds several more expensive models I've tried. The style is pretty much second to none. The charging port is on the speaker stem a few inches below the bud that fits into your left ear (which I personally believe is MUCH better than charging these earbuds via a port located ON the actual earbud itself. Oh, and the built-in magnet feature? Now that is something I wish all bluetooth earbuds came with.So, with all of that said, why am I shorting this a star and a half? Quite simply the audio quality. They were better than an earlier pair which included the magnet feature that I reviewed a few months back, but the honest truth is the audio quality was just so so. It got loud, plenty loud, but the bass, while present, was just simply nowhere near what it needs to be. I understand that fitting all of that into a small package is easier said than done, but it CAN be done.I found that they never fit into my ear canal very well either. I tried multiple different sized plugs that came included, which was nice, but they all seemed to slowly fall out after walking a block or less. Trust me, that became insufferably difficult after my 4th mile and just plain annoying. My ears certainly aren't the same as everyone else's, so these very well may fit you perfectly.In short, there is a lot to like about these earbuds. Everything from the packaging (which really was first rate) on down was done very well, and better in fact than I've seen in quite some time. I just had a difficult time with the decent, but essentially not quite up to par audio quality. That was my biggest concern, as it is for many. If having superior sound quality isn't your top priority, these could very well be the earbuds for you.

I owned (briefly) the original Galaxy Note several years back when I worked in between gigs for an AT&T authorized retailer. At first I wasn't sure if I'd like such a large phone, but man did I ever come around. I haven't purchased a phone with less than a 5" screen since. I'm not going back. As phones become more and more capable, the reasons for larger screens become more apparent, and nobody makes screens better than Samsung. NOBODY.First off, I went back and forth over whether or not I wanted the Note 5 vs the Edge + for quite some time. I finally settled on the Edge simply for the "wow" factor, for which this phone has LOADS. The gold edition is just wicked cool. The build quality equals anything iPhones have ever manufactured. I'll stipulate that iPhones have always done a great job of build quality. But I don't dislike plastics on a phone either. What I want more than a super sleek device which "looks" nice is one that will actually do what I want it to do. While working for AT&T, almost daily we had iPhone 4 and 4S phones come in with cracked screens. It seemed to be the most prone to those types of issues of any device ever manufactured at that point (the Nexus 4 wasn't far behind for ease of breaking, too). I'm sure the Edge is better manufactured than either of those, but still, it isn't impervious to accidents, so a case is absolutely critical no matter WHICH smart phone you buy. I went with the Tech 21 case that is a dirty, almost see-thru, which covers up the majority of the gold, but you gotta sacrifice a little if you want to protect your new product from the eventual spills it will take at some point no matter how careful you may be.No phone is perfect, and the Edge + is no different. Picking it up with the super slim bezels on the side can be tricky, but you get used to it. Those who have a major issue with this need to get over it. You bought a phone that has a pretty nifty feature that allows for just this kind of thing, deal with it. Coming from the LG G3 this phone is about the same width, but noticeably taller. I became rather adept at learning to use it one-handed after some initial period of figuring it out, so it isn't that big of a deal for me, after all, I knew what I was getting into. However, if you are coming from a phone with a screen smaller than 5" you're going to want to go into a store and handle one in person FIRST, because if you have tiny hands, this is going to be akin to operate a 7" tablet for many. Be aware of what you are getting first so you don't have any surprises after you get home and become frustrated that your new purchase is too damn big.The screen is magnificent. That's all there is to it. I've heard and watched all the YouTube videos touting this or that and how the iPhone 6+ has a higher brightness scale or whatnot, but in the end, what matters is what you SEE with your own eyes. This screen is amazing, pure and simple. Over 100 pixels per inch MORE than the iPhone 6+, and you can tell. That isn't to say that the iPhone screen isn't great as well, it just doesn't have the "wow" factor that this one does I don't care WHAT anyone says.Let me say I have been disappointed in the battery life right up front. The G3 had impressive battery consumption, especially compared to my older Nexus 4 which had abysmal battery life from the get-go. With all of Samsung's claims about optimization and whatnot with its newer and faster processor, I expected the battery life to be at the very least as good as the older G3. I'm sorry to say it does not. I'd say that the Edge+ is a good 10-15% worse (that isn't scientific mind you, just a guess, but it IS worse I can assure you). On the flip side the quick charging and ability to use wireless charging IS a nice way to side step this issue, but clearly Samsung focused on form over function when it came to this particular model of phone. I keep hearing that Samsung is "possibly" going with a 4K screen within the next year...please, PLEASE don't! You honestly don't NEED a screen with any more than the QHD displays we already have...especially with the battery life we currently have. I haven't spoken with ANYONE who'd sacrifice battery life for screen quality, and I sure hope Samsung is listening. Unless and until they can dramatically increase battery life, going with anything above and beyond QHD is utterly a waste of time IMO.With Samsung's newest chips, I expected the Edge+ to be screamingly fast. In most ways, it is. However when I checked the RAM usage, I was shocked to see that 81% of the RAM--which is 4 freakin' gigs by the way--was being taxed. This is Androids BIGGEST problem in my opinion. How can they NOT make a phone that doesn't automatically turn on apps without you asking it to after all these years? When I close off the apps, I would dearly love them to not use up precious RAM from that point forward til I want to use that app again. I know some apps run in the background for obvious reasons like G-Mail, but I don't need my game of Solitaire to be open and ready at a moments notice now do I? If Android could figure this problem out, no iPhone could ever catch it. But unfortunately that isn't today.In most ways I love the phone. The speaker phone on the bottom is a noticeable improvement over the one on the back of my old G3, and not that it wasn't good, but the placement left a lot to be desired. Front facing is almost ideal, except for the times you have your phone set down face first. On the bottom is about as perfect as you can get without it being covered accidentally because of how you place it down. They copied apple in this, and I agree it was a copy worth making.I'm not a huge fan of TouchWhiz, and I seriously considered not going with this phone specifically for this reason. Yes, I know that since the introduction of the GS6 and the GS6 Edge that its been toned way down, but in my opinion, not nearly enough. Samsung, for all its cool and nifty things that their phones can do that others cannot (and lets be honest, NO phone comes with as many bells and whistles as Samsung crams into theirs, but unfortunately, the vast majority of which are entirely gimmicky at best) still hasn't figured out how to optimize their own OS so their incredible processors have to be so much more powerful than apple's simply to make up for all the glitches it tends to foster. Come ON guys, figure it out. If you optimized your devices even HALF as well as apple does, your phones would slaughter theirs on every conceivable scale known to man. With that said, I'm much happier with this version of TouchWhiz than what I experienced when I had the original Note. Some things are great and intuitive, some are buried so deep in the settings menu's that you almost have to Google How To video's in order to discover what your phone is capable of.One thing I saw before I bought my phone was that the Edge+ had an Auto Restart feature (FINALLY!). Something my 9 year old Blackberry used to have and I used regularly. Unfortunately, the version I have didn't come with it (T-Mobile) and I'm wondering why? Its a feature that Android really ought to put in as standard as it helps to make your device run smoother when you restart your phone on at least a semi regular basis. I gotta say I'm a bit disappointed it was left out of the software on my phone.The Camera is nothing short of stellar. Before I bought my phone I did a ton of research, and it was down to the LG G4 and the Note 5/Edge+ for best Camera on a mobile device...until I saw a quick look at the iPhone 6S and 6S Plus, and they bumped their Camera's up to 13MP and without even TESTING them, the horribly biased reviewer automatically claimed them to be the best new Camera's on the market today. Now I'm not going to say they are or not, but I just find it interesting that without even getting to test one this reviewer online chose the iPhone as the new champ. Sheesh. How stupid. Let's get some hands on experience and THEN make your claims, okay? Until then, the Camera on this phone is wicked fast, takes unbelievable pictures as well as video. I just wish the OIS feature was also there for 4K recording. Since I don't have anything to watch the video on in 4K, I don't even use that feature. I'm big on taking lots of photos, so this was another HUGE selling point for me. Love the new features, too. I'm interested to really try out the Pro and Raw photo abilities to see how it stacks up. VERY excited to see my photos from here on out take a noticeable bump in quality.The fingerprint scanner works--at least so far--flawlessly. I was worried that it would have the glitches of the S5, but I'm happy to say it works, and does so reliably so. I must say it takes a bit to scan your finger into the phone--at first.
