But TRUST me, the reason why is so you can hold your finger even at odd angles or as I've discovered, even sideways and it will still work. Unlike the S5 where you had to slide your finger across, this one you simply hold it in place and it very quickly unlocks the phone. I have seen it open faster, and sometimes slower than the iPhone--but I have also seen this same reaction from the iPhone. But the truth is it always unlocks pretty quickly.One of my few gripes with my old G3 was that you would unlock the phone, but couldn't do a single thing until the Android on-screen keys appeared  FIRST. It didn't bother me--at first--but it just slowly ate at me until the last several months it bugged me horribly. I have since tested the G4 and noticed that the keys appeared much quicker, almost immediately, compared with the G3, which sometimes took as long as 3 seconds. Yes, I know 3 seconds isn't long, but it seemed like an eternity on occasion trust me. The Edge+ has NONE of that lag, though if I'm being honest, I imagine it will show up eventually as I fill up the memory more and more. However, so far I am also happy to report that its as snappy as the first moment I turned it on.Some have made a big deal out of the phone missing the ability to add memory or include a removable battery, and this is either going to be a deal-breaker for some or it won't. While I'm still a bit surprised at the amount of battery consumption for what Samsung claimed was especially optimized to give users as good if not better battery performance as the Note 4--that simply hasn't turned out to be the case. My original Note 1 I personally believe had seriously better battery life. Say what you want, but after nearly 4 years, I expect MORE life, not less out of a flagship device such as this. But with that all aside, iPhones have proven that you don't need a removable battery in order to get through the day. If you're going to go to the trouble of buying a separate battery for some devices, why not just get a couple of decent portable charger/batteries (which cost much less, btw). This way you won't have to power down your device to swap out, and you'll have all the power you need. With the cloud based services available these days, some argue the need for additional memory is moot--but I submit that no matter how convenient that might be, it certainly isn't faster to have to link up to a cloud-based storage location to find a photo, or song then it is when you have it ON your phone already. Plus, what happens if you are in an area with spotty to no service, what then? Too many variables. I just don't see why they couldn't add another drawer on the side or top similarly to where you place the SIM card where you could also add an expansion card. That's my .02. I really think that if Samsung wants to lure a lot of those who stayed away from these new devices simply for those reasons to consider some kind of workaround on the next model if they want to get back to being the market leader like they were a couple years back. Come on, nobody can tell me it can't be done rather simply given what they did to redesign these phones in the first place.Oh yeah, if you so desire, you can actually use your phone as an actual PHONE, which is tremendously convenient to be honest. The ear speaker works great, sounds great and the call quality I found to be good to excellent. The loud speaker was fantastic, but at higher volume sounded a bit scratchy--but that's to be expected from such a smaller speaker no matter what anyone says. Sure, the iPhone's might be clearer at higher volume, which IS a strong selling point if I'm being honest, but I don't use my speaker for anything other than phone conversations, so if you plan on using yours to listen to music, I would strongly reconsider. These phones really shouldn't replace an actual stereo speaker to listen to music on. Your experience may vary however.I think that basically covers it all. I'm sure over the next few weeks I'll come up with a few additional things that will pop into my mind to share, and if they are worthy of note, I'll come and add them on an as needed basis. Otherwise, my summary is this: is the phone perfect? No. Is it great? Absolutely. I love it MUCH more than the G3, which I also loved. If you happen to be an apple fan, stick with what you know and love. Just because I prefer Android doesn't mean iPhone's don't perform admirably. I just prefer Android--issues and all--to what apple does...and their phones are by no means trouble free either. Both have strong points, both have weaknesses. It'll be a long time before a perfect phone comes along, so until then, I personally believe you cannot go wrong if you do your research and buy accordingly. Happy computing!***UPDATE***I must hand it to Samsung for a couple of things, despite the battery issue I talked about earlier, at least the phone has two major--and I DO mean MAJOR advantages over the latest apple devices: fast charging and wireless charging. If you order the special Samsung wireless fast charger it will charge even faster than the typical wireless dock, but honestly, I'm not THAT concerned about it. I'd rather buy 2 or 3 fast charging cables which would save me a bundle. But the point is, the choice is yours...AND its a choice you simply don't get to make, as with so many other things, with the iPhone. The fast charging, I must say, WOW. It really charges quite rapidly. I knew that going into this, but I was still amazed and thrilled with how quick you can boost your battery--but again, ONLY if you use the cord which comes with the Edge+ or if you purchase another cord online, and thankfully, they ARE available. I got a 3rd party wireless charging dock and it works brilliantly with my Edge+. Yes, its darned slow (as almost ALL wireless chargers are) but freakin' convenient I must say.I have noticed that while in a car, answering a call has a distinct disadvantage so far: the ear speaker just doesn't get all that loud in my opinion. I found a way around that by using my ear buds or just placing it on speaker phone. That bottom speaker is mighty impressive I must say. Easily the loudest I've experienced in a mobile phone personally (I'd bet the boom speakers on the HTC models and the newest Nexus probably out perform it handily). VERY impressed with that.I am still super impressed with the screen. And no matter what anyone says, the curved edges garner more attention than the iPhone, period.  Everywhere I go I get comments, many by die hard apple fans, which is no small victory as far as I'm concerned. I just showed a coworker how the camera takes much better pics than his iPhone and even HE admitted they were better--which I didn't think I'd ever hear.One tiny--but significant complaint I have is that on previous androids I had the option of creating a shortcut to dial or text a group of people. All I had to do was tap on their face and voila! I'd go directly into the texting app. For some reason they eliminated this feature with the S6, the S6 Edge and the Edge+. Not sure but I suspect they did away with it on the Note 5, too. So now, it takes an additional 2-3 extra taps to text where it used to only take one. I understand that I can download a 3rd party Launcher and get that feature right back--at least I THINK I could--but doing so would take away all the edge features that admittedly I bought this phone for in the first place. Yes, its minor, but I thought I'd pass that along anyway. I just wish Samsung would give us that option back and let us decide if we want to use it or not.The camera is just unbelievably well made. It takes exceptional low-light photos that I've never seen the equal to--at least not on a cell phone anyways. The zoom feature is great, even from far away its ability to focus with the OIS ability is nothing short of phenomenal, MUCH better than my LG G3 camera. If you zoomed in too much, the laser focus simply couldn't handle it. I never took a pic that was zoomed in all the way that came out anything but blurry on my G3. NOT so with the Edge+. Impressed is all I have to say. I WILL add that some features that the phone is capable of using you have to download and are not immediately available ON the device right away, like snapping a photo or video taping with the front & back camera's at the same time. Keep in mind when you touch the 'More' button down by the shutter button, if you see a circle with an arrow pointing downward, that is what you press to access other features that you can download that the phone doesn't come with natively when you first turn it on. FYI.All in all I am not only STILL impressed, but very happy that I went with the Edge+.***UPDATE #2***I mentioned in my initial review how the GS6 Edge+ had a built-in feature that I used to have with my Blackberry which allowed the phone to auto re-start at a pre-determined time but for some reason the T-Mobile version didn't have it...I received an update a couple days ago and on a whim I decided to go check again and VOILA! It was there! It won't allow you to auto re-start it more than once a week, but at least its there. Just one more thing I thought I'd point out that I now love about the Edge+. I wish, however, that this device had the productivity on the Edge feature like the original Note Edge came with, and I must say that I'm a little mystified as to why it didn't come available right out of the box like that, but I'm still unlocking new and improved features of my phone almost daily. If/when I come up with any that are truly ground breaking I'll try and remember to update this review accordingly.

First off, these are not Noise Cancelling. I looked all over the box they came with and inspected the earbuds closely and they just aren't. They might be Noise Isolating, which is similar, but NOT the same, but certainly they aren't Noise Cancelling, so please be aware of that up front.Range and charging was convenient. The charging port was located on the mini volume rocker located several inches away from the actual earbuds themselves, which I thought was novel and way more convenient than the sweat resistant bluetooth earbuds I've reviewed of late which has the charging port on the actual earbud itself and is slightly a pain to pull out the rubber stopper in order to charge. You take the good with the bad, right? These fit well and comfortable too, which was a nice touch, too. I noticed not everyone felt the same way, but I have to say they fit me quite well, and even had the correct size rubber ear buds attached so I didn't have to remove them and try a different size.My only major concern was the sound quality. It was decent, but was mostly the highs and mids with very little bass to speak of. Now I'm not looking for a bass-driving pair of earbuds that artificially enhance the bass of everything I listen to (beats does this), but I DO like there to be great range of lows to compliment the mids and highs. Unfortunately these didn't have that in my opinion. 25 years in radio has shown me what that really sounds like, so I'm not speaking entirely from a position of no experience. I KNOW what good sound is, and this was okay at best. Sorry. I really wanted to like them more, too. Oh well. I was asked to give a fair and honest review, and this is what I personally think and believe.

I like to protect my investment. There is probably nothing I use daily more than my phone--and the same is probably true of most people. Since you generally buy them at a discount in exchange for signing a contract or something similar, its hard to remember sometimes that to buy them brand new would run you north of $600 in most circumstances (especially for flagship model cell phones). It stands to reason that no matter how careful you are, sooner or later you're going to drop your device. Its not really a question of IF, but WHEN. Doesn't it make sense to protect your phone  as best as you can?The case for my LG G3 is stylish and fairly thin considering its durability. The back is a mass of raised bulbs which act as shock absorbers for that eventual tumble it will most likely take at some point. The back feels a bit rough in your hand I must admit, but it isn't so annoying that I cannot see the advantages far outweigh any disadvantages. I think it'd be great if those raised bulbs had been much softer, but I'm not sure if that is more of a wish or in doing so it would make the case less capable or not. In particular I like the built-in stand that comes with this one. I've always thought that was a fantastic idea, and especially when watching media/videos and whatnot. Very convenient and they did it without adding too much bulk, too. I have noticed however that because of the case, the charging port is not as easily accessible as it used to be with the previous case I had. This may or may not be a deal breaker for you, so I recommend you make your choice wisely and with the most information possible so you wont' be surprised once you pop it onto your G3.Over all I am very satisfied and happy with my case, but is it perfect? No. Not yet. But close.

I have been fortunate to have been given access to several different styles and kinds of bluetooth earbuds in the last 6-9 months and most were very good--especially considering what they cost, a couple were okay, and one in particular was abysmal. This came as a bit of a surprise since almost all of these I tested were quite economically priced, proving once and for all you don't have to fork over large sums of money to get a quality, well-made and most importantly, great-sounding set of earbuds that also happen to be wireless. So, for those of you in the market for good quality but with limited budgets, the good news is you CAN find great bluetooth earbuds if you're willing to do your research.I'm happy to point out now that the QCY earbuds are now my favorite of all that I have tested so far. In all fairness, they are slightly larger than the previous models, but don't let that bother you. They pair easy. They are comfortable to wear as they come with additional ear plugs to adjust to your size ear etc and another piece of good news: they stay put quite well. The cord isn't too long or too short as some seem to be one or the other as of late. They hold a great charge for many hours (although I couldn't tell you if the claim of continuous playback of close to 9 hours is accurate or not since I've only used mine for just over 2 hours straight) and are even sweatproof, making that yet another wonderful selling point for those who plan to use them while actively exercising.However...best of all: they sound GREAT. I found that while they aren't Noise Cancelling, they certainly worked incredibly well to almost eliminate the vast majority of outside interference by fitting in my ear SO well that 98% of everything I heard was what I wanted to hear. In my book that is a downright miracle for a product that is only Noise Isolating and not Noise Cancelling (they are entirely 2 different--but similar things). Great highs, wonderful bass--but not too much. Fantastic volume and I particularly like when turning it on you can hear a voice say, "Power On" or "Power Off" when turning on/off respectively. Yet another fantastic point is that you can also use it to answer calls on your phone. Talk about ultra convenient. Simply put, I cannot recommend the QCY earbuds enough--ESPECIALLY when you factor how little they cost. I would put their quality, sound and convenience on par with bluetooth earbuds which cost 3 times the price easy. If you're looking for a winner, my top pick for those on a budget would be these hands down.

I got this for my grandson who turned 3, and he is ALL boy. The look on his face when he saw this was beyond priceless. The big task was trying to keep him off it while it was assembled--which goes together rather well and pretty easy. As another reviewer noted, the seat doesn't lock into place as well as I would have liked, but for the price, I must say, this is an exceptional buy.The track appears to be rather sturdy, but as with most things, only time will tell whether it can weather the storm of a 3 year old little boy, right? It doesn't go quite as fast as a bigger toddler may like, but for my little 3 year old, it is plenty, and maybe even slightly too fast if that makes any sense? He's such a thrill-a-minute little stinker that I doubt he has any clue to his own mortality, so the top speed is plenty for this little tyke.Let me just add the one major thing which makes presenting a toy such as this to a child: the look on their face when they see it is worth it all, trust me. His pure joy was something to behold, and is the major reason why I would not only encourage you to buy this, but happily so. I sincerely doubt you'll be disappointed. Winner all the way around.

I've been waiting for a mighty long time for Jack DuBrul to come back to Phillip Mercer, a character I would put up with Dirk Pitt or most other action adventure characters you can find in print. It was nice when Jack took over writing some of the Oregon Files novels with Cussler, but I always wanted him to get back to writing his own original novels. My wait seemed forever--but oh so worth it.Mercer Is Back, baby! And better than ever. His geologic background is in prime focus as he witnesses the murder of a good friend and some colleagues and immediately sets out on revenge to put things right. Along the way we find out more about the Lightning Stones, and their connection to one of the most famous pilots of all-time (appearing in a wonderful prologue). Along the way we have a healthy dose of amazing action, adventure and loads of information about everything from geology to weapons. Its a wealth of information that proves that not only is Phillip back where he belongs, DuBrul has honed his exceptional writing style and talent and has only become better...and The Lightning Stones only serves to prove that.Welcome back Phil. We've missed you. I only hope we don't have to wait as long to read about you again.

I love all things audio--always have. Its one of the reasons I've been in the broadcasting business for the last 25 years (and counting). The honest truth is, I know what sounds good and what doesn't. But, I have also come to realize that with most things in life, there are many opposing opinions regarding earbuds, headphones and whatnot--else, why would people continue to pay outrageously stupid high prices for Beats headphones despite the fact that they are mediocre--at BEST? I have a couple theories: first, they don't really know what great sound really is, and only bought them because its the "IN" thing to do and wanted to fit in with the crowd, or second, people talk up the great sound simply because they feel the desperate need justify having spent so much on what clearly are about the most overrated headphones available on the market today...and possibly 3, they genuinely believe that they are good and worth the money (I can assure you, along with the incredible number of studies done and available on the web which prove beyond a doubt they most certainly are not).With that long-winded statement over and done with, let me promise you I have a HUGE amount of experience wearing devices to listen to music...and I DO mean a lot. I wear headphones on average 4-5 HOURS each work day. Most people don't wear them that much in a week. This alone does not make me better at understanding decent sound than anyone else if I'm being honest, but I'd like to THINK it does since audio quality is essentially my life. You can either take my word for it or not--its totally up to you.While lately I've been using mostly bluetooth earbuds (some of which have been exceptional to be honest) but I always fall back on my old tried-and-true plug-in earbuds when I want the absolute best sound possible. My favorites (especially for the money) are the Sony X-Tra bass models, man do they sound great. But if I had to choose a runner-up pair at this point, I'd go with the Panasonic Drops 360. Yesterday I decided to put them through my own personal test: I wore them on a hike in 99 degree temps around traffic. The sound was honestly impressive--very much so considering the price. I've had many earbuds which sounded great, but couldn't play music very loud (which I prefer, especially on hikes & runs) which tended to allow way too much traffic sounds to sneak into the listening experience, thus spoiling it. The Drops were exceptional in this department. Great highs, great lows and impressive bass (again, especially considering their price). Can you find better? Of course, but I doubt you can for cheaper.They also stayed put--which is another extremely important factor for me and I would venture to guess, most of us who wear earbuds. I have tested many earbuds which were great, but ultimately I couldn't recommend simply because they wouldn't stay put when I wore them. Honestly, what good is the audio quality if you are constantly having to adjust them from falling out of your ear? I am thrilled to say the Drops stayed put and never gave me issue on my nearly 4 mile hike.I can honestly say without reservation that these are some of the all-around best earbuds I have ever tested and they are so much more worth what they cost, in short, I am VERY impressed and have zero hesitation recommending them to all. These are simply put: a GREAT BUY PERIOD.

While I am a fan of Ted Bell and Alex Hawke in particular since his first novel, I must say after finishing up "Patriot" I found it to be my least favorite of Alex's exploits so far...and I feel the need to explain that Bell at his worst is still better than most at their best. So yes, its a criticism, but still high praise indeed.ALL of Ted Bell's Hawke novels have, for better or worse, a ring of James Bond to them (and for good reason), but this one was almost a bit too much in my opinion, and by that I mean over-the-top. One of the things I have enjoyed about Hawke's adventures is that while unbelievable, they still had a certain ring of probability that made it all the more realistic while reading. This one? Not so much (again, IMO).Taking on Putin directly certainly paints yet another very current picture as Bell typically does as his novels seem to generally be very 'ripped from the headlines' in its realism--and in some instances, almost prophetic. Does anyone really not believe that Putin isn't much more than a big bully with the power of nuclear arms? Bell captures much of this bravado in fine, adventuristic form and made me excited for what would come next. The results: another winning entry into the Hawke series which are ALL genuinely fun, entertaining techno-thrillers absolutely over-flowing with tremendous action. If you are a big fan of Ted Bell's previous novels, come ON, you KNOW you're gonna read it, the only question is whether or not you get it now or wait til later? My recommendation: go ahead and splurge.

I have been interested in bluetooth earbuds for several years now, and I still recall the very first time I saw a pair of earbuds that had this particular style (which are not unique to SoundPEATS by any stretch). I had never seen anything quite so different and instantly thought, I need to get some of those! Well, it took me longer than I expected, but I finally got some. My experience? Read on...They were simple to set up, charge and pair with my mp3 player & my phone. Honestly, it was super simple. I really appreciated the easy way to pull out the charging plug and get it all powered up. I own several other pair of bluetooth earbuds that are water resistant, and the charging port can be somewhat of a nightmare to pull out just to charge, so this was a great feature I believe. Point SoundPEATS.They fit around my neck comfortably. The actual ear buds themselves have a relatively short cords, but that is by design. On occasion they get caught underneath the frame and it seems like every time I turned my head I felt it pulling against the actual frame around my neck. Easy enough to correct, but keep it in mind. the upper portion of the connecting stem is made of soft rubberized material, and doesn't irritate whatsoever, and as I mentioned above, is comfortable, so another point for SoundPEATS.Quality sound-wise...let's face it: without decent sound what's the point, right? I'm happy to say these delivered pretty good to great audio quality. They don't provide the highest of volume I have seen and experienced before, but thought for the audio quality, it was very sufficient. I also have to remember how affordable these are. Sure you can go much more expensive, but in my opinion (and please note that I work with audio for a living in the broadcasting industry for 25 years), you'd have to pay not just a little, but a LOT more in order to drastically improve the audio quality--again, an important thing to remember.Battery life is rather impressive, too. This is where the Q800 really excels. The frame that fits around your neck automatically can hold (I believe) a larger rechargeable battery, allowing it to hold bigger, longer charges giving you more time in between having to plug it back in. Another point for SoundPEATS.Now you might wonder why I gave it just 4 stars? The truth is this: I prefer the smaller models where they just hang from your ear and the cord goes around your neck, and not to a frame that fits around your neck. Strange, but that is just MY particular preference. For you, it definitely might be different. If that isn't a factor, I say pick these up asap. I am really happy with mine and use them quite frequently, but tend to stick to my other SoundPEATS bluetooth for when I do exercising.

After seeing a preview to the film several weeks back, I instantly figured this would be a movie I was going to see for sure. The entire premise just struck me as utterly compelling. I was unaware of the novel at that time. Saw it at the book store a few days later and picked it up. I read quite a bit that first night. I must say I haven't read a novel this compelling in quite a few years.First off, kudos to Andy Weir for doing his homework. I'm sure preparations to write this was exhaustive and you can tell. The science--at least to me anyway--seems about as real as it gets. There may be a few things discussed that haven't come about just yet--but I would venture to say they are all based in GENUINE science, which is one of the core reasons the novel was so fantastic. Being stranded on Mars, literally and entirely alone, with essentially zero hope of survival, no way to communicate with earth to speak of and supplies that simply cannot last until the next Mars mission (some 4 years away) arrives, how in the WORLD do you overcome this kind of herculean obstacle? In the same way that NASA came together to bring the men of Apollo 13 home safely (seriously, bringing them home after what had happened to their ship was easily a bigger miracle than landing Neil and Buzz on the moon and bringing them back), the world comes together to bring astronaut Mark Watney home from Mars.About 100 pages into the book, I got to wondering how the author was going to handle the day-to-day business of surviving, based on the situation and how many close brushes with death he endures and make it all not just readable, but thoroughly entertaining? I can tell you this: Andy Weir pulls it off in style. Part of that was his careful plotting. Face it, unless you are familiar with the in's and out's of literally going to another planet and what it would take in order to REALLY pull that off, you might be a bit confused at how someone can make all of those sordid details interesting, but boy is it. Everything from making water out of incredibly dangerous hydrazine rocket propellant, how to grow potatoes on Mars when technically it should be entirely impossible to do so and how to traverse great distances on the surface in order to ensure your survival, its all here. As the novel progresses towards the climax, I can say that Mr. Weir notched up the thrills by making it all sound amazingly realistic. Does everything go as planned? Heck no. In fact, Mark Watney nearly kills himself many, many times--some due to his own mistakes, some beyond his control, and it all makes for an incredibly GENUINE experience. Plenty of times I felt like I was reading what actually HAD happened versus a true-to-life sci-fi novel. Yes, the science IS real--even if you don't understand it, the author does a great job of "dumbing it down" in order to better process what is happening and why. At its core, The Martian is a story of incredible tenacity, determination and an amazing will to live by someone who--by all rights--should have died on the lonely surface of another planet. His triumphs as well as his failures all ring true and that is part of what makes this book simply incredible.In short: I LOVED THIS BOOK. I was interested in seeing the movie before, but now I'm downright excited. My only worry now is whether or not they screw it up--as Hollywood does 99 out of a 100 times they adapt an excellent novel into a film. Just FOLLOW the damn story folks, the closer the better. Its what makes the book amazing in the first place. Don't mess with it unless absolutely necessary. In this particular case, the closer they adhere to the story, the more compelling it will be on the big screen, especially the very last 15-20 minutes. Please, PLEASE don't screw it up!

I wanted to like this product--badly. For one, I'm a tech kinda guy, and I collect watches and the like. I used to work (briefly in between jobs) for AT&T and I've been in radio broadcasting for almost 25 years. To say that I "get" tech items may be stretching it, but on the flip side, rare is the product that I buy that I cannot get to work. The iHealth Edge is one such device.Before I go any further, I am willing to admit that the fact that I may have received simply a lemon model. I don't care who you are, every company manufactures a lemon every now and then, and this is quite possibly what I received--however, since I can only review what I actually DID receive and not what I had HOPED it would be, I will do just that.On the surface, the iHealth Edge looks a lot like the Motorola Moto 360 smart watch, just smaller and slightly thinner. The device came with a second band (gray) along with the original (black) and the clasping mechanism isn't exactly my favorite, but it works rather well for what it was designed to do. The screen is, well I'm not entirely certain. I'm getting a bit ahead of myself here. Let me just say that I was never able to get my device to work at all. Not even in the slightest. I read plenty of reviews of the Edge and pretty much expected that I was going to have to figure out on my own how to get it up and running--and this is where my tech experience I mentioned earlier comes into play. Its the only reason I mentioned it to be honest. Thankfully however, a few kind reviewers had actually been able to figure it out long before mine arrived and detailed exactly how to get mine up and running seeing as the included instruction manual--which LOOKS thorough enough, just isn't. I charged my watch until it showed battery was full. I downloaded the free app from the Google Play Store--oh, and by the way, there are TWO iHealth apps to choose from, and nowhere could I see which one I was supposed to download, so I did both on the off chance that one wasn't correct. I think a simple explanation to which you should use with the device you purchase isn't too much to ask now is it? I was able to figure out which one went with the iHealth Edge by the way (no thanks to the instructions that it should have come with), and followed the instructions TO THE LETTER mind you...which is kind of a joke since the instructions don't really explain a heck of a lot. I followed the online instructions that were left by the kind reviewer I mentioned earlier. I KNOW I followed them properly because everything they mentioned happened just as explained, except that my device never once paired with my phone thus enabling me to see ANYTHING but the following on the screen: "Launch App Ver 1.0.1"...well, that isn't entirely true. It showed the code to write down in order to get the watch paired with the app on my phone. Other than that, I got nowhere after 45 minutes of trying over and over and over and...well you get the idea. I visited their official website to troubleshoot the issue. No luck. I googled how to fix my known situation. No luck. So, whether or not the iHealth Edge can do literally ANYTHING it says it can do, I have no clue whatsoever. All I know is I couldn't get the device I had to work properly even in the slightest. And that bugs me, because I really wanted it to work. Dang it!

Let me start off by saying that I grew up with the author. Henry and I go back to--oh, I'm not entirely certain to be honest when we first met--just that it was a long time ago. Aside from one High School reunion, I haven't seen Henry since high school graduation...and if you had asked me all these years later which student I went to school with would eventually self-publish a book about teenage girls playing volleyball--I'm not sure if I would have put Henry at the bottom of the list, but he'd for sure be close.One thing I CAN say is that he is endlessly inventive and this story took me entirely by surprise...and not just the story line--which certainly did I must say. Henry can actually WRITE. His working knowledge of volleyball is pretty obvious, even to a novice such as myself. But it goes much further than that. We get INTO the game, the players, the action and definitely the excitement surrounding this explosive and fast-paced sport. It all goes into the book. The up's, the downs and even the heartache.Year of the Phenoms is a classic feel-good tale that gives you the same excitement you got from watching films like the Karate Kid and the original Rocky. Almost everyone can identify with their school's ________ program and how it didn't necessarily live up to another sports success. In my high school we had a stellar wrestling program year after year, but everything else? Well, we'd be good in football one or two years and then not so much for a couple years and soforth. But what if your school suddenly has not one, but several legitimately talented players all at once in a volleyball program that has, well, struggled to say the least for a VERY long time...? You now have the recipe for excitement as only someone like Henry could bring to the pages.A year ago if you had told me I would read a Young Adult story about a girls volleyball team--and on top of that genuinely LIKE it, hmmm, I really, REALLY doubt that I would've believed you...but that is exactly what happened. I was not just surprised, but thoroughly thrilled that my friend managed to self-publish Year of the Phenoms and I can proudly say that it wasn't just decent, and good but it was downright FUN. What's more is the end promises a sequel! Congrats Henry on putting in the hard work necessary to publish a great read that deserves a spot on the shelves with Harry Potter no less. I've always been happy to say I know you, but now comes my opportunity to brag a little bit, as well.

I cannot stress enough how impressed I am with this little package. I must admit I was quite skeptical--especially after reading several reviews claiming it was crazy loud, especially for its size. Well, let me say this: those who made that claim were absolutely right on. First off, let me start off by my impressions with MPow packaging...its pretty sparse--but well done. No gigantic packaging for such a small speaker with a lot of unnecessary wasted space in the box. Hardly any as a matter of fact. I've seen worse packaging done by much better, well-known electronics. So kudos for a job well done.This is my second MPow device (previously I reviewed my pair of bluetooth earbuds which also were exceptional BTW) and I have to say that this little package kicks some serious hind quarters. Small, water-resistant and with a shocking amount of bass--especially for how small it is. This is my 3rd bluetooth wireless speaker and by far the smallest--but also the best sounding. Not only is the audio pretty crisp and very well balanced (again, VERY impressive considering its tiny size) but it can get crazy loud. This was my impression before I even realized I had it sitting on one of the two built-in speakers. Let me just say if you are looking for a game-changing little unit without forking out the stupid-crazy high prices being charged by beats (all but a colossal waste of money), JBL, BOSE and many others (a lot of which are good, but also much more expensive), I recommend you do some research and see what this little baby can offer you.One more small--but critical and essential thing to mention is that this is also dust and water resistant. Meaning you can bring it into the shower with you, but don't let it get submerged. It isn't water PROOF, just resistant--a minor but very important distinction.In a pinch, not only will this provide audio for you when you need or want it most, but will also substitute for an emergency power bank for your smartphone when you are out of range of your vehicle or a wall socket. It may not get you all the way to full charge, but if you need a little extra juice before you can get to someplace to fully charge your phone, this will do in a pinch. Another pretty nifty little advantage if you ask me. It also comes with a very convenient cord to plug your mp3 player directly in so you can listen to that (or your cell phone) in case you have a device you'd like to listen to but it may not come with bluetooth capabilities like many smaller players these days.The list of reasons to buy this are long and I can't think of any compelling reasons not to--unless you are against buying anything that doesn't come with a well-known brand name on the side and you just absolutely, positively MUST part with way more money than necessary...I say you owe it to yourself to seriously consider the Armor Portable Speaker. You'll thank me later, and so will your pocketbook.

I must say, I did quite a bit of research before making my purchase, so there was very little to surprise me upon opening up my 360 upon its delivery. In fact, the only real surprise was how much more convenient the newest update was after it downloaded than I expected.First off, packaging: very well done, Motorola. I found it to be very well done, inside and out. Nice touch. The device was nowhere as big as I initially expected it to be, even though I had handled the display model at Best Buy multiple times, its entirely different actually strapping it to your wrist. I like big watches, so this did not feel huge, bulky and it certainly wasn't heavy. I own several ABC watches that are significantly larger, so I was pleasantly surprised with how comfortable it felt.Craftsmanship was exactly what I expected. The watch itself looks great. The screen, while not as pixel-dense as some of the competitors out there (including the apple watch), still looks great. It was bright, and in fact, I wish the settings allowed me to turn it even further down than it does. I'm sure it was help battery life considerably...speaking of which, the battery will be a problem IF you don't turn on Theater Mode (new setting which came with the latest update) and turn off the screen after each time you receive an update or when you look at the screen face. I was surprised at the number of texts, emails and facebook updates I received during the course of the day and yet I still had 60% battery life when I left for home from work. I literally look at my watch when and ONLY when I felt necessary, and shut off the screen as quickly as I could after reading or dismissing each notification. For those who let the watch turn off after reaching its time-out limit will see a dramatically different percentage at the end of their work day. I recommend trying this for those who are worried about how quickly the battery can go down. Since my model had the update from the get-go I cannot compare it to how it performed before, but I hear its noticeably better.Some of the things I wish the watch did that it does not include being able to read more of each message I receive, if not all of it. I appreciate how I can dismiss an email on my 360 and it will follow suit on my phone. I had to download a different texting app in order to be able to dismiss those on my watch and have it also be dismissed on my phone. (I use Textra for that in case you were wondering). I also downloaded Light Flow in order to have my watch receive patterned vibrations when receiving texts and emails. I must say the free version works pretty good, too. Not for all messages mind you, but for free, it was more than worth the time setting it up. As I mentioned above, I wish there was a feature that allowed me to turn the brightness up or down however I wanted. I think that alone could add an additional 20% more battery life. Oh, one more thing: I wish that the screen when off the moment I pressed the button instead of staying on an extra second and a half. Minor complaint yes I know, but the more juice I can get out of the battery, the better IMO.When it comes to what it can do? I was both surprised and mildly disappointed. I liked the collection of watch faces, but I quickly found several 3rd party apps which allowed me to increase my watch faces by quite a bit (I even have one that makes my watch look like a round apple watch). The flat-tire at the bottom of the screen is a royal pain, let's be honest. Its a major pain that they went with a light sensor in this manner when I believe pretty much anyone who buys a round faced smart watch would rather have a full screen. However, the watch faces that have black backgrounds mask the flat tire much better than anything with a white or lighter background. When not displaying the actual watch face, I find that I didn't care about it being there at all. Some of the weather updates arrive a bit more often than I would prefer, but I'm pretty sure that changing that is nothing more than a setting I'm just forgetting to search for.I like how I can say "OK Google" and send a text message--however I have noticed that it is much less accurate than using my phone. As in, I use it much less than I probably would were it to work better. Even so, the times I have demonstrated it to UBER Apple fans who I work with, it did (thankfully) work flawlessly and boy were they impressed. They also thought the style and overall look was more impressive than the apple watch telling me specifically they were very disappointed in how cheap the apple watch looked in general. I think that however is in the eye of the beholder. Those who are apple fans will more than likely think their watch is better and soforth. I don't think the apple watch looks bad at all, and the screen is really well done IMO.After the initial set-up and time frame of getting used to what the watch can and cannot do, I must say that it has become much less important than I expected it would become after owning it for several weeks. It IS a conversation starter with many people, and the majority all say it looks great. I happen to use the Matrix screen at the moment and that has never failed to garner a positive comment or two from almost everyone who see's it. But overall, is it more convenient to have it than to not? Well, that is debatable. I genuinely LIKE my Moto 360. It looks nice, it works great and I appreciate all it can do. I can definitely see further and more practical ways in future updates where its usefulness will become much more of a "must have" type of gadget. I DO know that I have caught more text messages that I normally would have missed (some were very important, too) because I take my phone out of my pocket and have to have the volume shut off for work purposes. In this I have been very grateful. But so far, it hasn't become the all-important Must Have product that I thought it would be initially.If Motorola improves just the battery, screen resolution (although increasing the resolution will also adversely affect the battery life as well, and the honest truth is--at least for me anyway--the screen resolution is adequate), improves speech recognition, better vibration--in fact, if it gave vibration patterns to choose from right there would be an improvement, and the ability to read more of the messages received, I believe this will be easily a 5 star device that I would deem a "must have" gadget.

I have struggled to find a convenient, workable phone mount for my car for quite some time that wasn't outrageously expensive, but also capable of holding something slightly larger than a small iPhone. The last several I have purchased came with a sticky substance that would 'secure' my device in place and was supposed to NOT leave a sticky residue. First off, only one relied entirely on the sticky substance...and it worked great--until it got hot one day and suddenly the sticky substance began to adhere to the phone in very inconvenient ways which became VERY difficult to remove. The second simply wouldn't expand beyond the width of a smaller iPhone and the sticky crap started doing the same thing on hot days (I have since discovered they ALL will do this when the temperature becomes very warm to hot). I live in a very warm city--especially in the summer--so these have become literally garbage to me.When the opportunity to review this model became available I jumped at it. FINALLY! A Universal Car Mount that will expand more than enough to fit my phone (or even a Note 4 for that matter) and requires NO sticky crap whatsoever! It fit together easily and simply. I thought for a bit that it might adhere to my dash, but the texture made the seal a bit difficult to achieve, so I just stuck with the window. It worked. PERFECTLY. The two edges are coated in a rubbery substance which closes on the sides of your phone and holds it carefully without the danger of scratching, another added bonus in my opinion. There is a small section which pulls down so you can rest the bottom of your phone for added safety, but I find that I don't use it because the hole underneath doesn't line up with my charging cable, and I find that the sides capture it more than sufficiently, including on un-even surfaces.The adjustability (is that even a word?) is another convenience. It can be manipulated in so many different ways there is certainly one that will work best for your viewing angle.All in all, I am not just satisfied, but I am THRILLED with my Multi-Angle Universal Car Mount. It is manufactured well and convenient to work with and adjust. It is more than capable of handling larger phones, so if you have found difficulty as I have finding a decent mount that will also be able to handle something other than a phone with a miniature screen, this is definitely the car mount for you.
