I must admit, the very first time I saw a 'Selfie Stick' I laughed. Hard. I thought, how silly can you be? I mean REALLY?? But after a few days using my LG G3 phone to make videos for my radio stations facebook page, it suddenly--and shockingly--became apparent that I not only could use one, but they could actually serve a purpose more than what I had initially thought.As I was approached to review this particular selfie stick, I noticed that they were available at the check out counter at a local convenience store, if that gives you any indication of how popular they've become. Set up for the Kinzd was pretty straight forward and simple. It came with a micro USB cord to charge the bluetooth enabled stick and since my phone can take pictures via just saying, "Cheese" or by making a hand gesture, I find that I haven't used the bluetooth ability at all--however, for those who have phones different than mine, I can see where that particular feature would be immensely convenient at the very least.The adjustability (is that even a word?) of the device is also very simple. My phone has a 5.5" screen and it has no problem whatsoever opening up to fit snugly. It will handle even larger and of course, smaller smartphones, too. The articulation of the telescopic end is simple, strong and easy to manipulate under a number of circumstances and will provide a long time of use. The button to operate the bluetooth feature is of course placed conveniently on the handle and makes operation a breeze.All in all, if you're looking for a genuinely simple and versatile selfie stick, look no further, the Kinzd IS the model for you.

When bluetooth speakers first hit store shelves, I was skeptical--at best--that they would turn out to be anything but a small blip in popularity followed quickly by them disappearing. As usual, my ability to predict the future was off only by 99.99%. Based on current technology, bluetooth and NFC powered speakers have become not only the norm, but incredibly popular. This particular model is my second.Let's start off with the Pro's: It lives up to its billing as a rugged little speaker...and it IS smaller than I expected it to be. It's about a third as small as the other model I own. Range is pretty good, too. A lot depends on what you currently use to transmit the audio. I tested it using just my little MotoActv sport watch and it performed flawlessly and had impressive reach. The speaker gets a bit louder than I expected as well, but I noticed at high volume it seemed to be taxing the audio quality a bit too much, so I wouldn't recommend it. I have yet to attempt to use it in the shower, but from what I can tell, it certainly *looks* as thought it would be water resistant enough to use daily. It charges fairly quickly, too and maintains that charge rather well from my real-world experience.Cons: Not a whole lot. My biggest was very little bass registers. The highs are almost too high and tinny, especially at higher volumes, and the lows were virtually nil unless you had the volume somewhere in the middle. Turning the volume up as I mentioned above, tended to show the very real limits of the audio quality.Some have expressed opinions regarding difficulty using the buttons, but I personally did not find that to be an issue. All things considered, if you want a rugged speaker that also can be used in a rather wet environment should expect that some compromises need to be made in order to achieve this. Honestly I didn't think it was a big deal.So in conclusion, for the money--and you can spend your money in a LOT of ways, especially with the expansive number of bluetooth speakers available nowadays, it is very hard to beat what the SE90 offers. I enjoy mine very much and I am considering buying one for my oldest son to use. Think long and hard before spending a lot simply to get a logo on the side of your speaker, and good luck!

For the price--WELL worth it. I have a nice collection of bluetooth earbuds, and the more expensive models don't necessarily sound better or work better than the cheaper ones, so its important to do your research. I have several things I like to judge my earbuds by, namely:Comfort. Do they fit comfortably? Do they stay PUT easily?Sound. Let's be honest, if they don't sound good, comfort is kind of a moot point.Durability. I wear earbuds and headphones (due to my career in radio) arguably more than most people. I like the products I use to last, especially if I like them.I can tell you that the Q2's deliver comfort, they sound pretty good and seem to be very well manufactured. The lows aren't quite as well defined as I would personally like, but then again for what they cost, I am definitely NOT complaining.Can you find better sound for the money? I doubt it. Can you find better earbuds overall? Absolutely--but you'll pay a great deal more, too. For those on a budge who want quality sound, comfort AND durability, the Q2's really should be right up your alley. The carrying case was a very nice touch, too. I also particularly like how they fold up so compactly when not in use. I highly recommend the Q2's as a great way to get the convenience of bluetooth earbuds without having to break the bank. Oh yeah, you can also use them to make calls! Talk about versatility! (although in total honesty, I don't use mine for that).

I never thought about owning a bluetooth speaker before. I own currently 3 pairs of bluetooth earbuds however, and they are of varying quality (the Solememo earbuds are spectacular, though). I had the opportunity to pick this speaker up and haven't looked back. Not only is it relatively small, but charges rather quickly, and what I found impressive was the range of the bluetooth. I haven't tried to see how far it'll reach, but was impressed with the distance I found purely by accident.It can get rather loud, too--especially considering its compact size. I have yet to put it to this particular test, but it claims to have a 10 hour battery when volume is on setting 10. I used it for several hours and the battery was still pumping out at full volume and it only took a very short amount of time to charge back up to full.It was very simple to pair with my phone and my Motoactv Smart Watch (which is where all my music is for bluetooth). It also comes with a handy cord that allows you to play anything off of a mp3 player that doesn't have bluetooth, which I also find VERY convenient.The build-quality is impressive, too. I love the fake leather strip at the top with the volume controls. It just LOOKS cool. The speakers work on both from and back and the sides, so it doesn't matter where you point it, you'll get great sound. I must point out that the bass doesn't seem to be super, over-inflated, so if that is what you're looking for, you might be a little disappointed. I like just regular bass, and for me this little baby ROCKS, literally.I couldn't be happier with my speaker and I think for the money especially, you will be too.

For the money, the Clip Sport is a great little device. There are some things I wish were different compared to my old Sansa Clip, but I'm not complaining. I have a great little mp3 player that holds a lot of music, is easy to add more memory to and plays what I want it to. Honestly, I'm not sure what else I'd want, except for a better, more intuitive equalizer. Other than that, I think I'm pretty much thrilled with what this little baby gives me.If you want dozens of additional options, you can get them, but at a cost in different devices. These days if you buy a device like this and don't read up on it (like here on amazon) and it doesn't have a particular feature you were desperate to have, honestly I think the fault is your own. Mine works great. I'm very satisfied.

Bluetooth wireless earbuds have come a LONG way in a relatively short amount of time, and for the second time in a week, I'm writing a review of bluetooth earbuds that have impressed me on a HUGE level. I work in radio and I have been associated with audio for 23+ years now and I know what good sound is (not that you wouldn't), and I know the difference between "good" and "exceptional" audio quality. I've used a TON of different brands over the years and some tend to always give great quality (Sony, Sennheiser, Bose) and some are hit and miss (Phillips, Sanyo, Beats, JBL). If you type in bluetooth earbuds at amazon your choices are seemingly endless--meaning competition is incredibly fierce, which I honestly think is a great thing for the consumers. The only real problem is weeding through the so-so products to get to the decent stuff actually worth the price tag.If you're looking for wireless convenience in an earbud, and want to enjoy great sound without breaking your bank, look no further than the Mpow Swift earbuds. Seriously. Before a couple weeks ago I had never even heard of the company, 'Mpow' and yet here I am singing their praises. Let me explain why...PACKAGING--pretty minimalist here, but that doesn't mean cheap. I was impressed that it didn't take a gigantic box to pack what I received. I got what I ordered and nothing more. It was packaged nicely and professionally. I like that. I am not a fan of opening up a package and leaflets for virtually every product the company has ever produced in history also comes falling out.INITIAL IMPRESSION--Great. The earbuds look even better in person in my opinion. They also come with an impressive number of attachments to help insure that they not only fit comfortably, but securely so. Once again, I'm impressed--especially considering how small the overall package is.PAIRING--as technology improves, so does this particular issue which used to be a serious problem with so many bluetooth devices I've used in the past. The Swift paired quickly, and simply with my Motoactv Smartwatch. Within less than a minute I was linked and listening to music.SOUND--now this is a tricky area which is up for some major debates. Again, having been in broadcasting for more than 2 decades, I'm pretty familiar with poor, good, great and exceptional audio quality. Personally I enjoy good bass--but not at the expense of decent mid's and highs. The Swift provides I believe between good and great audio without much bass whatsoever. Yes, I missed the additional bass, but again, when you factor in the price of these earbuds, honestly, you simply cannot beat the audio quality.COMFORT--as others have noted, the inclusion of so many attachments to help with the comfort means it may take a bit in order to add the one which works best for you, but I encourage you to take the time to find the one that works best as you'll be immeasurably grateful later on. Wearing devices such as these for long periods of time can either be a pain or a pleasure. The Swifts can be both--depending on what you're willing to do. Its pretty much up to you.BUILD QUALITY--I was VERY impressed with how well the Swift not only looks, but how well it was manufactured. They are actually made very well indeed and seem on par with some rather expensive earbuds I've worn over the years. They don't seem like they're going to fall apart at any given moment (my previous Sanyo's) and feel every bit as quality made as my Sony's and the Beats earbuds (the only thing with the letter 'b' on the side I'll endorse).CONCLUSION--for the price, seriously, you cannot find better in the world of wireless bluetooth earbuds. The sound quality was pretty good, too--not exceptional mind you and virtually no real major bass, but then again if you know what to expect, you may find them even more impressive than I do--and I found them to be very much worth every penny.

Great product all around. These bluetooth earbuds/phones (not sure what you would classify these since they fit around your ears and not just IN them, earphones...?) are remarkably simple to operate, and paired quickly to my bluetooth Motorola Motoactv GPS mp3 sportwatch. I haven't had any issues with how far the devices will work since I wear both at the same time.The packaging was straightforward. I'll admit upon examining the earpieces, I was a bit skeptical that they would fit as well as they did. The actual part that goes into your ear seemed bent too far backwards to fit naturally, but I am happy to say they fit rather well and most notably, comfortable too. I also know that each persons ears are slightly different than everyone else's, so your experience may vary. The portion which fits around your ears to hold them onto your ear is flexible and will mold easily without worry of going back to the original shape, at least in my experience. The charging cords were simple and easy to figure out even without the owners manual which explained everything rather well. I like how the charging cable (provided) has two separate cords to charge both earpieces simultaneously.Okay...sound. Is it any good? Well, yes & no. Again, keep in mind what these cost and you'll be truly amazed. If you're looking to compare them with Bose, Sony, JVC, Sennheiser etc. The convenience of bluetooth 4.0 (which really DOES make a difference) and a strong connection which allows for the music to flow much better without the occasional song getting clipped due to poor reception truly IS very nice. The fact that you can buy these for UNDER $40 makes all of that convenience even more remarkable in my opinion. The Solememo earphones delivers fair sound quality without a ton of bass or treble. If you are a fierce audiophile looking for deeper low's, mid's and high's you'll probably want to skip these. If you are happy with the earbuds that come with your mp3 player, then you'll be ecstatic over what these can and do deliver.I haven't as yet had the chance to test the length at which the charge lasts, so I cannot yet comment on how long you can listen without needing to recharge, but hopefully I'll be able to come back soon and add that to my review.All in all what I CAN say is that these wireless earphones work--they work really well and even though sound quality isn't what you can get for $100, it IS about the best you can expect, especially for how economical the price is. Would I recommend them? Absolutely without question.

Wow, I'm impressed. Seriously. For the cost, I don't think you can do better than the Tudia protective case for the LG G3. It fits great, it feels good in my hand and like it says, is relatively thin, considering how tiny the G3 is (especially comparing it to similar sized smartphones). One thing I was worried about was how the case would actually "feel" and by that I mean whether it would be like similar cases made from silicone that are SO rubbery, that pulling it out of your pocket many times pulled your entire pocket inside out because of how the texture tended to adhere itself to your clothing. I am thrilled to say the Tudia is a more cleaner finish and smooth to the touch compared to what I just mentioned. No issues there at all.All in all I am VERY satisfied--again, especially for what this product cost. Honestly, I don't think you can go wrong. My previous Tech21 case was great and worked wonderful, but it attracted dirt like nothing I've ever seen before. I tried to clean it many times, a few using a hard bristled brush I typically use to clean my dishes with and had ZERO success. Once that baby is dirty, its not ever gettin' clean I'm afraid.Oh, and one more thing: this is my first white finished phone and I always felt sad that the only other case I found at the phone store where I purchased it (also, for more than 3 TIMES the price of the Tudia) was blue and it covered up the color of my phones natural cool white color. This model is a cool whitish-clear color which still shows off how great the phone looks. Again--VERY happy.Kudos to Tudia for a great case that is incredibly inexpensive, too!

Let me start off by saying that I work in broadcasting (radio) and I am an avid collector of headphones and earbuds. I've used expensive and the cheap, and by and large, aside from death and taxes, what I've found to be pretty much an absolute is that Sony makes fantastic products. Period.My professional studio monitor headphones are Sony's (MDR-7506's) and they are pretty much the industry standard. I've used Power Beats earbuds (which are the ONLY things by beats that I will actually endorse) and I've used fairly cheap Phillips earbuds and been remarkably surprised at their quality vs actual cost. I currently have 2 pairs of Sony earbuds, one pair was relatively inexpensive ($29.99) and provide great quality and audio as well as being great for use on my cell phone for calls. I've owned several noise cancelling earbuds (my personal fav being a Phillips pair that were rather impressive considering how little they cost). However, I have discovered after initially jumping on the Noise Cancelling bandwagon how they simply are not worth the additional cost unless you really do travel a lot on planes (which is why they were created in the first place). Noise Cancellation does NOT make the audio sound better. AT ALL. Let me say that again for those considering buying some: they do NOT make music sound ANY better. ALL they do is help isolate the music when you have a lot of ambient background noise surrounding you (such as on an airplane). Some are better at it than others (see anything with "Bose") but Phillips actually makes some good ones too.All things considered though, you can buy expensive and great sounding earbuds (such as the Power Beats or Bose, Klipsch, Sennheiser etc) or you can get JUST as great audio quality without breaking the bank and buy something like the Sony MDRXB50AP Extra Bass earbuds. It took very little time wearing these to determine they gave me Power Beats audio quality for less than HALF the cost. They were great at noise isolation (not noise cancelling) and boosting the audio levels on my mp3 player  by a pretty hefty amount over even my regular Sony earbuds--which was very gratifying considering some of the songs I have were recorded at pretty weak levels. They impressively gave a boost to the bass, which I expected, but also were great at the mid's and highs as well--which I did Not expect.I was going to mention how I wish the cords were flat, when it hit me that they ARE flat, just very narrow. Basically this means they won't tangle like many of the cords on earbuds available today. They still CAN tangle, just not as easily. A nice touch by Sony, and for someone who has dealt with tangled cords like I have, I was VERY happy to see this feature. It'll make a difference for you whether you realize it or not.Long story short, if you want exceptional audio quality with added bass (but not TOO much), great highs AND lows with punchy mid's too--look NO further than these. As I mentioned above, they give you truly incredible sound at less than HALF the cost of some other brands which we all know well enough. In other words, why pay more?

What a different novel from an author who is best known for riveting courtroom thrillers. Some authors make the switch between genres and manage to pull it off (Greg Iles comes to mind as one who has done it with incredible finesse), but while Phillip has branched out before, this one is still different than what we've come to expect...and that isn't a bad thing to be sure.If you've read Margolin previously, you're already familiar with his intricate plotting of his mysteries, and this is again on display here as well...just in a much different manner. For one, this is a period piece thriller which takes us back quite a ways. An author sees a photograph appropriately called, 'Woman With A Gun' and becomes quite transfixed with what he sees. It becomes somewhat of an obsession for her. As it turns out, the woman in the photo was a suspect in a murder investigation. Somehow our intrepid author, (Stacey Kim) becomes convinced that either the women's guilt or innocence is somehow connected to the photograph. The resulting investigation opens up much more than Stacey thought possible and unlocks a mystery that is at the core of this tale.Was it as compelling as previous Margolin courtroom dramas? No, not in my opinion. However, it WAS very well told and I deducted a star simply because I wasn't expecting this tale to be anything like it ended up being--which was MY fault entirely to be certain, but hey, this is MY review and I chose to hold Phillip responsible anyway. Call me petty, I don't care. Knowing this in advance may somehow make the story more enjoyable for YOU however, and I hope you rate it accordingly.I must admit however, that I look forward to Mr. Margolin's next thriller in the courtroom, because it is in that environment which he excels at, in fact more so than most writers in this same genre.

What can you say about Jeremy Robinson's Jack Sigler/Chess Team novels...other than they freakin' ROCK. Savage not only helps to put an exclamation point behind that statement, but does so with as creative a story as I've seen come from Mr. Robinson--and that, my friends, is saying a LOT. Let's face it, I look for creative as well as entertaining stories to read, and few--and I DO mean VERY few authors have the seemingly endless well of shockingly awesome ideas that comes out time and again by this guy. Clive Cussler had it (I dare say he's all but lost it in the last ten years or so), so did Tom Clancy once upon a time, but we saw his writing go steadily downhill at a progressively rapid pace and yet over and over Jeremy seems to discover new and even MORE creative ways to propel a story forward at a dizzingly rapid pace.The Chess Team novels are an amazing triumph of that never-ending well of creativity attached to the back of a hyperdrive running at 110% capacity. Each novel is great and absolutely LOADED with action and adventure--and again, I don't say that lightly. I think of all the action/adventure authors I read regularly, only Matthew Reilly exceeds the action level of Robinson--that's pretty much it. And by the way that includes James Rollins, Cussler, Crichton and others. Trust me, he is in fine company if not a class by himself. Plus, he does it without sounding all cartoonish like Reilly's action sometimes tends to be.Savage has got it ALL. Nuclear weapons, ancient mysteries, and more action than you'll find it ALL the James Bond movies COMBINED. I won't rehash the plot as so many others have done already. I'll just give you my impressions of yet another adventure that is the reading equivalent of being launched off the deck of an aircraft carrier: Yet ANOTHER Winner from the mind of Robinson and Ellis. I don't know how much of the writing was one or the other, but the end result is the same: a sure fire entertaining juggernaut which can satisfy the action thirsts of any ten adventure enthusiasts--and THEN some.If you have yet to pick up a Chess Team/Jack Sigler novel--first of all, what the HECK are you waiting for??? I WILL say this though, if you plan to do so--and why wouldn't you, either start here, or at the very beginning. Savage is actually a good place to begin if you have never read any previous Sigler novels, but honestly, you're going to end up doing so anyway, so you may as well BUY this one, but then immediately go get ALL of the previous books and sit back, relax, enjoy and repeat. You can thank me later.

Talk about a great case! I did some research before I purchased my phone, and doing research on which case to buy is equally as important. I read a LOT of good things about the Tech21 cases in general, and then I went INTO a store and talked to the representatives there and asked them about it. Several there SWORE by the protective power of this product. But then again, they work off commission, so I was pretty skeptical up front. Then one of them put his own phone in one of the cases and proceeded to throw it against the floor as hard as he could. This he did without warning. I was entirely unprepared for what he was going to do. Needless to say he shocked me was an understatement. However, the end result was a perfectly protected Samsung GS5 which had ZERO nicks or scrapes or any sign of damage whatsoever.With all that said, I think what he did was just shy of irresponsible--but after the fact, I clearly learned a real-world fact about this case by seeing in action, and THAT my friends was the major selling factor in my eyes. A sales person can talk all they want about how a product performs in the real world, but rarely do you get the chance to test drive something like this before buying. I learned that Tech21 is the real deal and whether or not the mumbo-jumbo talk about the space-age special absorbing material used on the inner lining means anything other than just a funny talking point to make it sound more sophisticated than it really is, I don't much care. It worked and protected the phone and did so without what looked like a single bit of damage whatsoever. Now THAT was a great job selling the product.If you're looking to protect YOUR investment--and let's be honest, you should--look no further. The Tech21 LG G3 case is really thin and barely adds any bulk to an already skinny and light device. This I appreciated VERY much. You will, too. All I can say is this, I am glad I bought one. And also, one more thing: unlike some rubbery-type phone cases which are SO rubbery (mainly the silicone kind) that every time you pull your phone out of your pocket it seems to pull the whole pocket out with it, this one is slick enough to NOT catch on the lining of my pockets--and yet maintained enough of a grip in my hand that I didn't feel as though it would be in danger of slipping out any any time.I hope this helps!****UPDATE****Just a quick note to tell you that after a while, the textured surface of the case tends to get dirty--like REALLY dirty...and if you don't clean it daily, good luck getting that dirt to come off. I waited a bit too long and even used a brush normally reserved for cleaning tough, cooked on stains from my dishes, and it made absolutely ZERO difference. I recommend cleaning your case every other day or so, otherwise you'll find some unsightly stains that ain't gonna come off. Just an FYI. Everything else I still love.

SO glad I went with the G3. To be totally honest, I worked (albeit very briefly) with AT&T, and during that time the one thing I figured out aside from the fact that Windows phones were simply unreliable was that LG made the most issue and bug-prone Android phones I had seen. So many came back with serious problems that I vowed that (at least at that time) I probably wouldn't be trying an LG phone out anytime soon.Jump ahead a couple years when I have the chance to buy a Nexus 4. Imagine my surprise when I realize it was made by none other than LG. I very nearly went with something else. I did my research however and made a decision to buy it anyway. Easily the most stable phone I've ever owned--aside from the asinine freakishly easily broken rear panel. Jump ahead 2 years and I'm seriously considering the Galaxy S5, the Galaxy Note 4 or the LG G3. Then I saw the price and availability of the Note 4 and immediately ruled that out. Then I noticed that the Note 3 went down in price with the Note 4 coming out and immediately thought that I would more than likely go with that instead. I did a great deal of additional research and as I went in to buy my new phone, I was pretty much convinced that I'd get the Note 3 specifically because of the cheaper price. When I realized that the G3 was only a few dollars more AND happened to be the 32GB version, with 3GB's of RAM, that sealed my decision right then and there.First off, plastic or not, this phone LOOKS premium all the way, baby. If anyone says otherwise, they simply are not viewing the same phone I am. LG insists that underneath the back brushed metal looking surface IS in fact a layer of metal (I haven't been able to confirm or deny this BTW) but nevertheless it really does look quite stunning. I went with white, mostly because I have never owned one that color before. I couldn't be more happy with the build quality regardless of what any reviewers say. Don't go off of what you have read, if you are on the fence, I urge you to go INTO a store and handle one yourself and see before making up your mind.The screen is stunning. I won't say its Super Amoled stunning like the Note 4, but even so it IS gorgeous. The colors are reproduced beautifully and, I might add, a bit more realistically than I would say the typical Samsung screen renders--but that doesn't mean I prefer it to the rival smartphone. I think the Note 4 easily has the greatest looking screen manufactured as I write this--hands down. But despite the brightness issue that some have problems with on the G3, I think its still awesome and nothing I could see with my own eyes looked pixelated one tiny bit. Crisp and clear, which is why I wanted it partially in the first place. One note about the default setting when you first turn it on is to switch it from Auto Brightness to manual. The standard Auto dims the screen as to make that amazing device impossible to tell the difference between it and a much less inferior screen. Turn it up to about 65% or so and you'll begin to see the genius of how awesome it really looks.The back buttons are an interesting design choice. From what I read based on those who have this phone is you either love them or you will almost wish you had bought a different device because you simply could not get used to their placement. Honestly, before I even held one I thought placing the buttons on the back was a stroke of brilliance. Yes, it DOES take some getting used to, I'll admit. But what makes it all much simpler to deal with is their absolutely PERFECT Knock On feature. I think I've actually used the power button twice, the rest of the time I just tap on the screen twice and it comes to life. A similar double tap turns it off. Gosh what an unbelievably awesome feature, especially coming from the Nexus 4 which had the power button exactly on the opposite side of the power buttons. I can't tell you the number of times I went to turn off my screen only to turn ON the volume instead. That came back to haunt me a few times in Church I assure you. Knock On, no matter WHAT you hear otherwise is probably my favorite feature of the G3 aside from the screen.Battery life so far seems to be noticeably better than my N4 which admittedly was on the sour side of horrible. It is nowhere as long lasting as my original Note, which I was rather impressed with several years ago. But again, with all those additional pixels powering that QHD display, comes a downside of less battery life. It's a trade-off I'm willing to make, especially knowing I can buy a separate battery which was not even possible with the N4. But regardless, each of us use different priorities when buying a phone and this one may very well be a deal breaker for you, so judge and plan accordingly.The Speaker on the back is a whopping 1 watt power-plant. Now for those not familiar with speakers, that may sound on the surface to be kind of laughable, but I assure you that little speaker pumps out some serious volume. It isn't something I'll be choosing to listen to Pandora with mind you, but it is far and away the loudest speaker I have personally used on any smartphone. From what I gather as I write this only the HTC One's speaker can truly beat it for quality and loudness overall, but that too is in the eye of the beholder--or in this case, ear.I've found some neat little tricks that are built-in via helpful YouTube videos which I encourage you to look up if/when you make the decision to purchase the G3 because it will make owning the phone a much bigger pleasure after you have figured out some of the really cool and helpful tricks it is capable of. Some may be a bit gimmicky like with the Samsung phones, but some truly are valuable and come in handy.Reception was a BIG issue for me as I just moved a couple days before I bought my phone and my new area had some pretty poor reception with my Nexus 4. Granted, it was only capable of HSPA+ and even then only in certain areas, but I figured that since 4G LTE was still brand new to my area with T-Mobile (the service I currently have) I would possibly have even less coverage than before. Boy was I wrong. Not only does it have a fantastic signal even in the basement, but its also LTE. So at least from my personal perspective, the reception is significantly better than with my N4, which was a VERY welcome surprise.The camera was another area where I labored my decision making before buying the phone. It lacked less megapixels than either Samsung phones I was considering, but yet it was considerably more than my previous device. In most of the camera tests I have viewed either on YouTube or through other written comparisons, the G3 was consistently ranked ahead of the Note 3 as well as the GS5 but lagged slightly behind the Note 4. Several comparisons rated it better than the iPhone 6 and the equal of the 6Plus. All of that means nothing if it doesn't work for you in the real world. What ultimately won me over were two significant things that the G3 had that many other phones didn't. First was OIS, or Optical Image Stabilization (in fairness, a few other phones DO have this, but again, not very many). It helps to take clearer photos and video without the shakiness and the other, which as I write this NO other smartphone has (at least that I am aware of) is laser focusing. There simply isn't a phone available that can focus faster than this one. There just isn't. At first I was worried that it may be a bit of a gimmick, but no, its the real deal. It really works. The photos are much, MUCH better than my N4 and I'm happy to say they are every bit as good as the iPhone 6's. Nuff said.The ability to multi-task on this device is really pretty awesome. I'm not sure why I would need to answer an email WHILE watching a YouTube video, but by golly, I could if I wanted to. Running two apps at the same time is an amazing ability--one that apple simply cannot even attempt regardless of which model phone you may have. It falls short of what the Note 4's capability is, but then again its a much older device, too. I would recommend getting the 32GB model with 3Gigs of RAM if you plan on using Dual Window multi-tasking regularly, but that is just my opinion. That extra gig however really makes a difference, trust me.Call quality has been excellent thus far, and one other thing is I was quite surprised at how much I really love the LG keyboard right out of the box. I fully expected to want to use SwiftKey Flow, the regular--but incredibly accurate Google keyboard or my old standby, Swype but I find that I have been alternating between SwiftKey and the LG keyboard exclusively. Bravo to LG for making their keyboard SO user-friendly and customizable right away. That makes a HUGE difference for those of us who not only want, but demand the ability to switch things up and customize to our hearts content.The ability to customize your phone has just gone up a HUGE notch with the G3 in general--which again, for those of us who love to really make our phones truly UNIQUE is not only a plus, but one I have grown to really love on my G3 the more I use it.Not every phone is perfect for every person, but I CAN say this: I am more than pleased with this phone, and while it no longer sports the quickest chipset and processor on the market like it did when it was released, I don't really much care. What REALLY mattes is this phone WORKS, and works really well--especially coming from my 2 year old Nexus 4. I truly find that the G3 is simply amazing. I could NOT be happier with my choice to buy it.***UPDATE***I've had additional time to play with my phone and if its possible, I love it even MORE. For me, part of the fun of getting a new phone is getting to know the in's and out's of what its capable of doing, and I have literally been falling in love more and more with it. I am STILL in awe of the screen. I have read additional reviews which basically say that because the display is LCD and not Super Amoled, the colors don't render as well, or they aren't as sharp as they expected it to be and whatnot. I gotta say that they couldn't be more wrong. The color saturation may not be as much as on a Samsung, but that means they tend to be more true-to-life. I think they pop PLENTY. Much more and it'd look simply cartoonishly odd in my opinion. The sharpness is just amazing, as you'd expect from a QHD display. If anyone says otherwise, either their screen is broke or they're simply not telling the truth. LG didn't only hit a homer with this phone, but they knocked it out of the park with a Grand Slam.I didn't use any other previous LG branded phone other than the Nexus 4, so I don't have any experience with their former UI which pretty much everybody universally slammed as just shy of incredibly annoying. Personally, I am finding LG's UI with the G3 to be a pure joy to work with thus far. The amount of customizing you can do is nothing short of amazing. SO much more than any previous phone I have owned. I've found some cool built-in features that I had to download via 3rd party apps in my other devices, such as flash alerts when a text or call is made using the camera flash. I had to use a different app in the past but the G3 has it built IN. Before if I wanted the LED indicator light to flash different colors based on who texted me, I had to download yet another app, but not here. The more I delve into the capabilities, the more impressed I am--and that is not as simple as you may think. Having sold phones in the past, I am more aware of smartphones and what they can and can't do than the average power-user, in fact I knew more than the folks at the T-Mobile store I bought my phone at--but in all honesty, not much more though. Once again, I love my phone.About the only thing I haven't really gotten into is the camera. Which is unusual, I tend to go full-bore into my devices from the moment I unbox them. But I've been so dang busy that I haven't been able to just yet. One thing I have noticed was of the few pics I have taken, the laser focus is like freaky fast and definitely NOT a gimmick. It really does assist in getting the pic unnaturally quick. Plus, I've zoomed in on photos that on older phones would have looked stupidly pixelated, but was still SUPER clear with the additional 5 megapixels. You can seriously see the difference. I don't take a lot of video, but if/when I finally do, I'll make sure and do another update.I understand to a degree why the apple fanboys dislike android. Part of its because androids can be customized SO much, it takes a LOT more time to set up your device to do what you want it to do. But in so doing you make the entire experience so much more enjoyable and fun. Face it apple folks, android simply can DO A LOT MORE, but that comes at a price. It is nowhere as simple to use out of the box as OiS is. I concede that. To some it is nothing shy of confusing to the max--trust me, I GET that. BUT, the overall experience works, but you've got to be willing to put in the time to learn it in order to get the most out of it. For those who do, the experience is nothing shy of magical in my opinion.***UPDATE #2***Can't believe I forgot to bring this up earlier, but while this is without a doubt the MOST compact 5.5" screen device available (at least as I write this), it IS a fairly decent sized smartphone. For those with big hands you'll love it--however, if yours tends to be smaller, I recommend going INTO a store and physically handling this before you commit to buying it. I know that sounds almost redundantly obvious, but you may be surprised how many people buy stuff online without ever really knowing if it'll fit their hands etc. Even though LG has their own version of compacting the screen to make it easier to use one-handed (which Samsung did first--and still does best I might add), it just wasn't very convenient. The one-handed texting screen was better. If I could ask for one thing of the LG G4, or whatever they replace this phone with is to directly copy Samsung in this area, they did it RIGHT. So to re-cap: go to a store and physically HOLD this phone and play with a REAL one, not those stupid fake mock-up's they tend to have at a lot of stores so you can get an idea of how you would hold it yourself and use it before buying.After a few more days using the LG keyboard, I take back what I said earlier. It started out working great--unfortunately, the more I used it, the LESS accurate it became...which is supposed to be the opposite of what SHOULD happen, but that's the facts. I went in and deleted the cache in the keyboard settings and it worked great--again for a while, and began to do the same inaccurate stuff as before. I am a bit perplexed as to why, but I've gone back to SwiftKey Flow and Swype and the trusty and VERY accurate Google keyboard (now if only Google would clean it up to make it LOOK a bit better and more customizable, honestly its the best keyboard for direct accuracy I've used, but it just LOOKS so dang boring and blah). Oh well.***UPDATE #3***Wanted to bring up a couple things now that I've had the phone for a while now. First is battery life. I've gotta say how impressed I am considering the amount of pixels that screen is powering--especially coming from the Nexus 4. Now, with that said had I come from something else with known decent or even great battery life, I may be singing a different tune. Keep in mind the Nexus 4 had well-known HORRIBLE battery life. So almost ANYTHING I went to was going to be better than what I had before. But I cannot compare it with the LG G2 or the Droid Maxx or Galaxy Note 3 etc just what I had before, so please keep that in mind--but so far I think the battery life is pretty darned good.The camera is absolutely AMAZING. The camera default setting is on 10 MP resolution, and those alone are fantastic. The color has been incredibly vivid and crisp, especially in bright conditions. I've only used the flash once, and was rather impressed with how that turned out as well. The one thing I wish they had done different is when you switch to full resolution of 13 MP you also lose full screen photos. I wish that they had kept it the same for all the different resolutions you could choose from. In that way I kinda feel a bit cheated...but I just have to say this thing takes wicked good pics so far. I am VERY happy with that camera. I can only imagine what the next LG phone camera will be capable of next year...one thing is for sure though, it'll take GREAT pics.***UPDATE #4***One thing I had done with my Nexus 4 was change settings so I could access Developer Options and switched the Runtime from Dalvik to ART (Android Run Time). While typically this is MUCH more efficient, not all apps and/or phones have updates which are compatible with switching to ART--that is until they receive the Android 'L' update. I did this with my N4 and it worked pretty well, but not long after doing the same to my G3, I began to notice my phone freezing up. It frustrated me to no end, and in fact I performed a full-on hard reset--which I later determined was unnecessary (gosh do I wish I had known this first). The LG G3 hasn't received an update which will allow its core adaptation of Android to run on ART just yet, and as a result, when it ran into incompatibility issues, it simply froze up--which as you all know is incredibly frustrating. Not once did my N4 freeze on me, so after it happened 3 times within a couple hours, I knew something was seriously wrong. After the reset, it naturally went back to running Dalvik and absolutely ZERO issues since. While I cannot say with 100% certainty that this was in fact the problem to begin with, the fact that it only began freezing up shortly AFTER switching and has since stopped the moment I corrected this is a bit of an obvious giveaway if you ask me. I have since found several detailed blogs talking about this exact problem. Again, I WISH I had seen that before performing the reset, but at least I'm letting YOU know so you can hopefully opt to NOT make the same mistake as I did. The honest truth is I did not see any significant difference in performance after switching to ART anyway. Since the G3 hasn't been optimized to run on it just yet, I am only assuming that is the main reason why I haven't seen any noticeable difference since having it revert back to Dalvik.Can I just say once again how much I LOVE the Knock On feature? This is seriously one major awesome ability that I have found immensely helpful from literally the beginning. I find it JUST as useful now as I did when I purchased the device. Honestly, who needs a fingerprint scanner when a knock code is JUST as reliable and every bit as secure? While technically it isn't, I'm just trying to imagine the absolute NEED to have security THAT deep that a knock code couldn't suffice? I imagine for some this may be a supreme feature and necessity, but not for me. But everyone is of course, different. Besides, I hear that one thing the iPhone definitely has on Android is a real world RELIABLE finger print scanner with their home button, unlike Samsung whose scanner seems to work sporadically--if at all--and don't get me wrong, I am a BIG Samsung fan. I came THIS close to getting the Note 4... If I'm being honest, apple has one major leg up on the Android community and that is the reliability of their home button finger print scanner. Kudos to them for that ONE thing. I still prefer Android by an unbelievable margin.I am (again) still impressed with my phone, its capabilities and pretty much everything all told. It's VERY thin, maybe not iPhone thin, but in the grand scheme of things, its hardly noticeable, and at least mine isn't known for bending. It FEELS comfortable in my hand, and STILL takes killer photos, even in low light thanks to the OIS capability minimizing your movements in order to take some clearly awesome pics in the dark. It won't replace your full camera just yet, but it honestly takes some fantastic photos which I would normally hesitate to even attempt with previous phones--and leaps & bounds ahead of the N4.I read this week that LG has not only claimed that they were committed to timely updates, but actually are releasing Android Lollipop in Poland THIS week, which is ahead of the announced release of Android 'L' to even the Nexus 4 and 5. Word has it we won't see it here in the states for a few more weeks, but this certainly is a great sign considering last year LG was ranked dead last for releasing updates to their devices. Talk about a gigantic about face. While I haven't received it just yet, I still think this is a great sign and one which helps me to know I made the right choice in buying the G3.

Fun, but I have to say that after about 15 minutes, my son (all 3 of my young sons) got rather tired of the train.For the most part, it LOOKS impressive. All set up its rather large, which for a child is a big thing actually. Unfortunately the instructions to piece it together were essentially so poor that it was easier to just look at the box and go from there. Unfortunately that made us have to experiment with several pieces being in the wrong place before figuring it out properly--but we DID get it together after a few minutes of frustration.Some of the pieces fit together better than others, but all in all I have to admit that the train works just as promised, and the little moving portion of the bridge really does work pretty well, even though leading up to it, if I were a betting man, would have bet money that it wasn't going to work at all. I would've been wrong.The only real downside is that since the train only does exactly what you see on the front of the box (admittedly, it does it well) it gets rather boring to watch again and again after say 5 minutes. Plus after it does everything, you've kind of got to readjust a few of them in order for it to do it the next time around--and that gets rather tedious after a few times as well. All in all, it works as promised, but gets super boring VERY quickly...and for my boys who have attention spans the size of a gnat, that makes me wonder whether or not it is entirely worth it to make this purchase. If your child can watch the same boring train go round and round again and again without any complaints, then maybe this is the set for you. If your children have much shorter attention spans (such as mine) you may want to reconsider.Hope this helps.

Initially I bought these because I thought they looked cool and they were comfortable. After 8+ years of wear & tear (mile after mile of plenty of usage) the only reason I still don't have them is because I forgot to take them out of my van when I sold it.Hands down the most comfortable pair of sandals I've ever worn--and I've owned my fair share. My son keeps trying to convince me to buy a pair that he has which are supposedly guaranteed for life (Choco's or something along those lines). Sure they LOOK good, but the sole directly under your feet are akin to walking on concrete (NOW I know why they last forever, they're darned near made of stone). They are amazingly uncomfortable (at least for me) and so I'll stick with what works for me.So comfort is important to me, but I had NO idea just how durable these sandals would be as well, especially considering how much I've put them through for easily close to 8 years. Now THAT'S a quality pair of sandals if you ask me. I have tried to find a replacement pair for the one's I stupidly lost, but to no avail. I need to just break down and order a new pair online because I have absolutely GOT to buy another pair.In my opinion, BEST pair of sandals I've ever purchased. Hands down.

Wireless charger AND built-in battery too?? Pinch me! I didn't think this would be any more than just a regular wireless charger, so imagine my surprise when I realized it also doubled as an external battery as well!Yes, its true that wireless chargers don't charge with the same speed as plugging directly into a wall outlet, but the convenience it offers far outweighs that in my personal opinion. Also, the speed is pretty standard for wireless chargers, too. I keep wondering whether or not apple will EVER move into the modern age by offering what some Android devices have had for a few years now. If apple really is the innovators as they and the incessant whining of their fanboys continue to claim, why is it this technology has yet to find itself inside an iPhone for the last 2 versions? OR NFC for that matter? But I digress, let's stick to the wireless charger.The simplicity with which you can use it right out of the box is pretty important in this day and age and I am happy to report that this charger is no exception. I plugged it into my computer and it began charging the internal battery AND wirelessly charging my phone literally right out of the box. Say what you want but that's pretty darned convenient in my book. It's easy to know your device is charging, too. You place your phone on top and make sure you can see the row of lights at the bottom right-hand corner of the top and you'll hear it when it begins. Hard to miss, actually. Bam, that's it. Oh, and it charges without having to remove my protective case, either. Yet another convenience in my opinion.The device is well-built without being overly bulky and sits rather snug on my desk. All in all this is just about the best wireless charger I think I've ever seen. VERY happy with mine.

I've been a fan of Gillette razors for quite some time now, and honestly believe they are about the best available. I have since found several razors that work pretty much just as well--all for cheaper (sometimes quite a bit cheaper) than what a typical Proglide razor will cost.Initially I just thought I was ordering a regular Fusion Proglide razor...but no, this is the model that comes with the Flexball Handle. So what does the Flexball Handle actually DO? Good question. The razors have tilted backward & forward to follow the contour of your face for literally at least a decade or more, right? The Flexball Handle essentially now allows it to curve not only up & down, but now left & right as well, giving your new razor unprecedented facial comfort and coverage. All this should translate into not only the best shave ever, but smoothest as well, right? In reality, I noticed absolutely ZERO difference in how close the razor shaved than my previous Proglide without the Flexball Handle.Now, let me be clear: I still LOVE the Proglide, and firmly believe that if I have the choice of using the Gillette versus pretty much every model of personal shaver available, I'll go with the Gillette pretty much every time (unless of course I cannot afford one, in which case I have 3 different and much cheaper models which I believe work easily 98% as good).To sum it up, I LOVE the Proglide--but don't see that the Flexball Handle works really any better than the regular model. Maybe that's because the regular Proglide works so well, that the difference is purely subjective to each user, I'm not entirely certain to be honest. All I know is it works, and works well...but if the Flexball is more expensive, I cannot endorse paying more. If they are the same price as the regular Proglides, then no problem. Otherwise, I'd stick with the regular razor.
