Simple, easy to use and does the job quite well. The only thing I wish it could do that it doesn't is power more than one thing at a time. Other than that, this Micro USB charger will fit virtually all android phones and tablets and even most Windows phones as well. It seems that aside from apple and the Nook tablets, everyone else has converted to this particular mode of charging. It works, and does its job relatively quickly too. Especially for the money. Economical, well-built and does what its supposed to do. What more can you ask for?I'm perfectly satisfied--and then some.

I had hoped that when I ordered this, that somehow, someway it would also be compatible with an Android tablet, but I gambled and lost. Darn it. Oh well. I gave this to a friend who uses nothing but apple products and they have nothing but enormously high marks for usability, simplicity and set up.Everything comes with the keyboard, and sets up very quick. After charging (which is via the included micro USB port, strangely enough, what almost all android phones & tablets use) its simple to turn on, pair and operate. Keys were responsive and always worked with maximum ease. I liken the quality to something actually produced BY apple, which is high praise indeed. The layout is VERY similar to apple keyboards and therefore, the more familiar you are with them, the quicker you're going to adapt.The only issue I have is that it isn't compatible with an android tablet. Now this may seem like nitpicking (and let's face it, that is exactly what I'm doing) but I've found earbuds that were initially designed for an iPhone/iPod but still work flawlessly with my Nexus 4 phone. Complete with answering calls and the buttons working to stop, start or pause the music. If THOSE can incorporate the use across different phone platforms, why can't keyboards? I don't believe I'm asking too much to have a simple keyboard be usable by two different systems. Since I received the keyboard through my amazing Vine program, I won't complain because I'm not out any money, but I'm just saying, if you do what I did hoping that it'll work across both platforms, you're gonna be sorely disappointed as I was. Again, that is my ONLY gripe, meaning otherwise, the keyboard works and works WELL. Belkin knocked this one out of the park.

Let me just say that the deodorant that I use most also is an Antiperspirant...this Speed Stick is JUST a deodorant. With that being said, it still works pretty good. I wouldn't say nearly as well as if it were an antiperspirant as well, but still, much better than the basic deodorants I've used and subsequently shunned in the past.The smell was also better than I had thought it would be. All in all--as far as deodorants go, there isn't much more to add, other than I wish it had also included antiperspirant, other than that, I think I was pleasantly surprised at how much I liked it and how well it worked.

I didn't think I'd ever get laundry detergent using amazon but I'm actually glad I did. I must admit, I'm a penny pincher when it comes to buying detergent and usually go with the cheaper stuff available and then complain if it doesn't work well and/or smell nice afterwards. The easy way to counter that of course is to spend a little more and get ACTUAL results. This Tide really does work, doesn't require a lot in order to do the job (especially if you use a High Efficiency washer) and the smell is really good. I find that I don't even have to use dryer sheets or any type of fabric softener for it to do the job and still smell great as it comes out of the dryer. A nice feat you simply cannot recreate using the cheap stuff that I'm rather known for buying...because I'm again, cheap.Spend a little--but you'll get a LOT. Considering how much extra cheap detergent I have to use in order to get my clothes not even quite as clean as a little Tide means when all is said and done, I'm paying for right about the same amount and it all ends up smelling nice the FIRST time around. I don't really see a reason to continue getting the cheap stuff anymore. I actually believe I'm convinced now...and I really didn't think I would be when I first used it. My eyes have been opened, so-to-speak.

I am a 23+ year radio veteran--so I KNOW what good audio sounds like. There is NOTHING that will get me to believe the beats headphones are even remotely worth the outrageous price they cost. I've worn several and owned a pair, too. Were they good? Yes...b-u-u-u-t my Sony MDR 7506's sound BETTER and they are one-third the price. I've heard ALL the arguments, TRUST me. I'm not gonna change my mind. Period.However, I was mildly impressed with the urBeats earbuds by Dre. The sound really was pretty good. But let me also say this: I have a pair of Sony earbuds that I paid a whopping $20 on that I would say sounds 95% as good--and can out-do the beats in one very crucial area: they actually stay in my ear while exercising. I really would've kept them if they had managed to just stay put. I can't seem to figure out exactly why they kept coming out, either. Style wise they are remarkably similar in shape to the Sony's, but darned if they just didn't keep falling out and I found myself about ever half-mile being forced to reach up and push them back into place. Sorry, but that alone was a deal breaker. Now--I WILL say this: I won't suggest that all urBeats will act the same for each person. They may fit your ear like a glove and provide you with remarkably great sound for years. All I can say is if they cannot stay put, I've simply got to move on to something else.I was sufficiently impressed however that I just may take a gamble and buy a pair of their sport earbuds...if that means anything.

I'm a little torn by the new attire that seems to be sweeping the athletic apparel industry as of late. Shirts and clothing made from this smooth and comfortable material promising a cooler, more comfortable workout due to advances in material technology, sweat absorption and whatnot. They may as well promise to increase your athletic ability for all of the other claims made.The truth of the matter is this: in all my workouts wearing the Tasc Performance shirt as well as multiple others designed by many other manufacturers (from the stupidly expensive to Walmart cheap version) not once have I been able to say, "Wow, this makes my workout more efficient or more comfortable!" Not one single time. I liken this so-called miracle fabric to the claims Sketcher made with their shoes a few years back about how they would make you work harder because of their unique shape. Interesting, but in practical use, I could see ZERO difference all the way around.What I CAN say is that the shirt IS comfortable. I took a gamble and ordered mine without knowing what size it would arrive in, and imagine my surprise/disappointment when it showed up no less than 2 sizes smaller than what I needed. By golly, I put the darned thing on anyway and wore it like a second skin for a couple workouts (I simply must've looked like a moron to those around me) and I can say without reservation the shirt is quite comfortable. It stretches abnormally far and even though it hugged me quite clearly, it wasn't too snug that it became uncomfortable (other than to those who had to view me). After a couple wears, it stretched sufficiently that it no longer felt too small, but felt almost just right. Even so, it was still too small so I gave it to a co-worker who absolutely LOVES it.Say what you want about the fabric and what it "claims" it can do or not, but in my opinion, I love the shirts and the fabric, but I simply don't believe it works--nor does ANY of the similar models on the market--the way its advertised. That is THIS guys opinion, and nothing more.

If you're a power Nazi like I am, I get nervous whenever I'm away from an outlet for too long (I KNOW I'm not the only one) and having the ability to power up your devices from essentially anywhere is a mighty nice option. For a person like me though, it represents a necessity. Not that I absolutely MUST have it, but it certainly keeps my worries down to a bare minimum.First off, its pretty compact, and can fit in my pocket easily. Yes, its a bit thick, but not overly so. It comes with TWO usb ports which allows the charging of more than one device at a time if need be--which is tremendously convenient. I didn't think it would be, mostly because this is the first device I've owned which has more than one port, but now that I HAVE one, I gotta say, its come in handy multiple times when I didn't even expect it to.7800 mAh is a pretty hefty amount of power, and it doesn't even take long to charge fully. I have yet to plug it into the wall, rather I use my outlet in my vehicle do it for me. ZERO issues so far. Works like a charm, literally. About the ONLY complaint I have is that I haven't been able to get my miniature light to work. I rarely would use it, but even so, it'd be nice to have on certain occasions I'm sure. So far, it hasn't been obvious to get it to work, which has only been slightly bothersome. I haven't completely read the instructions, but being a man, I like to figure some things out on my own without needing to read all the directions (wish I could shake that habit, but apparently its in my genes), but for whatever reason, I haven't figured that little on/off light thing out. Oh well. No big deal.If you're looking for extra power that'll work when you need it, is pretty compact, especially considering how much power it provides, and comes with multiple sized plug-in's to adapt to virtually any device you may have or need, you have GOT to give this little baby a try. I simply couldn't be more pleased with how mine has worked for me.**I received my OXA Juice Box in exchange for my honest and unbiased review and opinion.

I own several earbuds which have built-in microphones for conversation using smartphones...they all work pretty good. Actually ALL of them work remarkably well for having conversations using the built-in microphone. But all of them have one thing in common: they don't SOUND really good playing music. My Phillips Sport ActionFit earbuds sound absolutely awesome. I mean that. The outside noise reduction is amazing, especially for not being noise cancelling specifically. They were loud, crisp and just plain sounded great all around.However, each phone conversation I had remarked that it sounded like I was in the wind and it was difficult to hear me, even in the car with the window UP and no air blowing at all my direction. I thought it was an isolated event, but it happened with each conversation I had while using it. I knew it was too good to be true. Oh well.The included rubber earbuds (it came with 2 sets of spares) fit great, and were comfortable. I was initially worried they wouldn't stay put, but I've done some strenuous stuff while wearing them and haven't had a problem with that happening. Compared with other earbuds which cannot replicate the audio very well, but can do phone calls great, I'm still wondering when I'm going to find a decent pair of earbuds that don't cost a fortune, but can provide both phone calls AND music quality that meet up with my ridiculously high standards.I'm happy to say that the Phillips ActionFit provided me with 50% of what I was hoping for. Which, for the money, really isn't all that bad. Your experience may vary.

Yeah, you read that right. I figured since both tablets had similarly sized screens, they'd swap easily. Let me say right up front: I was wrong. Cutting these screen protectors, especially ones that were pre-sized to fit a different tablet perfectly is no small task. I've done enough for cell phone screens to know that. It takes patience to put them on no matter how well it fits, and lets just say, I ran out of all the patience I had--plus all my reserve trying to get this one to fit properly after my semi-decent editing job.Let me just say that had I used this on a Kindle (like I should  have from the beginning) I'm sure my review would be different. As it is, I know that these are quality made protectors, but I just can't recommend them for Nooks. Sorry, but its true. Yeah, I'm a moron--but I'm being honest.

I have fairly small fingers and hands, and therefore, thought that this keyboard would be easier to operate than it turned out. I'd say I could comfortably hit most keys, but using an apostrophe while writing simple words like DON'T or  CAN'T became a colossal pain in the keister because finding the key was inconvenient at best, and a downright challenge at other times. The key wasn't where you'd expect, and therefore if you wanted to look as thought you had finished at least 4th grade English, writing anything more than a short message was simply unpleasant for me.With that said, if you aren't big on using that kind of punctuation, and you have really small fingers and hands, you'll most likely love the Belkin Portable Bluetooth Keyboard. It really is compact and worked just as promised. It paired quickly, and I was pleasantly surprised how overall simple it was to set up and use right out of the box--which is big these days.If at ALL possible, I'd go for a keyboard at least a couple inches wider than this (minimum) or at the very least, I say try this out physically whenever possible before purchase so you'll know if it works for you before purchasing. It'll either save you the pain of returning it, or you'll be better off knowing exactly what you're buying. Keep that in mind before buying and I think you'll make a wise decision all the way around.

No, it isn't a surprise that this is a co-written book. Its not like the first books passed off as written by Tom Clancy and yet were penned entirely by someone else. This one clearly states Grant Blackwood's name on the front (who, interestingly enough co-wrote with Clancy, too) and this is Rollins' first Sigma Force novel which tackles a different set of main characters than the regular fare we've come to expect. Introduced not long ago, Tucker Wayne and his trusty dog are front and center in The Kill Switch.Tucker and Kane have quite a unique relationship--almost bordering on what you'd normally reserve for a close human bond. If you've ever had a pet like Kane that you've bonded with, you know it can extent to special animals as well. The storyline is quick and unravels pretty fast--and I might say a bit too fast, which sometimes I don't mind when I expect it (like with a Matthew Reilly novel) but I expect a bit more story development from a novel with Rollins' name on the front. Not a huge complaint, mind you, but one I just thought worth mentioning all the same.There was plenty of entertainment, and more than a fair share of, shall we say, difficult to swallow exploits? Sure, your average Sigma Force novel has plenty of that, but one of James Rollins' many talents is to make each story sound entirely plausible even when you KNOW it certainly couldn't be--and yet you wonder if its possible anyway. The Kill Switch didn't have any of that in my opinion.For fans of Tucker and Kane from their previous Sigma introduction will find plenty to like here. Overall, I was pleasantly surprised, but along the way, there are some pretty obvious signs that I wasn't reading a book that had been penned mostly by Rollins. I can't say it any more specifically than that. If you've read enough of his books, you'll see it. Otherwise, get ready for quite a roller coaster ride!

Are you like me, do you get nervous when you see your phone battery dip below 80%? Well, that may explain why I have 3 separate portable power supplies. Now I realize not everyone is as anal about powering their devices like I am, but for those of you who happen to have a smartphone--which you totally rely on--without the ability to remove and replace the battery, you really need extra power when you need it--and you NEVER know when you'll need it. Chances are, it'll be when you least expect it. This is where the OXA Portable Power Bank really comes in handy.Another reviewer said they liked this external battery, but felt that it wasn't really for 'power users.' MY argument for that is: WHY did they get a 2600mAh battery then? My current cell phone battery is 1700mAh so I easily double my power with this device...if you really ARE a power user, then of all the different sized external batteries available, why did you settle on one so small? They have positively gargantuan batteries out there to choose from which are able to power not only your phone, but laptop and tablet and still have enough to get you through the day--so why not get one of those? I have a 3300mAh battery which works great, too--but isn't nearly as stylish as the OXA. Sure, style isn't always what you're shooting for, I get that, but as long as you're going to use extra power, why not get a battery that looks as good as it works? Just sayin'.After the initial set-up and charge, I have nothing but high praise for my Power Bank. It charges quickly, and powers my phone with all the speed of plugging it directly into a wall outlet--easily 30-40% faster than using a car charger (if not, it certainly SEEMS like it). I like the included key ring, too. While it may be a little too big for some to carry around on a keychain, it really isn't by a whole lot. Plus, I really like how the included charging cord isn't ridiculously long. One of my other chargers came with an obnoxiously long cord which seems to be always getting bunched up and tied in knots, even when I TRY to keep it from doing so. Annoying? You bet. I understand that some prefer shorter cords, and some need and even require longer charging cables, but honestly, for ME, this is just about perfect. I haven't once had to untie it from a knot which is a tremendous blessing to me--especially when I happen to be in a hurry.You have plenty of sources to choose from when it comes to external power supplies, in MY opinion, if you need an extra boost and you aren't a super-power-user, think long and hard about giving the OXA Power Bank a try. I am perfectly satisfied with mine.

Before receiving this copy of Influx, I hadn't read anything by Daniel Suarez--however, I had heard a great deal about his novel, 'Daemon' from a a close relative who had tremendous praise for the novel, and ultimately, is the sole reason for my reading this book. Was it all worth it? Ultimately? I'd have to say absolutely.The idea is as brilliant as it gets in my opinion. I've always found it interesting how 20-30 years ago we thought we would be literally leaps and bounds ahead--technology speaking--of where we are now. Well what if we actually were--but those advancements were kept OUT of the public domain for what initially seem like noble reasons, but when the dust settles, those reasons really aren't the REAL reasons. Supposedly, some advances can become a horrific disruption to the world in general, and that just isn't good--which is why the Bureau of Technology Control (BTC) searches tirelessly to find such techno-leaps and does their best to recruit the inventors into their select circle. The idea is to keep their work secret--but now and then some inventors feel the greater good is served by allowing their sacrifice to be made public--which is a Super No No to the BTC. You see, you're going to join them--OR ELSE. You either do it willingly, or they kidnap and imprison you and that usually comes with no small amount of torture.Physicist Jon Grady resists when given the opportunity to join the almighty BTC, and this is where his life takes a dramatic turn--and not necessarily for the good. Previous decades of technology hasn't disappeared, those at the head of the BTC control it and have the perverted view that only they are worthy of it, and will stop at nothing to keep it away from ordinary citizens. I have to admit, as others have noticed, some of the technology in the book certainly SEEMS plausible (I'm no scientist, but Mr. Suarez did an admirable job of at least making it all sound believable under certain circumstances) These ideas are loaded with creativity on a massive scale. Explaining the unexplainable was certainly one of Michael Crichton's major talents, and the comparisons to Suarez are certainly warranted, because he does an equally fantastic job of making a moron like me almost feel like I actually understood all the gobbledegook he was writing about--which is no small task, by the way.The BTC was created by a group who felt it was necessary--and yet over the years the agency was totally forgotten, and before long, those who used to take orders from others were now in charge of their own work, and when that happens, bad things are afoot...trust me. There is so much to like in the clever storyline of Influx and while I enjoyed it thoroughly, was it perfect? Nope. Did I enjoy it enough to recommend it to others? Yes, absolutely. If you like Michael Crichton-like technology based thrillers, its time you discovered Daniel Suarez. I certainly am glad I did.

I've been a huge fan of submarine themed techno thrillers since reading Red October back in the mid 80's. With all the novels out there to choose from, its nice to know I was fortunate enough to at least pick this one. Full of action, thrills and compelling entertainment--even if it isn't 100% plausible.Almost immediately after leaving port in Hawaii, the USS Kentucky receives some chilling orders: launch ALL ballistic missiles at the country of Iran. Some clever techno work involved keeps the crew from receiving any actual orders rescinding the fake launch edict. As you can imagine, the end result would be the deaths of millions of innocents in Iran, and the President does exactly what they do in the Hunt For Red October, he orders the fleet to hunt down and destroy the Kentucky before it has a chance to reach optimum launching position.So WHO is responsible for sending the fake orders to nuke Iran? Despite how plausible that explanation may sound, I found other holes in the plot to be remarkably huge. Another reviewer noticed the same, so I definitely won't be the last to catch some of them. I found how the Kentucky treated coming upon other US Naval ships to be utterly without merit in the scope of what supposedly has happened in the story. Also, communication between them and other ships...? What happened to that ability, except for when it became convenient for the plot...? There are a few others, but despite all of that, I STILL found myself so totally involved with the plot to not continue forging ahead to find out what was going to happen next and how they would end up solving the problem at hand. Would a nuclear showdown be avoided, and if so, by how much? Honestly, there wasn't any real doubt that things would manage to work out--but I have to say that I kept reading because part of me wasn't quite sure.Aside from its flaws, I was able to really and fully enjoy the Trident Deception quite a bit. I recommend it if you get the chance...especially if you're a fan of fun sub thrillers like I am.

This is the second K'Nex building set we've purchased for our son (who is 11 now). He is VERY much into building anything and everything, but he is currently going through a pretty serious 'Lego Phase' and he was kind of reluctant--at first--when he opened the box and discovered it WASN'T Legos--to show any kind of enthusiasm. It broke my heart--but only briefly. It took him quite a while to get over the initial excitement of his other birthday presents before he chose to finally begin assembling the Supersonic Swirl. What was absolutely dramatic is how he transformed--quite literally--right before our eyes as he slowly realized that the K'Nex were a lot more entertaining then he had remembered. He prides himself on being rather proficient in following directions and putting things together properly, and again, it was eye opening to see his excitement grow by leaps & bounds as it dawned on him that the building set was a bit more of a challenge then he ever considered possible for his ever-improving degree of assembling talent.It all built to a head until he couldn't contain himself further and called everyone over to watch him as he turned it on for the first time. He was quite literally overcome with thrills. He learned a lot along the way--which is one of the primary purposes of building sets such as this, and he is gradually understanding the reasons for why certain items are built the way they are in order to support other items and heavier things above and beside. His incremental learning experiences are really giving him a dream to shoot for: becoming an architect. He enjoys building things so much through Legos and now, K'Nex, that he sees the framework of homes being constructed in a totally new light. He points out structural needs of a building mid-way through being built in such a way that I can't help but be impressed with not just his comprehension, but his genuine "thirst" for knowledge these toys have helped build within him.Because of the very nature of the pieces needed to build these types of items, I don't feel that they are particularly durable--but then again, I don't think they are really *meant* to be, if you truly understand these types of things. This is designed to be a bare-bones building toy, and that is exactly what it is. Don't think you can cart this around all over the place without some consequences--unless of course you're very careful. I don't want to make it sound as though once you finish building it, that is all you'll ever be able to do, but keep in mind the fragile nature of the long, thin plastic pieces made to manufacture the set and you'll probably be better able to make it last as long as necessary.For children who love to build, tinker and make things work via small & tiny machines, I can't recommend K'Nex enough. Great building designs and allows for a lot more freedom in construction than I would have normally thought possible. Fantastic building set, very impressed.

From the perspective of a young boy, this toy is nothing less than a portable piece of paradise. My 9 year old's eyes nearly blew their sockets when he opened up the box and saw this guy. The packaging alone is top notch and certainly makes the toy LOOK 'beyond awesome' I believe was the term my son came up with. It also managed to  make both of his brothers (one 11 and one 6) SUPREMELY jealous--which is yet another WIN for my son. The boys debated for quite some time as they worked it out of the box whether or not it transformed as well (it kinda does, but NOT like Optimus Prime--sorry boys).I was pretty impressed at how fast it can go, too. It goes from the character to a vehicle-like machine fairly quick, and can actually shoot mini rockets which the boys pretended were everything from that to nuclear tipped laser weapons (aren't imaginations wonderful?). To control it using the remote takes a bit of practice, but my son certainly had fun with the learning curve. The Ooh's and Ahh's he and his brothers were making certainly announced to me firmly that this was not only a good gift for my child, but I had hit a home run in their eyes.I must say that removing it from the box DOES require a screwdriver (which I had left at work, so we couldn't get to immediately--so make SURE to have one handy when you unbox yours). If you have your child with you and no way to properly remove it, you're going to have a revolt and quick-like on your hands. Do yourself a favor and have it ready. It also requires plenty of batteries (8 in total I believe) so have those standing by as well.One more thing to consider: the toy alone is fine, but seems better suited to play with a second model to be operated by another child. It seems designed to 'fight' and if there really isn't anything for it to battle, well, it seems to me that you limit some of its playing ability. That isn't to say my son had a lack of stuff to do with it, but from my perspective, I thought it was something worth noting all the same.I AM a bit concerned with the durability of the robot...I can see a small tumble down a tiny flight of carpeted stairs could be enough to render it all but beyond repair--but let me stress, that is only my assumption based on observing it being used for maybe 20 minutes or so. Either way, I also believe its a valid point.***UPDATE***It's been several days and my sons enthusiasm is still running at probably near 95% of what it was when he initially opened the toy, so all in all, I am STILL very happy and satisfied that I made the right choice. Also, my other sons are still mucho desperate to not only play with it, but have their own as well. I'd have to say that in short, I think the toy is very worthwhile for young boys no less than 7 years old (much younger and I think its just a bit too technical to operate and control properly).

I couldn't wait to try out these ear buds. Being in radio, I own and wear headphones and ear buds pretty much all the time, certainly more than the average person, and I'm a stickler when it comes to audio quality. Not only do I know what sounds good, I know what doesn't. When I first got them, I immediately plugged them into my board in my studio and was supremely impressed with how well it cut out the outside sound--easily better than my more expensive Phillips Noise Cancelling ear buds. It did have a tinny quality to the sound, though which concerned me. But I had to remind myself, these are ear BUDS and not studio monitors, and therefore I was stupid to believe they'd sound the same as my much more expensive headphones.I waited and tried them on my mp3 player and that's where they really shined. Again, I was on the verge of being dumbfounded at how superior its noise isolation was. Again, having been in and around professional studios for virtually all of my adult life, I've used some remarkable ear buds and headphones and these tiny little sport ear buds virtually eliminated outside sound to a degree that not only I hadn't experienced before, but wasn't even sure was possible--especially given what they cost. I was able to 'hear' a LOT of what I had just been missing with most of my other ear buds simply because the sound was actually getting TO my ear more than almost everything else I was used to. If you use ear buds while working out or jogging, your music tends to compete heavily with wind and automobiles and any number of things which interferes with the music, essentially making the music compete with all that noise--and the end results usually mean you miss out on a great deal of audio quality. Not so with the Sport-Fi's.Build quality is nothing short of exceptional. The memory wire used works really well and I was quite impressed with the comfort, too. No matter how good the sound is I'm less likely to wear anything for long if it isn't at least comfortable. I was once again impressed with this part as well. Without having worn them for hours on end, what I DID experience certainly makes me hopeful that I've finally found a pair of ear buds I can wear for long durations, which will really come in handy on my long drive to pick up my children on weekends. As for staying put while exercising, while I can't speak for everyone, it seems to me that you'd have to be doing something beyond strenuous in order for these to come loose. For one they wrap around the back of your ears and do so quite comfortably. They are so light you almost forget you're wearing them. And for two, well, I simply cannot fathom doing something that may result in them falling off, I just can't. Not that it can't be done, but honestly, I have no clue what you'd have to do in order for that to happen.I've answered a call exactly twice and I was impressed yet again. I own a Motorola Motoactv Sport Watch, which is my mp3 player and it bluetooths to my phone as well. Any time I have my ear buds in, I can answer a call via my bluetooth watch very simple. As long as the connection is good (and so far, it was great) my calls were clear, crisp and best of all, even with the window down going 75mph and the wind just screaming into the car, I could hear the caller quite well. Because of the placement of the window, the caller couldn't hear ME all that well, (the wind was hitting the mic pretty much head on) but as soon as I raised the window a little, they heard me just fine. It wasn't anything scientific, but in a real-world test, I discovered one more way in which my Sport-Fi ear buds worked really well.CONCLUSION:When it comes to devices like these, there are no small amount of choices to pick from...in fact, its hard to make an informed choice given how many are on the market to be honest. Well, here's a piece of advice: do your homework and trust those who you know won't screw you around. For me, I couldn't be happier with mine. It works, and works well. The sound it wonderful and the quality reminds me of ear buds which cost many times more than what you can purchase these for. All are great points of sale for me. Since I do wear these more than the average person, build quality is VERY important. I've had some great sounding ear buds in the past but I was less than impressed with their overall durability. Not that the average person would wear them as often or be as hard on them as I am, but isn't it nice to know that either way, you can be assured that they should last you a mighty long time? I look forward to a long time with mine. Call me one VERY satisfied customer.

I quickly gave this to my ex-wife--and she mistook it for a regular vacuum. I tried to explain to her that it was a regular floor cleaner, NO carpets, but I don't think she heard me...all she saw was something that resembled a vacuum and filled in the blanks. She opened it up and was immediately confused. When I saw her next she asked how it was that she was supposed to use it. I asked her if she had bothered to look at the owners manual--and take a WILD guess what she said? Well, no matter. I spent a couple minutes glancing at the manual and figured it out pretty quick--and I'm no Einstein by any stretch.Within a few minutes after that we had that puppy up and running and shining up her kitchen floor better than it had been since, well, probably since it had been brand new. Yes, it works really, REALLY well on linoleum. We were ALL impressed. The Hoover came with its own cleaning solution pre-packaged, which was a VERY nice surprise, too. The built-in rotating scrubbers really work--and work really well, too. Now, let me say up front that I haven't tried this on a carpeted floor, but by the looks of the scrubbers, I'd wager that if you didn't have any carpet steamer handy and wanted to try and clean something quick, this puppy would probably fill in quite nicely--but again, I haven't tried it so cannot say with any authority.As I played with it, the only downside I discovered was around corners, it was hard to suck up the cleaning solution once it had cleaned that particular area, and so had to be manually soaked up with a rag shortly afterwards, but that was only a minor gripe at best. I'd have to say that for those who really dislike mopping, give this baby a whirl and you'll be amazed at how much you may actually enjoy it now. Again, no scientific analysis here, but my children are notorious at hating virtually ALL kitchen cleaning duty's--especially mopping, and they were all chomping at the bit to get a turn. Not just that one, time either. My ex told me no less than twice they have all asked independently if it was their turn to clean the kitchen floor. Right there, that alone makes this device worth just about ANYTHING they can charge, but thankfully it won't break your bank.Kudos to Hoover for making me a believer!

I honestly cannot remember a time when I was NOT a fan of Journey. From my earliest memories of the band, I always loved their music, and its a love which continues to this day. While no particular Greatest Hits package will please literally everybody, this certainly comes close. There are only about 3 songs I wish it had and about 3 or 4 I feel could be dropped from the lists, but again, everyone is different. What I AM trying to say is this: if you like Journey, you cannot go wrong with this collection.I have been a fan of Steve Perry's voice for it seems the bulk of my life...and while those who replaced him by and large were virtual clones of his voice and style, they all lacked one important thing: they weren't Steve Perry. Let me be clear: a couple have actually been VERY good (the current singer in particular is wonderful) but while they all ((sound)) like Steve, NONE of them sing with the passion and raw emotion that Steve brought to his music. One may argue otherwise, but success without Steve has been fleeting at best and seems to back my theory--but that may also be a factor of many other additional things I did not mention.With all of my love to Steve's vocals, you may be interested to know that my two favorite Journey songs do NOT have Perry singing lead. "Feeling That Way/Anytime" have always been my absolute favorite songs, and feature Steve on backing vocals, a job he didn't have very often, thankfully...but on these two songs, fits absolutely to perfection. Disc 1 seems to have the majority of their radio hits, while Disc 2 has fewer hits, but a lot of Journey love nevertheless. The really interesting thing about this band was even though they were amazingly popular, filling stadiums across the country left and right, they only charted a very small number of actual Hits. Being in the broadcasting business, it always bugged me that record sales had far less to do with a song making it up the Billboard charts than actual money. If sales were the only barometer, Journey's number of Chart-topping singles would certainly be a LOT larger.Covering from the early years to the last record recorded with Perry, this compilation ought to please most hard-core Journey fans and those new to their music alike. I am often interested in the state of radio these days as I listen to what qualifies as a 'Hit' song and I find myself constantly disappointed. Sure, there are some really catchy songs now and then, but what I simply do NOT see these days is the staying power a band like Journey has. For example, the number of radio stations that will STILL be playing 'Faithfully' and 'Don't Stop Believing' in another 20 years will dwarf the number of stations that will be playing Justin Bieber, Britney Spears and Miley Cyrus (that is if ANY stations will be suicidal enough to actually play any to begin with). Never did I think when I first heard 'Stone In Love' that I'd be rockin' out to it in my car STILL some 30 years later. Regardless of how much you love their music, there is NO doubt to their impact on the Rock 'N Roll genre...and from the popularity of their music all these years later, I don't see that diminishing any time soon.Journey fans, rejoice. Greatest Hits 1 & 2 is a collection VERY well worth having.

For those who feel that unless they own the ridiculously priced vacuums which "claim" no loss of suction and whatnot, why not just save yourself some money and purchase a model which actually works, has all the attachments you'll need, and is easy to operate and gives you all the bang for a lot less buck. Don't get me wrong, those expensive Dyson's and Rainbows all work, and in most cases, work really well...but are they truly WORTH the outrageous prices they cost? Not in my book. I realize there are many who would argue, but for MY money, the Dirt Devil Vigor Cyclonic vacuum gives all that for a microscopic amount in comparison.The pet hair attachment is simply brilliant. I've owned some stupidly expensive vacuums over the years, some which had attachments which had a mini rotating head similar to the brush which is at the bottom of your vacuum, and they were not nearly as well made or efficient as this one. Let me also add that with those other models, the mini attachment had to have its own motor in order to rotate the mini brush. This model manages to do it all with just plain suction. And it rotates FAST, too. Again, impressed.The hose which attaches to the main body at the bottom near the height adjustment has an interesting feature, when you pull it out, a swivel cap closes the hole. I'm not entirely sure why, or whether or not it actually contributes to the efficiency of it all, but it certainly seems to work well. Actually I think it stops anything from the main brush from shooting through while it continues to spin while you use the hose for other things. All in all, a pretty nifty idea which works quite well.The suction seems rather clean cut as well. Quite a lot of suction seems to power this device and it really does SUCK--but in a good way. Plenty of power as far as that goes.The height adjustment works really well, too...no complaints.When the vacuum is full, it is quite simple to pull out the holding bin and empty it. I'd recommend doing it away from wherever it is you want to stay clean seeing as there tends to be plenty of dust which accumulates as you let it drop. Keep that in mind, especially if you have anyone nearby who is sensitive to that kind of thing.One other thing: I LOVE the idea of being able to clean the filter myself rather than having to endlessly purchase more of them again and again if I want my vacuum to continue to work at top efficiency. While this may not be a new feature to the world of house cleaning, its the first model I've personally owned with this feature and find it to be a fantastic addition.In all, I am VERY satisfied with my Dirt Devil (which is a nice change seeing as the previous model I owned many years ago was VERY cheaply manufactured and it showed) and plan to tell my friends what a great buy it is...even though I received mine through the Vine program here at amazon.

There have been many things which have sparked acts of war, the shooting of Archduke Ferdinand is widely considered what sparked World War I and the sneak attack on Pearl Harbor dragged America into the Second World War...but the reality, over the course of history, simple words have sparked more wars than any other acts. Such is the power of words, which makes Lexicon such a tremendous novel...not only entertaining, but informative at the same time.Talk about a world class 'What If' scenario: what if a school existed which taught the skills of language to be used in such a way as to actually influence virtually everything in life? The REAL power comes in knowing how to form the rather random sounds together in such a way as to control the thoughts of others. This is what is taught to a very select few. The storyline essentially is a straight-forward sci-fi adventure tale--but not just ANY tale. Either the plot connects with you (as it did with me) or it won't. It seems from reading some of the reviews that those who read it either really enjoyed it or they thought it just missed the mark a bit. What would YOU do if you understood that sound placement could bring down entire civilizations? Its a staggering thought, and one I am grateful remains in the realm of sci-fi, but one which is utterly compelling to me.While the story is quite thought provoking, I can assure you that action and violence are not left in the backseat. If anything, the story moves at a very rapid clip and I believe contains just the right amount of story AND action. It held my interest all the way through, even though at some point, you're going to NEED to adjust your 'Reality Meter' in order to accept what is going on. There are more than one story lines going on as the novel progresses, which the author has under tight control, by the way. I enjoyed learning more about how language is used, and how those who are manipulating others (called Poets) must know more than mere words and sounds but actually know the person as well. Whether you liked the book or not there is no doubting the creativity on display within Lexicon. The plot was--IMO--quite ingenious.How much did I enjoy Lexicon? Let me end by saying this: I had never read Max Barry before, but after this I plan to search out ALL his previous works. Hope this helps.

The premise of Reboot really IS clever and pretty original in how its presented. Teens who have been resurrected shortly after death, but afterwards just aren't the same. They are kind of Government bounty hunters who listen and OBEY, without question. They no longer really live on with purpose. They do what they're told and for their hard work they are treated with virtually zero respect, or a distinct lack thereof...by almost everyone. Reboots retain less humanity the longer they were dead before being brought back. Wren was dead for 178 minutes, which reportedly makes her THE best Reboot because of her lack of emotions and efficient ability to do her job.Wren also has the job of training new Reboots. Her newest trainee Callum, wasn't dead for long before he was turned...and this shockingly disturbs Wren. But being the good little automaton she is, she continues to do her job as best she can to train the seemingly un-trainable. Before long, Callum is determined to be beyond training, and Wren is dispatched to eliminate him with extreme prejudice. Wren is a good Reboot, exceptional actually and has not once disobeyed ANY order for any reason...and yet, she feels compelled to do everything within her power to help Callum not only escape, but stay alive. Thus begins an awkward and truly original relationship--and adventure loaded with action and pure danger, not to mention plenty of terror.The obvious comparisons to The Hunger Games are plenty here and I can see why--however, let me stress that despite on the surface these books may share more than just a certain tone, there is MUCH more to Reboot than that, in fact, I'd go so far as to say I enjoyed it quite a bit more. The originality is a GREAT deal more than what The Hunger Games gave us (Come on, fighting to the death? There are literally DOZENS of stories written by tons of authors like Steven King which have VERY similar plots). Reboot is genuinely different (at least in my opinion), and aside from the quasi-uncomfortable romantic relationship, I found almost every single page one which truly made me want to continue reading...not an easy task as I believe I have ADRD (Attention Deficit Reading Disorder) and give up on novels MUCH quicker than I believe the average reader. Either you keep my interest or I simply give up and find something else to read right away. Congrats to Amy Tintera for keeping me satisfied all the way through.How much did I enjoy Reboot? I anxiously look forward to whatever Amy writes next. Hope this helps.

If you count yourself a fan of Clive Cussler, Michael Crichton, James Rollins or Jeremy Robinson and you haven't discovered Boyd Morrison yet, you really owe it to yourself to give him a shot. I discovered him through The Ark several years back and I've been a fan ever since. His previous novel 'The Roswell Conspiracy' wasn't even published here in the US (which really makes me disappointed in the publishers here) but thankfully I got a copy of the UK version and devoured it rather quickly.The hero for the bulk of Morrison's novels is Tyler Locke. Go ahead, get to know him, you'll be glad you did. His stories really accelerate quickly and usually has one foot in reality, despite how hard it may be to believe. This time the story centers around Loch Ness, and there is plenty to keep you on the edge of your seat. We start off in the United Kingdom and Charles Darwin formulates his famous 'theory' based in part by what he encounters in a mysterious body of water in Scotland. Next we move to a party being held ON the Eiffel Tower in Paris, which quickly turns into a terrorist attack which threatens much more than just a few lives. The technology featured is either real or very CLOSE to being real, which only helps the story flow in a more believable manner, despite all the supremely close-calls which Tyler and his former Pro Wrestling giant of a partner, Grant find themselves in.From one place on the globe to another, reading the Loch Ness Legacy is kind of like a cheap way to see the world without being hurt in the process. Bullets fly, unmanned drones attack and deadly science all play major roles in how the action continuously moves at the speed of a runaway Tomahawk missile. If you truly enjoy a few hours of pure escapism entertainment sprinkled with a healthy dose of adventure, mixed with a stellar plot which will hardly give you a chance to catch your breath, then this book really ought to be on your MUST READ list. The sooner you discover Boyd Morrison, the better. Trust me, I'm a reader...no really.

I've been quite surprised at the number of reviews which are anything less than complimentary of this series and Witch Wraith in particular. Sometimes I wonder if I read the same thing, but like anything else in life, opinions vary, and nowhere is that more obvious than reading reviews of books here at amazon.Yes, I can admit that Terry borrowed heavily from his own earlier books, chief of which was Elfstones--but that can either be a good or bad thing depending on whether or not the storyline 'clicked' with you. By my giving it five stars, you can guess where my thoughts are. Since I view the Elfstones as one of Terry's all-time best books, I really enjoyed reading about the events regarding the failing of the Forbidding, the consequences of letting it grow weaker, and the penalties for those who--even accidentally--enter into the world of the Demons. We have several stories to cycle between. From inside the Forbidding, again in the Four Lands, and of course, the quest to re-establish the Ellcrys in order to wall-away the Demons to where they belong. I've always found Terry's boundless imagination one of the things which really struck me personally, and it was working overtime here.What will the Ohmsfords legacy be by the end? What does the Ilse Witch have to do with helping the seemingly hopeless situation that faces our heroes? I believe if you think about it a little, you can wager a good guess and more than likely be right. Again, while others have regarded the inclusion of partial plotting from previous novels to be a mistake, here I found the familiar mixed with fresh storylines simply kept me turning the pages. I understand that not everyone will see my point of view as one which they share, and that's okay. What matters is what I personally think and feel, and in truth, that is ALL that matters, right? Read the reviews, but form your OWN opinion regardless of what I may believe--and don't let anyone tell you differently.I'll admit, the first book in this series was my favorite, but I still really enjoyed the two sequels. Being brought into the world of Shannara has always been a place where I feel welcome and happy, and I've discovered that things haven't changed much. I still love visiting. While I look forward to the time when Terry writes a stand-alone Epic Fantasy novel in the vein of the original three Shannara novels, I love his stuff enough that I'll accept it any way I can get it.In short, I love visiting even a portion of the world which Terry Brooks gives to us, and found this conclusion to have been satisfying and entirely worthwhile. Either way, I hope you get out of it what you are hoping for. Terry, you STILL amaze me after all these years. Thanks.

We have been really pleased with this set of headphones.  Our grandson comes over a lot and wants to play games either on my phone or my laptop and the noise and music gets to me after awhile... I mean you can only listen to so much Angry Birds music, right?  They are very comfortable and fit on my head as well as my grandson's.  I was amazed considering the very reasonable price, how good the sound is with these headphones.  They also help to block out sound.  I used them one night while I was working on my laptop late at night, listening to music while my husband slept soundly in the bed next to me.  It was wonderful that I could listen to music without bothering him.So far we have not had any trouble with the ear padding coming off.  The size is adjustable, the microphone is convenient and it comes in a very neat travel/protective bag so the kids can put it in their backpack without tearing them up.  The only slight problem I had was trying to adjust the volume with the button located on the wire... it took a few tries before I could get the volume down, but you can also adjust the volume on whatever device you've got it hooked to.  If you are listening to music through your phone and the phone rings, the music automatically shuts off while you answer the phone thru the mike.  My husband said he had no trouble hearing me when I used the mic.  So far we are impressed with this set of headphones.  Will get back with an update if anything changes but for now it's 5 stars for this pair of Sentey Headphones!

This was my first Richard Paul Evans book and all I can say is he has a new fan!  What a treat this book was...  although I had a pretty good idea where this story was going, it was still a great trip getting there.  Kim has not had a lot of luck in the romance department, yet her dream is to get her romance book published.  So she attends a romance writer's conference where she makes two new friends... Samantha and Zeke... one will entertain her and make her laugh and the other will cause her to look at herself and how she views her life in a totally different way. Kim also has a very close and loving relationship with her father who is key in helping Kim take those difficult steps towards the healing she so desperately needs. The ending pulls out every emotion and the writing is not only riveting but heartfelt and beautifully done.  The characters are well drawn and the revelations that Kim experiences, both from her time with Zeke at the writer's conference and the tender moments with her father, allow her to finally face her demons from the past. Zeke is a wonderfully drawn character and a man very easy to like, especially since he helps Kim to understand that she is indeed worthy of being loved. Also for those aspiring authors out there, since the story takes place primarily at a writer's conference, it will give you a peek at what it's like to try and get your book published!Engaging, moving, funny, tender, informative and with two great supporting characters in Kim's new friend Samantha and Kim's father Rob,  this book is a treat from start to finish and it might just help you believe that sometimes good things really do happen to good people, especially at Christmastime. Five Stars for Richard Paul Evans and The Mistletoe Inn.

I love Lindsay McKenna's normally action packed romance and have read quite a few of them.  But this one was a bit of a disappointment.  The prequel was fast paced and gritty and I expected the same from this first book in the new series.  It was not to be.  There is so much inner monologing that it was a distraction and slowed the pace of the story.  There was very little action and only one bedroom scene at the end.  Too much of the story focused on Lia's scars and Cav's childhood.  Basically this was an action romance with too little action and not enough romance.  Also there were quite a few mistakes in the Kindle version...missing words, etc.  Hopefully the rest of this new series will pick up... if not then I guess I will just reread the books from her Shadow Warrior series!

Unfortunately, hackers have the edge these days and there are more ways than ever to have your information stolen from you.  But at least with this product you have a fighting chance to protect yourself when you are the most vulnerable.  If you are in a crowded area like an airport or a sporting event for example, it's possible for hackers to sit there with a device that can scan personal information from people sitting around them, without anyone knowing.  That's what these little RFID envelopes can protect you from.  They fit perfectly over your credit card and the inside of the envelope blocks anyone's ability to get your info.  These envelopes are slim enough that they won't bulk up your wallet and considering what it is you're protecting, it's worth the extra couple of seconds it takes to slip them out of the envelope when you need to use them.This packet comes with 10 credit card size envelopes and two passport size envelopes and should be a must for anyone who travels a lot...especially overseas.  These days it pays to be smart and this product can help you do it!  Five stars and my hearty recommendation.**I was asked to use this product then give my honest opinion in an effort to help consumers make more informed purchase decision.  No other form of compensation took place.

This is a really cool little wireless device that will make your home BBQing a little bit easier.  There are two little units... one has the probe attached to it that you stick in the meat you are grilling to keep track of the temperature.  It is attached to the unit by a heat resistant cord and the unit has a little stand on it so you can set it up by your grill.  The other unit is wireless and really cool and is the half that you keep with you in the house so you don't have to get up so many times during the football game which is especially nice if it's 110* in the shade or when your wife decides she has to have something done on the grill and there is a foot of snow on the ground.  (Hey... I've done that to my husband...)  The second unit will tell you what the temperature should be for whatever meat you select... ground beef, ground poultry, beef, veal, chicken, pork, poultry, lamb, fish, etc and you can indicate whether you want it well done, medium or rare and everything in between.  It comes with a timer (in case you really get caught up in the game) that will remind you to check it and/or let you know when your meat has hit the temperature you and this handy little gadget have decided is exactly the temp you want!Of course you can use this to test meat from the oven too... you just open up the oven door, stick the probe in your meatloaf, or what have you and you get a nice clear digital readout of the meat's internal temp.  It's easy to use, takes batteries and will help you in your quest to be the best outdoor chef in the neighborhood!  Five stars for the ThermoPro Wireless Meat Thermometer.** I was asked to use this product then write an honest and unbiased review in an effort to help consumers make a more informed purchase decision.  No other form of compensation took place.

It's also easy to clean off with a wet towel.  A great addition to the supplies in my car and my grandchildren love being able to reach the books, wipes and bottled water I keep in the car for them. Emily March has struck gold with her Eternity Springs series and Heartsong Cottage is one of the most moving and heart wrenching stories to date. Dealing with child abduction and abuse is a very difficult topic and March handles it honestly which means at times the book is difficult to read.  Daniel is for the most part a sympathetic character and you feel for him and the loss of his family but it's obvious even ten years after the fact that he still has some major healing to do.The heroine of the story, Shannon, has some baggage of her own and is hiding in Eternity Springs, hoping to elude her stalker.  When she and Daniel meet at Gabi and Flynn's wedding, sparks fly and before you know it, they are both looking back on their one night stand with mixed emotions.  But Eternity Springs is a place of love and healing so these two are exactly where they need to be, surrounded by all the people we have come to know and love from past books.  This story will make you sad, make you laugh and make you believe in love and second chances.  March's next book in the Eternity Springs series Reunion Pass comes out in April and it looks like two more of the town's special people will find love and I have no doubt we will enjoy the ride!  Five stars for Emily March and Heartsong Cottage.

Hallelujah! Finally I have a way to keep my grandchildren out of the cabinets where I keep all my cleaning supplies.  These straps are very effective... especially on the refrigerator.  They did not come with directions, so it took us a minute to figure out exactly how they work, but after that it was  breeze.  I like that they are size adjustable too.  Now I can keep them out of my fridge too since they have discovered exactly where Nana keeps all the snacks and Capri Suns! One word of warning... my daughter used these on some cabinets that she had refinished and painted and when she pulled them off the paint came with it!  So use caution when attaching these straps to a painted surface.  Otherwise it's a great product that will help give you peace of mind and keep the little ones in your life safe.

I LOVE this diffuser and here's why. First released in 2004 under the title When Christmas Comes,  Trading Christmas is a humorous and touching story about four different people who are unexpectedly thrown together for Christmas.  It's typical Debbie Macomber fare with all the trappings of the season in a simple modern day romance.Widow Emily Springer is disappointed when she learns that her daughter Heather has decided she isn't coming home for Christmas.  Sad at the thought of being alone, Emily decides to trade her home in the little town of Leavenworth, WA for a condo in Boston and surprise Heather with a visit over Christmas.  But it's Emily who gets the surprise when she arrives to find that Heather has made plans of her own which include roaring off to Florida with a questionable biker and his less than stellar friends.  Emily is shocked and disappointed when she realizes she will be alone in a strange condo in a strange town for the holiday and things look bleak... that is until the door bell rings and the owner's brother Ray shows up.Charles Brewster is a Harvard professor who is desperately seeking a place to hide over Christmas since he has no desire to do anything but work on writing his history textbook over the holidays.  Thinking a town called Leavenworth would offer peace and quiet, he has no idea that he has just agreed to spend two weeks in a house swap in a place that appears to be Christmas Central... complete with snow, lights, sleigh rides and happy children building snowmen.  In short... it's his version of hell.  That is until Emily's friend Faith Kerrigan arrives to surprise her for the holidays and instead finds a very Scrooge like professor has taken over her friend's house.It's an entertaining scenario as these four people stumble upon each other and are forced to spend the holiday together.  None of them have had any type of relationship for awhile so all four are surprised to find how much they begin to enjoy their unexpected roommates and suddenly it becomes more about enjoying everything the Christmas season has to offer rather than facing it all alone.  While the main theme of the story surrounds these four mature adults, Emily's daughter has some growing up and soul searching to do too and it isn't long before she realizes that the traditions of Christmas mean more to her than she thought!Also included is a story Macomber published back in 1991 about a man and woman who reconnect after eighteen years and find that the pretend marriage they had when she was 8 and he was 10 might have been a prelude to the best Christmas either one has ever had.  While Cait is sure she's in love with her boss (even if he doesn't know she's alive), it's old friend and construction worker Joe who gets her heart pounding with kisses that are a whole lot more enjoyable than the little peck Joe gave her all those years ago.  But he is sooo not the type Catlin has in mind for her future... or is he?Two simple, warm hearted and humorous romances by Macomber plus the first chapter of Sheila Roberts' upcoming holiday romance entitled Christmas on Candy Cane Lane from her Life In Icicle Falls series due out in November makes this book a sure bet!

For those of you who are environmentally conscientious, these jumbo plastic reusable K-cups will help you sleep better at night and will be waiting to help you wake up in the morning!  I love my Keurig and I love my K-cups and the variety and ease of popping in whatever I'm in the mood for when I get up every morning... whether it's tea, hot apple cider or hot chocolate.  I do realize that sadly it's a bit wasteful and my husband has found that he doesn't mind using these reusable K cups.  They seem to be fairly well made and if you like to play around with the strength of your coffee and don't mind the mess of cleaning out the cups after you use them, then these are a great invention and they are dishwasher safe.  For me, I like the ease and convenience of the pre made K cups and I can't do cider or hot chocolate with these things, but for my coffee drinking husband... its works.  Be aware though that these cups do NOT fit into all Keurig machines so read the description carefully to make sure it will fit in your specific model machine.

I don't smoke and I don't drink coffee but I do drink hot and iced tea and that combined with natural aging has caused my teeth to be less white than they could be.  My dentist charges roughly  $400.00 for a whitening treatment (with a $200.00 special he runs every January) but that's still more than I am willing to pay.  So when I was asked to use this product for an honest review, I was happy to do it. You leave them on for roughly 20 - 30 minutes but that part is easy... I just watched tv or read a book in bed and let these little strips do their job! No other form of compensation took place.

Another Christmas winner by one of my favorite authors, Linda Lael Miller, Christmas in Mustang Creek is a fun, whimsical romance about the next (possibly the last?) Brides of Bliss County.  This time around we find Charlotte Morgan (affectionately called Charlie) home from her fast paced job in New York City.  She returns to Mustang Creek and the beautiful old, large and little bit drafty, home she grew up in with her beloved great aunt Geneva.  Charlie knows that her aunt Geneva is having trouble with her memory due to the early stages of dementia, so she thinks she is prepared for this new stage of her life.  What she isn't prepared for is the two unexpected house guests that seem determined to turn her world upside down, or maybe right side up...she can't quite decide.Jaxon Locke arrives in Mustang Creek to start a new job as a Veterinarian.  Glad to be out of New York, the only things Jax misses is the woman he loves... Charlie Morgan.  When he finds himself with the opportunity to move to Charlie's home town, it seems like fate is giving them another chance and when a little white haired lady conveniently named Millicent Klozz offers him room and board in Charlie's huge home... how can he refuse?  Mrs. Klozz is heaven sent and cooks like an angel.  She also seems to be aware of exactly what everyone is thinking and just exactly what it is they need to  be happy.  So between Jaxon, her Aunt Geneva and the mysterious Mrs. Klozz, Charlie might just be in for the best Christmas of her life... if she'll only take a chance on love.It's a warm and simple holiday romance with all the things that make Christmas stories such a pleasure to curl up with... a beautiful setting, snow, adorable animals... of course... this is LL Miller after all... hot chocolate and romance with a handsome guy who seems heaven sent and a woman who has to decide if she wants to risk it all for love.  Five stars for Christmas in Mustang Creek (The Brides of Bliss County).

This is a great mini lantern that was VERY useful on our last camp out.  It's wonderful that if the light starts to dim, you can just crank the handle to recharge it.  It compresses small enough to carry comfortably in your pocket so it's available when you need it.  You simply press the button if you want a flashlight type spot light, or it will expand to a lantern shape like you see in the picture and it puts out a decent amount of light in two different levels, high or low.  We set it on our picnic table and actually played a board game solely by the light of this little lantern.  It also has a very handy handle if you want to carry it around in it's lantern state.  I also comes with a USB charger although ours came fully charged and we have not had to recharge it yet.  Just a great little lantern for camping, home emergencies, your kids' room or anywhere else where you might need a quick bit of light that you can carry around and recharge with a simple turn of the crank if you are without power.  Our family really loves this little orange lantern... we call it Ollie!  :-)

Read on Kindle this book seemed a little long to me but none the less it grabbed my attention and kept it throughout.  That's one of the nice things about the way McKenna writes, you never know when you are going to suddenly be in the middle of a tense life or death scene that has your characters using all their wits and talents to stay alive.  The heroine Cathy was put through so much it's hard to believe that she didn't have a nervous breakdown... she comes close but I never would have been able to withstand everything she did from her commanding officers and clearly defined bad guys Major Louise Lane and her XO Kate Ingram.  The hero Jim Boland is everything you want a hero to be... handsome, strong and dedicated to his men... and to Cathy.Used as pawns in a political tug of war that reaches all the way to Washington DC, Cathy and Jim find themselves fighting to stay alive and stay true to their core values as they are forced to choose between what's right and what's expedient.  Both are sympathetic characters who have suffered in the past and you find yourself hoping that circumstances beyond their limited control won't keep them apart.  McKenna has a few inaccuracies when using military jargon and protocol which can be distracting at times, but the plot is solid, the action tense and believable and the romance heartfelt and touching.  Basically it's everything you are looking for in a military romance and sets the stage for her Shadow Warrior series, again about a group of women who are determined to prove that women can be successful in front line combat roles.  The book that follows this one is about Cathy and Jim's daughter Morgan and her life as a Marine Corps Captain and sniper searching out the bad guys in the Hindu Kush.  Note:  This book was first released under the title Valkyrie in the year 2000.

They wash and wear well and seem to keep their color.  They also feel light on your foot, not heavy like some other athletic type socks I have tried before.  I have no complaints about these socks and wouldn't hesitate to buy from this company in the future.  Five stars for DARE Color 6 pack of women's socks.

This is a very useful, user friendly pitcher that I love making iced tea in.  The core is very convenient to use... either by filling it with water and then sticking it in the freezer (you have to attach the lid so the water won't spill) or simply putting ice cubes into it.  It's nice that you don't have to worry about the melting ice diluting your beverage. In a moderately temped room the frozen core kept the tea cool for roughly an hour.  It's also nice to be able to insert the infuser core with lemon wedges or any other fruit that you want to slowing and continually flavor your drink.  It would be awesome for Sangria... all the taste without chasing the fruit around in your glass or pitcher.  There were only basic instructions printed on the outside of the box but like I said it's pretty easy to figure out.  You can probably put it in the dishwasher, but I wash it by hand.  I was able to pour the hot water into the pitcher to melt the sugar for my tea, then I filled the remainder of the pitcher with cold water and the acrylic handled it just fine.  I'm satisfied all the way around!  Five stars for the Perlli Fruit Infusion Pitcher.*I was asked to use this product and give my honest opinion in an attempt to help consumers make a more informed purchase decision.  No other from of compensation took place.

Fans of Mary Balogh and the historical romance genre are sure to want to add this book to their collection.  In the time honored tradition, the author brings us a love story that will touch your heart. The heroine Imogene lives a shadow of a life, chained to the belief that due to events in her past she is not deserving of the kind of happiness that love can bring.  A widow for the past 8 years, Imogene has no idea that the new Earl of Hardford is about to descend on her quiet corner of the world and make her wish for things she has long denied herself.Percy Hayes is bored with the perfect life he has been blessed with and decides on a whim to visit his newly acquired (two years ago) estate in the remote region of Cornwall, England.  A tall, dark, handsome and intelligent man, he has lived a life of relative ease with every comfort imaginable... yet an emptiness remains,  until he meets a woman who has seen horrors he can only imagine.  Percy and Imogene's relationship at times is an exercise in frustration and it seems to take an extraordinarily long amount of time before they recognize their relationship for what it truly is. Their passion is worth the wait though. The dialogue is realistic and takes you to another time and place and you find yourself hoping that this lone female of the survivors club will finally lay down her burden of guilt and embrace a life worth living.Strong characters, a variety of interesting family members, a smuggling side plot and a few too many animals to keep track of, Only A Kiss is a satisfying journey for anyone who loves historical romance at its best.  Five stars.

It's a Wonderful Wife is a strange title that doesn't roll easily off the tongue and although I am a big Janet Chapman fan... this book was not her usual satisfying read.  Having said that however, I realized that the book held my interest even though I could not relate to the two lead characters... Cadi and Jesse as easily as I usually do with Chapman's novels.  The heroine Cadi is just a bit too naive (she is amazed that the hero's assistant is black when she meets him since he didn't "sound" black on the phone... Jesse forgives the insensitive remark since Cadi has never actually talked with a black person before!)  I'm all for having a sheltered heroine if the story calls for it but that was a stretch.  The plot itself seemed a little off kilter as did some of the reactions of the players.  People familiar with the first two Sinclair stories in this trilogy will have an easier time following things than I did.Quick synopsis... billionaire Sinclair brother Jesse decides to build a beautiful home on the island he has purchased in Maine but when he arrives he finds himself attracted to the daughter of the deceased owner who is gifted in making models of home designs.  Mayhem and misunderstandings arise when Cadi's fake boyfriend is caught in a compromising situation opening the door for Jesse to make his moves on the lovely and innocent Cadi... who does have a strong will though and a mind of her own along with the strange habit of talking to her body parts.  When a loan shark thug sets his sights on Cadi, Jesse decides it will be his job to protect her since he is fairly certain she is the Mrs. Right he has been looking for.The dialogue between Cadi and Jesse had me smiling more than once... I always enjoy the snappy come backs as two people begin a relationship and begin learning about each other.  It's just the plot and lack of chemistry between Cadi and Jesse until almost the end that kept this story from being a truly engaging read.  Chapman is still one of the best in the art of romance storytelling, but this one just lacked her usual bit of magic... both literally and figuratively.  Four Stars for Janet Chapman and It's A Wonderful Wife.

This book is a sad, introspective look at one young man's journey through the horrors of WWII and how it affected him for the rest of his life.  Written through letters to his son Harold from later in his life, it's clear that the 17 year old country boy had no idea what would be in store for him when he illegally enlisted in the Navy.  Forced to endure conditions that would test even the strongest of full grown men, J.P. found himself in a constant fight to stay alive during the two years of his enlistment.  When freedom and a return to home beckoned, J.P. finds that he is not the same person who left home and he brought a most unwelcome  companion home with him...PTSD in the form of raging alcoholism.  Unable to hold a job, control his temper or maintain relationships, J.P. struggles through a life of addiction that is directly related to his time as a "Sailor Man".A bit uneven at times, yet non the less interesting and thought provoking, Sailor Man will make you think twice about the sacrifices so many of our young men made when they felt the call to leave home and make their mark on the world by defending their country.  Unfortunately the price so many of them like J.P. Nunnally paid can be measured in the heartache and troubled lives that dogged them for the rest of their days.

This is a very nice alternative to carrying a thick leather wallet.  Because of its material it's very lightweight and has places in it for roughly six credit cards and some folded bills.  It's very slim and attractive looking and would fit perfectly in a man's suit coat pocket if he wants to avoid the back pocket bulge in his suit pants.  My husband uses it while he is out running and wants to have ID on him but doesn't want to lug his entire wallet while he exercises.  We also found it very convenient when we went to Disney World.  He slipped it in the pocket of his cargo shorts, closed the button on the shorts and hardly new it was there all day.  He didn't have to worry about pick pockets or about it accidentally slipping out of his pocket while he's climbing in and out of rides or lugging strollers on and off the bus.  And it was the perfect size to carry his essential cards and some cash.  It could also be used to carry business cards and would fit easily into any briefcase or computer bag.  The outside is shiny and will leave fingerprints, but it would also be pretty with initials carved onto it.  A good solid purchase at a good price.**I was asked to use this product then write an honest and unbiased review.  No other form of compensation took place.

This is a very comfortable sleep mask.  The others that we have used were not this thick and soft feeling.  It does a great job blocking out the light, the strip of fabric that goes over the nose if very comfortable and the adjustable velcro head strap makes it a comfortable fit for any size adult head.  My husband said this is the most comfortable and effective sleep mask he has ever used and it folds up nicely and is very light so it would be easy to slip in your pocket or purse if you are traveling.  A good product at a good price, I recommend it without hesitation.**I was asked to use this product then write an honest and unbiased review in an effort to help consumers make a more informed purchase decision.  No other form of compensation took place.

This is a wonderful, well written yet simple account of one family's journey through the disaster that was Katrina.  This author has a very clean, clear way of writing that makes you feel like you are sitting down talking to a friend.
