The chapters are dated so you can follow the progression of the event along with Karlin's family and you can feel the frustration right along with her as you read of their endless hours in the car on a highway going nowhere, their inability to get the most basic of necessities like food and water for their children and coping with the ever present question... what do we do now... where do we go from here?All of us probably remember the horrible scenes from New Orleans but within a week or two, our thoughts drift to other news but for the millions of people like the Karlins whose lives were forever impacted by the ravishes of this monster storm, the nightmare continued not just for days, weeks or even months, but for years. At first their needs are basic and immediate... get out of the path of the storm... along with the millions of other people on the Gulf Coast... but where to go and how to get there?  There's no power, no water, no stores, no gas, no ATMs... what about her husband's job... where will the kids go to school... is the house still standing?  Is it flooded?  We need the valuables from the safety deposit box... the bank...?  underwater.  Their medical records... underwater... the kids school records... underwater.  And so it goes as family after family try to pick up what's left of their lives in what's left of New Orleans.Humorous, touching, heartfelt, amazing, sad and at times astonishing, Below the Water Line:  Getting Out and Going Back by Lisa Karlin is a fascinating read about how vulnerable we are to mother nature and how strong the individual spirit can be in times of crisis.  An outstanding read you won't soon forget.  Five Stars!**I was given a copy of this book in exchange for an honest and unbiased review which I have given.  I do not know this author and no other form of compensation took place.

Without a doubt this is the hit toy of the summer!  It's a durable child's megaphone that they can speak into and includes a very LOUD horn like you might hear on a firetruck.  When I agreed to use these megaphones and write a review, I had no idea how much my grandchildren were going to love this toy... but they do.  Their parents, the neighbors and Granddad.... not so much.  But it's all in the name of fun and it's a much better outside toy than inside (did I mention that it's loud?)  It has a great fold up handle and a strap that allows them to carry it over their shoulder.  Do be aware though as with any toy that has a longish strap that it could be a  strangulation hazard for younger children (under three).  Our one year old decided to slip the strap around her neck and then roll around on our bed... not a good combination but luckily I was right there and no harm was done.  It's no different than any other toy that's inappropriate for younger children and the older kids (three and older) really love it.  We have both the fire and police megaphone and they love both but they think the siren on the police one is better than the straight horn sound on the fire megaphone but they happily trade back and forth and I can recommend both for hours of fun.  When you pick up the four double A batteries each require, I'd also grab some earplugs...

If you are a grandparent and you think back on the days when your kids made so much noise you thought you were going to lose your mind... then you will appreciate these kids megaphones for your grandchildren.  The kids will LOVE them... the parents... not so much.  We solved the problem in our house by making them an outside toy only and that seemed to work.  The necessity of this is because this thing is LOUD which is exactly what the kids are wanting and expecting when they are playing policeman/woman and want their playmates to HALT!  It's made of a very sturdy plastic with a fold down handle to grip and the siren sounds very authentic... and LOUD.  You will always know where your child is when they are playing with this toy.  My grandchildren really love them... we have the fireman megaphone too so you will definitely get your money's worth.  Do be careful with very young children though... our one year old slipped the strap around her neck and started rolling around on the bed... it was an accident waiting to happen but it just calls for due diligence like any other toy not meant for younger children.  Ages three and up will be safe with this toy.  Five Stars for Dress Up America and the Police Officer's Megaphone.**I was asked to use this product then write an honest and unbiased opinion in an effort to help consumers make a more informed purchase decision.  No other form of compensation took place.

I have used  several Brainwavz products and have been pleased with every single one.  This is a company that keeps trying to give its customers the best product on the market and so far they seem to be doing a great job of it.  These earphones are everything you would want them to be... they are comfortable, easy to use, attractive and most importantly the sound that comes through them is brilliant, clear and even.  I really like the flat cord... it looks stylish and doesn't tangle as easily.  You can find all the product details described on the product page so I won't repeat them here, but my husband and I have both been very pleased with these earphones.  Five Stars!**I was asked to use this product in exchange for an honest and unbiased opinion which I have given.  If I had any trouble with the product I wouldn't hesitate to state it, but I did not.  No other form of compensation took place.

The Love Inspired Suspense series is a treat for anyone who wants a heart thumping mystery romance without all the questionable language and love scenes so in depth you find yourself blushing while you read.  It takes a talented author to deliver a compelling story without those trappings and Carol J.Post does a great job in Hidden Identity.Meagan is a likeable character who is hiding from her past and the man who would like to see her dead.  Hunter Kingston is a handsome cop and a man of faith with his own ghosts from the past who is determined to help Meagan stay safe after her cover is accidentally blown by a high profile rescue she is involved with.  As Hunter and Meagan circle each other, both are wary of becoming too involved but when Meagan's life is threatened time and again, it brings them closer together as they fight not only their growing attraction to one another, but the unknown person who appears to be stalking Meagan's every move.Fast paced with a few twists and turns and a tender romance between two injured people who really deserve a break when it comes to issues of the heart,  Hidden Identity is a satisfying read and a welcome addition to the Love Inspired Suspense by Harlequin.**I was given a copy of this book in exchange for an honest and unbiased opinion which I have given.  I do not know this author and no other form of compensation took place.

This metal patriotic star is made to be put out in your yard, but since the colors matched the decor of my guest room, I ordered it to go inside and it looks great.  It comes in two halves that you have to line up together and then insert the little flaps to keep them connected.  When it first arrived I could not get the holes and the flaps to align no matter how hard I tried which is the reason why I gave this product 4 stars instead of 5.  My husband was able to get it together though and after that I was pleased with how it looked.  It comes with two poles that can be inserted into the tips of the two bottom points of the star to be placed in the ground or it also has a twine loop at the top which is what I used to hang it on the wall above my guest room bed.  It's very light and was fine on a standard size nail.  With the kinds of wind we have around my house, I can see this thing taking off to Kansas during a storm if it was placed outside so I guess you will have to judge for yourself according to the kind of weather you get if the star will stay secure in your yard.  Without measuring I would say that the sticks you place in the ground are around 6-8 inches long.It's an attractive Americana decor piece at a decent price that can be used inside or outside of your home.  Would I recommend it to a friend... yes.  Would I order it again... yes.

This is a cute book and the first one I have ever read that was written by a sweater.  I was afraid that I wouldn't be able to relate to Sophie since our lives are so different... I mean she is a sweater and I am a middle aged mother and grandmother who loves to read and write and play with my grandchildren.  But it seems that Sophie and I have a lot in common and as I read about her fascinating story from the factory to the warehouse, to the store and then finally to her special person's house, I realized that a lot of the feelings this beautiful little sweater has are ones that we all feel at one time or another.Sophie has a lot to learn as she goes through life trying to make sense of the world around her and how she fits in.  She is basically a happy sweater but finds herself sad, lonely and even a little depressed at times, especially when she finds out that she is an UGLY sweater!  With the help of her friends, Sophie learns that she is in all the ways that matter a beautiful sweater and it's up to her to look at the bright side of life.A delightful story appropriate for children, teens and adults,  Diary of an Ugly Sweater is author Cassie Eubank's way of reminding readers that the power of living a truly happy life lies within each of us and the attitudes we do or do not embrace every day and she does it with creativity, style and humor.  An upbeat little book sure to make every reader feel empowered by the idea that we can create our own happiness.  Five stars for Cassie Eubank and Diary of an Ugly Sweater.**I was given a copy of this book in exchange for an honest and unbiased opinion which I have given.  I do not know this author and no other form of compensation took place.

I guess it's just going to take greater literary minds than mine to figure this book out.  I'm with reviewer J.C. on this one... I just could not wrap my mind around the point of this story.  I'm sure that some will find great symbolism and meaning in this book, but I am not one of them.  The scenes jump around and circumstances change with little to no warning which is confusing.  One minute Mary/Maria is at home, the next minute... poof she's gone... on to another life.  One minute Linda is home cooking, the next thing we know she's hanging out having sex with a bunch of hippies! First Tony hates having Linda there... then with no explanation he suddenly looks upon her as a daughter!  Where is the transition here?  Why was Linda's character even prehistoric.... it had no bearing on the story one way or the other and wouldn't her appearance have caused some attention as they walked down the street?  And I'm totally not getting the description of this book as humorous.  Not only did I not laugh once ( and I have a good sense of humor) but I don't think I even smiled while reading this story.I wish I had better news to report about this book.  I think author Molly Rainer writes well but this particular effort just did not work for me.  Not every book appeals to every reader... maybe you will find it humorous and empowering... sadly I did not.*  Three stars for Linda and Mary.*I was given this book in exchange for an honest and unbiased review which I have given.  I do not know this author and no other form of compensation took place.

What a cute book!  Yia Yia (not sure exactly how to pronounce that) is a grandma with a dozen grandchildren and a high spirit of adventure!  When she decides to share her wild excursions and her every day life with her faithful (if somewhat prissy) pooch Lucey,  Yia Yia's grands and we readers are in for a treat.  Yia Yia's wacky friend Shirley comes along for the ride sometimes and ups the ante on the "crazy" part of their adventures.Written in a  "tongue in cheek style" and all in the spirit of fun (translation - don't try these adventures at home kids)... author Patricia Linaris is out to make her readers smile and shake their heads and she succeeds splendidly.  This is a book that can be enjoyed by anyone but kids in the 9-12 year age range especially will enjoy it.  I enjoyed it and I'm an adult!  One fun grandma, her crazy friend and a prissy little pooch out for high adventure equals 5 stars for Patricia Linaris and The Misadventures of Yia Yia and Lucey.**  I was given this book in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion which I have given.  I do not know this author and no other form of compensation took place.

I was given a copy of this book to read  for my honest and unbiased opinion and since  I am a teacher for the visually impaired I looked forward to reading it. Unfortunately the reality was something a little less than what I hoped for.  The premise of the book is a good one, but the simplistic writing makes it very difficult to enjoy the story.  The characters are flat and impossible to identify with, the plot is weak and the general flow is very choppy.  The sentences are written almost as if by a person whose first language is not English.  For example:  "I do not understand what you are saying" instead of  "I don't understand what you're saying".  It makes the sentences very stilted and unnatural sounding.I wish I could give this book a better rating and it was interesting when Gloria tried to teach Anna to use her other senses beyond her vision but as a whole the book was a disappointment. Two plus stars for Auditory Viewpoint.

We've come a long way in terms of self care in the privacy of our homes and this easy and convenient way to find out if the stork is circling is a perfect example how our lives have changed in the last 50 plus years.  It's simple (you pee in a cup), easy (you put the strip into the pee cup as opposed to peeing all over your hand while you desperately try to make sure strip meets stream), convenient (you can do this in the privacy of your home and keep the strips in your bathroom), economical (with 20 strips to a box at this price you don't have to feel guilty about checking AGAIN... just in case), accurate (without keeping a log, I have to assume their claims of accuracy are correct), safe (I'm not sure how you can injure yourself in this process except maybe to lean over too far while you're filling your pee cup and fall on your head) and it tells you what you want to know... when you want to know it... as in right now!  So if you're worried (wow...maybe I shouldn't have had that last Margarita...) or you've been hoping and praying for a new little bundle of joy (or another tax deduction as my husband always said) then here's your answer.  Simplicity, privacy and convenience... right at a time in your life when you need all three the most!  Five Stars!**I was asked to use this product in exchange for an honest and unbiased review which I have given in an effort to help consumers make a more informed purchase decision.  No other form of compensation took place.

My daughter-in-law has been using these and has been pleased with the  results.  She said the cost is very reasonable and there are 20 strips in the pack which is convenient.  They are easy to read and she likes peeing into a cup rather than holding the strip and peeing on her hand!  The cup should be as sterile as possible and she uses the strips in the morning when her urine is the most concentrated after sleeping all night when she wants to check and see if she is ovulating.  A good product at a good price!

This is a cute, fun little kit that I enjoyed using with my grandchildren.  This kit is exactly as it appears in the picture.  We had a little bit of trouble scraping the clear seal off each section of paint, but once we got past that we had a great time being "artistic"  and drawing on each others faces!  There are some sample pictures of animal faces you can draw located on the back of the box, but I looked some more up on line so we had some other ideas of ways to paint your face! The child should be old enough to be able to hold the little paint brush and foam applicators but they can always use their fingers if that proves too difficult.  It is soft on the skin and cleans up easily.  The kit comes with one paintbrush, two round sponges and two little foam applicator wands.  You just add a little water and start creating.  Obviously the paint is non toxic.  The kit is a little smaller than I thought it would be but it was certainly big enough for an afternoon of fun!  Five stars for Beetastic's  Kids Face Paint Kit.**I was asked to use this product then give my honest and unbiased opinion in an effort to provide consumers with information that will help in their purchase decision.  No other form of compensation took place.

Against the Tide is a good addition to author Kat Martin's long standing and successful Against the.... series and I always look forward to the next story in line about these tough, rugged and honest alpha males and the smart, feisty women they get tangled up with.  This book is no exception and has the beautiful setting of Alaska that has a charm all its own.The only reason I didn't give this book five stars is that it moves a little slowly and there is not a lot of action til toward the end, even though the entire novel starts off with the murder of hero Rafe Brodie's first mate.  Rafe and the beautiful but intensely private Olivia Chandler circle each other for awhile then finally decide the attraction is too strong to deny and begin a relationship that has some obstacles to overcome... the biggest of which is that Olivia is not who she claims to be.  The sex scenes are hot and well written... like all of Martin's novels and you can count on characters that are easy to like and a story that will keep your interest.  I've read all of Kat Martin's books and this one isn't bad by any means, but it's still not as good as some of the others she's written that had me on the edge of my seat with one action scene after another... like Against the Night... my favorite one.  Will I come back for more with the next Martin release of Into the Fury in February?  Absolutely!

We love Minnie Mouse in our house so this was a perfect find for our littlest granddaughter.  Since we are always traveling to each others houses for meals and I babysit quite a bit, this is a perfect solution to keeping our little one safe, happy and contained while she is eating and the convenience can't be beat.  It will fit on almost any standard dining room or desk chair.  The tray is removable and easy to clean and our one year old likes to set her bottle or sippy cup in the drink holder.  There is a belt across and between the legs to keep her seated and it's just so easy to pack it up and take it anywhere!  We have been very pleased with this chair and it's the perfect solution if you're short on space or need something that's easy to take with you... our baby girl loves it ... so 5 stars it is for Disney's First Years Minnie Booster Seat!

My four year old granddaughter has inherited her mother's American Girl Doll and is just now taking interest in changing the doll's clothes every five minutes so when I needed a gift for her birthday, I found these outfits on Amazon and ordered four different sets.  This set is especially cute... it has a white shirt, jean type leggings, rain boots, a rain coat and hat and a very cute little umbrella with a kitty face on it. My granddaughter was very excited and didn't waste a second putting all this on "her baby".  It was especially cute since it rained all day yesterday and they made quite a pair.  I want to stress that these are NOT clothes made by the American Girl company and as such they are much less expensive than what you would pay for an actual American Girl outfit.  The quality may not be quite as good, but it's definitely not bad either and since my granddaughter tends to be a bit rough on her toys, I'd rather pay more reasonable prices while she is still young and doesn't know the difference.  The selection was nice too... I also ordered her a cute swimsuit with cap and goggles, a ballerina dress with ballet slippers and a blue sparkly dress that looks very much like Elsa's from Frozen.  She was thrilled with each and every outfit... so it's a win win for everyone!

This is a great little picnic table for the kids.  It can seat six small kids, the construction is sturdy and it's easy to put together with helpful instructions including photos(All you need is a Phillips head screwdriver).  It's attractive and my grandchildren love the umbrella which easily shades the entire table.  This table can be used indoor as well as outdoors, wipes up easily with a wet towel and can be used for playtime, art time or snack time and there is room for everyone!  My grandchildren are ages 6, 4, 2 and 1 and the six and four and two year old fit very comfortably with plenty of room between them and the one year old is able to sit at the table too.  Right now it's in my kitchen, but I can definitely see that it will get a lot of use out on our deck and in the yard.  Happy kids and a great product at a good price delivered right to my door... doesn't get any better than that!

I have always loved Lindsay McKenna's action romances based on members of the US military, most of whom in recent books have all been SEALS stationed in Afghanistan.  She is ex-military herself so she knows the lingo and she is skilled at setting up tense survival situations where these men and women have to fight the enemy at every turn.  McKenna is also very adept at taking the reader through the intense emotions of these romances that develop in the heat of the battle.  The characters in Running Fire are appealing, especially the hero Kell.  Physically he is an exceptional specimen of a man and he has the courage, bravery, insight and wisdom needed to help the shattered and broken Leah survive not only a horrifying helicopter crash, but the scars of her past abusive marriage that continue to threaten her.  Never expecting to fall in love, Kell and Leah find themselves growing closer and hoping with each passing day that they can make it back to camp BRAVO before the Taliban close in on them.  And since Leah's vengeful ex-husband will be waiting for her when they get back, it's going to take a whole lot of skill to keep their budding relationship under wraps and keep Leah safe at the same time.A fast paced, sensitive story about two people who find each other and fall in love in the most unlikely of circumstances and are determined to triumph over their current dangerous predicament as well as demons from the past that threaten their life together.  Another great addition to the Shadow Warrior series of military action romances that McKenna is so good at.  Five stars for Running Fire.

If you go by the picture only, you might be led to believe that this hanger/hook is larger than it really is.  But the dimensions of the product are clearly stated so when it arrived it was about the size I thought it would be.  I like that it is small and compact and have chosen to use it to hang my sets of keys and two of my aprons on it and place it in my kitchen.  It's attractive, simple to put up and feels sturdy enough to hold anything but the most heavy of objects.  Certainly it can hold purses, belts, jackets, keys, small kitchen items, etc.  I like the high gloss black metal too.**I was asked to use this product and give an honest and unbiased review in an effort to help potential consumers make a more informed purchase decision.  No other form of compensation took place.

There is a lot to be said for being a woman.  We get to primp and play dress up, we get to know the singular pain and joy of giving birth, we get to appreciate the uniqueness of our bodies and the comforts it can provide for us and the people we love.  We can experience the satisfaction of staying home to nurture our children, or the thrill of success in the business world.  We can even decide to do both at once or neither at all and be brilliant in the doing! But just as it is with men, there are downsides to being a woman too and authors Douglas Ginter and Dr. Jason Sachman wants to make sure that you are armed with the knowledge of what being a woman really means especially in terms of your sexual health... an area that is a big part of our lives but gets very little attention when it comes to how to make what you know work for you.Let's face it, we have our fair share of annoyances associated with being a woman... cramps, PMS, mood swings, tender breasts, pregnancy issues, postpartum depression, birth control, increase/decrease in our sex drive, painful intercourse as we age, sagging, drooping and that one stubborn hair that continues to appear on our chin when our hormones go wonky! And that's just to name a few!  As the old saying goes, knowledge is power and this book aims to help you understand your health as a woman, especially your sexual health which is probably one of the hardest things we have to discuss with our doctor.  Whatever problems you may be experiencing, this book reminds you that you are not alone and while it's not meant to take the place of a consultation with your own physician, it can help steer you in the right direction and give you the basis of knowledge you need to better understand your own body and why it's doing what it's doing. Just like its companion book, Total Male, Total Female is a book worth having and reading if you want to enjoy all that life has to offer you as a woman, no matter what age or stage you may currently be in and I have no problem recommending it as a worthwhile read for women of all ages.**I was given a copy of this book in exchange for an honest and unbiased review which I have given.  I do not know the authors and no other form of compensation took place.

You have to admire the dedication it took for author Kathryn J. Kappler to pursue this project for so many years, determined to see it through to its completion.  It's a very interesting and enlightening telling about her relatives and their involvement in the beginnings of the Mormon Church (Jesus Christ of the Latter Day Saints).  No matter your feelings about Joseph Smith and the Mormon Church, My Own Pioneers makes for interesting reading and while the author's version is certain to be slanted toward presenting her relatives in a flattering light, there is no denying the tremendous hardships these early believers of this new religion were subjected to.  The pictures and formatting of the book make it all the richer and Mormon philosophies aside, it is a fascinating look at the history of the birth of Mormonism whose followers were willing to endure an endless variety of deprivations in their quest to give life to Joseph Smith's vision.  Was this man a delusional heretic or The Chosen One?  Members of the Mormon Church (whose numbers are easily in the millions) such as the author would say it was the latter, but when all is said and done it's up to the reader to decide.  Four stars for Kathryn J. Kappler and Volume I of My Own Pioneers.**I was given a copy of this book in exchange for an honest and unbiased review which I have given.  I do not know Kathryn J. Kappler and no other form of compensation took place.

I enjoyed this combination of dystopian and post-apocalyptic fiction.  The authors do a great job of introducing multiple characters and their stories while keeping everything distinct.  I had put off reading this because the last few post-apocalyptic books I read felt a bit stale.  But Piperbrook and Adair have a unique story here.

I put off writing this review because the book bummed me out so much.  I like real romances, romances where people act like people and have real flaws.  But this is the story of how a woman puts up with abuse and mistreatment from virtually every man that she encounters, including the two men who claim to love her.  Scratch that.  ESPECIALLY the two men who claim to love her.  And instead of finding some way through to and building a better life, a life including respect, for herself and her children, she learns to embrace it, like she shouldn't expect anything better.  It's truly disheartening to see how much she is willing to endure to gain such a dubious prize, the affection of a petty criminal who thinks nothing of calling her names and is willing to physically assult people whose children misbehave (he knocks out a man's tooth after the man's son misbehaves in nursery school).When the book begins, Meadow is a young teenager. She befriends classmates Jared and Justin (who are identical twins).  Over the years, she is romantically involved with both of them.  They're completely immeshed in a dysfunctional and ridiculously melodramatic love triangle.  As a result, by the time the three reach adulthood, the brothers cannot be in the same room without physically assaulting each other.  Add to this cringeworthy song lyrics (Meadow is a lyricist), a refusal to ever practice safe sex, and a cartoonishly over-the-top bad guy.  Meadow values herself so little, it's hard to imagine a HEA for her that doesn't involve years of therapy and cutting these men out of her life.  Instead, she embraces being treated like a human trash bag.  Jared's biker buddies joke about passing her around?  No, don't worry.  Jared says that aren't that bad.  Jared explodes with verbal abuse whenever there is a misunderstanding?  Oh, but he got a tattoo for you, so it must be love.Note to author:  identical twins are identical because they have the same DNA.  Paternity tests determine paternity by comparing the DNA of the potential father to that of the child.  A paternity test would be useless for determining which identical twin fathered someone's children.  Yet another reason why Meadow should buy some condoms already.

This is one of the most complex mysteries that Ive ever read.  I reached a point, relatively early, where I stopped trying to figure out what was going to happen and just enjoyed the story.  Once you get past the rough beginning (were dropped into the middle of a complex story), youre sucked into the story and Pattison excels in bringing the cultural alienation his colonial characters feel to complete life.  We may take elements of Native American culture for granted due to their familiarity, but this wouldnt have been the case for them.  Everything becomes fresh and fascinating  even sometimes frightening  as his characters experience it.I wish the book had started earlier  before the characters were on the ship.  That Duncan, the main character, spends so much time confused doesnt mean that we should necessarily replicate his condition.  As a mystery, the book does leave something to be desired.  But its such an enjoyable and immersive reading experience, I found it easy to forgive the sometimes confusing and slow plot.

This is the second installment of the Southerland family romance series.Reading the first isnt required to enjoy this, but I did like having the background on the characters.  Bailey, one of the sisters, is the chef/owner of a restaurant in a resort area.  Shes had her eye on Trace, a local farmer, for a while, but his hang-ups about love have kept their relationship platonic.  This isnt an elaborately plotted book and I did feel like the ending was extremely rushed.  But overall, it was a sweet and entertaining romance with some real heat between the two main characters.  I look forward to continuing the rest of the series.  I like how Adams writes realistic women, women who dont sit at home pouting and waiting for men to notice them.

Authors are told to write what they know and Young has obviously taken this advice to heart.  His exploration of the world of crack addicts is vivid and often harrowing.  Unfortunately, the rest of the novel doesnt live up to the power of those scenes.Herby and Kerby are identical twin brothers.  At one point, they were both police officers.  But Kerby is now addicted to crack and working as a security guard.  When Young is writing about Kerbys world, the story is at its most powerful.  But when he tries to expand the story, he too often gets caught in distracting factual errors (like those involving police work or legal procedures) or stumbles over his confusing timelines (the brothers are clearly middle aged  one of them has teenaged children  but the story often makes it seem like Kerby began using crack right after their parents died, when they were in high school).  As a secular reader, having actions and thoughts attributed to God was often confusing.  I found myself wondering why God would single Kerby out for special treatment and favor while letting others in the story suffer and die.The editing is very rough.  It's difficult, in some scenes, to tell exactly who is talking or what is happening.

Rebecca (or Bex) is a struggling actress who pays the bills by being a pretend nurse (she breezily tells us she is trained by her employer  a long-term care facilityto perform the duties of a nurse, something that is both illegal and represents a substantial opportunity for a civil lawsuit).  One morning she runs into a handsome and apparently wealthy man on the street.  Shes instantly attracted to him.  Soon afterwards, she is hired to be eye candy at a swanky society party.  Somewhat inexplicably, she decides to tell a group of guests that she is dating the host.  Unsurprisingly, the host turns out to be the man from earlier in the book.  Marcus (or Markus, the author goes back and forth on the spelling) is a billionaire playboy.  Hes famous enough to be on the cover of Time and subjected to constant photographer attention, but  despite the fact that they live in the same city --Bex somehow has no idea who he is (although within a few days, shes confident enough to provide analysis of his business and personality to others).  Its weird and it makes the book feel like it never gets established in reality.  Rose cant decide if Marcus/Markus is truly famous or not  hes only famous, it seems, when it suits the plot.  At other times, he can get in a confrontation outside a coffee shop and nobody in a crowd has an idea who he is.Anyway, when Marcus/Markus finds out that a struggling actress is pretending to be his girlfriend so she can tell off his party guests, he decides to go along with the act.  And then he decides to offer her a bunch of money to continue the act.  Why?  Some business reasons that make little sense.Rose is vague on how Marcus/Markus actually maintains his fortune (which he initially inherited from his father).  When Bex describes his business to others, she makes him sound like some sort of middle management asset manager.  Its another example of how the book struggles to depict reality.  The plot is artificially drawn out by the main characters refusing to face reality or apply common sense (there are multiple scenes where Bex wonders why Marcus/Markus is being romantic or sexual with her even when there is nobody to witness it  uh, maybe he likes you?).Sometimes waiting for character to realize theyre attracted to each other adds to the fun of the book, but I found Bexs obtuseness more annoying than engaging, especially given that there is nothing else in the plot to pay attention to.

Angel is a retired safe cracker who reunites with her old gang for one last job (for a good cause).  While executing the robbery, she runs into Cole.  Hes posing as a security guy, but hes actually deep undercover to expose criminal activity.  He works with the Association, a collection of uniquely skilled operatives who target the worst of the worst in the criminal world.  He quickly devises a plan to use Angels elite safe cracking abilities to further his own mission.  Cole and Angel each think the other is up to no good, but that doesnt stop their growing attraction.This book has a quickly moving plot and characters who feel real (and generate real heat).  From the first chapter, I had that wonderful feeling where you want to read just one more chapter . . . and then one more.  The story just sucked me in.  The bad guy is truly bad without ever going over-the-top.  This is a strong start to the series.
Barely a soda at all.  Thin and obviously diluted.

This book was a fast read, although I was surprised  at the end  how little medicine had to do with the thrillers in this so-called medical thriller.  Its kind of like Fatal Attraction mixed with the plot from a 1980s Robin Cook thriller, but it moves quickly enough that you dont notice any of the seams until the end.Jemma Sands is a busy, but content, wife, mother, and doctor until a surgery goes wrong.  Although she did everything that she could, the patients baby was stillborn and the patient lost her uterus, impacting her future fertility.  This sets a somewhat far-fetched revenge plot into motion, one that is heavily reliant on some unlikely connections between the patient and Jemmas husband.With all this, Adler is a graceful writer and the flow of the book is strong, especially in the suspenseful final scenes.  There were a couple of false notes (a single sex scene that seemed unnecessarily explicit given the overall tone of the book -- I'm a fan of explicit scenes, but this just seemed completely incongruous; a reference to 9/11 at the end that seemed to come completely out of left field), but I would consider checking out more books by this author.

Andrea is a young culinary student who is tricked by her grandmother (her only surviving relative) into travelling to Alaska and taking over as caretaker for a giant mansion.  Andreas grandmother doesnt give a thought to what this might mean for Andreas career, studies, and life in Chicago.  As it turns out, this is the beginning of a trend where nobody in the book cares about Andrea, what she wants, and what dreams she has for her own life.  The grandmothers goal:  to get Andrea knocked up by one of the two handsome hotties inhabiting the mansion, hotties who happen to be werewolf-style creatures from another realm who visit Earth from time to time.The world-building in this novel is actually pretty good.  I was intrigued by the different species and how they interacted, as well as the natural science and history of their realm.  For being the third book in a series, it was easy to catch up on what had happened before.But man.  Mathin, the guy who winds up falling for Andrea, is such a jerk, even by Alpha standards.  He thinks nothing of taking Andrea from her home, friends, career, and planet without even discussing it with her.  He binds her  forever  to a symbiotic creature.  He knows that his mating standards (once you do it, youre mated forever) vary from hers, but it doesnt seem like he was ever going to let her know (someone else lets it slip).  And despite abundant evidence that breeding between their species can be dangerous, he doesnt take any precautions once they do become intimate.  Hes one of the biggest Alphaholes Ive ever encountered.  That Andrea takes this treatment for love casts a pall over the entire book.  That her grandmother, the only mother figure left in her lift, thinks this is cute underscores that she doesnt value her for anything besides her ability to reproduce.  Its deeply saddening.Id love to think were past this sort of thinking, but here it is.  Nothing in your life is as important as the sexual attention of a almost-stranger.  And nothing you could ever accomplish in other areas is as important as the child you will bear for him.  Given the heavily domestic bent of all the women in this story, I wonder if this is just a series about women being broken down.

This book is all over the place. We begin with four young women, teenagers, who seem to be normal (theyre planning for the future and careers like nursing, for example). And then, suddenly, theyre robbing banks and shooting people in the head. Its like they turned into a different bunch of women.Editing is very rough.

This book is awkwardly written.  The dialogue is wooden, the POV is confusing (part of the book is in first person, but the narrator has knowledge that he couldnt possibly have, and part is delivered by an omniscient narrator who withholds key facts to enhance the mystery), the editing is rough, and the author doesnt appear to know anything at all about police procedures.Marcella is less an actual character than a stock grizzled detective type.  Donovan doesnt spend much time at all developing the character or sharing details about him  hes just a vehicle to share the story, nothing more.  He frequently crosses the line into clich, even when it doesnt make sense.  For example, he refuses to use a computer at all.  So does his police department not require the filing of reports or even reading routine emails (let alone doing the internet research that modern detective work requires)?  This disregard for character and ignorance of how detective work is actually carried out compromises the entire novel.The idea of a decidedly non-supernatural detective investigating a supernatural crime is an interesting one, but the execution is so poor I cant recommend this book to anyone.

Kate is a shy history student doing a fellowship at a British museum. She catches the eye of James, a wealthy museum benefactor and he invites her to indulge with him . . . and eventually with his friend. A whirlwind of M/M/F fun, shopping sprees, and expensive vacations follow. Adams begins to set up an interesting conflict between the threesome and the increasing emotional connection between Kate and James, as well as the mystery of what happened to the last woman who indulged with the two men. But both of these plots are hastily resolved. It was so rapid and cursory that it seemed like Adams just got tired of writing and decided to end the book.

I love the forensic detail in these books and I think Brockton is a great character  but as the series progresses, the plot often feels like an afterthought.  This book has a plot, but it isnt much of a mystery.  While its very interesting, its hard to escape the feeling that it fails to meet the expectations of the genre.I will continue reading, but I hope the next installment features more investigation beyond digging up bones.
This is a very slow read and it was far too mannered for my taste.  The Kindle formatting is decent for a free version, no major errors.

Taylor is a sweet, but completely ordinary, college student.  Kyle is a raging jerk of a heir, a substance-abusing and emotionally stunted child of privilege whose deepest thoughts involve who he plans to bang next and how to keep daddys money flowing.  In a genre that is increasingly delving into unappealing male main characters, hes easily one of the least appealing Ive encountered for a while.When Kyle accidently hits Taylors car, he is inexplicably attracted to her.  This instant attraction is never really explained or justified by anything in his character or hers  it seems to happen simply because it needs to happen for the plot to progress.  Before long, he is devising a way to get back into her life, no matter what is does to her career prospects.This is a serial story, which the title and description do a good job of making clear.  It was a bit annoying that it was never really told in the moment  its told by alternating Kyle and Taylors POV and theyre both prone to lots of foreshadowing, making it clear the story is being recounted from some future vantage point.  But neither one of them seem to have changed from the time of the original events, so its a bit confusing.  The overall feel is that of a story that never really begins.The editing is very careless.
Fairly standard solar storm story.  I wish the description had made it clear that this is a serial novel, not a trilogy.

This book is very slow moving.  After opening with a scene of a character in peril, we then go years earlier in the life of another character -- Peter.  Before we can find out what is happening in the first scene, we must go through years of Peter's life, often in tedious detail.  His life as a school teacher is mostly made up of random scenes with occasional moments of high drama (sometimes these moments are disturbing, like when another character describes a puppy being stomped to death in vivid detail).There is something very odd about the construction of this book, as if Tennant had trouble deciding exactly whose story he wanted to tell.  He chooses Peter as the main character, but the drama only involves him somewhat -- as a result the climatic events of the novel (when they finally arrive) never really seem clear and key events are often recounted in a rush of clumsy exposition.  We have the wrong main character for the story that the author wants to tell, which means the story is rarely framed in a way to make it interesting to readers.

This was a difficult novel for me to get into.  There's a supernatural/ghost angle that never gets fully developed, a prickly lead detective who is hard to root for (she's doesn't have the essential "great detective quality" that allows a reader to spend a book with a less pleasant main, she just seems to stumble through the investigation), and a plot that basically involves bad guys pouring out of the woodwork (and in some cases revealing themselves as serial killers despite seeming normal for the vast majority of the story).Laura Cardinal is a Tucson-based detective investigating the murder of a teenage girl.  Laura has a lot going on in her life and, unfortunately, the author doesn't always do the best job of making it clear what exactly is going on.  I am not a reader who usually needs a lot of handholding, but I spent far too long in this book wondering exactly what was going on or trying to remember who certain characters were.The plot develops slowly -- Laura's investigation involves a lot of waiting.  When things do begin to move faster, it's hard to take it seriously because it's so far-fetched.

Somewhere around the fifteenth or twentieth time we're told how tiny Abby and her body parts looked against her older stepbrother's massive parts, I got a little bit weirded out.  Maybe it's because they constantly called each other "brother" and "sister."  Or maybe it's because their love apparently began when she was way underage and he . .  wasn't (although when the book takes place, Abby is legal -- barely).  Maybe it's because despite her age, Abby still seems so much younger than Kaiden -- immature, childish, naive.  She doesn't even seem to understand how babies are made.  This isn't a story about step-siblings who meet and fall for each other.  This is a story about two people raised as siblings and consider themselves to be brother and sister falling in love.  Know that before you download.That aside, this story has major gaps.  Abby has to move in with Kaiden after their parents die (yeah, I know they're step-siblings, but they're essentially siblings and no mention is ever made of the parents except as their JOINT parents) and she finds out her college money was blown on bail for him years earlier.  Kaiden supposedly wants to keep her out of his trashy life, but instead of helping her brainstorm ways to actually go to college, he lets her move in, incessantly abuses her verbally, and does nothing to help her escape the orbit of his criminal set.  This made no sense, especially when we find out later that he actually loved her all along.  Is he dumb?  Or is he just selfish?An somewhat incoherent thriller plot emerges, but it's just a backdrop for their budding romance.  The plot has major holes and the HEA, such as it is, seems dropped from the sky.

Maddy is a young police officer who lives in the in-law quarters of her father and step-mother's home.  In one day, she receives a new roommate -- her stepbrother, Brock, who has returned from a mysterious absence -- and a new assignment.  The assignment -- to find out what Brock and his tough street racing buddies are really up to.  Maddy is keen to prove herself, but she's also keen for Brock -- despite their history of animosity.This book was . . . okay.  There were things that kept jarring me out of the story.  Example:  the story is apparently set in the San Francisco Bay area and Maddy is supposedly a native.  But the writer delivers her internal dialogue in what I believe is Australian English, which means we're hearing about car "bonnets" and her bum.  It's distracting.  The author also seems a bit vague on police procedures and audio surveillance (the police can't just decide to turn on your cell phone and record all your activities for the day, even if you are an undercover police officer).  And the actions of characters just didn't make sense sometimes -- at one point, we find out that Maddy's father hid key information from her for years -- information that impacted her personal safety and her relationship with her stepbrother.  Why?  Because he just didn't care for his step-son?  It didn't make sense.If you're craving a bad boy stepbrother fix, this could probably do the job.  But there are better bad stepbrother books out there.

This book is a downer!  That isn't a point against it.  Many great works of literature are downers.  But great downers are great because they typically reveal something, they allow us to connect to the human condition in a way we hadn't before.  This book, despite throwing virtually everything at us, never really connects or feels real.As the book begins, Afton is the beautiful and carefree young daughter of an English villein.  When her innocent mistake kills the family ewe, they are unable to pay their rent and Afton is given to the lord and lady to raise as a lark (Lady Endeline, a ridiculously over-the-top villainess, craves beautiful peasant children to raise as her own).  Although she has moments of happiness, Hunt basically spends the next few hundred pages making Afton endure every type of awfulness.  The sheer misery of the book isn't the real problem (although I can see how some readers may be put off by it).  What got me was how constructed and anachronistic everything felt.  The thoughts and words of these people just aren't in keeping with their times (like when Afton's father muses to Afton's mother -- when they face giving up their child -- that although they have been poor all their lives, this is the first time that he actually *feels* poor).  Nothing seems truly alive because the characters didn't seem authentic.

"Lightweight" is an understatement.  The material is thinner than most of my t-shirts;  fine, it's expected due to the low price.  However, it also runs incredibly small.  Order at least one size larger than usual.

These all have the same flaw:  cheap metal for the rods.  When -- and it's not "if" -- the rod gets even the slightest bend in it, the frother will cease to be usable.  It can be something as simple as not laying on its side gently enough, or in the case of this brand, it was off kilter enough just from shipping.  I honestly think I'd be better off using my Dremel.

This book had too many characters and they were all introduced so rapidly, with little to distinguish them.  I found it difficult to care about any of them, even when they were thrown into extreme peril.

This book was kind of confusing.  Elizabeth (Bennett, ugh, why  the author never provides any details to explain WHY the female mains parents decided to give her such a cutesy name) has suddenly been fired rom her job when she encounters handsome billionaire dominant Alexander Fairhaven.  Alexander talks like a Brit out of Central Casting (including outdated slang like bird) despite the fact that he went to college in the US.  He immediately falls for Elizabeth but she  despite being raised by wealthy drug company millionaires (who have since disowned her)  is convinced she could never fit into his world.  Im not sure why Elizabeth  Harvard educated, raised in the 1%, independently wealthy thanks to family stocks  is so convinced she is an outsider to Alexanders circle.  Its the most enduring mystery of the book and far more mysterious than the mystery the author would like for us to focus on.Another potential problem:  despite the instant attraction they feel for each other, Elizabeth has never been dominated and shes pretty sure that she doesnt want to be.  But Alexander has magic domdar and he is just positive that she is a natural submissive.  He wants her in his silks, a phrase that he will repeat at least once per scene for a few hundred pages.  Elizabeth agrees to try and their relationship begins.But there is a cloud hanging over Elizabeths head.  Despite her widely reported status as a whistleblower (on her parents, no less!), Elizabeths job at a high powered accounting firm involved  unbeknownst to her  significant tax fraud.  Why, you might ask, would criminals hire a woman who famously narced on her own parents for business misconduct?  I dunno, cause it seems like a terrible plan to me.  And then, to top it off, they systematically underpay her ($60,000 a year, in Boston, for a senior account manager for multiple big ticket clients) and fire her on a pretext after she gets just enough evidence to implicate them . . . its almost like the plot required it or something.  Well, now they just have to try to kill her, dont they?Despite the ridiculous set-up, the thriller part of the plot does work a little better than the romance (maybe because it gets Alexander to take a break from murmuring poshly about his silks).  This isnt a bad book, really.  Its just a bit silly, like the early ideas and plot points werent revisited and revised as the book progressed.  That Elizabeth, an Ivy League graduate raised in the type of wealth most of us can only imagine,thinks she couldnt possibly fit into Alexanders world makes no sense no matter how you squint at it.  If you have a favorite English tea that you picked out on your vacation to London, you arent exactly slumming.  And if your first instinct when facing legal trouble is to fly to Seattle to visit your familys long-time personal lawyer (a visit that requires a retainer of several thousand dollars, a fee you pay easily by selling some of the stock you hold in the family company), then you arent exactly from the wrong side of the tracks.  When Elizabeth expresses her worries about the gap in their financial status, he says It doesnt matter.  He should say What are you talking about?

This book boasts one of the faster moving plots in the series -- although the author still has a tendency to go over details more than once and include repetitive scenes, usually featuring JP's slowish investigations.  There is a sub-plot involving domestic abuse that keeps things moving fairly quickly.  And although the characters sometimes seem absurdly sheltered (it just strains credulity that JP isn't sure what is going on when he encounters a house full of Asian women working on sewing machines that an antagonist wants to keep hidden), this is one of the better books in the series due to the pace and the author's improved skills in writing dialogue.Note:  Given that Sabre is such a straight arrow that she wouldn't even entertain the idea of having an ex parte conversation with a judge, it's hard to believe that she was so cavalier when, later in the book, she receives a confession about the assassination of a judge.  It was wildly out-of-character.

There is a germ of a good medical thriller here, compromised by a clunky narrative structure (the story is told in flashback format, a man telling his daughter about things that happened hundreds of years earlier) and a general lack of realism.  The main character, after some false starts highlighting other characters, is scientist Jason Roy.  After his wife dies, their daughter Lily becomes the center of his world.  Lily has Down Syndrome.  As I have a close family member with Down Syndrome, I was intrigued by this part of the plot and hoped it would add some interest to the novel.  Unfortunately, Lily's character just isn't written very well.  It wasn't realistic based on my experience with my family member and her friends with Down Syndrome.  Her dialogue and actions didn't ring true.  Maybe Lily is based on someone the author knows, but it seems as if she (and the other character in the book with Down Syndrome) were written as precocious sweet children rather than pre-adolescents/adolescents with intellectual disabilities.  In the quest to humanize Down Syndrome (something I completely support), it seems like their genuine differences were erased.  And that's a shame, because I would love to see more accurate and true-to-life renderings of people with intellectual disabilities in literature -- that is what is truly humanizing.Setting all that aside, the plot doesn't really work and the execution is frequently uneven.  The evil big pharma angle is stretched to the breaking point and the book dedicates too much time to a cross-country chase that never really means anything.  Roy's research, the cornerstone of the story, is rushed over and hardly described.  If you think everything will be explained by the end of the story, you're going to be sorely disappointed.  It's never clear how we get from the present-day to the future where Roy's story was being told (or how the narrator knows the thoughts and actions of the main characters).As a raw story this has potential.  But this version just isn't that good.

I downloaded this book because I found the theme so scary -- being submerged in a car is one of my greatest fears.  And the parts of the book where characters were actually submerged were . . . not bad.  But there was so much unnecessary stuff around it dragging out the story and the end, where more and more villains keep popping out of the woodwork, was just ridiculous!

This is another enjoyable installment in the series.  The lives of the characters continue to intertwine in various ways and the scenes are as interesting as ever.  Powell has a sort of genius for writing conversation.  We feel like we know these people and how they have evolved simply through conversations -- most of the "action" of the series takes place off-stage and is only recounted later, in conversation.

This is a fast-paced and competently plotted debut mystery novel featuring Quinn, an art forger turned PI.  While at times the connections between characters seemed a bit far-fetched, the story moved quickly and Quinn is an engaging character (if a bit thick about personal matters).As some other reviews have noted, the editing is really rough.

This is a creepy and heartfelt book, the kind of story that stays with a reader long after it is over.  After beginning with a completely improbable event (during a deadly accident, a woman experiences physical death while her mind is transferred into her daughters body), it never afterward feels anything less than realistic.The translation seems . . . competent.  I can't read Japanese, but I suspect that the original flows much better than this translation.  The dialogue occasionally comes across as slightly stilted or unlike the speech of actual people.  That said, this book was good enough that I would rather read a faulty translation than not read it at all.  Recommended to fans of dark fiction.

Dr Bill Brocktons latest case is one of his most complicated yet . . . and his life continues to be even more complicated that the mystery.  Old grudges  both personal and political  are stirred up when Brockton is called to consult on the mysterious death of a retired nuclear physicist.  The tangle of his death leads all the way back to World War II, but has dramatic and dangerous consequences for Brockton and those closest to him.These books shine at delivering a regional flavor and careful research.  I like that these books arent totally self-contained, but new readers should be aware that while the plot of the book stands alone, the personal relationships draw quite a bit on what has come in previous books and parts of this story will continue into the next book.  Although the pacing can sometimes be uneven (I found myself getting impatient during some of the lengthy flashbacks told from one characters POV), this is a solid installment in an interesting and developed series.

This book collects all of Carver's poetry in one place.  He won his fame through his short stories, but his poetry is often wonderful -- the language is carefully chosen and clear, and the poems explore so many aspects of life.  Nature, relationships, and mortality are frequent themes.  If you love his stories, check out the poems.  They are worth the read.

Baker returns to his fascinatingly quotidian poet, Paul Chowder, in this follow-up.  The writer's block that bedevilled Chowder in the past has been replaced by a spurt of creativity as he turns his energies to songwriting and seeks to recapture the love of his ex-girlfriend.  This book isn't for everyone -- your enjoyment will be directly related to how much you like accompanying Chowder in his varied musings.

This is a beautifully written and thought-provoking read.  Mitchell absolutely avoids the glib or the language of easy fixes.  It's an exploration more than a "how-to."  It has the potential to be interesting to everyone, regardless of their current relationship status.

This is a fun and hot M/M/F erotic romance with a real emotional foundation.  Sometimes you feel like you have to choose between romance and erotica -- this combines both perfectly.  Rai's writing is witty and intelligent.  Highly recommended for M/M/F fans and those who like their erotica mixed with romance and love.

The implausibility of the plot was a major obstacle to the success of the author's first novel in this series (The Advocate (Volume 1).  While parts of this have improved, there are still some really unlikely events in this book that will jar the reader out of the story.  There is also lots of repetition.Sabre, the intrepid child advocate lawyer, is convinced that there is a trend of ritual abuse emerging in her area.  Or she isn't convinced -- her stance seems to flip from chapter-to-chapter.  With the help of her buddy, Bob, and their PI, JP, she launches an investigation.  The truth winds up being more complicated and almost as unlikely as ritual abuse.  When I finished the book, major portions of the plot were still unclear to me.  Why would you invite someone who was blackmailing you to commit further crimes with you?  Why would a criminal start a ritual abuse panic that might draw attention to their activities?  When you're in the middle of the story, you keep hoping that the ending will tie it all together, but I had as many questions when I finished as I did halfway through the book.
Grippy bottom hold it in place, and the brushed surface is smooth, looks good, and seems to resist any scratches from my gaming mouse.  Clearing dust off the surface is the only maintenance needed.

This book features some of Jessica's nastiest and most selfish behavior as she and her sorority pals gang up on overweight Robin, a girl who wants to join their clique.  Elizabeth tries to help Robin, but her plan may backfire because it relies on help from notoriously self-absorbed Bruce Patman.Looking at Jessica's nastiness through 21st century eyes is illuminating -- when I read this book as a girl, bullying didn't have nearly the attention that it does today.  As a result, the casual treatment of Jessica's cruelty is sometimes jarring.  Despite the subject matter, this is still a fun and light read that doesn't go too deep.  At the end of the day, even Robin doesn't seem too upset by what happened.Some of the reviews of the paperback version note changes to the text.  As far as I can tell, the Kindle version duplicates what I read when I was young (that is, the Wakefield twins are described as size 6, not size 2).  If you want to read the original, go with the Kindle version.

Nelson Rockefeller crammed so much into one life -- politician, heir, reformer, father, policy wonk, art lover and patron, ladies man -- and Smith does an admirable job of bringing him to life.  His life was so much more interesting and complex than I had realized.  Smith does an excellent job with the more dramatic events of Rockefeller's life -- his divorce, his runs for the presidency, the death of his son, Attica -- but he also manages to handle the less intrinsically exciting details of his political life in a way that is interesting even for those of us who don't get excited about state budgets and urban renewal.  It would have been easy for large sections of this book to sink into tedium, a less skilled author couldn't have managed to make this full account of Rockefeller's life as readable as it is.  The clear-eyed fairness of this book really makes the man come alive.

This book is an odd mixture of hero worship (Sex's regular character, Andre, the wise therapist who can never do anything wrong), a tale of redemptions, and some clunky moralizing about sexual standards.  The stories rarely get a chance to flourish without being thrown off by scenes of implausible therapy sessions, paeans to Andre's wonderfulness from multiple characters, or sermons about sexual standards or the proper way to respond to abuse.  Despite Andre's supposed greatness, I questioned how ethical it was for him to sleep with a young woman placed in his care or how appropriate it was for the young woman to begin work as a sexual surrogate under his direction (despite the fact that she has completed no in-person training, only online psychology courses).  That this young woman goes on to make a patient think she may marry him and tells another patient that she loves him on during their second sessions makes me question the reality of this book.  There's a lot that doesn't seem right here.Sex is so intent on the point she's trying to make (abused people aren't at fault for being abuse and sex doesn't need to be attached to commitment) that the story never gets a chance to truly develop.  These people are vehicles, not characters.

Easily the worst book yet in this decayed wreck of a once solid series.  It's hard to escape the impression that Cornwell just doesn't care any more.The loathsome entitlement and self-pity of Scarpetta's character have never been more apparent.  The book begins with her plans for a vacation with Benton, her husband, and bemoaning that they hardly get to spend time together.  Never mind that this is the result of their professional choices.  That these choices are freely made doesn't seem to register with her.  Nor does it occur to her that her subordinates could act as more than glorified assistants to her genius, allowing her to take a day off (most of these subordinates will, over the course of the book, be revealed as venal or incompetent or even venally incompetent -- maybe Scarpetta should spend some time examining her recruitment and talent evaluation processes?).Scarpetta is called to a crime scene by Marino and the tedious dance of their relationship, explored to death over the past few books, is renewed.  She can't stand him, but is unable to contemplate a life without him.  Her contempt for him is wearying.  I actually think most of the first half of the book is just the two of them conversing in the car or at the crime scene.  I am now convinced that the Marino/Scarpetta/Benton triangle is more about Cornwell exploring her own issues than anything else.  This clearly resonates deeply with her -- there is no way that any reader can be as fascinated by the trio and their murky aggressions and complusions as she is.  She has an endless appetite for scenes where Marino and Scarpetta talk around their bizarre connection, scenes where Marino pulsates with rage while Benton flexes his cold, WASPy, cryptically phrased disdain.  What is wrong with these three?  I can't even begin to imagine a legitimate explanation for their profound dysfunction.  As Benton grows increasingly bloodless and Scarpetta increasingly icy, Marino has become the locus of the trio's emotions -- and, in the world of this series, emotions are never anything but negative.  Rage, jealousy, crude joy, pride -- Marino is a vessel for all of these so Benton and Scarpetta can live in a zone where risotto and chilled white wine is a substitute for authentic emotion.  Lucy also continues devolving into an emotion-free state -- a more violent version of Scarpetta's super-achieving ice princess persona, but with more expensive cars.I was shocked to see the beginnings of an intriguing plot emerge in the first half of the book and thought we may have the rare treat of a bad guy who wasn't a super-genius with no motivation beyond hurting Scarpetta (the most famous and obsessed over medical examiner in the history of medicine or examining).  Unfortunately, my hopes were dashed more quickly than Kay and Benton's vacation plans.  Cornwell has never been particularly insightful about why people choose to hurt others, but the muddled motivations in this book were a low point even for her.  She loves Scarpetta and her associates, therefore bad people must hate them and want to hurt them.  It truly goes no deeper than that for Cornwell.After the train wreck of the previous book, I didn't think it was possible for things to get worse.  Oh, I was wrong.  Scarpetta spends less time than ever actually doing her job.  Her contempt for everyone except for Benton and Lucy grows thicker with every book and it's unclear what is driving it since there is no true insight into her as a character on display in these pages.  It's important, I think, for Cornwell to build these people up.  Unfortunately, she doesn't know how to do that without tearing down the characters that surround them, sometimes for reasons that are utterly trivial or even unclear.  Example:  she judges her subordinates for learning more about the crimes they are investigating, thinking this will cloud their findings.  But she is unable to apply that to herself, when she spends the day interviewing suspects or discussing theories of the case with Marino.  Foregrounding the relationship between Marino, Scarpetta, and Benton was the worst thing to ever happen to this series.  At this rate, the next book will consist of someone getting shot, Benton and Marino having a fight, and then 300 pages of Kay and Marino driving to the scene while Kay frets about why Benton isn't answering his cell phone.This series was much more fun when Scarpetta was human.

I was intrigued by the unusual setting of this book (child advocacy legal system) and the focus on a non-cookie cutter main character.  Sabre is a smart and independent lawyer.  Unfortunately, the plot and execution of this debut novel leave a great deal to be desired.Too much of the plot involves implausibilities (characters who are inexplicably virtually identical, people stalking people on the flimsiest of pretexts, etc) and there is an inexcusable amount of repetition (seriously, if I had to read about Sabre's red notebook one more time, I was going to scream).  The mystery was engaging, but the resolution was so far-fetched I ended the book with a major feeling of dissatisfaction.  This being the author's first book, the series may get better.

This book reads as if it was written by a twelve-year-old -- the simplistic characters, the unrealistic setting, the stilted dialogue. Katelynn, the daughter of a former US Senator -- has just gotten her Master's degree in political science. But she hates politics and doesn't want anything to do with it (why didn't she realize this at any point while getting her degree?). Instead of getting a job that draws on her advanced degree in any way, she moves back home and decides to apply for minimum wage jobs. She's hired at a local discount superstore as a manager trainee (apparently the company doesn't want managers to have any relevant experience) and, instead of being trained by another manager, Nate, the billionaire son of the CEO, comes to handle her training personally.Now, being a CEO requires a very specific set of skills that have little to do with running day-to-day operations of the company -- recruiting top talent, inspiring investors, maintaining investor returns, managing relationships with the board of directors, high level financial planning -- so why would a CEO who wanted his son to be the future CEO have him doing inventory reports, coaching tardy cashiers, and stocking shelves? Like so much of the novel, it seems like the author just doesn't get it.Of course, Nate and Katelynn fall for each other. They don't have much chemistry. They frequently think about how attractive the other one is, but you never get a sense of any heat. Their connection has to be resolutely non-sexual because they're both committed to remaining virgins until marriage. This book wasn't listed as a Christian romance, so it was a bit frustrating to get this bait-and-switch.It's a cliffhanger, so the book ends on a note of uncertainty. I'm not sure if the author is extremely naive or just trying to reach an audience that is, but the simplistic nature of this book and the lack of chemistry between the two main characters will make it unsatisfying to most adults.Edit:  Upon further consideration, I think this author's body of work may be some kind of social experiment.  Her author bio is written like an obvious attempt to capture a certain demographic and as of today (10/27/15), a search of her author photo actually links to a stock photo tagged with -- I kid you not -- "normal woman."  She loves Starbucks!  And yoga!  All we need is a picture of her crunching through fall leaves in her Uggs.  I've read several of the author's books and I think this may be some sort of meta-project.  If so, I like the joke!

This is so formulaic and dull. A event planner meets a rich man who runs hot and cold (leaping at her one moment, being cold and rude the next) and, of course, she quits her job to work for him. He's planning a mega-party in Italy, so she goes there for several weeks. There are some scenes of her wandering around Italy, but overall there is no real sense of place, she could be anywhere. He buys her some amazing clothes and she meets an intense and sexy Italian man and soon both of them are battling for her affection (they know each other and hate each other, of course).Cliffhanger ending.
A generic mysterious billionaire meets a generic woman and then another guy is added. There is nothing particularly interesting about these three or the lust triangle they find themselves in.

Given that the story basically ended in the previous volume, there is a certain anti-climatic feel to this -- Gaiman is wrapping up loose ends, providing closure for (some) characters, and throwing us some interesting mini-stories about side characters.  With a story as complex and delightful as this one has been, this isn't necessarily a bad thing -- it just isn't as engrossing as some of the previous books.Art, as usual, is beautiful -- a wonderful accompaniment to the tale.

Gottman writes practical and thoughtful books on love, relationships, and intimacy.  His advice is supported by observations and research and -- best of all -- is stuff that you can immediately implement in your own relationship.This book focuses on betrayal (sexual and other kinds) and recovery.  It also discusses the circumstances in which ending the relationship may be a better option for long-term happiness.Gottman is the only relationship author that I find myself regularly recommending.  This is the third book of his that I have read.  Although there is some repetition of themes, there is still enough fresh content in this book to make it worth the read.

So much of this book was interesting -- Gwen is a compelling and intelligent heroine, her world is interesting, the mysteries (both present-day and in Gwen's pasty) quickly draw the reader in, and the language is often beautiful.  But the book is saddled with a real clunker of an ending where nothing really comes together.  We are kept guessing about who the killer is, but when s/he is unveiled things aren't much clearer than they were before.I would check out another book by this author, but would hesitate to recommend this one.

I cant compare these to other models in the Steelseries, but the Siberia 200 headset fits snugly, and the material is of a high enough quality that I doubt it will start peeling (like some cheap models Ive used) from wear and tear and sweat. I dont much care about how they look (Im not using them for a fashion show) but the self-adjusting over the ear design  keeps you immersed in what youre doing (listening, gaming, editing, recording) without having to pause and adjust them once you feel comfortable with wearing them.  Dont expect them to be equivalent to have noise cancelling features of expensive, pro models. The name SteelSeries is a bit of a marketing tool. They arent THAT sturdy.  I edit sound for my videos, and these were great in selecting the best downloaded  mp3 sound effects from various sound effect sites. I use a lot of ambient sound overlays (traffic, people talking on the street, documentary sounds in foreign languages, animal calls, nature sounds, etc.,) and it helped me choose the best tracks. Dont expect these to be like Sennheiser quality, whose gaming headphones start at $250 retail.  You just cant get that for under $100. If you work in the sound industry, its not likely this consumer-oriented model is on the radar. For my purposes, these rate a five.

These gloves are extremely durable and it's obvious the manufacturer put time and effort in coming up with the right design and combination of leather and fabric: a feature that is rare on cheaper work gloves you buy in the dollar store or hardware store. The large size is a bit tight on my hands, but I'm going to assume that with use, they will stretch out.  These are definitely outdoor gloves. Wearing them indoors would be like giving your hands a sauna. Don't expect to do fine tuned work with them, however. They are too bulky for handling screws or nails, or other objects that require fine motor skills. If you don't do work (like gardening) that will eventually soil the gloves, they could be worn as everyday gloves in cold weather. I believe they deserve a five because it's a lot more difficult to design good work gloves than plain woolen or leather or faux-leather gloves.

This product works ok. I have a cat and a dog and have used it on pet throw-up. The trouble is that if you use the product in a moist area, the 'organic matter' will return, since it's really just hiding out even if you can't see the stain, so I use this only in dry, low trafficked areas. There's a more high end product that works better, which is available on Amazon, although it's pretty pricey. It's called pet peed. Also, it explains why you shouldn't use enzyme based product if your pet is on a special diet or on medication.

Wilde wrote this play more like an opera than a dramatic play. Characters have long monologues in which there is much explication. This is a symbolist play, showing obvious influences from the French symbolist movement. In fact, it was originally written in French, which some critics have claimed is a reason the English version is a bit stilted.  The book is advertised as having the original Beardsley illustrations, but it doesn't. I had to use an image search on the internet to see the illustrations. Make sure you find out what is contained in your edition.
