The things Ari sees, all while trying to maintain decent grades in school and hide her current state of homelessness from her peers, it makes for very emotional reading.You'll find yourself rooting for Ari and even Gage. As a result, I couldn't put the book down until I knew if they would actually achieve their goals. I can see both middle school and high school boys and girls really enjoying this novel.

While my cats are indoor cats only, they have picked up fleas. Our last infestation occurred when my son's friend came over and his parents do not believe in treating pets with flea preventative. They also do not take care of the fleas that are in their home. They put down lemon oil in hopes of driving them away. It doesn't work effectively. So, two years ago, middle of December, and we suddenly found our pets scratching and found our worst nightmare - fleas.Since then, I treat all three pets year-round. Frontline Plus is one my veterinarian recommended due to the product's effectiveness in our area. Sentry Fiproguard Plus contains the same ingredients as Frontline - I checked - and is less expensive.So far, my cats have had no reaction to the topical preventative. I didn't expect they would, but I was still on alert. It went on easily, dried within a couple hours, and now more than a day later, they still have had no unusual side effects. I can't say for certain how the flea protections works as it is still winter, but if it works as well as Frontline (which it should since the ingredients and percentages are the same), this will be an excellent alternative to the more expensive Frontline. As a result, I'm sold.I will be back with an update if Sentry should fail to keep the fleas away.

I never thought I'd say I like a nutritional shake mix, but I'm going to go out on a limb and say I'm impressed. This has to be the weirdest combination - pea protein, hemp protein, veggies like broccoli and spinach, flax seed, maca, and then fruits like apples, pomegranate, etc. In the past, any nutritional shake I've tried has been too grainy for my liking. That was definitely not the case here.The PreparationI've been using cashew milk to make this. The unsweetened one that Silk offers. My first attempt yesterday afternoon was to mix it in with a spoon and that was an epic fail. I tried shaking it next and that still left some clumps. This morning, I used the food processor (no blender in this house) and that ended up being the smartest way to mix it and remove all the clumps.The TasteThe taste is where things get weird. I didn't hate it. The color is clearly off-putting. It came out an almost split pea soup green when mixed with the cashew milk. But, color doesn't bother me. I also don't mind the taste of stevia, though the rest of my household hates it. In this shake, it's there, but the vanilla balances it. The weird thing is that it ended up tasting like I would imagine a French Vanilla sugar cookie made with ground ramen noodles in place of flour would taste. There was the aftertaste that reminded me of ramen noodles. It's not horribly unpleasant - kind of nutty and wheat-y at the same time. I'm sure the nutty taste comes from the cashew milk, the ramen noodles I'm not sure though. Maybe that's what Maca tastes like or maybe it came from the flax or hemp.What mattered most is that I drank the entire glass and didn't struggle to do so. I'm not a fussy eater by any means, but I've yet to find a nutritional shake that was good for me and didn't have an objectionable taste or texture. This one didn't.Given initial impressions, I would be eager to try the other flavors and see what I think of them. I work from home, but usually that means 12 hour days managing a team. I have a bad tendency to skip meals because it takes too long to prepare something. This shake took seconds and is something I could sip while working, making it a double win!

It's still below zero at night, but the days are at least in the 20s, so we pulled out the grill this week and put the Cuisinart grilling thermometer to the test. I did grilled chicken, something that does take time and attention to the temperature to prevent eating uncooked chicken. We currently own a Bradley Smoker grilling thermometer, so that's my basis for the comparison.UsageMy Bradley thermometer works well, but the instructions were lacking and it took a bit to figure out how to use all of its function. That's not the case with the Cuisinart. The product guide is easy to follow and covered everything without any confusion. I could have used this thermometer without having to rely on instructions, it's that good.TemperaturesBoth accurately give the temperature of the meat. I tested with both and used my instant digital thermometer as a back up and all three matched within a couple tenths of a degree. They also both have magnets, though I did find the magnet on the Bradley Smoker unit is a little stronger, but the Cuisinart still stuck to the grill's lid. Now, the Cuisinart does say you can leave the thermometer on your grill permanently. I won't do that given the weather extremes. Maybe in a warmer, drier climate I'd be more willing to do that.Need BatteriesThe one thing that you should note is that the Cuisinart thermometer does not come with the required batteries. You'll need 2 AAA batteries. My other came with the one AA battery. Make sure you have batteries on hand and this won't be a problem.Final NotesThere is ample wire for the Cuisinart, so you have the meat on the grill and have plenty of length for the probe, even with the lid shut. I found the length of this wire was pretty similar to the Bradley that is 30 inches.That said, given that this Cuisinart is more expensive, I'm not sure it would be my first choice. It's good, but sometimes the brand name alone isn't enough to justify a higher price.

This two pair set is ideal for any wiring project you might have around your home. We've been replacing light fixtures and electrical outlets and the wire strippers/cutters my husband has have not been ideal for some of these fixtures. The nose of the cutters he has are too wide. The narrower nose on the darker pair has been extremely helpful.Four-in-One With the Two Pair SetOTC's Crimpro set contains the two tools. First, each cutters/stripper has strippers/crimpers for different gauges. The smallest these handle is 12 gauge while the largest is 20 gauge, and they work with both insulated and non-insulated wires. The tools themselves are solid, not too heavy, and right now it seems that they will stand up to regular use without wearing out.Both tools have teeth that make it easy to grip the wire. With the solid grip, pulling or bending/twisting the wire is a breeze. The handles are comfortable, and as previously stated, the narrower head has been great for working in tight areas, such as wall outlets.My Husband's POVMy husband works with cable on a daily basis. He works for a company that manufactures the wiring you find in cars, computers, planes, military equipment, solar panels, etc. I think his statement sums up OTC Crimpro's wire service set perfectly. "I wish my company would invest in a set of these for each of the workers. These are superior to the wire strippers/cutters we're expected to use. They're more comfortable, cut much more cleanly, and have the strippers for the different gauges, making them the best tool for what I do every day."

It's the publisher's line stating "Recalling the wit and emotion of Maeve Binchy" that caught my attention. I love her novels and have been excited to find an author who writes with her panache.Her Name is Rose introduces widow Iris Bowen. Since her husband died of cancer, Iris has been a single mom to teen Rose. Rose is currently away in London having been accepted into London's Royal Academy of Music. When Iris receives news that there is something troubling in her mammogram results, she begins to consider her husband's request. Find Rose's birth mom so that Rose always has family.Thus begins Iris's quest to uncover the truth of what happened to Rose's birth mom. This brings Iris to Boston where her quest will uncover some surprising truths about the past and the present.I liked the premise for Her Name is Rose, but the fluidity of the book ended up being my downfall. Rose has her own issues going on at school and they seemed thrown in. I didn't get the importance, but I kept reading. As Iris headed to Boston and started meeting characters, I started really losing track of the who is who aspect and had to stop and take notes to keep the characters straight. Any time I have to stop and take notes, it starts to bog down the story. Then there were the switches back and forth between these characters and that also detracted from a Iris's story for me.Once I had the characters straight, the story did pick back up and interest me, but by that point, I felt it was almost too late. I never felt overwhelmed with emotion, as I'd expected, and what could have been a marvelous read turned into just an okay one.

I never thought I would need to protect my pets against fleas and ticks in the winter, especially given Vermont's proclivity to have below zero nights in a row in January. However, I learned quickly a few years ago when all of our pets became infested with fleas in December. It turned out that one of our son's friends has multiple dogs and the parents do not believe in flea treatments, so their dogs and their cat are infested. He came to visit and with him came at least one flea that went forth and multiplied. We got rid of the fleas here and options became treat our pets year-round or ban this kid from our house. As much as I'd like to ban him (I really hate fleas), it's not fair to him. He cannot control his parents' beliefs.Active IngredientsSentry Fiproguard Plus has the same ingredients as Frontline Plus: 9.8% Fipronil and 8.8% s-methoprene. Frontline Plus is what we used to get rid of the flea infestation. It worked effectively, and since using it we haven't had deer ticks get on our dog anymore either, which is an added plus because I cannot stand deer ticks. I find them repulsive and hate pulling them off our pets.ApplicationThis is my first time using Sentry Fiproguard Plus. It went on easily. Cut the tip off the tube and then separate the pets fur and squirt the liquid in the vial in a strip between the dog's shoulder blades. Be sure you don't touch the area for about a day while it dries. Though my experience is that the liquid is usually dry within a few hours. If you forget, wash your hands with soap and water.The CostThe price for the 6-count package of Sentry Fiproguard is much more affordable than Frontline Plus. My vet sells it for $60 a three pack. I don't buy it from our vet. You can get it at Petco, Petsmart for $53/cat and $56/dog for a three pack. Walmart is generally best and sells it for $39 here, again a three-pack. The price for the six-pack of Sentry Fiproguard becomes a much better deal.OverallThe price puts Sentry in the lead. I'll need to use this for the long-term (through Spring and Summer) to really decide if it is as effective as I hope it will be. At that point, I'll update the review. For now, however, we still haven't seen any fleas, it didn't affect my dog's skin, and given the price, I give it a thumbs up.

I can't find fault with this movie. Beautifully shot, nuanced yet powerful acting, and complex characters and story-line. It made me tear up a bit actually at one point which happens once in a blue moon while watching movies. I cannot recommend this movie enough. Not just because it based on an important historical event (that spurred me to do further reading). Not just because it was restrained yet commanding art. Not just because it was simply a pleasure to watch and riveting entertainment. But because Belle's struggles are not unique to herself, they are felt by anyone who ever feels the odd man out. Her dignity, class, intelligence and courage was frankly an inspiration. Exceptional art.**After reading a few negative reviews, I feel compelled to add that it's true that Belle is nowhere near as gritty or as "edgy" as it could be considering its serious subject matter. It could have easily added much more explicit content. The thing is--it didn't need to. I think it told the story it was trying to tell without needing explicit content. It frankly would have been an entirely different movie if they did. One I would probably watch and enjoy--but a different movie. Appreciate "Belle" for what it is, a restrained though passionate Austen era movie.

The second season of Da Vinci's Demons finds Da Vinci pretty much exactly where the first season left off. The main plot of the second season revolves around Da Vinci traveling to the New World (the Americas) in quest of the Book of Leaves (a super mystical book of great value) and in search of more information about his missing Mother. While Da Vinci's two sidekicks and frenemy Riario do in fact come on the trip with him--I couldn't help but keep wishing Da Vinci was back in Florence interacting with the ever cunning Lucrezia and the Medici family. Simply, my favorite characters spent very little time together for almost the entire season so I was constantly sorta disappointed. I wanted the trip to the Americas to last maybe three episodes, and instead it lasted practically the entire season.That said, this season did push things in the right direction not to mention was suspenseful and exciting in its own right. Da Vinci's back story is more fleshed out. The minor plotlines were deserving of attention and I can't wait till they collide with the main plot (especially the whole real Pope/fake Pope story). I have no doubt the intrigue and frankly sensuality of the first season will be back in season three now that the main cast is all back together on the same continent. For fans of Game of Thrones, Tudors, Borgias and even Sherlock Holmes. Highly recommend (but definitely watch the first season first if you are a newbie).

My mother is an extremely talented musician, and used to play the guitar frequently when she was younger. However, her hands are a bit older now, and she's discovered that playing the ukulele is simply much softer and less abrasive on her fingers than her guitar. I bought her this one as Christmas present about four years ago when she was just starting to play around with the ukulele. Though she has since moved on to a higher quality uke, she actually still plays this one regularly about once a week to a group of 3 year old children--who she occasionally lets play it as well. For all of the negative comments about quality or build, this thing has stood up to these weekly sessions with those kids and still is in just about the same condition from when I bought it four years ago.Also, while I imagine a more serious musician could tell the sound isn't quite as full bodied as it should be, most people literally won't be able to tell the difference between the sound from this ukulele and a much more expensive one. And if you're just playing it as a one off, breaking it out occasionally at parties, or like my mother and playing it for children---then I would completely recommend going with this option instead of something more expensive. For most uses, it gets the job done and is solid construction on top of that.

To preface this review: reviewing things like this on Amazon is a little weird for me. I'm definitely from a family where you just don't talk about underwear in public. But I've come to realize that if nobody ever talks about things like underwear or a favorite brand of tampons--then this just makes things pointlessly difficult for all women when we should all be learning from each other instead.So what was the occasion for needing something backless and strapless? An evening out at a friend's birthday dinner in an LBD.What I liked about these? First, they were great in not letting anything hang out/show through (my personal need from every bra, the ones that are too thin to do this annoy me), and they stuck on and stayed on all night in the same place. No dancing though, so basically minimal activity, but they felt secure enough that I doubt they would have moved even if I had been breaking it down. If you were wearing a structured top, or something with support below like a sash, I think it's a good bet that these would stay on for basically any normal or mildly exerting activity. Also, unlike other options, these actually provided lift as well as put in a bit extra (since they are kind of gel-ish packs) thus creating enhanced cleavage.What bothered me? It felt like my chest was being held by jelly hands for most of the night. It was cold and they weren't at body temperature so I could always feel that they were there on my chest. This wasn't an awful feeling, but just something to consider if wearing them on a cold night. Also, If you were dancing/sweating majorly/doing something acrobatic--I'm not sure the adhesive would be strong enough to hold them on securely.In my case though, they did what they needed to do for the night--and I will definitely be bringing them back out when it's a little warmer. As for being able to use more than once, they definitely retained their stick and shape well enough for me to foresee being able to get several uses out of them. Probably best to wear with a structured, backless dress and not go crazy with them though. Also, I was grateful for the very discreet packaging.Note: Sample bra provided by Nudwear. This review is my honest and unbiased opinion.

To say that I was excited about this album release is an understatement. Much like Nicki did in the years leading up to dropping "Pink Friday", Angel has been generating a tremendous buzz by featuring on countless singles as well as releasing several critically acclaimed mixtapes (like "Reservation") over the past four years. However, with much buzz comes much scrutiny and a high potential for dashed hopes. After several full playthroughs though, I'm actually quite satisfied with the approach Angel took with taking her talent to the mainstream music world on this major label debut. "Dirty Gold" has its fair share of "softer" more  pop songs, yet Angel manages to mix them with hardcore rapping and deeply personal lyrics to make for one of the most exciting albums of 2013."A Tribe Called Red" is some of the hardest flo from any rapper in 2013--female or male. "Black Synagogue" is a similarly intense track with heavy religious imagery and philosophical life questions. Angel's family was involved with a cult like offshoot of the Pentecostal church for most of her childhood and you can really hear how she's struggled to intelligently and emotionally come to grips with this. "Angels & Airwaves" achieves a near perfect rap/pop balance of strait hard emotional rapping and beautiful ethereal hooks. "Battle Cry" featuring Sia is another standout that rightfully draws comparisons to "Love the Way you Lie".The one thing about this album that has really stayed with me though is how heartbreakingly authentic and real Angel sounds. Despite normally disliking talking bits mixed in with actual tracks, I actually really like some of the spoken intros to several songs. Angel certainly has her bragging moments, but by in large is focused on real life issues including her childhood, sexual abuse, insecurities, expectations and religion.  So often I feel like female rappers are pandering heavily to their male audience by being excessively sensual or ditzy. And despite Angel being like model status pretty, her lyrics focus not on her body but on life which I find refreshing and empowering. This combined with the genuine technical skill and catchy music already make "Dirty Gold" head and shoulders above most debut albums.Now is this album perfect--of course not. There are some duds and Angel clearly needs to continue evolving a unique musical perspective. But there is much here to be excited about. The least of which is Angel's commitment to her music which led her to leak her album herself after her label kept pushing it back--forcing the label to honor the earlier release dates.This is an album that has staying power for me--emotionally and musically, and Angel just firmly established herself a heavyweight in the rap world. Highly recommend.

"The Worse Things Get, The Harder I Fight, The Harder I Fight, The More I Love You" is certainly a mouthful of a title, yet is actually a very succinct indication of what headspace and direction Neko went for with this album. Neko primarily wrote this album during a period of unexpected dark depression stemming from the deaths of several family members. In songs like "Where Did I Leave the Fire", you can hear the disconnect and isolation in her voice and lyrics. Neko is simply too fine of a songwriter to fall back on cliched tropes like "I'm feeling lost" though. Instead she paints sensual stories that are visual representations of more abstract and complicated feelings like not feeling bad about a parent's death and not knowing how to process that or what that says about her as a person.Bracing for Sunday" is a particular favorite. It's a modern interpretation of a traditional Celtic murder ballad with Neko's alternative rock/country twist. "Nearly Midnight, Honolulu" is all acapella and is a positively heartbreaking look into Neko's relationship with her (now dead) abusive and manipulative mother. "Ragtime" is an inspiring end to the main album, as it is Neko's ode to the one music genre that was able to give her joy in the midst of her depression. The horns are a great touch that I hope Neko experiments more with in the future.In many ways, this album doesn't stray that far musically from what people have come to expect from Neko (fantastic vocals, effective alternative country/rock), but this is hands down some of her most gutsy and naked songwriting. And recognizing what an achievement that is when one is already one of the most respected modern songwriters, that makes this album a must listen as well as another cornerstone in Neko's lasting musical legacy.Very enjoyable, with plenty of musical range. Would definitely recommend to fans to add this album to the collection.

I must admit to not actually loving Bobby's past two studio albums, and yet I've happily bought both of them as well as this one without even listening to a single track. Sound pretty dumb come to think of it--but it's my way of supporting/saying thank you for his numerous mixtapes which he releases for free and are just as high production quality as his studio albums with the added benefit of stronger music as well. And to be honest, I feel about the same about this album as the past two studio ventures--decent yet not that exciting and certainly not as powerful as some of his mixtapes.I really do hate to be that person who goes on about the mixtapes and disses the studio albums, and yet I've always felt the more experimental and real side of Bobby is lacking on his studio efforts. That's not to say this album is bad though. Bobby writes catchy rap music that relies on his wide range of experience with rock and pop to create very current and unique music. He can rap, sing, write, play multiple instruments and is simply much more a musician and artist than almost all other mainstream rappers.Bobby has always been able to pick collaborators that compliment him well, and this album is no exception. The always welcome Ester Dean appears on "Wide Open", but it's the addition of another favorite of mine, Priscilla Renea, on "John Doe" that is really standout. Priscilla is a great match up for Bobby as she also is another very talented musician who dabbles in hip hop and R&B from time to time, yet can sing over anything from rock to adult contemporary pop. "Cranberry Moonwalk" with Mike Fresh is also another great collaboration."One Day" has a short interview clip at the end regarding Bobby's childhood, and his positive attitude on his rough upbringing is really admirable. My favorite song though is probably still "We in This..."  which he actually released on an old 2012 mixtape so it's not exactly new for me. That song though should indicate the general direction of many of the songs here though. This album is much more "gangsta rap" heavy than his previous ones.Still, I'm glad I can support Bobby and several songs (mainly his collaborations) will definitely make it into my "work commute" playlist. I would check out the singles to see what appeals. For fans of Chiddy Bang, Tinie Tempah, Labrinth and Wale.

To be honest, I'm generally extremely wary of shows like "Top of the Lake." In the past I've found them to be boring, pretentious, poorly done not to mention often needlessly depressing. I just kept seeing such great reviews for it though, and eventually thought, "why not, watching the first episode can't hurt." Reader be warned. You won't be able to just watch the first episode. About a day later, you will find yourself with bleary eyes and the realization that you just watched one of the finest  contributions to film of the year.To start off, it's not boring in the slightest which really makes no sense as a basic read of the plot would indicate that it should be. The essentials are that a young girl becomes pregnant, goes missing, and then the main character who is a detective spends the rest of the series talking to people trying to figure out what happened to the girl. However, writer and director Jane Campion has a brilliant ability to really draw out the major events and sustain the tension throughout long periods without big action sequences. She uses atmosphere and psychology to keep things riveting even when it's just two people talking to each other. Despite much of the major plot twists happening off-screen actually, Campion frames these events through the people who they affect and in turn these events take on a deeper meaning than if you saw them on-screen.As far as atmosphere and cinematography, "Top of the Lake" is positively stunning. Filmed in entirely on location in New Zealand, Campion doesn't need CGI or tricks for high impact--she let's the scenery speak for itself. This is no low budget production either. The quality of picture and color rivals that of any summer blockbuster.Now, this series does deal with some very heavy topics. Obviously, pedophilia is discussed--but so are a host of other things. Cancer, a parent's lies, incest, rape, sexism, misogyny, mental illness, clinical depression and organized crime all get the full treatment. Herein lies Campion's true gift. She somehow is able to craft the story and characters in such a way as to not drown the watcher in such a bleak and awful world and yet doesn't hold back from her subject matter either. Campion is also able to present these topics in a way that seems natural and integral to the story, instead of esoteric and pretentious.Holly Hunter's "GJ" character who is sort of a therapist/hippie/con artist/cult leader, did sometimes come across as a little over the top for me. Yet I could see how important her character was to the story and even the plot in spurring others to action.In short, this miniseries is gorgeous with stunning acting and a plot that is very dark yet won't overwhelm either. It should be obvious that this is most certainly not something for kids, but I would imagine almost all other age groups would find something to both enjoy as well as really contemplate. To often I find film to be used as a method for simply communication or entertainment, but it's the rare film that is all those things as well as art. And this is in fact one of those rare films that is both entertaining and provoking as well as exquisitely crafted art. Highly recommend.

One of my friends is from Hawaii and is always posting about local Poly bands. Sometime last year she started raving about this song, and I was immediately hooked. It steals a musical foundation of more traditional Poly music, but overlays tight R&B vocals to make a really standout song. It's just so chill and the lead singer has a fantastic range. Can't wait for their upcoming LP!

Buying relatively expensive items (like over $10) online always makes me wary. You just can't be sure of what exactly you're going to receive. I'm so grateful to every single person who wrote great reviews of these frames though, as it was the reviews that convinced me. And now I have a gorgeous frame that I know will be be loved when I give it as part of  Christmas present in a month.If you're expecting museum or high end art gallery framing, then these aren't for you. The "glass" is a thin sheet of plastic-ish material that works fine, but doesn't have quite the same reflection that a piece of high end glass would. But for most personal or home use, I can't imagine that anyone would be disappointed with these frames. My frame is sturdy yet surprisingly light given the how large it is (24x36 large and shipping info said it was about 14 lbs). The finish on the borders is quite detailed and the aged gold texture looks almost real. Simply, the frame looks and feels expensive.I bought the "Aged Ornate Gold" frame, which has a leather like border between the two wrought gold outer borders. I was impressed at how the middle section does genuinely look like leather from a distance, as the entire frame is all wood. I haven't used the back "hook" feature (and won't because this is a present for someone else), but I can tell that all the appropriate pieces are there and it looks sound in principal.Great purchase, and would recommend for anyone wanting a classy frame without wanting to pay hundreds of dollars.

***I just want to clarify something: I am not vested in any particular party and am speaking simply as a voracious reader and intelligent human being.  I have quite strong feelings about this, and want to be clear though that I am an "outside third party."***After chancing upon Rebecca Musser's "The Witness Wore Red: The 19th Wife Who Brought Polygamous Cult Leaders to Justice", I read it in a few hours and was intrigued to do further research in the FLDS world. After reading her little sister's book and a few other books, I chanced upon this one. As  Rebecca's book was actually quite similar to that of other ex members of the FLDS cult--I was intrigued in what exactly this alleged "brother Cole" was calling her out on as much of her story is public record and the rest has been attested to from several sources. Despite Cole hiding behind an alias, it does in fact seem as if this is the real Cole that Rebecca refers to throughout her book.However, after reading his "book" (really just a few pages of rambling and not a book at all)--I've come to several conclusions. Most importantly is that Cole doesn't call into question any major events from happening, simply the perspective of those events. As in, he doesn't say that Rebecca wasn't married to the 85 year old Prophet---but that she wasn't forced into the marriage.  He does go into some details over more minor events like he says he was never planning with her to help her escape, but frankly these so called repudiations either don't make sense, could have easily been misremembered or misinterpreted, or seem like its literally just a matter of a different perspective.Alleging that the events Rebecca described in her book as "lies" or "just a story" is an incredibly serious accusation. At first, I was just going to write this review to comment on Cole's issues with Rebecca's book--but the more I think about what he wrote, the angrier I get. Here's why.* It seems Cole's biggest complaint is that he doesn't believe that 19 year old Becky was "forced" into her marriage at all, as well as greatly enjoyed her time there with her 85 year old husband. He concedes that she was "brainwashed" but did not have misgivings about the marriage. I have several problems with this. Firstly, Cole was basically out of the picture by the time Becky was married. By his own account in this book, he was soon kicked out of the church and was considered an apostate.  I find it a huge overreach for Cole to assume any firsthand knowledge of a marriage that he was not a part of or in a position to literally know anything as he wasn't even in communication with Becky for the bulk of her marriage. Cole may have left the cult, and yet you can still see its insidious belief system in his way of thinking.* Cole's proof of Rebecca being "okay" with the marriage boils down to a single conversation he had with her and a random insert from another sister "Amelia". I'm not going to question whether either conversation happened--but will merely point out that two conversations if true, cannot disprove Rebecca's side of the story. It doesn't matter in the slightest whether or not Rebecca confided to her siblings at this time the thoughts she was having or whether she put on a happy face to "keep sweet." Giving them the benefit of the doubt--this is how they saw things. Doesn't mean at all that this was true from Rebecca's side of things. Cole pointedly doesn't mention the other conversations Rebecca had with her parents about her fears.* Cole repeatedly calls out his sister as being essentially an egotistical princess who loved her time in the Prophet's house/enjoyed being treated like royalty.  This more than slightly blows my mind. Again--he wasn't there so has zero credibility. Also, the things he talks about as being wonderful are frankly ridiculous.  Having access to a credit card means nothing when you're being monitored and your purchases tracked. Who cares if you get to ride in a private plane from time to time if you are not in control of where it is going.* The fact that he thinks these things would matter or somehow trump being sexually assaulted by someone old enough to be one's great grandfather and having no freedom of movement is both astonishing as well as clearly shows how little he values women. Blaming him is hard as this is what he was indoctrinated with since birth, but its no excuse. And to assume that a woman would or even should be happy as long as she has the trappings of some material comforts shows a total disregard for women as real people and is essentially reducing them to whores. This incredibly dangerous and appalling thinking  is a foundational element of rape culture and should be recognized as such.* As a last thought on this, women in the FLDS world were taught to keep their emotions hidden (to "keep sweet") and did not have honest conversations regarding things like rape. In fact I'd be surprised if that term even existed much like "sex" wasn't a word that was ever taught to the FLDS children (it was called "marital relations"). In short, even if Cole had been attune to the situation and was even in contact with Becky when this was happening (he wasn't--only got back in contact with her close to when she escaped), Becky wouldn't have been able to properly describe what she was really feeling to him anyway. And certainly wouldn't have gone into detail about the sexual abuse. This was simply a massive taboo topic.* The second big thing Cole says Becky lied about is that his father's first wife beating of him did not in fact cause his kidney to rupture. Rather, his kidney was simply infected. However, in the very next paragraph he writes: "My dad's first wife would get into a jealous rage, and in that blinding rage was psychologically, verbally, and physically abusive. She would get in a state where she just wasn't thinking rationally. Nor  likely even remembering what she did in those states."  He also states: "I don't know what happened or what they did while I was under anesthesia." I think this actually reinforces what Becky wrote, and at the very least doesn't "disprove it" as his knowledge of what happened actually came from others as he doesn't remember what happened. I'm not a doctor, but do know it's incredibly unusual for kids to get kidney infections unless there are extenuating circumstances.* As for the other "big reveals" of this book---there aren't any. Really, these are literally the only large issues that Cole has a problem with. He writes pages on how "Becky knows what her lies are" and "how damaging this is to the family" etc....  but doesn't provide any more detail or pinpoint any other major discrepancies. The things he mentions as being wrong all just so happen to paint him or other family members like his father in a much better light. Which honestly, I get. While Rebecca does give Cole plenty of credit for helping her start over, she also doesn't shy away from Cole's shortcomings. And I think that's the real issue here. He and quite probably his father who is described as both permitting grievous child abuse as well as later engaging in physical child abuse clearly did not enjoy this family history open to the public on a national scale. Thus this book simply becomes an effort to both discredit Rebecca over petty things that no one would be able to prove and salvage his and other specific family member's reputations.In short, I would seriously call into question Cole's perspective on everything--not just because he wasn't there for several events, or because he essentially is getting caught up on little details which do not in any way detract from Rebecca's story even if they are completely true (which I doubt)-but because Cole's fundamental perspective of this world and of women is vile and incredibly misogynistic. Ironically, several of the things Cole writes back up in fact as opposed to discredit Rebecca's account of what happened. To me this is obviously a case of a disgruntled family member who is simply upset at the attention that his two sisters have received and unhappy with how his and other family member's actions were portrayed. This book has a sensational title but zero substance.On a last note, Cole mentions that this book has not been edited and that it probably contains several errors. He wasn't kidding. This was a very hard book to read from both a grammatical as well as structural perspective. It doesn't flow well and reads like one long ramble.

As someone blessed to have been able to follow Delta Rae from their beginning (they're from my hometown), I've been eagerly anticipating when they would finally drop some new music. And thankfully--it lives up to those expectations! (mostly)....First the good: "Chasing Twisters" and "Run" are seriously fun. The band is at their best when it's Brittany and Liz on the main vocals (both pictured on the album cover), and these two songs were tailor made for the girls' explosive vocals. The boys deserve a lot of the credit though in pushing the energy to the max. In concert, you can tell that the entire band needs and feeds off of each other's energy--and you can really feel it in this EP. (Speaking of concerts--if they are ever in your area--go, go, go. Their live show is insane.) Also, "Dance in the Graveyards" though on their debut, was given a fresh new arrangement that is much more in line with how they actually perform it live and is a serious step up. "I Will Never Die" is a near perfect end and a great sequel to the mind blowing "Bottom of the River.""If I Loved You" was also on their debut, and this version with Lindsey Buckingham (of Fleetwood Mac fame) has been available for a single for a while, so if you're a fan you probably already have it. I dislike it when bands package their music 10 different ways. But honestly, my biggest complaint is not what's here--but what's not here. I was hoping/wishing/pleading that this would contain a studio recording of "Cold Day in Heaven" and "Rain Down on Me." I've seen them perform both songs live and they never fail to bring the house down. I want. I need. I crave. Please, seriously--if for some reason someone in the band ever reads this--please please please record them and put them on an album!Overall though--this is simply a very solid addition to the band's growing catalog, and is an exciting sign of what their second full album might sound like. If you love the band--buy this. For fans of Fleetwood Mac, ZZ Ward, The Avett Brothers, Wild Feathers etc... Hugely recommend and also a great introduction to the band for any newcomers.

Jhen Aiko has been around for years since some features on obscure B2K remixes back in the early 2000s, but it's only recently with some guest appearances on Big Sean and Drake tracks that she's been beginning to gain momentum. Though this track still features a rapper--the witty and thoughtful Donald Glover aka Childish Gambino, Aiko shows that she can carry a song on her own instead of just dropping a chorus. This song is chill and fresh sounding R&B. However, Aiko is slightly auto tuned at times (which she totally doesn't need) as well as doesn't show off her vocal range which would have helped give this song a bit more punch. Still pleasant though, and I hope Aiko can finally get the mainstream recognition that she deserves.

Thankfully, I have yet to test out this filter's ability to withstand damage/protect my extremely expensive lens. But I can speak to it's clarity and high build quality. I've used this on my Canon 24-105mm f/4 lens for several shoots and literally can't tell the difference between shots when this lens if off, and when it's on. I've studied side by side comparisons in detail in a variety of lighting conditions and can't tell any major difference between shots with this on and off my lens. So A+ on clarity.This also fits very well on my lens. Tight and like it was simply another part of my lens instead of being a separate piece. It also accommodates a large lens hood being placed on top of it with no problem. All the threads line up and fit perfectly. Hopefully I'll never have to discover if this can prevent my glass from cracking in event of a fall--but it's completely worth it in protect my glass from dust and scratches. When you are paying over a thousand for a lens, it's stupid not to make sure it's properly shielded. I've tried knockoff cheapo filters, and none have come close in terms of clarity and build quality. Highly recommend.

I bought this diffuser because I wanted to upgrade from my velcro cheapo setup, and after reading several reviews of various diffusers was content I was on the right track with the LightSphere. Does it work as intended? Yes. As far as various diffusers I've been able to try out--this works comparably. However, I was expecting something a whole lot better than comparable considering that a lot of diffusers cost barely ten dollars. The construction here is quite sturdy, which I should be thrilled about as that generally means quality product---but my main problem with this diffuser is that it's actually far too sturdy. The plastic might be flexible, but it's very dense and thick. It weighs like a ton of bricks on my flash and actually can move my flash out of position when it's at a strange angle because it's literally just that heavy. At one point during a recent night shoot, I literally had to hold my flash in position so that I could get the light to bounce correctly as the diffuser just kept shifting the flash.Too expensive and very hard to use when you're constantly worrying about whether it's going to shift your flash. Looks professional and works reasonably well but the build just let's everything down. Disappointing.

I wanted a pocket mirror for my desk at work that was simple and unobtrusive. I was pleased with the rather non super girly and classic look of this mirror, but was bummed when I finally got it. It's simply hard to open. I have to use my fingernails sometimes which is painful--and even then it still won't open on the first few tries. They should have made the "latch" area larger, and not as tight. Disappointing.

I tested this out recently on a video shoot that needed to look like it was shot at different times of the day--and the gels really helped in slightly changing the tone of my video. Also, it provided all the light I needed and more (although I was pretty close to my subjects at all times and didn't test it out over a large field or anything). I used if for about three hours of sustained shooting and it didn't get too warm either which I was worried about. I read several reviews here, and something I didn't realize until I received the light was that it comes with a battery adapter so that you're not tied down to just using AAs which is a nice touch. It would have been nice if the angle was more flexible but for the price, I couldn't be more happy.

Like pretty much every teenager ever, I would latch on to bands and artists that expressed some of the confusion and angst that are practically teenage rites of passage. Eminem, Skillet, Seether, Breaking Benjamin, Flyleaf, Evanescence and Amanda Palmer just spoke to my middle school soul. As a slightly older adult now, I find myself listening to these bands less frequently as thankfully I've grown and matured--but every once in a while--there is nothing else in the world that can fit the mood. That mood when you're just told off at work by your boss, or ditched by your friends, or caught in between a fight with people you love--that feeling.Icon for Hire has now entered that rotation of bands for when I can't process my thoughts but just know I'm hurt and angry. As nice and deep as bands like Bon Iver are--sometimes you just want something to hit you in the face. Subtlety and poetic lyrics can be checked at the door. Albeit much more poppy and less explicit than many of the bands mentioned above--they're honest and hardhitting. What makes Icon different though, is the message of hope interspersed with the pain. And that's incredibly comforting. I listen to music like this not to make myself more depressed or angrier--but to process my feelings and then come down and stabilize. And Icon let's me do that and more. I can know that whatever it is, will be okay.That said--I would be into this album for the music even without the lyrics. It has influences of early 2000's pop punk groups mixed with more modern electronic synth inspired tones--with hints of hip hop. While not perfect, Icon manages to basically nail this combination which makes for very "now" extremely catchy music.Highly recommend. For parents looking for music that might really connect with confused teens (yet with a positive spin) or young 20 somethings just looking for cool music. For fans of more punk rock bands like Paramore, Flyleaf, Fireflight as well as fans of more pop/electronic outfits like Kerli, Krewella or even Dev.

Gorgeous. Film makers tend to still score movies with "classical" soundtracks for a reason if they have the money for original scores. There is a timeless quality to well done classical music that just can't be touched. You don't have to understand the words to be swept up in the emotion or just bask in the beauty of exquisite art. In this song, opera legends Ernest Blanc and Nicolai Gedda pair their voices for one of my favorite songs. The solo parts aren't as powerful as when they are singing together, but in a way it's worth it to build anticipation and make you appreciate the duets that much more. When they hit the high notes on the chorus together, it's just sublime. If you're like me and tend to just "skim" from most music genres but can appreciate opera, then I would highly recommend this song as it's extremely melodic and accessible. And for any hardcore fans of the genre, then you probably already know and love this song. However, if you haven't heard Gedda's and Blanc's interpretation then I would still pick this up.

If you happened to have just completely loved Diane's first album and were expecting more of the same, then you might be somewhat put off by this followup. The first album drew quick comparisons to Carole King and Norah Jones, but this one is much more in the same lines as artists like Florence Welch or Adele. There's an increased emphasis on larger orchestral pieces punctuated with a strong bass line. It's darker yet more pop friendly and seems to be closer to the type of artist that Diane sees herself as."Lighthouse" is the first song standout (I personally would have started the album with it instead of the rather mundane "Speak a Little Louder." It combines synths, strong backing vocals, handclaps, hints of piano and a throbbing beat that veers between 70s pop and modern indie pop and really sets the tone for the album.  It's both darker as well as more interesting than almost all of her previous work combined.  "Tell Me Tomorrow"  has a strong piano line but pairs it with a restrained vocal and lightly upbeat music. If you switched out the piano for a guitar, it wouldn't be out of place on a Faith Hill album."It Plays On" is a softer ballad that is borderline magic. Hypnotic and ragged with raw emotion--it's worth the price of the entire album. Also, I cannot stress enough that the normal cd is not what you want-get the deluxe. "Adelaide", "Staring At You", and "Hold On A Little Longer" are massive tracks.Some people may  be surprised to see the appearance of the "[Explicit]" tag after the album title, and it's due to inclusion of "Unf*d" which probably isn't quite what you're imagining. It's one of the few pure piano ballads on the album and is actually one of Diane's most vulnerable and likeable moments. It's honest and so very human. That said---if language isn't your thing--no need to avoid the album for literally just one track.I really could go into detail about almost all of the rest of the songs on the album. It's all just that universally consistent and interesting. Diane's lyrics continue to be a bit of a problem area though. They're not awful, just sort of generic. She's capable of more. Her father recently passed, and while you can hear the darker tone and mood to the album--I think she could have reflected this darkness a bit more in the actual lyrics as well.I thought Diane's first album was pleasant--but this one is memorable. And that's honestly one of the highest praises I can give an album. I've been blessed to have been exposed to a tremendous range as well as volume of music, and while I enjoy lots of artists--not many stay on my mind. With "Speak A Little Louder" though, Diane has made an indelible impression. Highly recommend.

I have to admit that while I remember that at the time I liked Lissie's debut album, I can't really remember any songs from it (went back and listened to it for this review). I don't think I'll have that problem with this album though. It's like Lissie took all the good from her debut, and spiked it with bolder instrumentation and even better crafted hooks. This album is right on trend with hints of 70s and 80s rock like Tom Petty or Aerosmith with a healthy channeling of Stevie Nicks, wrapped up in a bright upbeat pop/folk/rock package.Lissie's not the most witty or poetic lyricist, but what she lacks in originality--she makes up for in earnestness and a willingness to just lay it all out there. The music on this album is bold and is much better vehicle for her emotions than her more muted and acoustic debut album. The drums and groove to "Shameless" manage to convey a sense of youthful rebellion which Lissie pairs with the admirable declaration that: "I don't want to be famous/If I got to be shameless." "Sleepwalking" is one of my favorites with a much more chill vibe and totally relaxed chorus that you will just want to sink into like a favorite recliner. "What It's Like" and "I Bet On You" are other standout tracks.There's something maddeningly about this album though--which is that several of the best songs have bits and pieces that sounds incredibly familiar. It's not to the point where I could say "oh song x sounds exactly like song y from back in the day." And yet there are repeated isolated sounds that I just know I've heard before. It's not a bad thing, and quite frankly probably played no small part in my immediate enjoyment of it--but it's just continually in the back of my mind which for a music junkie is super frustrating.Taking everything into account though, this is a very pleasurable listen with big hooks that have me hitting the repeat button, and enough honesty that allows me to really connect as well. For fans artists/bands like Brandi Carlile, First Aid Kit, Alabama Shakes, 70s and 80s rockers, and Fleetwood Mac.**Update, I've been listening to this album for weeks now--and it's only gotten better actually. I find myself really digging into it at a deeper level than I do with most albums. Pleasantly surprised.

Throw any expectations you might have had about this album right out the window. Whatever direction you thought British soul singer Vanessa (VV) Brown was going to go into after her commercially successful debut "Traveling Like the Light"--guaranteed this is not it. In fact, you would be hard pressed to even recognize her voice. So what is this album all about, and what on earth has happened to VV?"Samson & Delilah" is highly polarizing art pop. It's part conceptual, based loosely on the Biblical story of Samson & Delilah, and part swirling landscape of operatic/goth/experimental pop. It will either be your thing or very much not be your thing. It's the product four years of creative growth stemming from her ditching her previous label, recording an entire album which she then refused to put out as she felt it just wasn't her, creating her own fashion line, and finally creating her own music label which has let her put out an album that is all hers from conception to production.For anyone unaware, Samson was essentially a ruler of ancient Israel who was blessed with supernatural strength that was somehow tied to his hair. Also, he loved the ladies and partying it up. Over the course of his life, Samson amassed a large group of political and personal enemies who became intent on his downfall. Enter Delilah. She seduces Samson and after a while, he falls in love with her and lets her in on the secret of where his remarkable strength comes from. Delilah promptly betrays Samson for a large amount of cash money and has Samson's head shaved--thus rendering him weak and able to be captured. Most people familiar with the story stop there, but Samson's saga continues. Though his eyes were gouged out and he becomes sort of spectacle for mocking amusement, eventually his hair grows back out and he commits suicide by literally pulling down the central columns of a building where his captors were partying thus getting revenge and killing tons of people in the process.Whew. Bible history time is now over. Why does any of that matter? Well in pop culture, Delilah has become synonymous with a sort of cool sexy femme fatale but people often forget about Samson's role in all this. And what's interesting on this album, is that in many ways VV could be singing from the perspective of Samson instead of Delilah which throws a wicked twist on an already charged tale of obsessive lust, betrayal and murderous revenge. Lyrically, this album is simply light years more interesting and layered than her debut though she falls back on tired cliches more often than I'd like.Musically, this album is something else. Cohesive it is not. Which to be honest is half the fun. Album opener, "Substitute for Love" is one of the strongest tracks on the album and is VV's way of letting the listener know from moment one, that she's doing whatever she wants with this album. Slow and ethereal, it's almost a modern pop take on a requiem. "Samson" contains a similar feel, but this time VV drives the song with a big drum line which makes it more accessible and even danceable. If you like "Samson" then chances are you'll also probably like it's twin "Igneous." Aside from the opener though, there are several other gorgeous ballads like "Knife." Album closer, the six minute long "Beginning" is perhaps the most experimental track on the album. There's not really lyrics as much as sounds. It's meant to intrigue, tease.While I would respect VV for attempting something this ambitious, I respect her even more that she was in fact able to pull an album like this off. Sure it has it's moments where things just didn't come together, but I kept thinking of how I just haven't heard something quite like this done in this way before. What differentiates this album from others who would fall into the same vague genre--is that VV still retains hints of her background in vintage r&b powerful soul music--which gives her operatic delivery on this album some much needed edge and interest. This album was wholly unexpected, but a very enjoyable surprise for me.For fans of artists like: Imogen Heap, Lykke Li, Active Child, Marina & the Diamonds, Bjork and even someone like Tarja Turunen. Must have tracks: "Substitute for Love," "Samson," "The Apple", "Faith", "Igneous."

2013 has been the year of Haim. From dominating the summer festival circuit to performing for prime ministers and gaining rabid fans the world over--these three sisters from California have done all of this without an official LP to their name. Now that it's finally here, it's both what I had hoped for as well as refreshingly surprising. To say that their music contains a whole host of influences is an understatement, yet the sisters ground their many influences in their sweet perfect harmonies and bouncy feel good attitude floating throughout the entire album.The Haim sisters come from a family of accomplished musicians which makes sense as their technical skill and ability to craft songs is borderline genius. The flitting nuances and subtleties come not just from musicians who love music and can sing and play, but those who have deeply lived and breathed music their entire lives as well as exposed to an incredible range of music from birth. Thus the music has an organic and effortless appeal despite the many disparate tones which belies the tremendous talent it takes to create an album like this. Musically, this album really surprised me as it manages to both be almost immediately accessible as well as satisfying with real weight.The first three tracks off the album make for a 1-2-3 punch of frankly some of the best pop music of 2013. "Forever" is my favorite out of the three currently, but ask me in another month or two and it might well be "The Wire" or "Falling." "If I Could Change Your Mind" has a nice r&b influence, and while upbeat is one of the more serious and emotional tracks on the album. "Days Are Gone" is a really fun meld of electronic and folk with a strange little almost chirping synth sound in parts and also sees the appearance of Alana with lead vocal duties. Danielle has the majority of lead vocals on the album, but Alana and Este each take turns stepping up to mike. "My Song 5" is another showstopper with a wicked deep grunge industrial feel paired with a bass line that pops in and out making for a very odd yet memorable moment. "Let Me Go" is a continuation of the darker feel to the latter half of the album and really shows just how much depth these girls have.If I had just one minor criticism of this album, it's that sometimes the Haim sisters are too professional and polished for their own good. Produced by Ariel Rechtshaid (Vampire Weekend, Alex Clare, We Are Scientists) this album would have benefited from the vocals instead of the always the music conveying the angrier emotions. Imperfections are what make us human, and a few broken notes or a raw breakdown thrown in some songs would have made it a bit more relatable. Their live wild/hippie/rockstar personas don't quite match up with the very tight and technically sound song writing and instrumentals, and I think they need to work on a way to better mesh their personalities into their music. You can be wild and carefree while still being an un-apologetically serious musician.If you asked me to outright define Haim's sound, the best I could do is throw a bunch words out there and hope a few stick. I'm not sure I've ever heard such an effortless amalgamation of influences turned into one compelling and consistent feel. I realize I'm gushing about this album, but Haim is here to stay and their obvious passion paired with their breadth of knowledge and talent makes them the type of artists that I'm sure I'll still be hearing new albums from 30 years from now. I don't want to detract from the amount of blood, sweat and tears these girls have spent working for this moment---but they have a magic that can't be taught or bought. This music is a piece of their soul. Adventurous, Daring, Bubbly and so very SoCal. And they're only just beginning. Highly recommend.

Two things first: the majority of songs on this album don't come anywhere close to the radio friendliness of "Royals" and this album is most certainly a grower instead of an immediate sugar rush. Best advice--find these songs on YouTube or elsewhere and really listen before you decide whether or not buying the entire album is for you. You will be disappointed if you're expecting 10 songs similar to "Royals", but if you keep an open mind then I think you can really experience something special.Much has been made of New Zealand's 16 year old Ella Yelich-O'Connor's skyrocket ascension into the top of the charts--but when it comes right down to it--all I'm concerned about is whether she delivers. And I think she does--not in the way I was expecting, but in a way that makes me incredibly excited about her future and solidifies her as more than a one trick pony in my book. Lyrically Ella is both wise beyond her years as well as still a teenager, constantly walking a tricky balance of keen life observations mixed with insecurity and idealism.This album is extremely cohesive both thematically and musically, relying on minimal electronic pulses and a bass line that that grounds the entire album but never takes the forefront. This enables Ella to basically do whatever she feels like with the melody and use her own voice in layers and loops to become another instrument. Ella stays comfortably in her hypnotic lower register for the most part and paired with the stark and aloof beats makes this album sound different from every mainstream young pop starlet.But unfortunately, it means a few songs towards the middle all sound similar by lacking either a buildup or any special sound to really differentiate them. The album is essentially front and back loaded though with "Tennis Court", "Royals", "White Teeth Teens", and "A World Alone" being the must have tracks. The middle contains some growers like "Team", but the rest will have you pressing the skip button unless you just so happen to really connect to the lyrics.That said, Ella's fearlessness in creating an album that is just so out there is commendable and pays off when she gets everything lined up perfectly. The fact that she was discovered when she was 12 by a major label actually makes me appreciate even more just how hard she must have had to fight to write her own songs (which she does) and craft an album that is all her. Her best moments scream volumes of what she's capable of in the future, and I know that I'll be along for the ride.Ella doesn't sound that similar to any of these artists but I bet if you enjoy artists like Charli XCX, London Grammar, BANKS, Earl Sweatshirt (in attitude), Fiona Apple, Ruby Frost, or even Bipolar Sunshine that you'll at least enjoy the standout tracks here. Think lovechild between Lana Del Rey and Kanye.

I'm almost embarrassed to say how much I loved this series. It has ridiculous amounts of both explicit violent gore and sex. And if that is all this series was about-or if both of those aspects weren't flawlessly  integrated into making the story--then I wouldn't be here at all. However, here--it all just makes sense.I think the biggest thing that separates "Banshee" from similar tv shows that go for the "HBO" content--is that they realized that character development is foundation to all. The violence and sex would quite frankly have been awful if that was the star of the show. Instead, the characters are well drawn out and incredibly sympathetic, making the violence and sex just a part of who these characters are and just part of their intense stories.And the plot really is intense. Man gets out of prison, kills some people, then impersonates a sheriff all the while trying to stay hidden from a Russian mafia boss who wants him dead as well as maybe win back his ex-girlfriend. I realize that sounds absurd and rather dumb on paper--but again--it just works. In fact, everything would quite frankly either seem voyeuristic or just plain stupid if it wasn't for the amazing cast.  The acting here is top quality and this is what gives the far fetching plot and gratuitousness weight and a natural impact.Kiwi Antony Starr has a remarkable talent for being able to mete out extreme violence and yet look sad and regretful the entire time. Hoon Lee as Starr's sidekick could have been a very camp role as Lee's character is frequently in drag and spewing catchy one liners--and yet Lee's character "Job" is one of the most hardcore and rock like characters in the whole cast. Ivana Milicevic plays Starr's ex, and her physicality in this role is astonishing. She's believable as both a warm and loving mother as well as the type of person who you would want by your side to face an angry horde of zombies with. Ulrich Thomsen rounds out the fantastic cast as the local ex-Amish mafia lord who is emotionally caught in two worlds thus slightly sympathetic yet capable of horrible violence.The production value wasn't something that I particularly noticed--which actually speaks volumes to the quality of the CGI as I was never once pulled out of the story by too "fake" looking gore. Although, I also tend to shut my eyes when body parts get torn off so maybe I'm not the best judge of that. However, the set was really nicely done. They focused on just doing a small town and a few key locations really well--which works much better than if they had tried to spread out their budget.Again--if gratuitousness in any way isn't your thing--don't even try attempting to watch the first episode. I think within the first 10 minutes there was three people killed and a sex scene. However, if you can possibly see past that, or are coming here for that--know that you're in for a fantastic thrilling story. Can't wait for season 2!

Came across this song in a trailer and just needed to have it. It's subtle and repetitive which usually equals boring, but this is a song that you just wrap around you.  The general vibe reminds me somewhat of Active Child, but not as complex. This song though just floats across the cosmos and conjures up grand houses now standing empty, standing on top of a mountain by yourself and something not quite natural. The basic piano line bumped up with tinges of electronic makes for a compelling and ghostly soundscape. Love.

It was Sarah's cover of the The Decemberists' "Shankill Butchers" off of her 2009 debut when she was just 18, that first put her on my radar. Haunting with incredible technical skill on both the banjo and the mandolin--she was incredibly exciting and yet collectively both her debut and follow up record fell flat for me. Quite frankly, it always just felt like she didn't have much to say which in my eyes is one of the worst things in the traditional folk world. It can't just sound good--it needs to be torn from your soul. This is where all that changes."Mile on the Moon" has a crooning country atmosphere with an electric guitar giving it a little edge. Album title track "Build Me Up from Bones" is an early album standout and is a great example of how accessible Sarah can make traditional instruments sound. Soft and lilting with picked cello and fiddle notes, its refreshingly genuine and heartfelt. Sarah's take on Bob Dylan's "Simply Twist of Fate" is subtle with extremely minimal instrumentation--but sounds like its an original Jarosz song as she so completely owns it. Her other cover, "Book of Right-On" by Joanna Newsom is actually one of the album's few low points as it doesn't sound that different from the original as well as lacks Joanna's stunning quirk.This album was produced by longtime collaborator, Gary Paczosa (Alison Krauss, Dolly Parton) and also features a few guests spots with Chris Thile, Aoife O'Donovan, and Darrell Scott--but perhaps for the first time--the focus is consistently on Sarah and her band of two, Nathaniel Smith, and Alex Hargreaves. The music sounds more organic like it was all recorded together and less like it was just Sarah's parts with the rest dubbed. Her songwriting maturity is also on full display. Her use of second and third person has been replaced by Sarah finally being an integral part of the story.  And finally, I think the third thing which sets this album apart is the more expansive tone.  In the midst of finishing this album, Sarah graduated with honors from the extremely prestigious New England Conservatory--and I think everything she was exposed to there enabled her to both more more confident in her sound as well as branch out a bit.Sarah is part of a very exciting movement of young people who love traditional folk music yet understand how to frame it within a more modern melodic palette. Highly recommend. For fans of bands/artists like Gillian Welch, Valerie June, Nickel Creek.

You would have had to have been living under a rock buried under sand in different galaxy to have not heard the song of the summer, Icona Pop's "I Love It." It was everywhere and like it or not is going to be the standard by which people judge this album. Well did Swedith duo, Caroline Hjelt and Aino Jawo, manage to put out an album full of more "I Love It"s? No. But that doesn't mean plenty of songs don't make a very good attempt.Many people are already buzzing about album closer "Then We Kiss" as being the next big hit, but it lacks the aggression that made "I Love It" standout for me. "In the Stars" though has a euro pop edge with a bombastic chorus which I think makes it possibly even better than "I Love It." "Just Another Night" though is probably my favorite with its more melancholic tone and allows the girls to shine individually on the verses allowing glimpses of needed rawness in a very slick polished soundscape. "Girlfriend" borrows two lines from Tupac's "Me and My Girlfriend" and twists them into a totally new meaning. Big risk for a big payoff.Caroline and Aino got together about four years ago, and rumor has it that the very night they first met at a party was when they decided they were going to make music together. This clear chemistry and almost familial blending of voices is the thread that holds this album together. When it's right--it's very very right. And then at other times, you wish they just let loose a little bit which would have given the songs a needed hit of emotion.This album is not going to blow your mind, but it will occupy your mind for a long while after the music has actually stopped playing from your speakers. Very solid pop/dance music from two fantastic vocalists.For fans of bands like The Ting Tings, Florrie, Charli XCX, Natalia Kills, Marina & The Diamonds.

For the past year, buzz about Scottish synthpop band Chvrches has been steadily growing. From appearances at major festivals like SXSW to touring alongside bands like Depeche Mode and Passion Pit, Chvrches have been doing their best to stand out in a sea of synth pop. And on their debut, "The Bones of What You Believe"--they do in fact stand out in the best of ways. Accessible and fun yet with an underlying aggression and angst paired with strong beats and a full bodied vocal, Chvrches has created an album that many established pop stars don't seem to be capable of making.Lead vocalist Lauren Mayberry deserves much of the credit for the success of this album. A lot of similar bands have girl vocals that are thin and whimsical, but Lauren has a fuller sound, better range and an uncanny skill at building layers of drama and emotion through tiny tone changes. She can casually get away with quite dark lyrics at times and still have the music sound very danceable and light given her sweet clear tone. Just like how it took me several plays of Foster the People's "Pumped Up Kicks" to actually realize what they were singing about as the lyrics and bouncy tone are quite incongruous, Lauren's music has several similar moments though not to that extreme. Her lyrics have an intelligence and layer of complexity that is unusual, which may or may not be related to the fact that Lauren is highly educated with a full law degree as well as Masters in journalism.Musically, this album doesn't exactly break new ground but when playing the album through--the songs thankfully do stand out from each other which I find is my most common problem with synth based music. It's also more refreshingly straightforward than similar bands like Purity Ring. And yet-with Lauren's vocals--it still has the ability to stomp out major anthems for intense highs. "Recover" is mind numbingly catchy with a chorus that's going to wreak havoc with your subconscious. "Science/Visions" has a very ethereal almost movie score quality to it which is very interesting. "Gun" was just featured on the FIFA 14 soundtrack and suitably shiny and bright.Finally, if you happen to have a chance to see them live--do so. While they are naturally high energy with an infectious enthusiasm---they're also hilarious and self deprecatingly genuine. In short--though not musically brilliant, this album has so much going for it just entices and draws you in. It's like a will-o-the-wisp ghostly shining on a dark moor at night. You just can't help yourself but to follow. And dance.For fans of bands like Passion Pit, M83, The Naked and Famous, Purity Ring and Kate Boy.

I recently bought a custom machined pen that was created specifically for the Fineliner ink refill. I'm not a huge fan of Mont Blanc pens--but the actual inks are exquisite. The Fineliner is almost like writing with a marker or Sharpie--except smoother and the ink is essentially instantly dry. Also, this is not a fine tip but is instead closer to a broad. The ink does run out more often than I would like when each refill costs roughly $7.50, but the experience of writing with them trumps cost and inconvenience. This is the Ferrari of Mont Blanc inks, it both performs as well is ridiculously sexy. If you're a pen aficionado, then I highly recommend.

My feelings about New Zealand band The Naked and Famous's first album, "Passive Me, Aggressive You", verge on the ridiculous. They had simply managed to create such a unique synth/electronic/pop sound that was so fresh, memorable and fun that was I completely hooked. Ever since, I've just had huge expectations of the possibilities of this album. Does it completely live up to my expectations---no--and in many ways I think you could argue this is a weaker record, but it's good to keep in mind that the album I'm comparing it to one of my 2010 albums of the year. At the end of the day, this album is more mature and moodier with a wider range of instrumentation--and still has moments of epic bombastic highs.This album starts off with a bang-- "A Stillness", "Hearts Like Ours", and "Rolling Waves" are three of the best tracks off the album. Album opener, "A Stillness" also shows the broader musical range of the band on this album with it's acoustic guitar driven edge. "Waltz" has a classy duet of Thom's and Alisa's vocals floating over each others which creates something really special (this layering appears on a couple different songs actually). "The Mess" and "I Kill Giants" are both solid hits for me as well. Not spectacular, but consistently enjoyable and will be go to songs as they can fit many different moods. "A Small Reunion" is a beautiful epic close with the appearance of a building vibrant strings section that just makes so much sense paired with TNAF's signature synth/drum/guitar sound.In fact, I wish they would have played around more with the strings on several latter middle half songs like "We Are Leaving", "Grow Old", "Golden Girl" and "What We Want." They have great ends but tepid and rather boring beginnings. The addition of some interesting instruments on the first halves of these songs could have really saved them. It's not that I insist all TNAF songs be upbeat--but to have several in a row with the same song structure (minimal and quiet for about 2-3 minutes, then get aggressive), it just takes away the drama of the songs. It let's them bleed together which is just as bad on an album as it is when your clothes in the washing machine all come out hot pink. Also, I felt that nothing even the singles on the album reached the same heights of "Punching in a Dream" from their debut.That said--we're just a few months short of the end of the year here, and this is definitely one of the pop standouts for me. MGMT and Grouplove both have albums dropping today too, and I have to think this was somewhat of an intentional thing as these bands often get compared. In that tossup--hands down, it's TNAF. This album is just more cohesive with better hooks as well as an increasing depth of lyrics and atmosphere which I think really makes them stand out. Final round win for the Kiwis and here's hoping to even better progression and song structures on their next venture!For fans of bands like CHVRCHES, M83, and Passion Pit.

***If you don't already know the story--then this review contains the basic plot spoilers. Also, as of November 22, one of Rebecca's brothers has made some mildly inflammatory comments about this book in a short ebook. Short story--it's sensationalism without any substance over minor details and reads like that of a jealous family member angry at the way he was portrayed. Don't bother purchasing it (for anyone interested--I wrote a detailed review of it)***First things first. This book is not an attack against Mormons, God or even polygamy. And neither is this review. It makes clear distinctions about why the type of FLDS that Warren Jeffs was leading was in fact very different from both Mormonism as well as other forms of Christianity. If I recall--not once does Rebecca even use the word cult--but for the purposes of this review, I am going to. In my opinion, whether it's under the guise of religion or helter skelter--when you have a population of people who are both terrified of as well as essentially worship a singular leader, cut off from the rest of the world, indoctrinated from birth, driving out all those who dare to question, and most importantly creating a system of that greatly disadvantages and mentally stunts a portion of the population so that they are easier to control--that is in fact a cult.I rarely read books like these (although I did greatly enjoy the Susan Atkins' autobiography), but every once in a while I come across a news story that just captures my imagination. I remember seeing news articles when Jeffs was arrested where there was just a lot of controversy about whether or not Jeffs and his congregation of FLDS members were just misunderstood or whether they were in fact criminals. Eventually, during his trial--more evidence came to light that Jeffs was in fact a serial pedophile and abuser not to mention was a total con artist concerning his "religion". Jeffs would preach about abstaining from "worldly sins" but then would use the substantial tithe money to live the very type of life that he preached against.
