I don't consider this book to fall into the genre of "Christian reading" so much as to say that it simply does not need the foul language aspect to make the captivating points that it does. This book is well-written.Of course the thrust of this tale bulges with cloaked ethical messages, all nicely worked into the story but teens will get the picture clearly enough. I mention The Catcher in the Rye,(one of my huge favorites), in my title because it's the same *sort* of story: confused youth seeks moral direction - diaphanous hope lies ahead. An underlying theme here addresses the topic of bullying, making the book very timely and worthwhile, but that aspect is not in one's face and does not in any way blot out the joy of leisurely reading.This book is a rare find and would make a great gift for any young teen, especially boys but it's okay for girls as well. Highly recommended.

First and up front, you will not find a better no-stick skillet than this one for the price.If there was ever truly a non-stick pan it is this one. You want to fry an egg without using cooking oil? Go right ahead - I achieved that with no problem over fairly low heat using a plastic spatula. A perfect over-medium egg.The heat distribution in this skillet is terrific. The skillet itself is pretty lightweight but there's a fully adequate thickness to the bottom. I have used it multiple times at this point and I have yet to detect a mark or scratch on the inside. Of course, it is a breeze to wash and for frittatas, (for example), you can place this skillet inside a 350-degree F. oven without damaging it. The silicone handle feels very nice in the hand.I cannot say that I'm wild about the exterior color but neither do I find it particularly hateful. It does have a very modern appearance. If you're looking for a great no-stick skillet at a budget price, I can highly recommend this one. I've been cooking for many years and I'm a five-star chef on Food.com ["Bone Man" over there] so I'm not just yanking your chain.

Well, I'm sure that there are other folks who could also enjoy this book nearly as much as I have; however, to wring the last bit of reading delight it helps to know a bit about Russian history. I don't mean dates, wars, and all that so much but more along the lines of the cultural proclivities and the personalities mentioned, (especially political ones.) You won't be lost if you know little of Mother Russia - the author explains a great deal but it's just better if you can read the work with a sense of Russian anthropology and to be able to comprehend the depraved mindset of the repressive Soviet Regime.The author takes us through the years of her childhood and forward, often regressing to culinary tales from her past, (often re-told to her by friends and relatives.) The author immigrated to America in her youth but she clearly wishes to cling to her Russian past so far as food is concerned, even back to the age of the Tsars when life was radically different, even for the peasants, than it was during the Soviet years after 1918. [At that point, Tsar Nicholas II had been murdered along with his entire family, Kerensky had assumed the role of leadership, and the Bolsheviks, (Communists), were about to change life for the Russians and the people of many surrounding countries for the next seventy years.]This is neither a recipe book nor a cookbook so much as it is a reflection on life. There are some recipes, a number you might wish to try and some not. Still, for the average American, the distinctive nature of these dishes might just make you think in new ways about your own cooking.I loved this book and, especially for those I mentioned, I give it my highest recommendation.

At first I didn't care much for this tea pot but it has grown on me and now I couldn't do without it. I should say up front that I'm not using it for its intended purpose -- I'm just boiling water.This has become an item of major convenience since I can move it anywhere I wish, and it likely saves me money, instead of using my gas cook stove for the same purpose -- propane is high these days!I just plug it in, add about a quart of tap water to the pot, and then hit the little lever which causes a small power indicator light to illuminate. When the water is hot, you hear a "click", (the "start" lever popping back up - you quickly become acclimated to hearing this sound), and the light goes out indicating that the water is boiling hot. Now I'm ready to make my bagged tea or instant coffee.This heats water really fast, (about 7 minutes the first time around), and of course the less water you have added to the pot, the faster it heats. There is a convenient "see-through" gauge on the pot to let you know the status of the water level.The best thing about this tea pot is the handle. The balance with water in the pot is perfect -- a joy to the hand!If the pot has a drawback it is that you cannot get your hand down inside to wash it - you need one of those sponge glass washers. There is some sort of cone device up the center of the inside. But honestly, as I'm just boiling water, I don't see a need to clean it all that often.I love this "teapot", I especially like the mobility of the unit, and I highly recommend it to instant coffee drinkers or to those who use a teabag in a cup.

One of my family members is afflicted with sugar diabetes and she has tried this product for about two weeks. She is sold on its effectiveness in that it has improved her general sense of well-being. She says that she feels like doing more, evidently a result of something in the product which has somewhat stabilized her condition.She has experienced no difficulties in terms of drug interaction, (a concern with any product like this which one tries for the first time), so in summary, this represents an improvement in her quality of life.Highly recommended.

I have a family member who suffers from multiple sclerosis and, after using this product for a couple of weeks, he is quite pleased with the results.It's not so much that he feels better when he gets out of bed but rather when he is doing physical chores, yard work and the like, he has noticed that many of the discomforts which typically impede his movements are not so prevalent as they previously were. That is quite important to anyone who has to endure this affliction. It's not a huge change but any benefit whatever is much noticed and appreciated.Highly recommended.

This watch looks much more expensive than it is. The photo looks good but the watch actually looks much better.If you like a watch with a large face and lots of gewgaws, you should definitely consider this one. It's very accurate and includes the day, date, and month. The face also includes 60 clearly-viewable increments for the seconds, very handy for people who work in the medical profession.I was much pleased with the instructions. They are well-written and everything happened as it was supposed to.The three bands which come with the watch are each an attractive leather, black, brown, and dark blue to match your attire. They are no more difficult to change than on any similar watch, pretty easy.This watch gets my highest recommendation.

We have multiple bird-feeders for various species in the back yard, including two hummingbird feeders. Since my neighbor also maintains hummingbird feeders we have LOTS of birds coming in. This particular feeder has worked out great due to its thoughtful design.First, the reservoir is large enough to last for two days. (You don't want to go too long without changing the sugar water because it will cloud and ferment.)Second, this is an incredibly easy feeder to clean. I can take this feeder down, scrub it out, rinse and refill it in less than five minutes.Third, the "ant trap" on the lid, (a small ring/water reservoir), gets added to by any rain we get. Additionally, I see other bird species actually drinking the water from the ant reservoir which is okay since we don't have a significant ant problem anyway.In summary, this feeder gets my highest recommendation. If you are a more casual feeder of the birds, you might wish to get the feeder from the same company which has the smaller reservoir.

This turned out to be something different from what I was hoping for, so I don't intend to punish the manufacturer for my own oversight.The game amounts to a 21st century Scrabble game. (That was my actual hope, a game with high quality materials which was something like Scrabble.) However, it apparently spins off of the ZYNGA game which one encounters (ad nauseum) on facebook and which I view as an outright nuisance. There again, this is a personal foible and not the manufacturer's fault that I do not participate in that particular activity.What the game *does* offer is high quality materials/playing parts. To be honest, I'm going to try to figure out a way to adapt these materials to create my own "semi-Scrabble" game, probably similar to the way this game was actually intended to be used. I don't care much for the roll-around feature. I think my grandkids and I will have fun messing around with the game, even if we don't play it correctly - they love the colors of the pieces.The Smartphone feature also generates no interest for me. I do not own a smartphone or any other phone other than the ratty one that hangs on my kitchen wall. My point is, be prepared for that requirement to make the full use of the game.In summary, if you are an older person like me, stick with Scrabble if delving into new realms of the computer age irritates you as much as it does me. If you are young and adaptable to ever-changing technology and ideas, you'll probably like the game quite a lot.Recommended as described.

The most remarkable feature of this eye-catching bag is the obvious high-quality of both the materials and the craftsmanship. The best description I can yield of the *feel* of the exterior material is that of a very soft leather, (much like a pebbled doeskin glove), quite pliable and clearly durable.All the brass-finish zippers are heavy-duty, of the finest manufacture. They highlight the attractiveness of the bag. It's plenty large, without being bulky, offering more than ample interior space for its primary intended use.The sturdy, lengthy carrying straps make transporting the bag a breeze, quite comfortable. For the remarkable durability of the material, this bag is still plenty light and not burdensome in terms of weight. The ocean blue color is muted and classy-looking.Highly recommended.

My normal reading is classic literature but once in a while I have to clear my head with something less profound, something off the wall, (at least from my perspective.) In this instance I made a highly suitable choice because if this is not celebrated literature, the story was at least compelling to the degree that it held my interest from beginning to end.This was obviously a book aimed at female readers but I guess I chose it largely upon the basis of my being a cat lover, a facet of the story which I knew about in advance of acquiring the book. (Also, I'm from Ohio, so there was that.) It's also one of a series -- I regret that I cannot comment extensively on that aspect of the work as I have read none of the companion books and won't be doing so because, as I mentioned earlier, this read was simply to provide a break from my normal genre. Still, it was obvious that these characters had largely hung out together in the past and the author handled that smoothly enough as to not baffle me.The thrust of the story, the foundation, is simply this: What can one expect when a relationship un-expectantly shifts from "friend" to "lover"? And that's a worthy premise since so many people can relate to such a predicament, (if you choose to look at it in that light.).It's a middle-America love yarn like many others of its type, (and perhaps just a bit stereotypical but not egregiously so), and the disquiet generated by the events and the characters, (Anna in particular), is probably the part I enjoyed the least. But that's also the aspect of the story that kept me turning the pages. (I prefer long, rambling yarns where nothing much happens and this one is pretty pacey by my gauge.)In any case, while not precisely a roller coaster, I found this one enjoyable, captivating, and worth reading. If I were into the genre, I'm sure I would read the entire series.Recommended.

This is one of those items that I always idly wish I had during very specific times.  Like when we go to the beach or the one or two times a year when I do a potluck.  So when it became available I decided to give it a try even though I had no specific need for it right then.But then my husband, who travels to NYC several times a year, kind of idly mentioned that the last time he'd gone he'd found a great restaurant that does Ramen (and no, not the cheap little bricks you find at the grocery store) and wished we could try it but it would probably be inedible by the time he drove back (4-hour drive).  I remembered this and told him to get some on the way back and we could test the efficacy of this.We did and it performed like a champ.  Instinctively he determined that it would probably work best to preserve heat if the container was already hot.  So he cleaned it and filled it with boiled water to bring the temp up before discarding the water and filling it with the Ramen.  When he got home (like 5 hours later) it was still nicely hot and tasted great!  He was worried about spillage & spoilage but the seal does a great job.It is stainless steel, has a lifetime warranty and no BPA.  Also very easy to clean and store.

I have to say this is a pretty darned nifty printer.1. It is a littler bigger than I expected.  But not heavy at all.  I need to pay attention to dimensions more.2. It is really easy to set up.  We chose a wireless set up (a wired option is also available).  The quick-start guide is easy to read & follow and only requires a couple of steps. They give you a website to go to and all you do is follow the prompts3. If you have more than one computer in your home, follow the same steps on each computer to download drivers etc.and to allow that computer to 'discover' the printer4. Download the mobile app to your smartphone or tablet to allow you to print from your mobile device (need to be on your wireless network to do this).  This was pretty convenient since right now I have to upload stuff to the cloud and then go to my computer and then download it back to print it.5. Your printer gets assigned an email address!6.. (Optional, but I recommend strongly) set up an account with HP-Connected to manage all your printed devices as well as the ability to send documents to your printer remotely via email (and manage who can do this).7. The Printer comes with 2 ink cartridges (black, & tri-color) and a small quantity of photo paper.  Since ink is always the most expensive enterprise in owning a printer it is important to get an idea about how much you are gonna be spending in ink.  This uses HP 62 inks which retail for @ 14-16 bucks per cartridge (A LOT cheaper than my current printer inks let me tell you... but still....).  But when setting you you are given the option of enrolling in HP's instant  ink program which is a subscription service.  Your printer senses when it is getting low on ink and orders more and it is shipped to you.  You can set up the service level you think best fits your printing habits and there is a monthly scale based on how much you think you print per month. Yeah, I'm on that!8. It is a scanner & copier of course.  And the app uses your phone camera to document capture/scan & print.9. You can control it's functions from an LCD screen right on the computer or from whatever device you are printing from.I have tried all the functions, printing from all the computers, printing fro mobile devices, printing via email.  Everything worked great.

This is such a great song.  Whenever i listen to it I feel like I need to learn to samba! Or that suddenly a Latin ballroom pair should appear before me in all their glittery awesomeness and dance a samba before me.  Or that Carnivale is happening in my ears.What I am saying is... I love this song and it makes me want to dance!

I actually bought this because I had read somewhere that a molinillo could substitute for an Indian Mathani.  I was going to make a Makhani Dal and I needed a tool to puree some of the ingredients and mathani was highly suggested for it.  But I couldn't find one in my area. So of course I went online.This molinillo caught my eye because it is really quite pretty. I loved it even better when I got it.  It is a nice tool and bigger than I thought it was going to be.  It also did a great job on my Dal.  And welp, since I had it I decided to use it for its intended use, hot chocolate.  I had never realized my chocolate needing frothing until, well, I actually frothed.  Now I use it every single time I make hot chocolate.  Love this.  I also recommend using Mexican stone ground chocolate when making hot chocolate.  Somehow the texture of the Mexican chocolate coupled with the molinillo seems to add to a richer cup.

I used this over a three week period and am generally pleased with the results.  Generally speaking my normal skin moisturizing routine for years and years and years has been a combo of shea butter and coconut oil.  I live in an area where winter is can be bitter and can last from October to April some years.  Indoor air can become very drying as can outside wind.  I am also a woman of color so dryness is incredibly visible on my skin, hence I hold moisturizing as a necessary part of daily grooming.This is a light moisturizer and while it would never replace by go to's it does give the skin a nice smooth texture with no greasiness or tacky feel.  It has no obnoxious scent which is a plus.  The instructions say to apply it liberally to wet skin and then rinse off, but not to apply it feet as it can be slippery.  I didn't experience any slippery feel but results may vary.In a three week period with daily use estimate I used about half the container.So in sum a nice light moisturizer with no sticky feel, no obnoxious scent.  I would probably limit my personal use to this in the summer/fall and keep my heavier moisturizing in the winter months.

i love this reboot.  Yeah somehow Benedict Cumberbatch doesn't quite bring the Khan-ness of Ricardo Montalban's Khan, but still I loved this.  Funny, dark, broody and great use of very operatic music in the beginning.  Also the entire cast has great chemistry.
I can listen to this song over and over.  Make me want to dance and/or find a group of people to do a flash mob with.

I find my opinion of this has already beenv ery well expressed by other three-ish starred reviews.As others have said set up is a breeze.  Instructions are not quite clear, but I managed to get it all up and running in just a few minutes.  Take it out of the box, plug it in to an available LAN port on your current router and that is about 99% of the set up.  It does come with a disc that says you need to use it, but I never did.  There is a website to do some additional set up.  It comes with a pre-set security key which you can changeSo that was a pro.I got this mainly because we are a very connected family.  Multiples devices are running through our router all over the house.  Three desktop computers, two laptops, all of our phones, a couple of tablets, a couple of smart tvs.  We stream incessantly and truthfully we don't really have buffering issues or anything like that.  But  figured I'd used this to distribute some of the load, so to speak, and to see if at leas the A/C enabled devices would benefit from some additional speed.While I did not do any actual measurements, I did not *feel* like I saw an appreciable change in download or streaming speed.  Honestly, we have excellent internet where I live.  The only issue we've ever had is in obscure corners of the house where sometimes we get low signal strength, and I thought this might mitigate that.  But nope.  No difference.I do plan to experiment a bit more with some settings though, so maybe I'll update if anything changes.

I got this because my tablet is used primarily for work meetings.  I have a Samsung Galaxy 10.1 note that I got because of the ability to write notes.  However as I quickly learned, I am much more at ease typing that I am in writing these days.  And I don't like the keypad that pops up on the tablet.  Hence I needed a dock.I like this on for a couple of reasons:1 - it is sturdy so it it also serves to protect the tablet in case of drops2 - It is flexible.  The tablet pops right into some adjustible anchors at the top and the sides and they sorta 'sqeeze' the tablet in.  Also, the case folds completely back when i just want to use the tablet as a table (no keyboard) or pops up like a de facto laptop.  It also makes sure all the ports are accessible (earbuds, camera eye, charging) etc.3 - The set up was simple.  A quick bluetooth pair and we were good to go.4 - The battey life is insane.  I don't think I've had to recharge it yet (tho to be fair, when i an not using it, I do turn it off)... Still it has been over a month now.My biggest con.... is that the weight of the keyboard is enough so that it can activate the voice response when the case is closed because it can press on the front facing button of the tablet.  I don't know how many times this has happened.But overall, I really like this for my tab.

My first inclination in reviewing this book is just to fill this review up with quotes from the book. I think I highlighted about 60% of the book because it was so darned quotable. Every page has something I wanted to quote out.What I liked the most: Island. She was a hoot. Really funny and a little awkward. She had an unconventional upbringing traveling the world with her globe-trotting mother, incredibly smart and bit of a polyglot. The book has portions of dialogue in French, Afrikaans, and Japanese. But for all that, she is still a bit sheltered.What I liked second most: March. He is a cold eyed killer with some background angst that gets peeled back during the course of the book. But he has some wonderful quirks. He drives like a little old lady -- within the speed limit, observing all road rules meticulously (this drives Island nuts). He also has how own personal code and he becomes fiercely protective of Island even while he sometimes still menaces her. But she likes to tweak him on his OCD -- his reaction when she purposely moves one of his maps out of alignment in his car was great. He has interesting taste in favorite animals and his own roommate is...not a person. Such an interesting, charismatic character.What I liked third most: Each chapter is headed by an excerpt from one of Island's favorite romance novels. They have titles like "Two Earls for the Virgin" or "The Billionaire's Beautiful Waitress" or "The Shifter's Mail Order Bride." etc. Island's romance book titles are a sweet poke at some of the more eye-roll worthy romance tropes, but the author takes Island's love of the books seriously. You never get the sense that she's bagging romance at all.And finally this book has some great supporting characters and has some nice diversity in both location and in characters.

I am always iffy when I get sheets, towels, or bedspreads online.  Unless you can touch & feel and get a sense of the weight/quality, you are never sure what you are gonna get.I must say these sheets have what is called 'curb appeal.'  They are incredibly pretty in the box.  Seriously, these would make an attractive & classy gift just by going on the box & presentation alone.Outside the box they are a nice surprise as well.  Winter white, with lovely embroidery they have the cool crisp look of cotton.  I admit I love me some nice cotton or flannel sheets, so I was prepared to be a little snobby about these.  But these are nicely soft.  You don't feel like you are sleeping on man made material.All in all these are lovely sheets, very soft and creates an attractive look in my guest bedroom.

Watched this as a companion to the Robin Ghivan book.  I loved hearing about the reminiscences of the night straight from the models, still living designers and guests who attended.  It is a shame that so few pictures and very little footage of the actual event is available but I think the filmmaker  worked around this limitation rather effectively.  You are left with the feeling you 'saw' more than you actually did and you get a strong sense of the event.  Very much enjoyed this.

I have had this product for 30 days.  I decided to use is each night and assess the product at the end of the 30 day period. I was a little surprised to learn than the term 'mask' is misleading.  When one hears 'mask' one thinks of the chalky green stuff that you either have to peel off the next day of wipe off with a cloth.  This is actually a gel/cream consistency (closer to gel -- more like a pearly-gel) that you smooth on and it absorbs into your skin.  There is none of that unpleasant tightness you get with a mask.I was happy to know that the fragrance wasn't either heavily perfumed or heavily chemical.  It isn;t unpleasant, it smells vaguely 'creamy-like' (if that is a thing).So each night I cleansed my face and smoothed this on.  I have combination skin and a bit of an an uneven tone, so I was curious to see if I would see any result.The first time I applied it, I applied too much.  You really don't need much to cover the surface of your face.  This is 4.5 oz and after 30 days of daily use, I still have a LOT of product left.  Easily enough to see me through another couple-three months of daily use.Also, do not get this into your eyes.  Stings if it gets into the eyes.  Not pleasant.So after 30 days I can say I do see a visible difference both in tone of my skin (there is some nice evenness where there was some discoloration before) and in smoothness.  It isn't some dramatic thing, but it is noticeable to me.So after my first 30 days with the product I am very pleased with the results so far.

I rather like this scanner.  It is flexible and fast.Flexible because it allows a variety of hook-up options -- wireless, hooked up via USB or ethernet connected.It also allows a variety of file types and gives you a veritable laundry list of where you want your scan to actually go.  You can scan text or pictures or use the included software suite to scan OCR and create editable documents.  You can create naming conventions for your scans, specify folders, send it to a cloud storage, a thumb drive or just to your computer desktop.It also includes a feeder pocket to help feed through odd sized or fragile material or business cards.It would take a lot of time to really explore the different options.I set it up as a wireless connection to send files to my computer desktop.  This is my primary use and for that it works great.  The resolution is great for text or documents but not sharp enough for pictures, imo.  It also isn't a flat bed so obviously this excludes certain types of materials from being scanned.But if you need to feed through a forty page document, it will actually scan through very quickly and seamlessly  and show up as a multipage document of your choice.So in sum, great for scanning through  text based documents quickly and efficiently.  Not so great for picture resolution.  Lots of options and flexibility.  The included CD of software is not necessary to use the scanner.

This second book in the Hell's Viper's series is much stronger in both writing, characterization and tone than the first book. Although I liked the main plot a lot better in the first book, I think this book benefits from familiarity with the characters gleaned from the first book so that the author is able to deepen them to very good effect.For one thing, Jasmine and Nuke have settled into their relationship. They are married and committed to each other. She is accepted as 'good people' by the others at the club. In fact her and Nuke's ultra kinky sex life is a matter of continuing entertainment to most and bafflement to some.This brings me to one thing that I think this book had that the first book lacked was a very sharp sense of dark humor. Nuke and Jasmine are hardcore into their BDSM stuff and even amongst the jaded, free p****y on-demand anywhere anytime bikers, those two are a revelation. There was one scene where the President of the club, Mitch, has a 'Why in my day...." moment lamenting that a threesome or back-door action is no longer the high water mark of kinkiness.Also there is a darkly funny scene of Kevin, Pipe and Nuke going to dispose of bodies while Pipe fussily makes sandwiches in the back of the van and offering cookies like some Assassin Martha Stewart. The book is peppered with good moments of dialogue and humor.This installment also does a great job of showing how close Kevin, Pipe and Nuke are. In the last book we were told they were long time friends. This one, the author really brings it home. The three get more scenes together and the camaraderie between them feels very strong and so sharply defined that you have no trouble buying that they've known each other since they were kids.We get a lot more exposure to Pipe who bonds with Jasmine. And we see Kevin going to some very dark places in the aftermath of his doomed relationship with Cindy from the last book.The main plot involves a blast from Nuke's past in the form of his half-brother Holden. Holden is one of those guys who puts on a golden-boy face and make people believe he is a great guy but is in reality a devious person. I know Nuke likes to think of himself as a sociopath but he isn't because he actually has feelings. He feels love and guilt and loyalty. Now, Nuke is a psychopath, for sure but he is NOT a sociopath.  Holden is actually the real sociopath because he is nothing but calculation from the time he appears in the book.His appearance sets off a series of events that actually precipitates the first bump in the road for what had been a rather smooth sailing relationship between Jasmine and Nuke.I like where the author took these two in this book because it felt like a realistic conflict for them. It wasn't contrived but rather felt very much in keeping with their characters.  It also sets the scene for a rather epic and violent argument between the two of them, the likes of which none of their friends or members of the club thought these two would be capable of. I loved the way the argument unfolded and its aftermath.I must say the author really knows how to tell a good story and craft some great scenes. She knows the difference between 'show' and 'tell'.  The scene where Nuke has his final confrontation with Holden was well done and nicely written. I loved the way it ended.My only quibble with these books is that they feel a might too short. But only because I am enjoying them so much. Not necessarily because the story feels shortchanged. It doesn't at all.  Also, of course, the casual, sometimes extreme, misogyny that is present in these books still is problematic for me.But all in all the first two books in the series have been really engaging reading.  And I am jonesing for the next one.

3.5 starsI thought I was pretty much over MC romance novels. They tend to click too many of my 'hell-to-the-no' womanist buttons what with their 'ownership' and 'property' attitude toward women for me to be able to easily enjoy them as just fiction. Additionally this is a BDSM novel so the D/s aspect adds a whole other dimension. By all rights I should not be fine with this book at all.But I enjoyed the ever loving heck out of this! I think the intensity of the main relationship, the interesting plot and the strength of the storytelling worked to offset some of my personal mental triggers.The story actually follow two separate relationships: One that is just beginning and flourishes throughout the book and the other that is at the end and we witness the destructive aftermath and consequences of it's ending.Jasmine and Nuke are the main A-plot couple. Nuke is an interesting character. Intense as all hell, Alpha as all hell and crazy as all hell . He actually has psych eval to back that character trait up. But he is smart as a whip, deep as an ocean, well read, and falls in love with Jasmine in a way that the reader is never in doubt about his feelings. I should hate Nuke. But I didn't. I liked him. He puts all out there. He isn't some closed off broody hero. He says what he expects from Jasmine. He communicates.I also liked Jasmine but thought she wasn't as interesting as Nuke. Actually I thought she came to grips with what it meant being the "old Lady' of an MC way too easily for a person who was essentially a civilian with no exposure to the life outside of Sons of Anarchy. Sure she had doubts. In fact the depiction of how her early fascination/fetishization of the bad-boy biker morphed to dawning horror as the reality set in when Nuke explained what he really was during their first date was well done. She liked him, she wanted him but she throttled back realistically when he told her some truths. But that all went by the wayside after he kissed her and they got to boning.But the author gave them an interesting, involved and intense relationship that I enjoyed reading about (hard-core BDSM sex scenes aside). You come to realize they are a great fit for each other. They seemed like a more hardcore, extreme version of Kevin and Vee from the tv show Shameless.The other couple was Kevin and Cindy. As the book begins they are broken up because Kevin cheated on Cindy with one the hordes of females that are seen as available p****y to the bikers. Cindy is mad and bitter. A lot of the external conflict that affects Jasmine/Nuke is because of the Cindy/Kevin fallout. Jasmine is Cindy's friend and Cindy repeatedly tries to warn Jasmine that Nuke is bad news.I loved how complex the author made Cindy. On the one hand she was eaten alive with envy as she watched her friend have the sort of relationship with Nuke that she never had with Kevin. On the other hand she actually dropped some real words of wisdom the Jasmine. The problem is that her words were always filtered through her own bitterness so it was difficult to know if she was being sincere or if she was just letting her envy talk. I think it was a bit of both.I also got the impression that Kevin had authentic feelings for Cindy, it just wasn't in him to be faithful. And Cindy exacerbated it be criticizing the biker lifestyle.It almost felt like a theme for the two couples was to understand the person you are with and not try to change them into someone else. Jasmine and Nuke largely succeed because Jasmine embraces this concept and lets Nuke just be Nuke. Cindy, otoh, fails because she is constantly trying to remake Kevin into something else disregarding what the club means to him and how much it is a part of his identity.There is a larger plot about a feud between the Hells Vipers and a rival MC that acts as both a backdrop to the two relationship plots and as an element of conflict for both. With the state of both relationships and the feud coming to a head at the end of the book.I thought the last scene of the book, between Kevin and Cindy, was very well constructed and ended the book just right.

This book had potential to be better than it was. I like this author's voice, I really do. It is a bit irreverent and very smart. This book only had glimpses of that irreverence & smartness which is why I think this book could have done better.The basic story is that Pasha Markovitch is a Russian boxer who lives in London. He needs sponsorship to go on to bigger and better things in the sport but his lack of British citizenship is preventing that.Lily Asare has just had her life savings stolen by her boozing, gambling wastrel of a father. Without it she can't start her own business and she currently absolutely hates her current lech of a boss.Pasha's father has a solution. Lily marries Pasha so he can become a citizen by marriage. And he'll pay Lily the money.So this becomes a rather murky Marriage-of-convenience story.I rather liked Lily and Pasha together but I felt so many other elements of the story competed (too successfully, imo) with the romance. For one thing both Pasha and Lily each have a set of frightful parents. And their dysfunctional relationship with their respective parents take up some rather hefty real estate in the book.I generally like messy relationships amongst characters in books. Feels more life-like. People don't behave like book characters do, so when I see book characters behaving like real people I like it. In this case it had the effect of coming off as rather disjointed and a little un-cohesive.It may sound like I did not like this book. I did. I actually did whip right through it. But I think my rating and review in reflecting a comparison to other works the author has done and this book feels just a little not up to her normal standards.

A romance that at it's heart that was a little nod to the Boss/Secretary Harlequin romances. Yet it is modern and sexy and funny. It is also a little heartbreaking...but still very romantic.This book happens concurrently with the first book in the series  where during that book we got little glimpses of what was going on with Charlotte & Gabriel.  I very much anticipated finding out what was going on with Charlotte and her T-Rex in their own book.I really enjoyed Gabriel. He was just the right sort of Alpha hero I like. I also liked that he was an unremitting work-a-holic as well and that was an actual facet of his personality that was perceived as a flaw and not a celebration. That said, I enjoyed the work-place aspects of the book. I usually do when it it is well incorporated in a story.Charlotte was a sweet heroine whose back story was rather dark. I thought Gabriel's personality eclipsed hers a bit, but still I enjoyed seeing her blossom and come into her own over the course of the story. I also felt that her anxieties around sex felt well developed. Thankfully, this book didn't fell like a case of a 'Magical Healing Penis' where Charlotte just quickly got over everything with one night of great sex with Gabriel. He had to work for her and she had to kind of heal herself before his penis got anywhere near her.Good book, really enjoyed it

***I received an ARC of this book in exchange for an honest review ***This is the second installment of a serialized story following the love story of Nicole and Gabriel.  She is a recent college grad who had been in love with and fascinated with Gabriel for years.  Gabriel is a few years older than Nicole and is just on the cusp of reaching commercial success with his rock band.The first book of the series #1 Crush is an erotic novella that introduces them to the reader and allows them to recognize their attraction to each other and scratch a sexual itch.  It ends with them going their separate ways, having agreed that the sex was fun but they each have other priorities.  That book was pure erotica and a sort of appetizer for this much meatier dish of a book.In this second book, Nicole and Gabriel re-enter each others orbit.  Nicole is much more into Gabe emotionally than he is to her at first.  They hook up again and their sexual attraction is immediate and strong.  From there they continue to use sex to feed their emotional attachment until the two start to build something deeper and fall in love.Because this is a serialized work, this installment doesn't dot all the romantic I's and cross all the Happy T's.  This is another segment in their road happiness, but it isn't the end of it.  There is at least one more book on tap for them.  And therein I think lies some of my problem.Since the story doesn't end here, the romantic conflict felt somewhat manufactured. The internal conflict at first is just that Nic and Gabe can't admit to each other they love each other.  This went on for awhile and it got a little tedious.  They simply couldn't communicate.  When they finally could admit their feelings, you knew that something else was going to come along and muck it up.  And it did. There is conflict that comes from and external source as well.  I actually recoiled from some of the actions/decisions of the characters in the last 10% of the book.  Honestly, it kind of put me off them.Nicole came off as immature and honestly rather stupid and easily manipulated.  Gabe fared much better and I was really on team Gabe here.  But in the end my overall feeling as I was reading wasn't that this isn't the strong,  believable obstruction between the couple and their HEA that I wanted to see them work through, but rather they here was a conflict to throw in to get them to the next book.So in that sense I think the serialization aspect works against my own emotional involvement in the story and why I just couldn't give myself over to it and thus the book just didn't 100% succeed for me.But I must commend he author's writing.  The writing is strong and assured.  This is a work of erotica.  So the sex scenes are plentiful -- PLENTIFUL -- and they are explicit and they are well done.  On the characterization front, the author does a good job of crafting two distinct people and getting you into their emotional head-space.  This is the sort of writing you want to be reading -- descriptive, emotional and interesting.I do recommend this to readers who like really sexy erotica with an angsty emotional component and don't mind serialization.

More like 3.5 stars.Pros:- Very light & sleek- Switches seemlessly from a laptop to a tablet with just a swivel of a the screen- quick power up- Basically does what i need a leisure laptop/tablet to do.Cons:- Comes with Windows 8 which I HATE.  i notice other reviewers mention WiFi drop outs.  I haven;t had any so far with this machine, but the only other machine in our house that routinely drops out from our WiFi is a computer running Windows 8.  We have an IPad, a Samsung Galaxy 10 tablet, Iphones, two other desktops that run Windows 7 and never a single problem with WiFi dropouts on them.  The Windows 8 OS -- constant.  So I was worried about this one, but so far so good. (knock on wood)- Comes with a lot of Windows bloat-ware.  I spent a long time uninstalling crap.Overall I finding this a fine product to use for daily personal home computing stuff and its lightness and flexibility as a laptop also makes it good for travel.

This was an entertaining, gossipy, cultural & fashion history that described events that led up to and surrounded the glittery night at the Theatre Gabriel in the Chateau de Versailles that put the world on notice that American ready-to-wear fashion was to be taken seriously.The book starts out as a mini-history lesson in how French haute couture developed and how as a result, France and French designers became the<defining body of what was chic and fashionable.  It moves across the pond to also give background on how the American fashion scene developed.It is chock full of dropped names, including not only designers as far back as Worth, but also socialites, industry big wigs, society matrons, taste arbiters and even the models.  Almost every person mentioned gets a mini-biography distilled into giving you just enough information to make their story interesting and relevant.  The result is it gives the book a chatty intimacy that made the pages really turn.The book also does a great job of building up anticipation and suspense for when it finally gets to The Event.  The run up is chock full of anecdotes of the personalities, insecurities, battles and genius of not only the ten designers involved, but also of the models themselves.I admit what really attracted me to the book was what little I had heard over the years about the involvement and yes, triumph, of the black models in the show.  A lot of the credit for the success of the Americans at the event is given to the black models.  They only made up 1/3 of the models included (10 out of 30) but their presence is heavily felt.One of the things that I heard over the years -- and what this book reaffirmed -- is that the fierce walk/strut/showmanship of he black models was a huge factor in how the clothes were presented.  It also created a major contrast between the vitality, youth, brashness of the American show and the staid, stiff almost too much pageantry of the French show.The author invokes the name of the Ebony Fashion Fair as an influence on that showmanship and I immediately 'saw' in my mind's eye what it must have looked like as she describes Pat Cleveland whirling down the runway like a moth while the sophisticated Parisian onlookers gasp in awe.One of the biggest downers of the book is the lack of pictures.  There is a good reason for this as we learn in the book.  It was a confluence of many factors that make images of this night somewhat scarce.  The chairperson of the event,  Helene Marie de Rothschild ruthlessly controlled any access to images as she wanted to preserve an air of exclusivity for the show.  In addition the official American photographer was drafted to help out backstage and was not able to take as many photographs as he could have.  And finally, Liza Minelli was the celebrity performer for the Americans and her contract stipulated no film.Since the author could do a romance novelist proud in her breathless descriptions of the looks of the models and the clothes, I found myself relentlessly googling images of people just to see what they looked like.  Additionally I decided to watch the Versailles '73 documentary done by Deborah Riley Draper as a companion piece to the book.  This proved go be a great decision as the documentary had some images and even some filmed snippets and many of the personal reminiscence of the models and others who were there affirmed much of what was written in the book.All in all this was a hugely entertaining foray into fashion history.

The blurb of this book does not suggest it would make a good romance novel.  In fact the romance novel reader in me kinda cringed.  But you know what?  I am glad I was still intrigued enough to read it.This was an unconventional romance that kind of nods it's head a little to bit the movies 'Ghost' and 'All of Me'.  It has a dark, almost uncomfortable beginning that has the effect of making you wait for when the other shoe drops.And drops it does, there is a series of events that leads to the murder-suicide that the blurb alludes to.  Spicey is killed and Baxter kills himself.  And their spirits are tied to the house they died in.And then something curious happens... the book lightens up.  Over a span of 70 years Spicey and Baxter are allowed to explore their tangled relationship and grow their feelings for each, all the time while witnessing the changes in the world around them through the various inhabitants  of the house they are stuck in.  I liked the changing of the years and the changing of the attitudes between the two.I also liked how the story ended.  Spicey was able to gain a sense of justice and synergy and she is finally able to fully return the love that Baxter has had for her for almost a century.If you are one like me to complain about the sameness of romantic stories sometimes, read this one.  It is different and refreshing.  Also very well written.

Sequel to the fabulous The Parfit Knight This features the Duke of Rockliffe who was a fantastic supporting character in the first book.Rock is looking for a wife and is dragged off the Worst. House Party. Ever. by his younger sister, Nell. Her two BFFs are twin daughters of the host and her biggest wish is for Rock to marry the ravishing, outgoing twin Diana.But Diana is a bitch on steroids. And Rock can't stand her. And the rest of the family are a perfect fright. Except the Cinderella-like poor relation cousin, Adeline. Adeline is treated like total crap by the family and mostly by Diana. But Adeline has learned how to cope. She is snarky as hell and uses her words like a weapon. She hates her family like whoa and doesn't care who knows.Despite himself Rock finds himself drawn to Adeline. Oh, he has absolutely no intention of getting himself in any way attached to this ratchet family. But intentions are not reality.My overwhelming feeling while reading this book was that I really wanted to set that entire family on fire. Poor Adeline to be stuck with those awful people. Ioved that she wasn't some shrinking heroine who kinda wallowed in her victim-hood. Instead she was defiant. She was "If y'all are gonna treat me like s***, then I will wear it on my face and bring it to the dinner table!"I didn't love-love this one as much as I did the first. There was this really big climactic scene where a lot of secrets come out publicly and i thought it felt overdone and out of place for a book that had been up to that point rather good about how it was handling all of the various revelations about the characters.But I massively enjoyed both Rock and Adeline together. And I kinda clapped with glee when Diana gets her comeuppance.

I have no idea what made me look this book up, much less buy it. But I am so glad I did.Let me first say I had never heard of this author prior to reading this book. But something about this (and it's sequel which I read immediately after) intrigued me.The writing made me feel like I was reading Heyer. Maybe if Heyer had been writing closer in spirit to authors of the 80s, but still Heyer-esque nonetheless.The heroine, Rosalind, in this book is blind. As the book starts the reader is witness to the incident that caused her blindness. Later as we meet her again we find that she's well loved by her brother, but it is an over protective smothering love that leaves her somewhat lonely and well aware that although she is beloved, she has been given no opportunity to live a normal life. She lives in a lovely home in the country with an army of devoted servants and every wish she could have granted...except for the possibility of love, marriage and family.Into her life comes Amberley, the hero. A broken axle, a snowstorm and he must take refuge at her home. Amberley is a great character. He is handsome, well dressed, witty and clever. He has a great sense of ridiculous. I liked that he wasn't some dour brooding hero but rather a guy who didn't take things too seriously and had a good sense of humor. But he was still very deep.The scenes of Amberley and Rosalind getting to know each other during their snowy ideal were fantastic. I also loved all the below stairs machinations of the servants as they observed their mistress and her mysterious guest. Amberley read the situation with Rosalind perfectly and later acts a huge catalyst of change for her.As I was reading this book I had one of those reactions that I don't get all that often anymore, the sense of really, really sinking into and just basking in the enjoyment of a well told story.The thing that takes it over the top is the bird. Rosalind has a foul mouthed parrot. For two glorious paragraphs the parrot gets a POV. I loved that. And he plays another important part in the story later.Beside the central romance, which was so well developed, I liked all the side characters and different relationships they all had with each other. There were some stands out such as the Duke of Rockliffe aka Rock (this made me giggle). I also loved how the author described the moment Amberley realized he was in love with Rosalind and later what he felt when he had no chance with her. Such good writing.After reading this I immediately picked up the sequel and some of her more hist-fiction books. Have been enjoying them all

I got this primarily for my husband who is the whitest white man I know.  He totally needs this because he does hours longs touring bike rides in the summer and he comes back with his neck, arms and other exposed parts red as a beet.  But he hates heavy sticky lotions that tend to characterize the higher SPFs.  I figured something that sprayed out couldn't be considered 'heavy'So we tested it on our trip to the Caribbean this year.  It comes out of the spray evenly with not clumping or anything.  I thought it would be tacky-sticky but it isn't.  It goes on and dries.  Out of habit I think he rubbed it on, but he didn't really have to. Thank goodness it is not heavily scented.  That would have been a show-stopper.  No.  It is lightly but pleasantly scented.  And even that fades in a bit.Truthfully, 70 SPF is probably overkill, but it did the job and he came out with no burns and he felt comfortable,  he was even able to swim for awhile and the product was still protecting him.One thing I think that may be a bit of a con vs. a pro, is that as a spray on product it may not be as long lasting as a cream product.  It feels like it will easily be used much more quickly than a lotion, since you don't control the amount that gets misted on the way you do the amount that you spread on with a lotion.  So given the price point you could be spending more on this in the long run.

The shade of this lipstick is very true to the picture.  Sometimes what you get in person doesn't match what you see, but not in this case.  And being a brown girl, I tend not to but make-up online.  This lipstick though, is deeply pigmented and very rich.  This is shade 07and it looks very good next to my skin.It is also does the one thing that is an absolute must for me with lipsticks -- it does not dry out my lips.  I live in an area that has cold, dry winters.  I carry around lip balm in various pockets and purses.  My skin tends to the dry.  So I trend away from darkly pigmented  lipsticks in the winter because usually they just wear off unevenly.  But this one has the consistency almost of a balm.  It is nice and moist and lasted without fading or cracking.Very nice lipstick.  I know I'll order other colors.

I got this bulb because of the reviews I had seen for it that it did help some of its users at least relax & unwind. The science behind this PM bulb is that the low levels of blue light help with the increase in melatonin which in turn promotes sleepiness.The light is very low on the blue spectrum.  It gives of a mellow orangey-amber light that does look like it should be soothing and promote relaxation.  I gave it to my son to put on his bedside table because he likes to read before bed and the light he had has a harsher light.  I figured he'd be a good candidate to try this out to see if it works because he also has a hard time unwinding.After a month of use, he did tell me that he finds himself falling off to sleep more quickly each night. So anecdotally this seems to work.Another big plus is that it is an LED light that is more energy efficient and has a longer life than an incandescent bulb.  They tend to be more expensive in the short run, but in the long run they save you money.  We have been slowly replacing our incandescent lights with LEDs and this one is a good addition.

This was a very good story.  I really, really enjoyed it.So why 3-stars?  It was too short.  And this isn't just a 'oh, I like longer books' rant.  No, there was too much going on in this book for it to be this page length and none of it felt fully cooked.There were some great relationships, friendships, soon-to-be-ex-friendships, romantic musical chairs and last minute bombshells roiling around in this story.  All these things were juggled well in the book and I got completely immersed in all the personalities and plots.  But I also felt shortchanged.  None of them concluded to my satisfaction.  So many of the balls being juggled still felt left up in the air.Even the romance...again well done, but I still wanted them to explore each other more.This was a very well written, very interesting, completely engaging book.  But for what the author had going on it really need more pages to feel fully realized.All that said, this author has quietly become one of my favorites.

To be honest, I rarely keep wine around long enough for it to need to be vacuum sealed.  It tends to be consumed really quickly.  If it isn't then I use it in cooking.  But I figured I'd give this a try.It is a nice little item, i will say that.  But I had to read the instructions a couple of times to figure out how to go about it.  Even then I wasn't  sure when to stop pumping.  Was that enough resistance?  Is he seal not good if I am still pumping after seven pumps? 10?  Did I do it right?Even with the insecurity, the wine that I did use it on tasted fine the next day, so maybe I did do it right.Not sure if I'd continue to use this for myself but it might make a nice gift for a wine enthusiast who would most likelt appreciate it (and use it better) than I did.

Smaller than I expected, but no less mighty.  I have been needing a good, reliable kitchen scale for awhile.  The reviews are easy to follow and the scale itself has a rather simple interface.  You turn it on, cycle through the weight measure you want to use (I tend to stick with ounces), use the tare feature to exclude the weight of containers etc.  It will aut-shut off after  couple of minutes of dis-use.  It comes with batteries already installed.It is a sensitive scale that can measure something as light a single raisin or a dollar bill with accuracy.Very pleased with this.

I was a little concerned when I first took these out of the package.  I am 5'9, 150 lbs and I got large because better safe than sorry when it comes to sizing.  When I pulled them out they looked smallish.  And they did not appear to have the length (mid-calf) they had in the picture.Boy was I wrong.  They fit perfectly!  Not only that they do fall mid-calf for me.  And even better these things are light as air.  They do not have that constricty feel that some leggings have.  They are comfortable and move with me.  I wear them for every work out now.  A quick wash in cold water and they dry fast (i don't put them in the dryer, but just dry them flat on a laundry table).  Great find.

...Way out of my comfort zone that is for sure.This book is about a D/s relationship. It isn't a BDSM book with all the spankings & such, even though Rick does have a 'playroom'. It really is a relationship book about a strong submissive who completely lives the life and her search for, and successful landing of, a caring Dom.This was a very sweet book that alternates POVs between Micah, the female sub and Rick her Dom. Rick was simultaneously Masterful and nurturing, while Micah was strong minded about how she needed to cede control.The two fall in love fairly soon, but take a while to admit it, mainly because they need to negotiate their relationship on two levels. One of course is the more conventional emotional relationship and the other is making sure they are a right D/s fit for each other. I liked how the author told both levels of that story.It was also very sexy.One thing I really appreciated was reading the author's foreword on using lowercase for Micah's name as well as any other references to her (even when she refers to herself in first person the 'I' is in lowercase). Meanwhile all references to Rick is uppercase. While his proper name was expected, whenever Micah used pronouns such as 'Him' and 'He' they were also capitalized. It had the curious effect of giving him an almost God-like quality. You really start to believe in him as Dom. It was rather fascinating.Really good book, I recommend it even to people like me who get a little squiffy about D/s stuff.

So what happens when an avowed racist white inmate finds out the woman he has been exchanging letters with (and falling in love with) via a pen pal program is black?That question gets answered in this book. Kinda.I found the premise interesting and the writing to be clean. It was engaging and I found Katie to be a sympathetic heroine.More problematic was Logan. For a racist he is remarkably bad at it. Honestly, he couldn't really get his back into it, really. For Logan, his brand of racism feels more like something he learned by rote and circumstance, rather than something he truly internalized. He begins to fall in love with Katie in her letters and once he discovers she is black, he takes a moment to be shocked and dismayed... but then she's pretty! So he can get over it.The book succeeds in what it attempts, meaning it took it's own premise and made it work. By not making Logan this bone-deep racist in the first place, the ease with which he reconciles himself to being with Katie doesn't feel so unbelievable.On the one hand, since I don't tend to like my leisure, escapist reading to spend too much time on people navel gazing about race, I bought what this book was selling.On the other hand, I can't help but wonder how much more affecting and powerful the story could have been if the author had allowed Logan's racism to go deeper than his epidermis?In any case this was an quick and interesting read.

Kinda like an angsty, reworking of the Goldie Hawn/Kurt Russell movie 'Overboard'- Heroine was a bit of a classist snot....but she had reasons.- I liked the hero a lot- Class warfare & 'you make me afraid of what I am feeling' is the romantic conflict... and deception of course.- ...but found myself skimming.  Was too impatient to get to the part where she gets her memories back.  Constantly waiting for the shoe to drop and for his deception to be revealed-  Book ended on a very strong note.Rather middle-of-the-road HistRom with a slightly different hook.

Felt like a mystery/police procedural more than anything else.  Basically Ash & Janvier investigate stuff.  But the bad guy was telegraphed early on. So I didn't feel any real suspense personally.  Also, there was very little romantic tension as Ash & Janvier already have a thing going before the book starts.  The romantic conflict is based on a Big Secret of Ash's....but it did not feel very mind-blowing.  Naasir was fascinating, though.  I liked his partsNice enough installment but central romance didn't wow me.  Recommend it for it's place in furthering the series.

The good:  Back to Drew's POV.  For me the books in this series don't really POP unless Drew is the one speaking.  Funny.  Kinda like Hangover-lite.The not-so-good  Honestly, this just felt like and extended epilogue to the first book.  I did not feel any real romantic conflict or immediacy because Drew & Kate are obviously in love and have a two year old they both adore.  Drew make noises about messing up & placing wedding in jeopardy, but it never really materializes and frankly I didn't believe he really would.Final word:  First book is the best in the series

This is a typical Joan Wolf Trad Regency which means it is well written, with some actual real history included, and a smart romance at the center of it all.The heroine is dragged to Africa as a missionary by her zealot father and is  rescued by Hero from being sold into a Harem.  Back in England she just wants to settle to a "Normal Life."Yeah, RightHer life experiences have touched her too much and "normal life" in England doesn't really fit who she is.  I did feel kinda bad for the poor fiance who got caught up in her need for normality.  But not too much.  The connection between the hero & heroine was too well established & palpable for anyone else to come in and feel believable.

-  Picks right up where the last book ended, hence this is not the place to start the series a new reader would miss a lot-  Rowan, Clive and a few trusted people from their inner circle are on the Hunt for Sorceress Vamp Enyo-  But...for a hunt the characters felt curiously like they were standing still in places-  A little too much discussion, not enough action, imo-  Romance between Rowan & Clive takes a nice definitive step.  This was a very nice development.-  I am loving how the author is crafting the political situation between Hunter Corp and Vampire Nation & Rowan caught in middle.  For me this was the best part of this book and feels like awesome set up for a possible change of course for the next book for Rowan-  Final conclusion is that this one felt mostly like filler.  However I LOVE this series and am now waiting for the next one.

I loved the first book in the series. It was a good, solid book that looked at the building of a relationship from the inside. No real external conflict, just the struggles and issues that a pair of grown ups with lives and a past have. It also did a great job of drawing a picture of a big, complex family as well as a fantastic friendship between two friends, Natalie (the heroine from that book) and Tuesday (the heroine in this book).So when Tuesday and Ezra circle around each other in that first book, meeting eyes and zinging with awareness, the anticipation for them was set.With such high expectations I was a bit nervous whether this book would really meet them.Boy did it.Just like the first book, there are no external conflicts here for the couple. They acknowledge they want each other. But each has a lot of baggage that is potentially problematic in trying to start up something new.Tuesday is still coming back from the devastating loss of her first husband to a quick and brutal bout with cancer. While Ezra is a 5-years clean ex-heroin addict. The book does a great job of letting us in on how the two of them are somewhat still broken by these things but because of their relationship, are starting to put it behind them and heal. Ezra struggles a bit more than Tuesday and I must say I liked that the author allowed this aspect to be a little lopsided, rather than trying to make both of their issues completely equal.Ezra is terrified of back-sliding back into the behaviors that made his addiction possible. We learned quite a bit of what happened to him and how it affected his family in the first book, so this one just colors in the lines a little bit more and gives some insight from his POV. He is deliberate in the things he does and the controls he needs to wield over his life. I was fascinated by the parts where he described how much of his success in staying clean was the result of behavior modification and how vigilant he still is. So Tuesday becoming a real part of his life must be approached with some caution by him.Of course, Tuesday is a grown-ass woman with ideas of her own and I like how she pushes him and doesn't shy away from saying things. She doesn't tip-toe and is rather frank in her feelings.This is a relationship book more than anything and it follows the pattern of the first book which just allows the couple of fall in love without odd misunderstandings or unrealistic situations.I enjoyed this quite a lot and am looking for the next one in the series.

This book is equal parts humorous chick-lit and a loving ode to the journey a black woman takes when deciding to wear her hair natural.  It used the main character's Mahogany's transition from a life of relaxers and weaves to a natural style as a framing device and metaphor for her changing love life.When we first meet Mahogany, she has been in a seven year relationship with her Indian boyfriend Vinyay (Vinny) and he has yet to propose.  This bothers her.  What bothers her more is that she has never, not once, met any member of his family.  The obvious reason for this is that he can't tell his family about his  black girlfriend.  That is true and it isn't.  It is more than just being in an IR relationship on the down low. One of the reasons I like this book so much is that is is never just that simple.What comes next is reminiscent of that song in that commercial 'I'm gonna wash that man right out of my hair.'  Mahogany, in a moment of in vino veritas, realizes that the time, money and effort she spends on her hairstyle -- a style that she was maintaining because Vinny liked it so much -- was not worth it.  So she does the Big Chop.Thereafter each step in her new hair journey becomes another step away from that relationship and toward another one.  Not only that, but in learning how to care for her natural hair -- something she has never had to learn before -- she is also learning how to care for her heart.Hence, we meet her grumpy co-worker Trent.  Trent and Mahogany have this great hate-hate relationship that morphs into an uneasy detente and then into attraction.  Another In Vino Veritas moment shifts their relationship irrevocably.  I was totally on Team Trent here.The book is told in Mahogany's first person POV and she is hysterical.  I just loved her.  She has exactly the type of life outlook I want all my best girlfriends to have.This was a fantastic book.  And by the time Mahogany had gotten to her full on Angela Davis fro', I was cheering for her and Trent.I only wish it were longer or we got an epilogue or something.  It is categorized as a novella and kindle page count has it at 173 pages.  It felt meatier than most novellas and I don't feel like I got shortchanged in the story.  But still {{whines}} I wanted more time with them. {{/whines}}.

I always prefer toaster ovens over toasters and I like the Black and Decker series.This is a nice, compact toaster oven that fits four bread slices.  it comes with a removable crumb tray for easy cleaning and a nice broiler pan.It has baking, toasting and broiling functionality.  I rarely actually bake in a toaster oven except to re-heat slices of pizza or pie etc.  There is a 'keep warm' setting as well.The toaster setting has 3-generic temps light, medium and dark and it does toast true.  I turned it to the 'dark' setting when I first tried this because my previous toaster had a very stingy definition of what 'dark' meant.  But not this one, glad I was watching because it would have been really dark.It heats up very quickly and the top part of the toaster oven can also get hot to the touch, I actually used it quickly soften butter while I was making my bagel.All in all it does what it says it does, it functions well and it is a reasonable price.  Well pleased.

I am giving this a three-stars for now, may up my rating or lower depending on how I can live with the bulbs & functionality over time.The pros:- The cool factor.  The ability to control your lights, dim them, program them with just your phone.- The clarity and brightness of them- The 9.5 watts, very efficientThe cons:- The set up started so promisingly and then devolved into frustration.  It took awhile for it to discover my devices.  I had to restart a couple of times.  I have an IOS device.- You can only use your phone (or tablet) with the App to remote control the lights. You can't use a computer, not even one that is connected to the same wifi connection your app is.- In the end you are paying for the cool factor.  At it's most basic these are LED lights that you can use in a regular lamp and turn on and off with your own hands with a regular on/off switch or even other long standing analog timers.

This is a handsome, study canvas bag.  It it dark, navy blue with brown faux leather accents.  And the handles are attached with also very handsome dark-bronze colored hardware.At first I was a bit dismayed that it looked liked it only had handles, but there is an over-the-shoulder strap available tucked neatly inside the bag when I received it.It is well padded and very roomy.  I was able to put in my Macbook Pro, my Galaxy tab & other peripherals and there was still room left.  The documentation says it fits laptops up to 15.6 inches.But wait... that's not all!  There is also a zipper compartment on the outside of the bag with little pockets for pens, a slot for your phone an a couple more inner zippered pockets for whatever you want to keep zippered.But wait... that's not all!  There is a final external pocket.  It isn't zippered or secured but easily reached in for quick access to whatever you throw in there.All in all a very serviceable and nice looking bag.

Fantastic ending to a fabulous series.  I was very conflicted about my feelings for Walter.  On the one hand, I wanted him to triumph but on the other, I needed him to answer for all the things he did.  In the end, I think the ending -- everyone's fate (well except Hank & Gomez) -- felt absolutely right.And OMG, is there a better, ore emotionally gutting, episode than Ozymandias?

I bought this for my older son who likes to draw and needed a desk of his own to do his homework.  It took my husband and younger son about an hour to assembled.  The finished product is a very handsome piece of furniture that also feels sturdy and well constructed.  I was very nervous about the glass top, but it also feels sturdy and I has a reassuring thickness.  It is apparently tempered and so far has no scratches or anything, even though my son has been using it daily.We chose not to put the casters on the bottom and the desk is staying put.My biggest con, is that I wish it had a lip that ran across the bottom of the desk to keep papers etc. from slipping off when the desk is at a tilt.  There is a pencil/pen holder but that isn't adequate to keep stuff slipping off.Also, I need to remind my son that it only allows 25 lbs of weight on the surface.  Not an issue if all you;re doing is drawing or writing on it, but he can't set huge heavy books or anything on it.  So unlike other desks, he can't use it as a catchall for everything to set on it.But overall I am pleased with it.

I generally like this author's voice so I tend to graviate toward her work.In this one, the heroine Laura is a young widow who had a scandal in her past and has been consciously trying to live a correct life since then.  But the past collides with the present when her young niece, on the cusp of her debut for the season, falls in love with a young man.  The son of the same man Laura herself was involved with so scandalously years ago.  In order to prevent history from repeating itself, Laura attempts to nip the romance in the bud.  But fate throws a lot of obstacles in her way.My 3-star rating reflects the actual romance between Laura and Ross and it is the strongest and most enjoyable element of the book.  Since they fall in love rather quickly, the conflict is primarily external and  unfortunately, this is the part that I think is the weakest.The ill-considered romance of Laura's niece starts off promisingly enough as a premise, but it devolves quickly because the niece is rather unsympathetic.  Actually I hated her.  It didn't take long for me to want her to be left to her fate with the loser who would eventually make her life miserable.  I wanted Laura to just wash her hands of the brat ans say, "oh, well, this is what you wanted.  I tried to warn you." and let her make her own mistakes.  But this is a romance, and Laura is a heroine, so she has Romance Novel Heroine disease, which means she is almost too nice and selfless.There was some amusing comedy-of-errors aspects of the story that result in some cute plot twists, especially as Laura lies outrageously to a couple she meets and she and Ross must make everything come out right.  But  in places there was a bit of a kitchen sink feel to the plot.  In addition to keeping the young lovers apart, there is some domestic drama with Laura's sister, a resolution of the old scandal and a spying subplot as well.Still the writing was good and the story flowed.  And it was an amusing way to spend an afternoon.

I loved this.  I've read other books that use reality shows as their settings.  Of all the books I've read with this setting, this is probably the one that feels like it gets closest to the truth. The manipulation, using a small thing and changing the narrative to make it worse than it is, sound-biting to create a narrative etc. Felt very smart.This is told from the heroine Lola's POV.  I loved her voice.  She was funny and smart and had a good sense of the ridiculous as she knows she is just the token black girl on the show, so she kinda plays around with her pre-ordained fate.  The writing was really quite witty.  Just the sort of light, breezy tone a book like this needed.One of my quibbles is with the hero Neil.  He felt opaque to me.  Understandable in some ways as this is told from Lola's POV, but still I wanted to see a little more of what made him tick.The supporting characters were great. Very intrigued by Neil's brother Aidan and the camera guy, Wedge. I also love how the author conceptualized Aram, Lol's cousin. In another book he would have been the gay best friend. In this book he is straight but with a gayfabulous sense of style.Finally the author  did not fall into any of my pet peeve traps with skin, hair, eye coloring etc. descriptions. I give her clever points for this sentence:"She had a Valrhona complexion..."I have begun to heartily dislike "food coloring' descriptors (you know, chocolate, caramel, mocha, honey-skinned etc.)  This is how you  use chocolate to describe  coloring without actually using the word 'chocolate.' Snaps!Great book, heartily recommend.

My rating reflects the fact that I enjoyed the heck out of this book.  Almost immediatelyLord Crane is the titular character, a despised second son who inherited his earldom after the death of both his father and older brother.  He is tall, handsome, well dressed, never a hair out of place and has an incredibly colorful and varied background.  He is also funny and an all around decent guy.  I really dug Crane and want to hear more about his various adventures when he lived in enforced exile before coming back to claim his inheritance.Stephen, the other major protagonist, is not quite so blindingly awesome (or as tall) as Crane.  And yet he manages to create as much of a vivid, memorable  impression as Crane.  Poor, from a family disgraced by scandal, Stephen is a mage who is called upon to help Crane escape a death curse. He is acerbic and biting and honorable as all heck.While Crane's character is immediately engaging, Stephen's character is a lot more stealthy.  And in the end, when I closed the book, he actually felt more dynamic than Crane.  The Stephen we met at the end was not the same Stephen we met in the beginning.  I liked how the author peeled his layers away. The plot was all kinds of fun.  There is a magic system in place that governs who practices and how it is administered and controlled.  Also how it works. Poor Crane is laboring under a death curse and the ways the author allows it to manifest are inventive and creepy.  Even the descriptions of Crane's home and the surroundings and the people all play into the dark, macabre, creepy  elements of the magic swirling around Crane.And yet, the book does not feel  that dark at all.  The dialogue is great and Crane has such a smart wit and Stephen has a such a dark humor that you find yourself gliding through the pages.  The relationship between Crane and his Man-of-All-trades, Merrick is all that that sort of relationship should be.  And the relationship that builds between Crane and Stephen is also well conceived and great to experience.I take half a star off, though, because I was not convinced of the romantic connection between Crane and Stephen.  They felt more bromantic than romantic.  It almost felt like simply dotting an 'i' or crossing a 't' to have them consummate a sexual relationship that I wasn't completely feeling.  In the end they are together and you know they are embarking on a relationship that has some significance given that it also ties into some powerful magic.  But yeah, just wasn't feeling them as a couple.I do plan to continue the series because it was sooo good and I want to hang out with them some more.  Maybe the romantic chemistry that I am missing will manifest then.
