"This is happening." - Kate DanielsYes it was.  And like Kate I wasn't ready.  I really wasn't ready.But so what?  I love that the Andrews did this.  They threw me a curveball.  I was so sure Kate we'd get a little more lead up before a big showdown.  But nope. This book skips the appetizers and goes straight to the main course.The action kicks in almost immediately and it is relentless.  Kate and crew are constantly in crisis mode and it becomes increasingly clear that it is all leading straight to Roland.Because Kate is aware that she may not live much longer she becomes a bit ruminative. She faces some hard truths about Voron and thinks about her past, her training  and what she has  been made to endure to prepare for just this thing.Fittingly, this book also acts as somewhat of an old-home week as characters who had been instrumental in pivotal ways in the earlier books make re-appearances and prove to be instrumental in pivotal ways  again.  It was a nice to see some call backs and realize how they fit within the overall narrative.  Even Kate's own revelations are the fruit of seeds that had been planted early in the series.But before we get to the climactic scenes and the inevitable showdown, there is some business that needs to be taken care of.  There are some really, really, really satisfying fight scenes.  Some vengeance is meted in a very satisfactory manner.I loved the ending and resolution of the events of this book.  Loved it. It was smart and logical and gratifying.  It opens some some really interesting possibilities.  The epilogue was, well, rather epic.

So the X small is a pretty sweet little automatic espresso maker.  It isn't huge that's for sure but I don't think I'd actually call it Extra-small.  It was a tick bigger than I expected.  Takes up about the same counter space as my Kitchen-Aid Stand Mixer.It comes with great instructions.  The instructions walk you clearly through initial use, operations and maintenance. It has a quick start guide and a full instructional pamphlet.  They come in three languages (French, Spanish & English) but each set of language instructions is it's own little set, so you can just read the ones in your language and discard the others if you want.The operational design is also really nice and seems to be geared toward the decidedly non-Barista in most of us.  There are a series of lights that easily telegraph when things are a 'Go' (green) and where you need to pay attention (red).  If anything isn't properly closed, if the water is low, if you need to remove the dregs etc.  a light on the panel will alert you.It has a grinder in the top that automatically measures and grinds beans when you start the brew process.  There is a hopper where you store the beans.  It also has a grinder key that allows you to adjust the grind in 5-increments from fine to coarse.There are three modes: Steam, hot water, coffee brew.The steam wand comes with a panarello, which, imo, is a must for a foamy-milk-making amateur like myself.  Basically, you stick it in the cold milk and it does all the work infusing it with the air to make your foam.  It takes about 15ish seconds for the temp to come up hot enough for steam when you first turn it on.The brew mode is pre-measured to give you either single or double shots.  You can however program it to change volume.  The major con here is that you can't change the amount of coffee it uses per shot.  All of that is automated inside the machine. The instructions do say that the machine is designed to brew a "true Italian espresso" coffee.  But if you like your espresso super strong, this may not be the one for you.In Hot water mode, it simply dispenses hot water.  Just position your cup under the panarello.It takes a little practice to get the flow of the machine, especially if you go from foaming to brewing back to foaming.  There are little in between steps that the machine needs to adjust itself.  Also in the switching from brew to steam, it can sputter a little, so have a paper towel handy to wipe droplets.The water container is small approx. 32 oz.  So you'll be refilling a lot.  The dregs tray and the brew assembly are easily accessed and removed for cleaning.It took me about three brew cycles until I think it was where it needed to be.  Taste wise, it was perfect for me.  So I loved this!

I am not gonna lie, when I saw all the parts come out of the box, i was not enthused.  I actually let it sit for a few days.  But I finally rolled up my sleeves and got to work.I should not have been concerned.  Even for the mechanically challenged (Me!), putting this chair together was a dream.  The pieces are clearly labelled with letters, and directional signs like 'this side faces front'  and 'this side goes up'.  The instructions are clear and easy to read as well.  Gone are the days of line drawings that only vaguely resembles the pieces in your hand.  the thin booklet was bullet pointed with concise instructions and each piece on the sheet was labelled exactly to the piece in your hand.  Even the hardware -- the bolts, washers etc. -- were all clearly labelled so you know when you'd need them.  It took us 35 minutes to put it together and some of that was just organizing.  Everything you need to assemble this is in the box, it comes with a tightening/twisting thingy (see, mechanically challenged). No additional tools necessary.Once it was done, this was a damned handsome chair.  Dark grey with sleek silver/chrome accents.  It swivels, it adjusts up and down, it glides on smooth casters,  and it tilts.  Our only moment of concern was the tilt.  The tension was super tight and it did not move at first, but again -- Instructions are your friend -- and it told us how to adjust the tension.  The arms even swivel up  to allow pushing the chair in close flush against the desk.It is very comfortable as well.  Very pleased with this.

10-17-14 UPDATE:  So I upped my original review from 4-stars to 5 just on the weight of fantastic customer service (original review follows under the dotted lines).  We had been using these light pretty non-stop since we got them.  My husband rides a lot on trails and seasonal roads.  They are not paved and are often bumpy.  At some point during one of these rides the enclosure that holds the battery on rear light must have worked itself lose.  Truthfully, since we fiddle with the flasher setting, we may not have screwed it in as tightly as we should.  Whatever the case, a subsequent ride on an even rougher road caused the base to disengage completely.  My husband didn't notice it was gone until he got back home.Bummer.  No problem, though.  We really liked the lights so we just decided we'd call the company and order a replacement base.  The company cheerfully replied to our inquiry email and said they'd simply send a replacement base.  No charge.  When the package arrived, it wasn't just the base, but an entire new light set.We had already liked the product, but it the extra little things like this that foster brand loyalty.  Of course I do not expect future lights or replacements for free, but this was unexpected and very gratifying.  And we are more careful of checking to make sure the base is completely screwed in.---------------This is a really nice little light set and perfect for my needs.  The rear light is a red LED, which can be steady or flash, I set it to flash.  The front light is white and is adjustable to 'beam' or 'flood'.  Both lights are incredibly bright and easily seen in the dark.The lights have a nice weight and heft, and all the stuff you need to install is right in the box, including batteries.They are easily installed and feel very firmly seated.  They not only installed on my  regular bike, but I also installed them easily on our ElliptiGo (outdoor elliptical bike) with great result as well.We do not do a lot of night time riding, but once in awhile we can be caught out in the dusk and these more than meet the need.Very pleased.

There are two things this item does well:  1) Be a clock and 2) Be a bluetooth speakerThe rest is all needless complication.The clock had 4 modes:1. Standby - this is the one where you set the time & the alarms.  You can't do anything else in this mode.  For instance, don't try to adjust the volume in this mode because it will think you are trying to set an alarm because volume and alarm set share the same buttons.  This feels counterintuitive because no matter what mode you are in you should still be able to change the volume.2. Bluetooth - this is the one where you can listen to a BT paired item through the speakers3. AUX -  didn't use4. FM - this is the one where you can listen to the radioThe clock allows you to use it as a charging dock for your iphone.  I didn't mind that you needed to use your own charging cable, but the threading and the physical st up to get it properly seated felt, again, needlessly complicated.  Since it makes you listen to your music through bluetooth, the dock is really just there for charging.  Why so why go through all the trouble of doing the threading etc. etc. when all you need to do is set the phone next to the clock-radio in order to listen through the speaker.  That is what bluetooth is for.,  I will say the speaker was fairly decent so no problems there.You can use the little phone symbol to answer incoming calls.  But you can't use it to initiate an outgoing call.You can only use 'radio' or 'buzz' as an alarm.  The buzz is really more of a beep.  And the volume on it is incredibly low.  I had the volume set on the highest it could go and the beep was still difficult to hear, especially above a white noise machine.So in sum, this is a pretty good clock and bluetooth speaker.

I have always purchased my desktops from Dell or HP etc. and they come pre-loaded with all sorts of stuff (Rhapsody music player anyone?)  So it was a little alien to have this machine start up without all that extra stuff.I was happy that this came with Win7 as I am not a fan of Windows 8.  It also comes with a MS Office trial and McAffee anti-virus.  But I already had additional licensees of my Norton and my own MS Office so I just activated those.In the box the tower come with a keyboard and Mouse.  So you will have to add a monitor and speakers.  It it easy to set up, basically it walks you through everything, It comes with bluetooth and paired seemlessly with a set of bluetooth speakers I had.My husband has been using it primarily as his home work computer for the past month and it has been working flawlessly.Very pleased

This unit had a rather quick and simple set up. It installed easily in my window.  We've been running it for about 3 weeks now and it cools a 14 X 15 den rather quickly and quietly.  It does not have a remote or push-button functionality, rather the controls are dials, so in that sense it feels rather old-fashioned.  But ti does the job and I am pleased with it.

Normally I run like my hair is on fire, far away from anything that is a retelling of or homage to or re-imagined Jane Austen fiction.  But as far as that goes, this wasn't bad.  It was clearly little bits and pieces of Austen fic & characters with the requisite drawing room romance and plot.  The thing that makes this a little different is the addition of magic.In this society, people -- young women especially -- use Glamour to enhance the beauty of their surroundings, create a mood, or even just scent the air with a hint of their favorite fragrance.  I liked the concept of the magic system and thought the author did a good job of incorporating it into the more familiar romance plot.Overall this was a fun little story and I actually enjoyed it more as it went on.  May just look up the rest of he series...

You know.... I was really rather disappointed in this book.Tangled,  the first book in this series is a 5-star favorite of mine.  It was funny as hell and written with such dash and verve that it stood head and shoulders above a lot of books I read last year.I couldn't wait for this one.  To be fair, the writing is still fantastic.  I really enjoy this author's ability to create atmosphere, how she crafts her dialogue, and the fact that she writes humor so well.This time instead of getting a story told in Drew's needle sharp voice, this one is told from Kate's POV.  Honestly, I didn't quite connect with Kate the way I did with Drew.  Maybe I am a secret Dude Bro at heart?  Or maybe it could just be that it felt like the author was really going for broke with Drew and so the first book came off as a bit more fearless?  At any rate, Kate's voice felt more subdued.  Or rather more conventional.But that isn't what disappointed me.  Not really.  My biggest issue with the book is the plot.  The basis of this book is that Drew and Kate needed to get broken up.  How to accomplish that because they were so in love at the end of the previous book?  Why, a Grand Mis of course!  And frankly it wasn't even that clever of a Grand Mis.The whole thing depended on Drew and Kate speaking at cross purposes.  He was talking about one thing without actually explicitly saying in actual words what he was talking about.  Ditto with Kate.  I won't say what the Grand Mis was about, but it was unbelievable because all Kate needed to do was use one  very unmistakeable word and the whole misunderstanding would have been over right there.  But she never actually says it.  And I just couldn't buy that a guy like Drew -- the Drew from Tangled -- wouldn't spew out everything he was thinking.So the whole foundation of the plot was really rather.... disappointing.Still I find the author's writing style and voice so appealing that even with the plot, I couldn't help but read the darned thing.  And late in the book, the POV switches back to Drew and BOOM!  Immediately the energy of the book spikes.So yeah, didn't live up to the first one but still I'd recommend it.

This was such an engrossing read and so well done.  It felt smart and even though the romance kind of takes second place to all the stuff that is going on with Carter, it was enough to feed my romance soul.Carter is a high school senior whose mother is an alcoholic.  He is a mass of emotions.  He loves her but he hates her.  He is ashamed that she drinks.  She isn't really a visible drunk and she isn't abusive or anything, so they manage to hide it, somewhat.  But Carter feels the burden of it all.  Of keeping his mother's alcoholism a secret,of trying to keep his younger sister from knowing, of trying to keep his mother from inadvertently harming her.The only time he feels any sense of freedom is when he is playing basketball.  And when he meets the new girl, Kira.  Kira is a free spirit who changes her look and hair like a chameleon.  She is funny and smart and she comes along at just the right time.This book is told in Carter's first person POV and his voice was very vibrant. I loved Carter.  I wanted to reach into the book and give him a big old hug.  He needed it bad.  I also loved him and Kira together.  They were sweet and awesome.This is a solidly written book that for once made me forget that I don't really read YA.

Before I got this book, I read the sample and was cautiously optimistic. There were no glaring typographic or grammatical errors. The premise seemed interesting. I love the friends-to-lovers trope. I really enjoy reading about smart, urbane professionals of which both Lacey and Rye were. It took place in Atlanta, so it sidestepped the small-town thing that is a bit overdone. So, yeah, I was happy.However my problems begin very early on with the book.  Before you can blink an eye Rye and Lacey go from longtime friends enjoying a friendly celebratory embrace to him having her top off and he's suckling on her breasts. In a public place.The sex in this book is pervasive.  There is a lot of it. I would venture to guess that approx. 70% this book is sex related. Either Lacey and Rye are having it or someone is talking about it or they are busily clenching/getting hot/wet/hard thinking about it.Now, truthfully a lot of sex in a book does not bother me. I like and read a lot of erotica. I actually prefer my romances to have open-door sex scenes. So it isn't the sex per se that bothers me. It is the bad sex that bothers me.  This book is chock full of poorly, crudely and rather purple-y written sex scenes.  The sex should have made me hot and bothered on Lacey & Rye's behalf.  But it didn't I kept giggling or rolliing my eyes at them.I could have tolerated the bad sex if the story had been strong enough to overcome it. But sadly there wasn't enough of it to really sink into.  And what there was of it felt full of tropes.Lacey and Rye start out as Lacey insists :"no strings, no rings" But within one chapter Lacey is fretting about being nothing but a booty call. She's beginning to fall in love but worries about her family and what people will think.As well she should, oddly her family were very resistant even though they'd known Rye all his life.  And then there is a scheming other woman and Lacey's lack of consistency from chapter to chapter.The one bright spot in this book is Rye.  Even through all the alpha-male chest thumping and "Whose p***y is this!?" demands, he is actually a pretty good character.  He is gone over Lacey and makes no bones about it.  He wants a real relationship, he shows her in every way he wants her.  He is a decent guy and tries to convince Lacey they have a future.But Lacey falls into one of my pet peeve traps.  While Rye is jumping through hoops to show that he is in this for the long haul, she is distrustful and illogical and really can't see what is in front of her face.  I found her very hard to root for.it is obvious this author knows how to write.  I just wish the story had been more engaging and the sex less pervasive.

I have never read a mm romance before and I think this was a very good book to start with.This one hit all my happy places.  It has two very appealing protagonists who have chemistry to burn and compliment each other wonderfully.  It has really good supporting characters that add to the plot as well as act as interesting characters all on their own, it has an interesting setting, and finally it has antagonists with believable (if stupid) motivation.The book is told from Whyborne's first person narrative.  Whyborne is the youngest son of an incredibly wealthy business magnate.  He has rejected his father's ideas of what he should do with his life, choosing rather to use his formidable intellect to become a philologist at a local museum.Whyborne doesn't have the most forceful personality.  His father is overbearing and makes no bones about the fact that he considers Whyborne a disappointment.  His older brother has been somewhat of a bully. And Whyborne keeps himself somewhat repressed because of his nature.  Suffice to say, Whyborne has some self esteem issues.Griffin is a great compliment to Whyborne.  Handsome and dashing, his bright waistcoats paint him the peacock to Whyborne's more sober peahen (Whyborne always wear brown or grey).  He has the self confidence that Whyborne lacks, and yet he does have his own vulnerabilities which are revealed rather vividly.  I liked how the two slowly came together and how the relationship developed.As far as the plot, it was a mix of gothic horror and paranormal that moved briskly and was really rather entertaining.  As mentioned above I love how the motives of the antagonists for getting involved in what they were doing felt realistic and understandable.I can't not mention the fabulous Christine.  She is an archaeologist who works at the museum with Whyborne.  She is sharp and has lovely pithy observations.  Through her we get to see the frustrations of a smart, educated woman in a male dominated society.  She is also an awesome friend and handy with a gun.  I hope she remains a big part of the series.Definitely gonna pick up the next book if only to see how Whyborn and Griffin develop and to hang with Christine some more.

I had never used a french press before but my husband swears that the coffee tastes better.  He also read something about the oils in the coffee beans being preserved during the press process and not in the drip process.So when this came we were excited to try it.  it is very pretty and yielded approx. 2 16 oz cups of coffee.  So perfect for us two.The instructions are written on the side of the box, but since I was a newbie to using the press and unsure about measuring and was not sure what 'coarsely ground' really looked like, I found a video on youtube done by a barista using a press very much like this one.  It was very helpful.It took a couple of tries and some experimentation with measuring & steep time before we finally got the result we liked.  I have come around to my husband's way of thinking and now think the coffee done in the press tastes better.We use it quite a bit and are very pleased with the product.

This book was a very nice surprise. It was well written, had engaging characters and a romance that felt naturally occurring. It also had a great sense of place and atmosphere.Zora is a NYC editor at a big fashion magazine who is on an enforced "break" from her job because she has been acting erratically. Turns out, Zora is suffering from rather vivid dreams involving an ancestor, a former slave named Julia who lived among and married into the Lakota Sioux 150 years ago. At the behest of her therapist, Zora travels to South Dakota to the Oglala nation to see if she can find out any information with the hopes of stopping the dreams.There Zora meets John Iron Hawk the Chief of Police on the Reservation. He is immediately suspicious of her and her motives having seen too many times a slick rich looking people like her come to the People to do silly articles. But Zora earns an ally in an elder who feels something in her story and is determined to help her seek the truth.This is a romance, but it is more appropriately a romantic suspense because there is a real mystery surrounding the fate of Julia and Zora is placed in jeopardy as she unearths those secrets. Also present is a light dose of the mystical woo-woo.While this story has some of the rather recognizable romance elements (Zora and John's animosity hides attraction) and romantic suspense elements (the bad guy manages to orchestrate things just so in order to silence Zora) the thing that I liked best were the pieces that were not necessarily plot related.There was a nice bit of setting in that the book takes place on a Reservation that that is struggling with poverty and services not being properly funded despite being the site of a thriving Casino that is raking in millions weekly. The frustration of the people is shown in little and big ways. And the results of being at the mercy of leaders who aren't looking out for their best interest is also shown in little and big ways. In the midst of this comes Zora with her poking about and raising hackles.The biggest con for me is the suspense element of the romantic suspense. I don't think the author connected the dots in a believable way. I thought the villain was too immediately concerned with Zora. Her excuse of wanting to track down info about an ancestor from 150 years ago should not have caused the consternation it did as early as it did. We later find out why her poking about was of concern and how a 150 y.o mystery could be dangerous to someone in the present time, but I don't think the road to that realization was as carefully plotted as it could have been.Overall though this was a good story that had nicely crafted characters, an evocative mood and a believable romance

I think the blurb that comes with this book doesn't quite get the tone of this book.  I was attracted to it solely on the name of the author and only cursorily even read the blurb.  Unfortunately, imo, the blurb makes it sound like this is some breathless billionaire romance. With Magic!  It isn't.  It really isn't.The book is set in Modern day Houston where history has been slightly altered where people have magical ability. Powerful magic users formed Houses that were headed by the most powerful users in their family known as Primes.In this setting we are introduced to Nevada Baylor, a young woman who is the primary investigator in the PI firm her family owns and runs.  She is given the job to track down the young heir to one of the major Houses and return him to his family before he is killed.  He is a powerful prime who can control fire.  And he fancies himself some sort of anarchist who doesn't want to knuckle down to the man!  Whatever.But Nevada isn't the only one looking for the destructive young man.  Mad Rogan (and he is always called Mad Rogan)  is the Prime of another very powerful house and he has a vested interested in the young man too.  He inserts himself into Nevada's investigation and causes her no end of consternation.  Not only because he is interfering, but also because they are very attracted to each other and she simply does not like him.When I began reading this book I was curious to know how it would be.  I was already very deeply invested in Andrews' Kate Daniels series and also really enjoyed their Edge series as well as a bunch of scf-fi novellas.  Those books all felt very distinct from each other so I was excited to see what new world we would get.This one does not disappoint, although I would say that the tone and setting it is reminiscent of their Edge series.Nevada is a strong heroine to hang a series on.  With the exception of the first chapter and the last one, the book is told from her first person POV.  She is funny and resolute.  She is compassionate, has a very strong moral center, and her number one priority is that she must be able to look at herself in the mirror at the end of the day.  I massively enjoyed Nevada.  She wasn't some major kick-ass heroine and there were times when she felt like she was in over her head, but she was a scrapper!Mad Rogan, though, to me was the more fascinating character.  He and Nevada will undoubtedly get together, but not just yet.  Nevada  and he have chemistry that super leaps off the page.  In fact, Mad Rogan all by himself has such a strong magnetic sexuality that it reaches right through the book and grabs you by the hair.  But he is not a nice person.  He really doesn't care about people like Nevada does.  In fact he finds them easily expendable.  He has a goal and he will use excessive force up to and including torture to get what he wants. However, he does have his own moral code which saves him from being a complete sociopath.  I really liked Mad Rogan.  A lot.  And I am rooting for those two crazy kids.This was a really good book.  I read it in one sitting and I very much looking forward to the rest of the series.

I read this author's Tairen Soul series up through the third book.  While I enjoyed the first two books of the series, my enthusiasm waned during the third book.  I never completed the series because I found the pacing to be somewhat glacial and the villain to be rather uninspired.Still, I liked the writer's voice and was glad to see that she had written a new book completely separate from that other series.First, I must say, I had the hardest time getting into this book.  The beginning of it was full of exposition with nothing that really hooked me into the story.After awhile, though,  I did begin to get interested in the plot because there were moments where I felt the story was beginning to gel.  However I can't say that I actually enjoyed the story.This is a fantasy romance.  If you read for the fantasy parts, you'll find them  ok but nothing really new.  The idea of  Khamsin's Summer Heat melting or thawing Wynter's ice-cold heart is a theme revisited over and over.  There is an enchanted heroic sword whose power can only be unleashed by the real heir to the sword.  There are Priestesses who guard prophecy and speak in enigmatic riddles.  There is a big bad that can only be defeated by the sword (or the power of true love take your pick).The romance aspects, however, come across as somewhat joyless.  Khamsin and Wynter's relationship start with a series of deceptions.  And throughout the story one or the both of them are constantly accusing the other of mistrust and betrayal.  The periods of mistrust are broken up by periods where it seems they are beginning to feel something and open up to each other.  Only to have something else happen that plunges them back into their cycle of accusation again.  I simply could not relax and enjoy the two characters.  I wanted to watch them form a bond and a relationship, but I knew it wouldn't last.  I found myself skimming parts just to get to the inevitable.  To be fair, they were being betrayed left, right and center.  You really needed a score-card to keep up with all the betraying going on. And the bad guys are telegraphed so broadly, it dulled their impact a bit for me.Even so, I was still rather engaged in the plot.  It says a lot about the author's ability to keep the story going that even though I had a ton of issues with the characters and some of their motivations, I didn't want to close the book before the end.Unfortunately the ending rather falls apart for me. It felt all over the place.  And frankly the Big bad they have to fight falls into the same trap I thought this author's earlier series' villain did.  He was just evil for evil's sake.  I had no idea what he wanted except to what be Ice king and kill people?  But if you kill everybody what exactly are you king of?The book had the bones to be an affecting fantasy romance.  I am sure my issues aside, there will be some who will really love it because there is a solid plot and some strong sexual chemistry between Kham and Wynter.  But I just didn't completely enjoy this one.

The picture does not do this faucet justice.  Its' picture makes it look rather awkward.  But in person it is a very handsome and functional faucet.  It had a very nice heft and the Moen quality is very evident here.  It was easy to install.  And even in my guest bathroom which has somewhat traditional decor, this modern faucet does not look out of place.  It is sleek and I love the pewter color (it looks more silver/chrome in the picture).  Very pleased with this item.

At first I was a little dismayed when I got these.  They felt thinner than the towels I currently have.  I was sure they;d fall apart when I ran them through the initial wash right I after they arrived.But after running them through the washer and dryer, while they still weren't the thick and fluffy towels I have, they did feel softer and more pliant than when I opened the package.I decided to give them to my sons to use in their bathroom.  It turns out they love them.  They are easy to wrap and hitch about one's waist (the boys complain the fatter towels don't hitch well) and they are surprisingly absorbent.  Interestingly, they seem to do best when they are absorbing water, so how relatively thin they feel when dry is a bit deceptive.Also, they do not pill.  Which is a huge plus!

I was very pleasantly surprised by these.  They are very handsome, have a very solid feel, and most importantly, they cook evenly.  The ten piece set is very versatile ranging from a small saucepan to a sizeable stock pot that can double as a dutch oven.  As an added bonus they are oven & dishwasher safe.  I am already looking to expand the set.

3.5 stars.As I was reading the first chapter of this book, I wasn't sure if I would like it.  It was basically an info dump.  Lots of inner thinking by the heroine, Danica.  Lots of telling us about her.  I fervently hoped the book would not continue in this vein.Luckily it didn't and the story smoothed out nicely.  I began to really enjoy it once Danica and Dex entered each others' orbit on the page.  Their interaction and chemistry was the strong point of the book.  She is front office, the GM of the football team and the person who just fired him.  He is a talent, a hard partying ex-quarterback who is now battling for his reputation amidst allegations of game fixing.The basic conflict between them is well constructed and offers up believable tension and potential romantic obstruction.  I also liked that from a basic personality standpoint they were really different.  I swear if Danica took the Meyers-Briggs, she'd probably be typed at an ISTJ.  She is responsible, capable, focused and able to easily handle situations of stress.  She's also intensely loyal.Meanwhile, Dex would be more like an ESTP.  Funny and charming, yet works hard.  Communicates directly, no hidden agenda, an easy going risk taker who also liked to live in the moment.  But more than anything he just loved football.Really the two of them together was the best part of the book.The other thing I really liked was that football wasn't just wallpaper or a forgettable backdrop for the story.  When I read a sports romance, I like for the romance to also include a good amount of the sport.  Otherwise, what's the point?  The plot outside of the romance was all about running a football team and in Danica's case also about trying to rehab Dex's rep.  Her family not only owned the franchise but were hands-on owners that added to the conflict.  The football was included enough to give realistic flavor to the story yet did not swallow the narrative.Which brings me to the part about the book that didn't work so well for me. Danica's family  was messy enough and interesting enough that they added some layers to the story. And yet... I got impatient with them and the little subplot regarding her ex-husband.  His got a few POV's that felt  intrusive and I found myself wondering what his motives were? I don't think it got answered necessarily well.  Also, everybody seemed waaay to preoccupied with her single state.Otoh, Dex's family backstory was very intriguing and yet the author didn't explore it as much as I would have liked.On the whole, this was a smartly written book with the romantic relationship being the highlight.Review is based on an e-Arc provided by author

I got this because I already had the companion products -- the conditioner and the leave in treatment for thermal styling.  Having had good results using the other two items, I was very curious how my hair would react when using all three as suggested.I definitely say there is a noticeable difference.  The Keratin acts to keep the hair manageable and reduces frizz for a longer period of time.  The smell is lovely and I did notice my hair did not revert as much in humidity.That said, I do have other shampoos I prefer more. But as a total hair-care solution, I have been very impressed with Tresemme's 7-day keratin system of products and will use them when I want a smoother look.

So I am not a huge gardener or anything.  But we have a pretty nice little plot.  My husband broad forks it to prepare the area for planting.  But I wanted something small and simply to clear weeds and maybe aerate other small patches  for planting.This is a decent little cultivator.  It feels a bit sturdier than I thought it would.  Not really heavy or durable for hard-packed or more gravelly soils, but works good for the smaller stuff I need it for.I did notice there was a tendency for the handle to disengage.  Gets a little frustrating.So it was fine, but not fantastic.  Suitable for light gardening.

I tutor the ACT professionally, and I'm happy to report that this book is a useful addition to the ACT prep marketplace.Each section of the test is covered in a helpful, down-to-earth manner, and the advice is clearly written by an experienced tutor. I also like that the book explicitly refers to the Real ACT Prep Guide and tells readers to practice with it. The review of each section is not (nor do I think is intended to be) comprehensive; serious studiers may want to supplement with books specializing on one section of the test.Due to its length, this book does not have many practice questions. However, this is a blessing in disguise: students should generally only be practicing with authentic (ACT-written) questions anyway.I did like the humor, but at times, it can be grating; some students will be shaking their heads like I did and saying, "please just get to the point without trying to be funny!". Don't get me wrong - the humor does, on the whole, make the book more readable than most of its competition.Overall, I would recommend this book for most students: it does an admirable job of explaining the most important parts of the ACT. If you'd like more ACT prep recommendations, you can click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I tutor the ACT and have been doing so for several years. I can tell these cards were written by people who actually tutor the ACT (surprisingly, most ACT prep materials are not). As a product, these cards have some strengths and weaknesses.Strengths: English. Making up nearly half of the cards, the English cards do a good job of presenting many of the skills tested on the real ACT. Since English questions are fairly short, I like flashcards for this kind of practice. The answer explanations are also good.Math: Flashcards are generally a good way to practice math. I don't think the Math cards are as comprehensive as the English ones, but they provide good practice, and again, have good explanations.Weaknesses: Reading. I'm not the biggest fan of the reading strategies on the cards overall. Some I liked, and some seemed a little too good to be true. As you might expect, the cards are too small to test Reading passages and instead just offer strategy.Science: I don't think these cards will add a whole lot to a student's Science ability. Again, flashcards don't really lend themselves to Science passages and questions. I think the strategies would be more understandable if a student had a passage in front of him.Writing: The advice for writing seems tacked on, and is now outdated, since the ACT essay has significantly changed since these cards were published.Overall, if your son or daughter is allergic to books, these cards are a good plan B. But consider the opportunity cost. Students would probably be much better off if instead of using these cards they were using a good ACT Prep book in conjunction with authentic ACT tests. The biggest reason to practice with real tests is question authenticity. The questions on these cards do not reliably duplicate the nuances of real ACT questions.If you'd like more ACT prep advice, you can click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm a GRE tutor, so I've read a lot of GRE books over the years. Since this book is from a small publisher, I didn't know what to expect. The book delighted me at times, but overall, it is not a complete resource and suffers from serious flaws.Good stuff: The book has insightful test-taking advice. I especially liked the advice on pacing, reading, and I enjoyed most of the strategies presented in the beginning of the book.The essay advice is very good - much better, in fact, than that of most GRE books. Since this book is inexpensive, you might want to buy it for the essay advice alone.Bad stuff: The book has a tendency to oversimplify verbal technique. The examples used are simplistic to the point of being obvious.There is no discussion or inclusion of Critical Reasoning questions, which make up 10-20% of verbal questions.The book discusses "author's feeling" and "extended reasoning" questions in the reading comprehension section, but these types of questions no longer appear on the GRE.The practice test has an Issue essay prompt that is outdated, offering a choice of two prompts, neither of which are written in the current GRE style.Practice test question realism is generally poor.The book is completely anonymous. No author, no website, no mailing address. Kind of weird - I like to know the background of authors of books like this.Overall, this book does have some bright spots, but is fundamentally flawed as a GRE prep guide. If you'd like more GRE prep recommendations, you can click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I've been tutoring the ACT for 8 years now. Quantity sells, but quality improves scores. Unless you've exhausted all AUTHENTIC ACT practice material, there's little or no reason to use a book like this one.To the layman, the questions in this book might look the same as real ACT questions. As a tutor, I can assure you they are not always the same. There are many subtle differences, and students using this book will be subtly misinformed about the real test in many different ways. Speaking from experience, it's HARD to completely capture the complexity of real ACT questions.The good news is that there are five real ACT tests in the Real ACT Prep Guide, one on the ACT's website, several old ones online in various places, and probably a couple in your high school's guidance office. If you do all these tests, I'd rather see you analyzing and deconstructing questions in them instead of doing Princeton Review tests, since analyzing the real tests will teach you much more about what the ACT actually will test on test day.IF you've not only done but thoroughly analyzed ALL available ACT tests and you need more timed practice, then you could use this book. Just don't analyze the questions - they're not authentic and will behave differently in ways that can screw you up.If you'd like more ACT prep advice, you can click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm a GRE tutor, and I take a particular interest in this book since the company that writes it (BTPS testing) uses the book in courses throughout the California State University System. Unfortunately for the students taking these courses, the book is one of the worst GRE guides on the market.1. The book is out-of-date. Even though the GRE hasn't changed since 2011, ETS (which writes the GRE) recently published 150 verbal and math questions. These new questions reflect subtle changes to the test (the math is getting harder, the verbal has phased out certain gimmicky questions) that this book doesn't reflect.2. The practice test and question quality isn't very good. Unlike real GRE questions, the question in this book are usually simple and straightforward. Real GRE questions make you use reasoning skills; they make you think. Some of the math questions in the book are good, but on the whole, these are not the questions you want to practice with.3. Essay advice has little substance, and the "strong" sample essays are only about 4-5 on the 6 point scale.4. Reading passages are not written in the GRE's style and they're largely way too easy. The book neglects to provide any technique for Critical Reasoning questions, which make about 10-15% of verbal questions.5. Math concept review is very light, and not all concepts are covered. Some concepts that WON'T be tested are covered (calculating standard deviation).6. Perhaps most importantly, this book neglects to tell the reader to use ETS-written materials, in what I can only assume is BTPS Testing putting profits before helping students. Any good GRE book, tutor, class, or course will quickly tell you that the best practice sources are the books published by ETS, which writes the GRE.The only parts of the book I liked were the parts in the beginning with general test-taking advice.Overall, I'd avoid this book. There are many better options on the market. BTPS, if you ever read this, I urge you to re-think the decision to include this book in your GRE courses; in my opinion, you're doing a real disservice to students. It needs a major overhaul.If you'd like more GRE prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

As a GRE tutor, I've seen lots of different companies' practice material. Kaplan's latest GRE Verbal workbook, like the previous versions, provides lots of practice, but yet is not what I'd recommend for GRE prep.The biggest problem with the workbook is question realism. Kaplan-written GRE questions are usually less complex than ETS GRE questions. Even though there are a limited number of ETS-written questions available, you can get lots of mileage out of them by reviewing them until you can precisely explain your justification for the right answer, as well as why the wrong answers are incorrect. This takes MUCH more time and effort than just doing them, but is also much more rewarding.Another problem with the workbook is the lack of technique supplied for Critical Reasoning questions. The book addresses "highlighted parts of a passage" questions, but doesn't offer technique for the strengthen / weaken an argument or "explain a paradox" questions. Though the answer explanations explain the answers to these questions, test-takers looking for a step-by-step technique to solve them may be frustrated. The real test will have 1-2 of these questions per section.Reading passages sometime reflect the style of the GRE, but often are much simpler and easier to read. For instance, there is a passage about an Antarctic explorer on pg. 158 that is barely middle-school reading level!The essay advice is generally good, but doesn't offer a lot of options; instead, templates are offered. This is probably ok for average scorers, but high scores may find this section wanting. Furthermore, it is a waste of time to practice with Kaplan-written essay prompts; ETS publishes all possible test prompts on its website for free. The more ETS prompts you practice with, the higher the chances you'll get one on test day that you've already worked with!I did like the sections of the workbook with vocabulary and writing drills. But I'd urge test-takers to consider the opportunity cost of working with this book: the time you spend working on Kaplan questions would be much better spent working on ETS questions. If you'd like more GRE prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I tutor the GRE full-time, and I look at this book from that perspective. Kaplan's latest math workbook is okay if you need to improve your math skill, but there are better options, namely CliffsNotes Math Review for Standardized Tests and the books in the Manhattan Prep GRE series.There is plenty of math practice in this book, but it has two main flaws:1. The review of math concepts is incomplete. The book teaches arithmetic, algebra, geometry, and statistics concepts, but some of the less common concepts are missing. The level of practice for each concept is enough to get people familiar with it but not usually enough to really master it. Remedy: if you're looking for a comprehensive math review, Manhattan Prep (which is actually owned by Kaplan) is MUCH better. (Note to Kaplan: please retire your Kaplan GRE brand and just sell your Manhattan Prep brand. It's so much better in every way!)2. The realism of math questions is, like that of most books, not great. The GRE is a REASONING test in addition to being a math test. Although there are a few exceptions, most of the math questions in this book do not involve reasoning. Whether they're easy or hard, they just involve math skills. Real GRE questions are usually more complicated - they're often more like puzzles - and also reward you for noticing ways to make them simpler. Remedy: make sure your practice includes ETS GRE questions.I applaud Kaplan for trying to make the math questions in the book harder - there are 80 new "advanced math" questions. But they're hard for the wrong reasons. The writers of the questions just made them a pain-in-the-butt to solve. Real GRE questions are not like this: they're hard because you have to think logically in addition to using your math skills.Working through this book will improve your math ability, but it won't improve your GRE math skills as much working through other books will. If you'd like more GRE prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I've been tutoring the ACT for about eight years. Kaplan's ACT guide, like its previous editions, provides basic advice for the test, but fails to deliver by a wide margin on its claim that it's "all you need to get ready for test day."1. The book doesn't cover many English and Math concepts that will be tested, and those it does cover often do not offer enough practice for students to become proficient. Remedy: get books that focus on just one section of the ACT if you want in depth coverage and more practice.2. The practice question and test realism is not great. Remedy: practice with REAL ACT tests that are published by the ACT, not those written by third-party companies. Real ACT questions are generally harder, more complex, and most importantly, more reliable in terms of duplicating what you'll face on test day.3. The book offers one way to look at Science and Reading questions, but I find that students need to experiment with technique in these sections to find what works best for them. Remedy: be willing to use trial and error to find methods that work best for you.Overall, I'd urge serious students to look beyond this book and to particularly analyze real ACT tests, which are much closer to the real thing than the ones in Kaplan books.If you'd like more ACT prep advice, you can click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I've been tutoring the ACT professionally for about 8 years. I'm only giving this book three stars because I don't think it delivers on its promise to get students to a perfect score. A much better title would be, "ACT prep for smart kids who want to improve their scores".My first area of concern is the English and Math sections. This book doesn't cover all tested concepts (of which there are many) for either section. It covers most of them. How are students supposed to get perfect scores without full coverage?My second main area of concern is question and practice test realism. The writers don't work for the ACT and do not reliably duplicate the nuances and complexities of real ACT questions. Furthermore, they don't point students to the obvious source of better practice material, The Real ACT Prep Guide (published by the ACT).So although this book contains good advice, it's incomplete and certainly not a one-stop-shop for a perfect score. If you REALLY want a perfect score, you'll probably have to analyze several real ACT tests until you can identify what each problem is testing, not just get it right. Additionally, I'd recommend looking for books that just cover one section of the test. These books have a narrower focus and can therefore cover all the little concepts missing from ACT 36.If you'd like more ACT prep recommendations, just click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I tutor the GRE professionally, so I am reviewing this book from that perspective. The short answer regarding whether this book is useful is no. Since ETS makes so many verbal questions available, and since the technique offered by this book is so rudimentary, I don't recommend it.I'll start with technique. Kaplan techniques are simple at the expense of effectiveness. They may work on easy Kaplan questions, but for many, they won't work very well on harder, more complicated GRE questions. For example, all reading comprehension question types are lumped into the same technique. It would be great if it were that simple, but it's not.The practice questions in the book look like GRE questions, but upon closer analysis they are much simpler and more straightforward. There is little point practicing with questions that would be way too easy for the real GRE to ever use.The essay examples provided by the book lack critical thinking, merely presenting one side of an issue instead of analyzing the issue's complexity, counterarguments, and implications of the essay's thesis. These are not good models for your writing compared to the real sample essays that ETS provides for free on its website. Furthermore, there is no good reason to practice with Kaplan essay prompts; ALL the prompts ETS uses are published on its site.The book does have a good vocab / word roots section and some useful writing drills. But instead of using this book, I highly recommend you practice for GRE verbal with ETS questions and books. Try Manhattan Prep if you'd like more robust technique, as well. If you'd like more GRE prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

As a GRE tutor who thinks about this stuff for a living, I urge you to get both of these books.Why? One simple reason: these are REAL GRE questions: 150 verbal ones, and 150 math ones."But wait, Vince! Aren't there way more questions in other GRE books?"Yes, there are. But here's the thing... quality trumps quantity every single time. Real GRE questions are much more convoluted, complex, and nuanced than any other company's. Also, real GRE questions play by the same consistent, fair rules that the questions on the real GRE do. That's why it's so important that these questions are part of your prep.Yes, you may need other sources of questions to increase your experience level (I like Manhattan Prep's). But make sure you master all the real ETS questions, which is the best way to prepare for the real GRE questions you will be facing on test day. If you'd like more GRE prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

As a tutor, I recommend certain books to my students so that they can accomplish as much as possible outside of my office. The Ultimate Guide to SAT Grammar is the most helpful book I've yet seen for the new SAT (which will debut in March of 2016). Here are a few reasons why:1. The book is comprehensive. I've been teaching SAT prep for a long time, and most of my students are fairly to highly serious about their scores. I'm glad to be able to offer them a workbook that covers everything, rather than one that covers most of the test.2. Practice question realism is very good. It's essential that students get used to the nuances and style of the real test, and unlike books published by most companies, this one aptly mimics the complexities of real SAT passages and questions.3. It's up-to-date. The new SAT writing section is much different than that of the current SAT. This book reflects all the changes we know about right now.4. The book cross-references the College Board / Khan Academy tests, so that students can look up authentic questions on which to practice concepts.The only real criticism I have of the book is the formatting and look - it might be easier for certain students to use if the graphic design and layout were more engaging. But this is easily the best book on the market for students who truly want to understand the material. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm a full-time SAT / ACT tutor, and I recently got very familiar with the new PSAT because I recorded a video training course for it. I'm happy to say that Barron's new book is a helpful companion to the College Board's revised PSAT and SAT materials.The strengths of this book stem from the fact the author is an experienced tutor. The strategies rang true for me, and I found the answer explanations and insights about the test to be helpful.The practice test question quality is good, and students should find the review of grammar and math concepts helpful. I also liked the tips for building foundational skills for the subject matter.All in all, this is a very good book to include in your PSAT test prep. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

As far as one-big-book GRE guides go, The Princeton Review's "Cracking the GRE: Premium" is not bad. It will get you familiar with the test. Sound good? It shouldn't. If you want a competitive score, you'll need more than familiarity.Positives:The book is user-friendly, easy to navigate and use. The techniques for verbal reasoning questions are fine, and unlike Kaplan's books, it covers all critical reasoning question types. Math techniques are fine, and the major math concepts are covered. Essay advice is ok, too.Negatives:The book tries to cast the GRE as a silly test that only measures "your ability to take the GRE". But if you buy that, you might not prepare as rigorously as you need to: the GRE will test your vocab, reading comprehension, math knowledge, and writing ability, but also your ability to adapt, perform under pressure, and to THINK. Many of these abilities will be things you've developed or can develop further independently of traditional prep.The book doesn't cover concepts very deeply or offer technique options. Lower or higher scorers may be disadvantaged by this. Don't expect this book to get you to a high level in math, for example - you'll need a much more comprehensive review and more practice if you're rusty. The back cover of the book claims, "If it's on the test, it's in this book." I would disagree - not all math concepts are covered, and those that are often don't go deep enough to prepare you for harder GRE questions which test those concepts.Finally, the practice question realism is not great. Questions (like those from most prep companies) generally do not capture the real GRE's nuances and complexities very well. For this reason especially, I urge you to practice with official GRE materials.The bottom line: this book is ok if you don't really need a competitive score. But if you do, you may want to do quite a bit more work than this book suggests you need to. The thing that bothers me is this book's marketing: it claims to be an "all-in-one solution", but it's just not. I like the Manhattan Prep GRE books when used as supplements to ETS's GRE books. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm a GRE tutor and I review GRE books to share my opinions with people who will self-study for the test. This GRE practice question book is okay, but there are better options for practice questions, namely, Manhattan Prep's 5-lb book.The questions in this book are usually less complex and easier than real GRE questions. So if you do buy this book, make sure you use it as a supplement to the questions written and published by ETS (which writes the GRE).Quantity is much less important than QUALITY when it comes to practice questions, and mastery of questions is more important than how many tests or questions you've done. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm a long-time GRE tutor, and I review GRE books to help self-studiers with their prep. Kaplan's latest version of their GRE prep guide, like its previous versions, is a basic primer for the test, but not what I'd recommend. I think it is inferior to its competition in several important ways.1. First, this book is a one-size-fits-all book. But kind of like a one-size-fits all hat, it's not going to work as well for people who are below or above average. If you're starting from a high or low point, this may not work well for you: high scorers need more depth; lower scorers need more technique options.2. Practice question realism is poor, especially for verbal questions. It's so important to practice with questions that capture the nuances and complexities of the real GRE. Kaplan, like most companies, doesn't duplicate these nuances well. In general, these questions are simpler and easier than real questions. So even if this book included access to a million Kaplan computer tests, I would avoid it.3. The book does not adequately cover all the concepts the GRE will present. I am surprised to see there is still no treatment of logic or "critical reasoning" verbal questions, and that not all math concepts are covered. Again, bad for you if you want a competitive score.4. The level of depth for math concepts will, in my opinion, not get people to competency in many cases, let alone mastery.5. The techniques offered for math are fine, but verbal techniques are fairly fluffy - they may work on Kaplan-written questions, but I don't think for many they'll work well on more difficult ETS GRE questions.The thing that gets me worked up about this book is not that it's mediocre. It's that it's marketed as the best, most comprehensive GRE prep option. I guess it sells more books to say your book is an easy one-stop solution than to tell people that you may need multiple books and that hard work is required. Also, Kaplan books have a funny way of garnering tons of 5-star "reviews", and as a result, millions of people buy them. Whatever prep materials you choose, I suggest researching them in detail. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm a GRE tutor and I recommend this book. It has tons of practice problems for the GRE (obviously). The quality of these problems is quite a bit better than that of companies like Kaplan and The Princeton Review.However, here is my warning: do not let working in this book prevent you from doing (and more importantly, MASTERING) all the ETS questions (in the Official Guide, the computer tests, and the Verbal and Quant practice books). Authentic questions are much more valuable than Manhattan questions; make sure you can do all the ETS questions forwards, backwards, and sideways and that you understand them well enough to explain them to a friend. That will ensure you're really good at the GRE, which obviously only contains questions written by ETS.Even though Manhattan Prep does a better job than most of its competition at writing practice questions, its questions do not dependably have the same nuances and complexities that ETS questions do. So I'd view this book as a supplement to, not a replacement for, real ETS GRE practice questions. If you can't afford both this book and the ETS books, buy the ETS books: quality > quantity. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm a GRE tutor, and I'm reviewing this book from that perspective. GRE For Dummies is a good book to get if you're happy with an average score or you don't have much time to work on the test, but this is not a great choice for people who want competitive scores.There is plenty of good advice in the book about the test, the math, and the essays. But due to the book's length, it will get you familiar with things but probably not actually get you to MASTER those things. If you want a high score, you want mastery, not just familiarity.The practice question and passage difficulty / complexity and the robustness of verbal techniques leave something to be desired. Real GRE questions are harder and more complex than the ones in this book. The technique in this book may work well with its practice questions, but success with real GRE questions will demand better technique and flexibility.I'd recommend the Manhattan GRE series over this book, unless you really don't have that much time to work on the test. Hopefully you do, since for most people, getting ready for the GRE is not as easy as this book would have you believe. In the experience of most of my students, they need much more than a "refresher". As with any successful GRE prep, the materials published by ETS should be where you're spending most of your time. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

What makes a great math teacher is the same thing that makes a great math book: mastery of and passion for the subject, and the genuine desire to help. Finding a math book that exhibits these qualities is rare. I'm excited to recommend this book because the reader really gets the sense that the author cares about him understanding the concepts. Consequently, it's a powerful tool for learning algebra.Also, the book is usable. The writing is down-to-earth, clear, and engaging. Inquisitive students will love it.I think this book will be great for smart kids who haven't taken algebra yet, but it's also helpful for those who need to re-learn algebra (for a more advanced class or a science class, or for a standardized test). I'm a SAT / ACT tutor, and I learned several things from this book. More importantly, I learned how to better teach some of the concepts I already know. So I would certainly recommend this book for teachers as well. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

Like Erica Meltzer's The Critical Reader (which covers the SAT's Critical Reading section), The Complete Guide to ACT Reading is thorough and thoughtful. As a full-time tutor, I've read many ACT prep books. This one is an improvement on them for several reasons:1. There's an entire chapter devoted to timing strategy. Since students have different reading speeds and abilities, different strategies must be taught. It's nice to see different options presented, which makes it more likely that your student will find one that works for her. Most books will only discuss one strategy for pacing.2. The book has a great discussion of how to change the way you read passages for maximum benefit. Again, this is done in much more detail than most books and consequently students are more likely to be able to learn how to read more efficiently.3. Advice on how to THINK your way through the Reading section abounds. Using logic to find details and understanding how authors construct passages and paragraphs are discussed in detail. In fact, a theme of the guide is that thinking skills are necessary for doing well - a welcome change from the reliance on "tips n' tricks" by many of this book's competitors.The book also deconstructs all the major and minor questions types students will encounter on the test and provides a couple of practice tests. The quality and realism of the passages and questions is quite a bit better than other prep books I've read, and the techniques are more robust.The ACT has recently thrown us a couple of curveballs: a Reading section with paired passages and questions asking about both, and the inclusion of a science-style chart in a passage, so the book could benefit from an update to include those potentialities. I might also like to see more cross-referencing to The Real ACT Prep Guide. But overall, this is a must-buy for the motivated student and / or ACT tutor because of its comprehensiveness and level of insight. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I write this review from the point of view of a long-time ACT tutor. After a few pages of this book, I realized that the author was an experienced tutor as well. This matters a lot - many ACT prep books are written by committee or by academics with little ACT tutoring experience. This author has done a great job, both in terms of covering the material the ACT presents and giving the reader lots of insightful strategies. To clarify, the strategies in this book are MUCH BETTER than those you'll see in books by companies like Kaplan and The Princeton Review.The only major thing I'd add for readers of this book is to seek out real ACT practice tests to use in conjunction with it. There are five in the Real ACT Prep Guide, one on the ACT's website, and probably a few more at your high school. They, by nature, are more realistic than the practice tests in this book.Overall, this book is a refreshing departure from most of what's on the market for the ACT and is an excellent resource if you're just buying one ACT prep guide. For the student with the motivation to work through it, it will make a major difference. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm an SAT tutor and have been for more than seven years. It's hard to get a competitive score on the SAT for most students, but there are lots of test-prep publishers that would have you believe otherwise. "The SAT is tough and you're going to have to work hard and prepare extensively to do well" doesn't sell books. "The SAT is silly and can be beaten with our clever tricks" DOES sell...Unfortunately, this book falls into the latter camp. Advice, overall, is light and fluffy at the expense of offering usable technique or rigorous preparation. Perhaps this is because the book was developed by people who were extremely high scorers on the test. I hired tutors for a tutoring company for over four years. High scorers don't always teach well because they so intuitively understand how the test works and that intuition can be hard to translate into useful methods.If you're really, really smart, almost any technique you use will work on the SAT. However, if you're not a genius, you'll need good technique and good preparation - which includes building extremely solid vocabulary, grammar, math, reading, and writing skills. I understand that the book wasn't meant to be comprehensive, but it covers topics so superficially that I don't think it will help most students.The book isn't all bad; there are some useful tips for math and grammar. But bad advice for all sections abounds. The critical reading technique will do almost nothing for most people.Though your teenager may actually read this book, he shouldn't. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

Hello, GRE studier. I'm a long-time GRE tutor. I'm probably more excited about this book than you ever will be, but I hope I can convince you to buy it. I enjoy helping people get good information about the test, especially since there is so much bad information out there.Why is this book essential? So far, ETS has only published four practice tests worth of GRE material, along with a smattering of practice problems. With a limited sample, we can make many conclusions about the real test - but it's always good to get more data. And here it finally is.Careful analysis of these questions will help a lot if you take the time to dissect them and think about what they're testing and how exactly they're written. You could practice with 3rd party material like Kaplan's, but neither Kaplan (nor its competitors) will be writing the GRE you take. ETS will. ETS questions are subtly but significantly different than those from ANY 3rd party. The technique ETS provides is not the best - you can probably find much better technique in Manhattan Prep's guides. But ETS questions are what you want to be using to study.This book also includes 2 new prompts for each of the AWA tasks and sample essays for each with commentary. This is worth the price of the book, since it gives us a lot of new data about what the graders reward.Overall, this is a must buy if you're serious about your GRE score. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

Me: long-term GRE tutor. You: probably someone studying for the test. I hope this review convinces you to buy not only this book, but also to buy the Official Guide (if you don't already own it) and the Verbal Reasoning practice book (both published by ETS). Why? Because I believe these books will all definitely add points to your score. Even if we never work together, I hope you do well.This math book is invaluable for one major reason: there are 150 real GRE questions inside of it. Real questions! Why am I so worked up about them? Well, ETS has been stingy so far in providing GRE practice material. Now, I and you have more ways to get used to the real test. Careful analysis of and practice with these questions helps, and I'll be using them with all my GRE students. This book also includes strategies that ETS hasn't published before - and it tells you which questions the strategies work on. This is great and unprecedented. For more complete technique, you'll probably want to check out the Manhattan Prep math guides.Sidebar: hey, Vince - don't other companies publish GRE practice problems? Yes, they do - but they're pretty much worthless compared to the real thing. Even Manhattan Prep (which I like a lot) doesn't really write realistic math questions (and definitely not verbal questions). Don't even get me started on Kaplan...So, I urge you to practice with and analyze these authentic questions. Carefully reviewing the concepts tested and figuring out what techniques work best will make you much better at quantitative reasoning if you invest the time. Since ETS's explanations in the book can be obtuse or mathematician-y, I'll be posting free video solutions on my YouTube page (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIRZsN8eJEe4jHuITOEcShw) and on vincekotchian.com that teach easier techniques. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

Like Mike Barrett's SAT Prep Black Book, this book is a helpful resource for nearly any student preparing for the ACT. I'm an SAT/ACT tutor myself, and I recognize that the advice in this book comes from someone who has worked with the test over a long period of time. It's much better than the advice the big test prep companies offer.However, I do have a significant criticism for the book: it makes preparing for the ACT seem easier than it actually is. This is due to the author's focus on strategies and dismissal of underlying skills. The strategies in this book will work well for students who already read at a high level, who have a command of the math concepts tested, etc. But in my experience, even many straight A students do not read well or remember the math they've been taught.So, I recommend this book with the following caution: don't believe it's going to solve all your ACT problems. Read challenging non-fiction, practice math, and learn your grammar. Check out the books for the ACT written by Erica Meltzer and Richard Corn as supplements to this one. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I've been tutoring the ACT for over seven years. This book, like that written by any third-party, is different enough from the real ACT that it's dangerous. To the casual observer, the tests in this book look like the real ACT. But show them to a good ACT tutor and he'll cringe. There are many significant differences. Some questions are way too easy. Others test things the ACT won't. The passages are written in a different style than the real test. This all matters because to get ready for the real thing, you want to practice with the real thing.So, I urge you to only practice with real ACTs. There are five in the Real ACT Prep Guide, a few online, and probably one or two at your high school's guidance office.If you carefully analyze the questions on those real ACTs, you'll be prepared. If you analyze the questions in this book, your preparation will have holes in it - and you'll be in for some surprises come test day. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I've been tutoring the SAT for about seven years, full-time. This book is a good addition to most SAT takers' toolboxes, but it's not a complete solution. It can, at times, emphasize technique at the expense of foundational skills (like vocabulary, reading comprehension, math, writing). This emphasis rankles me a bit, mostly because the book claims to be the only prep source you'll need (besides the "blue book"). That, and the hyperbolic title, should give you a little bit of pause. However, buy the book! Its advice is mostly useful and you'll learn a lot about the test and how to prepare for it. I picked a few things up myself.I recommend this book to students with the caution that they should supplement with other test-prep books that provide more robust skill building. Try those by Erica Meltzer and Pwn the SAT. The exception is extremely smart students - if you're already at a 2000+ level, this book might get you where you want to go. The lower your score, the more trouble you'll probably have using the Critical Reading tips this book offers.In short, the SAT tests both test-taking and fundamental skills. To really get good at it, you'll need a balanced approach. You may have to use more than one prep book... but it's worth it. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I've been tutoring the ACT for more than seven years, so I've read many, many prep books. Like most of the big prep companies, Kaplan has done an okay job with this book. It has both pros and cons, and might be a decent recommendation for someone who can only buy one other book than the ESSENTIAL Real ACT Prep Guide (which I hope you buy). There are, however, much better books for certain parts of the test written by smaller companies.The English section covers most but not all of the error types on the real ACT, but the explanation level is pretty shallow. Furthermore, the questions do not imitate real ACT questions very well. Instead, I'd recommend Erica Meltzer's Complete Guide to ACT English, which is about 100 times more accurate and helpful.The math section has a solid introduction to techniques and concepts. The downside is that many practice questions are more straightforward than those on real ACTs. A better book is The Ultimate Guide to ACT Math by Richard Corn.The reading section largely has good techniques. Passages and questions don't really mimic the real test that well. Also, certain techniques need more rigor and explanation, for example, how to find a main idea of a passage. If you're a parent even of a student with great grades, you might be surprised that your child doesn't know how to do this.Science strategy is good. Question and passage realism isn't that good. The book doesn't include any treatment of logic or scientific knowledge questions; the real ACT will have one or two of each of these.The writing section is a standout. Good advice about writing the essay and writing in general with helpful drills.Other quibbles of mine include: typos, bad timing advice, practice test realism is uneven. Other good things include: test-taking strategies, helpful breakdowns of concept frequency. So, in my view, it's a mixed bag. I like the Princeton Review book better if you only buy one book. Calling this book the "2015" version is a little silly since a. it's 2014 and b. the ACT just rolled out some changes that will begin in 2015 and that this book does not reflect.One last thing: if Kaplan truly cared about raising your score, even though it might sell them fewer books, they'd tell you to get a copy of the ACT's Real ACT Prep Guide or even to just ask your high school counselor for free real practice ACTs. Spend a lot of your time analyzing real tests, which are subtly but significantly different than any third-party tests. It's a blessing in disguise that the online tests for this book don't work right now: avoid Kaplan-written practice tests and get yourself some real ACTs to practice with. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I tutor the SAT for a living. You'll probably never work with me, but one thing I hope to convince you of is that using third-party practice tests is not helpful and even harmful.Kaplan questions, particularly those for the SAT's Critical Reading section, are inferior to the College Board's in several important ways. They're more subjective, less complex, and in general don't mimic the real test very well. This is a really big deal if you're serious about getting ready for the real SAT. As a tutor, I can spot the difference from 100 yards away.
