Most parents and students unfortunately don't have enough experience with real SATs to realize this book misses the mark - and don't find out until they take a real SAT.There are about 23 real SAT tests you can get from the College Board's Official Guide, its online course, and just from the internet. Answer explanations are available from the College Board for its Official Guide for free. I urge you to practice with official material and to avoid material written any big third-party company since so many real tests are available. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I tutor the GRE and have done so since 2008. I'm happy to report that the Manhattan GRE books are like eight crisp breaths of fresh air compared to their largely mediocre (and stale) competition. For the serious GRE self-preparer, these books, when combined with official GRE material, will take you very far. There are a couple of flaws, but IF you have the discipline to work through eight books (and the cash to afford them), these guides are quite simply your very best bet.The foremost strength of these guides is their comprehensiveness. They aim to cover all the concepts the GRE will present, and I think they do. Most one-book guides can't and don't.The writing is authoritative and easy-to-read. The techniques presented are generally useful and easy to follow. I did notice a couple of things I didn't like: math techniques such as plugging in numbers and back-solving are rarely explained or described. This may be because only the practice sets at the end of each book have multiple choice questions. These are crucial math techniques and should be your first line of defense against many GRE problems. Verbal techniques are good, sometimes a bit oversimplified, and at times perhaps difficult for most students to use (the mantra advice for reading comp, for instance). I'd suggest Manhattan publish a separate math book with a focus on techniques as opposed to concepts, but that might cut into their course sales...Another benefit of these books is that any of them gives you access to six online multistage GRE-like tests, which are useful practice, since there are only two computer practice tests available from the real GRE. Another good addition to these books is Manhattan's famous 5-pound book of GRE practice problems. Manhattan questions are not perfect imitations of real GRE questions, so use them but do not analyze them too much compared to authentic GRE questions.Despite my issue with the dearth of math techniques and my lukewarm feelings about those for verbal, I strongly recommend you get these books early and use them often. These guys know their stuff and it shows. The only sporting thing for their competition to do at this point is to throw in the towel. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I write this from the point-of-view of an SAT tutor: I've been helping students with the test for over seven years. We tutors typically disparage big companies like The Princeton Review and Kaplan; their one-size-fits-all approach, oversimplification, and poor practice test quality will leave high-achieving students needing more. However, though more rigorous and useful alternatives to this book do exist, it's a good choice if you only want to buy one companion to the Official SAT Study Guide (which is the SAT bible).The main strength of this book is the test-taking and question solving technique you will learn from it. Learning how to do well on the SAT is a lot different than the skills used to do well in school. This book offers easy-to-read descriptions of techniques for all the question types on the SAT. Some of these techniques, particularly those for reading comprehension, do suffer somewhat from being written to work for everyone. Others, like those for math questions, are very good. If you want better techniques, you'll probably have to seek out books that are just written for one section of the test (like The Critical Reader and Pwn the SAT). If you want a score above 2000, certainly seek out those books.Other sections of the book are a disappointment. The grammar section oversimplifies what you'll need for mastery, as does the essay advice. The practice test quality, like that of pretty much any third party company, is not good. Don't use these practice tests, please. The other thing I don't like is that the book insults your intelligence by claiming that the SAT "just tests how well you take the SAT". C'mon, dude. I know that pandering to students might sell more books, but the SAT is a good indicator of how well-read you are, how well you can adapt, if you can think critically, whether you can apply your math skills, and of many other qualities. That's why most colleges take it very seriously.Overall, this book does get my recommendation for most students for the strength of its technique and its readability. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I tutor the SAT for a living and I have done so since 2008. To be blunt, I'm writing this review to try to talk you out of buying this book. In fact, I really think it's disingenuous of companies like the Princeton Review to offer SAT practice tests. Why? The tests are different enough from the real SAT to screw you up - plus, there are so many real SATs available.Real SATs are extremely carefully written and standardized. Though the tests in this book LOOK like SATs to the casual observer, when I look at them I cringe. There are myriad subtle differences between these and the real test: many questions are too simple or straightforward, particularly in the Critical Reading and Writing sections. Math questions are a little better, but they're all over the place, too. Other questions are inconsistent: more than one answer choice could be argued for, concepts are tested that the real SAT won't, etc.The Official Guide to the SAT, published by the College Board, has ten real tests, and there are three more online that you can find for free. If you run out of those, you can buy the College Board's online course which has ten more. Also, the College Board has FREE answer explanations to all ten tests in the Official Guide online [...] In light of this, there is no reason I can think of to buy this book or ANY third party book merely offering practice tests. You might as well practice for your Spanish final by studying Italian. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I've been tutoring the SAT for seven years now, so I write this review from that perspective. I've seen a lot of SAT prep books over the years, and this one is pretty much what I expected from a big test-prep company. It does cover most parts of the test adequately, and students who diligently use it will certainly improve. The point I want to make is that the book falls short of its claims of comprehensiveness and excellence.First, and most importantly, there is a big difference between Kaplan practice SAT questions and tests and real SAT practice questions and tests. The latter are extremely carefully devised and edited; they're complex and varied. Kaplan questions (like those of nearly every company) are more straightforward and simpler. This matters a lot in preparing. Sadly, Kaplan seems to pretend the College Board's Official Guide, which contains 10 real SATs (and so you should absolutely have it), doesn't exist, in what I assume is a strategy to sell more Kaplan books,Some of the techniques in this book work well, in particular, the math techniques. When it comes to Critical Reading techniques, Kaplan techniques work well...on Kaplan-written questions. In the wild (when you're taking the real SAT), you'll need more robust,  nuanced, and adaptable techniques and skills.The message I want to get out there is: do your homework and educate yourself about SAT prep and what it takes. One resource I'd recommend checking out is The Perfect Score Project by Debbie Stier - written my a mom who took seven SATs. Despite what many big test-prep publishers would have you believe, picking up one giant book is not going to get most students to a competitive level on this difficult test. Oh, and by the way, if you don't think big companies have ways to pay reviewers to write five star reviews, check out the obviously fake five star reviews for this book... If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I tutor the SAT professionally, so I'm basing this review on my experience teaching the test and on a comparison of it to the other SAT books I've read. It's of average quality and contains a lot of helpful information; but it does have flaws mainly pertaining to oversimplification.First, the good stuff:- the book will get students to a decent level in area like math and grammar due to the adequate coverage of most concepts- the writing is easy to read and down-to-earth- certain parts of the book appear to be written by an actual tutor - these are good spots to pay attention since the writer at these times has "been there and done that"And now, the not-so-good stuff:- the book never mentions that you should use it as a strategy guide to help with real SATs (like those in the College Board's Official Guide). This is sad. Real SATs are significantly different than those written by Kaplan (or any other company). For that reason, it's ESSENTIAL to practice with real SATs. But I suppose Kaplan would rather not tell you this since you might not buy their books if you buy the College Board one.- on that note, the practice questions and tests in the book resemble real SATs, but upon closer inspection, most questions are less complex and often easier. Not a good way to practice and certainly please avoid analyzing these questions and their answers.- some techniques, particularly those for the Critical Reading section, will only work in a perfect world. On the real SAT, these techniques (particularly those with which to answer passage questions), will not work so well. You'll need more robust, adaptable techniques if you want to handle medium and hard passage questions.- there is a smattering of bad advice amongst the good advice in the book. For ex., the experimental sections recently have NOT looked "just like" normal sections; the SAT has been testing its 2016 format on students - which is weird and different looking. Grammar IS arranged in order of difficulty. You SHOULDN'T guess if you can eliminate one choice on a hard question if you have no idea about the other four choices: the SAT is really good at making you guess wrong on those questions.Overall, this book is okay. But if you want to master the SAT as opposed to just get familiar with it, you'll need more. Educate yourself and don't believe the hype - mastering the SAT is not as simple as buying one big test prep book - despite what Kaplan's marketing would have you believe. Speaking of Kaplan's marketing... see if you think the 5-star reviews for this book were written by real people. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I tutor the ACT (and SAT) for a living, so I've read many, many prep books. Like most of the big prep companies, Kaplan has done a decent job with this book. It has both strengths and weaknesses, and might be a good recommendation for someone who can only buy one other book than the ESSENTIAL Real ACT Prep Guide (which I hope you buy). There are, however, much better books for certain parts of the test written by smaller companies. I'll score the book ACT-style since it's more fun that way.English: 22. The English section covers most of the error types on the real ACT, but the explanation level is pretty shallow. Furthermore, the questions do not imitate real ACT questions very well. Instead, I'd recommend Erica Meltzer's Complete Guide to ACT English, which is about 100 times more accurate and helpful.Math: 27. The math section has a solid introduction to techniques and concepts. The downside is that many practice questions are more straightforward than those on real ACTs. A better book is The Ultimate Guide to ACT Math by Richard Corn.Reading: 27. The reading section largely has good techniques. Passages and questions don't really mimic the real test that well. Also, certain techniques need more rigor and explanation, for example, how to find a main idea of a passage. If you're a parent even of a student with great grades, you might be surprised that your child doesn't know how to do this.Science: 25. Science strategy is good. Question and passage realism isn't that good. The book doesn't include any treatment of logic or scientific knowledge questions; the real ACT will have one or two of each of these.Writing: 11. The writing section is a standout. Good advice about writing the essay and writing in general with helpful drills.Overall: 25. Other quibbles of mine include: typos, bad timing advice, practice test realism is uneven. Other good things include: test-taking strategies, helpful breakdowns of concept frequency. So, in my view, it's a mixed bag. I like the Princeton Review book better if you only buy one book. Calling this book the "2015" version is a little silly since a. it's 2014 and b. the ACT, today, just rolled out some changes that will begin in 2015 and that this book does not reflect.One last thing: if Kaplan truly cared about raising your score, even though it might sell them fewer books, they'd tell you to get a copy of the ACT's Real ACT Prep Guide or even to just ask your high school counselor for free real practice ACTs. Spend a lot of your time analyzing real tests, which are subtly but significantly different than any third-party tests. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I am a long-time GRE tutor, and I've checked out a lot of what's on the market in terms of resources. Since working with a tutor doesn't work for everyone, I'm always on the lookout for resources to recommend to people who don't end up working with me. This latest GRE guide from Kaplan is of poor quality compared to its competition and I recommend that you avoid it. There are a few things I like about the guide:- the essay advice section has extensive drills on how to improve your writing.- the answer explanations are well-thought out and detailed- there is a lot of material to practice with, both in the book and onlineHowever, the flaws of this book outweigh the benefits, in my view:- practice question quality is average. Questions are less complex and generally easier than real GRE questions.- the book has no logic questions other than the "two bolded parts of a passage" questions. This is an egregious omission, since the real GRE will have 1-3 of this type of question per section! (Strangely, the online practice tests DO have logic questions - would be nice if the book had covered them so you'd have strategy for them.)- coverage of most topics is cursory and not good enough for mastery or even basic competency in many cases- Kaplan strategies will work pretty well on Kaplan-written questions, but aren't nuanced or robust enough to handle many real GRE questionsThe fact that this is the #1 selling GRE book confounds me - I assume it's partly due to Kaplan's multi-million dollar marketing machine (and some seriously dubious 5-star reviews - check 'em out yourself). If you're looking for a recommendation, Manhattan Prep writes the best GRE books on the market. If you can just buy one book in addition to ETS's Official Guide, I'd recommend the Princeton Review GRE guide - better all around than this one. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

About me: I'm a GRE tutor and have been since 2008. I can't recommend this book: despite its strengths, there are important concepts the GRE covers that this book completely misses or glosses over. Overall, the coverage of the material is spotty and not as robust as I'd like it to be.Things I liked:- many answer explanations are comprehensive and well-written- the essay section actually has drills to improve your writing (most books don't do this)- the math reference in the back is a good study toolThings that made me literally cringe and feel angry:- the verbal advice and practice tests in the book have NO LOGIC QUESTIONS.(The online tests do, but you never get strategy for them.) You may know these as "critical reasoning" questions - they ask questions like "which answer would strengthen/weaken the argument" or "resolve the paradox". The author(s) did include some "two bolded sections" questions in the book, but they completely missed the other types. This is bad for you, since each real GRE verbal section will have 1-2 of these questions.- the math concept coverage is really brief. Not nearly adequate to develop basic competency, let alone mastery.- there's no mention of ETS's "Official Guide to the Revised GRE". Though the Official Guide is ESSENTIAL to your GRE prep, I guess Kaplan would rather not tell you about it (since you might buy it instead of their books).You might wonder why this book makes me angry. Well, that's because it's weak, but thousands and thousands of people will buy it, since Kaplan has the marketing budget of a small country and fantastic brand recognition. Overall, there are ways this book will help you prepare, but I'd avoid it if you're in the market for a one-book GRE prep guide.***UPDATE*** Check out the 5-star "review" from Elisa S. Davis (a Kaplan employee) for this book. If you agree with me that Kaplan employees shouldn't be reviewing their own books, let Amazon know! If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I review a lot of GRE books since I'm a GRE tutor and have been for several years. This one is a good choice if you only buy one supplement to ETS's Official Guide to the GRE (which I hope you have). Several instances of bad advice occur, and the practice question/test quality is average, but overall, I like the book.Good stuff:- test taking advice and techniques are largely useful. In particular, I like the advice to "walk away" if you're stuck. (I picture a helpful friend trying to help you avoid a fight: "Just walk away, man! It's not worth it!")- the book covers most of what you'll need for math concepts and all of the verbal concepts- certain areas, like the coverage of critical reasoning, are better than the competitionNot-so-good stuff:- like most Princeton Review books, this one implies that the GRE is a silly test and that it's your enemy. But purporting that the GRE "just measures your ability to take the GRE" is pandering. Don't believe it. The test measures a lot of different skills that are worthwhile: vocab, reading comprehension, critical thinking, logic, adaptability, prioritization, etc. But it probably sells more books to paint the test as a bogeyman.- in that same vein, the book also says the test should be prepared for "for 4-12 weeks". That advice combined with my above complaint might dissuade you from achieving mastery of the concepts. If you want a score that reflects MASTERY as opposed to a decent score, you'll need more time and more than this book (unless you're already really good at this stuff)- essay advice is on the light and fluffy side- practice questions and tests are less complex and easier than the real GRE (this is a pervasive problem in the test-prep industry, though)Remember that knowing a concept vs. mastering a concept are two different things. If you merely know a math concept, for example, you'll get the question that tests it right if you recognize the concept. But the GRE is good at disguising concepts. Overall, this book has a lot going for it, and if you consider the above disadvantages, it's a good buy. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

As a GRE tutor, I've read a pretty good variety of GRE books. In their latest "Cracking the GRE" edition for "2015" (It's May of 2014, guys), The Princeton Review - as they usually do - does a decent job at informing the reader about the GRE and provides usable strategies to help deal with the test. However, in attempting to appeal to a wide audience, the book oversimplifies the process and adulterates its quality.Things I liked: the strategies in the book work. If you're new to the GRE or self-studying, these strategies will provide one way to deal with GRE problems. Maybe not the best way, but one workable way.- The writing is readable and the organization of the book is logical. To be useful, books must be usable and this book is easy to follow.- The book covers all of the major concepts the GRE is likely to present.Things I didn't like:- Like most books by The Princeton Review, this one starts off with the claim that the GRE is a silly test that doesn't measure your intelligence and only measures "how well you take the GRE". This is pandering and untrue: I'd argue that many of the things the GRE tests ARE good predictors of your intelligence and ability to succeed in grad school - things like writing skills, vocab, reading comprehension, logic, critical thinking, and adaptability. But it probably sells more books to disparage the GRE and then claim that this guide is an "all-in-one solution". The problem is that students who buy into the pandering may be less likely to build crucial foundational skills.- the treatment of most topics is too brief. Those with higher than average score aspirations should supplement with other books.- practice questions are, generally, too easy and less complex than real GRE questions. Some topics are neglected in the book's practice tests (for example, passages with two bolded parts).Overall, unless you're starting from a high skill level, you'll almost certainly benefit from more material and better material than this book offers. One good example is Manhattan Prep - though they break up their GRE guides into eight books (which is expensive), it's also unfortunately necessary. One book just can't do it all, despite what The Princeton Review claims. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I tutor the GRE professionally and have done so since 2008. If you're new to GRE prep, this book is a good start, but don't think it's a one-stop shop for all your GRE prep needs. It's far from a "total test-preparation program": like most things in life, getting good at the GRE is not as simple as picking up one book. With that said, this book will help in many ways. I give it 3.5 stars.Things I liked: - Some strategies are well-explained and useful, in particular, those for reading comprehension. Text completion and sentence equivalence are good as well, those not as robust. Math strategies are solid - particularly the quantitative comparison strategies. - The review of math concepts is largely good, though certain concepts get glossed over too quickly or even ignored (combinatorics). - Answer explanations are thorough and understandable.Things I didn't like:- The quality of the practice questions is just average. Real GRE questions are more complex and varied - particularly the verbal questions. This is important - do not just practice with these questions and expect to be ready for the real GRE. But one area that does stand out to me is the reading comprehension PASSAGES, not the questions. The passages are well-written and representative of real GRE passages.- The essay advice is on the light side - falls short of what you'll most likely need. For instance, very little advice is given on how to construct a body paragraph other than providing examples of them.- The practice test question quality of the online practice tests is unfortunately a bit worse than the book ones.- The book makes no mention of ETS's Official Guide to the GRE, which is (in my opinion and experience) an unfortunate prioritization of book sales over the desire to help students as much as possible. The Official Guide is essential and much more helpful than any third party book. - The title. 2015? C'mon, bro. It was published in April. The GRE hasn't changed since 2011.Overall, this isn't a bad companion to the Official Guide, but you'll need more if you're serious about the GRE. And like I said, it's not as simple as buying one book. No third-party company does a very good job of duplicating the real GRE's nuances - particularly in the verbal section. I do like Manhattan GRE, but many of the same criticisms as above apply - just in different areas. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm an SAT tutor and have been full-time since 2008. I think this book is absolutely great for three reasons:1. The author has found the luminaries in the field (Erica Meltzer, Pwn the SAT, etc.) and tells you about them. Now you know about them and can follow their advice, too. There are countless not-so-good places to find SAT advice, so this is tremendously valuable.2. She's actually walked the walk. This is rare. She speaks from experience, not theory. All her advice carries a resulting authenticity.3. She was able to motivate her son to do well on the SAT and explains how she did it.My job would be a lot easier if all parents had to read this book. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

As a full-time SAT and ACT tutor, I'm familiar with a lot of what's on the market in the way of ACT test-prep materials. It's easy for me to give this workbook five stars; it's not only best-in-class but obviously MUCH more thorough, insightful, and therefore useful than its competition.Since there are so many different ways the ACT tests grammar, punctuation, and rhetorical skills, this workbook is a welcome way for students not only to get an explanation of each tested skill but also to get realistic practice through the accompanying exercises.For the serious student, the book is a godsend if he or she will put in the time to work through it. Essential for anyone really interested in getting a competitive (30+) ACT English score. Needless to say, I'll be using it with my own students. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

As a veteran SAT tutor, I've seen firsthand that one of the most intimidating aspects of the SAT, for many, is the difficulty level of the vocabulary present in its sentence completion questions. But learning or even memorizing all the words the SAT may test is an unachievable task, and making a noticeable improvement in one's vocabulary can take a long time.The bad news? Most students do need to learn many new vocabulary words and word roots - and there is no shortcut for doing so. The good news? Good technique and high-quality practice material goes a long way. That's where this book comes in.- there's an authoritative explanation of sentence completion technique- the author debunks the dangerous myth that sent. comp. is just about vocab and explains how even students with superior vocabulary skills can and do miss questions- the practice questions are very SAT-like and consequently much better for practice than nearly any book I've encountered- the answer explanations are articulate and thorough- the list of common second meanings of words is very usefulThe book's no-nonsense tone and rigorously explained questions are a welcome change from the flash and lack of substance of books written by bigger SAT-prep companies. This clearly is the labor of someone invested in improving SAT scores. Highly recommended for self-studying students of any level. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm a long-time SAT tutor, and I'm always looking for resources to help my students (and to make me better at what I do). This guide, though not completely comprehensive, is a valuable edition to a student's SAT writing toolbox for several reasons:- no pandering. I like that the author debunks the myth that a student can memorize a series of examples that work for any essay prompt.- good writers and smart students will find their intelligence is respected - instructions are clear without being dumbed down- the writing is down-to-earth and consequently engaging and easy to read- it's not the size of a phone book (like many SAT prep books) - it's easy to get through- the essay and its necessary components are well-explained- many sample student essays are presented, dissected, and gradedThe only area in which I found the book to be a little lacking was its treatment of how to actually write the details and subsequent analyses that make up an essay's body paragraphs. This could be more explicitly explained. However, many students will be able to glean information from the excellent writing in the author-written sample essays and some of the sample student essays.Overall, I think the book is a great resource for students who are smart enough to realize that there's more to writing a good SAT essay than tips and tricks. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm an ACT tutor and have been since 2008. This book is a useful tool for students who want to improve their ACT math scores by getting extra practice. It provides realistic math problems which are organized by topic and difficulty level.Things I liked:- the problems are much like real ACT questions- the ordering by difficulty level makes it easy to start at the right place for your skill level- the problems have detailed answer explanations which often include multiple ways of solving the problem- many of the answer explanations actually teach math and calculator skills- good time management strategies and study strategies are givenThings I would change:- the problems can become slightly repetitive - good, since repetition helps learning, bad because students aren't always forced to adapt that much- problems could be more like the ACT in terms of creativity (though I've never seen an ACT math book which perfectly mimics the ACT's styleI would use this book as a supplement to the Real ACT Prep Guide. Many students will also need a book that teaches or reminds them of the foundational math the test covers. But this is useful additional math practice that might best serve as a warmup to the Real ACT tests. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I tutor the SAT for a living, and I've read a lot of SAT math books. This one is a breath of fresh air amongst the "phone book-size" (as the author aptly calls them) manuals churned out by the big test-prep companies. It functions perfectly for its intended purpose.Things I liked:- the writing is conversational, readable, and funny (think tough love with a sense of humor)- the techniques are sound and well-explained- there is a good overview of the math needed for the test- the time management and test-taking advice is clearly explained and various plans for different score levels are givenThe book does not cover every single concept or question type the SAT might throw at you. If you are a high scorer, I'd recommend supplementing with the challenging Pwn the SAT. But if you think this book's breadth is a detriment, I'd say you're missing the point. The book is useful for both low, medium, and high scorers because it covers things 99% of students need to learn. Most importantly, it's usable, manageable, and readable. No book in the world will help if your kid won't read it. He'll read this one. Highly recommended. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

Since 2008, I've been tutoring the ACT full-time, mostly to smart kids from private school. I've read a lot of ACT prep material. Kaplan's ACT 2014 is better than many of them, but the book falls short in a few areas, enough for me to both like it and hate it. I might recommend it for those who only plan to buy one ACT prep book - but I hope you can buy more than one.Good things:- the intro chapter is readable and informative- timing advice and "ACT mind set" tips are useful- solid intro to the material each section will test so you know what's coming- "workouts" for each section are a good way to get students to practiceThings I didn't like:- practice questions and tests differ from real ACT questions (please use real ACT's instead of these)- enough unhelpful advice is included to make certain sections harmful- some techniques work well; some don't- the "perfect scorer" tips are usually facile- several questionable claims, for example: "Any score above 23 will be an asset for competitive colleges". Huh??The book is a decent choice, but I'd recommend that you 1. purchase the Real ACT Prep Guide (because it has real ACT's) 2. seek out more specialized books for each section of the test. Yes, you'll spend a lot more, but students who want to maximize their potential will need a lot more than this book offers. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I've tutored the ACT since 2008, and I've read a lot of different ACT books. This one is better than many, but it falls short in a few areas, enough for me to end up feeling ambivalent about it. I might recommend it for people who only plan to buy one ACT strategy book - but hopefully you can buy more than one.Things I liked:- the intro to the test is readable and informative- timing strategies and "ACT mind set" advice are sound- good intro to the material each section will test- some useful techniques (especially in math)- "workouts" for each section are usefulThings I didn't like:- practice questions and tests are not like the real ACT (please use real ACT's instead of these)- enough bad advice is included to make certain sections dangerous- techniques are a mix of useful and not-useful- the "perfect scorer" tips are simplistic- the DVD included, for some reason, was labeled "Kaplan ACT" but had a reading comprehension video for SAT- a few questionable claims, for example: "Any score above 23 will be an asset for competitive colleges". Uh, say what now?I think the book is a decent choice, but I'd strongly recommend that you 1. get the Real ACT Prep Guide (has real ACT's) 2. seek out specialized books for each section of the test. Yes, you'll unfortunately spend a lot more money, but this book isn't a one-size-fits-all solution even though it claims to be. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

Picture yourself in a museum. In front of you is a masterful Jackson Pollock painting. Next you to stands an art critic. You glance at him. He's frowning. "It's a fake!" he says. Weird, you think. Looks real to me.The painting is these practice tests. You're you. I'm the art critic. I've been tutoring the SAT since 2008 and have read a lot of different SAT material. One of the most important things for students is that they practice with SAT tests written by the College Board. The SAT writes these tests extremely carefully. The Princeton Review's tests might look the same to the untrained eye, but I assure you they are not.This matters - a lot. The Princeton Review's tests are easier in certain ways, less complex in most ways, and sometimes even test things the SAT won't. Practicing with them is kind of like training for the Superbowl by playing rugby. You'll be in for a surprise when you get to the real thing. This is particularly evident for the verbal questions - the math ones are better but still too straightforward. Now granted, I think 98% of prep books don't write SAT questions well. My guess is that it just takes too much time and effort to really get the nuances right. And quantity sells.So, in my opinion, there is no reason to buy this book, since the College Board makes so many real SAT's available. There are books which offer answer explanations, too.The other thing I don't like about this book is that it makes the claim that the SAT is silly because it just tests your ability to "take the SAT" and that it doesn't measure anything important. I would argue that the SAT DOES measure important things, and it measures them pretty well (vocabulary, reading comprehension, critical reasoning, math skills, ability to adapt). I know most people don't like the SAT, but people need to give it more credit. The kind of reading passages on it, for instance, are similar to those you'll have to read in college - and require the same skills (active reading, ability to read for main idea and to understand multiple viewpoints in a passage).I'm giving the book a star for its math questions and discussion of the essay. But I can't imagine recommending that anyone use it. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm a professional SAT tutor. Here's a quick analogy to help explain this review: me looking at these tests is like an art critic looking at a fake Rembrandt. The critic spots it in two seconds. To the untrained eye, however, the painting looks real. How much is the fake worth? If no one had spotted it, it could have sold for millions. But now that it's exposed, it's almost worthless.SAT tests written by a third party (like Kaplan) are not good representations of the real thing. The differences range from minor ones (too-straightforward math problems) to major ones (verbal questions that are too easy). I always recommend that students use authentic material. Practicing with this book will kind of get you familiar with the SAT, but you'll find the real SAT writes more complex and challenging questions - especially in the critical reading sections. Using this book for critical reading is like practicing for a baseball game with a softball and an aluminum bat.A one-star review may seem harsh, and I'm sure the authors put a lot of time and effort into this book, but I can't recommend that any student use it when the College Board makes so many real tests available. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I have read many SAT prep books - because I tutor the SAT for a living and have done so since 2008. This book gets SAT prep wrong in many ways.1. The 8 practice tests do not resemble real SAT's. As I tutor, I can spot the differences right away, especially in the critical reading and writing sections. This is BIG DEAL: students who use these tests will find the real SAT different - and more difficult - in several ways. Kaplan's questions are usually less complex than real SAT questions. Even if you buy this book, I urge you to not practice with these tests - use College Board written tests instead. There are plenty.2. Verbal question techniques are oversimplified: "get the main idea", "cross off wrong answers", "listen for the error". There are many smart students who need more explicit instruction for how to find main ideas, determine if an answer is definitely wrong, etc. Also, I disagree with several of the verbal techniques. Mapping a passage by "circling important details", for instance, is a bad idea if you want to get the main idea (in my opinion).3. The techniques offered are demonstrated on Kaplan-written questions. It isn't hard to make a technique look useful if you've written the question it's utilized on.4. Some minor things are not accurate - for instance, this book makes the case that the SAT tests trig (??) and double negatives in sentences. It does not.5. The speech bubbles on the side of each page tend to have really obvious tips. The DVD is dumbed down - it will probably insult your intelligence at some point.I did like some parts of the book. The treatment of grammar errors is mostly solid. The math strategies are good.Students who are serious about the SAT should not, in most cases, buy just one book. It's not that easy, though big test-prep companies might like you to think so. Instead, I recommend seeking out more specialized books that focus on one section of the test - these authors don't have to cover everything and thus often do a better job.Also, Kaplan: you're doing students a disservice by not recommending the College Board-written tests as a companion to your books. I know they're a "competitor" and people might not be able to afford both your book and theirs, but claiming your tests are accurate representations of the real SAT is not helping students. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I have been tutoring the SAT for over 6 years and have read a lot of SAT material along the way. Though this book does have some merit, I wouldn't recommend it for several reasons:1. The practice tests are not like real SAT's. The differences are subtle but significant, especially in the verbal sections. This is a major downside: students who practice with these tests will find the real SAT different in several ways - most importantly, Kaplan's questions are usually more straightforward than real SAT questions. Please, do not practice with these tests - use College Board written tests only. There are plenty.2. The techniques presented for verbal questions are oversimplified: "find the main idea", "eliminate wrong answers", "listen for the error". Sure, those methods work - IF you can do them. There are many bright students who need more explicit instruction for how to find main ideas, determine if an answer if definitely wrong, etc.3. The techniques are demonstrated on Kaplan-written questions. It's easy to make a technique look effective if you write the question it's used on.4. Several minor things are incorrect - for example, this book makes the case that the SAT tests trigonometry in math and double negatives in grammar. It doesn't. Certain reading passages are way off SAT style - for example, a passage that looks like it was taken from a science textbook about blood.5. The little bubbles on the side of each page with tips tend to have facile tips. For example, one "perfect score tip" says that "I found that I didn't need to be overly creative to get a good score on the essay. Simply following Kaplan's rough format is enough to get you a good score.". How is that a "perfect score" tip?Ok, so what did I like about the book? The breakdown of grammar error types is, overall, solid. The math strategies are good, too.Students who are serious about the SAT should not, in most cases, buy just one book. It's not that easy, though big test-prep companies might like you to think so. Instead, I recommend seeking out more specialized books that focus on one section of the test - these authors don't have to cover everything and thus often do a better job. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

This book is a good supplement to, but not a replacement for, the math review in ETS's Official GRE Guide.I tutor the GRE and my students often need to review math. But if they jump straight to math strategies, they often find they have foundational holes in their math knowledge. This book will help them fill most of the gaps in their math knowledge and practice skills at a basic level. It does a nice job of covering nearly all the math topics tested on the GRE.The book has several issues: some topics explained are not tested (using the quadratic formula and calculating standard deviation), and some topics are tested but not covered (normal distribution of a variable). Also, it's written by a "math guy" - and people with backgrounds teaching mathematics, like the author, sometimes explain things in a way that presumes the student understands certain things. Worse, the techniques used are too "math teacher" - there are more helpful techniques that the layman can use.The practice questions and tests are way too straightforward - GRE questions are tricker, more complex, and more creative.If you need to brush up on math, this book will help. But you'll also need math strategy and you'll need to practice with authentic GRE math questions (i.e., those written by ETS). If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I've been tutoring the GRE since 2008. Most of the problems I have with this book come from me picturing the average student using it. I am afraid this book will give students a false sense of efficacy for three reasons:1. The Kaplan methods tend to assume the student has certain skills. For instance, the reading comprehension strategies assume students have a good way to get a main idea from a dense passage. In my experience, many students don't know how to do this. The strategy doesn't work if a student can't do part of it - instead, the book should more clearly explain HOW to look for main idea. Likewise, Kaplan advises to "think strategically" as part of math strategies. I don't think most of my students can see the logical way to make questions simpler, because many haven't done math in a while. I think teaching techniques is much more effective. Of course it's easy to do a math question if you happen to see the logic behind it - but that won't work for many if not most students on the real GRE's complex, multi-layered math questions.2. The second false confidence booster is the practice questions and tests. They're too easy, and more importantly, too straightforward. Though you might think they're hard enough because they have tough vocab, in fact, the real GRE writes MUCH more complex questions for both verbal and math - questions that are tricky in spite of easy vocab. The reading comp questions are too straightforward. If you just practice with these questions, you will be in for a nasty surprise when you take the real GRE. Admittedly, no one really does a bang-up job of writing verbal GRE questions that are like the real thing - Manhattan Prep is ok.3. The math section doesn't cover all concepts tested. The verbal tests don't even have logic questions! Not good.I did like some of this book. The essay writing drills stand out to me because they will help students improve their writing style and get rid of some bad habits. And the math reference in the back is pretty useful. Other than those, though, I think the book isn't a good resource. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I don't think any student should use this book to prepare for the ACT. I know that's a bold statement, but let me try to back it up. First, I've been tutoring the ACT and SAT full-time since 2008. I have read a lot of ACT prep material. There are many better books out there. Here's a list of the things about this book I didn't like:- the top 50 strategies list, which many students will read first and study before the test, goes from the obvious: "get a good night's sleep and eat breakfast" (duh) to the hard-to-follow: "relax!" (it's not always easy to relax even if you want to) to outright bad advice "read science passages for main idea". (This doesn't work for most students and most science passages.)- the diagnostic test and practice tests in the book are not good models of real ACT tests. They're usually too easy. To the untrained eye, they might look the same, but I assure you they are significantly different. There is no good reason to practice with them when so many real ACT's are available for purchase (and for free).- the foundational skills (grammar, punctuation, math) provided are cursory and could go much further- the techniques for solving questions are oversimplified and not very effective as a result- the attitude of the book that "the ACT test writers are evil" seems like pandering to students - in fact, I think the ACT writers are pretty good at determining if students have certain skills- the organization of certain sections didn't work for me - for instance, English rules are presented as an appendix instead of part of the chapterTo be honest, this book makes me angry - because I know thousands of people will buy and use it because McGraw Hill is a big company with a big marketing budget. There are some useful tips in the book (it's not all bad), but with so many other options, I would recommend looking elsewhere for ACT help. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I tutor the SAT (and ACT) full-time, so I've read many SAT prep books. I like this one. It's comprehensive and competent. It seems that they worked closely with SAT tutors as opposed to having an academic write it, and it shows. So, do you want the good news or the bad news first? Ok, I'll start with the bad news.- the practice questions and tests, like 95% of those that aren't published by the College Board, do not represent the SAT well in terms of question style and difficulty. This is especially evident in reading comp. and grammar, where the questions are too easy. This isn't because the authors are lazy or incompetent - it's just really HARD to duplicate the nuances of real SAT's. The math questions are pretty close. BUT - do not let this stop you from buying the book. Just practice with College Board tests instead of this book's.The good news:- the rest of the book. It's solid. I like the caution against learning tips and tricks and glossing over foundational skills. That's exactly what I've learned is important (and I learned the hard way).- great sections on planning your studying- the book is well-organized and color-coordinated, and therefore easy to read and use- it functions like a workbook broken up into lessons, many of which are insightful and usefulNow, this isn't my favorite SAT book. But it's a good choice if you can only buy one guide. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

Since 2008, I have been tutoring the SAT privately, mostly to high-achieving students, so I've read a lot of SAT prep material. Overall, this is a decent choice for a strategy book, but I wouldn't really recommend it if you have the budget to buy a few books.Advantages:- techniques are mostly useful and well-explained- the book's writing, overall, is easy-to-read and engaging- time management and test-taking strategies are helpfulDisadvantages:- the book claims it's a one-size-fits way to master the SAT. Though the book is a jack-of-all-trades, it's a master of none. In my opinion, there are better resources for each section of the test.- practice questions and tests are not accurate reflections of the real SAT both in terms of difficulty and question content/style. This is a really big deal. I strongly recommend you avoid using these questions; use the ones written by the College Board.- the book's focus on "cracking" and tricks at the expense of learning fundamental skills can steer students away from putting in the time to learn vocab, math, do extra reading, etc.For those students looking for a high percentile SAT score, I would look for more specialized books written by people focusing on just one area of the test. Books like these tend to be more rigorous, since the author doesn't have to cover everything. For math, try Pwn the SAT or the New SAT Math Game Plan; for verbal, try the books written by Erica Meltzer (for critical reading and grammar). I also like Pwn the SAT essay book. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

This review is from the perspective of someone who has been tutoring the SAT privately since 2008. Overall, if you can only buy one SAT strategy book, this is a decent, but not great, choice.Strengths:- the DVD provides another way for the book's mostly helpful techniques to get into your brain- question solving techniques are mostly good and well-explained- the book's writing, overall, is down-to-earth and readableWeakness:- the book poses as a one-size-fits all solution to SAT prep. This is an oversimplification, and though the book is a jack-of-all-trades, it's a master of none. In my opinion, there are superior resources for each part of the test.- practice questions and tests are not good reflections of the real SAT both in terms of difficulty and question content/style. This is a big deal. Do not use these questions; use the ones written by the College Board.- the book emphasizes "cracking" and tricks at the expense of learning fundamental skills, which can steer students away from putting in the time to learn vocab, math, do extra reading, etc.I would recommend this book only to people who can't afford to buy more than one SAT book. For those looking for a competitive SAT score, I would track down more specialized books written by people focusing on just one area of the test. For math, try Pwn the SAT or the New SAT Math Game Plan; for verbal, try the books written by Erica Meltzer. I also like the Pwn the SAT essay book. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I have been tutoring the GRE since 2008. I like this book, but I am only giving it 3 stars for one important reason: the verbal questions are less complex - and therefore easier - than real GRE questions. There are several nuances to the real GRE's verbal questions and problems that this book doesn't capture. To see what I mean, compare the GRE questions on ets.org/gre to the ones in this book.The trouble with practicing with verbal questions that are too simple is that you're not going to be used to dealing with the more complex, convoluted questions that the GRE likes to write. Oddly enough, the GRE doesn't go as crazy with hard vocab as it used to - but it does often write sentences that confuse many of my students even when the vocab is easy. The vocab in this book is hard, but there is a lot more to verbal questions than hard vocab.The reading comprehension questions are better, but obviously you should spend more time with real GRE reading comp questions.The math sections are good - the book goes topic by topic and provides practice questions that are realistic. Overall the strategies the book provides do work.If you buy this book, I would use the verbal questions sparingly as a warm-up, and then spend most of your time with real GRE verbal questions. But go nuts with the math - it will help. Ignore the essay prompts in this book - they are a waste of time - only because the GRE publishes all of its potential essay prompts on its website. If you spend time working on a prompt from this book, it's time you could be working on a real prompt (that actually could be on your real exam)!Those with high score goals, of course, will probably need more than this book can offer - but that's true of pretty much any test prep book.

I'm a full-time test-prep tutor, and I've studied at least 12 real ACT tests with students of mine. This book is a good overall guide to the ACT. However, students who want to be really high scorers (above 90th percentile) will need more. If I could give this 3.5 stars, I would.Helpful things:- solid global strategies for things like time management- most strategies for specific parts of the test work- it's user-friendly (what use is a book if students can't or won't read it?)- the book's test questions are a decent representation of the real testUnhelpful things:- there is oversimplification of certain concepts, which sometimes obscures the rigor needed for mastery- the book says the ACT "merely tests your ability to take the ACT". This is pandering to people who don't like standardized tests, AND it's a dangerous misconception. If you don't believe the ACT tests a whole range of foundational abilities in things like reading ability, critical reasoning, math, etc., then you're probably less inclined to work on those skills - and you should be.- the statement that "every other part of your application counts more than your test scores? More pandering - and again, if you believe that one, you might not work on the ACT as hard as you should.If you just buy one ACT book, this is a solid choice. Keep in mind, you also need the Real ACT Prep Guide (published by ACT), since it has real ACT tests, which differ significantly from The Princeton Review's tests. Together, these two books will give you a foundation that can then be built upon with more specific instruction. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I have been tutoring the ACT since 2008, and I've studied at least 12 real ACT tests with students of mine. I'm not usually a fan of corporate test prep, but this book is a good overall guide to the ACT. It is not, however, sufficient for people who want to be high scorers (above 90th percentile). I would probably give it 3.5 stars if possible (I'm rounding up; it's better than average).Things I liked:- DVD is helpful if you like to break up your reading with some video. Same concepts as the book.- good global strategies for things like time management- most of the strategies for specific parts of the test work- it's readable (what good is a book if students can't/won't read it?)- practice questions are a pretty good representation of the real testThings I didn't like:- there is some dumbing down and simplification of certain concepts, which sometimes obscures the rigor needed for mastery- the book claims the ACT "just tests your ability to take the ACT". This is not only pandering to people who don't like standardized tests, but it's a dangerous misconception. If you don't think the ACT tests a whole range of foundational skills in things like reading ability, critical thinking, math, etc., then you're probably less inclined to work on those skills - and you should.- the claim that "pretty much every other part of your college application counts more than your test scores? More pandering - and again, if you buy that, you might not work on the ACT as hard as you should.Overall, if you just buy one ACT book, this is a good choice. But you also need the Real ACT prep guide, since it has real ACT tests, which differ subtly but significantly from The Princeton Review's tests. In tandem, these two books will give you a solid foundation that can then be built upon with more comprehensive and specific instruction. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I write this review from the perspective of someone who tutors the GRE professionally and has done so since 2008. Overall, the book is good, but not great. It's a mix of helpful advice, oversimplified advice, and dangerous advice.Helpful stuff:- most of the DVD. Good tips for time management/test taking. Good, specific techniques for most question types. The presenter is clearly a real tutor and knows his stuff. Easy to watch and follow.- concepts and techniques are presented in plain, helpfully written English- most techniques are usable and effective- vocab is appropriately chosenAverage stuff (the theme here is oversimplification):- practice questions are generally representative of the real test (but sometimes too simple)- math review does a nice job of simplifying things (at the expense of sometimes oversimplifying)- techniques can be a little bit too basic and some need to be expounded upon to actually be usefulBad advice/things that are just wrong:- from the DVD: "the essay is by far the least important part of the test". Not true for MANY grad programs.- from the DVD: "the test is scored from 200-800" - not since 2011...- the book's title and assertion that the GRE "just assesses your ability to take the GRE". If you don't believe the test measures your vocab, math, writing, and reading comprehension skills, and that those fundamentals don't matter, and that you can just use this book to "Crack the GRE"... then you've just fallen for The Princeton Review's marketing. Unless you have average score aspirations, you will almost definitely need to do MORE than this book suggests.- the claim that you don't need to buy the ETS Official Guide. The ETS book has a ton of real GRE questions that are real, therefore worth your time.All in all, a pretty good book - just be aware of its shortcomings and it can be a useful tool in your GRE prep. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm a full-time GRE tutor, so I bought this to see if it was a resource I could recommend to my students, who often need to relearn a LOT of math. This book is a solid treatment of the math concepts the GRE tests, as well as a decent overview of the different kinds of questions on the test. But, those with higher than average score goals will need to supplement with other books (and of course everyone should be working with ETS's Official Guide).Things I liked:- covers most of the concepts that can appear on the GRE- each concept has a good number of practice exercises of varying difficulty- the 100 "most important" concepts list at the back is a good checklistThings that could be improved:- the questions are usually too easy - or more importantly, too SIMPLE - the questions on the GRE are usually more creative and complex, especially at the higher score levels- in my opinion, the time management advice only applies to the top 20 percent of scorers- the book seems to have been modeled on the math concepts that the GRE TELLS us the test covers, NOT on actual observation of GRE tests or practice tests. What the GRE says it will test and what it actually does test are sometimes two different things.So what you're getting is coverage of the concepts you'll need to know without getting the difficulty level or complexity of real GRE math questions. This book will help to a degree, but you'll definitely want to use another source of practice material as well. It's a pretty good resource for those who haven't done math in a long time. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

As an SAT tutor, I'm always looking for resources that my students can use WITHOUT me. For students who want competitive scores, meeting with me once or twice a week isn't enough time to learn all the different math concepts that can show up on the test (unless the student is willing to do a LOT of tutoring). These students need to be doing daily work in areas like math - the question is often finding them a resource that represents the real SAT in terms of the types and difficulty level of questions.This book is a great resource for those students who can already score around 600 in math and who want a score of 700+. It's broken down into 28 techniques, concepts, and lessons that can be considered to be tools in a student's SAT toolbox. The author makes the point that the more tools you have, the more likely it is you'll find a way to solve the problem in front of you. Each concept has several practice questions that range from easy to very hard.Mr. Warner does a nice job of covering the tricky concepts the SAT is likely to present and seems to be basing the book on observation of many real SAT tests. One of the strengths of the book is that multiple ways of solving the same problem are often provided. Another strength is that there are some great calculator tips - many of which I haven't used before. I also liked the way the book is laid out graphically - the different colors and diagrams make it easier to follow without losing focus.Overall, for the student with the discipline to work through it, this book will absolutely raise his or her SAT math score.

I tutor the GRE professionally and I have taken the Revised GRE. I've also written a couple of GRE books, one of which (Barron's 6 GRE Practice Tests) could be considered to be a competitor to this one - so you might want to take this review with a grain of salt. However, this is really not a good GRE math book. I was hoping it would be a more GRE-targeted edition of the fantastic CliffsNotes Math Review for Standardized Tests - which I gave 5 stars to and have been recommending to my GRE students for years.The main trouble with this book is that the questions are way off the style, difficulty level, and even the content that the GRE covers. The book does cover most of the math topic areas that the GRE covers, but I don't think the authors used the real practice tests at all. The resulting practice questions do test the math topics the GRE tests, but in much different ways - usually MUCH easier ways. For example, one of the practice test questions just tests your ability to get the square root of 119. Uh - there is a calculator with a square root button on the GRE now - the real GRE would never write a question like that. The real GRE also doesn't test your ability to use the quadratic equation or calculate standard deviation or variance - but this book makes it seem like it does.I challenge anyone to check out a real GRE practice test and compare the math questions to the practice questions in this book - the differences should be obvious even to the novice.There is also some bad advice about taking the test: "never spend more than 1.5 minutes on a math problem". That MIGHT be good advice for top scorers, but for most people - who shouldn't be trying to work on every question - it's problematic since it will spread them too thinly. Even if you're above average, you don't want to spend time working on all the problems in a math section - you should probably make a couple of sacrifices for the greater good.This book does cover a lot of the math the test covers and for that I give it two stars. But there are many better options on the market if you want a book that just helps with GRE math. Cliffs Notes - I hope the next version of this book will be better.

I'm a full-time tutor of the SAT and other standardized tests. Compared to the majority of SAT prep books, The Critical Reader is outstanding in the breadth and depth of its treatment of its subject - the Critical Reading section of the SAT. I was consistently impressed while reading it. Even though I've helped students prepare for the SAT for over six years, I've picked up several useful teaching tools from the book and will both recommend it and use it as a reference.What I liked:- the extremely comprehensive breakdown of all question types- the focus on underlying skills as well as techniques- the well-written practice questions- the overall level of care and insightWhat I didn't like:- the book's layout, fonts, and design could be more user-friendly/readableOverall, this is an admirable work, and it's in a different class than other books on the subject. It's a valuable tool for motivated students and for nearly any SAT tutor. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

As a full-time tutor, I've observed that there is a world of difference between students who merely do well and those who strive to be at or near the top of their class. High-achievers have a MUCH easier time getting into competitive colleges - not because they're necessarily smarter, but because their applications can't help but show their desire and drive to do noteworthy things. This book is for those high-achievers and for any motivated student who genuinely aspires to do better in school - whether it's high school or college.Weisman, clearly speaking from successful experience, outlines numerous ways to get motivated, get organized, and to achieve. Students will find it easy to relate to her conversational, friendly advice. Even if they just flip through the book, they'll find lots of practical tips and techniques that they can put into immediate use. This is great, because no one tells students how to do this stuff. High schools certainly don't offer much in the way of study skills or organizational advice. Students either find a way that works - or they don't. This book is a nice way to save most students a lot of time.I might like this book better if it were two books - one for high school, and one for college - but most of the advice overlaps. With that said, it's a great find and should be helpful to those who take the time to peruse it.

I've been tutoring the GRE since 2008, and I've written two preparation books for it (Barron's 6 GRE Practice Tests, and GRE Vocab Capacity). So I'm very familiar with the test (maybe a little too familiar). This version of the ETS Official Guide to the Revised GRE is exactly the same as the old version except for a couple of important things:1. There's a new paper practice test. This is great, since it brings the number of authentic GRE practice tests available to four. The practice tests on the CD are the same ones you can download from the GRE website for free.2. Sample responses to the 2nd paper test's essays are included with grader commentary. This is useful since you can see what the real graders liked and what they didn't.Things I like about this book:1. The AWA (analytical writing assessment) chapter is well-written. Not only does it clearly explain how to score well, but it includes real sample essays (and there are more sample essays + commentary at the end of each paper test).2. The book and CD have real GRE questions and tests (obviously). Using real questions is much more valuable that using those written by a third party because they are always more realistic and therefore are MUCH better preparation for the real GRE you're going to take. The computer tests are exactly like the real GRE I took.3. The book covers all question types and *most* but not all of the math concepts.Things I don't like:1. The question explanations are often inaccessible to the average student, too technical/highfalutin, or too presumptive that the student understands certain concepts. I realize that the book can't explain everything, but more question explanations could be written in layman's terms. Similarly, the math review goes into too much detail about certain concepts and skimps or even leaves out others. There is a dearth of math technique to make problems easier.2. The strategies in the book are not very insightful. Any good tutor or test-prep book can offer more helpful strategies than this book - but I guess we shouldn't expect ETS to give us the best tips on its own test - just like we shouldn't expect the IRS to tell us how to save the most money on our taxes.Overall, this book is essential to prepare for the new GRE, and your time spent with it will pay off. Even if you think you're very good at math, verbal, and/or writing, mastering the GRE demands getting used to its format, quirks, and nuances. Do not let third-party material (Kaplan, Magoosh, etc.) give you a false sense of confidence!  ***Update: you should definitely also buy the additional verbal and quantitative practice books that ETS is now publishing. Real questions are worth their weight in gold.***If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm a full-time SAT tutor, and in my experience, students approaching SAT math for the first time often try to apply the same math techniques they would in an algebra or geometry class. This isn't always a bad thing, but sometimes, SAT math problems are more easily solved when different, test-specific strategies are used.This book discusses 32 math strategies that work for SAT-style math problems, and includes sample problems on which the strategies may be applied. I really liked the description of most of the strategies, and think that any student who seriously works with this book will improve her math ability. Additionally, the author has a lot of insights about the test that I'm sure come from working with many students over the years.The only thing I would change about the book is its breadth - some of the strategies are a bit esoteric, and may only be useful once in a great while - such as certain geometry strategies. The average student may be a bit overwhelmed - but top math students may appreciate that the book covers so much. I would rather see the book spend more time on the most common strategies and less on the seldom-used ones.Overall, this book is a great resource, and I strongly recommend it for students who are ready to spend the time and effort to improve their mathematical confidence and ability.

As an SAT tutor, I'm always thinking about ways to teach students math. So I really enjoy when a book teaches me something new.I really liked the author's advice about two things in particular, and I'm going to steal his advice and use it with my own students:1. Do a little bit of math work every day. Such a great point - students will learn much more if they study a little bit at a time vs. spending a lot of time once or twice a week.2. Redoing incorrect problems with a DIFFERENT method. I like this point because students gain confidence from having multiple ways to solve problems - plus, if the first way of solving it produced an error, it may be a sign that the method initially used is not the most appropriate method.Aside from those points, I liked that the book breaks down problems into difficulty level and provides clear explanations of the problems. The only thing I didn't like was that I sometimes didn't think the problems were realistic representations of SAT problems. I would also like to see the author point the student to problems in the College Board's Official SAT Study Guide that were similar. But overall, these are minor quibbles, and the student who uses this book will no doubt greatly improve his SAT math ability.

I am a full-time test-prep tutor, and have found that most of my students only have a rudimentary grasp of the many of the grammar rules that the SAT tests. Though many of these students are excellent readers and writers, no one has ever taught them the fundamentals of grammar or explained the building blocks of sentences. Meltzer's book is a fantastic resource since it thoroughly covers all the grammatical concepts an SAT test taker needs to know. Things I liked:1. All error types are explained. Unlike many other SAT books, which gloss over or skip certain errors, this book covers everything with the insight that only comes from long-term scrutiny of actual SAT tests.2. Blue Book (College Board Official SAT Study Guide) questions are categorized. This is important, since students need to be able to recognize the errors in actual SAT questions and can use this book as an index to look up and practice troublesome error types.Things that I think could be improved:1. The book often is dry and utilitarian. It's hard to make grammar interesting, but all but the smartest and most motivated students may find this book difficult to read and use, even though some of the writing is down-to-earth and funny. I think changing the layout, graphics, and look of the book might help.2. Most of the practice questions and exercises do not have answer choices. It would be great if the author had written SAT-style answer choices to go along with the exercises. Of course, students should spend more time with blue book questions than with the questions in this book.Overall, this book is the best of its kind, and is a great resource for SAT tutors and for motivated students.

I'm a full-time test-prep tutor. A lot of very smart students come into my office who are acing their current math classes but who are rusty on one or more of the mathematical concepts that the SAT covers. These students also need to learn math techniques that work for the SAT, like estimating, backsolving, and plugging in numbers. Though there are other books that do parts of what Pwn the SAT does, it stands out because it's the complete package. Here are five things I really liked about it:1. It's tailored to smarter kids. The book gets right to the point and doesn't spend time covering the basics of arithmetic, algebra, and geometry that most smart kids know, opting instead to dive into the trickier concepts that many kids have trouble with. It doesn't try to cover every single possible concept (which is good because that can be mind-numbing for students).2. Each concept review is followed by several practice questions, and question explanations are very good (I like the handwritten ones a lot).3. The math techniques are well-described and the use of them is encouraged (I would have liked to see "being nimble" and "guesstimating" described as techniques and moved to that section.)4. It assigns categories to all of the College Board SAT Blue Book questions.5. It's pretty funny (and the down-to-earth language is a refreshing change from most test-prep books' serious tone).I think the practice questions, overall, are too hard/somewhat unrealistic and that students should spend much more time with the actual blue book questions than with the questions in this book. But then again, no test-prep author can perfectly imitate SAT questions and this book's questions are a good supplement to the blue book for those who want more practice.Overall, this is a great resource for students with a lot of motivation and intelligence - highly recommended for students who are self-studying.

I'm a full-time test-prep tutor and admissions consultant. In my view, Mr. Carpenter has done a wonderful job in doing what he says he set out to do: creating a concise, useful guide to college admissions for smart kids and their parents. It's particularly helpful for the kids.The book won me over pretty quickly with its insight into several different types of smart kids and their individual strengths and weaknesses in terms of admissions. And I think this book is better than any other I've ever read when it comes to telling kids how to figure out their unique talents and attributes. I love that it essentially tells kids to embrace who they are. One of the things I respect most about the book is that it is not afraid to state what everyone knows but few have the courage to say - some kids are smarter than others - and that the book is for those smart kids.I don't think this book is as perfect as some of the reviews seem to imply. I think the advice on essay writing and interviews is good, for instance, but I think in these areas, Carpenter gives students - even geeks - a little too much credit to be able to figure out everything on their own. For essays, I wish he'd included some common pitfalls (writing about cliched subjects), and for interviews, I wish he'd explicitly emphasized that students should practice mock interviews and maybe that he'd provided some sample questions. For geeks in particular (and I know, since I was/still am one), it is not easy to just "be yourself" and be candid during an interview if you're not used to thinking on your feet. The campus visiting advice is missing something I think is crucial - visit when the students are there, not during the summer. It also doesn't seem to emphasize how important it is to visit schools early and often. I hope Carpenter adds more content regarding the above in future additions of the book, since he covers the topics he does treat with kindness, wisdom, and authority.In spite of these minor omissions, this book's insights and merits absolutely make it a worthwhile purchase for parents of any smart kid. Carpenter really gets it, and I think his advice will really make a difference in many kids' lives.

If a tree falls in the woods and no one is around to hear it, does it make a sound?
