Likewise, what good is a book on grammar, usage, and style tips if most people do not, cannot, or will not read it due to its impenetrability?Grammar Girl's book is useful because she avoids the over-technicalities that so many grammar and usage instructors use. When she does need to be technical, she lets the reader know (and often apologizes or adds some humor). The result is a readable, friendly, useful guide to better writing. This book is not a panacea, but it would, in my view, be a helpful tool for almost anyone.P.S. I'm a full-time test-prep tutor and many of the tips within this book will come in handy for SAT, ACT, GRE, GMAT, and ISEE students (though it's not as comprehensive as these tests require).

I'm a full-time test-prep tutor and have been for the past several years. As such, I'm familiar with the past few editions of the Official SAT Study Guide. The version of this book WITHOUT the DVD is essential, as it's the best source of real, College-Board-authored SAT tests.The only real difference between this version and the non-DVD version is - you guessed it - the DVD. (Ok, there's also a snazzy new cover.) Is the DVD worth the extra cost? Probably not:1. The DVD does have a new practice test, but between the book and the tests the College Board offers online, you'll have about 13 real SATs, which is plenty for the vast majority of students. If you really want one more test, getting the DVD may be worth it.2. The SAT test timer can be duplicated with any electronic timer.3. The math concepts video only explains a few questions.4. The SAT Skills Insight Video and Additional Tools are more marketing than anything.Keep in mind, any information that ETS provides to help you solve SAT questions is not going to be very insightful - after all, the maker of the test is not the source to turn to if you're looking for tips and tricks. All in all, this version looks a lot more like an attempt to make more money for ETS than to provide new, helpful material. I'm pretty sure ETS is banking (pun intended) on buyers' tendency to get the most recent version of any test-prep book. I hope this review gives you some information to help with that decision for this book.If ETS had offered a few new tests on the DVD, it would have been worth the extra money.If you're looking for SAT help or have a question about the test, just lemme know!

I'm a full-time test-prep tutor. Many of my students, particularly my GRE and GMAT students, haven't taken a math class in years. They might have been strong math students at one point in their lives, but if they haven't used the "math lobe" of their brains (if there is such a thing) for that long, their math abilities have usually atrophied.I view math skill for standardized tests as a foundation - if a student has a strong foundation without any holes in it, they'll more readily learn how to handle some of the trickier questions that standardized tests can present. But if there are holes in their math foundation - a missing triangle formula here, a forgotten exponent rule there - then those deficiencies will come back to haunt them in the midst of a multi-step problem.That's where this book is so useful. If you do all the practice problems, you'll cover the great majority of concepts that tests like the SAT and GRE will test. Doing the problems is essential - they will give you enough repetition to learn (just staring at a page of formulas isn't that helpful). By the time you're done, you'll have a strong basis for learning the nuances of the test you'll take. This book even has helpful sections for the Data Sufficiency problems on the GMAT and the Quantitative Comparison questions on the Revised GRE.For math review, I'd recommend the exercises at KhanAcademy.org if you're more of a computer learner, but the advantage of this book is that it's easier to find the concepts on which you want to work. And it's only about nine bucks. Highly recommended. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

I'm a full-time test-prep tutor, so part of what I do is help students work on SAT subject tests. I agree with the reviewer who complained that this book hasn't been updated enough. The student who really wants a competitive SAT 2 test score will ultimately be disappointed in this book, since there is only one of each test. If the College Board had deigned to include new versions of all the tests with the new version of this book, at least students could supplement this book with the old version and have 2 tests for each subject.Serious students will have to supplement this book with practice tests written by a third party, which is unfortunate since those tests will not be highly accurate representations of the real thing.I wouldn't recommend buying this new - find a cheaper, older version or a used one (just be careful that it isn't marked up).

Although this book was published in the late 1980s, 95% of its information is still relevant. It provides a concise, accessible overview of the college admissions process in language that most students and parents will readily understand. The book's friendly tone and insightful observations about human nature make it a comforting resource for worried applicants.If you want your kid to actually read a book about college admissions, track this one down. I don't think there is a current equivalent published by the Princeton Review.

As a full-time test prep tutor, I know that students who take several real practice tests do better than those who don't. Unfortunately, the previous edition of this book only included three tests - so I was happy to see this edition includes five. Take all five of these tests, and you'll be familiar with what the ACT will throw at you on test day. However, don't expect the ACT to give you insightful advice about its own test in the answer explanations - those explanations are usually convoluted and technical.I highly recommend you buy this book instead of books written by test-prep companies like The Princeton Review, Kaplan, and the like. Those companies have neither the resources nor the motivation to make their practice tests highly accurate representations of the real ACT. Most students and parents, unfortunately, are not familiar enough with the real ACT to realize this until test day. If you'd like more prep recommendations, click on my name and you'll see a link to my website.

You want the truth about college admissions? Are you sure? Hint: it's not the pretty picture painted by those glossy college brochures that are coming in the mail.What colleges SAY they do and what they ACTUALLY do are two different things. From the point-of-view of an experienced college counselor, Allen explains why colleges admit certain students and why they deny others. It's difficult to believe that he is anything but an expert on his subject as he outlines all the steps of the college admissions process, from financial aid to early decision to test-prep.Chances are, your college counselor doesn't have the time, inclination, or ability to give you this type of advice.Required reading for any student seeking admission to any competitive private school, college, or graduate program.

These are great!  I first found them in a 7-11 but they don't seem to have them anymore (at least in the one near me).  There seem to be two companies and two sizes but the products seem about the same to me.  They make a great snack or even a side veggie for a meal--esp. if you're as lazy as I can be!  They're not overly salted, but tasty.  Kind of mild tasting, but with enough flavor to make them worth a chew or two.  I've eaten them many times now and they're pretty darn consistent in texture and flavor.  They're baked, not fried.  There are also ones that are flavored--which is quite nice.  Also you can by similar lentil crisps--I found them on Amazon--haven't seen them anywhere else.  They're much tastier.

Guess I twisted the original in my new house too hard because I completely broke off the knob. Searched for a fix or a replacement and fortunately, Amazon had this kit.  Yes, it's not cheap, but it comes with several alternatives so it can fit on a lot of different switches--and one worked great for me.  Also, it's metal--more durable, although the posts are plastic.  Still, I plan to be gentler with the switch from now on.

My macrobiotic chef friend Juliette introduced me to Quinoa--very useful for someone allergic to gluten.  It's tasty and usually easier to make than rice, and probably lots better than white rice for your body.  Having enjoyed the regular, white quinoa, I tried this one.  It's harder to make as you have to rinse the kernels several times before cooking it and then add the quinoa to boiling water.  Since the kernels are small, you need a strainer (not a colander) to strain them.  More to clean up and they stick to the strainer.  As a retiree, I'm interested in tasty, but easy to prepare meals.  It's maybe not that big a deal, but I don't find the red variety any tastier than the regular, the package is smaller, it's more expensive, and it's more annoying to prepare.  So, I'll stick with my TruRoots 4 lb. bag in the future.

I bought this specifically to use at Thrasher's Fries because they only serve their high quality/tasty fries with (groan!) malt vinegar.  I don't care much for vinegar (except for balsamic on a salad), so I find that combination rather horrid--but everyone to their own taste.  Also, in Rehoboth Beach (where there are 3 Thrasher's stands) there isn't a handy burger stand (like in Ocean City, MD where there's another Thrasher's) to get your ketchup (and a burger) at.  Anyway, these small packets (just like you get at many burger places/fast food places with takeout) work great!  I just leave a bag of them in my car -- and if I want the fries, I take the bag along and I can have my fries and eat them (with ketchup) too!!!

My shipment arrived quickly and was perfect.  The soy milk is among the best I've tasted--lots better than most of them (which are often too watery or thin for my taste, kind of like skim milk).  This one is much like regular milk in consistency, color, and flavor.  I am allergic to both dairy and gluten so I have this for breakfast with corn flakes and fruit.  Works great!  I don't tire of it.  I drink my coffee (and tea) black, so I can't speak to how it works with coffee or tea (if you take it British style with milk), but I expect it would work well.

Along with their Tomato Basil, this is my favorite pasta sauce.  It's tasty, organic, has a bit of fiber, some vitamin A & C, not much fat, a bit of protein, but also some sugar and quite a bit of salt (1/2 gram/113 gram serving=1/6 of a jar).  Tastes differ, but many pasta sauces seem rather bland to me--but not this one.  Still, I like it hot so I add some hot sauce etc. to it.  Enjoy!

This is what I call an "A" level performance--which means: I hear it once and buy it.  It's the only song I bought from this year's Voice competition.  Meghan has a great voice, and this rendition seems to me to go back to her Country roots.  It's rich and pithy and emotional.  IMHO, if The Voice (once voting is by the public and not the judges) didn't become an image/personality/preference contest, Meghan would have won.  I hope she does well in her career.

It works okay with my Android phone--like having a speaker phone, but doesn't work at all with my old iPod--which is why I bought it in the first place.  I also bought a handset at the same time from Amazon--interestingly, it will play with either my phone or my iPod.

While I'm not a big fan of rap (so I didn't particularly enjoy the lead-in portion of this recording) but the actual song is great--especially the refrain.  Of course the lyrics don't say much and the song is based on an old joke about lawyers or politicians (How do you know a _________ is lying?  Their lips are moving).  The refrain goes on and on in your head--kind of a happy note despite the kind of negative direction of the lyrics--saying goodbye to a guy who is lying to her since she smells another woman's fragrance on his shirt.  I like it: I bought it.  Dollar Votes count!

I was visiting my friend Chris in Phoenix when she introduced me to these towels.  I used them to clean my eyeglasses.  They're as clsoe to cloth as they are to normal paper towels.  They do the job regular paper towels do--and, perhaps, better.  But, they have two special features that put them above the rest--they're softer (yet retaining strength and absorption) and they are perforated to make smaller pieces.  This is very useful for small jobs (cleaning glasses for instance) and saves a lot of waste.  Finally, the price seems quite reasonable to me.

I've tried a few different items for this problem, but this one definitely works the best.  You get 3 small tubes of it and it goes a long way, at least for me.  It reduces the size, itching, pain all at once--leaving a cooling feeling.  It comes with conical applicators for each tube, but I just use a finger to apply as it's rather like a thick paste and needs to be rubbed over the affected area.

I usually decline to review an item if there are already many reviews but I will if there seems to be something I can add that hasn't been addressed previously; similarly, I don't reiterate the plot.  This book in Muller's long-evolving series on Sharon McCone is a multi-perspective one in which several characters report from their own perspectives and observations.  This is especially appropriate in this book because Muller is evaluating/commenting on a relative's responsibility to someone who's has simultaneous drug and mental problems.  Even though Darcy is only a half-brother, Sharon pursues him and his kidnappers with dogged determination--though she's unsure of her own degree of responsibility.  It is important to note that Darcy has been in and out of both drug and mental therapy to no avail.  The question is: when/where does the family responsibility end and co-dependence begin?  This is a tricky question and, unfortunately, Muller doesn't really provide an answer, but her travail in addressing this sticky issue is IMHO informative and understandable.  This is not (as extremists might imply) a black and white situation.  In fact, in Nature/Life there are virtually NO such situations!  There are, however, spectra and Normal Distributions which fit virtually everything in Nature (you can, however, create dichotomies artificially -- e.g. computer binary).As for the characters, Darcy isn't likable--of course, and his character is hardly going to "develop" in this book.  There are some potential developments in the relationship between Sharon and Hy regarding a possible merger as well as the relocation of Sharon's agency.  But the main character development IMHO is with Mick.  He's at the computer but wants to go into the field.  This reminds me of Gordon Ramsay's visits in "Kitchen Nightmares" where people have acquired a restaurant with no knowledge of what they were getting into.  Mick finds out the hard way (as do these foolish restaurateurs) what the real world is like.  This may actually save his relationship with Allison (if you plays his cards right and stays at the computer).There's also a pseudo character development in Gaby.  Though she's dead from the start of the novel, your opinion of her changes as people reveal more and more of her life and personality--kind of back and forth too as she's filled in.There's also a very fine set of scenes with Lisa and Molly worth a laugh and a half.  They're a riot.  Unfortunately, I didn't take any quotations from this book.  Overall, it was IMHO a worthy addition to the series though certainly not one of its best.

This book includes 6 different reports on mystery stories for 2003 including award winners etc. plus the 32 mystery or crime stories.  It covers a spectrum of sub-genres so there will probably be several provided for the ones a particular reader likes.  As with most such collections, I find there are ones that I found to rate 5 stars, but others that left me cold.  I can usually find a number of quotations for my collection:p. 103: Mat Coward "Offenders"--All the social graces of a thunderstorm.p. 196: Robert S. Levinson "Take my Word for It and You Don't Have to Answer"--[He] knew how to get to the bottom of a gin bottle five minutes before the cap was unscrewed.p. 349: Joyce Carol "The Hunter"--Women are forgiving of weakness if it is a bridge to their strength.p. 352: Peter Robinson "The Cherub Affair"--I understood the woman's pride was such, she had convinced herself she was without pride.One of the special values to this collection are the small abstracts the editors have provided preceding each story.  I find them helpful in that they usually delineate other works by the author--so, if I like the story, I can read more by the same author--esp. those that have been specifically recognized/recommended (such as those receiving prestigious awards).  While this volume was published a decade ago, its stories are not dated, so it's quite a good buy today.  It's like buying a new car after "next year's" models have come out.

THE GOOD--AMS writes very well indeed; his books are consistently well-written IMHO.  Secondly, he uses the books as vehicles to transmit pithy observations and rational conclusions about people and life.  This book is no exception and, IMHO, this raises his works above many other talented authors'.  Thus, he provides much insight and also contributes to my collection of quotations.  For example (from the hardback edition):p. 3: Every love has within it the echoes of past loves.p. 185: Inequality is written into the way the world works...Fate has her own rules of equality.p. 186: 'They were so nasty, weren't they?--The Greek gods.'  'Horrible.  Full of mean tricks and petty jealousies..'pp. 187-8: Young men these days have been encouraged into narcissism...you end up with a lot of self-obsessed young men.p. 212: If weaning from dependence succeeds, it often does so intermittently, and there will be periods of back-sliding, of weakness, when the temptation to do the thing that you know you should not do is just too strong.p. 236: If you're too worried about being kind to people, you end up saying nothing about anything.p. 266: We don't like to hear about ourselves...The truth can be a little creepy, I think.p. 315: We imagine that people know what we're thinking, and they don't.  We misunderstand one another.His works often have considerable humor, though this one seems to have quite a bit less than usual.  Nevertheless: p. 195: Half-price drinks...Full-price hangover.THE BAD--AMS' series' (e.g. 1st Ladies Detective Agency, 44 Scotland St., etc.) usually have at least one major character who is likable, sympathetic, admirable, such as Mma Ramotswe and Bertie Pollock.  Even his series in which the main character is rather silly (e.g. Portuguese Irregular Verbs etc.) one has sympathy for him.  But the two main characters herein don't get much sympathy from me--they're too pathetically passive.  This book consists of two stories, one of mother Amanda, and the other of her daughter Clover.  But its emphasis seems to be on their irrational emotions rather than characterization or character development.  During the 9 or 10 years of the story, Clover doesn't seem to age psychologically beyond the age of 13.  Amanda doesn't fare much better in the book either though I wonder if she's the shape of things to come for Clover.  Like Mother, Like Daughter?  Now, if you like Gothic Novels or Harlequin Romances, you might like this book, but as a man, I found it quite boring--like a bad TV sitcom.  Maybe it was written for teenagers?  But then it would be placed in the Young Adult section, not in Fiction.THE UGLY--AMS sometimes writes about really dumb people and this book's a case in point (I think his Philosopher books may be parodies and maybe this book is too).  How can anyone be as stupid as Amanda?  (with her obvious lies--so she really wanted to be caught for not doing anything?)  Oh, Clover can--with her obsessive fixation on James--who she's hardly seen for a decade but is still mad about--so as to stalk him from Cayman to Scotland to Australia to Singapore.  Guess she never heard that "insanity is doing the same thing again and again and expecting to get a different result."  And her decade-long angst goes on and on ad nauseum, ad infinitum!Yet all the characters are paper-thin to cardboard.  It's basically a helium-weight romance about a pair of idiots.  The only real character (though he has a bit part) is Ted.  He's the only one without unrealistic expectations--no wonder "love hurts" for the two main characters.  And the 4-leaf Clover ending (which I predicted halfway through the book) was as sappy as it was ridiculous and abrupt.  It seems to me that AMS had an idea for a novel, began writing, and ran out of steam.  He persevered redundantly through an entire book, but couldn't come up with the goods--and threw in an ending--perhaps in response to a publication deadline.  He might have deleted much of the repetition and replaced it with a better ending.  It would have been instructive to see whether Clover's teen fantasy could evolve into a real relationship, but I doubt it could have.  Happily Ever After only happens in fairy tales--but then this book closely resembles one.

As usual, AMS has added another well-written book to his repertoire,  This one's a sequel to "Corduroy Mansions" which was somewhat similar to his "44 Scotland Street" series except set in London vs. Edinburgh, Scotland.  However, this entry differs quite a bit from any of those prior works in that it is much lighter and much sillier.  I think AMS is attempting satire of espionage and counter-espionage, and for some readers, it's probably hilarious.  But to me, it was too silly.  The Green Man episode was also somewhat disappointing in its methodology and the Ginkgo one was so absurd--especially to someone who watches "Shark Tank" on TV.  The whole book, while enjoyable, was just too over-the-top for me to give it 5 stars.  But I can't give it 3 or less because of AMS' (as usual) delightful turns of phrase such as--p. 79: the cascade system [hand-me-downs; re-use]and very profound and insightful comments/observations (which I add to my quotes collection):pp. 62-3: She knew that this was quite simply wrong, but the beliefs instilled in childhood and youth are hard to dislodge, and Marcia had eventually stopped fighting the convictions that lay within her.p. 63: 'I know I'm pathetic,' she once said to a friend, 'I know I should be all independent and self-sufficient and so on.'p. 69: These pigeons had become dependent, they were the unintended casualties of her kindness.  William found himself wanting to warn her of the consequences of her misplaced generosity. [i.e. her co-dependence]p. 78: Bentham's view that the only things that should be prohibited are those things that harm others.p. 80: The parties of others--or those that one doesn't attend--are always so self-indulgent.  For most of us, the knowledge that somebody, somewhere, is enjoying himself more than we are is strangely disturbing.  A common human response is to disapprove, and to try to stop the enjoyment [narcissism]p. 86: There are some people who really need an on-off switch.  I can think of at least three.  Maybe even more.p. 153: Those most in need of help simply cannot see the need

As reputedly the first married couple to write mysteries together, Marcia Muller and Bill Pronzini have again collaborated on a sequel to "The Bughouse Affair."  Per the prior book, chapters are headed by one of the two PI partners--I presume each author wrote one of the sets -- for each of the two detectives, but not necessarily.  The characters are not all that similar to Pronzini's nameless detective or Muller's Sharon McCone, so don't expect these novels to reflect their other series.  This series in set in 1895 San Francisco and some effort was taken to add some of the colorful life of that time and place into this book.  There are actually two interrelated mysteries--basically each approached by one of the two detectives: Sabina Carpenter and John Quincannon.  They don't collaborate very much.  Also, there's a somewhat mysterious character calling himself Sherlock Holmes, but he only has a small part to play in this book (unfortunately).This is a light mystery--much more so than the main series of the two individual authors. Interestingly, the two authors have written novels before in which their main characters (McCone & nameless) were both involved: "Double" and "The Dangerous Hour" (though not involved proportionally).  They also collaborated on "Beyond the Grave."  Actually, Muller has authored two trilogies other than the McCone series: starring Elena Oliverez and Joanna Stark which differ considerably from her McCone books.  Indeed, "Beyond the Grave" is an Oliverez book--probably the first one they collaborated on.  They have also collaborated in editing a number of themed short story collections such as: "Chapter and Hearse," "Child's Play," "Kill or Cure," "She Won the West," "The Wickedest Show on Earth," and "Witches Brew."  I haven't read "The Lighthouse" yet so I don't know what form their collaboration took in that book.This particular book is a "fun mystery" IMHO, not a thriller.  I found it easy reading and quickly finished it.  It was enjoyable IMHO and pointed to future books in this series--especially regarding romantic interest.  There isn't much romance in this book but the tension between the two main characters is similar to the TV series "Moonlighting."  I liked the book, but I've enjoyed some of the authors' books far more.

This book consists of several parts:270 pages of personal experiences in the village of Auburn during WWII,12 pages on the people in the book,30 pages of Allingham's diary 1940-42,6 pages originally censored at publication6 pages of letters to Joyce Allingham16 pages of notes--listed by referenced page #, (notes are NOT referenced in the text) and7 pages of indexIf you're very detail oriented or you are interested in how it felt to experience WWII from an English village, this book's for you.  However, if you're not so interested, it can be quite trying if not completely boring.  There are some valuable observations though:: England was terribly unprepared for war even after Poland was invaded.  The people didn't realize this for quite some time--having much too much faith in Chamberlain and Parliament.  It makes one wonder if the West is far too sanguine about the rise of Islamists/Sharia in the 21st century.  Perhaps the most important thrust of the book is Allingham's analysis/feeling of the decision to fight/die for freedom/liberty or to accept domination from others inimical to your way of life.There are some notable quotations though:p. 22: The whole generation had to learn by trial and error [because of so many adults killed in WWI]p. 23: The present popular theory that it is a sin to be rich is due, I fancy, not only to the fundamental urge towards universal equality, but also to our passionate efforts at self-defense at that time when it was still a sin to be poor.  [jealousy]p. 89: The art of being governed is to do the necessary voluntarily and in one's own way before anyone starts shoving.p. 120: Nobody must ever be forced into doing good and must only be forcibly restrained from doing evil if he is actively harming somebody else.p. 177: Doubtless any well-armed parachutist could have killed all these dear gallant people.p. 181: Would you rather die, perhaps horribly, than be controlled by a force of which you do not approve?p. 184: I still accepted that mental and moral slavery was worse than death.p. 184: There is a way of living, entailing constant effort, which leads to growth, and another which leads to stagnation and then to rottenness, and finally to the death of one's power of every kind.  There is an up-pull and a down-pull, a building and a demolition, a fecundity and a sterility.  That is true.  That is a fact.p. 190: It is all very well to summon your courage one day, but to keep it sword-bright for a week, or a month, or a year, if no sign of danger materializes is quite another matter.p. 192: Never being able to do anything constructive is a monstrous sort of restriction.p' 270: Avoid all schemes which are based solely on a theory.p. 274: Work for the freedom which means life.  Pray for it, fight for it, die for it if you have to, live for it if you can.  It's worth it.p. 275: Only the really lovable is beloved for long.p. 316: So frightened of missing something that she misses everything.p. 353: note p. 189--L.D.V.s: Local Defense Volunteers, better known by Churchill's name 'the Home Guard.' Call for volunteers 14th May 1940.  250,000 men came forward within 24 hours.

This book seems to me like an updated cross between Chaucer and Dickens.  Like Chaucer's "Canterbury Tales" it's about travelers sharing stories on a trip.  Like Dickens (as well as AMS' "44 Scotland Street" series of books) it's broken up into small chapters with episodes concerning different characters interspersed.  However, unlike Scotland St., this book seemed a bit choppy to me--hard to hold my attention and keep the stories in mind.  Of course in Scotland St. the characters interrelate and influence each other due to their propinquity and relationships--this was not possible in this book.  Also, I felt rather let down by the endings of the stories--didn't seem fully resolved to me.  There were a couple of quotes I collected,p. 231: 'Nothings ever really black and white, is it,' he said.p. 240: 'Loving others is the good thing we do in our lives.'I don't usually review books that already have a lot of reviews, but I wish to counterbalance what may be the influence of the Halo Effect.  Yes, he's a terrific author (esp. of the Mma. Ramatswe and Scotland St. books IMHO) and his works are well written, but not all his works are of the same caliber IMHO.

This is a very well-written book explaining the basics of the American Legal System including constitutional, civil, and criminal law at a reasonably high level of abstraction.  Obviously, it is impossible for the author to explain all the details in a book of this size but he successfully describes the history of the development of both the theory and practice of law in the US--up to 2005--including numerous important legal cases, both federal and state.  For example: CONSTITUTIONAL THEORY:p. 28: Part of the constitutional scheme is that the federal government is a government of limited powers.  The branches may exercise only the authority that the people have delegated to them in the Constitution.  Therefore, any act that is contrary to the Constitution or beyond the powers enumerated in it is void.p. 32: How do we empower a government to do what we cannot do for ourselves, while making sure that it does not become so strong that it threatens our liberties?p. 32: The framers of the Constitution responded to the widespread perception that the government created under the Articles of Confederation was too weak.p. 89: But this is antidemocratic, isn't it?  In a sense it is.  That's what constitutional law is all about.  The will of a temporary majority, the sentiments of the moment, a vote in the legislature, cannot upset basic constitutional guarantees [but] can be shaped by the temperament of the times as to what rights are fundamental.CONSTITUTIONAL PRACTICE (IN LIGHT OF THEORY)p. 42:: The federal government is a government of enumerated powers, exercising only those powers specifically granted to it in the Constitution--though we have seen that that limitation is usually more theoretical than real, given the Supreme Court's acquiescence in the explosion of federal authority granted to it in the Constitution--though we have seen that that limitation is usually more theoretical than real, given the Supreme Court's acquiescence in the explosion of federal authority granted to it in the Constitution--though we have seen that that limitation is usually more theoretical than real, given the Supreme Court's acquiescence in the explosion of federal authority.And, some RESULTS of legal practices on society:p. 143: The increase in liability has contributed to a society in which people do not feel responsible for their own actions and all look for an excuse for their behavior and someone else to pay for the losses. In the 'sue-em' society, no one has to bear the consequences of his or her acts anymore.p. 309: Police, prosecutors, and criminal court judges see too much crime, so they tend to see crime everywhere.p. 329: the jury is the conscience of the community in the courtroom.  By bringing in the community's perspective, the jury may do something other than simply determine the facts and apply the law in a neutral way...As one court stated, the jury can act as a 'safety valve' for exceptional cases without being a 'wildcat or runaway institution.' (United States v. Thomas, 1996).It also includes some GENERIC QUOTATIONS for my collection:p. 74: Justice Louis Brandeis, who wrote in Whitney v. California (1927), 'fear breeds repression' but 'courage is the secret to liberty.'p. 191: As an old legal saying goes, 'Not even the Devil knows the mind of a man.'And provides some observations relevant to future legal developments:p. 322: As Justice Clark wrote in Mapp v. Ohio (1961), 'Nothing can destroy a government more quickly than its failure to observe its own law.'I'm not a law student, but I found this book quite fascinating and enjoyable to read.  It read quite fast for me--possibly due to the author's engrossing style.  Highly recommended for both those contemplating study of law and for those desiring to know more about the legal system in which they are necessarily encompassed.

I've used Tiger Balm many times in the past--both the red and the white types. But I'd never seen this large size before--it makes the balm more affordable -- and it works great too! Active ingredients are camphor and menthol (11% each). This is higher than almost any other balm of its type. It also includes mint oil (though not how much of it) which also acts against pain generally). I have some smaller containers I travel with, but I've found you can reload them from a larger container (such as this one) with your finger tip. When I was in American Samoa I had a painful muscle in my face--oral analgesics (Naprosyn and Ibuprofen) didn't do the trick. But the Tiger Balm worked.

I've used this product many times before--it's great as a body rub and has a pleasant aroma, but I've always purchased a bunch of 8 oz bottles.  Now I've found that Amazon sells this half gallon size--so I can save a bunch of money and still have the same great product.  I only wish they had a version with a significant amount of mint oil--it would really help with painful muscles.  Now I use this oil first, then rub in a little mint oil if my muscles hurt.  If you use this procedure, it usually works the entire day.

You need to pull out a piece of plastic which covers the batteries before it will work.  BE CAREFUL doing this because, unlike most, it has two different batteries--one for the time and one for the back light.  I pulled out the plastic--but not carefully enough and left part of it inside--so the watch worked, but not the back light.  I had to take off the back and remove the other part of the plastic--and then the back light worked.  Getting the back back on was also a bit of a problem.  Otherwise, the watch works great.  I really like the back light esp. when traveling.  If I awaken in an unfamiliar hotel room, I can see what time it is--esp. useful if I need to get up early.

I've used Tiger Balm many times in the past--both the red and the white types.  But I'd never seen this large size before--it makes the balm more affordable -- and it works great too!  Active ingredients are camphor and menthol (11% each).  This is higher than almost any other balm of its type.  It also includes mint oil (though not how much of it) which also acts against pain generally).  I have some smaller containers I travel with, but I've found you can reload them from a larger container (such as this one) with your finger tip.  When I was in American Samoa I had a painful muscle in my face--oral analgesics (Naprosyn and Ibuprofen) didn't do the trick.  But the Tiger Balm worked.

Love this song--which is kind of like 2 related songs in one.  It addresses what it's like to be on your own in life.  I esp. like the refrain: "Don't go crying to your mama, 'cause you're on your own in the real world."  This should be the mantra today rather than dependency which seems to be a contemporary political current.  I bet Carl G. Jung would have greatly approved of it--as opposed to infantile grandiosity and the Peter Pan Syndrome.Not only are the lyrics pithy and valuable, but the melody and rhythm are catchy and engaging.  I like playing it and enjoyed watching and listening to Jena Irene sing it with Paramore on American Idol.  I very much enjoyed watching lead singer Hayley Williams dance while singing--she has great moves IMHO.  After I got this song, I listened to other Paramore songs and purchased "Still Into You" as well.

This is basically an overview book--as well as an introductory one.  I think it's worth 4.5 stars in that it's so well-written and easy to understand.  It covers a lot of territory (or space if you don't mind the pun) so it obviously cannot go into too much depth.  The author attempts to convey the latest (as of publication date) scientific evidence and opinion as to the nature of various cosmic features.  I like that she is unapologetic about the limitations of our present knowledge while emphasizing international attempts or projects to extend that knowledge.  There are a few probably typographical or printing errors--notably on p. 138 where we sum to a total of 104% and on p. 198 where Einstein apparently received a degree (stated to be in 1905) while his birth date is given as 1914.  Obviously, he was precocious to the max--getting his degree not only before either his birth or conception.  Overall, I enjoyed reading this book very much--and learned quite a bit from it--but it's not at a College level--even for an introductory course.  Nevertheless, the author's definitions of astronomical phenomena are very helpful--as is having an index.  The chapters are short and concise.  I especially found the discussion of dark matter (though very limited by present knowledge of it) quite intriguing.  Enjoy!

A woman hires someone to kill her then changes her mind (after a significant occurrence) and gets a NYC police detective to try and protect her.  The idea may have been original in 1967, but the mystery is a bit thin--more of a thriller than a regular mystery.  The dialog and mores are very dated IMHO, but they do provide some insight into yesteryear.  The book is short and a very fast read.  The ending is rather predicable--a movie style ending.  Fast's mysteries are quite different from his science fiction works.  I did, however, get some quotes from the book:p. 34: Stupidity is not a thing to be doubted.  The whole human race suffers from the particular disease.  It is epidemic and in season always.p. 47: [New York] A city of people who have never given a second thought to being nice.  Oh, they can be a lot of other things, but nice--no, I don't think so.p. 74: Ninety-nine and maybe nine-tenths per cent of everything that goes around as fact is a lie.  You've got to look for the one-tenth of one per cent, and most people, I guess in their whole lives, they never find it.

A farmer checks out his aging apple cider and the barn holding it blows up in his face.  After the fire's put out, a body is found in the wreckage--but who dunnit?  This is an interesting mystery by a member of the British Detectives Club (a contributor to "The Floating Admiral").  The best aspect IMHO is the juxtaposition of researches by a team of policemen vs. that of a contributing, civilian criminologist--who, of course, solves the intricate mystery.  Much of the mystery can be ascertained by the reader, but the process is worthwhile.  I guessed the culprit pretty early on, but proving it was another matter.  The book is well written in a simple, straightforward style.  It was an enjoyable, relatively quick read.  There were a number of quotes for my collection (from the scientific approach of the criminologist to the policemen):p. 47: Everybody, once they have suggested an explanation of any event, or series of events, has a tendency to interpret any subsequent discoveries they may make in light of that explanation.p. 101: The fatal mistake is to try to twist facts to suit this theory.  Form a dozen theories if you like, but never lose sight of the fact that all of them are merely tentative, and must be modified in accordance with each fresh fact as it is ascertained.p. 122: There were some people who preferred hunting in dark corners to looking at facts written on the wall in front of their eyes.p. 229: You are a victim of the elementary error of confusing ascertained fact with unconfirmed statement.

This was perhaps Jena's crowning achievement on American Idol and IMHO showed that she was not only a talented singer but a creative artist.  It's a challenge for the contestants to sing covers yet show some uniqueness.  She certainly did that here--I've heard the original but didn't purchase it.  I don't think it was done anywhere near as well as Jena did it--whether one likes the slowed down version or not, her voice quality was far better than Radiohead's.  Unfortunately, at the end of the competition, American Idol (as in most viewer voted game shows) becomes more a contest between/among the voters rather than between/among the performers.  IMHO Jena outshined all the other contestants due to her creative style, uniqueness, and voice quality--though Caleb shined in stage presence.  A lot depends on the weights a voter has on the various aspects of performances--and how easily/early voters commit to a particular performer--ignoring later differences at times.  I only bought one song this season of American Idol, and this is the song.

I enjoyed this unusual book--with chapters written consecutively by members of the British Detection Club.  While the styles, of course, differ from chapter to chapter, the authors do provide considerable continuity as well as some twists and turns for the later writers to address.  An appendix provides the authors' explanations of the crime/activities.  I made the mistake of reading them as I went along--i.e. after reading a chapter of the book, I'd read that author's explanation.  I suggest you don't do this as it tends to spoil the continuity and somewhat prejudice your point of view through later chapters.  The appendix is quite interesting--esp. seeing that several authors came up with the same/similar ideas.  However, the final author, Anthony Berkeley, while successfully pulling together the many loose ends (clever, no doubt) deviated significantly from the prior authors--though he probably didn't see what they had written till he'd written his.  I admire his completeness, but I liked the earlier authors' ideas better than his.  So I ended up a bit disappointed at the end.  Still, it's my fault for reading the Appendix early (which I generally do with books to establish the context).  That said, I found the book an excellent experiment by the Club and good reading overall.

GENERAL COMMENTS ON SERIESDutch diplomat and sinologist Robert Hans van Gulik (1910-67) apparently wrote 16 fiction & published 1 translation of the exploits of historical Judge Dee (630-700 AD).  He includes a short "Postcript" @ the end of most--worth reading 1st--esp. if it's your 1st one--woodcut type drawings/maps which greatly enhance the volumes and, in most novels, a "Dramatis Personae" list--especially valuable since it's divided up by case (most have 3 cases/book).  The Postscript to "The Chinese Nail Murders" describes the author's approach to them--mostly based on old Chinese documents & their conventions towards magistrates--though he modernizes them somewhat.  "Judge Dee at Work" includes a valuable chronology with dates.  Usually a Magistrate spent ~3 years in a district & was then transferred: Peng-Lai=663-6 AD, Han-Yuan=666-668, Poo-Yang=668-670,  Lan-Fang=670-676, Pei-Chow=676-677, and (after promotion) to the Capital=677-700).  Interestingly, most of the books take place during his 14 years (663-677) as district magistrate rather than this book which takes place during his 23 year tenure (677-700) in the capital after his promotion.  But, have no fear, he and 3 of his assistants, Tao Gan, Ma Joong, & Chiao Tai, are pretty much their old selves but with more authority.  I believe this is one of the last van Gulik wrote.THE SERIES INCLUDES:18 Judge Dee books (in alphabetical order with date): Celebrated Cases of Judge Dee (the one translation), The Chinese Bell Murders=668 AD, The Chinese Gold Murders=663, The Chinese Lake Murders=666, The Chinese Maze Murders=670, The Chinese Nail Murders=676, The Emperor's Pearl=668, The Haunted Monastery=666, Judge Dee at Work=663-70, The Lacquer Screen=663, The Monkey & the Tiger=666 & 676, Murder in Canton=681, Murder in Ancient China, Necklace & Calabash, The Phantom of the Temple, Poets & Murder, The Red Pavilion=668, and The Willow Pattern=677.  Of the 18 books one is redundant, one is a translation, and the other 16 are fictional works by van Gulik.  Interestingly, the 1st fiction books (The Chinese ____ Murders) were written in the order: Bell, Maze, Lake, Nail and Gold, but chronologically (in the fictional world) are ordered: Gold, Lake, Bell, Maze, & Nail.  The short stories are chronologically interspersed with the novels.THIS INDIVIDUAL VOLUME: (Others reviewers have already described the plot)Like some modern detective novels, the clues can be subtle and, in this case, based upon certain ancient Chinese customs.  As in other Dee novels, the mysteries tie into past crimes--here by a tyrannical marquis.  Unlike all the other books, Dee works with the military when marshal law is declared and is the only high ranking official who hasn't fled the plague in the capital.  Thus, the courtroom scenes differ somewhat.  As usual the several separate cases (according to the Dramatis Personae) are all interrelated.  Van Gulik often introduces interesting, unusual, and/or humorous characters--here there are dichotomous twins, naked dancers, a seriously enthralled lieutenant, a triumvirate of former rulers--of the old town, a puppeteer, etc.  Several of the books in this series began to be a bit disappointing IMHO due to their obvious repetition of themes, but this one is unique in the series--which I greatly appreciated.  I didn't get any quotes for my collection from it, but overall, I liked it very much.TYPE OF MYSTERY:Dee stories are more straight mystery vs. action/adventure/thriller, though some action does take place--sometimes including personal danger--implied herein due to the plague.  If you enjoy Golden Age Mysteries (e.g. Sayers, Christie, Marsh, Allingham, Tey), you'll probably enjoy the Dee books.  They usually have less social commentary, flowery description, political intrigue & physical action than contemporary "mysteries" but do provide insightful cultural descriptions/incidents--perhaps why I like them better--though they're not always historically accurate--per van Gulik's Postscripts.  Unlike the West, most describe the punishment of the criminals.OTHER ORIENTAL MYSTERIES:If you are particularly interested in Oriental mysteries, you might try Ingrid J. (I.J.) Parker's ~11th century Japan Sugawara Akitada mysteries, Laura Joh Rowland's ~18th c. Japan Sano Ichiro mysteries, and/or James Melville's more contemporary Japan Superintendent Otani mysteries.

I had a metal one of similar design before--but without the overwind feature, so I inadvertently destroyed it.  They can be effective without bait but the placement and positioning can effect whether you catch mice or not.  On the other hand, you can use the traditional peanut butter (which works well) or Tomcat's Mouse Attractant--I just got some and haven't tried it out yet.  I suspect it won't be as messy as the dried up peanut butter can be.  I'd suggest depositing the caught mice some distance from your house though.  Mice can learn.  If they get into your house again, they won't be so easily caught the same way.

I was pleased with the performance of this product.  I think it exceeded the usefulness of other counter-top type cleaners I've used in the past.  I liked the thicker consistency and the fragrance isn't overpowering--and it comes in a variety of fragrances too.  I even tried it on some cookware with baked on food.  It did pretty well; almost as good as Krud Kutter.  The bottle seems to last a pretty long time too.

At first, the blades were very sharp yet the shave was smooth.  The large head doesn't restrict the smaller areas (e.g. just under the nose) as much as might be expected.  But the blade doesn't last as long as some others I've used--even the Schick Hydro 5 disposable razors I've used in the past: a bit strange to me.  I had hoped to use this one and just pack refills on my world travels, but the handle is a bit heavy for that.  The built-in lubricant saves space in my 1 quart liquids bag in my carry-on though.  I'll stick with the disposables for travel and do price comparisons for home use.

GENERAL COMMENTS ON SERIESDutch diplomat and sinologist Robert Hans van Gulik (1910-67) apparently wrote 16 fiction & published 1 translation of the exploits of historical Judge Dee (630-700 AD).  He includes a short "Postcript" @ the end of most--worth reading 1st--esp. if it's your 1st one--woodcut type drawings/maps which greatly enhance the volumes and, in most novels, a "Dramatis Personae" list--especially valuable since it's divided up by case (most have 3 cases/book).  The Postscript to "The Chinese Nail Murders" describes the author's approach to them--mostly based on old Chinese documents & their conventions towards magistrates--though he modernizes them somewhat.  "Judge Dee at Work" includes a valuable chronology with dates.  Usually a Magistrate spent ~3 years in a district & was then transferred: Peng-Lai=663-6 AD, Han-Yuan=666-668, Poo-Yang=668-670,  Lan-Fang=670-676, Pei-Chow=676-677, and (after promotion) to the Capital=677-700).  Interestingly, all the prior books I've read (I haven't read The Willow Pattern yet) took place during his 14 years (663-677) as district magistrate rather than this book which takes place during his 23 year tenure (677-700) in the capital after his promotion.  But, have no fear, he and 2 of his assistants, Tao Gan & Chiao Tai, are pretty much their old selves but with more authority.THE SERIES INCLUDES:18 Judge Dee books (in alphabetical order with date): Celebrated Cases of Judge Dee (the one translation), The Chinese Bell Murders=668 AD, The Chinese Gold Murders=663, The Chinese Lake Murders=666, The Chinese Maze Murders=670, The Chinese Nail Murders=676, The Emperor's Pearl=668, The Haunted Monastery=666, Judge Dee at Work=663-70, The Lacquer Screen=663, The Monkey & the Tiger=666 & 676, Murder in Canton=681, Murder in Ancient China, Necklace & Calabash, The Phantom of the Temple, Poets & Murder, The Red Pavilion=668, and The Willow Pattern=677.  Of the 18 books one is redundant, one is a translation, and the other 16 are fictional works by van Gulik.  Interestingly, the 1st fiction books (The Chinese ____ Murders) were written in the order: Bell, Maze, Lake, Nail and Gold, but chronologically (in the fictional world) are ordered: Gold, Lake, Bell, Maze, & Nail.  The short stories are chronologically interspersed with the novels.THIS INDIVIDUAL VOLUME: (Others reviewers have already described the plot)Like some modern detective novels, the obvious solution is not usually correct--there's an abundance of both suspects & hypotheses as to the culprit(s).  As in some of the other works, Dee resorts to a Nero Wolfe type of bluff-confrontation with the suspects, to catch a culprit in a trap, & as in other Dee novels, the mysteries tie into past crimes--here a missing Imperial Censor (rather than an inanimate object).  Dee ventures out of the capital on a special mission (unlike the other novels).  As usual the several separate cases (according to the Dramatis Personae) are all interrelated.  Van Gulik often introduces interesting, unusual, and/or humorous characters--here there are coquettish twins, a belly dancer, an enigmatic blind girl, suspect financiers, a Governor and Prefect, a very unusual sea captain, Arab assassins, and a seemingly barbaric folk called Tanka, experienced with poison and strangling, but no hint of the supernatural/magical of some of his books.  The last couple I read were a bit disappointing IMHO due to their obvious repetition of themes, but this one is unique in the series.  I didn't get any quotes for my collection from it, but overall, I liked it at least as well as the majority of his other works.TYPE OF MYSTERY:Dee stories are more straight mystery vs. action/adventure/thriller, though some action does take place--including personal danger--somewhat more here than in his other works.  If you enjoy Golden Age Mysteries (e.g. Sayers, Christie, Marsh, Allingham, Tey), you'll probably enjoy the Dee books.  They usually have less social commentary, flowery description, political intrigue (though it is important in this particular volume), & physical action than contemporary "mysteries" but do provide insightful cultural descriptions/incidents--perhaps why I like them better--though they're not always historically accurate--per van Gulik's Postscripts.  Unlike the West, most describe the punishment of the criminals--vague herein.  Van Gulik explicitly describes the cultural and racial prejudices of ancient China.OTHER ORIENTAL MYSTERIES:If you are particularly interested in Oriental mysteries, you might try Ingrid J. (I.J.) Parker's ~11th century Japan Sugawara Akitada mysteries, Laura Joh Rowland's ~18th c. Japan Sano Ichiro mysteries, and/or James Melville's more contemporary Japan Superintendent Otani mysteries.

This is a very short novel (184 pages in the hard cover edition).  It features her main detective, Inspector Cockrill who's confronted with first one, and then another murder in which a family member appears to be the culprit.  As usual with Brand, motives abound but opportunities are rare--2, more or less, impossible (locked-room type) murders.  She also interjects bunches of red herrings and emotional complications.  I've only read 4 of her books so far, but I liked this more more most of them.  The characters are a bit more fleshed out and a bit more endearing than in some of her other works IMHO.  Of course, this was written over half a century ago in England and the mores don't map easily onto the 21st century.  But, perhaps, humans haven't changed so much in that time?  The characters don't seem to care a whit for justice and will lie to protect each other or let the supposedly unbalanced member appear to take the blame, etc.--and I'm not speaking only of the actual murderer.  I find that rather appalling myself, but maybe that's just me.

This is a very clever mystery with lots of twists and red herrings.  I'd like to like it more, but I didn't find the characters very appealing and the style didn't engage me very well--I had to plow through it.  Many of the characters are more like caricatures it seemed to me.  Also, while there was some suspense, and I did figure out the culprit and method--I still wasn't sure it was correct because (and I still believe this) there are other possibilities inherent in the plot--kind of like those mystery plays in which the culprit & ending change from performance to performance.  I find this to be rather annoying--and it makes the ending rather dubious (unless and until the perpetrator confesses--but that's really a ploy in this circumstance).Interestingly, Cecil appears in this work--as he did in her first novel, "Death in High Heels," which is referred to in this book.  Brand actually has two detectives, Inspector Cockrill (her main one) and Inspector Charlesworth who appears, apparently, in only two of her novels.  "Death in High Heels" is one of the two--he was her initial detective.  Thus, Cecil has met both of the detectives.

Some Brands improve with age--I think this one did.  Reminds me a bit of Margery Allingham in that respect at least (she also wrote about dress designers).  This is, I believe, CB's 1st novel.  It stars Inspector Charlesworth who did not become her main detective in her later works (except, I'm told one more).  I've only read one other, "Fog of Doubt" which I liked much better than this one.  So if you don't like this one, you might consider trying a later Brand novel.The characters are not deeply drawn though most are appealing.  The mystery was written prior to WWII so the climate and mores differ from today.  Some of their motivations seemed a bit much to me.  The mystery is rather complicated and I think a figure or two (esp. of the dress shop floor plan) would have been very helpful to the reader.  I figured out some of the mystery, but a number of clues are given quite near the end of the book.  It's a rather small book, but it didn't read particularly fast.

This is my 2nd Paul Charles but my 1st with Inspector Starrett.  It moves rather slowly, even more than normal for a police procedural, with heavy emphasis on interpersonal relationships.  The latter include ones: between Starrett and his team, between Starrett and his girlfriend's family, and (primarily) among the Sweeney family (of the deceased).  The language is sometimes difficult for an American reader with many colloquialisms--some of which are difficult to decipher from the context.  The author is attempting to depict dialect, but I wonder how realistic it is: do people really still say "Bejeepers" so much anymore?  I'm soon off to Northern Ireland, so I might find out soon.The mystery is fine though the method is similar to that in "A Pleasure to Do Death with You" (the other Paul Charles I've read) and I figured out most of the mystery fairly early (possibly because of the other book).  It did have a couple of quotes for my collection: p. 21: You could flirt for Team UK at the Olympics. &p. 80: You should always be wary of someone who walks at least a step or two behind his wife.I'd give it a better rating if it weren't so slow-paced and if much of the "activity" (mostly dialog) didn't seem overdone or extraneous to me.  I can't really recommend it.

I enjoyed reading this book (my 1st Paul Charles)--it flows easily, the main character is likable, several other characters are unique and/or very interesting, the settings and plot are enjoyable, and it has a bit of humor--and quotes for my collection:p. 82: He'd really have preferred to wipe his bum with a brick than settle down.p. 314: Platonic is only passion with the brakes on.p. 322: Anything that keeps the flies your side of the dinner table is all right with me.p. 327: That's the FPO's domain;...that's the Fun Prevention Officer, a.k.a. his wife.The reason I'm not giving it 5 stars is that it has several (to me) flaws.  Firstly, there are obvious errors such as p. 36 "Inspector Poirot" (per Agatha Christie, he was a detective but not with the police and not an inspector) and p. 302 where the main character enjoys having the same dollar notes as the cowboys had--older currency in the US were much larger physically than they are today.  Of course, I can overlook such things since the character, being human, can make mistakes.  Secondly, as it's about a Northern Irishman living in contemporary London, an American reader (such as myself) must try and understand various colloquialisms--but this book seems to be loaded with them--and they're nothing like the Britishisms of Christie, Sayers, etc. with which I am familiar.  Also, numerous references to unknown (but apparently real) people.  But, the worst aspect IMHO are the very hard to believe actions of the culprits when they've been caught.  I don't want to put in spoilers so I won't provide detail, but some things in this book are extremely difficult to believe.

This is a sweet (as labelled), pareve, large gefilte fish made from: "water, carp, whitefish, mullet, pike, egg whites, sugar, onions, potato starch, salt, cottonseed oil, carragenan, carrots, and pepper."  It's made by Manischewitz.  It's gluten free and MSG free.  I ate 3 at a time.  Yum!  They come from Amazon in bubble wrap and whole.  But, don't forget the horseradish!  I find the sweetness goes really well with the bite of the horseradish and the subtle taste of matzah.Also, it's great to have Amazon Prime if you've forgotten to get something and need it in a hurry.  Stores sometimes run out early too.  Enjoy!

This book is reputed to be the first mystery novel (Poe wrote a mystery story prior to this, however).  The Saturday Review said it was "considered by many to be the ranking detective story of modern times."  Agatha Christie called it "one of the best detective stories ever written."  Dorothy Sayers said it "ranges from a vividly colored rhetoric to a delicate and ironical literary fancy."  Pretty good reviews!  It was written in 1913 and many of the great mysteries built upon its foundations.  And, it's a fine mystery--a bit slow at first, but the ending--kind of like some of the very best mystery short stories or the mystery plays where the real culprit is changed from performance to performance.  I have to admit though, that I somehow psyched out the killer early on--without any real evidence to support my conjecture/conclusion--just from having read tons of mysteries I think.Frequently, even in modern times, the detective/sleuth, whether professional or amateur, will reach a startlingly logical and totally wrong conclusion in a novel prior to the denouement and final solution to the puzzle.  It isn't much of a spoiler (especially considering the earlier reviews) to state that this book includes such an arrangement--but it does it very well.  So well that one becomes a doubting Thomas regarding specific interpretations of the facts.  As a former practitioner of Knowledge Management, I have to say that not only facts/data, but also information (organized data including statistics) are not knowledge.  Knowledge includes both information (content) and appropriate context.  This is, perhaps, why in some mysteries the detective (s) seek to find out all they can about the victim and the suspects.  I think we would improve our judicial system if potential jurors were required to read mystery novels such as this one.  It's a bit chilling IMHO.

I use a high school type rating system--A=excellent, B=good, etc. where I'll buy an A song as soon as I hear it, a B maybe later, a C just to listen to on the radio, and below that I change the station! This is an A song to me. I heard it once and downloaded it. I do MP3 songs, not generally albums. I heard it sung on an awards show and bought it at my next opportunity.  I've played it quite a few times since then.  It's different from other songs by either artist but does them both proud IMHO.  If you watch The Voice on TV you'll notice that they are both judges on the show--possibly how they met and then chose to collaborate on this song.  Hopefully, it's the first of many future collaborations by The Voice judges (which also presently include Adam Levine from Maroon 5 and Usher but on alternate seasons include Christina Aguilera & Ceelo Greene).

I use a high school type rating system--A=excellent, B=good, etc. where I'll buy an A song as soon as I hear it, a B maybe later, a C just to listen to on the radio, and below that I change the station!  This is an A song to me.  I heard it once and downloaded it.  I do MP3 songs, not generally albums.  This song has a fine melody and seems uplifting to me.  Also, the title's clever and I like Urban's voice.  It does seem funny though--a country (rural music) singer named Urban!  Not to mention that he's Australian; but then I love Australia--been there about 1/2 dozen times so far and planning to go again next year.

This is a set of 12 articles (some given as lectures) by C. G. Jung's major disciple M-LvF from 1960 to 1992 and, apparently, a sequel to her "Number & Time."  It's much tougher going than some of her later works--e.g. "Psychotherapy" or "Creation Myths."  The main thrust of the book is her erudite (e.g. regarding quantum physics and world mythology) attempt to relate/integrate Jung's synchronicity to Matter, Time, Jungian Archetypes, etc. as reflected in her very extensive chapter endnotes.  The articles are not in chronological order which would have been: 6-12-2-1-5-3-4-8-11-9-10-7 (dates are provided for each article) which would have been better IMHO (so as to experience the development of her ideas over time), and the editors did not attempt to relate anything in the articles & ignore the tremendous redundancy amongst them.  Major themes include--time vs. space, numbers & archetypes, synchronicity & myth/divination, psychology & physics, order vs. meaning, conscious & unconscious, data & information vs. knowledge & meaning (~modern Knowledge Management).  Her arguments have tremendous breadth as well as depth, some of her conclusions may be astounding for many readers, though a few seem a bit of a stretch for me, & her references to physics greatly support Synchronicity.There are a couple of pages of quotes for my collection, including: [brackets are my comments]p. 29: A hypothesis according to which synchronistic events, being sporadic "miracles," were only a special case of the more general principle of acausal orderedness.p. 72: As Jung pointed out, this is the telling question of our life: whether we are related to something infinite or not.  'Only if we know that what truly matters is the infinite can we avoid fixing our interest on futilities.  In the final analysis we count for something only because of the essential we embody, and if we do not embody that life is wasted.'p. 121: Every schematic model clarifies but also blurs in some ways the facts which one tries to describe by it. [analogies aren't identities so they have errors]pp. 129-30: Synchronistic events are not only irregular but even seemingly arbitrary.  For this reason they were in our Christian past called 'miracles' which were performed by either God or the Devil.p. 139: [quoting Jung] 'The brain might be a transformer station, in which relatively infinite tension or intensity of the psyche proper is transformed into perceptible frequencies of 'extension.'pp. 204-5: We know today through the results of modern nuclear physics that strict causality is only an interpretive mode of our intellect, that in nature there are only probabilities...therefore, logically accidents or chance occurrences must also exist.p. 213: Sir James Jeans writes...'Radioactive break-up appeared to be an effect without a cause, and suggested that the ultimate laws of nature were not even causal.' Jung chose for this...the term acausal orderedness.  This is not the same as 'meaning'...'without the reflecting consciousness of man the world is a gigantic meaningless machine for in our experience, man is the only creature who is capable of ascertaining any meaning at all.'p. 304: In physics causality has become only a relatively valid principle and we now only look for 'statistical laws with primary probabilities' as [physicist Wolfgang] Pauli puts it.My favorite two anecdotes regard a patient's dream of a green suit with a black back--when the wearer walks into a black wall he appears to disappear though he's still there--pp. 73 & 138: "In dying we may only step outside the 'event horizon' [~black or dark star] of the living, but still exist in an unobservable state;" & 2nd, the much quoted experience of Richard Wilhelm who asked a Chinese rainmaker: p. 161:  "how he made the rain.  But he answered, 'I haven't made the rain, of course not.'  And then, after a pause, he added, 'You see it was like this--throughout the drought the whole of nature and all the men and women here were deeply disturbed.  It was so bad that it took me three days to bring myself again into order.' And then he added with a smile, 'Then naturally it rained.'"

This is the only Crispin I've read so far.  Since there have been many prior reviews, I won't reiterate the plot or most of the comments which have been pretty accurate IMHO.  I think the book was pretty good, but not, as the NY Times Book Review (quoted on the cover) "Immensely witty and literate" though it does have some humor even today.  On the upside, it's clever and some of the characters (esp. Nigel and Helen) are quite likable, but the "detective" Fen not so much.  As with many "impossible" crimes, it's a bit far-fetched (comes with the territory, I think).  The reader is presented with almost all the clues.  On the downside, the author injects tons of Latin/French phrases as well as obscure English words which detract from the tale--though I suppose they contribute to an understanding of Fen a bit.  There are two quotes I liked:p. 148: "Nigel, mindful of his vow of silence, projected a burst of telepathic applause in her direction.p. 200: If one wasn't a little adventurous sometime, the world would be intolerable."I'll probably read the book of Crispin's that other folks have recommended.  Many authors improve over time as they have inferred.

I didn't notice that the ingredients list included Sucralose as the 5th ingredient listed out of 9.  I tasted a bag and it was IMHO sickeningly sweet.  I could hardly taste the salt.  Looking up Sucralose on Wikipedia, I found out it has several commercial names including Splenda.  It's 320 to 1000 times as sweet as table sugar.  So they can list it low on the ingredients' list and it's still overpowering IMO.  Yes, it has few calories and pops pretty well (though I had a fair amount of unpopped kernals).  I am giving it one star because I think it's not described sufficiently on the box--it should allude to the very strong sweetness of the contents.  You may like this sweetness--you're entitled to.  But I exceedingly disliked it.

GENERAL COMMENTS ON SERIESDutch diplomat and sinologist Robert Hans van Gulik (1910-67) apparently wrote 16 fiction & published 1 translation of the exploits of historical Judge Dee (630-700 AD).  He includes a short "Postcript" @ the end of most--worth reading 1st--esp. if it's your 1st one--woodcut type drawings/maps which greatly enhance the volumes and, in most novels, a "Dramatis Personae" list--especially valuable since it's divided up by case (most have 3 cases/book).  The Postscript to "The Chinese Nail Murders" describes the author's approach to them--mostly based on old Chinese documents & their conventions towards magistrates--though he modernizes them somewhat.  "Judge Dee at Work" includes a valuable chronology with dates.  Usually a Magistrate spent ~3 years in a district & was then transferred: Peng-Lai=663-6 AD, Han-Yuan=666-668, Poo-Yang=668-670,  Lan-Fang=670-676, Pei-Chow=676-677, and (after promotion) to the Capital=677-700).THE SERIES INCLUDES:18 Judge Dee books (in alphabetical order with date): Celebrated Cases of Judge Dee (the one translation), The Chinese Bell Murders=668 AD, The Chinese Gold Murders=663, The Chinese Lake Murders=666, The Chinese Maze Murders=670, The Chinese Nail Murders=676, The Emperor's Pearl=668, The Haunted Monastery=666, Judge Dee at Work=663-70, The Lacquer Screen=663, The Monkey & the Tiger=666 & 676, Murder in Canton=681, Murder in Ancient China, Necklace & Calabash, The Phantom of the Temple, Poets & Murder, The Red Pavilion=668, and The Willow Pattern=677.  Of the 18 books one is redundant, one is a translation, and the other 16 are fictional works by van Gulik.  Interestingly, the 1st fiction books (The Chinese ____ Murders) were written in the order: Bell, Maze, Lake, Nail and Gold, but chronologically (in the fictional world) are ordered: Gold, Lake, Bell, Maze, & Nail.  The short stories are chronologically interspersed with the novels.THIS INDIVIDUAL VOLUME: (Others reviewers have already described the plot)It's the 16th I've read so far.  Like some modern detective novels, the obvious solution is not usually correct and with this one there's an abundance of both suspects and hypotheses as to the culprit.  Indeed, some early conclusions are quite incorrect and misleading such that, unlike the other seriesworks, Dee resorts to a Nero Wolfe type of bluff-confrontation with the suspects, catching the culprit in a trap set by a turtle--so, "slow and steady" won the race.  Indeed the favored dragon boat didn't win the race in this novel.  As in other Dee novels, the mysteries tie into past crimes--especially missing Imperial items (in this case a pearl, in another bars of gold, etc.).  Dee stays within his own district (unlike several other novels) but without his 2 burly lieutenants who are outside the district.  His sergeant has a larger part herein.  As usual the several separate (according to the Dramatis Personae, are all interrelated.  On the other hand, he again employs the King of the Beggars and the wonderful Mongolian Violet Liang who adds humor and spice to this book--it's a shame she didn't have a bigger part IMHO.  It's interesting to me that while Dee is a very conservative Confucian and looks down on both Taoism and Buddhism, in this book he seems more accepting of the supernatural and magical realism.  Having read 15 of his books prior to this one, I was a bit disappointed at the obvious repetition of themes in this one.  Antithetically, I didn't get any quotes for my collection from it.  Overall, I liked most of his other works a bit better than this one, but it's still worth reading.TYPE OF MYSTERY:Dee stories are more straight mystery vs. action/adventure/thriller, though some action does take place--including personal danger.  If you enjoy Golden Age Mysteries (e.g. Sayers, Christie, Marsh, Allingham, Tey), you'll probably enjoy the Dee books--I'll read all.  They usually have less social commentary, flowery description, political intrigue, & physical action than contemporary "mysteries" but do provide insightful cultural descriptions/incidents--perhaps why I like them better--though they're not always historically accurate--per van Gulik's Postscripts.  Unlike the West, most describe the punishment of the criminals.OTHER ORIENTAL MYSTERIES:If you are particularly interested in Oriental mysteries, you might try Ingrid J. (I.J.) Parker's ~11th century Japan Sugawara Akitada mysteries, Laura Joh Rowland's ~18th c. Japan Sano Ichiro mysteries, and/or James Melville's more contemporary Japan Superintendent Otani mysteries.

GENERAL COMMENTS ON SERIESDutch diplomat and sinologist Robert Hans van Gulik (1910-67) apparently wrote 16 fiction & 1 translation of the exploits of historical Judge Dee (630-700 AD).  He includes a short "Postcript" @ the end of most--worth reading 1st--esp. if it's your 1st book in the series--woodcut type drawings/maps which greatly enhance the volumes and, in most novels, a "Dramatis Personae" list--especially valuable since it's divided up by case (most have 3 cases/book).  The Postscript to "The Chinese Nail Murders" describes the author's approach to them--mostly based on old Chinese documents & their conventions towards magistrates--though he modernizes them somewhat.  "Judge Dee at Work" includes a valuable chronology with dates.  Usually a Magistrate spent ~3 years in a district & then transferred: Peng-Lai=663-6 AD, Han-Yuan=666-668, Poo-Yang=668-670,  Lan-Fang=670-676, Pei-Chow=676-677, and (after promotion) to the Capital=677-700).THE SERIES INCLUDES:18 Judge Dee books (in alphabetical order with date): Celebrated Cases of Judge Dee (the one translation), The Chinese Bell Murders=668 AD, The Chinese Gold Murders=663, The Chinese Lake Murders=666, The Chinese Maze Murders=670, The Chinese Nail Murders=676, The Emperor's Pearl=668, The Haunted Monastery=666, Judge Dee at Work=663-70, The Lacquer Screen=663, The Monkey & the Tiger=666 & 676, Murder in Canton=681, Murder in Ancient China, Necklace & Calabash, The Phantom of the Temple, Poets & Murder, The Red Pavilion=668, and The Willow Pattern=677.  Of the 18 books one is redundant, one is a translation, and the other 16 are fictional works by van Gulik.  Interestingly, the 1st fiction books (The Chinese ____ Murders) were written in the order: Bell, Maze, Lake, Nail and Gold, but chronologically (in the fictional world) are ordered: Gold, Lake, Bell, Maze, & Nail.  The short stories are chronologically interspersed with the novels.THIS INDIVIDUAL VOLUME: (Others reviewers have already described the plot, so I will avoid being redundant here)It's the 15th I've read so far.  Like some modern detective novels, the obvious solution is not usually correct and with Dee there's a partial solution that misleads you 'til the non-obvious complete solution at the end.  There are also mysteries within mysteries and as here, tie into past crimes.  As opposed to others, Dee is within his own district.  While this one includes only 2 of his 4 assistants, it also includes some scenes with his wives--demonstrating his domesticity and more on life in ancient China.  While it does include the Dramatis Personae, this volume is unusual in that it has no separation of the 3 mysteries--though they are all actually interrelated--but then that's not unusual in a Dee book.  There are also many parallels with other books in this series--but differences emerge as the book progresses.  As usual, Dee is a very conservative Confucian and looks down on both Taoism and Buddhism--but this book goes a bit further in criticizing Tantric Buddhism vs. Fundamental Buddhism.  His attack is mainly aimed at the sexual aspects, ignoring the main differences offered by Vajrayana (mostly Tibetan) Buddhism.  It's unclear whether van Gulik is actually familiar with the various types of Buddhism.  Overall, I liked most of his other works a bit better than this one (though the solution is quite clever IMHO), but it's still well worth reading.A valuable quotation for my collection:p. 131: 'If we ever succeeded in reaching the utmost of what we are longing for,' the judge said drily, 'there would be a sense of surfeit.'TYPE OF MYSTERY:Dee stories are more straight mystery vs. action/adventure/thriller, though some action does take place--including personal danger.  If you enjoy Golden Age Mysteries (e.g. Sayers, Christie, Marsh, Allingham, Tey), you'll probably enjoy the Dee books--I'll read all.  They usually have less social commentary, flowery description, political intrigue, & physical action than contemporary "mysteries" but do provide insightful cultural descriptions/incidents--perhaps why I like them better--though they're not always historically accurate--per van Gulik's Postscripts.  Unlike the West, most describe the punishment of the criminals--though this particular one does not.OTHER ORIENTAL MYSTERIES:If you are particularly interested in Oriental mysteries, you might try Ingrid J. (I.J.) Parker's ~11th century Japan Sugawara Akitada mysteries, Laura Joh Rowland's ~18th c.
