Japan Sano Ichiro mysteries, and/or James Melville's more contemporary Japan Superintendent Otani mysteries.

I like the James Melville Superintendent Otani books--I believe I've read them all.  I'm uncertain, but I think this might be the earliest one.  His later ones show Otani later in life and are more solid mysteries--where the reader can attempt to discern the guilty party (ies).  Still, this one is interesting too.  The setting is post-WWII Japan with Otani being the top police official in Kobe and the surrounding area--the 3rd largest (after Tokyo and Osaka) in Japan--so his title (compared to English mysteries) is a bit misleading--he's much higher in rank than it would appear.  The characters in this book are, IMHO, intriguing--from Japan, the US, Ireland, and Denmark.  It is also important to understand the relationship between the police and the criminal organizations in Japan at that time--more competitors than enemies in some ways.  The Yakusa are frequently in Otani books.  Also, there is, of course, a heavy emphasis on etiquette and formality as usual in Japan (from a Western perspective).  The police procedures are considerably different as well.  So, this is an opportunity to learn about another culture and time.  But, I wouldn't rate the series only on this book.  There isn't, however, a lot of insight into Zen or too much use of Zen terminology here--so don't worry if you are unfamiliar with it--just that zazen is a form of Zen meditation.  The characters are all too human--not at all zombies or automatons (stereotypes do not abound herein).  Overall, it's an enjoyable book.  I hope you like it.

Unlike his earlier, more advanced books (Carefree Dignity: Discourses on Training in the Nature of Mind & Fearless Simplicity: The Dzogchen Way of Living Freely in a Complex World), Tsokni Rinpoche (the son of Tulku Urgyen and brother of Chokyi Nyima) covers many basic Vajrayana precepts such as the paramitas (perfections), bodhicitta, tonglen, etc. but in a very down to earth & easy to understand way using a great many personal anecdotes about his own training and experiences as a teacher.  This book is simply & effectively written.  The author embeds a number of Western psychological parallels (e.g. patterns of behavior, complexes) and provides easily understood Buddhist practical practices towards opening one's heart and mind per his own teachers:p. 233: "He [his teacher Khamtrul Rinpoche] built bridges of the heart."Relates Buddhism to Western Psychology (esp. Jung whom he quotes):pp. 4-5: A shadow is projected by some source of light, and by recognizing and acknowledging our shadow selves we can begin to trace a path toward the light.p. 10: Real but not True [e.g. his fear crossing a glass sky bridge between buildings]p. 11: A mantra is basically a means of looking with your thoughts and feelings...an opening of a conversation between the heart and the mind.  You can begin by saying something like "yes, I know that you're real." Then ask "are you true? Are you based on present conditions, or are you based on past experience?" [info.=content=Real vs. knowledge, with context,=True]p. 60: Patterns emerge from social and cultural influence, as well as from personal experiences that, over time, become familiar.  And questioning the familiar is almost always uncomfortable.p. 60: narcissism...is based on low self-esteem and a reliance on gaining a sense of recognition or power through dominating others.p. 159: Speed Limits & news crawlers [activation/arousal theory w/characteristic point--a speed right for you]Wonderfully elucidates (correcting misconceptions) Vajrayana word meanings in a personal way with anecdotes:p. 44: The basic meaning of emptiness, in other words, is 'openness' or 'potential.'  At this basic level of our being, we are 'empty' of definable characteristics. [~the words of Pema Chodron]pp. 66-7: Often overlooked in the instructions of tonglen is that the most fruitful time to practice it is when we're feeling bad about ourselves--when we're consumed by anger, despair, jealousy, or some other negative feeling: we take these feelings and our desire to get past them, as a starting point...Bring your attention to the person or persons who have brought about a painful situation...Breathe in the darkness and pain that may have caused that person to act that way ...Breathe out brightness--the essence of your own spark--and imagine it filling that person with confidence, light, a connection to essence love...Tonglen is not about forgiving or forgetting.p. 108: The idea of extinguishing 'ego' or 'self' or 'I' is inaccurate.  You may as well try to 'extinguish' your feet or hands.p. 109: {~brushing your teeth} We don't need to get rid of the various 'I's.  We just need to brush away the residue we pick up along the way.pp. 207-8: Practicing compassion...involves doing things that you don't really want to do... Compassion is not just a feeling; it's an action...a willingness to endure hardship on the behalf of others, which is the basis of relative bodhicitta: Do what needs to be done, even if you don't want to, even if it causes you hardship or pain.His Teaching Methods:p. 56: I need to understand the background, the culture, the habitual pattern, the environment that shapes the lives of the people I teach. & p. 231: I shift my teachings to suit the people sitting in front of me.Personal revelations through anecdotes demonstrating his sincerity and humility:p. 182: I started 'borrowing' books about meditation from the monastery library, which were not part of the tulku curriculum at that point. [a  parallel student?]pp. 205-6: [leaf from Bodhi Tree incident on how he dealt with selfishness vs. bodhicitta]More advanced practices:pp. 186-7: clouds and gaps in thought [while I've done the Dzogchen Sky Exercise, it occurred to me from reading Rinpoche's description that the space and the sky were like those bistable optical illusions such as the 2 faces vs. the vase in the middle where one is black and the other is white.  It also occurred to me that you could do it at night with the stars since stars blink, unlike planets]So, this is a solid introductory or refresher book but also provides considerable exposition on difficult ideas that are, perhaps, not completely understood from other books.  The style is lovely and you can easily tell that his heart is in the right place.Note: words in [brackets] are mine.  As an introductory book it rates 5 stars, but I found his earlier works more enlightening--I wish I didn't have to assign a grade via a highly limiting 5 point system.  Even movies have 1/2 stars.

Dutch diplomat and sinologist Robert Hans van Gulik (1910-67) apparently wrote 16 fiction and 1 translation of the exploits of historical Judge Dee (630-700).  He includes a short "Postcript" at the end of all the ones I've read--which you might read first--especially if you haven't read any of them before.  He also includes several woodcut type drawings which (while not historically accurate) IMHO greatly enhance these volumes and a "Dramatis Personae" list--especially valuable since its divided up by the case (most of these books involve simultaneous/multiple cases.This particular book is actually two separate novellas of about 70 pages each: (1) "The Morning of the Monkey" taking place in 666 (there's a hair raising date for you!) in Judge Dee's own district--he is involved by a Gibbon (actually a type of ape and not a monkey--but close enough for fiction (poetic license and all) carrying a gold ring with entwined dragons.  This leads the good judge on a fun, interesting, and challenging adventure--with his usual panache and flashes of insight.(2) "The Night of the Tiger" which takes place in 676 & pits the new Lord Chief Justice of the Empire and President of the Metropolitan Court (i.e. Judge Dee, promoted after "The Chinese Nail Murders," once again travelling, & born in the Year of the Tiger) without his strong entourage against the Flying Tigers--a gang of cut-throats.  Admittedly, his separation from his guards is a bit far-fetched--it seems a bit arrogant to me--maybe because of his promotion?  Of course, these bandits have no relation to the WWII Flying Tigers who actually flew planes.  Interestingly, the Judge seems quite complacent despite the apparently dire situation.  He does, however, as usual, figure out whodunnit--even when there isn't an apparent crime and also figures out a unique, clever, and IMHO satisfying way out of the dilemma of the Tigers.Overall, as usual, the tales/cases are very enjoyable and delightful IMHO--especially for readers more interested in straight mystery vs. action/adventure/thriller.  If you enjoy the Golden Age of Mysteries (e.g. Sayers, Christie, Marsh, Allingham, Tey), you will probably greatly enjoy the van Gulik books; I plan to read them all--with some now on order at Amazon.  The Judge Dee books IMHO are more mystery oriented with less social commentary, flowery description, political intrigue, and physical action than many "mysteries" esp. contemporary ones--but do provide cultural insights--perhaps why I like them better.If you are interested primarily in Oriental mysteries, you might read Ingrid J. (I.J.) Parker's ~11th century Japan Sugawara Akitada mysteries, Laura Joh Rowland's ~18th c. Japan Sano Ichiro mysteries, and/or James Melville's more contemporary Japan Superintendant Otani mysteries.The 18 Judge Dee books I've found are (in alphabetical order, ignoring "the"): Celebrated Cases of Judge Dee (this one's a translation), The Chinese Bell Murders, The Chinese Gold Murders, The Chinese Lake Murders, The Chinese Maze Murders, The Chinese Nail Murders, The Emperor's Pearl, The Haunted Monastery, Judge Dee at Work, The Lacquer Screen, The Monkey & the Tiger, Murder in Canton, Murder in Ancient China (I've heard this is a sub-set of Judge Dee at Work), Necklace & Calabash, The Phantom of the Temple, Poets & Murder, The Red Pavilion, and The Willow Pattern.  So, there are 18 books but one is redundant, one is a translation, and the other 16 are fictional works by van Gulik.

Dutch diplomat and sinologist Robert Hans van Gulik (1910-67) apparently wrote 18 books as the fictional exploits of the historical Judge Dee (630-700).  He includes a short Postcript at the end of these (at least in the ones I've read so far) which you might read first--especially if you haven't read any of them before.  He also includes several woodcut type figures which (while not historically accurate) do IMHO enhance these volumes.  He also includes a list of "Dramatis Personae"--especially valuable because many of these books involve simultaneous, multiple cases, and this character list is divided up by case.In this particular work, Judge Dee is travelling in another district than his own (actually several of the Dee books have this type of setting--outside his own district due to traveling).  In such cases he generally doesn't have his entire coterie of 4 assistants, but only one or two.  In this book, he's only accompanied by Ma Joong (reminds me of Mah Jong which my Mom used to play) who amazingly demonstrates his gold interior as a foil to his rough and ready exterior.  Both men get involved (in startlingly different ways) with the courtesans of Paradise Island--ancient China's predecessor to Las Vegas.  As usual Dee has 3 puzzling, non-obvious, cases to solve--with vested interests attempting to sway his judgment.  And, as usual, the tales/cases are very enjoyable and quite satisfying--especially for readers more interested in straight mystery vs. action/adventure/thrillers.  As a great fan of the British Golden Age of Mysteries, I greatly enjoy the van Gulik books and plan to read them all--have several on order at Amazon now.The 18 Judge Dee books I've found are (in alphabetical order, ignoring "the"): Celebrated Cases of Judge Dee, The Chinese Bell Murders, The Chinese Gold Murders, The Chinese Lake Murders, The Chinese Maze Murders, The Chinese Nail Murders, The Emperor's Pearl, The Haunted Monastery, Judge Dee at Work, The Lacquer Screen, The Monkey & the Tiger, Murder in Canton, Murder in Ancient China, Necklace & Calabash, The Phantom of the Temple, Poets & Murder, The Red Pavilion, and The Willow Pattern

It's easy to trace Margery Allingham's development as a mystery writer.  First she published an adventure about smugglers in "Blackkerchief Dick," then her first (serialized) murder mystery, "The White Cottage Mystery," then her first murder mystery with Albert Campion (not the center of the stage though) in "The Crime at Black Dudley" (aka "The Black Dudley Murder"), and then a series of 18 more mystery novels starring Campion (the last, "A Cargo of Eagles" which, interestingly, includes smugglers completed by her husband Phillip Youngman Carter).  Along the way, she also published several (very enjoyable IMHO) short story collections (e.g. "Mr. Campion and Others").This is a nice armchair or cozy British mystery with little action but lots of thinking and hypotheses.  It reads easily and quickly though it does drag somewhat after the middle--when the characters relocate to the French Riviera.  The reader can figure out the killer, but only after reading the bulk of the book.  Of course, as a novella, it lacks space for a larger character development, and as a between-the-wars novel, it includes far different attitudes (especially towards women) than are observed in the West today.  This demonstrates, IMHO, how western civilization has progressed since then.Its also includes some psychological reasoning as well as a fine quotation for my collection:p. 155: "A child only knows what it is told.  The difference between God and the Devil is only clear to it because it has been told that God is good and Satan is bad."  It's unfortunate, IMHO--as opposed to the characters in this book--that most folks don't revisit childish views and opinions and understandings once reaching adulthood.  If they did, there might be far more tolerance in the world.

After Margery Allingham's demise, her husband Youngman Carter, who did at least to some degree collaborate on her books, completed her last, unfinished novel, Campion #19 and then wrote 2 Campion books on his own.  The first was entitled "Mr. Campion's Farthing."  The present volume is his 2nd (and apparently final) work.  It's a good, complex story.  While there is a murder to solve, the main mystery seems to be what Mr. Porteus is looking for.  Unfortunately, it seems impossible for the reader to unravel this on his/her own, making the book something of an adventure rather than a mystery--though it's written in a mystery style.  Call it what you will.  I don't think the style is the same as in Margery Allingham's works, but it's a reasonable replica thereof.  There are differences: e.g. Campion drives a Jaguar in this book.  There are similarities too: Miss Peregrine is a feisty (and IMHO an engaging) lady and Makepeace a humorous, eccentric character.  For Campion aficionados, however, there's no Lugg, Oates, Luke, or (my personal favorite) Amanda Fitton--except for a phone call.  Still, it's an enjoyable book unless, perhaps, you're a purist.  Enjoy!  p.s. unlike the vast majority of Allingham's works, I didn't get any quotes for my collection from this book.

Dutch diplomat Robert Hans van Gulik (1910-67) apparently wrote 18 books as the fictional exploits of the historical Judge Dee (630-700).  He includes a short Postcript at the end of these (at least in the 5 I've read so far) which you might read first--especially if you haven't read any of them before.  He also includes several woodcut type figures which (while not historically accurate) do IMHO enhance these volumes.  He also includes a cast of characters--especially valuable because many of these books involve simultaneous, multiple cases and the character list is divided up by the case.In this particular work, Judge Dee is travelling in another district than his own (actually several of the Dee books have this type of setting--e.g. The Red Pavilion).  But, in this case, in addition to the usual murders, he's involved with both a Taoist monk of considerable spiritual development and with an Imperial Princess.  The intricacies of the Water Palace and its politics spice up this book considerably though I'm unsure how accurate the details though van Gulik was a noted Sinologist.  But as usual, the tales are very enjoyable and quite satisfying--especially for readers more interested in straight mystery vs. action/adventure.I especially liked a quotation:  "A gourd becomes useful only after it has been emptied.  For then its dry rind may serve a a container.  The same goes for us, magistrate.  It's only after we have been emptied of all our vain hopes, all our petty desires and cherished illusions, that we can be useful to others" by the Taoist monk.The 18 Judge Dee books I've found are (in alphabetical order, ignoring "the": Celebrated Cases of Judge Dee, The Chinese Bell Murders, The Chinese Gold Murders, The Chinese Lake Murders, The Chinese Maze Murders, The Chinese Nail Murders, The Emperor's Pearl, The Haunted Monastery, Judge Dee at Work, The Lacquer Screen, The Monkey & the Tiger, Murder in Canton, Murder in Ancient China, Necklace & Calabash, The Phantom of the Temple, Poets & Murder, The Red Pavilion, The Willow Pattern

Renowned orientalist and former Netherlands Ambassador to Japan Robert van Gulik has now published quite a few Judge Dee novels.  Judge Dee was an historical person who lived from 630-700 AD and served as a magistrate (as in these novels) and later in the central government of the Tang Dynasty in China.  Van Gulik includes further information in his Postscript which I recommend reading first -- especially if this is your 1st Judge Dee book.  It was my 3rd and I like them more and more.  Strangely, there is no obvious copyright date--though the Postscript is dated 30 December 1961.These novels take place earlier than Ingrid J. Parker's Sugawara Akitada series which takes place in perhaps 11th century Japan but they are similar to them to a certain extent--relying more on logic and atmosphere than on a lot of action--thus, they are, IMHO, true mysteries--something like Doyle's Sherlock Holmes or Rex Stout's Nero Wolfe as opposed to Laura Joh Rowland's Sano Ichiro series (around 1700 AD in Japan) which is more action-adventure incorporating some mystery.  Also, van Gulik's works explain the ancient Chinese judicial methods -- rather different than our modern ones.  I find these works, especially this one, to be quite satisfying and enjoyable, and look forward to reading many more.Despite the differences in culture, there are similarities to modernity: logic is, after all, logic.  There's a bit of scientific thinking in this book, e.g. p. 21: "Once he had established his theory, he adapted every new fact to it, instead of testing whether these new facts should not make him revise his theory."

Margery Allingham wrote this, her first novel, at an early age--but she came from a very literary family.  It was written before she tried her hand at mystery novels.  I believe both this and the following The White Cottage Mystery (her next effort which was a mystery) have been unavailable until recently, but Bloomsbury has issued both.  I am about to start the latter (which BTW is pre-Campion).  So, her writing progressed from novel to mystery to Campion mysteries (for which she is famous as a member of the British Golden Age of Mystery."Blackkerchief Dick" gets its name from the main character (who is quite a character) who wears a black kerchief over his hair.  Compared to the other characters he's quite a dandy.  The novel, while set on an island frequented by smugglers is mostly about a love triangle--Blackkerchief Dick, his rival Hal, and Anny (the latter two work at The Ship).  It includes a host of characters ranging from very nice to very selfish.I found it a relatively slow read and seemingly somewhat predictable--until the end.  Similar to a mystery novel, there's a twist or two there which I certainly didn't expect.  The light and dark are juxtaposed with fate--including a situation reminiscent of "Hamlet" for Hal.  "The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune..." apply here.  This fairy tale is more Grimm's than Hans Christian Anderson's.  A quote from the book is also an appropriate addition to my quotes collection: p. 214: "The Lord gave women tears that their hearts might not break every day."

This is a large format, glossy, coffee table type book.  While it features some witty repartee between Robert and Joan Parker, the value of it lies in the wonderful photography.  There isn't, however, a lot of insight into the racing world in the text except to describe the food!  The original price of $35 may be steep to some, but coffee table books tend to be rather dear.I bought it because I've read all 69 of Robert B. Parker's fiction books but none of his non-fiction till now.  This is one of his 3 non-fiction books (all co-authored with his wife Joan).  The other 2 are "Three Weeks in Spring" and "Training With Weights."I do wonder if, perhaps, Parker's great Spencer-Susan dialog didn't evolve from his actual dialog with his wife Joan.

Not all the stories in this book are murders, but they all tie into XMAS in some way and are all mysteries.  They vary a bit in quality but cover a wide variety of authors, styles, and content.  It's a fast read of the 374 pages.  I got it because it has 3 Marjorie Allingham short stories.  It includes (surname order is mine) 32 tales and an introduction:Thomas Larry Adcock: XMAS CopMargery Allingham: The Case is Altered; On XMAS Day in the Morning; Murder Under the MistletoeGeorge Baxt: I Saw Mommy Killing Santa ClausLawrence Block: As Dark as XMAS getsAnthony Boucher: Mystery for XMASAnn Cleves: A Winter's TaleSir Arthur Conan Doyle: The Adventure of the Blue CarbuncleEnnis Duling: The Embezzler's XMAS PresentRon Goulart: Believing in SantaMalcolm Gray: Miss Crindle & Father XMASEdward D. Hoch: The Theft of the XMAS Stocking; The Spy & the XMAS Cipher; The Theft of Santa's BeardPeter Lovesey: Supper with Miss Shivers; Pass the ParcelJohn D. MacDonald: Dead on XMAS St.John Mortimer: Rumpole & the Spirit of XMAS; Rumpole & the Chambers PartyPatricia Moyes: Who Killed Father XMAS?Francis M. Nevins: The Shape of the NightmareJames Powell: Grist for the Mills of XMAS; Santa's WayHerbert Resnicow: The XMAS BearJeffry Scott: Inspector Tierce & the XMAS VisitsGeorges Simenon: A Matter of Life & DeathRex Stout: Santa Claus BeatDan Stumpf: White Like the SnowRobert Turner: XMAS GiftJacqueline Vivelo: Appalachian BlackmailMartin Werner: XMAS PartySome authors were previously unknown to me while others (Stout, Doyle, Allingham) were well known to me.  I'm giving it 5* partly because it's so inexpensive and a holiday treat; Enjoy!

While it's not the fastest moving mystery, I found this book engaging and very enjoyable.  The characters, while something of a parody perhaps, were IHO quite interesting, especially Great Aunt Caroline--see page 14 for a genealogical table of the residents of Socrates Close (the home of most of the characters).  There's also a chart of the rooms of this house and grounds on page 138.  I thought the mystery was clever and the writing very good, if not as beautiful as Ngaio Marsh's.  But, I think its individual claim to fame lies in its psychological commentary or analysis of human faults:p. 73: "If a man is not worthy of responsibilities at 30 there is very little likelihood of his ever attaining to that station.p. 106: Beneath the rigid bond of repression, human nature had begun to ferment, decay,  to become vile.pp. 198-9: Every man, however, unworthy, can engender an undying spark of affection in the heart of some unlikely woman.p. 282: He was so mentally short-sighted that he was not capable of foreseeing the most ordinary consequences of his actions other than the immediate effect of which he was aiming.  I think his insanity lay largely in the possession of this particular blind spot.p. 289: There is a primitive strain in us all, which makes us a little afraid of the clothes of the dead."This is IMHO most profoundly obvious in the p. 282 quotation above which, despite the author's seeming intention to apply it only to one of the characters, seems to my mind to apply, in varying degree, to many of us.  I think Jung would say it's an extremely "sensate" personality which exemplified this (per his "Psychological Types" or The Myers-Briggs Type Indicator).  It points to a lack of vision, associative power, or perhaps the ability to step outside oneself and see what is, without regard to one's own existence.  In any case, I enjoyed Caroline and the book very much--especially as compared with many mysteries being published today.

This is a can of Yellow fin tuna packed in olive oil  Yellow fin tastes differently than either blue fin or the albacore (which is what you get in the usual can of tuna from the supermarket.  I've been in aquariums which had profiles of various fish and was amazed how different the 3 tunas actually look in profile.  Without a doubt, I like yellow fin the best.  The Bumble Bee is a high quality product though certainly some folks prefer other tunas and water vs. oil packed cans as well.  I prefer the oil packed because I use the tuna to stir fry--pouring in the oil first, then veggies, and finally the tuna.  Yum!  I would give this product 5 stars for quality, but I'm only giving it 4 because of the price.  I've been eating the Genova brand for quite some time--also Tonno Yellow fin packed in olive oil and about the same quality IMHO.  But, it's quite a bit less expensive even on Amazon--about $1.85/5 oz can vs. the $2.50 or so here.  But this price difference could certainly change.  Enjoy!  p.s. this tuna is high in omega 3 oil similar to salmon though I'm not certain which has more of it.

The 23rd Alphabet Mystery is a bit slower paced than many of the others--and is longer as well--these two factors go together here.  Kinsey seems less assertive yet quite philosophical herein.  I wouldn't normally review a book that's been reviewed so many times, but I think something needs to be said about the wisdom of this particular work and its treatment of the homeless.  Firstly, Grafton is addressing the homeless as those who choose to be so, not someone who's just lost their home to foreclosure.  What she's stressing is that the chosen homeless have dignity and that our reaction to them has more to do with ourselves than with them--indeed, such reactions, objectively speaking, might appear a bit hypocritical to an outside observer.  Some of her great turns of phrase and pithy philosophical statements (especially regarding the homeless) include:p. 9: Sometimes the import of a minor moment makes all the difference.p. 15: A gloat-worthy turn of events.p. 16: Even for nomad, the urge toward ownership is apparently irresistible.  Regardless, of social status, we derive comfort from our stuff; the familiar ways and weft of our lives.p. 27: Being rule governed, I operate in a world filled with imagining restraints.p. 59: There's something inherent in human nature that has us constructing narratives to explain a world that is otherwise chaotic and opaque.  Life is little more than a series of overlapping stories about who we are, where we came from, and how we struggle to survive.  What we call news isn't new at all...It's folly to assign meaning to every chance event yet we do it all the time.p. 129: This was like winning the lottery without buying a ticket.p. 220: Watching her drink was like watching roses bloom by way of time-lapse photography.p. 226: Being righteous and opinionated reduces everything to black and white; much easier to deal with than all the shade in between.p. 286: Like many whose poor choices have led them astray, he accepted no responsibility as long as he had someone else to blame. [projection]p. 336: Kids are egocentric.  Parents exist for their convenience.p. 473: Do not argue with a lunatic.  Arguing with a lunatic simply ensures that you'll dive into his craziness with him when what you want to do is take a big step back.pp. 482-3: We seem determined to save the homeless, to fix them, to change them into something other than what they are.  We want them to be like us, but they are not.  The homeless do not want our pity nor do they deserve our scorn.  Our judgments about them, for good or for ill, negate their urge to live as they please.  Both the urge to rescue and the need to condemn fail to take into account the concept of their personal liberty, which they may exercise as they see fit as long as their actions fall within the law.  The homeless are not lesser mortals...Why are their choices so hard for us to accept?

First rate mysteries without the murder--I found this refreshing.  While Amanda and Lugg are lacking in the stories, Superintendent Oates is the main supporting character.  The 13 stories are quite clever and IMHO satisfying, and many are humorous as well.  Campion is in fine form, as stated on page 237: 'You're too bright,' he said.  'You'll blind yourself one of these days.'  The most unusual feature, to my way of thinking, is the relationship between Campion and Oates--perhaps not as warm as some of the later Campion works.  BTW, this is not considered a numbered Campion book, but was published between #10, "The Fashion in Shrouds" and #11, "Traitor's Purse" -- two of her best IMHO.  Admittedly, if you prefer novels, you might not appreciate this book as much as I did, but I think things should be evaluated within their own context (in this case the short story).  Otherwise, very few books would rate 5 stars (or maybe even 4) vs. Shakespeare or Hemingway etc.For additional Campion short stories, Omnibus #1, The Mysterious Mr Campion, and Omnibus #2, Mr Campion's Lady each have 3 novels plus a Christmas story.  Also, The Allingham Minibus is a collection of Allingham's short stories.

This was my first Martha Grimes book, and I have somewhat mixed feelings about it.On the down side:--it's rather slow moving, especially at first--it has lots of presumably British expressions or word usages that are quite unfamiliar (though I've read all of Agatha Christie, Dorothy Sayers, Josephine Tey, Ngaio Marsh, P. D. James, and most of Margery Allingham).  "Polishing the optics" perhaps means the mirrors?  Closest I could find in my dictionary--seems a stretch to me..--there's quite a bit of snooker specifics especially in the final chapter where it's very detailed indeed.  I haven't a clue about that though.On neutral ground:--the mystery slowly unfolds, but the reader doesn't, IMHO, really have much of a chance to figure it out.  It is, however, rather clever especially if you have some understanding of the British peerage.On the up side:--I actually laughed out loud several times.  Grimes is quite humorous, especially with her dialogue. It's first rate, funnier than Robert B. Parker's (though his is more consistently crisp).--several quotes for my collection (page numbers from the edition given):from Martha Grimes Jerusalem Inn Onyx/New American Library NY 1984--p. 125: Was it a mere coincidence that whenever Agatha approached, one thought of shooting something?  Aunts or antelopes, it was all the same.p. 168: It's amazing, really, how much people think you must know if you know about something nobody else much cares about.p. 234: A dress designed to make its wearer look simple and countrified, as if she'd just come in from milking silver-plated cows.

This short book is a fast read--it's fun reading and full of twists and turns and false explanations etc.  It was nice to follow up on Inspector Queen's Own Case : November Song (BCE) with this one in which the inspector joins his new wife.  He is the lead through most of the book and discovers lots of deceptions and creates several explanations.  Of course, Ellery comes in to finish up.  However, that's my only hang-up with the book--why not 5 stars?  The ending left me kind of cold.  After all that build-up...not too satisfying IMHO.  But, maybe you'll love it?

I greatly enjoyed reading this book--it holds your interest even through the chases, but I think it is a bit hokey.  My two criticisms are:1. I think it borders on cheating to cover the killer's inconsistencies/irrationalities by saying he's insane (but not too insane to cleverly commit murders and stand trial).2. While minor errors by the murderer might very well lead to his/her capture, they're not necessarily sufficient to convince a jury of guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.  I think there's reasonable doubt here.  I'm certain a good defense attorney could come up with alternate explanations of the evidence despite Queen's statement that p. 231: "the reader is in possession of all facts necessary to a correct solution of the crime or crimes.  The Egyptian Cross Mystery is no exception: by the exercise of strict logic and deductions from given date you should now be able, not merely to guess, but to prove the identity of the culprit.  There are no ifs and buts in the only proper solution..."  Regrets, but I don't think that's true in this case.

Helen Brann, Parker's literary agent completed a partially written manuscript that Robert B. Parker was composing before his death.  It apparently, needed an ending and editing as well.  How close to final copy it was, I don't know.  Obviously, it cannot be 100% authentic Parker, but she seems to have done a pretty good job.  The writing is close to Parker's other novels IMHO though, of course, readers can take exception to phraseology etc.  No doubt Parker's other works were edited and not merely published from his manuscripts.  The ending is rather abrupt, but some of Parker's other novels ended rather abruptly too--after all, in 70+ novels there was quite a bit of variation.  Indeed, relative to his later style, this book is closer than his early style was--just consider the nature of Spenser and his dialogue.  Of course, purists will object to every variation in jot and tittle, fine for them.  But many will enjoy this book even if it's not 100% Parker.  It would be interesting to know on what chapter the original manuscript ended.  I believe that even die-hard fans will vary in guessing the answer.There is, however, one very great variance from Parker's prior works, a big humanistic change to Hawk towards the end.  Some people will love it as a character development and others may hate it as a variance from pure Parker.  I have no idea if he wrote it or Brann did.  I suspect the latter.  Also, it's rather short--but then several of Parker's earlier works were short as well.  Writers tend to write longer books as time goes on--especially when they become successful.  I've also read the two extant Ace Atkins Spenser books.  The first one, Robert B. Parker's Lullaby (Spenser), was a far cry from Spenserian dialogue--I found that disappointing.This book is far closer to Parker.  However, Atkins' 2nd work, Robert B. Parker's Wonderland (Spenser), was much closer to Parker's Spenser IMHO.  I haven't read the post-Parker Chief Stone or Cole/Hitch books, so am unable to comment on them.  Hopefully, readers find them enjoyable.  Interestingly, Parker himself obviously approved of completing another writer's manuscript since he did so himself with Poodle Springs in which he completed a Raymond Chandler Philip Marlowe work.  Also, he wrote an original Philip Marlowe novel after Chandler's death--Perchance to Dream, a sequel to Chandler's The Big Sleep (Vintage Crime/Black Lizard).  Basically, it's up to you to decide if you want to stick with pure Parker or to seek solace in this book and other authors' continuations of Parker characters.  But, if you don't choose to read them, I wish you luck in finding something as good or better!I did get one quotation for my collection from this book: p. 108: "You know how easy it is to throw everything away when you never had anything to begin with?"

I've been drinking various brands of Earl Grey tea for decades, in the States, in England, etc.  It usually taste pretty much the same except for the strength and quality.  I drink tea (except for iced tea) straight up--no sweetener, no milk, no lemon, or anything else in it.  I also like Darjeeling, Green, and Jasmine teas.  I have, of course, had Lipton teas--even in hotel rooms--Lipton Yellow Label Tea Bags 100ct which is the best general type I've had IMHO.  Very nice.  I've also had teas in pyramid bags before (theoretically they should have more surface area and thus more flavor but they don't taste any different).But, I have to say that the product in hand is the strangest Earl Grey I've ever had.  The contents are: "orange pekoe and pekoe cut black tea, marigold flowers, natural flavors."  Yet on the front of the box it says: "black tea made with premium long-leaf Earl Grey with bergamot flavor with other natural flavor."  So bergamot (the substance that makes Earl Grey unique) is advertised but not listed on the ingredients list--is it an "other natural flavor?"  Obviously, they use more marigold flowers than bergamot, if they use bergamot at all.  Or, maybe they have a small amount but the marigold changes the flavor?On the bright side, it doesn't taste bad--just strange and not like other Earl Grey teas.  I do like their mentioning that it contains 25mg of caffeine per serving and 115mg of flavenoids (compared to 58 in orange juice, 11 in pomegranate juice, and .4 in coffee).  Wow, I didn't know coffee had any in it.  Yay coffee!  As for Earl Grey, I'll stick with my Amazon Twinings Earl Grey Tea, Tea Bags, 50-Count Boxes (Pack of 6)--a fine tea at a great price and it is made with "black tea with bergamot flavor."

Basically, it's a can of nice quality albacore tuna with some pieces of jalapeno pepper in it.  I wasn't surprised that the heat was not overwhelming.  It does taste very good--I ate it straight from the can as a snack--didn't really need to drink much liquid with it.  The oil seems good as well.  It seems a bit pricey though.  You can easily buy canned tuna and a jar of jalapeno peppers... Still it was an enjoyable experience for me and, IMHO, an interesting idea.  But, I mostly stir fry using canned tuna or salmon and add my own jalapeno (and other peppers) and lots of veggies--so it won't help much for that.  But, as a snack it's quite nice.  Also, if you are making tuna salad and want a different flavor--and a small kick to it--you might try out this product.
