I received this item free for a no-obligation review. I really wasn't sure what to expect from it as I've never had this type of thing before.I got the Istanbul print, which is really pretty and the colors are quite true to the picture. I live in a windy place -- and it's especially windy this time of year -- so I primarily got it to wear around my neck.There are no seams; it's seamless all the way around. I like that because there are no seams to scratch the sensitive skin on my neck, and there is no front or back. There are also no logos; it's just the print which I like a lot.The ends do roll a bit, a little annoying but not a deal breaker for me. I think it's just how this type of fabric (microfiber knit) behaves. I haven't been able to figure out how to achieve all 12 styles with this -- but I only care about 2 or 3 of them anyway!Overall I like this a lot. It keeps my neck protected in the cold wind without my having to worry about a scarf getting unwound from my neck or getting in the way. Going to get a lot more use out of it through the rest of the fall, and in winter and spring too --

I received a free sample to try out so I could share my experience with it in a review. I wasn't sure what to expect. Here's what I found.It is a heavyweight black glass jar, with the white logo (super cool logo) and the "Dope Turtle" name on the back.What sets this apart from other jars is its weight, and its quality. It is nicely made and perfectly smooth -- the top is nicely finished plastic, and it twists on and off with no hesitation or catching. So easy. But it also fastens really tightly.So, given how secure it is, it keeps the scent of your herb inside the jar where it belongs. No one is going to walk into the room and know what you've got in there. :-)Not only does it keep the scent from getting out -- but it also keeps light and air from getting in. Light and air will deteriorate almost anything given enough time, and plant matter is especially vulnerable. So the black color -- aside from looking good -- actually serves a function. It protects from UV rays.It's also a good size -- holds plenty!It feels substantial in the hand, too -- and the thickness of the glass makes me feel confident it's not going to break easily. There is nothing cheap about this and it protects its contents (which weren't cheap either!) very, very well.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and point out any issues and rate accordingly -- but can't find anything not to like about this. I'm thinking it would make a great holiday gift too (maybe with something tucked inside...) and I may just do that. I am glad to have this.

I received a free sample to try out, so I could, optionally, share my experience with it in a review. I wasn't sure what to expect as I've never had anything quite like this before, and wasn't sure to expect from this brand, either.It is a bright green! It's a fun color but also practical because it's very easy to see in a dark purse or pack, or in the car's console.I have used a number of power banks / portable chargers before and like to keep one with me for those times when my phone's battery is running low and I'm not near an outlet or don't have time to wait for it to charge up. This has plenty of juice to charge a small device like a phone or tablet. It is compact so travels well in a bag or in the car without taking much room.But this power bank isn't like others, because it also has a light, and a humidifier. When you turn it on, the humidifier draws a little water from the small chamber near the top of the unit, and sends it out a valve on the side, ina very fine mist. Really refreshing on a summer day, or if you just feel warm and want a little refreshing spritz. It is a very fine mist so even though the water chamber is small, the water lasts quite a while. The light is blue and shines through the water. Really pretty!This is such a unique item and one that I find very useful. I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and point out any issues, and rate accordingly -- but couldn't find anything not to like about this. I've had it for almost a month now, and am really getting a lot of use out of it; it has a home in my purse right alongside my phone.

I received this free so I could try it out, and share my experience in a review. I wasn't sure what to expect as I haven't used a headlamp before -- and this brand was unknown to me.It is quite adjustable to the right head size. I'd worried that it would be heavy -- but it isn't really; it didn't weigh me down. I found it quite comfortable and it stayed secure on my head.We do a lot of DIY projects and sometimes it's hard to get a regular flashlight to point just at the right place. This is great because the light shines exactly where you're looking.By spinning a ring around the light, you can also adjust it into a wide or narrow beam. And, there are 3 modes: regular light, brighter light, and flashing light.It is really good for tight spaces, and projects where your hands are occupied with something else. I wish I had had one of these years ago. I recently cleaned 2 sets of dusty old antique drawers. This allows me to see into the dark recesses, underneath the drawers to get it looking good again. I'm planning on replacing a bathroom faucet, and this is going to be helpful for seeing the plumbing under the cabinet.My husband says it's good for working on the car -- he can get a good, strong directed light under the hood where it's hard to get good lighting.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and always point out any issues, and rate accordingly -- but couldn't find anything not to like about this headlamp. It is well-made, makes my life easier and I am glad to have it.

I received a free sample to try out so I could share my experience in a review. I've used many Lightning cables over the past couple years, some much better than others. I wasn't familiar with this brand and wasn't sure what to expect -- so I was curious to try it, and hoped for the best.Turns out, this works really well.It seems like I'm forever rummaging around in the car searching through our console, glove box and my purse, for my Lightning cable. This is super easy, because it's small and can just be clipped to a keychain with a lobster clasp. And it's useful not just in the car; as long as I have my keys with me I have a cable. This is such a simple solution to the problem. It takes very little room.This cable is MFi certified (I double-checked on Apple's website that it really is) meaning that it will continue to work through future iOS updates and won't eventually throw errors like the non-certified cables often do.It is well-made and charged my Apple devices quickly, no problems at all. The design is really clever and I wish I'd had one of these long ago. I'm glad I took a chance on it.

I received a free set of headphones so I could share my experience with them in a review. I really wasn't sure what to expect as I wasn't familiar with this brand of headphones. I've used quite a few in the past and some have been better than others. I was curious to see how these would compare.Turns out, this is one of the better ones I've tried. The sound is remarkably good, especially in this price range. Most of the others I've tested are very bass-shy. Not these. Not expecting these to have much bass, I was surprised that they did. Wow.I first played one of my favorite Bob Dylan albums -- I've been listening to it for 30 years now and know every note by heart. These headphones did right by it; those notes sounded just like I expected them to. I then listened to the new albums by Prince and Janet Jackson, then Jack White, Beck, Miles Davis, Jefferson Airplane, Uncle Tupelo and the Grateful Dead. Quite a range of musical styles and it all sounded great.The sound is very clear and doesn't distort at higher volumes. Midtones and trebles are clear and true. And the bass...amazingly to me it's really good.Some attention was given to aesthetics with these, too. The red and black is very attractive, and it comes in a matching carrying case. The carrying case zippers shut to keep them protected. I also found these comfortable to wear, and to adjust. A little more padding might be nice, but that's a nitpick.I'm not a hardcore audiophile, but music is important to me and I think life is too short to listen on tinny headphones. If you are into really high-end audio gear you will probably want something else. But for the rest of us, these are an excellent pick. I always cast a critical eye (an ear!) over the items I use and review -- and point out any issues I come across and rate accordingly -- but I couldn't find anything not to like about these. They are my new favorites.Update: These sure block out a lot of sound when you have the sound cranked up. I was rocking out, while doing some housework in the entry of our home, while wearing these. My husband came through the door, slammed it, tried to talk to me -- very loudly -- (I had my back turned) and when I finally turned and saw him, I must have jumped two feet high. He said he couldn't hear what I was listening to. So they block sound pretty good both ways! :-)

I received a free set of these, and wasn't sure what to expect, quality-wise as it was my first experience buying knobs of this brand.When I first took them out of the box, I was confused because they didn't look clear and the edges looked indistinct. But -- then I realized that each is covered in a thin layer of protective plastic. Once I pulled that off, wow! They were crystal clear and really sparkle! And that is what I wanted. At the widest edge the cut isn't very sharp but I don't find that very noticeable. The silver finish is very good.I had two purposes in mind for these -- a small antique cabinet which I painted last summer needed new knobs. These are the right size and, I think, just the right finishing touch. Its original antique knobs had gotten chipped over the years and these are a good replacement.I also have a small wooden freestanding cabinet I use in a bathroom -- replacing the old drawer pull with one of these gave it an instant makeover. My third project was replacing the worn wooden knobs on an old maple hutch I've been meaning to refinish (in the meantime these gave it more energy). The hutch is what the photo below represents.If you have thick doors or drawers you may need to buy longer screws. Each screw is 1 inch long and will go into the knob as much as 1/4" inch. So it is ideal for 3/4" inch thick drawers / doors, or just slightly thicker.I am happy to have these and they worked really well for my projects.

I recently was given a free bottle of this to try out, so I could share my experience with it in a review. Honestly, it's kind of hard to review because it's hard to tell if it's working or not.But -- I ran across a web article about how most people are at least somewhat deficient in magnesium, and the symptoms of magnesium deficiency sounded very familiar to me, because I had many of them. I haven't been tested by a doctor but figured it was worth trying magnesium.As of yet I haven't seen any big changes. But I imagine I probably need to take it longer -- probably need to get through the bottle - to give it time to work. I'll give it a fair chance.The capsules are lightweight, not too big, and easy to take. (That's good because I have a hard time with big, hard pills -- and this certainly is not one of those.) They don't have a strong, obnoxious odor -- it is mild.The jury's still out on this, but given everything I've read about it I feel good about taking it and will continue to do so.

I received a free set of these to try out, so I could share my experience in a review. I wasn't sure what to expect and was curious to try them out..We have two smartphones. One is newer and these fit that phone great. The other is an older one with a slide-out keyboard. The clip went over our new one very well -- but the ancient one was a little too thick. That's OK and as expected. On our primary smartphone, the lens fit fine even with a case on it.The set comes packaged in a really nice little case that keeps everything safe and organized.But how's the quality?Well, very good. I was worried that putting an external lens over my phone's lens would add some blur. But it didn't -- the photos were very clear with no blur or distortion.I take a lot of photos with my phone but am always a little frustrated at the lack of options. These lenses have given me a lot more possibilities. I'm mostly using the macro lenses but the fisheye is a nice option to have for those times when you want that.I am glad I took a chance on this set and will continue to get a lot of use out of them.

I received the book for free, so I could share my honest opinion of it after reading it. As a web developer I've read a lot of technical books over the years and was curious to see what this one was like.I'm a longtime web developer, building sites mostly on WordPress, which runs on a database. Though I can find my way around the WordPress database, I have never really studied SQL. I don't like having that gap in my knowledge and wanted to get up to speed.The author writes pretty well and starts from the beginning, explaining what a database is. From there he explains the basics of SQL, walking the reader through the various topics using a widely available Microsoft Access sample database as an example.Honestly, the book didn't answer all my newbie-type questions and I have looked up some other resources (available online) as I try to learn this subject. But it does bill itself as a beginner's guide and at only 54 pages of text I didn't expect great depth anyway. It is, as the title suggests, a place to start and covers the topics it addresses pretty well. I found it useful.

I received a free easel to try out, with no obligation, so I could relate my experience -- good or bad -- with it in a review. I make collages, and also like to display framed art and prints and own several types of easels. I was curious to try this tabletop easel out.When it arrived I was surprised at how small a size it folds to -- very compact. It could fit in a tote bag or a backpack, and also stores easily (as someone with less storage space than I would like, I appreciate that).It is fairly lightweight. So it's easily portable, if you need to take it to a show or class or presentation. I'm just using it at home for now, but it's nice to have the option.It is quite sturdy.If I were putting the easel in a situation where it would be heavily jostled I might go for a heavier duty one -- but for other purposes it works nicely. It can hold up to 5 pounds, quite a lot for its size.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and point out any issues and rate accordingly -- but I couldn't find anything not to like about this easel. It has met all my expectations.

I received a free bottle of spray to try out, so I could share my experience with it in a review. I've used two other scents of Mask before, but not this one. The first bottle we got is all but empty -- we use it almost every day -- so I was curious to try this one to see if it would be a good replacement.I didn't know what to expect from "Santorini Breeze" -- and have no idea if it smells like a Greek island (though I like to think it does) -- but it does smell really pleasant, and fresh and cleanAs we discovered with the other two bottles we have had, a little of this spray goes a long way. We do just 4 spritzes into the toilet bowl before, well, you know, and it forms a barrier that nothing can escape.I was skeptical but it really does work. Although I think this scent doesn't work quite as well as the other ones we've used from this company. Close, but not quite.The bottles of spray have lasted quite a long time for us. We have one in each of two bathrooms -- neither of which has really good air flow -- and it has really helped; it just keeps those nasty smells from wafting up. And in a tiny bathroom that's really appreciated!There's nothing I don't like about this spray and it has certainly made our two small bathrooms more pleasant to step into!

I received a free pack of these to try out so I coul share my experience in a review. I have tried other cable clips / cable dots before but not this brand, and wasn't sure what to expect.They come in a pack of six. I received two black, two blue, a green and a purple one. They are very lightweight, and unlike some others I've used, can each handle three cords.The first thing I did was stick one to my laptop. I am not crazy about the placement of the power cord on my laptop -- it's on the back on the right, and I plug it into an outlet that is to my left. So the cord often droops down or gets in the way -- and I have tripped on it more than once when I get up. I stuck a cable clip to the back of my laptop near the bottom of the cover opposite where the cord plugs in and it keeps that cord out of the way. Perfect.I also put two in my office, where charging cables tend to fall down and I have to get on my hands and knees and search for them behind the desk.Do note that the sticky mounting foam on these is not repositionable -- so be sure you have it in the right place before you put it on. (If you goof, and you have some mounting tape / foam around the house, that could easily be used, though.) I learned this the hard way.I really like these -- they are light, soft, and it is easy to get the cables in and out of them, yet they hold them snug enough to keep them in line. Overall I am really pleased with them and they compare well to others I've owned.

I was given a free jump rope to try out so I could share my experience with it in a review. I wasn't sure what to expect, as I wasn't familiar with this brand and was curious to see how it would perform.This is the third jump rope I've owned. The first I bought at local sporting goods store, but it turned out to be much too long (I'm 5' 5") and not adjustable. The second looked much like this one and was adjustable, but the rope itself was a little stiff.So I was curious to try this one out, and it turns out that it was a good choice. The handles are comfortable to hold and the foam means they don't get sweaty and slip out of my hands. It is adjustable to the right length. And the rope itself is softer and more flexible than the other one I bought recently -- it straightened out pretty fast after I received it.So, after three jump ropes, we have a winner! I recently got more serious about getting fit after hitting a milestone birthday jump roping is such good exercise. This is what I needed for that.

I received a free set of these to try out, so I could share my experience in a review. I wasn't sure what to expect and was curious to try them out..We have two smartphones. One is newer and these fit that phone great. The other is an older one with a slide-out keyboard. The clip went over our new one very well -- but the ancient one was a little too thick. That's OK and as expected. On our primary smartphone, the lens fit fine even with a case on it.The set comes packaged in a really nice little case that keeps everything safe and organized.But how's the quality?Well, very good. I was worried that putting an external lens over my phone's lens would add some blur. But it didn't -- the photos were very clear with no blur or distortion.I take a lot of photos with my phone but am always a little frustrated at the lack of options. These lenses have given me a lot more possibilities. I'm mostly using the macro lenses but the fisheye is a nice option to have for those times when you want that.I am glad I took a chance on this set and will continue to get a lot of use out of them.

I received a free diffuser to try out, so I could share my experience with it in a review. I wasn't sure what to expect as I've owned quite a few oil diffusers and some definitely work better than others.This is so easy to set up...in a nutshell, you basically fill it with water, add a few drops of essential oil, turn it on and it's good to go. If the mist is turned on, it goes continuously; you can  set a timer for increments from 30 to 180 minutes A border of lights toward the bottom can be turned on or off.I've owned this for several weeks now and have been using it in at the edge of a living room, near a bathroom; it gives a relaxing scent (I've been using lavender or green apple) and can be smelled across the room. It would be good just about anywhere, though! I love the way it smells when I pass by.Two changes that I would wish for:- A volume control, and a selection of sounds to choose from. The sounds are birds (maybe seagulls) and waves. But you can turn the sound on or off.- White. I would really prefer white over the black. Black is inconspicuous, though. But I think white is a little more cheerful.I should also mention that while you can run it for quite a long time, it doesn't take as much space as other diffusers I've used. So, it's good for those of us who are pressed for space, as I am.I am glad to have this diffuser and will be getting lots more use out of it.

I received a free keyboard to test out and to review. As a web developer, I've used a few Bluetooth keyboards before and was curious to see how this one would compare.I like to use a keyboard with my tablet -- not always -- but depending on what I'm doing, it can be easier. So I got this to use with the tablet; it is the perfect size for that. I do prefer a full-size keyboard but when I'm working on a tablet this is the size I want. It is comfortable to use, and pretty quiet, too. They keys are very responsive.It paired super fast with my Kindle HD 8.9" -- I was up and running in a few seconds.Backlighting isn't a necessity, but it is nice. Sometimes I'm working in low light conditions and it really helps me to see what I'm doing. And, of course, it looks cool!The ability to choose the light color is great -- though I usually just have it set on a favorite color. To change the color you hold down the key with a lightbulb icon on it, and move the up or down key. It's really easy.Though it is pretty light weight, it certainly doesn't feel flimsy -- and it seems well-built, with no construction issues. It is easy to carry in a laptop bag or backpack without adding a lot of bulk or weight.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and always point out any issues I discover, and rate accordingly -- but I couldn't find anything not to like about this keyboard. It lived up to all my expectations and is very useful to me.

I received a free strainer to try out so I could share my experience with it in a review. I wasn't sure what to expect -- I've had a lot of tea strainers over the years, but this design was new to me. I was curious to see how it would compare to others I've used.It's stainless steel a polished, shiny finish. The lid twists off and on. It is lightweight but sturdy; It doesn't feel cheap or flimsy like others I've used.This one is also notable because it has a flat bottom and sits at the bottom of the cup. This is great because all the tea stays submerged.The holes are very small so it gives a nice clear cup of tea without leaking loose bits of tea into the cup. It holds plenty enough for a cup of tea with room to spare.It also washes up well. Being stainless steel, it can go in the dishwasher but I find it easier to just give it a good rinse under the kitchen faucet.I have tea strainers which are cuter than this -- but this one sets itself apart because of its thoughtful design; it gives me great cup of tea. I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review, but couldn't find anything not to like about this one. It's working well for me.

I received a free set of these so I could try them out, then share my experience in a review. I have owned a lot of string lights over the years but hadn't had any by this company so wasn't sure what to expect and was curious to try them.The rattan lights are so pretty. They are about an inch and a half across. Half are a creamy white and the other half are a deep reddish brown.The light is beautiful as it shines through them; it is just warm and something about it just reminds me of fall. Though they could easily be used any time of year I'm thinking about incorporating them into my Thanksgiving decorations later this month.There is also a bonus string of teardrop shaped lights, made of bright gold mesh. These are so pretty! There are only 10 lights -- but the length makes it perfect for winding around a smaller wreath, around a small mirror, or to decorate a table or mantel. I'm using them on a table in the entry to my home and it just looks so festive when you walk in! It also occurred to me that they would be good in my office, where I have little space but still like to have a few decorations for the holidays.But these aren't holiday lights, per se -- they can certainly be used anytime. I like that the rattan balls are sort of rustic -- and they come with the gold lights which at more glitzy and sophisticated.Each set takes AA batteries -- the small set takes 2, and the rattan set takes 3. The teardrop lights are solid, but the rattan lights can either shine solid or flashing lights.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use in my home, and review -- and point out any problems I encounter, and rate accordingly -- but there's just nothing I don't like about either of these sets. Really glad to have each of them.

I received a free meter to try out, and to share my experience with it in a review. I wasn't sure what to expect, as I hadn't heard of one of these before. But we have a few houseplants -- and several outdoor plants in pots -- but it's sometimes hard to know if we're watering them enough, or too much. So I thought it was worth a try.My husband is the one who tried it out. He stuck it in the first pot, and wow, the result was instant. I don't know what I was expecting -- maybe to have to wait a minute -- but it registered immediately. That plant, an African violet, was in the clear. So we moved on to a cactus (didn't need water). Everything we tried it on, it registered how we expected it to.And then, we tried it on a problem plant, a tiny seedling we've been trying to grow indoors (a souvenir of a recent road trip to the redwoods). We have done that successfully before with a similar seedling, which grew to over 5 feet tall -- but this one just didn't seem to thrive. Despite our best efforts, it hasn't looked very healthy lately. This meter showed us why. We didn't realize how much we were over-watering it! Every day this meter showed that the soil was absolutely saturated, even when we hadn't watered it every day. We have backed off on watering it -- checking every day or two with the meter -- and it's looking a little better. Very happy about that!On the back of the package are lists of the moisture levels for various plants -- so if they are under the stated levels they should be watered -- and if they are over the level you should back off a little bit. This is such useful knowledge to have.The meter seems very well-constructed. It also has a loop so you could thread it to a hanging loop. To my surprise and pleasure, it's worked flawlessly for us and we are looking forward to getting much more use out of it.

I received a free sample to try out and review. I wasn't sure what to expect, as this brand is new to me. My husband and I like chai a lot, often order it out, and occasionally make it at home. When we make it at home, we usually get Oregon Chai, which is a liquid in a carton. This was our first time making it ourselves from loose tea.When we opened up the package -- which was a little bigger than I expected -- it smelled wonderful, very rich. Before brewing, we shook the package a bit to make sure the spices were mixed in pretty evenly.Afterward, we mixed the brewed tea with a little milk. I loved the way it tasted -- mild but still unmistakably the flavors I've come to associate with chai over the years. You can vary the time the tea is steeped, and/or the amount of milk used, to get a stronger taste if you like. I've tried it a few ways and found a combination that I like very much.Something I haven't seen on other teas -- the bag even has the date that the tea was harvested (a few months ago).I like being able to make real chai at home, without resorting to the premixed liquid stuff! And I love that this is the real deal, imported right from India using an ages-old recipe. Overall we like this tea very much and would happily buy it again.

I received a free shower head to try out so I could share my experience with it in a review. I hadn't heard of this company before and wasn't sure what to expect.I got this to replace a 10-year old shower head which had finally begun to leak. Even the hose had begun to leak! So I was looking for a new one.The pieces screwed together in just a couple minutes. But I ran into an issue with the mount. I didn't realize, when ordering, that the mount has to be permanently screwed into the wall. I had a few problems with that concept:1. The mount doesn't look all that heavy duty -- what happens when it wears out (as I'm sure it will after a while) and I'm left with holes in the wall? Other shower heads we've had have screwed right into the shower plumbing that comes out from the wall.2. We have a fiberglass shower enclosure and I am not comfortable with drilling holes in it.I do like that the mount swivels to adjust the angle -- but unfortunately in our situation I'm unable to use it.When I put this in our existing mount (for our Delta handheld shower head, which needs to be replaced), it didn't really hold it at quite the right angle.The shower head itself is nice looking, a very clean combination of white and chrome. Looks clean and contemporary. And, it screwed  onto the hose easily. Though I can't comment on durability, it seems well made.It only has one setting, as opposed to my old shower head that had 7, but Purelux does sell a 3-function shower head which is a nice option to have.This didn't really work out for me but if you have a shower where you can screw a mount into the wall and need only one spray function it may work for you.

I received a free shower head to try out so I could share my experience with it in a review. I hadn't heard of this company before and wasn't sure what to expect.I got this to replace a 10-year old shower head which had finally begun to leak. Time for a new one! I found that this shower head is very lightweight, and easy to hold. It screwed onto our hose really easily and we had it going in just a few minutes.It doesn't have as many settings as my old shower head and there is really only one that I would use on. But that is a personal preference -rather than a comment on the quality of this shower head. The mount we already had installed didn't really hold this at the right angle; I need to look for another alternative.Though I can't comment on durability, it seems well made. And it looks good too; I like the clean lines and shiny chrome finish.

I received a free set of lights to try out and share my experience in a review. I've owned many string lights over the years but none by this company, so wasn't certain what to expect and was curious to try them.The lights are a warm color, and the way they shine through the creamy white rattan balls is so pretty. They are about two inches across.They could easily be used any time of year but they really light up a dim fall day. I already have them decorating a table in my living room -- and they are also going to look great during the holidaysThere is also a bonus string of pierced round silver lights They are silver and very shiny -- and unlike any lights I've seen before, they have jingle bells in them. I think they would be perfect wrapped around a wreath on a door so they jingle when it's opened There are only 10 lights but the short length makes it perfect for a 10 or 12-inch diameter wreath, or to decorate a small display or centerpiece. (And my husband had the idea to drape them around his neck when we go to the local annual Christmas parade!)Each set takes AA batteries -- the small set takes 2, and the rattan set takes 3. The silver ones have a constant light, but the rattan lights can either shine constant or flashing lights.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use in my home, and review -- and point out any problems I encounter, and rate accordingly -- but there's just nothing I don't like about either of these sets. Really glad to have each of them

I was given one of these lights to try out so I could share my experience with it in a review, without obligation. I'd never seen anything like it before and wasn't sure what to expect.Now that I have it, I'm charmed by it. It comes nicely boxed with an instruction sheet - but it's so simple instructions aren't really needed. If it's off, touch it once and it comes on at a low level; touch it again and it glows a little brighter.It is ideal for keeping at the bedside, because it comes on with just a light touch. It's easy for a small child to do -- or an adult -- or even someone who is ill. You barely need touch it and there's the little bird lighting up the night.The light is meant mostly for children, but I'm a middle-aged woman and just want to keep it for myself. :-)It's also easy to carry with you if you want to use it as a lantern; there is a little white hook on top and it doesn't weigh much. A child can easily carry it.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and point out any issues I discover, and rate accordingly -- but I can't find anything not to like about this light. My family finds it quite charming.

I was given a free light to try out so I could share my experience with it in a review. I wasn't sure what to expect as I've never had a clip-on LED light before and wasn't really familiar with this company either. I've had it for a couple weeks now, and here's what I found.When it arrived I was pleased to say that it was in a really nice box. Not a big deal, but it does show some care and attention to detail. (And it is appropriate for gift giving).The back of the base slides off so you can insert AAA batteries. Up top, there is an on/off -- low --- high switch. I like that it has two brightness settings. At night when it's dim, often I don't want to wake myself up so "low" is what I want. But "high" is good for when I plan to stay up reading in low light for a long time.The neck is flexible so you can put it in whatever position you like. The base slid securely onto my Kindle HD 8.9" and also onto my new Acer laptop. (See the photos.) It slides on and off easily but stays pretty secure when it's on due to a little rubber on the inside surfaces.It isn't an overwhelming amount of light but just enough for some extra illumination, to shed a little light on whatever you're doing. The lighting in our house isn't ideal and I really like to haveThough I haven't had it a real long time, and can't speak to battery life yet, I do like that these are LED lights so draw little power and should last a good long time. The construction of this little light is pretty solid too.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and point out any issues I discover, and rate accordingly -- but this is a nice little light and I just can't find anything not to like about it. It is compact and really easy to take along in my pack, laptop bag or purse as well.

I was given a free pair of thest to test out. I've used quite a few Bluetooth earphones by now, and was curious to see how these would compare.Though they look a little large, they actually fit on my ears fine without falling out and without hurting them as some others have done in the past.The visual design of these is very nice -- the black plastic is faceted. Because of this detail I think these may appeal more to women than men. (I'm a woman and like it.)But, how do they sound? Well, pretty good. Like most Bluetooth earphones in this price range, they are a little bass-shy, with better treble and midtones. But I don't necessarily need a very deep, booming bass directly in my ears either, so it is OK -- and not a major factor anyway with most of the music I listen to. These sounded great with jazz playing over them; I also listened to some singer-songwriter tunes, and a little classic rock. Overall I was pretty pleased.These are beautifully packaged (so, quite giftable) and also come with a velveteen drawstring bag for storage. Overall I'm quite satisfied with these.

I received these free to try out so I could share my experience in a review. After years of using cheapie drugstore tweezers, for the past few months I've been on a quest to find the perfect tweezers, so I was curious to try these.The case is good, as it keeps them from getting knocked around and potentially damaged in my already too-full bathroom drawer. It's a soft black faux leather.The pointy one is meant for ingrown hairs and I haven't had occasion to use it. The flat-tipped tweezers are all right but this style isn't my favorite because it isn't precise enough for fine work. They will grip several hairs at once if that's your goal (beware of catching skin though).The slant-tip tweezers are fine. They are easy enough to hold and are good for catching the occasional eyebrow hair or facial hair. They did the job nicely.Overall I was pretty pleased with these -- not perfect but OK for most general plucking I need to do.

I received a free foot massager roller to try out, so I could share my experience with it in a review. I almost declined it, as I was a little skeptical that it would work. But my curiosity won out, because I have recurrent nerve issues (numbness and tingling) in my feet -- and my husband is on his feet a lot at his job and comes home with feet in need of a little TLC. We have had it for almost a month.This massager is well-sized. It is wide enough for even wide feet and the nubs are sized to be effective but not uncomfortable. On one end the nubs are larger which is great for massaging aching heels. If you don't want those on your heels you can turn it around so that roller faces the front where it is easy to avoid altogether.I really felt this more than I thought I would. I have recurring issues with numbness and tingling in my feet (I don't know what causes it -- but it's not diabetes) -- and that had been going on for a couple months when I first tried this massager.I actually noticed somewhat of a difference -- noticeable but not huge -- after using this the first time. Now, I don't know if that was just a coincidence, but maybe stimulating the nerves in my feet was helpful. Since I have been using it (which, admittedly, is not every day) I have noticed some gradual improvement. Again, I don't know if it's due to the massager, or just natural (as these foot nerve systems tend to come and go for me).But at the very least it sure feels great. It is stimulating and relaxing at the same time. You can control how intense it is by how hard you press your feet on the rollers (or if you wear socks or not).My husband has been using it occasionally to massage his aching feet and just likes the way it feels, especially on the balls of his feet.I should also note that this is made of solid wood, and is well made with no splinters or other issues. It doesn't feel at all cheap; care has obviously been made in its construction and I expect it will last a long time.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and always point out any isuses I discover and rate accordingly -- but really can't find anything not to like about this foot massager. While it hasn't worked miracles for us, we have definitely experienced some benefits, and I am glad that after my initial hesitation, that I took a chance on it.Overall, we are really pleased with this massager.

I received this free for review, with no obligation. It is designed nicely, fits my medium-sized hand nicely, and takes only one AA battery.Unfortunately after trying for 15 minutes I was unable to get my brand new Acer laptop, which has Bluetooth and Windows 10, to recognize it. I'm pretty tech savvy and tried everything I could think of. It turned on, and lit up when I pressed "connect" button...but just didn't get recognized by my computer.I see others have gotten it to work with Windows 10 -- so am not sure what's going on. But unfortunately the one I received just wouldn't pair with the laptop.

I received a free diffuser to use so I could share my experience with it in a review, with no obligation. This was my first time using one and I was curious to try it out.This diffuser creates a nice soft light, which is so useful in particular situations. In photography, lighting is everything and sometimes the light is just too harsh. Having a diffuser like this allows you to manipulate the light and shadows for better photos.It is very lightweight and pretty compact, so fits in a camera bag easily. It folds flat, and has its own soft case (which adds almost no bulk). The zipper on the case works fine. All the pieces are made from lightweight nylon (I think it is nylon). You just unfold the black part, then the white velcros in. You can begin assembling it and less than a minute later be taking photos; it is really easy.Overall, I'm quite pleased with this -- it met all my expecations. Though I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and point out any issues I discover, and rate accordingly -- I can't find anything not to like about this. I'm glad to have it.

I received a free laptop cooling stand to try out and to share my experiences in a review. I wasn't familiar with this company or its products before, so was curious as to how it would work.I have an older HP laptop that gets insanely hot. It actually caused a big red spot on my leg from using it on my lap! And sometimes it gets so hot that it just shuts itself down without warning. That is so annoying. So I hoped that this would help.It does. The four fans keep the laptop from overheating. And the bottom of the laptop isn't in contact with my leg so no possibility of it affecting my skin. The stand doesn't weigh much and is comfortable on my lap; keeps both me and my laptop from overheating.It also has a wicked design! I love the angular edges. it goes really well with the mouse I like to use which has various color lights and angles. Looks very cool all together.Really this was everything I was hoping for. I'm glad I took a chance on it and would buy another if I needed a second one.

I received a free set to use so I could share my experience with it in a review. I have used a lot of chalk markers over the past year but hadn't heard of this brand before. So I was curious to give them a try.I use chalk markers on windows to decorate for holidays, to cheer on our fave sports teams -- and also sometimes to leave messages on the mirror.Most of the chalk marker sets I've used have six or eight markers -- this one has ten. It is great to have the additional colors. Bright colors are always great, but this one also has black and brown -- which are so useful! The only other thing I would wish for is a deeper blue (like a navy or medium blue).These are easy to start, and the color is excellent. The color flows really easily.I like that they have a reversible nib. And they have something  I haven't seen in other sets -- 2 extra nibs. Very nice to have in case one eventually gets worn.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and point out any issues I find, and rate accordingly -- but didn't find anything not to like about these markers. They are everything I expected them to be, and I like having such a range of colors. I'm happy to have them and would buy them again in the future.

I received a free set of these to try out, so I could share my honest experience in a review.  We like tea at our house and have quite a variety of tea infusers, some which we like better than others. So I was curious to try these out -- I haven't had silicone tea infusers before and wasn't familiar with this company, either. Here's what I found.The halves pull apart easily and the opening is wide enough that it's easy to get the tea into them.I found that when I set it in a mug with a wall of standard thickness, they sit far enough up that the water doesn't cover all the holes. But I don't need to fill it up with tea to the top of the holes anyway. With a thin-walled tea cup, they sit down a little farther (because of the thin edge, the cup goes all the way into their armpits).It looks like a happy little guy dangling his lower half into a hot tub. Too cute. My husband thinks they are fun, too. This is not a necessary item -- but sure does inject a little fun into something that's usually just functional.They wash up well, too -- still look like new. We're getting a lot use out of these and I'm thinking of picking up a set as a stocking stuffer for a tea-loving friend, too.

I received a free light so I could use and review it. Though I've had solar lights before, this was my first experience with this brand, and wasn't sure what to expect. Here's what I found.When it arrived, I was surprised at how small it is -- but it does shed a lot of light. It was partially charged when I received it -- and charged up the rest of the way within a few hours outdoors.It certainly throws enough light to illuminate a step, or a dark corner. I actually have it by our porch and it is nice to have the extra light there, especially as it's getting dark earlier and earlier these days.If it gets enough light during the day to charge it, it could even be used indoors.It is very compact -- and the housing is metal (not plastic like some others I've had) so it is rather discreet and looks nice when you do see it.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and point out any issues I discover, and rate accordingly -- but I couldn't find anything not to like about this solar light. It's performing up to all my expectations and I'm glad to have it.

I received a free ring to try and review. The whole concept of silicone rings is pretty new to me -- so I was curious to see what this ring would be like. I admit, I was a little skeptical.I ordered the camo ring in a size 9. It arrived in a ring box, a nice touch. I noticed that the edges are really nicely rounded -- and it fits exactly like a size 9 should. It is comfortable on my hand, too -- not too thick or bulky It moves with my finger, it doesn't constrict it.I got the camo color, which is a soft blending of white, green, and brown. It is maybe a little more casual than the rings which are one solid color.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and always point out any issues I discover, and rate accordingly -- but I couldn't find anything not to like about this ring. Though I never would have guessed that I'd be impressed by a non-metal ring, I really like this one and am happy to have it in my jewelry wardrobe.

I've heard a lot about the benefits of turmeric / curcumin for quite a long time now and a few months ago tried it for the first time. My husband and I have been taking other antioxidants (especially resveratrol) and anti-inflammatories, and I appreciate that about turmeric too. But it's also been claimed that turmeric helps protect against cancer and heart disease, and even possibly Alzheimer's.I'm certainly no doctor and only know what I've read on some websites; it's not definitive.But heart disease and cancer run in my family, and I am interested in reducing my cholesterol. I have the beginnings of arthritis and have some other inflammation issues which I really want to get under control. So I began taking it last summer.I've been experimenting with different turmeric supplements. But this was my first experience with this particular brand. I was drawn to it because it includes bioperine (black pepper extract) which makes it easier to absorb.I found the capsules easy to take. They are pretty light and go down easy for me, which is a good thing because I have a difficult time with big hard pills (and this isn't one of those). Unlike other turmerics I've had this one also has black pepper extract which makes the turmeric more easily absorbed.Like many other supplements, I don't have hard evidence that this is working. But I feel good about taking it and will continue to do so.I received a free bottle to try out, and so I could leave a no-obligation review afterwards. That didn't influence my opinion; I am glad to have this and will ta

I received a free money belt to use so I could share my experience with it in a no-obligation review. I have had a money belt before but was unfamiliar with this brand and wasn't sure how it would compare.It's not like those old fanny packs from days gone by -- while it is also compact, it's got a low profile. No one need ever know you're wearing it. It is an unobtrusive way to take money, phone, and other essentials with me when taking a purse is impractical.My husband and I like to take walks in the woods near where we live, and on the beach. I don't want to lug a big purse with me but still want to take some things along. and also on the beach. This is what I need.It is very adjustable and fits my size 14 waist just fine. The pouch itself is nicely designed with quality zippers. Both compartments have plenty of space, for money, phone, comb, etc. I like having more than once compartment so money can be kept separate. The mesh on the back is breathable and soft on the skin.I'm more or less a perfectionist and sew a little, so always notice how well sewn things are stitched. This is well made, with quality materials and thread. Due to its construction it appears it will live a long time.I'll continue to get a lot of use out of this for walks and longer trips, too. I am glad to have it.

I received a free wig for a no-obligation review. I don't often wear wigs, but have toyed with the thought so this was a good opportunity to try one out.I got a blonde color which is a lot of fun because I'm a brunette and haven't actually been blonde since college. The color was a rich blonde which I found really attractive. The length is great -- most of the way down my back (much like my real hair). The bangs were kind of heavy, but after styling them a bit I decided I liked them.The cap is adjustable -- around the bottom are little ribbons sewn in, and hooks that you can hook into them to adjust the sizing. It was surprisingly easy to do.I'm going to be wearing this on Halloween -- but also just occasionally for fun. My husband likes it...I should also mention that the wig came beautifully boxed, nice for storage.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and point out any difficulties I find, and rate accordingly -- but I really couldn't find anything not to like about this wig. Glad I took a chance on it!

I received a free wig for a no-obligation review after trying it out. I don't often wear wigs, but thought it would be fun to do for a change, so I decided to give this one a try.I got the purple color -- a big change because I'm a brunette but have sometimes thought it would be fun to have a bright color hair. I found that the color of this wig is rich and true.I brushed the bangs to the side rather than wearing them straight down. The length was almost the same as my real hair -- over halfway down my back.The cap is adjustable -- around the bottom are ribbons sewn in, with hooks that you can hook into them to adjust the sizing. It was surprisingly easy to do but took a little experimentation to get the size right.My husband likes it, too -- and it goes with my purple cowboy boots.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and point out any difficulties I find, and rate accordingly -- but I couldn't find anything not to like about this wig. Glad I took a chance on it!

I was sent a free squeezer to use and review so I could share my honest experience with it in a review. I was curious to try it out and see how it worked.In case you're wondering how it works -- you cut your lemon or lime in half, then put the flat side down (counter-intuitive, isn't it!) over the strainer side. As you squeeze the handles together, the fruit gets turned inside out into the bottom of the strainer, pushing the juice out.I found the handles pretty easy to grip and to squeeze together. It is sized for a lime or a smaller lemon. It's really too small for some of the very large lemons we get (but we tend to slice those, anyway). For the smaller lemon or lime, it works great -- and is sized just right for cuties or clementines and those sort of smaller citrus fruits, too.Citrus season is fast approaching and though I'm using this for lemons and limes now, I'll be getting more use out of it as the smaller orange-type fruits fill the grocery stores.The stainless steel is shiny, and the squeezer seems very solidly made; given its construcitonn, I would be very surprised not to get many years of use out of it. I'm glad to add this to the gadget drawer in my kitchen and am kind of wondering how I ever did without it. It sure beats those old-fashioned reamers -- it's both simple and very effective.

I received this free in exchange for sharing my experience with it in a no-obligation review. I've used many Lightning cables by now and can never really have too many; they seem to get lost of misplaced often.This is the length we most often use -- 3 feet long -- which is perfect for charging in my office and in the wall charger in our home. I'm glad this cable is MFi certified too (guaranteed to keep working through future iOS updates), as every non-MFi Lightning cable I've gotten has, over time, eventually given errors.This cable seems very well made -- I can't speak to durability yet -- but it does not seem flimsy like some others I've used.I always cast a critical eye over the items I use and review -- and point out any issues I discover, and rate accordingly -- but this worked exactly as I expected it to, and I can't find anything not to like about it. I'm glad to have it.

I received a free bottle of shampoo to try out and share my experience with it in a review. Though I have an HSI flat iron, I hadn't tried this brand of shampoo before and wasn't sure what it would be like.I have very long, very fine hair and it can be very flyaway, get dry, and tangled. I've used products with argan oil in them before, which left my hair soft and help detangle them. I'd hoped this would do the same thing for me.It actually did. It didn't take a whole lot to use. After washing my hair it felt soft and didn't tangle badly, tangling was minimal and it detangled easily. After drying, my hair felt light, and it looked smooth and with a little extra shine.I like this shampoo a lot and would get it again. Anything that makes my hair look and feel like this makes me very happy!

Spectacular television!  Hands down, the best show we've seen in years -- a heady mix of reality, history and gripping fictional narrative.  Don't be put off by subtitles.  There is absolutely zero degradation in the enjoyment factor from the show being presented in German.  What you get is 100% authenticity.Granted, I'm a total sucker for East Germany/Stasi/country-in-a-bubble-and-on-the-brink tales.  I'm of the opinion that The Lives Of Others is one of The Top Five Movies of All-Time.  I eat up books like Red Love: The Story of an East German Family and Stasiland: Stories from Behind the Berlin Wall. But take that history and mix it together with Golden Age of Television alchemy from co-creators  Anna Winger & Jrg Winger? Magic.  The high point: Northern Wedding, the 4th episode.  You'll never see anything better.There's so many good performances it seems ridiculous to list them all.  I'll just give one special shout-out to Sylvester Groth as Stasi manager Walter Schweppenstette.  Just so good.  There's one wordless scene that summed it up for me -- he's watching a show featuring this East German band of ersatz western rockers & does this small little jig in his office.  Just the brilliance to pull that off.  It conveyed so much about his character.Plus, let's not forget about the soundtrack.  It's an absolute blast.  The team that curated it deserves an award alone for good taste.  And that starts with the selection of Peter Schilling's under-rated classic "Major Tom (Coming Home)" that is draped over crackling good opening credits that reek of 1983.  You'll want to breathe deep to gather it all in.  if you told me I could watch an hour of those credits on a loop, it'd pay to go see it.What's next, Anna and Jrg?  The ending teed up -- in fact, almost demands -- a Season 2 (Deutschland 84?). I'll watch right now.

This cute and charming little film has five things going for it...1. Director Eytan Fox. I'm a big fan of his work, most notably Walk on Water (in my all-time Top Five for sure), Yossi and Jagger and The Bubble.2. Its celebration of the kitsch that is the Eurovision song contest, masquerading and very thinly disguised in the script as the UniverSong contest.  Look up guilty pleasure in the dictionary, you'll find a picture of Eurovision.3. Dana Ivgy. Enough said.  She's a wonderful actress and gorgeous to boot. [She's a real singer, too, by the way.  She's released a solo album called 'Band Camp.']4. Lior Ashkenazi's cameo.  He's Israel's biggest star.  He and Fox go way back (see 'Walk on Water').  His screen presence is magnetic.5. The song at the heart of the story - "Song for Anat." It's super-sweet and catchy.  As a plus, there's no lip-syncing afoot here: these are the six stars singing their hearts out.

Brilliant work -- ought to be required reading.  Starting with the small, beleaguered, now-downtrodden town of Portsmouth, Ohio, author Sam Quinones weaves a tale of dual scourges: over-prescribed Oxycontin and low-priced black tar heroin. The first rising from the East, the second from the West, they meet in the middle of the country in towns like Portsmouth and Columbus and simply take out communities en masse.Quinones tells his tale with a novelist's flair for narrative and an investigative reporter's eye and nose for a firecracker of a story.  In addition to the sordid tale on the streets where most of the disspiriting events play out, he takes us inside the corporate roots and strategies of Purdue Pharma (producer of Oxycontin) and hills and villages of Xalisco, Mexico (where black tar heroin is cultivated and distributed).  One fascinating part is when the Law of Unintended Consequences plays in a slow-motion car wreck: when federal authorities step in to make Purdue reformulate its product (to address the full, rapid release that comes from crushing the pills), vast swathes switch to the Xalisco-sourced product.  The results are not pretty.Despite the soul-sucking subject matter, 'Dreamland' a rollicking good read.  I learned so much from reading this book.

"The Ugly Game" recounts the feverish efforts of The Sunday Times' investigative journalists Heidi Blake and Jonathan Calvert to piece together the tale of Qatar's successful efforts to buy the World Cup for its country in 2022.  Provided safe-room access to a mountain of electronic data by a still confidential source, the veteran duo go into a bunker for months sequestered from family, friends and co-workers.  The goal: assemble this almost insurmountable trove of firsthand documents into a blockbuster narrative. The Sunday Times aims to publish just before FIFA-dom assembles in Sao Paulo for the self-congratulatory circle jerk that was WC 2014.  Mission accomplished: when the story hits the press on June 1, 2014, the authors report that they "felt like they had detonated a nuclear bomb from [our] dark little cluttered bunker in this anonymous British suburb."The book's hero/anti-hero is Mohammed bin Hammam, the Qatari business magnate and long-time FIFA ExCo member. He's a classic behind-the-scenes fixer/facilitator.  Never fully acknowledged by the Qatari ruling family that spearheaded the bid, it was bin Hammam's largesse, wiles, indefatigable spirit and  -- most importantly -- understanding of the way inside an ExCo members' hearts (and there's only one way) that won the day.As I write this review, news has surfaced -- knock me over with a feather -- of Germany's bribes to secure the 2006 World Cup.  Blake & Calvert also pack in other well-known tales: that South Africa out-largessed Morocco to secure 2010; that Russia used its oil wealth and oligarchic class do to the same for 2018 rights; and that Qatar knew the score and simply resolved to outpace the other bidders on this same metric to lockdown 2022.As the authors conclude (referring to the thoughts of a confidential source:) 'As far as he was concerned, Qatar had secured the 2022 tournament simply by playing the corrupt FIFA system, and who could blame them? What Qatar did, he said, was they excessively applied the rules of FIFA. They always did that. What they did was the way in FIFA. They were playing by FIFAs unofficial rules.The most delicious part of the book: reading the parts about the duplicitous, scheming, supremely machiavellian Sepp Blatter and -- instead of experiencing a sense of rage and swallowing a mouthful of bile -- smiling with the knowledge that great American Loretta Lynch and her federal counterparts in Switzerland have taken the measure of this almost comical villain. [You can just about picture him stroking his pet cat in his secret lair on these pages.]The book concludes right before Lynch launches her first dramatic strike.  When Blatter's hall-of-mirrors, pious performance gets to be too much, Blake quotes herself as saying "This is too ridiculous for words...[t]he man has become some sort of ludicrous parody of a dodgy dictator clinging to power."  The authors then write that 'It would have been funny if it wasnt so deeply insulting.' Indeed.  But knowing what comes next makes this book oh so satisfying.  The Ethics Committee -- a body of Blatter's own disingenuous making -- has hoisted the boss on his own petard.Every fan of football needs to read this book.

We came here after 'Srugim' and 'A Touch Away.' We needed something lighter after the emotional body blows delivered by the devastatingly sublime 'A Touch Away.'  'Like a Fish Out of Water' delivered the goods.I'm surprised the creators didn't make a short mini-series out of this concept. Its' a delightful tale of Israeli assimilation featuring Tal Lifshitz, a classic Israeli beauty, as unmarried Anat, and Esteban Gottfried, as good-hearted Argentine immigrant Marcelo, a most unlikely and unexpected suitor.  It's got the usual rom-com tropes -- their unplanned first meeting, her initial distaste, his unflagging spirit, her seeing through his ungainliness and language barrier, her long-suffering parents (oh, the burden of an unmarried daughter).There's kind of an in-joke here: Ms. Lifshitz is a casting director by profession (IMDB notes she played that role in the production of "BeTipul" or "In Therapy" as you would know it, the Israeli show that started the great wave of Israeli-inspired imports).  For "Fish Out of Water," I imagine a scene in which the showrunners say "Get me Ayelet Zurer!" Failing that, they look at Ms. Lifshitz and an idea springs into their head "Hey, Tal..." Indeed, she's every bit the beauty of the Ice Princess.  The in-joke's extended further when you watch a plot unfold that includes casting agents, Marcelo's struggle to get roles (mostly due to his work-in-progress Hebrew) and Anat's assistance with his read-throughs.  This is art imitating life.

'Deep Down Dark' is a spellbinding tale, woven intricately and expertly by Hctor Tobar.  His first triumph was to win the confidence of "Los 33" and earn the right to tell their official story.  His second triumph was to pull off the feat of writing it so magically.  He positively delivered the goods here.  The 33 can rest in comfort that their story got told so accurately and so well.Want to take your enjoyment to the next level? I went the Audible route here.  You need to do it.  It is an absolute PERFORMANCE by narrator Henry Leyva.  He not only has the perfect accent on all the Spanish names and phrases, he also gives you an amazing range of voices for each of the characters he inhabits.  His voice for Super Mario Seplveda ('The Ultimate Leader'!) alone is worth the price of admission.  The only downside: you'll find yourself blurting out things like "Galeguillos" to random strangers, using Leyva's voice.  It's downright intoxicating.

Kingpin is a rollicking good read made even more enjoyable by the author's scrupulous attention to detail.  I work in the payment card industry and can attest that Kevin Poulsen gets all the facts right when he lays out nuances of things like how the Card Verification Value ('CVV') and CVV2 work as well their benefits and shortcomings.  He also gives a spot-on discourse on EMV towards the tail-end of the book.  I can only assume that his discussions of other aspects of the carder underground are equally redolent in good scholarship.  As testament to that assertion, you need look no further than the enthusiastic review by hacker extraordinaire Kevin Mitnick, which you'll find as a spotlight review on these pages.Another thing that makes this book work: the inherent likability of its protagonist, Max Butler, aka, Max Vision.  Nefarious financial crimes aside, the reader is left with the distinct feeling that the author likes his subject.  He certainly respects his hacking skills and audacity.  And what Butler pulls off on these pages is nothing but breathtakingly audacious.  That likability shows off at the end, too: even Max's hunters -- expecting a dark, vile character -- are struck by just how taken they are with him.  It's a godsend for the author who knows a story and an anti-hero when he sees them.

God's Slave ("Esclavo de Dios") is another compelling release from the good people at Film Movement.  The film's inclusion into that series is no doubt down to the rising talent that is director Joel Novoa.  His fingerprints are all over this film.  It's a surging, driving, building piece of work.  At 90 minutes, it plays out more like a taut, well-crafted TV movie than a feature film.The film hopscotches around the globe: its first scenes are set amorphously in the Middle East; a few decades pass and sleeper agent Admed (an excellent Mohammed Alkhaldi) is embedded in Caracas; a few years later, Ahmed's call to duty comes and he's shipped to Buenos Aires.  This befits the production of the film itself: co-Venezuelan/Argentine by heritage, its star a Caraquenian of Middle Eastern descent.What's most interesting: Fernando Butazzoni's script fashions a story around the real-life bombings of the Israeli embassy and AMIA Jewish Community Center in Buenos Aires (1992, 1994 respectively).  It does this in an oblique manner, but it uses those events to craft its movie as a fictional backstory.  It's a fascinating technique.Along those same lines, the other part of the film shadows actor Vando Villamil as investigator David Goldberg.  It's never quite said overtly, but Goldberg is Mossad 'boots on the ground' in B.A.  As he tracks down threats, the sleeplessness and obsession starkly etch themselves on his face, frame and broken homelife.  It's not paranoia that has him that way. Reality does.This is a director to watch.

I can't recommend Lev Golinkin's memoir highly enough. It's a beautifully told story, one that carries extra resonance these days with a new generation of refugees making their way across Europe.The book starts taking readers through Golinkin's family's brutal upbringing in Kharkov, Ukraine.  Belittled, berated and objectified with hatred, Golinkin's family has its Jewishness almost literally beaten out of them.  As Golinkin writes:"The reminders of being a zhid still came, at school and in the yard, but over time something else began to creep up on me, in addition to the fear. I considered the bullies lucky: they only had to see me once in a while; I had to live with myself every day. I envied them."By the time they left -- along with tens of thousands of other Soviet Jews during a brief window of Glasnost-produced loosening -- it wasn't religious freedom that Golinkin and family sought:"What my family and many families like mine desired was peace of mind, not a synagogue. We wanted freedom, the freedom to live our lives without trembling, and naturally we, like our innumerable predecessors, cast our gaze across the Atlantic."This skillfully produced and assembled work has four main parts: the family's life in Kharkov; their journey to America (could be a movie in itself -- indeed, its indelible images are seared into Golinkin's mind's eye for the next two decades); Lev's upbringing in America (I loved his passages about Boston College to whom he seems truly indebted and grateful); and a subsequent trip made back through Europe 17 years after his seminal initial passage.  It's that last part that gets to the emotional core of the book: he goes back and tracks down all the people that played a part in making that trip a reality and thanks them.  It's a beautiful thing.

The excellent, heartrending movie springs from the singular vision of writer/director, Rama Burshtein.  One of the few devoutly Orthodox women making films today, Ms. Burshtein brings a unique perspective to this project.  Her deep, rich understanding of this community shows in every frame.  Her camera shows us all the small rituals, all the social interactions and all the layers of complexity and meaning that make up this devout corner of Judaism.Hadas Yaron - a secular Jew in real life - does a wonderful job here portraying the frum, flowering sister.  There's an important age gap here between Ms. Yaron's Shira and older sister Esther (the choreographer Renana Raz doing one of her occasional screen turns).  Esther is the beautiful older sister ("The most beautiful person in the world" as an adoring Shira refers to her at one point), Shira always the notably younger "little sister."  These dynamics are important because when tragedy befalls Esther, our little duckling Shira is slowly thrust into a role that at first seems very unsuited for her.  Neither she nor the audience can at first accept her as Esther's replacement.I loved the casting here. Irit Sheleg and Chayim Sharir are superb as parents Rivka and Aharon.  They are bulwarks of the community and love both of their daughters equally.  [Wow, I just learned that Ms. Sheleg is Dana Ivgy's mom, WHAAAAT??]  The amazing Purim scene -- with Sharir literally heading the table and Sheleg looking on in the background and basically running the books...that scene alone -- an incredibly deep, rich dive into tradition -- is worth the price of admission in this movie.  It's a superb piece of filmmaking from Rama Burshtein.

This first full-length feature from writer/director Talya Lavie presents a unique take on conscripted service into the IDF from a female perspective. The result is a Heller-esque tale replete with absurdities and inanities of military servitude.  It took a woman to tell this story.  Unlike other military movies, this one is almost entirely female - other than two smaller parts that come to mind, girls rule here.Lavie's script stitches together three loosely connected tales: "01: The Replacement"; "02: The Virgin" and "03: The Commander". The constant in the three stories is the presence of Dana Ivgy as Zohar. Ms. Ivgy is a personal favorite dating back to Broken Wings. She's a great actress and an arresting on screen presence even when dressing down or meant to be bristly and difficult like she is here.  Ivgy shines brightest in Lavie's 2nd story as the title character.The movie' surprise, though, is Nelly Tagar as Daffi.  She plays a big part in the first story, ostensibly training her replacement as she angles for reassignment in Tel Aviv. Tagar is a naturally gifted physical comedienne with fun, expressive eyes.  Her ability to cry on contact plays a big part in the story and to watch her to do it with aplomb -- and have you chuckle at the results -- is a real treat.  I was saddened to see her not appear n the second tale, but excited to see her return in the third and finale story, whose title -- The Commander -- is a neat little head fake from Lavie.The third star turn in the film is that of Shani Klein as Rama, a commander and boss to Zohar and Daffi.  I really liked Ms. Klein in this role.  Her Rama is a thin sheen of bluster with a sensitive core underneath. Zohar doesn't see it, but the audience can.

I'm a fan of Lawrence Wright's work.  I loved "The Looming Tower" and "Going Clear."  This memoir was re-published in 2013, twenty years after its initial publication.  Wright mentioned the book during a fascinating appearance on Alec Baldwin's podcast, "Here's the Thing.""In the New World" held special fascination to me because he grew up in East Dallas no less than five miles from where we live.  His passages on the Kennedy Assassination and Dallas' heavy burden ring true.  If those parts of the Wright's book held you in thrall, I recommend you to Dallas 1963 by Bill Minutaglio and Steven L. Davis.Other favorite parts of the book: Wright's time at Tulane (50-yard-line memories...& you still owe Dionne Warwick $20, Larry); his period teaching in Egypt; his reminiscences of Watergate's effect on the country; and a nuanced look at Jimmy Carter, the first leader Wright thinks of as "My President."

'Last Tango' is one of my favorite shows - it takes a stumble at the outset of Season 3 but ultimately wins out thanks again to the writing prowess of series creator and workhorse Sally Wainwright (she's written all 18 episodes to date) and the show's power axis: the dynamic duo of Sarah Lancashire  (Caroline) and Nicola Walker (Gillian). These two are joined through the late-in-life union of their respectively widowed parent (Caroline's Mom + Gillian's Dad).As first conceived, the show was about those two - Derek Jacobi's Alan and Anne Reid's Celia.  Now though, the series clearly flows through the daughters.  Wainwright''s talent is that she gives her characters big, meaty one-on-ones.  No quick-hit, made-for-TV fluff here.  When Caroline and Gillian talk, it goes on.  And on and on - often seven or eight minutes of riveting conversation.  Both have a lot to deal with in Season 3 - Caroline, alas, has to deal with a tragic loss (frankly, I thought this was a cheap trick by Wainwright -- too soap opera-y and out of character with the tone of the rest of the show). Her acting has been been better.Gillian, meanwhile, prepares for her wedding with Robbie -- a decision covered in decades of complexity, backstory and emotional entanglement Short story: Robbie is the brother of Gillian's ex, Eddie, now deceased...in Season 3 we get additional layers of information about Eddie's treatment of Gillian and Robbie's implicit knowledge of what was happening.  A lot of this information starts tumbling out as the wedding hurtles near.  How Gillian acts out is  among this season's highlights.

This brilliant show is scandalously under-reviewed on these pages. I love Israeli movies and Israeli TV.  I've seen heaps of it.  It's a country that punches far above its weight when it comes to quality productions.  [Ask the showrunners for Homeland, In Treatment and Hostages, among the various worldwide adaptations of Israeli product.] But believe me when I tell you that nothing can prepare you for power of this can't-take-your-eyes-away, real-to-life Romeo and Juliet-like saga as it plays out over eight, crisply told parts.  It''s not just me: "A Touch Away" (Merhak Negiha) took Israel by storm when it aired in 2007.  It's last episode was - at the time - the highest-rated drama ever on Israeli TV.The storyline brings together two at-the-time under-represented groups on Israeli TV: the ultra-orthodox and Russian immigrant communities, here represented by the Berman and Muntz families respectively.  Forced by economic circumstance to live across the hall in substandard housing on the outskirts of Tel Aviv, the heart of the tale is that of star-crossed lovers Zorik, head wage-earner for his Moscow emigre clan (his parents and sister arrive as the story opens), and Rochale, daughter of devout parents Shmuel and Leah.When Zorik first catches a quick glance of Rochale behind a quickly opened and then closed door, he's literally rocked backwards by her beauty.  You will be, too. You will have your breath taken away by Gaya Traub.  The thin walls, back-to-back bedrooms and Zorik's late night bass-playing help build what is at first an unspoken bond.  What helps seal the relationship: Zorik listening and comforting when no one else will pay attention to Rochale when she attempts to come to the assistance of close friend, Ita, newly married and beaten by her husband (a chilling, dead-eyed performance by Nitai Gvirtz).Just as good: the tale of the Zorik's family, especially Jenya Dodina as his mother, Marina.  She's fabulous as a histrionic, self-absorbed but ultimately loving and endearing matriarch, at constant odds with her exasperated daughter (Lucy Dubinchik, flashing fierce, beautiful eyes).  Her unruffled, patient husband, Sasha (a regal Slava Bibergal) is the story's unsung hero.The Tel Aviv suburb of Bnei Brak is a hall-of-mirrors reality for the immigrant Muntzes: squeezed out of Moscow for being too Jewish, they're shunned and abused in their new community for not being Jewish enough (indeed, graffiti at one point accuses them of being Gentiles).  As Sasha tells his erstwhile friend Shmuel in the penultimate scene: "I thought you were different." Sadly, not.

I've raved about writer/director David Trueba's film to so many people, I've probably started turning them off.  But that won't stop me from doing it again here.  This complete surprise of a movie -- I defy you not to be moved at the end -- dominated Spain's Goyas.  It's easy to see why.  It's cinematic magic.To be upfront: Like many others, I worship the canon of John Lennon.  So, to see that someone crafted a film out of Lennon's time spent in Almeria in 1966 to film "How I Won the War"...well, that's enough to shoot any fan steeped in the arcania of Beatles history into fits of joy.  And, moreover, the main narrative -- that of Javier Cmara's character driving to meet Lennon so he could get him to translate Beatles lyrics (supposedly the impetus for all Beatles releases after that to include lyrics) -- is based on a true story.  As is the backstory that Lennon conceived one of his masterpieces, 'Strawberry Fields Forever',  while in Almeria (a fact known not even to Richard Lester who directed "How I Won the War" and was thrilled by Trueba's film). Well done, David Trueba!But even non-Beatles fans will love the movie.  My wife falls into that category.  Trueba hooks them, too, because he's stitched together an equally compelling story parallel to the Lennon tale that provides the backdrop.  It's a classic road trip tale: Cmara's Antonio plus passengers Beln and Juanjo (a fetching Natalia de Molina and impressive newcomer Francesc Colomer), each running away from repressive situations.  All this plays out against the background of a gray, severe Spain of the Franco era.
