Indeed, the hues and stringency of Trueba's film could not be more different than the colorful explosions of Almodvar, what first springs to mind when western audiences think about Spanish cinema.

It's a shame Amazon doesn't offer the third and final season of 'Srugim' as a Prime streaming option like they do for Seasons 1 & 2.  I had to go to a competing streaming service (let's call it 'H') to see Season 3.  I was happy I did and got to spend 15 more episodes with these fascinating characters.  Thank you, co-creators Laizy Shapiro and Hava Divon, for the creativity and production skills that brought these lives into my life.  I really feel like I know these people.Again the five leads -- Yael Sharoni (Yifat), Tali Sharon (Hodaya), Ohad Knoller (Nati), Amos Tamam (Amir), Sharon Fauster (Reut) -- are superb.  Of special note, the Yifat/Amir relationship -- strained at the end of Season 2 -- is strong and vibrant here. Well, strong even in spite of Amir's pre-baby extended walkabout stroking baby goats in the Negev (the weakest storyline in Season 3).Unexpectedly, Season 3's best storyline belongs to Knoller's Nati.  Painted heretofore as a rather self-centered jerk who quickly works his way through one woman after another (all of whom are beautiful, intelligent keepers), Nati falls hard for Tehila, played wonderfully as a quirky hippie with an intoxicating, crooked smile by Dikla Elkaslasi.  You can guess the set-up here: the tables are gonna get turned on Nati.  Still, it's a beautifully told story.Another compelling part of Season 3's Nati arc: his suspension after being accused of negligence in death of an elderly woman, Mrs. Schwartzman, under his care (he's a intern at a local Jerusalem hospital).  This despite the tenderness and attention he lavished on her during her convalescence.  Their scenes together are touching. The payoff: when Nati is called to Schwartzman's lawyer's office.  Nati, freaked and on a bad run, figures he's getting sued.  The truth is something far different.  Even though my wife and I guessed what would come, it was still for me the single best scene of the season. If you can keep it together during this scene...you can't be human.I can't end my last review of Srugim without giving a shout-out to Sarah & Shayna, the two girls who co-authored the awesome, unofficial companion blog, Srugim Recap.  As fun and fulfilling as the show is, the humor and insight of these two made the whole experience two or three times better.  Ladies: I would pay to watch you watch TV.

My wife and I absolutely love 'Srugim.'  We can see people tune out when we start raving about it and recommending it.  Sorry, not into 'GoT' or 'Breaking Bad' or anything so violent and widely beloved.  I wish we could convince and win over more people to watch this superb production.  The quality hasn't dipped at all here in Season 2, a testament to co-creators Laizy Shapiro and Hava Divon and a superb staff of writers (led by the co-creators themselves).  They've developed five leads which such fleshed-out and carefully crafted personalities that you'd swear you knew these people.Each of the five leads -- Yael Sharoni (Yifat), Tali Sharon (Hodaya), Ohad Knoller (Natti), Amos Tamam (Amir), Sharon Fauster (Reut) - continue to turn in excellent work.  They're joined this season by Uri Lachmi, excellent as Natti's younger brother, Roi.  He takes part in the season's single best storyline: his tortured, self-flagellating, conflicted courtship of Reut, the understated beauty of the female trio with her arresting eyes.The only downer for me about Season 2: how unlikeable Yifat and Amir are -- both to each other and the audience -- at the end of Season. This despite the brilliant spectacle and joy of their marriage capping their unexpected pairing at the end of Season 1.  Yael Sharoni as Yifat is the beating heart at the center of the show so it suffers notably when she turns unhappy and hectoring.  [Lucky for us, the pair turn it around in Season 3.]One final observation: Tali Sharon looks astonishingly beautiful and radiant throughout Season 2. [In Season 3, she's post-real life baby and showing it.]  I defy anyone to watch her here and not be smitten...even when her character is exhibiting the most maddening of her introspective, morose, self-centered traits.  As Reut says: "You know, Hodaya-land."

We love Romain Duris and have thoroughly enjoyed many of his films including Paris, Heartbreaker, L'Auberge Espagnole and its follow-up Russian Dolls...and most emphatically "The Beat that My Heart Skipped."  "The Big Picture" is another winner in that stretch.  Even when Duris' characters are not fully likeable (and he definitely straddles the line here), you find yourself rooting for him.This well-plotted thriller is adopted from the novel of the same name by Douglas Kennedy.  The life of Duris' Paul Exben -- already in tumult due to an impending breakup of  his marriage and ownership changes at work -- takes a sharp, shocking turn for the dark and desperate thanks to a fit of anger that goes horribly and tragically wrong.  A quick thinking Paul "solves" the bloody aftermath but at the expense of his normal life in the environs of Paris.  He "Splits" (pin intended) for Croatia.  Can Paul make a clean getaway or will his past catch up with him? Watch to find out!Good here as always: Niels Arestrup, whose character may not be the drunkard he appears on first glance.  That piercing gaze and foreboding manner...he's intensity personified, so good in 'A Prophet' and again with Duris in "The Beat My Heart Skipped." I love seeing this guy pop up on screen.

"Drama High" is an enthralling read.  I highly recommend it.  Writer Michael Sokolove has placed layer upon layer of brilliant writing into this work.  Headline writers have tabbed this book to be about a "real-life 'Glee'" or "'Glee' meets 'Friday Night Lights'."  Those are too pithy and don't do justice to the book's impressive scope, depth and emotional resonance.Ostensibly, Sokolove's book is a paean to his former teacher, Lou Volpe, retiring after four decades at his post as drama teacher at Harry S Truman High School in Levittown, PA.  While the book focuses on Volpe's career as its touchstone, so many other excellent themes here including: the role of arts programs in American high schools; the effect of budget cuts; theater programs' position in lower- to middle-class communities; the regression of the middle class; the roots, struggles and perseverance of Levittown; Volpe's family history and sexual identity; the stories of Volpe's ex-wife and now-adult only child; the business of high school musical; the kids' stories, motivations, fears and dreams...and so much more.Lou Volpe is an American hero.

If the Obama/Raul Castro thaw in relations continues at its current pace, Julia Cooke's book -- in the oeuvre of the American observer noting the etched-in-amber life of Havana's exhausted residents -- could be one of the last of its breed.  Look instead for a new wave of journals detailing the new opportunities by first-movers and the sure-to-happen split between young Habaneros making the shift and older generations left behind and contemplating a life lost waiting and hoping.In the mean time, Julia Cooke's book makes for interesting fly-on-wall reading.  She writes about the small, not the big, shadowing and recounting the lives and struggles of a dozen of so companions and friends of friends.  It's the well-worn but never tiresome story of Habaneros struggling simply to get through the day much less build for a future.  Interviewed in the New york Times about her book, she says ""I miss how important every moment was."Best of breed here for me is still Isadora Tattlin's Cuba Diaries: An American Housewife in Havana.  It's a brilliant, through-the-looking glass look at life in Cuba through a thinly veiled pseudonym of a wife of a Eastern European (and thus then allied) consulate officer.  Simply fascinating, especially the part where Fidel visits their house for an official function.

This classic novel by the Ukraine's best-known living fiction writer Andrey Kurkov is well worth your time. It's a look at an absurd hall-of-mirrors existence in post-Soviet society in which everything is in a state of tumult and on offer to corruption.  Even public stewards like journalism are not what they appear upon first look.  The story has extra relevance given the current state of the Ukrainian state.19 years on from its publication, Kurkov remains a relevant voice in his homeland.  His recent non-fiction release "Ukraine Diaries: Dispatches from Kiev" is a gripping first-person account of the events leading to the fall of Viktor Yanukovcyh.

Bill Browder is one of the world's top investors.  His book, 'Red Notice' tells you how he got to the pinnacle of the investment professional only to have his life -- and the lives of many others - torn asunder by Russian kleptocracy.As Browder write about Russia "If powerful people wanted you arrested, then you were arrested. The law didn't matter. Sergei [Magnitsky], on the other hand, was 36 years old and had come of age at a time when things had started to improve.  He saw Russia not how it was but how he wanted it to be.""Because of this, he didn't realize the Russia had no rule of law, it had a rule of men.""And those men were crooks."'Red Notice' reads like a Cold War novel, but it is all too real. The results of this reality was tragedy for Sergei Magnitsky, Alexander Perepilichnyy and the people who lived and worked with both men, both whom died while attempting stand on principle against brazen kleptocracy.  Browder tells their story, but also tells the story of his fight to get justice for Magnitsky culminating in the passage into US law of  the Sergei Magnitsky Accountability Act of 2012.

I adore this show from Garry Trudeau, Elliot Webb and Jonathan Alter. It's drenched head to toe with insider jokes about life inside the Beltway, but has enough intelligent adult comedy to appeal to those who aren't political junkies.  I suspect Mark Consuelos (excellent as the Marco Rubio-esque Andy Guzman) speaks for much of the cast when he says that his work on the show is the best role he's ever had, hands down.The four leads are fantastic: John Goodman (the beating heart of the show) as Sen. Gil John Biggs (R-NC); Matt Malloy (a Trudeau veteran from Tanner '88) as Sen. Louis Laffer (R-NV); Clark Johnson as Sen. Robert Bettencourt (R-PA); and Consuelos/Guzman (R-FL).  Each has meaty, compelling storylines, many times ripped from the headlines. Calling for an end to the Cuban embargo for example? Nice idea, President Obama, but Sen. Andy Guzman beat you to it.Equally good are the staffers. Like real life, the star wattage may come from the personalities on the Senate floor, but what makes the town work are the staffers.  Standouts are the four chiefs of staff: Alicia Sable (as Tammy Stackhouse) in Gil John's office; Natalie Gold (as Katherine Sims) in Guzman's; Brooke Bloom (as Julie Carrell) in Laffer's; and Kobi Libii (as Aaron Stimson) in Bettencourt's.Finally, the lagniappe: excellent star turns. Word clearly spread after Season One that this show was a bipartisan hoot.  Everyone seems to want in on the deal. Season 2 cameos include Ed Rendell, Elizabeth Warren, Jake Tapper, John King, John McCain, Wolf Blitzer, David Axelrod, Andy Cohen, Rachel Maddow and a hilariously profane Penn Gillette.

I discovered this film via Film Movement. It starts slow, but hang on: about 30 minutes in, it gets very, very interesting. It becomes a taut, seat-gripping drama that will have you holding your breath and rooting for everything to turn out well for our protagonist, Malika, winningly played by newcomer Chaimae Ben Acha.The best scenes are the most intimate ones: that of Malika and jaded drug mule Amal (Soufia Issami). Writer/director Sean Gullette has us right in the car with these two as they embark on a risky trafficking journey.  We see Mailka from Amal's front-seat perspective and vice versa.  They've not met before being paired on this trip. You can feel the edginess and tension as they feel each other out.I especially loved Belgian actor Mourade Zeguendi as Samir.  His hard exterior masks a soft heart for Amal...and for Malika as well.  It's a brilliant acting job.

"The Girl on the Train" is a voyeuristic, cleverly plotted thrill ride.  Paula Hawkins is a first-time novelist.  She's a writer and editor by profession though, so 'Train' is no flying blind leap into a new career.  The writing and plotting here is ingenious and first rate.Were someone to tell you about the literary device employed here --- three first-person voices, alternating by paragraph, over different time periods -- you might think, jeez, that sounds hard to follow.  It's not. You pick up on it right away and get immediately into the flow.You can almost see the cinema version of the book in your mind's eye as you blitz through it.  So, no surprise then to read that Dreamworks preemptively acquired the rights to Hawkins' work late last year.

This excellent piece of investigatory journalism from ESPN The Magazine's Senior Writer Brett Forrest takes us inside the shocking world of international football (i.e., soccer) match-fixing. There are two main threads of the story: that of the main chaser, Chris Eaton, one-time Melbourne cop turned Interpol sleuth; and that of the most notorious of the fixers, Wilson Raj Perumal, Singapore's "Kelong King."  Though Forrest came to the story by way of Eaton (who, post-Interpol, did a stint with FIFA as its chief security officer and now sets up office at the Qatar-based International Centre for Sport Security), what's notable about the book is his access to Perumal, whom Forrest tracks down in Hungary.  In his Acknowledgements, Forrest notes that "Perumal earns my gratefulness for his courteous recollections."Beyond the cat-and-mouse aspects of the book, Forrest's work is notable for its descriptions of how the spectre of match-fixing permeated the game's highest levels.  It's a perfect storm of the ascendancy of Chinese wealth (a country of serious gamblers), the rise of Internet bookmaking sites (creating market-making and transborder cash flow) and strapped international federations hungry for cash.My favorite passages of the book weren't directly related to either Eaton or Perumal.  They involved Carsten Koerl, founder of Bet to Win, later renamed to Bwin, one of the foremost Internet bookers (and coincidentally a prominent sponsor of many top-flight clubs).  Koerl went on to found Sportradar (and later Betradar), whose speciality is in spotting games whose betting action -- as compared to expectations -- made them outliers and possible fraud cases.

This excellent, thoughtful book from John Browne mixes parts of his personal history with stirring, well-crafted passages detailing the author's current passion project as founder of The Glass Closet.  That organization seeks to convince business leaders that "any policy that fosters an inclusive environment makes good business sense."  As Browne says:"Paul Reed, my former colleague at BP and now a senior executive there, puts it best: `I don't want people saving a quarter of their brain to hide who they are. I want them to apply their whole brain to their job.' Inclusion creates a level playing field, which allows the best talent to rise to the top. Respecting diversity of sexual orientation and gender identity should therefore be recognised as a matter of strategic importance to every company competing in the global market for talent."Browne further relates what Peter Sands, CEO of Standard Chartered Bank, said to him:"[Sands] explains that being trapped in the closet is `miserable for individuals and bad for business. In a world where business success is all about unleashing people's creative energy and imagination, it makes no sense to cripple so much talent.' The evidence points in one direction: people are more satisfied and more productive when they can bring their whole selves to work."That's really what this book is about: issuing a call for inclusiveness that allows talent to flourish and personal productivity to be realized, regardless of sexual identity.  Browne's thesis is that achieving these goals is going to take a combination of "clear and consistent tone from the top...accompanied by stories that make the issue real."Browne's asks that "[e]mployees who have come out...talk about their experiences, because there is nothing more effective than real-life examples at dispelling fears."  The author's call is tinged with regret that he did not have the opportunity to be one of those examples on his own terms.  Instead, he was famously and publicly outed.In this book, he recounts his life over that tumultuous period.  The pain is still clearly raw.  While he lays his soul bare, those you looking for real dirt from Browne will need to look elsewhere.  The Glass Closet is not that book.  Consider "The Glass Closet" making up for lost time: this John Browne confidently looks forward, not backwards.  His book is a spirited, well-reasoned call for "leaders who have a deep understanding of authenticity, and for the emotional and human investment that is required for LGBT employees to feel comfortable coming out at work."

If you're like me, you'll enjoy the 'approachability' of this book -- it's an engaging read, told like a guy regaling you over a pre-dinner beer about the unlikely, fascinating path that led to ZenDesk's ultimate sucesss.  Not "unlikely" in the sense that writer Mikkel Svane (& co-founders Alex Aghassipour + Morten Primdahl) were lucky or undeserving.  Rather that they started their journey in Copenhagen (Svane recounts the abysmal state of the VC industry there when they started out), picked a mundane corner of IT (their genius was to make the mundane exiting...help desks: who knew?) and spent a good period of their early years being ignored (or worse) by the VC/IT kingmakers.  By going direct to users (one of the first to perfect that now pervasive model) and getting bottom-up support in companies, the founders were able to persevere and win their seats at the table.I love this passage from Svane early on in the book, laying out his basic premise on work (and life)..."For me , finding true Zen in building a company has been the realization that almost everything is difficult. Most things are complicated. People are imperfect and don't always act rationally. Relationships are hard. If you want to make something look easy, you have to put a lot of effort into it. Only by embracing the fact that nothing is easy and that the most important things are so incredibly hard can you approach work (and life) with the right humility that can set you up for success."Well said.Much of this book's success goes to its co-writer (the 'with' person), Carlye Adler.  Much as she's done to great effect with Marc Benioff (a big personality if there even was one), Adler has succeeded here in getting Svane's personality on the page.  She's crafted a compelling story.One side note: it's interesting to note the dissonance between what Svane has to say about life and work in Copenhagen (he's almost clawing to get out at one point) vs. its #1 position on many "most livable cities" lists, most notably Monocle where the city has topped the table in 2013 and 2014.  My takeaway: It all depends on what you're measuring.

This very readable book is notable in that it makes the mundane -- the prosaic matter of a checklist -- fascinating and essential.  Dr. Atul Gawande expertly details surgery's aversion to adopting simple checklists to minimize avoidable mistakes. That's due to that profession's adherence to the now outdated master surgeon/hero model.  Gawande -- in a position to make this claim definitively -- posits that the vast complexities of the job far outstrip the abilities of any one person to master it all and remain error-free.Gawande brings in excellent case studies of the building and aviation industries.  In both cases, he does boots-on-the-ground reporting about how checklists work in those professions.  Of building, he notes that the era of the "master builder" faded long ago -- projects just got too complex.  Decision-making and responsibility got pushed downwards and out.  Gawande sits in the trailer office of one such complex undertaking and watches with fascination as it all comes together.Likewise, the examples pulled from aviation are equally compelling.  He takes us through the industry's relentless dedication to continuously improving checklists for all matter of situations that a pilot may encounter.  These run the gamut from the mundane to the almost unimaginable.  Of special note, Gawande's work was published shortly after US Airways "Miracle on the Hudson." He takes us through checklists' role in that event.  Indeed, pilot Chesley Sullenberger is on record as fully deflecting the "hero" appellation bestowed upon him by the press.  He instead credits ingrained checklist-driven routine and a well-prepared crew.There are lessons in "The Checklist Manifesto" that can be applied readily by people of every profession.

We saw "1,000 Times Good Night" as part of the wonderful Film Movement" program.  It's one of their strongest entries to date.  The film is a fascinating production: conceived, produced and directed by Norwegians (with a premiere there); starring French and Danish leads whom the script -- not attempting to hide their provenance -- has settled in Ireland; featuring Irish children of the French/Danish parents; and with filming split across Ireland, Norway, Sweden, Morocco (as a stand-in for Afghanistan) and - most notably - Kakuma Refugee Camp in Kenya.Sound like a recipe for a mess? Well, against the odds, no.  This film -- a brilliant creation from writer/director Erik Poppe -- is a gripping, relentlessly watchable affair.In Poppe's script, we're confronted with the question: how does home-life go for the photographer whose life work is spent in conflict zones?Answer: not well. Juliette Binoche's Rebecca suffers through a near-mortal shock in Kabul.  Post-trauma, she tries to leave her adrenaline-fueled life behind and work on domesticity.  At loose ends and a relative stranger to her kids, she's coaxed into a visit (as a guest of an NGO) to a refugee camp in Kenya.  Terming it a "safe camp" from her experience, she convinces husband Marcus (great, taciturn performance by Nikolaj Coster-Waldau) that she'll take daughter Steph (Lauryn Canny - all that is good about Ireland) along for bonding (& to ace Steph's school project to boot).All I'll say here: does NOT go according to plan.Ultimately, at movie's end, Rebecca ends up back in Kabul.  Watch for the subtle, powerful ending, beautifully underplayed by Binoche.  I'd seen her on some 2014 Best Actress lists for this performance.  She needed to be on more.  She remains one of the world's finest actresses.The DVD's extra features are superb...plan on spending an additional 30+ well-invested minutes consuming those.

Released ever-so-briefly in the US under the title "Paris Follies," we saw French release "La Ritournelle" in Australia under the name "Folies Bergre," which appears to have been its original working title while under production.  It's a charming French comedy starring legends of French cinema Isabelle Huppert and Jean-Pierre Darroussin.  Despite their lengthy, contemporaneous careers, "La Ritournelle" marks the first time these two have worked together.  Here, they play a long-time married couple working agriculture well outside the bustling cities we are more accustomed to see depicted on-screen.Darroussin's Xavier clearly adores Huppert's Brigitte, but their farming life - steers, animal husbandry and manual labor - isn't the stuff of smouldering passion.  In the screenplay, we see Brigitte's head turned, first by young party guest Stan (Pio Marma - excellent recently in Aliyah (English Subtitled)) and then by a cosmopolitan Dane, Jesper (Michael Nyqvist of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo (English Subtitled) fame).  These two events play out during a two-day jaunt to Paris by Brigitte, ostensibly to seek treatment for a rash.  Xavier, sussing out events but not correctly interpreting them fully, catches Brigitte in the company of Jesper.  You'll want to see the movie to see how it all plays out.The movie's best scene by far: Xavier surprising son Grgoire (Clment Mtayer) by dropping in on his acrobatics class.  Earlier in the film it's been established that Xavier's approval of his son's chosen career path is grudging at best.  Seeing his son in practice though...I can't fully describe just how sublime and intelligent Darroussin's performance is here. He lets the audience see subtly how profoundly affected he is by the mastery of Grgoire's routine. It's a superb piece of acting.  I asked my wife about the scene (she'd seen the movie separately) - she nodded vigorously and said she "bawled my eyes out." It's that good.

We watched Three Worlds (original title: "Trois mondes"), a taut, well-plotted French drama conceived by writer/director Catherine Corsini, as part of the Film Movement subscription service.  It's a great way to see foreign films that don't often get a fair chance here in the US.  That's certainly the case for Three Worlds: it never got a chance here, playing only in one theater.  Now's your opportunity to see it in video or, better still, Amazon Instant Video release.  It's compelling watching well worth your time.The cast here is first rate, starting with the beautiful and talented Clotilde Hesme, who made me a fan with her winsome, girl-next-door performance in The Grocer's Son (English Subtitled).  Then, we have Raphal Personnaz, the ill-fated center antagonist/protagonist who panics and flees after a hit-and-run and spends the rest of the film attempting to salve his wracked conscience.  He's definitely a personnaz of interest in my book after seeing this film.  [Yeah, couldn't wait to use that lame joke.]The film's "third world" is fleshed out by Arta Dobroshi as Vera.  This striking Kosovan actress plays a Moldovan immigrant to Paris.  Her world and that of Al's (Personnaz's character) are brought together brutally by the accident in which Vera's husband is mowed down in the street.  The glue between the two is Juliette - witness to the incident - who forms unlikely relationships with each side of the triangle.You won't rest a moment while watching this film.  It starts with a super high energy scene of drunken "boys' night out" revelry and never lets up.  And, about that scene: hats off to Reda Kateb here for his portrayal of Al's friend and co-worker, Franck.  He brings a level of malevolence and intimidation here adds a extra shot or two of tension to every scene in which he appears.  [Check him out in Jacques Audiard's astonishing masterpiece, A Prophet (Un proph?te).]

"The Everything Store" is a wonderfully reported book about an "abjectly miserable" place.  I've been an avid reader of Brad Stone's work at Newsweek and now Bloomberg BusinessWeek.  He's taken his experience of 10+ years of covering the Amazon beat and written his compelling warts-and-all history of its mercurial, relentless founder, Jeff Bezos and the pioneering e-commerce company he envisioned and birthed at the very start of the web's era of commercialization.It's notable that the first spotlight review here on this page is penned by one of the book's early protagonists, Shel Kaphan.  By most accounts, Kaphan was Amazon's first employee.  By Kaphan's account, he's a co-founder (and, by Bezos' account, he's not, which tells you a lot about Bezos).  Kaphan says that the book "...describes not only Amazon's ultra-hardball business practices, but the better aspects of their services and products as well. To the extent of my knowledge it is a pretty realistic account, though necessarily incomplete."  Exactly: it encapsulates both the good and the bad of the company.  He's also spot-on that Mackenzie Bezos' ill-conceived one-star review only serves to boost the book and underline its integrity.As a fan of the company, it was dispiriting to read extensive accounts of what a harsh, Darwinian place Amazon is for its employees.  The "abjectly miserable" expression comes from one of its employees, noting that Amazon had to resort to remote development centers because word had flooded the Seattle area about Amazon's true nature.The company takes on the personality of its CEO - though no doubt brilliant, visionary and successful by most measures, Bezos is repeatedly described here as an executive who openly disdains people who don't meet his exacting standards and "uses up" those that do.  Indeed, the book is replete with tales of short tenures by exhausted key contributors and targets of his well-documented 'nutters.'That aside, hard to dispute the guy's track record.  It's an amazing run.  His combination of smarts and guts plus his resolute desire to be a technology company not a merchant are what led to initiatives such as AWS and Kindle.  Stone's recounting of how AWS came to be is stirring stuff indeed for anyone in the IT industry.

If you like your movies where something big or meaningful has to happen, else you think "it's boring," "it's dull" and "nothing happened, so we walked out," then steer clear of "Land Ho" as it won't be your cup of tea. But if, like me, you appreciate small, quirky films that resemble real life inhibited by characters you could surely meet in daily passing, then this winning little film is just the ticket for you.  A few months after seeing it, I find myself thinking about it quite a bit and end up smiling thinking of the sweetest parts of it.I joked recently that the film's credits include the line "Filmed on location in Kentucky and Iceland" and that was the only time in recorded history that that sentence had been assembled.  It speaks to the inventiveness of the script devised by co-writers/co-directors Aaron Katz and Martha Stephens.  Retirees and former brothers-in-law (and still friends) Mitch (Earl Lynn Nelson) and Colin (Paul Eenhoorn) meet up in the former's Kentucky residence.  Mitch springs a surprise on down-in-the-dumps Colin, proposing a trip to Iceland to push him out of his rut.From there, 'Land Ho' follows these two around Iceland in their rented Range Rover.  Indeed, nothing much happens...but that's entirely the point. It's two guys of a certain age bonding and living their lives.  The third co-star at this point is Iceland, its vistas and stunning backdrops captured in vibrant color by cinematographer, Andrew Reed.  A natural reaction to this film should be to put Iceland on your travel agenda.Nelson and Eenhoorn are fabulous here.  Nelson is a doctor-turned-actor.  His lack of formal training in the arts is clear here. That's part of the charm.  He makes up for it with his boisterous, larger-than-life personality.  I have to believe that the Earl Lynn Nelson we see here is exactly what you get in real life.  Who wouldn't want to be friends with this guy?The acting chops come from Eenhoorn playing the reserved, taciturn Colin.  Of course, part of that taciturn nature is imposed upon him by Nelson's Mitch, whose boisterous love of life is manifested by a running commentary on just about everything that crosses his path or mind.  However, the movie succeeds on the strength of Eenhoorn's gentle change and his ability to express intimacy after the pain of a recent split.  It's credit to Eenhoorn's considerable skill as a actor.I can't talk about this film without noting the Katz & Stephens' brilliant use of Big Country's "In a Big Country" to drive home two key parts of the narrative.  First is to back a montage depicting highlights of the guys' trip, most notably a scene on a beach with dark sands.  I later read an interview in which the stars said they showed up to film at that beach and encountered brutal winds that whipped sand into their faces. The planned scene was impossible.  However, the footage Katz and Stephens collected of the stars laughingly leaning into the elements is a perfect complement to the jolt of energy that "In a Big Country" delivers.Then, in a Sgt. Pepper's-like reprise, the song appears again right at film's end as Colin and Mitch, resplendent in a spa's white robes, make their way around a pool edge - the stars, captured in slow motion by Reed's camera, their white robes offset against the scene's vibrant blues, the attention paid to them by the young girls in the water as they pass, "In a Big Country" building to its exuberant fullness of noise...well, that's just a great piece of moviemaking.  I defy you not to be smiling when the credits roll.

"Countdown to Zero Day" is a phenomenal piece of work from Wired reporter Kim Zetter. It performs the difficult feat of being rich in technical detail while possessing the steely narrative spine of a first-rate thriller.  By doing so, I've no doubt that it will win over both the digital technorati as well as the fascinated layperson.It's an astonishing story: how Stuxnet -- the world's first fully unleashed nation-sponsored cyber-weapon -- got built, weaponized and distributed. The great unseen actors in the story are the groups that envisioned and created the weapon.  Zetter's reporting makes it all but certain that Stuxnet and its offshoots were co-parented by US and Israeli government-sponsored organizations.  But Zetter's book's heroes and protagonists are the weapon's hunters, notably Symantec & Ralph Langner's small German-based industrial control system team.As Zetter adroitly points out "[t]he attackers had no doubt assumed, even counted on, the Iranians not having the skills to uncover or decipher the malicious attack on their own.  But they clearly hadn't anticipated that the crowdsourced wisdom of the hive -- courtesy of the global cybersecurity community -- would handle the detection and analysis for them."Far from losing steam, Zetter's work remains compelling throughout its entire 406 (hardcover) pages.  She's sublime when discussing Stuxnet's longer range implications, starting with the fact that "attacking Iran made it harder [for the US] to condemn other nations for cyber transgressions...As the party that fired the first known digital weapon, the US was no longer in a position to preach abstinence to others."

"I Must Say" is why they invented the audio book genre.  I'm sure Marty's book [dead tree edition] is a wonderful read, but you're missing out big time if you don't experience his memoir by listening to him narrate his own work.  In a word: fantastic.  You simply can't imagine a better way to spend eight hours and forty minutes of your valuable time.Not only do you get the author jumping into character as Ed Grimley, Jiminy Glick, Jackie Rogers Jr., Nathan Thurm and others as you'd fully expect, you also get drop-dead perfect impersonations of Bernie Brillstein, Robin Williams, Eugene Levy and countless others.  [His Williams recollections are especially poignant.] Short has a ton of stories - all engagingly told. It's one thing to remember everything (and, yes, he cops to a prodigious memory --- he seems to recall every little detail of every story that matters), but another thing to unspool them all in such winning fashion.  The stories never flag, never fail to amuse.Part of Short's motivation here in writing this book: to pay tribute to his late wife, Nancy Dolman, who passed away in 2010 after a long bout with ovarian cancer.  He says such beautiful and moving things about her here.  It's not just eight hours of jokes and funny stories here.  We get to hear about Short's daily life and the act of making a life.  It's evocatively written and stoically recounted by the author.  Again, maybe good on the page, but absolutely unmissable in audio format.By the way, the title is part of the joke: you know from early on that Short is far less than the ego-filed star.  He's by all accounts a humble and generous friend, beloved by a wide circle.  Vanity Fair's David Kamp (Short's writing partner for this book) wrote a story about him last year that was telling.  The article relates:"[Steve] Martin noted that Nora Ephron--who, in the meticulous instructions she left before her death last summer, dictated that Short speak first at her memorial service, ahead of Meryl Streep, Mike Nichols, and Hanks and his wife, Rita Wilson--referred to Short as "the best person." "Not the best person at something," Martin said. "Just `the best person.' Period.""That's the Martin Short on display here.

This purposefully absurd, delightful movie deserved a bigger audience. The always likeable Nick Frost is excellent here, especially when playing against Chris O'Dowd who's in top form here as Frost's co-worker and office cad.  There's one completely over-the-top dance-off/confrontation between the two that takes place in a parking garage...well, I can't accurately convey the sheer goofy hilarity of this scene.  Suffice to say these are two gifted physical comedians pulling out all the stops.  It's like 'West Side Story' meets 'Strictly Ballroom.'It's 'Strictly' that kept springing to mind when I was watching this film.  That's very high praise in my book.  In 'Strictly,' Baz Luhrmann (in his audacious debut as writer/director), folded sequences of sheer slapstick hilarity inside of his real dance movie.  And here in 'Fury,' it's the same deal: comedy aside, Frost took his entre into the world of Salsa very seriously.  The excellent "extras" package show him arduously learning the craft of salsa dancing over seven months of lessons and workshops.  Frost says in an interview that he didn't want the type of movie where "they showed my top and cut to someone else's bottom." All the steps, lifts and twirls here are his.  It's clear from the Extras that that effort won the respect and admiration of his instructors and the real salsa aficionados called upon to fill out the movie's final rousing scenes.All this and Rashida Jones (radiant and beautiful here), too?  What's not to love?

I'm not a big science fiction reader but I bought into the backstory behind this book:  Andy Weir is a software engineer who -- having been rejected by publishing houses when attempting to go the traditional route -- self-published his book on his website in serialized fashion.  The groundswell of ardor for his work led to deals, in turn, with Amazon (as a $0.99 offering), then an audio house, then finally Crown Publishing for a "traditional" book release.  The love for Weir's effort reached such a fever pitch that it's a forthcoming movie with Matt Damon...a sentence that almost reads like a cliche.As expressed on the these pages by countless others, the science here is brilliant.  The book is really a tutorial on how a mission to Mars could work wrapped inside a compelling novel.  The science has to be airtight given the reading audience's attention to the details of the how-tos.  In the paperback version, Weir mentions that he worked out his own orbital paths and "[wrote] my own software to track constant-thrust trajectories."  That's the type of guy we're talking about here.  It's a deeply impressive piece of work.

I watched "Aliyah" as part of the Film Movement series.  As is the case with many of these films, this debut outing from director/co-writer Elie Wajeman was a small and pleasant surprise.The title of the film is surely meant as a joke: it is hardly religious with drugs, violence, Paris' seamy underbelly and crime playing notable roles in the plot.  Indeed, one of the script's recurring themes is just how unlikely the concept of Aliyah is for Alex, the lead character played by an excellent Pio Marma.  Barely aware of his Jewish roots (he has to scramble for proof), his hastily devised plan meets with skepticism and borderline disdain by the people in his life.  As the film goes on, we see that - far from any religious stirrings - Alex's 'plan' is in fact more of an escape from bad choices and an unrelentingly needy and flailing older brother.  Despite his bad choices, Alex's life looks positively brilliant next to that of Issac's.  Cdric Kahn is fantastic in this role - you can almost smell the desperation on him.Complicating the matter of departure: Alex needs a significant amount of cash to invest in a restaurant in Tel Aviv.  It's been well-established by this point that this is not your typical wage-earner.  Alex knows only one way to earn this money in a short period.  The paradox is, of course, that this path out gets him even more enmeshed in what's he's ostensibly escaping.Moreover, there's the small matter of a nascent relationship with Jeanne, a strikingly beautiful Adle Haenel.  She's attracted to him specifically because of his complications.  I think Wajeman uses Jeanne to show us just how ill-fitting a prospect Aliyah is for Alex.  As in: Who would give up this?As if to drive home the point, Wajeman presents a jarring juxtaposition between Paris and Tel Aviv.  While this isn't the glossy postcard of France's capital, the film does present it as a thriving, vibrant metropolis full of energy.  What we see of Tel Aviv from Wajeman's lens is telling: in very short order we see overcrowding, heavy military presence, homelessness, unsolved immigration issues and sub-standard housing...not to mention Alex's massive assimilation issues.  He speaks not a word of Hebrew.  Wajeman seems to be saying: here it is, dude.  What do you think?

I gobbled down Lisa Genova's excellent novel in one three-and-a-half-hour plane ride.  It's a realistic, sobering look at the insidious effect of early onset Alzheimer's on its victim and her family.  In this account, the impacts of the disease are incremental...and then at all at once. The resonance reflected by the many reviews of people on these pages in similar familial situations speaks volumes as to the true-to-life verisimilitude of Genova's story.I was impressed with the scientific background that she's packed into the text, from the accessible discourses on the genetics of the disease to the counseling and detection sessions she conveys in crisp back-and-forth dialogue.  By making Alice's husband and son both biologists, Genova is able to plop in the realities of genetics in a conversational style.  I wasn't aware of the advances in linking certain gene deformations to the certainty of Alzheimer's until reading this book.  On the diagnosis parts, the sessions with counselors and specialists reek of the truth of what those encounters must be like.  They're unnerving.One final note: I did find myself thinking of Pat Summit a lot.  Alzheimer's doesn't care if you've reached the peak of your profession or have been lauded throughout your career for your sharp mind and keen intellect.  Like Genova's Alice Howland, Summit's case reveals this disease to be an equal opportunity inflicter.

What makes 'Dallas 1963' unique is what it's not: an attempt to solve or unravel the Kennedy Assassination or unspool a particular theory.  What it is: a brilliant recitation of what Dallas was like from the period of January, 1960 through November, 1963, and how the city's agitated state of "indignation" (a word used frequently throughout the text) led to the moniker "City of Hate."This work by Bill Minutaglio & Steven L. Davis ought be required reading for all current residents of Dallas.  When I first moved here in the mid-eighties, my Massachusetts Mom fairly shrieked "But they killed Kennedy!" My wife got the same reaction from her Mom.  That's the history that Dallas has had to live down for now just past 50 years.  The Dallas of today feels so...different.  We have a ways to go, but this is an international city now with large, diverse communities. I think of the large groups of migrs that call Dallas home now - Russian, Indian, Mexican - and how taken aback they'd be to understand in detail what the atmosphere was like here leading to 11/22/63.The pacing of the book is spectacular.  In 1960, the authors go month by month...then week by week...then day by day.  Until, finally, on November 22nd we get an almost minute by minute breakdown of the events.  As a Dallas resident, you're imagining the route in your head as Minutaglio & Davis take you through every right and left turn from Love Field to downtown and, fatefully, past the Texas Schoolbook Depository.  Even better: I listened to the Audible audiobook which features a positively electric reading from narrator Tony Messano.Less than Jack Kennedy or even Oswald and Ruby, this is a book about Dallas' other influencers at the time, most notably the troika of Gen. Edwin Walker, Dallas Morning News chief Ted Dealey and Neiman Marcus's CEO Stanley Marcus.  What really comes through is just how in-the-grip America was of fear of Communism.  In the minds of people like Walker and Dealey, there was only one form of patriotism then.  If you weren't that model, you were - in their minds - treasonous. [Note the book's cover.]  Marcus, by comparison, attempts to urge Dallas' spirit to a better place.

This fascinating book from top-notch investigative journalists Mark Hollingsworth and Stewart Lansley is a good compendium piece to contemporaneous works like The Oligarchs: Wealth And Power In The New Russia by David Hoffman.  'Londongrad' takes those works and focuses the action totally on London and its environs.  All the usual players are here: Abramovich, Berezovsky (this book was published prior to his death by his own hand), Deripaska, Khodorkovsky and some others...but mostly in regards to how their evolution and machinations since the creation of the oligarchic class in the Yeltsin era has swept waves of change through the UK.Indeed, where the book shines is in its depiction of how attitudes went from curious fascination on the parts of most Londoners (the well-documented cartoonish amount splashed on mega-yachts, obscene overbidding on trophy properties, garish parties, etc.) to the sudden realization of how this new superclass of migrs has directly impacted their lives.  To that end, the Litvinenko case was a game-changer: the shock of the reality that the Russian state (as is alleged) would traffic deadly polonium into the heart of London to kill a critic.  Hollingsworth and Lansley's narrative on the Litvinenko case is fascinating.  I've read Alexander Goldfarb's Death of a Dissident: The Poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko and the Return of the KGB and feel like 'Londongrad' is an excellent second take at these events.The other way the new Russian Wave has affected Londoners: the cost of living.  This new super-rich class has pushed the traditional upper class out of its typical nesting spots in the city. The butterfly effect of the movement has spread waves of dislocation and change throughout London and beyond.  All of that is well-documented here.  The authors spend time with the estate agents who service both the 'dispossessers' and 'dispossessees.'

I'm a big fan of Jhumpa Lahiri's work most notably her outstanding novel, The Namesake: A Novel, and her short story collection Unaccustomed Earth (Vintage Contemporaries).  No one today writes or speaks so trenchantly about the Indian diaspora.  Despite being born in London and raised in Rhode Island, she seems to get the experience of the 'Indian expatriate in America' down to her bones.  Her exquisite writing and storytelling chops only add to that.'The Lowland' is another winner.  If I told you "I read this book about the Naxalite Movement and its impacts on Indian society and families...you should read it," you'd probably find a way of fobbing me off. But Ms. Lahiri has a way of getting that history lesson across to her readers by cloaking it in the tale of how those events play out in a single family. The meat of the story spans over 50 years.  As her skillful hand shows, though thousands of miles away and generations removed, this one small family still deals with the fallout of a single, tragic event that rocked a small Indian town in 1971.There are three different stories here woven into one.  First you think, "this is Subbhash's story."  Then, unexpectedly, it becomes Gauri's story.  And then finally, too, it becomes Bela's story, too. To tell you the relationship between three is to maybe tell you too much. Jhumpa Lahiri's stories are the tales of lives played out in the real world. You can't go wrong investing the hours to read her work.

We received this movie as part of the Film Movement series.  We've encountered a lot of unexpected, small-wattage international gems that way - 'Teddy Bear' from Denmark as a notable example.  "Will You Still Love Me Tomorrow" was another pleasant surprise.  We'd seen the trailer, which frankly seemed to reduce expectations.  But the film experience itself easily surpassed those. Writer/director Arvin Chen has come up with a small gem here.And, for anyone with a fear of 'foreign' film who thinks they won't relate to something from Taiwan: Chen was born and raised in California, attended USC, wrote the first drafts of the film in English.  The themes he explores here are universal and transportable across cultures.Leads Richie Ren (Wei-chung) and Mavis Fan (Feng) are likable presences.  Fan's background as a singer is put to good use here in the neat dream-like sequence that gives the film its title.I really liked Kimi Hsia as Wei-chung's little sister, Mandy - beautiful eyes, comedic delivery, involved in what I thought was the film's neatest trick: imaginary repartee with the star of a maudlin love story who has jumped off the screen and to her side as she wallows in abject self-pity during a pre-wedding break-up. Sounds treacly. It's not. Writer/director Chen plays it for a spot of fun and gets the tone of it exactly right than to Ms. Hsia.  We need to see more of her.

We binge-watched this excellent FX series in the matter of a couple of nights. It's based on 'Bron,' the Danish/Swedish original in which a body is discovered on the inter-country border on the bridge connecting those two countries, thus forcing cooperation between their investigative forces. This US version has been transported in a very imaginative way to the US/Mexico border by a crack team of writers. A similar adaptation took place in the UK. In that series, the body is found in the Chunnel and ropes in France.I love the work of Demian Bichir. He's outstanding here. Diane Kruger is equally sublime.  Her character, Sonya, exhibits Aspergers-like thinking and actions. In the wrong hands, acting this out could look rather foolish or ham-handed on camera.  Ms. Kruger pulls it off beautifully. You feel for the way she can't feel. Her work is artfully juxtaposed by Bechir's Marco, whose knack with people is established early, and by Ted Levine's Hank Wade, Sonya's boss, whose soft spot for her goes way back. Turns out he's the one who's basically got her through life thus far.The real revelation here is Matthew Dillard as reporter, Daniel Frye. If you just know him as Shaggy, prepare to be duly impressed. I especially loved the chemistry between his character and the cub reporter played by Emily Rios.The success of the show has fueled a second season. Season one's end sets that up perfectly as a distraught Marco begins to seek out revenge for the tragedy that has befallen upon his family.

If you've seen the first two installments (Before Sunrise, Before Sunset) of this intoxicating talk-fest from writer/director, Richard Linklater, you are pretty much obligated by law to see this third one. It's the darkest and most intense of the three, but no less winning and likable.Co-stars Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy have been credited as co-writers on 'Sunset' and 'Midnight.' It's clear that they know these characters, Jesse and Celine very, very well, giving them tremendous depth, complexity and back-story.  I love the way on each of these two later films how three creators plunge you right into Jesse and Celine's lives, then slowly fill you in on the details of what's transpired in the intervening years since the last installment ended.Often, this storytelling is done via exceptionally long, word-packed passages in which the characters do nothing more than interact with each other. Most notable: a single extended scene - easily more than 10 minutes in length - in which the two characters walk down a path and chat amiable.Then, by contrast towards the film's end, there's a devastating scene in which the two converse in a markedly different tone in a hotel room.  I'd been leery of seeing this scene as I'd been warned of its intensity and I have such good feelings towards these characters. Regardless, it's great movie-making...and bold stuff from Delpy, who really gives it everything during these climactic moments, both emotionally and physically. Though still beautiful, she's not afraid here to show us what a natural aging process looks like.

I've always enjoyed Katie Hafner's writing.  Now, for the first time in book form, she's turned the spotlight on herself.  This memoir proves once again how the most professional, successful talents can succeed through raw determination, grit and hard work....in spite of the often shocking handicaps they're handed early in life.Hafner describes a childhood that you'd wish on no one - a household torn apart by divorce, she and her sister subsequently stripped from an alcoholic mother, thrown into a trying Brady Bunch-style blended family. After years spent trying to reconcile her conflicted feelings about her mother, Hafner's book details her attempts to bring her now aging, solitary Mom into her house in San Francisco.  [Hafner's Pro Tip: Mixture of a mom with no filter and a 16-year-old, hormone-fueled daughter is maybe not such a hot idea for the generation in the middle.]I'm struck by how artfully this memoir is constructed: While most of us would have written it chronologically, it hops back and forth between present and past, each visit to the past clearing up and filling in the "whys" for the events happening in the here and now.  Like, for instance, I pieced together early on that this still beautiful, talented woman has been married four times and wondered "how on earth??"  As the story unfolds in her skillful hands, it suddenly seems like the most, understandable natural progression. Brilliantly done, Katie.

'Young Money' is an enthralling, exquisitely researched piece of work.  I think a lot of people would come into this book believing that the protagonists would - on the whole - be a rather insufferable lot...masters-of-the-universe-in-training and all that.  Nothing could be further than the truth.  What Kevin Roose presents instead is a hard-working, talented, conflicted, introspective group thrown into the cauldron of Wall Street's extraordinarily trying "two and out" intern program while simultaneously trying to feel their way into adulthood.  What differs with this group is that they're forced to navigate this extended frat rush at the very moment while Wall Street is trying to sift through the debris of its 2008 crash.  The result is a fascinating tale. Scoff if you may, but in Roose's compelling hand, it's hard not to shed a tear at the way he brings the story to a close for a couple of his subjects.Roose points out one positive outcome of the crash: while Wall Street will always attract the hard-core finance types (like the 'Black Diamond' student group he visits at Harvard), it also over the years pulled in talented would-be biologists, mathematicians, engineers and doctors, seduced initially by Wall Street draw and then trapped by the Golden Handcuffs.  Roose notes forcefully what's been lost by a process in which, for example, greater than 50% of the Princeton graduating class ended up in finance --- students giving up dreams, professions missing out on good talent, society getting lopsided by 'distributors' dominating 'creators.'  The crash has caused a major rethink by 21-year-olds that is borne out by statistics - finance isn't the draw at the margins that it was six-plus years ago.  Watching and documenting the frustrations of his book's subjects, Roose makes a forceful case why this is a good outcome for all.

We saw '2 Autumns, 3 Winters' as part of the excellent Film Movement series.  It's a winning little film that succeeds despite itself.  It feels at times like a parody of a French film: characters talking directly to the camera, baring their feelings (typically, deeply introspective); depression and ennui; perennial art students who appear to be underemployed well into adulthood.However, writer/director Sbastien Betbeder ultimately triumphs: he keeps the length of this work to 'feels right' 91 minutes and delivers some likable characters.  Vincent Macaigne ('Arman') is an unlikely leading man, but he grows on you.  By the end of the film, you're rooting for him.

We saw this sweet, small French film (original title "Et soudain tout le monde me manque") as part of the Film Movement series.I'm a fan of French cinema even though many of the works can be deliberately difficult to navigate. Not so with 'The Day I Saw Your Heart.'  If you like Mlanie Laurent -- and it ought to be a crime not to -- you'll especially enjoy this film. Despite a definite downer of an event near the end, it will leave a smile on your face. And, it's one those films where you wake up the next day, re-consider it, and think, yeah, I definitely liked that film.  Two days later, that feeling will grow on you again.I especially loved one of the story's main concepts: that Michel Blanc, as Laurent's character Justine's Dad was such a good guy and so well-liked that all of Justine's many exes remained firmly in his life, well after she'd moved on from each of them.  The full extent of those relationships becomes clear at the movie's end.  It's a beautiful scene.  You'll be hard pressed not to be affected by it.

Bulletproof, very large capacity, and FAST if you have USB 3.0 ports to use it with. Backwards compatible. Given a USB 3.0 port, this single drive would be IDEAL for backups, and it's so small you can take it with you rather than worrying about storing an external drive. Beautiful but tough exterior with a big ring for keychains or lanyards. YOU CANNOT HAVE TOO MANY BACKUPS. That's a fact. Set yourself up to look like a genius by having current data on one of these flash drives. USB 3.0 is (theoretically) TEN TIMES as fast as USB 2.0! That's a big deal. Slow drives aren't used as much, people don't want to sit and watch a progress bar crawl along. Samsung is a solid name, I'm much happier trusting a big name than a fly-by-night I've never heard of. Back up your photos and music and business files, then back up the backups. This is a terrific little device, looks great, good and fast. Highly recommended.---Surprisingly fast transferring data from a 2.x USB port but it REALLY flies when moving files via a 3.0 USB port!

Quite potent, and there's a LOT of spice in the jar! I generally put a little turmeric in whatever I'm preparing but especially in eggs. Apparently there are more health benefits in turmeric than scientists have been able to count so far. This smells and tastes like very good quality turmeric, and, as I mentioned, there's a lot of it, so use all you want, it's not going to do you any harm. Good value.

Interesting and effective. Mixes up easily in 16 oz of water. Cold water is recommended -- this stuff has an interesting kind of vaguely cotton candy taste, along with a weird little tang or tickle which prevents you from enjoying the flavor too much. I was out doing yard work when this arrived and had worked up a pretty good sweat and was tired when I wrapped things up and came in. I drank some plain water and sat for a while, then made a sandwich and ate that then mixed up 16 ounces of this and tried it. Definitely hits the spot, these kind of drinks aren't supposed to taste good when you're not in need of them. But when you need them, they taste pretty great. Interesting product. The next time I indulge a few "adult beverages" I'll try this out again to see how it handles dehydration in adults due to alcohol consumption. Overall I'm impressed. Doesn't taste bad and it addresses what you need after some sweat and exertion.

Ideally sized case -- not too big. I'm comparing this Asus unit to a homebrew PC I put together using a full-size case. Now I find that The Asus will fit beneath some kitchen cabinets from the non-kitchen side of the counter and the full-sized case will not! It's a far more sophisticated looking PC because of its size. Not horsey looking (like my homebrew).Looks great. Everything is all put together. I'm used to assembling PCs on my own from various parts. This is luxurious and easy in comparison! It looks great and fits in a home or office environment. "YEAH WELL MY HOMEBUILT COMPUTER HAS BITCHEN BLUE AND GREEN LED FANS, MAN" Yes, so it does. As I was saying, this Asus desktop looks sophisticated, which inspires confidence.A turnkey computer, no strife or troubleshooting. That was a real treat. It boots via a big silver power button on the front. There is not a switch to fumble for on the power supply. The rear connections are comprehensive and easy to work with. There are two USB 3.0 connections on the front of the case.I have not been a big Windows fan in the past (user since 2.0), and I've got to say that Windows 10 is much better than I expected it to be. There have been a few bumps in the road, such as spending an hour trying to grasp why the screen saver won't come on, but I gather that's just the lay of the land with Windows. Coming from a Mac, it sometimes feel a bit rough or even barbaric, but nothing like the train wreck of Windows 8.Aside from the OS software, which is not an Asus product, I haven't had any issues whatsoever. Setup was swift and painless. The sound is very good thanks to the Asus audio software. I'm working on figuring out how to connect the rear audio jacks to my home stereo. This shipped with a mouse and keyboard, which was thoughtful. I used the monitor from my Windows 7 build, though it's tempting to buy a larger monitor to use with this desktop, which I am quite impressed with.The on-board graphics card is adequate, though I understand that people that play hard-core PC games might want to consider upgrading the video card AND the power supply. For my own fairly simple game uses and office/business functions, the hardware is more than enough.Being a Mac user, it's hard to accept that I'm using a Windows PC and enjoying it. Everything is very snappy thanks to the SSD and 8GB of RAM. My kid has a gaming PC we put together and he kind of looks down on this desktop, but this unit is quite affordable compared to the stack of parts we bought to build his computer. Two different animals.This is the nicest PC I've ever used. It looks great, it runs everything I can think of without any issues -- the third-party driver issue is something I guess Windows users deal with, it's something I haven't encountered before. There's a little digging and research involved to figure out how to make things work the way I expect them to work, but no real complaints. I had a Windows 8 computer and it was really frustrating, I couldn't figure it out. Windows 10 is a big improvement.The perfect home PC? Yes, that would be fair to say. Everything an average user would want or need, with a little space to upgrade this or that if you need hopped-up graphics or something like that. I am genuinely impressed. A really solid PC right out of the box, ready to roll. Zero headaches. Highly recommended!

BIG. Colorful package, beautifully produced and professionally designed. That inspires confidence. Neatly packaged, well-documented. Easy to assemble.This has FOUR separate filters. Or, as the manual states, four STAGES of filtration:First stage: The Pre-Filter which traps above 10 microns particles like human and animal hair.Second stage:  The Active Carbon Filter has powerful odor removal benefits and pre-cleans the air before it reaches the HEPA filterThird stage: The True HEPA Filter captures 99.97% of airborne allergens down to . Three micron particles in the air including dust, pollen, pet dander, virus, bacteria, mold, exhaust and moreFourth stage: The Exclusive Patented Nano "Captur" technology "permanently destroys Formaldehyde, the most harmful indoor pollutant and a human carcinogen according to the WHO."We have cats and, more to the point, live about 1.5 miles downwind from a freeway. I've experienced the endless grit that collects in our garage from so many rubber tires abrading themselves on the concrete freeway surface. I'd rather not run that crud through our lungs. Which is where air cleaners come into play.The first air filter device I bought was after a serious brush fire here in San Diego. The air was thick with smoke, everywhere. There was no escape from it. Your lungs ached if you went outside. School was cancelled. We just sat inside and tried not to breathe more than was necessary. The local stores were sold out of air filters, they just sadly shook their heads when I inquired. I ordered one from Amazon and was happy to pay for ultra-speedy delivery. The difference in air quality was immense.About four years after that, there was ANOTHER big brush fire, and the air filters made an enormous difference in our interior air. That first one was a circular Honeywell filter (Honeywell10500 Envirocare) which lasted a while but died when it was accidentally dropped.I bought three smaller Honeywell devices (Honeywell HHT-011), one for each bedroom, and a fourth (Honeywell Desktop HEPA Air Purifier, 16200) for the living room, all of which lasted quite a while. We have a Claritin CAP529-U, which up until I got my claws on this Rowenta device was the largest air filter we had. We also have a smaller "desktop" Holmes HAP9240 air filter which I have particular fondness for and a Holmes HAP9414-UA which functions well, but is a goofy football shaped filter that doesn't exactly blend in with its surroundings.My point being that I'm a firm believer in air filter devices, clean air is right up there with clean water in my book. Worth investing in. No one in my house suffers from allergies or anything like that. I just like clean air. It's a big deal to me.This device claims to "capture 99.97% of pollution with True HEPA filtration including dust, pollen, pet dander, virus, bacteria, mold, exhaust and more" which is pretty impressive.Rowenta, it says here,  started out in 1909 in Germany. I'd never heard of them before, but apparently they manufacture a large line of products.The neat thing about this Rowenta device is that it provides "Smart Sensors" which detect particulate matter in your interior air and automatically adjusts the air filter settings. There's a novel blue-purple-red set of lights which report on the quality of your interior air. There's also a filter change indicator onboard and a "Night Mode" to keep sound from the device down while you're sleeping. I actually like a fan running at night for the soft background sound it makes. Nice detail, anyway.First impressions are that this device is BIG and built like the proverbial battleship. Setup was easy, first unpack the four filters and then assemble them from the center out, starting with the "Nanocaptur Filter" which addresses formaldehyde in the interior environment, then a HEPA filter, then the Active Carbon Filter, and finally the Pre-filter for dust, hair, fur and lint. Everything snaps together with zero frustration.Everything fits beautifully with zero slop. This is easily the nicest air filter I've ever seen. It runs quietly and seems quite powerful. Moves a lot of air through the filters. My kids don't comprehend my interest in air filters and our water filters, but clean air and water are about as essential as anything can be in my humble opinion.A sensational addition to your home. A serious appliance, not another desktop hey-look-I'm-cleaning-the-air fan and filter. This thing is profound. I am impressed.

Small and sexy like some kind of classic 1960s Japanese sports car. James Bond would use a laptop like this one.Weighs next to nothing (2.6 lbs). Dark, smooth metal finish. Pry it open, there's a surprisingly large trackpad (4.5 x 2.5 inches) and a responsive keyboard. I wish the keyboard were backlit. Surprisingly comfortable keyboard. You click the bottom of the trackpad, which took me a minute to figure out. I have big hands and didn't have any trouble using the keyboard.This thing is so small and sleek that it reminds me of jewelry. Especially the very tiny power and HDD indicators, set in the front edge. Clearly visible, but out of the way and ultra-sophisticated in appearance. The whole laptop is groomed and polished, nothing clunky about it.On the left side there's the power plug socket, volume control, on/off, a Micro-SD card slot, Micro-HDMI port, a USB 3.0 socket and a USB 3.1 Type-C socket. On the right side there's the 3.5mm audio jack and a USB 2.0 socket.Packaging and initial setup is as smooth as silk, totally professional and seamless, no bumps in the road, no weird stuff. Cohesive and enjoyable.Windows 10 is quite nice! I am happily surprised!  There's a new browser called "Edge" which is impressive in that you can annotate, draw, and type on web pages, make notes on a web page as if it was paper. Very clever. I was not happy with Windows 8 and it looks like Windows 10 has addressed complaints people had with that OS iteration. I'm usually disparaging of Windows at best (user since Win 2) and this is actually not bad at all. Kind of a nice surprise.I very cautiously opened the laptop past 180 degrees very slowly. This did not feel natural or advisable. But it works great! You can use laptop mode, "tent" mode, "stand" mode and "tablet" mode with a virtual keyboard that appears.  The "stand" or "easel" mode, where you'd have the keyboard rotated to make a stand would be useful for presentations. Folding the keyboard all the way around behind the screen would give you a tablet. I'm actually kind of interested in using this in tablet mode streaming a movie from Amazon while on the treadmill. Have to use a bungie cord to secure the device, I guess.The touchscreen feature has a fairly extensive set of motions which I will need to use the included cheat sheet to learn. This is terra incognita for me. The whole touchscreen concept is kind of baffling at this  point in time.Connectivity is good, completely transparent. You may not want to run Photoshop on this device, but for general use, it's more than adequate, more than fast enough. It comes with a 64GB flash drive which is mighty snappy.I am VERY interested in finding software and a style that might work with the touchscreen to draw on. Electronic paper?! Sign me up. I'm not sure this is possible or if it would work that way, but I want to find out. I think this is just a daydream.Setup with painless from start to finish. Battery charged up in no time.The big-as-they-could-make-it display (1366 x 768) is saturated with color, very impressive. The sound is surprisingly good for the size of the laptop. I can't imagine how they achieved that. Now I'm reading that there's custom software onboard called "Asus AudioWizard EQ software" which delivers the sound via one of five preset modes. Nice touch.Overall surprisingly fast and powerful for its size. I'd read a complaint about the screen resolution not being up to 2015 standards but I certainly have zero complaints. It looks great and this is as powerful as any other modern computer I own and the form factor will make your jaw drop. I was expecting a kind of glorified tablet, but this is a full-on computer, no compromises or apologies. And the thing is you're not going to be lugging around a battleship-sized laptop. That's heavy baggage. This will fit easily in a backpack. Which means you'll take it with you when you're out of the house. Perfect size. Looks professional. You would not be embarrassed taking this with you to a business meeting. Charge lasts a surprising long time.Gorgeous little laptop, sexy as can be. Small and powerful. Can you imagine such a device back around, oh, 1995? Laptops weighed 15 pounds back then and could barely load a spreadsheet. It pains me to say that this little gem is as well put together and functional as a MacBook. I never thought I'd say that about any PC.

For the price and for their size, these S120 speakers are remarkable. I'd bought a pair for a PC build and was fooling around with them today -- I've got a space music Internet radio station on, and the sound is outstanding, really gorgeous, full music. I bought them to get booms and ka-pows playing video games on that PC. These things are cheap, robust, and cost next to nothing!

Truly gorgeous hardware. I was expecting flat chrome, it's more of sophisticated brushed surface which is really nuanced and rather stately looking compared to the cheap H*me D*pot hardware this is replacing. The subtle reflections are really appealing. This is beautifully designed and functional. Not terribly difficult to install given a cushion to lie on as  you tighten the fittings under the sink. A camping headlamp is really useful for this task IMHO.Compared to my old, squat, ugly bathroom fixture, this is like royalty. Makes the entire bathroom look a lot better. The height of the faucet is brilliant, and the paddle-like Hot/Cold controls are easy to operate even with wet or soapy hands. Really a lot of bang for the buck with this item as far as dressing up your bathroom goes. Functional and gorgeous.

Big, substantial steam iron. Looks great. The water tank, however, is made of a dark plastic material that's impossible to see through, so it's difficult to know how much distilled water to add. Use only distilled water, it's a big deal.The B&D D3040 has a stiff tail coming off the rear end which holds the power cord up, a real plus. Instead of a dial, it's got a button that lights up LEDs indicating which fabric range temperature you've got it set at. Once you've added enough water (see above comment) it produces VOLUMINOUS amounts of steam, which I like.The face plate has deep channels for steam to escape and it's a fairly small footprint, which is a good thing, easy to maneuver.For comparison in the photos is an older steam iron I bought which has a translucent water tank, so you can easily see the water level. It also has a retractable cord, which is handy, but the cord is floppy and tends to get in the way when you're ironing. Compared to the Black & Decker, the steam volume is a bit on the anemic side (but that lime green is so cool!).The Black & Decker is a sensible, no-nonsense steam iron with all the fabric temperature settings you could want. A first-rate iron, if not for the somewhat weirdly hard to see water fill level.UPS delivered this by tossing it over my front gate. Fortunately, it didn't seem to be damaged. A decent iron would make a nice gift for a child who was moving into their own apartment or starting a new job. Ironing isn't a lot of fun, but it's a lot less odorous when you have a decent iron to work with, and this is more than a decent iron.

Impossibly fluffy and soft washcloths made of bamboo! Who knew you could make cloth from bamboo? Neatly woven, very plain, VERY soft, these are the obvious choice for scrubbing your infant. And yourself, for that matter. I've never seen softer washcloths. These would also be ideal to keep in your pocket to deal with sudden messes, sneezes, et cetera, which accompany child rearing. These are one of those sweet, endearing products that remind you of when your kids were small -- pure, sweet, innocent.===As I was putting these away, it occurred to me that these would be ideal to stick in your first aid kit AND to also keep with your glasses and/or binoculars and camera hardware.

Tough, no-nonsense utility stool. Wide five-spoke base, a gas canister, a seat with a nice thick cushion and a release handle to lower/raise the seat. Upholstered in some kind of tough cat-proof fabric. Not living-room pretty, but tough and substantial. The instructions caution a 250 lb weight max, although the assembled stool seems pretty robust. This thing may not win any beauty contests, but it's built like a workhorse.---It's worth adding that TEENAGERS LOVE THIS STOOL. Something about it being "alternate seating" or something like that. I cannot believe how much use this stool gets. This is worth taking note of if you have teenagers around.

Works great, but I had to put a foil heart-shaped sticker over the flashing red LED and then add a folded Post-It note to mute the colors of the other LEDs a bit. I like it a lot more with the diffuse, softer lights!

Very lightweight. Sound is passable but not great, probably because you don't have a rubber earpiece jammed in your ear canal. Reasonably detailed sound but I find I keep fiddling with the right earbud -- can't quite get it where I want it. Seem to most accurately reproduce midrange sounds. Treble is a bit tinny, but, again, that may be due to the way the earbuds hang on the behind-the-ear plastic piece. I wear eyeglasses and the over-the-ear things do not interfere with my eyeglass frames. I'd reviewed a jam-it-in-your-ear set of Panasonic earbuds a week or two ago which had far superior sound, but they were more expensive. These are more than OK. Better if you can find the sweet spot for the hanger and earbud to fit on your ear just right. Good stereo imaging overall.

Looks great, much nicer than the pink-ish Band-Aid color you think of Ace products being. The clip has some kind of micro-velcro on it. I usually just tuck the loose end into one of the wrappings, to tell you the truth. The fabric is nice and stretchy (don't wrap it too tight), good and wide and more than long enough, 63 1/2 inches. As I get older, I really appreciate my collection of Ace products! A little compression wrap goes a long ways -- nothing like these Ace products. Highly recommended!

I am genuinely impressed -- these are easily the best earbuds I've ever tried. I hear things I've never heard in familiar songs. The definition is pronounced. Not bass-heavy, really. I've been listening to my library of MP3s all evening and have heard things I've never heard before in 90% of the music. Very good indeed. I was expecting bass-heavy thump-thump-thump sound, but the stereo imaging is remarkable and detailed, nuanced and full.

Surprisingly well made. Why have I never considered Wrangler jeans? I always buy Levis, and they're not what they used to be. Why the brand loyalty? I mean, I'm surprised at how nice these jeans are. They fit well, they look good, details like the stitching is all as good if not better than Levis. And these Wrangler jeans are much cheaper than Levis. What have I been paying for? The logo? I feel like I'm waking up from being hypnotized or something. There are other brands of jeans other than Levis and they're just as good if not better. What have I been thinking?

Incredible. Best art tool EVER. Works great. IT'S BIG which is what you want! I had a 6x8 Wacom and it just wasn't big enough. You want ROOM TO MOVE YOUR ARM while you draw. Buy one of these and treasure it! And do yourself a favor and check out SmithMicro's "Manga Studio" which is now renamed "Clip Studio" for some reason. Works MUCH better with a graphics tablet than Illustrator, Photoshop, or Painter. Painter has a history of very weird behavior and bizarre crashes... Manga Studio is stable and tablet friendly!
